site_title: Nomura to introduce permanent flexible work for Japan employees
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to make flexible work permanent for employees in Japan once the pandemic ends, aiming for a minimum 40% of hours to be spent in the office each month. The firm is also considering a permanent flexible work regime at its overseas offices, with 50% of its corporate workforce working remotely at any one time. This move is seen as a response to the health crisis and potential changes to work styles in Japan.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong travel bubble expected to be delayed further
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong's travel bubble is expected to be delayed further due to Hong Kong's increasing Covid-19 cases, with the seven-day moving average reaching 16. The cities had initially planned to launch the bubble on November 22 but postponed it to review the situation. The extension is seen as a precautionary measure to strengthen social distancing measures, including closing gyms, bars, and leisure facilities, and mandating civil servants to work from home. The travel bubble's launch has been pushed back multiple times, with officials expected to announce the extension soon.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 2,802.44. The decline followed overnight US market losses. Despite this, the STI had rallied 0.4% on Thursday and 5 days prior to the latest drop.

site_title: Asia: Markets resume rally as traders focus on virus jabs
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors resumed their vaccine-fueled buying spree, despite concerns over surging virus infections. Tokyo led gains, while Hong Kong rebounded after a two-day slump due to new infection measures. Analysts expect a strong recovery in the world economy in 2021, citing the prospect of millions receiving COVID-19 jabs. However, Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell warned of a challenging few months due to rising cases.

site_title: SFF x Switch 2020 Ep 1: New digital banks to jazz up Singapore
summary: Singapore's digital banks have a larger playing field in the post-Covid world, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore's managing director Ravi Menon. Digital banks now have to overhaul proposals to cope with the new landscape, with MAS asking how they would handle the post-Covid world. The digital banks also face a gap in providing quick loans for micro-enterprises, a challenge learned from China. To address cybersecurity breaches, digital banks must prioritize standards, Menon emphasized.

site_title: Climate groups take on Shell in landmark Dutch case
summary: Environmental groups in the Netherlands are suing Shell in a landmark case, seeking to force the oil giant to meet emissions targets in the Paris climate accord. The case, backed by 17,300 citizens, aims to reduce Shell's carbon emissions by 45% by 2030. Shell has claimed the case is "inappropriate and legally without foundation," but the groups argue that the company's failure to act endangers the future of the planet. The case is expected to be heard over four days in December before a verdict is delivered next summer.

site_title: Killing Libor proves even harder than global regulators imagined
summary: Regulators have pushed back the deadline for phasing out the London interbank offered rate (Libor) by 18 months to 2023, citing the complexity of replacing trillions of dollars of existing contracts. Despite efforts to transition to the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR), many legacy contracts remain, posing systemic risks. Policymakers acknowledge that a temporary lifeline is needed, but warn of potential disruptions if a solution is not found.

site_title: Credit Suisse to propose outgoing Lloyds Bank CEO as chairman
summary: Credit Suisse has named António Horta-Osório, outgoing Lloyds Banking Group CEO, as its next chairman, succeeding Urs Rohner, who will step down in 2021. Horta-Osório's nearly decade-long tenure at Lloyds, where he revived the bank after its 2008 government rescue, will come to an end with his appointment at Credit Suisse. He replaces Rohner, who was praised for his mental health advocacy but criticized for high pay and handling of a major fraud. Horta-Osório will lead Credit Suisse as the bank seeks a new direction.

site_title: SoftBank bets on logistics startup at US$500m valuation
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund 2 invests $113.5 million in Flock Freight, a California-based logistics startup, valuing the company at nearly $500 million. Flock aims to revolutionize the freight business by applying advanced algorithms to the hub-and-spoke system, which handles less than full truckloads worth $40 billion annually. This investment seeks to disrupt the fragmented freight market, potentially transforming the logistics industry.

site_title: Brand marketplace Ankorstore raises S$40m from investors
summary: Ankorstore, a Paris-based online marketplace, has raised S$40.17 million from investors to fund its European expansion. The e-commerce startup aims to connect specialist brands with neighborhood retailers, making it easier for independent shops to source quality merchandise on affordable terms. Founded by entrepreneurs including Etsy veterans, Ankorstore's retail partners, mostly brick-and-mortar stores, seek to ease the impact of government lockdowns during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Egypt plans big rail expansion, nears agreement with Bechtel
summary: Egypt is expanding its metro and railway networks, with plans for a $5 billion, 30 km sixth metro line nearing agreement with Bechtel Corp. Most major transport projects, including dry ports and river transport, are expected to be completed by 2024. The sixth metro line will run east of the Nile from north to south, connecting 16 stations. Egypt has secured funding from Canada, America, Britain, France, and Japan for the project. Other planned railways include a 49 km line from Sixth of October City to the Nile and a 438.5 km fast rail at a cost of $8.2 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Keppel, Top Glove, Yangzijiang, Singapore Paincare
summary: CapitaLand divested three Japanese malls and an office building for S$448.7 million, and announced its first foray into Japan's logistics sector. Keppel Corp's property arm is divesting its 30% interest in Dong Nai Waterfront City for S$115.9 million.

site_title: WHO calls Mexico's rising coronavirus trend 'very worrisome'
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has expressed concern over Mexico's rising coronavirus trend, calling it "very worrisome." Mexico's death toll stands at almost 106,000, with confirmed cases exceeding 1.1 million. The WHO's director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stated that the surge in cases and deaths indicates Mexico is "in bad shape" regarding the pandemic. The country's health system is struggling, with at least seven public hospitals in Mexico City at full occupancy and 14 health centers at risk of being stretched.

site_title: Grounded pilots out of practice spark airline safety fears
summary: A grounded Indonesian Lion Air flight carrying 307 passengers and 11 crew on September 15 veered off the runway due to a pilot's lack of recent flying experience. The incident highlights the risk of pilot rustiness during the coronavirus pandemic, with airlines grounding planes and scaling back operations. Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee found that the pilot had flown less than three hours in the past 90 days, while the first officer hadn't flown since February. Experts warn that prolonged periods without flying can lead to complacency and decreased proficiency, posing a threat to aviation safety.

site_title: The White House Christmas decorations look strikingly normal
summary: Melania Trump unveiled this year's White House Christmas decorations, a traditional "America the Beautiful" theme, which features green trees with red, gold, and silver ornaments and white lights. The decorations, which include simple urns and ornaments celebrating pioneers for gender equality, were widely praised for being unimpeachable and lacking the bold, edgy choices of past years. This marks Melania Trump's last Christmas at the White House as first lady, amid criticism from her memoir and negative press coverage.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 25.99 points, or 1.66%, to 1,588.70. Volume reached 458.82 million lots worth RM224.73 million, with gainers beating losers 328 to 148.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover ground ahead of cenbank decision; China tensions weigh
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,537.5, recovering from a 1.3% decline the previous day, ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on the benchmark rate. Rising tensions with China weighed on gains. Despite this, the S&P/ASX 200 index posted a record monthly gain of nearly 10%. The RBA is expected to hold its cash rate at a historic low of 0.1%.

site_title: Multinational transport firms commit to Asean links
summary: Major US multinational transport firms, including Amsted Rail, Boeing, FedEx, and UPS, have pledged support for Asean connectivity amidst the Covid-19 pandemic. During a virtual consultation session at the 26th Asean Transport Ministers Meeting, the US-Asean Business Council committed to ensuring Asean's transport continuity. The move comes despite the ongoing economic slowdown.

site_title: China November new home price growth cools, private survey shows
summary: China's new home prices grew 0.32% in November, slowing down from a 0.4% gain in October, according to a private survey. Fewer cities reported monthly gains, with 28 cities seeing lower home prices. The southern Pearl River Delta and eastern Yangtze River Delta contributed to the market's strength, while cities like Liaocheng and Dezhou experienced significant price drops. This slowdown is attributed to policy tightening and weak demand in smaller towns.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on vaccine hopes, China data
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.34% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and positive economic data from China. The Nikkei 225 index gained 353.92 points to 26,787.54, while the Topix index rose 0.77% to 1,768.38. Moderna announced US and European approval for its virus vaccine, and China reported stronger-than-expected economic data.

site_title: Biden wins in Arizona, Wisconsin certified, further cementing Trump loss
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's victories in Arizona and Wisconsin were certified, further solidifying his win over Donald Trump. This marks a significant shift in the US electoral map, as Arizona had not been won by a Democrat since 1996. Despite Trump's baseless claims of vote fraud, the certification process was deemed transparent and fair by Arizona's secretary of state.

site_title: Keppel Land to divest remaining 30% stake in Dong Nai Waterfront City
summary: Keppel Land is divesting its remaining 30% stake in Dong Nai Waterfront City (DNWC) to Nam Long Investment Corporation (NLG) for approximately $115.9 million. The transaction follows the 2019 divestment of 70% stake to NLG, allowing Keppel Land to recognize a gain of around $52.5 million. The deal is expected to be completed in the first half of 2021, subject to certain conditions. This move aligns with Keppel's plan to monetize assets and support sustainable urbanization in Vietnam.

site_title: UK house price inflation hits highest in almost six years: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose by 6.5% in annual terms, the highest in nearly six years, according to Nationwide. This follows a 0.9% monthly increase from October, exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.3% monthly rise. The housing market continues to boom despite the broader economy's struggles with the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: British house prices rose by the most in nearly six years in November, mortgage lender Nationwide said on Tuesday as the country's housing market booms even while the broader economy struggles with coronavirus.

site_title: Samsung may discontinue high-end Galaxy Note smartphones: sources
summary: Samsung may discontinue its high-end Galaxy Note smartphones in 2021 due to declining demand for premium phones caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company has no plans to develop a new Galaxy Note, instead focusing on its Galaxy S series and foldable phone range. Sales of the Note series are expected to fall by 20-30% this year, while the S series may see a 5-30 million unit drop in sales. The Galaxy Note 20, launched this year, was priced similarly to the Galaxy S20, but its sales have been impacted by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics may discontinue its premium Galaxy Note phone next year, sources with knowledge of the matter said, a move that would reflect the sharp drop in demand for high-end smartphones due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Powell: 'Challenging' months until vaccine clears production, distribution hurdles
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the US is entering a "challenging" few months due to a slowing recovery and surging pandemic. Despite positive news on the vaccine front, significant challenges and uncertainties remain, including production and distribution, and efficacy across different groups. Powell acknowledged that it's difficult to assess the timing and scope of the economic implications of the vaccine developments. The economy's recovery is likely to be slow, and a full recovery is unlikely until people feel safe to re-engage in activities.

images.alt_text: A slowing recovery and a surging pandemic mean the US is entering a "challenging" few months, with the potential deployment of a vaccine still facing the hurdles of production and mass distribution before its impact on the economy becomes clear, Federal Reserve (Fed) chairman Jerome Powell said on Monday.

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals up 41.1% to 13,400 in October
summary: Singapore visitor arrivals surged 41.1% to 13,400 in October, despite the tourism industry still far from pre-pandemic levels. China, Indonesia, and Malaysia remained the top sources of arrivals. Room revenue and occupancy rates declined, with average room rates down 39.6% year on year, at S$136. The average occupancy rate fell to 56.7%, a significant drop from 87% in October last year.

images.alt_text: Visitor arrivals to Singapore jumped 41.1 per cent to 13,400 in October, though the tourism industry's performance remains a vast distance from pre-pandemic times, according to STB.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Reit's trustee proposes SC Capital unit to be new Reit manager
summary: The trustee of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has proposed SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management, a unit of SC Capital, as the new manager for the troubled real estate investment trust. This decision follows a directive from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to remove the current manager within a month. The trustee evaluated proposals from interested parties after a comprehensive request-for-proposal (RFP) process and selected SCCPRE Hospitality Reit Management due to its track record in managing and delivering strong asset performances. The proposed manager's appointment is subject to regulatory approvals and approval from stapled securityholders at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Gold rebounds from five-month lows as virus fears outweigh vaccine cheer
summary: Gold prices rebounded from five-month lows, rising 0.4% to $1,784.37 per ounce, as concerns over COVID-19 cases outweighed optimism around vaccine developments. The precious metal had clocked its worst monthly fall in four years on Monday. Investors are shifting assets away from gold and towards riskier assets, but some economists remain bullish on gold, citing its potential as a hedge against inflation from large stimulus measures. The US Federal Reserve's monetary policy direction will also be closely watched for further guidance.

site_title: Ex-Tesla factory worker to pay US$400,000 to end feud with Musk
summary: A former Tesla factory worker, Martin Tripp, has agreed to pay US$400,000 to settle a lawsuit with the company over revealing production delays at its Gigafactory in Nevada. Tripp, a process technician, admitted to violating trade secret laws and confidentiality agreements, and promised to pay an additional US$25,000 for continuing to disclose information. The settlement comes after a federal judge threw out Tripp's countersuit against CEO Elon Musk for defamation, ruling that Musk had not acted with actual malice.

images.alt_text: A former Tesla employee who locked horns with chief executive officer (CEO) Elon Musk has agreed to pay the company US$400,000 for telling reporters about production delays at its Gigafactory in Nevada, according to a court filing.

site_title: Bitcoin surges to all-time record as 2020 rally powers on
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time record of $19,864.15, surpassing its previous record of nearly three years ago. The surge is attributed to increased demand from institutional and retail investors seeking the virtual currency as a safe-haven and inflation hedge. The digital unit rebounded after a 8% drop on Friday, rising 6.1% to $19,306.35.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin soared to a record high against the dollar on Monday, as its 2020 rally steamed ahead, boosted by increased demand from both institutional and retail investors that saw the virtual currency as a safe-haven and a hedge against inflation.

site_title: Amazon unveils cloud service to power Apple app development
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has launched EC2 Mac Instances, a cloud computing service that powers Apple app development, running on Mac Mini computers and supporting macOS. The service, announced at AWS' annual conference, allows developers to build and deploy applications for iPhones and iPads, as well as corporate customers who use macOS for software development. Available now in the US, Europe, and Asia-Pacific, EC2 Mac Instances is used by customers like Intuit and Filmic Pro, with more regions to come.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com's cloud business unveiled a service that can provide computing power to developers and companies building applications for Apple devices.

site_title: Trump's controversial coronavirus advisor resigns: report
summary: US President Donald Trump's coronavirus advisor, Scott Atlas, has resigned, according to a report. Atlas, who lacked relevant experience or qualifications, had sparked controversy over his comments against mask-wearing and other issues. His resignation comes amid surging Covid-19 cases nationwide. Atlas had also been criticized for downplaying the severity of the US coronavirus spread and urging people to "rise up" against Covid-19 measures. The move is seen as a blow to Trump's administration as the US continues to grapple with the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Fox News obtained the resignation letter dated December 1 for Scott Atlas, who lacked relevant experience or qualifications in public health or infectious disease.

site_title: Korean Air's Asiana buy on track as Seoul court refuses injunction
summary: A Seoul court has refused an injunction request by activist fund KCGI, allowing Korean Air Lines' parent company Hanjin Kal to proceed with a stock issuance to state-run Korea Development Bank. This move clears the way for Korean Air to acquire indebted Asiana Airlines, with the airline planning to become Asiana's top shareholder at a cost of 1.8 trillion won. Shares in both airlines rose after the ruling, with Korean Air stating it will work to strengthen competitiveness and ensure employee job security.

images.alt_text: A Seoul court on Tuesday allowed Korean Air Lines' parent company to go ahead with a stock issuance, clearing the way for the flag carrier's planned acquisition of indebted Asiana Airlines.

site_title: GM won't take stake in electric-truck startup Nikola
summary: General Motors (GM) has terminated a planned stake in electric-truck startup Nikola, reversing a September deal. Instead, GM will supply its fuel cell technology to Nikola trucks and potentially use its Ultium batteries. The revised agreement does not include an equity stake. Nikola shares plummeted 26.4% following the announcement, while GM's shares dropped 2.9%. The deal is seen as a scaled-back version of GM's earlier commitment, following a Hindenburg Research report questioning Nikola's practices.

images.alt_text: General Motors terminated a transaction to take a stake in Nikola, but reached a preliminary agreement to supply its technology to the electric-truck startup, the companies said on Monday.

site_title: Indonesia Oct foreign visitor arrivals down 88% on year
summary: Indonesia saw a significant decline in foreign visitor arrivals in October, with 158,200 foreign visitors, a 88.25% drop from the same month last year. This is largely attributed to the coronavirus pandemic, which has led to border closures globally. On a monthly basis, foreign visitor arrivals increased by 4.57%.

images.alt_text: A total of 158,200 foreign visitors arrived in Indonesia in October, 88.25 per cent lower than the number of arrivals in the same month last year, data from the country's statistics bureau showed on Tuesday.

site_title: WHO says 'will do everything' to find Covid-19 origins
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reaffirmed its commitment to finding the origin of the Covid-19 virus, stating it will "do everything possible" to uncover the truth. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus rejected criticism of the agency's handling, saying transparency is key. The WHO is working to send a team of international experts to China to investigate the animal origin of the virus, which first emerged in Wuhan late last year, resulting in over 1.46 million deaths and nearly 63 million infections worldwide.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization insisted on Monday it would do everything possible to find the animal origins of Covid-19, insisting that knowledge was vital to preventing future outbreaks.

site_title: US 'Cyber Monday' sales at record-setting pace
summary: US Cyber Monday sales reached record levels, with predicted sales of $10.8 billion to $12.7 billion, according to Adobe Digital Insights. Peak online shopping on Monday night was expected to reach $13 million per minute. E-commerce giant Amazon and others began offering deals early, and shoppers snapped up discounts on items like televisions, toys, and computers before prices increased. Despite weekend deals, most consumers believed retailers saved the best bargains for Monday, and smartphone usage continued to rise.

images.alt_text: Online deals for gadgets, games, wine and clothes put "Cyber Monday" sales on track for record levels in the United States, according to an industry tracker.

site_title: Facebook buys online customer service startup Kustomer
summary: Facebook has acquired online customer service startup Kustomer, a five-year-old company specializing in helping businesses interact with customers online. The acquisition comes as Facebook continues to integrate e-commerce into its services, particularly WhatsApp and Messenger. Over 175 million people contact businesses via WhatsApp daily, and the number is expected to grow. The deal is part of Facebook's efforts to expand its offerings and provide businesses with better tools to manage customer interactions.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Monday announced it is buying a startup specialising in helping businesses interact with customers online.

site_title: Asian factories continue recovery from Covid-19 woes as China booms
summary: Asian factories continued to recover in November, with China's factory activity accelerating at the fastest pace in a decade, according to private surveys. This recovery offers hope the region is shaking off the Covid-19 crisis. However, a global resurgence in coronavirus infections has raised concerns, prompting governments and central banks to maintain or ramp up stimulus programs. China's economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The recovery has been steady, but the outlook remains uncertain due to the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: Asian factories continued to recover steadily in November thanks to a boom in economic powerhouse China, private surveys showed on Tuesday, offering hope the region was shaking off the drag from the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: UK says 'no time to lose' with one month to Brexit transition
summary: The UK government has warned businesses to prepare for the end of the Brexit transition period in one month, as talks on a free trade deal remain deadlocked. The government has urged businesses to finalize preparations to avoid potential disruption when new rules start on January 1. A new Border Operations Centre will be launched to monitor the UK border and minimize disruption. Despite the current impasse in trade negotiations, the government remains upbeat, arguing that Britain will prosper regardless of the outcome.

images.alt_text: The UK government on Tuesday urged businesses to get ready for the end of the Brexit transition period in one month's time, as talks on a free trade deal remained deadlocked.

site_title: Tyson accused of misleading interpreters at virus-hit plant
summary: Tyson Foods Inc is accused of misleading interpreters at a pork plant in Waterloo, Iowa, where over a third of workers tested positive for Covid-19. Plant management allegedly told interpreters to inform the non-English-speaking workforce that "everything is fine" despite the outbreak. The company also claimed county officials had cleared the plant, despite the Black Hawk County Health Department urging it to close. Tyson denied commenting on the matter, citing ongoing litigation, but previously reported costs of $540 million and $330 million due to the virus.

images.alt_text: Tyson Foods Inc is accused of giving incorrect information to interpreters during a Covid-19 outbreak that infected more than a third of workers at a pork plant in Waterloo, Iowa.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip at end of best ever month
summary: Europe's benchmark stock index closed down 1% on Monday, despite posting its best-ever monthly gain of 14% driven by hopes of easing coronavirus restrictions and a promising COVID-19 vaccine. Brexit trade deal negotiations remain stalled, with talks described as "quite difficult" and time running out. Oil and gas stocks declined 3.4%, while consumer and healthcare stocks led declines in Germany's DAX index.

images.alt_text: Europe's benchmark stock index posted its biggest monthly gain on record on the prospect of easing coronavirus restrictions and hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine, but ended Monday lower with eyes on the Brexit trade deal negotiations.

site_title: MAS flags risks of financial stress ahead amid uneven economic recovery in 2021
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has flagged risks of financial stress ahead amid an uneven economic recovery in 2021. The Singapore economy has rebounded strongly in Q3 but is expected to slow in Q4 and remain modest in 2021. Corporate firms, particularly smaller ones, and banks are vulnerable to financial stress due to declining earnings, rising debt, and asset quality deterioration. Households should be cautious in taking on new debt and consolidating existing obligations. Despite these risks, MAS's simulations suggest that the corporate sector remains resilient, and households' mortgage servicing ratios remain manageable.

site_title: Deforestation in Brazilian Amazon surges to 12-year high
summary: Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon reached a 12-year high, with 11,088 sq km of forest destroyed in the past year, equivalent to an area larger than Jamaica. This is a 9.5% increase from the previous year, with the Amazon accounting for about 60% of the world's largest rainforest. The surge in deforestation, attributed to President Jair Bolsonaro's government, has drawn widespread condemnation, with environmentalists warning that the destruction of the Amazon contributes to climate change and releases carbon into the atmosphere.

images.alt_text: Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon surged again over the past year, hitting a 12-year high, according to official figures released on Monday that drew a chorus of condemnation of President Jair Bolsonaro's government.

site_title: Prison pen pals: Hong Kongers keep in touch with jailed protesters
summary: Thousands of Hong Kongers have formed pen pal relationships with fellow activists and protesters jailed during last year's democracy protests. The initiative, led by 22-year-old Hei, aims to maintain morale and provide support to those behind bars. Hei writes letters and creates a DIY newspaper, and also visits activists with books, snacks, and necessities. The campaign has been championed by former lawmaker Shiu Ka-Chun, with over 5,000 letters sent and 500 pen pals paired up since January.

images.alt_text: When Hong Kong protester Hei saw fellow activists put behind bars for taking part in last year's democracy protests, she was determined to keep the flame burning by writing them letters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following a previous day's drop, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 26,422.71. The positive start is attributed to progress in vaccine development. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.08% and 0.16% respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong takes aim at yacht parties in latest virus crackdown
summary: Hong Kong has set up a hotline for residents to report parties aboard private yachts and rented party boats, amid a surge of virus cases. The move comes after nightclubs and karaoke parlors were closed due to new restrictions. Chief Executive Carrie Lam said the reporting hotline is aimed at targeting gatherings at sea, which pose a risk of disease transmission. Authorities have also increased fines for violating group gatherings, and have suspended a planned travel corridor with Singapore.

site_title: Philip Green's Arcadia UK fashion group falls into administration
summary: British tycoon Philip Green's Arcadia fashion group has collapsed into administration, putting 13,000 jobs at risk. Arcadia, which includes Topshop, Topman, and other brands, had struggled due to underinvestment and failing to keep pace with competitors in the online retail sector. The company's collapse is the country's biggest corporate casualty of the Covid-19 pandemic, and its brands are being sought by potential buyers. The move also raises concerns about the future of department store chain Debenhams, which is already in administration.

site_title: China funding squeeze at small banks is warning sign for market
summary: China's smaller banks are facing a funding squeeze, with the cost of one-year interbank debt rising to 3.34% and a widening gap with the People's Bank of China's medium-term loans. This is a warning sign for the financial system as rising corporate defaults start to infect the market. The PBOC's recent injection of $30 billion into the system has not trickled down to vulnerable parts, and concerns grow that the central bank may soon pull back on emergency stimulus measures. Elevated borrowing costs are expected to remain high, with more defaults possible in 2026.

site_title: Dirty fuel demand jumps with more pollution kits on ships
summary: Dirty fuel demand jumps with more pollution kits on ships, boosted by strong container shipping and unusually robust trade activity. Despite a 90% discount of high-sulphur fuel oil (HSFO) to crude, HSFO sales increased in October, with some nations like Pakistan and Bangladesh importing more fuel to power utilities during winter. The number of ships fitted with pollution-reducing kits rose 80% from January to October, but still only accounts for 3% of the global fleet. HSFO could account for 20% of global marine fuel demand by the end of 2021.

site_title: 'Cinema under the stars' offers Indonesians safe entertainment amid pandemic
summary: Indonesia's 'Cinema Under the Stars' offers an outdoor movie space with socially distanced seating, featuring 28 tents equipped with hand sanitiser and disinfectant. Located in Bandung, the outdoor cinema aims to provide safe entertainment during the pandemic, with a cost of 215,000 rupiah (S$20.42) per movie. Despite the high infection rate in Indonesia, film-goers seem content with the setup, citing proper health protocols as a reason to attend. The cinema is one of the few forms of entertainment available in the country amidst localised social restrictions.

site_title: US capital may end weekend subway service in 2021
summary: The US capital's subway system may end weekend service and close 19 stations in 2021 due to a forecast budget gap of $500 million if Congress doesn't approve additional assistance. The system serves about six million people and has seen demand plummet due to the coronavirus pandemic. This could also lead to reduced bus services.

site_title: Recycling food with insects takes flight
summary: Lam Tak, a Singapore-based company, is pioneering the recycling of food waste using black soldier flies. The firm converts food waste into insect protein, which is sold to major feed millers and farms across Asia. With the global insect protein market expected to reach US$1.34 billion by 2025, Lam Tak aims to expand its operations to the pet feed industry, where consumers are willing to pay a premium for quality and nutritional value. The company has secured a US$1.5 million contract with China's Henan Agriculture University for patented intellectual property licensing, allowing it to tap technology for automated breeding and mating of black soldier flies.

site_title: LG Chem to double China battery capacity to meet Tesla demand: sources
summary: LG Chem plans to double its battery cell production capacity in China to meet Tesla's growing demand for electric vehicles. The South Korean company will increase its output from China, as well as from its Korean factory, to supply Tesla's factories in Germany and the US. This move comes as Tesla scrambles to secure battery cells amid an aggressive global expansion plan. LG Chem's investment will be around $500 million to raise annual production capacity to 8 GWh.

site_title: Meituan delivers food slathered in EV spice
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery group, reported a 374% year-over-year increase in earnings for the third quarter, driven by a 200% gain in its stake in Li Auto, a green-car maker. However, core food delivery business showed little excitement, with operating profit margins remaining thin at 3.7%. The company's share price trades at over 90 times forward earnings, making it pricey. The company's revenue rose 29% to 35 billion yuan, while operating cash flow shrank by 2.3 billion yuan. Meituan's shares may be vulnerable to Li Auto's portfolio gains if the electric vehicle industry faces regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Japan bird flu outbreak spreads to farm in 4th prefecture
summary: Japan's bird flu outbreak has spread to a fourth prefecture, with avian influenza detected at a poultry farm in Miyazaki prefecture. The country's worst outbreak in over four years started in Kagawa prefecture last month. The agriculture ministry confirmed there is no risk of humans contracting bird flu from eating poultry or eggs. The outbreak has prompted concerns over the country's poultry industry, but the ministry has assured that the risk to humans is low.

images.alt_text: Bird flu has been detected in a fourth Japanese prefecture, the agriculture ministry said on Tuesday, as a wave of infections at poultry farms sparks the country's worst outbreak in more than four years.

site_title: Virus pushes Wendy's to open hundreds of cloud kitchens in India
summary: Wendy's is partnering with Rebel Foods to open 250 cloud kitchens in India, marking one of the largest such deals in the industry. The move aims to adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the fast-food industry, with deliveries surging and traditional stores struggling. Cloud kitchens, also known as ghost or dark kitchens, are remote facilities that prepare food exclusively for delivery. The partnership will help Wendy's expand its presence in India, with plans for 150 physical stores over the next decade.

site_title: Beer craze may boost Australia barley shipments to India
summary: Australian barley growers may benefit from exporting excess stocks to India, as the country's beer market is expected to grow due to increasing demand for craft beer among younger and wealthier people. With China halting imports this year, India is becoming a potential alternative market, with potential to become one of the world's largest beer consumers. The country's beer market, worth US$7.8 billion last year, is expected to continue growing, providing a new opportunity for Australian barley exports.

site_title: Secret to George Clooney's hair? The Flowbee
summary: George Clooney, 59, revealed in a CBS interview that he uses a Flowbee, a quirky home-styling device that attaches to a vacuum cleaner, to cut his signature silver locks. The device, which has been mocked since its appearance on late-night infomercials in the 1980s, has seen sales spike during the pandemic as people cut their own hair at home. Clooney, a long-time fan of the gadget, says it's easy to use and makes few mistakes, and has even endorsed it, saying "it works!" The Flowbee retails for around $50.

images.alt_text: Pandemic hair getting out of control? Take a tip from George Clooney: the Hollywood style icon has revealed he trims his signature silver locks with a Flowbee - a quirky home-styling device that attaches to a vacuum cleaner.

site_title: Cloud trade management platform Tazapay bags US$3.2m in funding
summary: Tazapay, a cloud-based trade management platform, has secured US$3.2 million in funding led by Sequoia India's Surge and Saison Capital. The Singapore-headquartered fintech aims to remove trust barriers for small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs) conducting cross-border trade and payments. The funds will be used for product development, hiring talent, and expanding to new markets in South-east Asia. Tazapay estimates the addressable market for cross-border trade and payments to be worth US$500 billion, with a growth rate of 25% per annum for the next five years.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong defer start of air travel bubble; review set for end-December
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have deferred the start of their air travel bubble due to rising coronavirus infections in Hong Kong. The bubble, which would have allowed quarantine-free travel between the two cities, was initially set to launch on November 22 but was postponed. The exact start date will be reviewed in late-December. The delay is the second for the ATB, which was initially set to launch in November but was halted due to a surge in Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Under the air travel bubble arrangement, there would be a two-week pause if the seven-day moving average of the daily number of unlinked coronavirus cases is more than five in either city.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenues drop 70.5% in Nov
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 70.5% in November, reaching 6.75 billion patacas ($1.13 billion), due to the ongoing coronavirus travel restrictions. The decline was less severe than in recent months, with a 72.5% drop in October and 90% in September. The gaming industry has been struggling since February.

site_title: China's aluminium bonanza may have more to offer investors
summary: China's aluminium sector has experienced a significant rally, with Aluminium Corp of China Ltd (Chalco) rising 80% in November, its best month since its debut. This surge follows China's V-shaped economic rebound and optimism over a vaccine for the pandemic. Analysts believe a deeper shift in the industry is underway, as concerns about overcapacity and high production costs are diminishing. Despite a sharp advance, some analysts think Chinese aluminium stocks are worth buying, indicating a potential long-term opportunity for investors. The rally suggests a more promising outlook for the Chinese aluminium sector.

site_title: China factory activity sees fastest growth in decade: survey
summary: China's factory activity saw its fastest growth in a decade, with a 54.9 reading in November, according to a Caixin survey. This surpassed expectations and is the strongest since 2010. Manufacturing firms attributed the growth to increased order volumes and recovery from COVID-19 disruptions. The official November PMI also showed growth at its fastest in over three years, at 52.1. Despite this, the data highlighted challenges, including stock shortages and prolonged delivery times. The growth is seen as a positive sign for China's recovery and is expected to drive further economic growth.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump 1.7% on upbeat trade, manufacturing data
summary: South Korean shares jumped 1.7% on Tuesday, driven by upbeat trade and manufacturing data. The Kospi index closed 42.91 points higher, or 1.66%, at 2,634.25. Major heavyweights, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, saw significant gains. The country's exports rebounded 4% in November, and factory activity accelerated at its fastest pace in nearly a decade. Neighboring China's factory activity also showed a sharp increase, adding to the positive sentiment.

site_title: Australia home prices heat up as super-low rates stoke demand
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.8% in November, driven by record-low interest rates and demand from first-time buyers seeking more living space. Regional prices also gained, with cities that have been largely Covid-free showing significant increases. The recovery is expected to continue, with some analysts predicting a turnaround as early as January or February next year, reversing earlier predictions of price falls. This comes as the Reserve Bank of Australia has cut rates to 0.1% and driven mortgage rates to all-time lows.

site_title: A rush to create Asean travel bubble holds too much risk
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is considering a travel bubble for essential business and official travel, but experts warn of the risks. Indonesia, the region's largest economy, has the highest number of coronavirus cases and is urging caution, with President Joko Widodo pushing for the bubble to boost economic activities. Economists advise a coordinated approach on vaccination programs and caution against rushing into travel bubbles, citing concerns of spreading the disease further.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam reiterates call to stay at home to curb spread of Covid-19
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam urged residents to stay at home and avoid family gatherings to curb the spread of Covid-19, following a rise in cases. The government announced tighter measures, including restrictions on group gatherings and most civil servants working from home. Schools will close for the rest of the year. With over 6,300 cases and 109 deaths, Hong Kong has avoided a complete lockdown, unlike other cities worldwide.

site_title: South Korea's exports rise in November despite worsening pandemic
summary: South Korea's exports rose 4% in November, exceeding forecast, driven by strong demand for tech devices and gains in key markets. Despite worsening pandemic, the increase suggests governments' targeted approaches to containing infections are supporting demand. The country's economy expanded more than initially estimated in the third quarter, with a revised 2.1% growth. South Korea's strong currency has also boosted exports, but risks include re-imposed lockdown measures in major markets. The trade surplus widened to $5.9 billion.

site_title: S&P 500 to swallow Tesla in one gulp; shares surge
summary: Tesla shares jumped 4% in extended trade after S&P Dow Jones Indices announced it will add the electric car maker to the S&P 500 index on December 21, requiring index funds to buy about $73 billion worth of its shares. This move will make Tesla one of the most valuable companies ever added to the index, with a stock market value of around $550 billion. The decision comes after Tesla's stock surged 40% since November 16, when it was announced the company would join the index.

site_title: Trump to add China's SMIC and CNOOC to defence blacklist, say sources
summary: The Trump administration plans to add China's SMIC and CNOOC to a blacklist of alleged Chinese military companies, curbing their access to US investors. This move aims to cement Trump's legacy and box President-elect Joe Biden into hardline positions on Beijing. The list comprises four Chinese companies, including SMIC and CNOOC, which would prevent US investors from buying securities from these firms starting in late 2021. China's foreign ministry expressed hope that the US would not erect barriers and obstacles to cooperation.

site_title: UOB raises S$75,000 for charity through virtual run-walk event
summary: UOB's annual Heartbeat Run/Walk event, a flagship employee volunteerism and fundraising event, was held virtually this year due to the pandemic. Employees worldwide collectively covered over 200,000 km and raised S$75,000 for 17 charities, adding to the bank's existing S$1.65m donation to frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable members. The event supports UOB's #UnitedForYou Covid-19 Relief Programme, which aims to alleviate financial burdens during the pandemic.

site_title: A year after outbreak, Wuhan kin struggle to move on
summary: One year after the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, China, many next-of-kin are struggling to come to terms with their loss due to the city government's handling of the initial outbreak. Families accuse the government of initially concealing the outbreak's emergence and pressuring doctors to keep quiet, leading to widespread fear and stigma. Many have tried to sue the city, but courts have refused to accept the suits. The government continues to dodge responsibility, promoting unproven theories about the virus's origin, exacerbating the emotional trauma of the families.

site_title: Malaysia to charge Top Glove over worker accommodations, government says
summary: Malaysia's Ministry of Human Resources has launched an investigation into Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, over worker accommodations. Enforcement operations were conducted at six of Top Glove's companies, finding cramped and uncomfortable conditions, poor ventilation, and lack of rest and kitchen areas. Nineteen investigations have been opened, and charges are recommended against the manufacturer. The investigation was prompted by a Covid-19 outbreak at a Top Glove factory and the department will continue to conduct operations to ensure worker accommodations do not spread diseases and prevent forced labor.

site_title: JPMorgan doubling Singapore private bankers for rich China clients
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to double its number of private bankers serving Chinese clients from Singapore over the next two years, driven by the country's rapid wealth creation. The move aims to tap into Asia's second-largest wealth market, competing with Credit Suisse Group and Morgan Stanley. Singapore is seen as a natural hub for wealth management due to its investor-friendly regulation, and the bank will leverage its balance sheet to grow its relationship with clients via lending and other market activities.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 1% as central bank holds rates on housing market boom
summary: Australia's central bank kept interest rates at a near-zero level, fueling demand for homes and boosting construction activity. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor, Philip Lowe, expressed optimism about the economy's recovery, despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1% to 6,588.5 points, ending a three-session losing streak. The Australian economy is expected to show 2.5% growth in the September quarter, according to a Reuters poll. The housing market boom and easy monetary policies are underpinning the economy, with gold stocks leading the charge.

site_title: Exxon tries to put the worst behind it with US$20b impairment charge
summary: ExxonMobil Corp has announced a US$17 billion to US$20 billion impairment charge for its natural gas properties, its largest impairment, amid the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on energy demand and prices. The company will slash spending next year to its lowest level in 15 years to protect a rich shareholder payout. Exxon will focus on its Guyana oil discovery, offshore Brazil, and the Permian Basin oil field, shifting away from the underperforming shale market. The impairment charge is part of a broader effort to adapt to the changing energy landscape.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Opec+ output talks uncertain
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as uncertainty over Opec+ output cuts persisted, with Brent crude settling at US$47.59 a barrel. The group was initially set to discuss extending 7.7 million barrels per day cuts but delayed talks to Thursday due to disagreements. Despite rising vaccine hopes boosting demand, economists predict Brent will average US$49.35 a barrel next year, and Goldman Sachs forecasts Brent to rise to US$65 in 2021, driven by vaccine progress and economic recovery.

site_title: S&P to buy IHS Markit for US$39b in year's 2nd top deal
summary: S&P Global has agreed to buy IHS Markit for approximately $39 billion in stock, marking the second-largest acquisition of 2020. The deal creates a combined company with a market data and analytics business, challenging the London Stock Exchange Group's dominance. S&P shareholders will own about 68% of the merged entity, with CEO Douglas Peterson leading the company. Regulatory scrutiny is a potential risk due to overlap in data offerings, but the deal is seen as a strategic move to deepen product range and relevance in the increasingly computerized financial markets.

site_title: US watchdog finds flaws in key unemployment data
summary: A US government watchdog, the General Accountability Office (GAO), has found that key unemployment data is based on flawed estimates, making it difficult to assess the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on jobs. The Labor Department's weekly data on unemployment benefits is inaccurate due to a backlog of claims, which distorted the national figure. The GAO has called on the department to retroactively correct the figures and provide more accurate information. This could challenge policymakers' responses to the crisis, as nearly 20.5 million people were receiving unemployment aid as of November 7.

site_title: Global banks reverse back-to-office push in Hong Kong
summary: Global banks in Hong Kong, including Goldman Sachs, Standard Chartered, and Citigroup, have reversed their back-to-office push amid a surge in COVID-19 cases in the city. Goldman Sachs will allow staff to work from home, except for those requiring in-person roles. Standard Chartered has implemented a split-team arrangement and shortened branch hours. The move comes as Hong Kong introduces tougher public-gathering restrictions and reports 76 new cases. This reversal is part of a global trend, with workers returning to 22.6% of pre-Covid-19 office levels in the US.

site_title: Activist funds opposed to Sabana-ESR merger slam one-proxy rule
summary: Activist funds Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital have raised concerns over a potential "voting irregularities" in Sabana Reit's upcoming merger with ESR-Reit. The issue stems from the "one-proxy rule" allowing custodians to submit only one proxy form, potentially limiting their ability to fully represent unitholders' votes. The funds have urged custodians to submit both approving and dissenting votes and for them to publicly disclose their practice. The voting process will take place on December 4, with a deadline for proxy submissions on December 1.

site_title: No success in telcos' fight to grow profits
summary: Singaporean telcos Singtel and StarHub reported double-digit declines in underlying earnings, outpacing revenue dips. This puts them among developed market network providers struggling to grow profits from infrastructure investments. Despite high demand for connectivity, telcos have failed to attract investors and grow their share of the profit pool. Their performance highlights the challenges faced by telcos in staying relevant and profitable.

site_title: CDL to report full-year loss; Deloitte completes Sincere review
summary: CDL, a Singapore property developer, expects a full-year loss of S$564.6 million in 2020 due to the prolonged impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Impairment losses are forecasted, affecting its British unit Millennium & Copthorne Hotels and China-based joint venture Sincere Property Group. Despite signs of improvement, the pandemic's effects are likely to continue into 2021. The company's overall business and financial position remains healthy, but shares fell 0.9% to close at S$7.80.

site_title: Dollar hits new 2½ year low after month of losses
summary: The US dollar reached a 2½-year low, falling 0.1% to 91.625 against a basket of currencies, due to a surge in global market sentiment fueled by the US election win, stimulus hopes, and positive Covid-19 vaccine announcements. Riskier currencies, such as the New Zealand dollar, rose, while the offshore yuan and euro also gained ground. Analysts attribute the dollar's decline to a risk-on market environment, but expect a reversal in December as the rally becomes unsustainable.

site_title: Moderna to seek US, EU emergency nod after study shows 94.1% vaccine success
summary: Moderna announced it will seek US and EU emergency authorization for its COVID-19 vaccine, which showed a 94.1% effectiveness rate in preventing severe cases and no serious safety concerns. The vaccine distribution is expected to be easier due to its compatibility with standard refrigeration. This filing makes Moderna's product a likely candidate for US emergency use authorization this year, following Pfizer's successful application.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation as of Nov 30, 2020, shows taxable book-entry prices. The article does not provide further information on the bonds.

site_title: GlobalWafers in talks to buy Siltronic for 3.75 billion euros
summary: GlobalWafers Co is in talks to acquire Siltronic AG, a German manufacturer of silicon wafers, for 3.75 billion euros. The offer, valued at 125 euros per share, represents a 10% premium to Siltronic's closing share price. The deal, if successful, would create a leading player in the wafer industry and prohibit job losses in Germany until the end of 2024. The proposed transaction is subject to regulatory conditions and follows a record year for semiconductor industry deals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, gaining 0.95% or 250.40 points at 26,684.02, despite falls on Wall Street. The move followed news that US pharmaceutical firm Moderna had asked authorities to authorize its coronavirus vaccine. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index and broader Topix index rose 0.78% and 0.78% respectively.

site_title: China seeks to import jet fuel ahead of CNY holidays
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) is seeking to import jet fuel for January delivery, its first buy tender since May, amid expected surge in Chinese domestic air travel after the pandemic. This move comes as Chinese air travel continues to recover. CAO is one of the largest buyers of jet fuel in Asia, indicating a growing demand for jet fuel in China ahead of the Chinese New Year holidays.

site_title: Malaysia extends virus curbs on Top Glove's worker dormitories in Klang
summary: Malaysia extends its movement control order on Top Glove Corp's worker dormitories in Klang for two more weeks until December 14 due to rising coronavirus cases. The order was initially set to end on November 30 but was extended after 3,406 workers tested positive for the virus out of 5,805 tested. The decision follows the company's factory in Klang recording 1,067 Covid-19 cases, and the government has ordered 28 of its factories to close.

site_title: Creating a gender-equal world is a mission for all
summary: The European Union (EU) has adopted its third Gender Action Plan, aiming to create a gender-equal world by 2030. The plan, launched on November 24, 2020, calls for concrete measures to empower women and girls, promote sexual and reproductive health and rights, and integrate gender equality into EU policies. The EU supports projects around the world, such as online education initiatives and training programs for women in India and Syria, to help address the challenges of gender-based violence and inequality. Despite progress, the EU acknowledges that much work remains to be done, and the plan is a call for action to address structural inequalities and build more inclusive societies.

site_title: Digital transformation key to adapting amid Covid-19: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of digital transformation in building Singapore's "adaptive capacity" amid the Covid-19 pandemic. He noted that businesses that successfully navigated the crisis were those prepared for change. Heng highlighted the need for businesses to redesign jobs, reskill workers, and manage risk to emerge stronger. He also stressed the importance of staying open to global talent and capital while taking care of the local workforce. The government will continue to support businesses and workers through initiatives such as the Jobs Support Scheme. Heng urged business leaders to stay focused on building credibility and trust in a more volatile world.

site_title: UOB to set up electronic FX pricing, trade engine in Singapore
summary: UOB plans to launch an electronic foreign exchange (FX) pricing and trading engine in Singapore by Q2 2021, aiming to contribute to the nation's push to become the region's FX electronic trading centre. The move is supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and joins other major FX participants in serving strong institutional FX flows in Asia. The engine will utilize co-location connectivity to reduce latency and enhance pricing capability, enabling clients to tap into market liquidity more efficiently.

site_title: Australia's Treasury Wine diverting China-bound wine over hefty tariffs
summary: Australia's Treasury Wine Estates Ltd will divert hundreds of thousands of cases of China-bound wine to other countries due to hefty tariffs imposed by Beijing, resulting in a significant shift in strategy. The company will redirect sales of its prized Penfolds label to the US, Europe, and other Asian countries, affecting a quarter of its upper-range wine. Treasury shares fell 12% in early trade, and the company's earnings contribution to China is expected to almost halve by 2023.

site_title: Don't pay the ransom; take these five steps instead
summary: Ransomware attacks have spiked globally, particularly in Asia Pacific, where the rate is 1.7 times higher than the rest of the world. The rise in remote work has increased vulnerability, with healthcare providers and other sectors being targeted. Despite a 29% decline compared to 2018, the region continues to experience a high encounter rate. Interpol warns that prevention is key to avoiding such attacks, emphasizing the importance of taking proactive measures to secure businesses.

site_title: Weston Robot sees opportunities in crisis
summary: Weston Robot, a homegrown robot developer and supplier, has seen its revenue triple since the Covid-19 pandemic, with order books packed till the end of the year. The company attributes its surge in revenue to the increased demand for automation in manual processes such as temperature taking, safe distancing, and disinfection. With the pandemic continuing to drive the need for automation, Weston Robot is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: Volkswagen accused of anticompetitive campaign by supplier
summary: Volkswagen AG is accused by Bosnian parts supplier Prevent Group of conspiring to "demolish" the company through an anticompetitive campaign. The alleged campaign, code-named "Project 1," involved VW officials freezing Prevent out of the market, denigrating it in the press, and persuading other suppliers to refuse to use its parts. The dispute began in 2016 over cancelled orders for seat covers and transmission cases, which forced VW to temporarily close plants and lay off workers. VW denies the allegations, calling the lawsuit "meritless."

site_title: Mortgage boom risks coming home to roost for Brazil's banks
summary: Brazil's mortgage market is experiencing a boom, driven by low interest rates, a housing deficit, and cautious credit models. Home loan volumes surged 49% in October, the highest since 1994, as benchmark interest rates dropped to 2%. This has made home ownership feasible for thousands, with banks like Itau Unibanco and Banco Bradesco benefiting from the surge. However, economists warn of potential risks, including rising interest rates and inflation, which could drive up mortgage costs. Defaults have already increased, but banks insist they are keeping risks to a minimum with cautious credit models and collateral.

site_title: Covid-19 widens field for new digital banks as inclusion gap narrows
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is sticking to its plan to issue up to five digital bank licenses by year-end, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The regulator is impressed with the quality of applications and says the digital banks will enter the market with a more digitally ready population. MAS managing director Ravi Menon emphasized the need to expand financial inclusion, particularly for non-digital groups, and is looking for digital banks to fill service gaps in areas like financial planning and micro-enterprise financing.

site_title: Singapore opens tender for 600 EV charging points at over 200 public carparks
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority and Land Transport Authority launched a tender for 600 EV charging points at over 200 public carparks, aiming to encourage more vehicle owners to choose electric vehicles. The tender, open until March 12, 2021, will cover installation and operation costs. The increased availability of charging points is expected to boost the adoption of EVs in the country.

site_title: South Korea's Nov exports rebound but miss forecasts
summary: South Korea's exports rebounded 4% in November, driven by brisk demand for memory chips, exceeding October's decline. The 16.4% year-over-year growth in memory chip sales helped fuel the recovery, but missed forecasts of a 6.8% increase. Exports reached $45.81 billion, slightly above October's $44.90 billion. The Bank of Korea raised its GDP forecasts for the year, citing strong export growth, but warned that the pace of overall growth could be slow until January due to the resurgence of COVID-19.

site_title: Pilbara Minerals to buy Altura Mining's lithium project for US$175m
summary: Pilbara Minerals Ltd has agreed to buy the lithium operations of troubled peer Altura Mining Ltd for US$175 million. The acquisition comes at a time when lithium prices are struggling due to flat prices in Australia. The global market for lithium may have reached a bottom, with prices climbing 17% off June lows. Pilbara will also contribute A$6 million to a fund to support Altura employees who have been made redundant. The deal is set to be voted on by Altura's creditors by December 11.

site_title: Asean Customs Transit System team looks to multi-modal transport, wider adoption
summary: The Asean Customs Transit System (ACTS) aims to promote regional trade by streamlining customs procedures and reducing costs for businesses. The system, which went live in November, enables goods to be transported across multiple Asean countries under a single regime, reducing the need for repeated customs declarations and border changes. Stakeholders call for greater promotional efforts and expansion of the system to include multi-modal transport and lift the cap on vehicles allowed per country, with plans to introduce the system in Myanmar next year.

site_title: About 1,250 Shell employees to benefit from upskilling
summary: Shell employees in Singapore will benefit from a joint upskilling initiative with the Singapore Shell Employees' Union (SSEU), targeting 1,250 employees. The Joint Capability Council will offer training in adaptive skills, digital literacy, and data analytics, starting with over 500 process and maintenance technicians. The move aims to support Shell's digitalization efforts and cut carbon dioxide emissions by a third within a decade.

site_title: Singapore to open payment rails to selected non-bank financial firms from February
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) will open payment rails to selected non-bank financial firms starting in February 2021, leveling the playing field for e-wallet players that meet risk-management standards. Eligible non-bank financial institutions (NFIs) will gain direct access to the banking system's real-time retail payments infrastructure, allowing them to offer PayNow services. This move aims to increase competition and simplify e-payments for individuals and businesses, enabling real-time fund transfers between bank accounts and e-wallets, as well as across different e-wallets.

site_title: US: Dow wraps best month since 1987 despite weak session
summary: The Dow Jones index concluded its best month since 1987, gaining 11.7% in November, driven by expectations of a 2021 recovery based on coronavirus vaccine progress. Despite a 0.9% drop in the final session, the blue-chip index finished at 29,638.64. The November gains followed a decline in October amid concerns over rising coronavirus cases and the US presidential election. Markets have rallied in the wake of vaccine announcements, including Moderna's 20.2% surge after announcing a 94.1% efficacy rate.

site_title: GIC partners 3 organisations and initiatives on climate change management
summary: GIC partners with three organisations, including CDP, Climate Action 100+, and the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change, to enhance climate change management and disclosures. As part of its sustainability strategy, GIC aims to increase engagement and disclosures on climate risks and opportunities. This move follows GIC's commitment to reducing its environmental footprint and contributing to a more sustainable future.

site_title: STI ends session 1.75% down, but up 15.8% for the month of Nov
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended down 1.75% on Monday, closing at 2,805.95, despite a 15.8% gain in November, its strongest monthly gain since May 2009. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the biggest loser, shedding 7.57%, while banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB also fell. Asian markets, including the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index, closed lower due to the Trump administration's move to blacklist SMIC and CNOOC, sparking concerns over US-China tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong imposes more restrictions to contain latest wave of Covid-19 infections
summary: Hong Kong's government has imposed more restrictions to combat the latest wave of Covid-19 infections, sending civil servants back to work-from-home arrangements. Chief Executive Carrie Lam urged private sector employers to follow suit, signaling concern over the outbreak's potential escalation. This move is the most far-reaching since a previous flareup started earlier this month. Authorities aim to contain the spread of the virus and prevent its scale from increasing.

site_title: Engineered to excel
summary: Total Facility Engineering (TFE), a Singapore-based engineering solutions provider, has achieved significant growth since its establishment in 2013. The company, founded by Ng Cheng Chuan, has expanded from a team of six to over 200 employees and has seen revenue rise from S$2.9 million to S$50 million in 2019. TFE has been recognized as one of the best-performing SMEs in Singapore and has secured major projects with global leaders in the semiconductor and chemical industries. The company's success is attributed to its innovative approach, commitment to continuous improvement, and focus on employee development and growth.

site_title: Australia government spending rises in Q3, adds to GDP
summary: Australia's government spending rose 1.4% in the September quarter to A$103.79 billion, driven by fiscal stimulus programs supporting incomes and employment. This increase is expected to contribute 0.3 percentage points to real gross domestic product (GDP) growth, partially recovering the 7.0% decline in the previous quarter. Analysts forecast a 2.5% GDP rebound, with public spending accounting for around 24% of GDP.

site_title: Sustainability drive: Everyone must chip in
summary: Singapore's government and industry players must work together to drive sustainability efforts, as individual actions alone are insufficient to address climate change. The country aims to become a zero-waste nation, with initiatives like recycling chutes in public housing and more e-commerce providers using recyclable packaging. However, balancing profit and environmental impact remains a challenge, with companies often choosing cost-effective options over sustainable ones. Collaboration between industry, consumers, and the government is needed to standardize practices, create guidelines, and promote responsible consumption and recycling.

site_title: Australia demands apology from China after fake image posted on social media
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has demanded an apology from China after a senior Chinese official posted a fake image of an Australian soldier allegedly harming an Afghan child on Twitter. The image, calling it "truly repugnant," was posted by China's foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian, sparking outrage and calls for its removal. Morrison condemned the post, saying it diminishes China in the world's eyes, amid deteriorating relations between the two countries.

site_title: Singapore's office market will never be the same again
summary: Singapore's office market is undergoing significant changes due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with flexible working becoming the new norm. As a result, office landlords face greater pressure to retain tenants and rents are expected to calibrate. A recent survey found that 69% of real estate executives predicted a decline in market performance, with 47% expecting the decline to persist until mid-2021. The trend of remote working may continue even after the pandemic, with hybrid workplaces becoming more prevalent, and buildings may be forced to redevelop or offer customizable space to remain attractive.

site_title: Digital skills to be taught in Mice training courses at SUSS
summary: The Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS) has partnered with the Singapore Association of Convention & Exhibition Organisers & Suppliers (SACEOS) to develop training courses for SUSS's BSc Events Management with Minor programme. The partnership aims to equip students with digital skills to meet challenges in the events industry related to the Covid-19 pandemic. The training courses will cover topics such as financial and risk management, trends and technologies, and event ideation, and are set to begin in July 2021. The partnership aims to build capabilities for the future and support the resilience of the meetings, incentives, conventions and exhibitions (Mice) sector.

site_title: Biden picks former Federal Reserve chair Yellen as Treasury secretary
summary: President-elect Joe Biden has named Janet Yellen, former Federal Reserve chair, as his Treasury secretary. Yellen, 74, is expected to champion "extraordinary fiscal support" to aid the pandemic-ridden US economy, drawing on her nearly two decades at the Fed. Her appointment is seen as a significant step towards addressing the economy's damage, and she is widely respected by lawmakers. With Senate confirmation, Yellen will be the oldest Treasury secretary in recent memory and the first woman to lead the agency.

site_title: Singapore needs new mindset to cement global hub role
summary: Singapore must adopt a new mindset to maintain its role as a global hub in a post-COVID-19 world, where global cooperation and trade are more fragmented. The city-state has the strengths to be a key node in the global economy, connecting markets and cooperating with other hubs. To succeed, companies must adopt an open mindset, agile operating model, and be able to reimagine the future, embracing innovation and technology. By doing so, Singapore can cement its position as a leading global gateway, fostering growth and development in the city and beyond.

site_title: Christmas, virus, fear of no-deal Brexit push Europe's warehouses to the limit
summary: Retailers worldwide are stocking up warehouses to prepare for Christmas and potential disruptions from the no-deal Brexit. With 30-35% of UK retailers' sales going to continental Europe, companies are bringing goods into the country before January or piling up stock in pan-European distribution hubs. Warehouse space is already at a record high, with demand expected to remain high even after the pandemic. Retailers are also considering splitting logistics operations across the UK and EU to avoid customs charges, and some are exploring alternative storage solutions, such as converting agricultural buildings into warehouses.

site_title: Sotheby's and Christie's look to luxury as a coronavirus antidote
summary: Sotheby's and Christie's are transforming into luxury-focused businesses, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. Sotheby's has restructured into two divisions: fine arts and luxury, art, and objects. The company has seen significant online sales of luxury items, raising $425 million this year, compared to $60 million last year. Christie's, which introduced online luxury sales in 2012, has also seen growth, with online sales of luxury items more than tripling in the current year. Luxury is seen as a key growth area, with art and luxury complementing each other.

site_title: Europeans snap up old cars to avoid public transport
summary: Across Europe, people are buying older used cars to avoid public transport during the pandemic, with a surge in interest in vehicles over a decade old. Data shows a 25% increase in prices for these cars, with buyers opting for cheaper alternatives to avoid coronavirus risks on public transport. This shift is expected to help carmakers recover from pandemic-related financial losses, but poses a setback to European targets for reducing carbon emissions.

site_title: Singapore commercial property investment deals dive, but should pick up next year: Savills IM
summary: Singapore's commercial property investment volumes plummeted to US$2.7 billion in the first nine months of 2020, down from US$8 billion in the same period in 2019. However, Savills Investment Management (Savills IM) expects investment volumes to rebound in 2021, reaching US$5.6 billion, driven by Singapore's attractiveness to investors due to its stable policy regime, sustainability initiatives, and plans to become Asia's digital capital. Key sectors expected to see increased investment interest include logistics, multifamily, and CBD offices.

site_title: No Signboard full-year loss widens to S$9.8m
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singapore-listed food and beverage group, reported a widened net loss of S$9.8 million for the financial year ended Sept 30, 2020, due to lower revenue of 46.8% to S$13.6 million. The company attributed the decline to temporary closures, lower tourist footfall, and ongoing travel restrictions. No dividend was declared, and the group expects the operating environment to remain challenging in the next 12 months. It plans to preserve cash and explore opportunities to strengthen its competitive edge.

site_title: European leaders need to pull together amid economic, political crisis
summary: European leaders face a critical moment as the continent struggles with an economic and political crisis amid the pandemic. The bloc's economy is spluttering, and divisions on providing economic support to struggling nations like Italy and Spain are deepening. A breakthrough agreement on a trillion euro budget and 750 billion euro recovery fund is now threatened by Poland and Hungary blocking funding tied to adherence to the rule of law. The EU's future, including eurozone reform and a potential expanded role for the European Stability Mechanism, hangs in the balance, requiring leaders to put aside divisions and work together to build momentum for recovery.

site_title: MAS orders removal of EH-Reit manager after submissions raise 'no new material facts'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) ordered the removal of Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) manager after receiving written submissions from EH-Reit Management's shareholder Mandarin West Holdings, which raised no new material facts. MAS directed DBS Trustee to appoint a new manager "as soon as practicable" due to multiple breaches of the Securities and Futures Act, including recurrent and ongoing breaches of capital and financial requirements. MAS also warned that it will take "stern action" against any financial institution that does not comply with its rules and regulations.

site_title: Universal Studios to open 60b yen Nintendo Park in February
summary: Universal Studios Japan plans to open its $580 million Nintendo-themed park, Super Nintendo World, on February 4, after being delayed due to the pandemic. The park, valued at 60 billion yen (US$580 million), features life-sized replicas of Nintendo games, rides, shops, and walk-through activities, including a Mario Kart ride. The project is a significant investment for the Osaka-based park operator, but its opening may still be impacted by Japan's ongoing outbreak and economic challenges. The park's success will be crucial for the theme-park industry, which is struggling with falling revenue.

site_title: Accuron Technologies CEO Tan Kai Hoe named chairman of Singapore Red Cross
summary: Tan Kai Hoe, CEO of Accuron Technologies, has been appointed chairman of the Singapore Red Cross, succeeding Tee Tua Ba who held the position for 12 years. Tan, who joined the SRC council in 2011, expressed his honor in taking over the leadership role. Madam Halimah, patron of the SRC, praised Tee's influence on the organization's volunteer culture, while expressing confidence in Tan's ability to motivate more people to join the humanitarian mission. Tan brings a mix of private and public sector experience to the role.

site_title: Bitcoin rallies toward US$19,000 after biggest rout since pandemic
summary: Bitcoin has rebounded, rising over 2% to nearly $18,692, after its biggest rout since the pandemic. The cryptocurrency's recent decline drew attention, but it has shown resilience, outperforming major asset classes in 2020.
