summary: Keppel Corporation donated S$2 million to support the opening of a new National Kidney Foundation (NKF) dialysis centre at Yishun Community Hospital, the first integrated centre within a hospital compound and the first to offer both haemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis services. The centre features 22 dialysis stations and aims to provide seamless care for patients. The donation is part of Keppel's commitment to uplift lives and care for the underprivileged, particularly vulnerable members of the community affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: HSBC considers exit from US retail banking: FT
summary: HSBC Holdings is considering an exit from US retail banking, according to a Financial Times report. Senior managers will outline the plan to the bank's board in the coming weeks, suggesting a reduction in investment banking activities to focus on international clients in Asia and the Middle East. A full exit from the US is no longer being considered, but no final decision has been made. This move follows HSBC's earlier restructuring, which included job cuts of about 35,000 over three years.

site_title: Brexit nipping at London's role as financial powerhouse
summary: London's financial hub is facing uncertainty as Brexit continues to disrupt its relationship with the rest of Europe. The UK's exit from the EU has led to a repatriation of business to the continent, posing a threat to the City of London's status as a global financial centre. The future of London's ties with Europe remains fractured and uncertain, as the UK navigates its new economic landscape.

site_title: Balestier unit fetches S$3.5m profit in October sale; Sentosa apartment records S$6.2m loss
summary: A 5,253 sq ft unit at Rajah Towers was sold for S$4.5m, earning the seller a 365% profit. The same unit was purchased for S$960,000. Another unit at Sentosa fetched S$6.2m, but the seller incurred a S$6.2m loss. These transactions were among the top deals in October, with the Rajah Towers unit having the highest gain by percentage.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia chairman ups stake
summary: Hong Leong Asia chairman Kwek Leng Peck acquired 4,044,100 shares of the company between Nov 18 and 24, effectively doubling his total interest in the company from 0.51% to 1.05%. The acquisition follows executive director and CEO Stephen Ho Kiam Kong's acquisition of 103,500 shares in November. The company's revenue for the first half of the year reached S$2.14 billion, a 4.2% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Medtecs strategises to be more than a one-hit pandemic wonder
summary: Medtecs International Corp, a Singapore-listed maker of surgical masks and medical products, is diversifying its business beyond pandemic-related products as the Covid-19 vaccine rollout slows demand for PPE. The company, which saw its net profit surge to US$85 million in the nine months to September 2020, is expanding its product line to include "flight suits" and antiviral products. Medtecs aims to become a one-stop procurement platform, with plans to establish a wholly-owned subsidiary in the US and increase its e-commerce presence. The company's shares have hit an all-time high this year, driven by its resilience during the pandemic.

site_title: DBS increases support for social enterprises with S$9 million in loans and grants
summary: DBS Bank has increased its support for social enterprises (SEs) with a S$9 million loan and grant package this year, its largest collective disbursement since its inception. The bank aims to support SEs in making a positive impact on communities, particularly amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This move reflects the growing importance of SEs in society, according to DBS Foundation board member Karen Ngui. The loans and grants will help SEs continue to deliver value to communities and address social and economic challenges.

site_title: Over 90% of The Landmark units launched sold on first day
summary: Over 90% of 120 units launched for The Landmark condominium in Singapore sold on its first day, with 110 units sold at an average price of S$2,250 per square foot. Most buyers were Singapore citizens and permanent residents, drawn by the development's breathtaking views and nearby amenities. The Landmark is expected to obtain a Temporary Occupation Permit in March 2025, and its pricing was kept relatively affordable to attract more homebuyers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BRC Asia, a mainboard-listed steel dealer, reported a 35.5% drop in full-year net profit to S$20.4 million due to COVID-19 disruptions. Revenue fell 32.9% to S$612.4 million. First Reit restructured master lease agreements with Lippo Karawaci and Metropolis Propertindo Utama, extending lease terms to 2035 with optional 15-year extensions. Shares of BRC Asia and First Reit closed flat, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: The economic impact of Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant economic impact worldwide. Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation and a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. The country is also poised to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Experts advise graduates to remain calm, as early data suggests better employment rates. Meanwhile, the government is exploring solutions for workers struggling with training, with the Singapore Business Federation offering assistance. The focus is on future-proofing careers and supporting affected businesses during the crisis.

site_title: Canada grants poultry, egg producers C$691m aid over free trade losses
summary: Canada has announced C$691 million in aid to poultry and egg producers, who have suffered losses due to free trade deals with Europe and Asia-Pacific countries. The aid, to be disbursed over 10 years, aims to compensate 4,800 egg and poultry producers affected by the supply management system. This move follows a pledge made in 2019 to compensate dairy farmers over eight years, with the remaining C$1.4 billion to be paid to them over three years. The Canadian government had promised compensation to breeders after announcing breaches of the supply management system.

site_title: QE size challenges central bank independence: BOE chief economist
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane warns that the unprecedented expansion of central banks' balance sheets poses a challenge to monetary policy independence. The BOE's bond holdings are expected to reach 50% of the UK's economic output, raising concerns about the role of central banks and their separation from government actions. Despite this, Haldane notes that the BOE's operational independence and inflation target offer protection against fiscal dominance. He also acknowledges the reduced effectiveness of central bank actions in stimulating demand, justifying a larger role for fiscal policy in supporting demand.

site_title: No Signboard full-year loss widens to S$9.8m on lower revenue
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a CATALIST-listed food and beverage group, reported a widened net loss of S$9.8 million for the financial year ended Sept 30, 2020, due to lower revenue. This represents a 100% increase from the previous year's loss of S$4.9 million. The company did not declare a dividend, citing no distributable profits. The net loss per share was 2.13 Singapore cents, compared to 1.05 cents in the previous year.

site_title: HSBC pondering over an exit from US retail banking: report
summary: HSBC is considering an exit from US retail banking, according to a report by the Financial Times. Senior managers will outline the plan to the bank's board, suggesting a reduction in investment banking activities and focusing on international clients, particularly in Asia and the Middle East. A full US exit is no longer being considered. This move comes as HSBC navigates rising geopolitical tensions in China and Hong Kong, which has driven its profits. No final decision has been made on the future of the retail business.

site_title: Tesla could widen release of 'self-driving' software in two weeks
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced plans to roll out a wider "Full Self Driving" software update in two weeks, following a beta release in October to a select group of "expert, careful" drivers. The system aims to become more robust as it collects data, with Musk initially targeting a full release by the end of this year.

site_title: Italy loosens Covid-19 restrictions in five regions, including Lombardy
summary: Italy is easing Covid-19 restrictions in five regions, including Lombardy, from Sunday. The regions will be downgraded from red to orange zones, while Sicily and Liguria will be designated as yellow zones. This decision follows a decline in hospitalizations and new cases in Italy over the past week. The move aims to relax restrictions and allow for more economic activity, but it may be subject to review if hospitalizations rise again.

site_title: China should further open up finance sector: PBOC official
summary: China's finance sector should be further opened up to support the country's "dual circulation" economic strategy, according to PBOC official Liu Guiping. This liberalization would provide extra support to the real economy and mitigate industry risks. Supervision in the banking and insurance industries is crucial to protect consumers' interests and lessen financial risks, said Cao Yu, vice-chairman of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission. The PBOC aims to improve financial risk prevention and maintain normal monetary policy to ensure stable macro leverage ratio.

site_title: First Reit to restructure Lippo Karawaci's master lease agreements
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has restructured its master lease agreements with Lippo Karawaci and Metropolis Propertindo Utama, extending lease terms to Dec 31, 2035, with optional 15-year extensions. The restructuring aims to increase cash flow certainty and provide a sustainable path for the company, with improved upside sharing for unitholders. The new rental structure will be based on the higher of base rent or performance-based rent, replacing the existing variable rent structure.

site_title: Opec and its allies are mulling extending output cuts
summary: Opec and its allies are set to discuss extending their current production cuts of 7.7 million barrels per day, aiming to avoid a repeat of the April price collapse. The meeting comes as the pandemic continues to impact global demand, with some member states, like Saudi Arabia, hinting at extending the cuts for 3-6 months. The potential extension would support prices in the first and second quarter of 2021, despite positive vaccine news, and comes as the cartel monitors production figures and oil storage levels.

site_title: Amazon says cloud outage triggered by capacity upgrade
summary: Amazon's cloud-computing network experienced a major outage on Wednesday, impacting media companies and the Washington Post, which is owned by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos. The outage was triggered by a capacity upgrade, according to the company, with the "trigger, though not root cause, being a relatively small addition of capacity." Amazon's AWS service was unavailable for several hours, affecting large users. The company has since restored service.

site_title: BRC Asia's full-year net profit down 36% amid Covid-19 disruptions
summary: BRC Asia's full-year net profit dropped 35.5% to S$20.4 million due to Covid-19 disruptions, with losses at its non-core subsidiary Pristine Islands Investment Pte Ltd increasing to S$14.4 million. Revenue declined 32.9% to S$612.4 million, and earnings per share fell to 8.72 Singapore cents. Despite a strong performance in the first half, the group remains cautious about the industry outlook, citing subdued economic activity and potential complexities.

site_title: Hearti Lab brings insurance, benefits to employees in SMEs
summary: Hearti Lab, a Singapore-based company, is helping small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) grow their businesses with a good digital presence. Founded by Keith Lim, the firm offers insurance and benefits solutions to SMEs, including human resource management and digital insurance platforms. Its products, Benefit.X and Surety.AI, use artificial intelligence and blockchain technology to streamline insurance purchases and claims. The company aims to capture a growing market in South-east Asia, where digitalisation is still low, and has overcome pandemic-related challenges to expand its reach.

site_title: Vietnam is top pick for businesses going overseas
summary: Vietnam is attracting a record number of Singapore businesses as companies seek expansion opportunities despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Enterprise Singapore supported over double the number of internationalization projects in Vietnam since 2018. Companies such as Doki Doki, Norbreeze Group, and Kalpha are scaling up their presence in Vietnam, citing lower operational costs and higher returns on investment. Kalpha's app, which relies on in-person meetups, has seen rapid growth in Vietnam compared to Singapore, with 15-20 sessions per day in Vietnam versus 1-2 sessions per day in Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia's embattled leader urges allies to stand together
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin urged his ruling coalition to strengthen cooperation ahead of a general election, citing tense ties between his Bersatu party and rival UMNO. He acknowledged the need for cooperation despite "open wounds" and "scars" from past conflicts, emphasizing the importance of unity in the face of challenges. The premier called for steps to prevent candidates from competing against each other in the same constituencies.

site_title: Rest of year may see rotation if investors shift from tech
summary: US investors are shifting focus from tech stocks, with a rotation towards sectors like energy, airlines, and electric cars expected as the pandemic continues. Despite promising vaccine trial results and a strong economic recovery, the US may experience more economic and market stumbles if the second wave of Covid-19 causes lockdowns and mass suffering. Electric vehicle stocks, including Tesla, have seen significant gains, but some analysts warn of a speculative bubble. The US stock market has reached historic highs, with the Dow Jones closing above 30,000 for the first time, driven by optimism over President-elect Joe Biden's plans for vaccines and a stimulus package.

site_title: China trade curbs hurt global confidence, says Australia
summary: China's trade curbs, including anti-dumping duties on Australian wine, have hurt global confidence in the economic recovery from the pandemic. Australia's Trade Minister Simon Birmingham described China's actions as "aggressive" and "assertive," saying they undermine confidence in the global economy. China has imposed duties on Australian goods such as wine, coal, and barley, amid rising tensions between the two countries since 2018. Australia may take China to the World Trade Organisation over its barley imports, with the government planning to assist exporters hurt by the trade measures.

site_title: UK's sole hydrogen car maker bets on green revolution
summary: UK-based Riversimple, the country's sole hydrogen car manufacturer, is betting on hydrogen technology to fuel the future of cars ahead of Britain's planned "green revolution" banning petrol-powered cars within 10 years. Despite conventional electric cars leading in the zero-emission vehicle race, Riversimple is optimistic about hydrogen's potential. The company faces competition from South Korean Hyundai, which sold 5,000 units of its Nexo model in 2019. Riversimple aims to capitalize on the growing demand for hydrogen-powered cars in the UK and globally.

site_title: Eight new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; one in the community
summary: There were eight new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore as of Sunday, bringing the total to 58,213. Seven cases were imported and placed on stay-home notices, while one was a community case, a migrant worker detected during community surveillance testing. The Ministry of Health confirmed the case had likely past infection based on serological test results. A 68-year-old man with pre-existing health conditions died from complications due to Covid-19, marking the 29th patient to pass away in Singapore.

site_title: Gearing up for the unexpected
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted businesses worldwide, with many adapting to remote work and digital transformation. Key changes include a greater focus on mental health, trust, and collaboration, as well as accelerated digitalization and innovation. Businesses have had to rethink their strategies to maintain trust, provide support to employees, and stay competitive in a rapidly changing landscape. As a result, companies are prioritizing diversity, sustainability, and employee well-being, and investing in technology to stay ahead. The pandemic has also accelerated the growth of industries such as e-commerce and digital transformation, and has highlighted the importance of agility and adaptability in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: Yoma Strategic sinks deeper into the red with US$60.5m full-year net loss
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a full-year net loss of US$60.5 million, widening from US$36.9 million the previous year. Revenue rose 13.6% to US$103.4 million, driven by a 90% increase in real estate development revenue. The group attributed its cautious optimism to the easing of COVID-19 measures and Myanmar's government focus on growth initiatives. No dividend was declared for the period, and the company expects its businesses to benefit from the economic transformation.

site_title: Sabana-ESR-Reit merger: Minority unitholders should make voices heard
summary: Sabana Reit is set to merge with ESR-Reit, with minority unitholders given the opportunity to vote remotely on December 4. The proposed deal, valued at a discount to Sabana Reit's net asset value (NAV), has sparked debate, with some arguing it undervalues the Reit and others citing the potential for 12.9% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion. Activist investors Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital have proposed alternative management, which Sabana Reit's management argues could put unitholders at risk.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine excitement lifts market mood, drives Russell 2000 and STI up
summary: The US market has seen a boost in optimism due to the potential availability of effective novel coronavirus vaccines and a shift in US policymaking under President-elect Joe Biden. The Russell 2000 index has surged 20.6% since October 30, outpacing the S&P 500 and DJIA. The Singapore market has also seen a rally, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 17.8% since October 30, driven by companies involved in transporting vaccines and reducing restrictions on movement. Investors are advised to be prepared to rotate holdings as the market shifts.

site_title: Opec faces seismic demand split as cartel plots next move
summary: Opec+ ministers are gathering virtually amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with Vienna's lockdown serving as a cautionary example. In contrast, Asia saw increased oil demand during the Diwali celebration and China's Golden Week holiday. Opec has trimmed oil demand forecasts for the next four years, citing a seismic shift in global consumption patterns. The cartel's next move is uncertain, with some analysts predicting a shift towards more flexible production targets. The pandemic's impact on oil markets continues to evolve, with global demand patterns changing rapidly. Opec's response to these changes will be closely watched.

site_title: JPMorgan, Lloyds set sights on Starling Bank: Times
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co and Lloyds Banking Group are reportedly interested in acquiring Starling Bank, a British challenger startup lender. The potential sale could mark the first big merger of an established lender with a startup in Britain. JPMorgan is set to launch a consumer bank in the UK in 2021, while Lloyds is interested in Starling's technology. The deal could have significant implications for the UK banking industry.

site_title: Zappos founder Tony Hsieh dies at 46; Bezos mourns untimely loss
summary: Tony Hsieh, the 46-year-old founder of Zappos.com, has died after being injured in a house fire in Connecticut. He was a Harvard graduate and led Zappos for two decades before stepping down in 2009 when Amazon acquired the company for $1.2 billion. Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos mourned Hsieh's untimely loss, praising his "curiosity, vision, and relentless focus on customers." Hsieh's unique corporate culture and management style, known as "holocracy," were widely admired in the tech industry.

site_title: Black Friday 99%-off sale sparks fears over garment workers' pay in UK
summary: A British fashion retailer, Pretty Little Thing, is facing criticism for its 99%-off Black Friday sale, which has sparked concerns over the treatment of garment workers in the UK. The sale, offered by the parent company Boohoo Group, has raised questions about how the company can keep its promises to pay workers fairly when charging low prices. Critics argue that the sale is a reminder of the industry's exploitation of workers and disregard for labor and environmental standards.

site_title: Loss-making private home resales bear watching as stimulus tapers off
summary: The share of loss-making residential transactions in Singapore's secondary market has eased to 15.9% in October, after peaking at 21.9% in June. This decline is attributed to lower volumes due to the circuit breaker and improved figures suggesting a containment of distressed sales. However, analysts warn that the situation needs to be closely monitored as policy stimulus and support measures gradually unwind. A recent survey found that nearly one-third of working adults in Singapore have issues paying off their housing loans, with some considering selling or downgrading their properties.

site_title: UK secures 2m more doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The UK has secured 2 million more doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine, bringing its total to 3.5 million doses, with deliveries potentially starting as early as the spring. This deal follows the UK's initial purchase of 5 million doses from Moderna two weeks ago. The UK has also secured 40 million doses of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine and 100 million doses of the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, with the regulator set to approve the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine this week.

site_title: Unravelling the holy grail of anti-ageing and longevity
summary: Researchers have found that increased sirtuin activity can protect against age-related diseases and increase human longevity. Sirtuins are a group of proteins that control cellular processes, including energy production, gene expression, and DNA repair. Studies have shown that sirtuins can delay cellular senescence, promote telomere elongation, and reduce DNA damage, leading to a longer lifespan. Increased sirtuin activity has been linked to delayed onset of age-related diseases, such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, and may also have protective effects on nerve cells.

site_title: Allowing border agents to question Huawei CFO before her arrest was best, officer testifies
summary: A Canadian police sergeant testified that allowing border agents to question Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou before her arrest was the best course of action. Meng was arrested at Vancouver airport in 2018 on US charges of bank fraud. Her lawyers claim Canadian and US authorities conspired to interrogate her without a lawyer present, while prosecutors argue that the investigation followed standard procedures. The sergeant, Ross Lundie, stated that the RCMP does not normally make arrests on planes unless extreme circumstances, and that the CBSA needed to be looped in for the investigation.

site_title: US online sales surge to near-record on Black Friday
summary: US online sales surged to near-record levels on Black Friday, reaching $9 billion, a 21.6% increase from the same day in 2019. This marked the country's second-highest one-day online sales figure, surpassed only by last year's Cyber Monday. The surge in online shopping was attributed to virus-wary Americans shunning in-person shopping.

site_title: Demystifying universal life policies
summary: Universal life policies (ULPs) offer a higher premium than term insurance but can be cost-effective for legacy planning, particularly for high-net-worth individuals. Key features include a guaranteed crediting rate, sum assured tied to death benefit or cash value, and mortality charges deducted from cash value. However, ULPs come with risks such as investment risk, currency risk, and interest rate risks. While ULPs may offer more coverage beyond age 100, term insurance is still a more cost-effective option, and ULPs should be considered carefully before purchase.

site_title: All so spectacular at the new, new course
summary: The Singapore Island Country Club's New Course has opened, offering a spectacular experience with its impressive clubhouse and waterfalls. The article does not provide further details about the course itself.

site_title: Airbus re-sells six jets built for AirAsia, denting surplus
summary: Airbus has re-sold six A320neo-family aircraft previously rejected by AirAsia, reducing its surplus of unsold jets by one. The move comes as the company makes progress in rescheduling deliveries and storing jets, with deliveries topping output in November. Airbus has seen strong demand for the A321neo jet, which has maintained its value, and plans to increase its output of the single-aisle jet. The redeployment of AirAsia aircraft is expected to further trim the surplus, which has been reduced to 135 jets.

site_title: China halts operation at Korean chip plant after worker tests positive for Covid-19
summary: A Chinese factory owned by SK Hynix halted operations in Chongqing city after a Korean worker tested positive for asymptomatic COVID-19 upon returning to South Korea. The worker had departed on Thursday for South Korea. The halt in operations occurred on Sunday, according to the official news agency Xinhua.

site_title: US appeals court rejects Trump campaign's Pennsylvania election case
summary: A US federal appeals court rejected Donald Trump's campaign's request to block President-elect Joe Biden from being declared the winner of Pennsylvania, dealing a significant setback to Trump's bid to overturn the election results. The three-judge panel ruled that charges of unfairness require specific allegations and proof, which were not provided. The case can still be appealed to the US Supreme Court, but the decision marks another defeat for Trump's efforts to challenge the election outcome.

site_title: Killing of suspected Iranian nuclear mastermind risks confrontation as Trump exits
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden faces a complicated task in reviving a nuclear deal with Iran after the suspected mastermind of a secret nuclear bomb programme, Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, was killed in an ambush near Tehran. Iran blames Israel, while implying the killing had the blessing of departing President Donald Trump. The killing complicates Biden's efforts to restore the Obama-era deal, and tensions are rising in the Middle East. Iran has vowed to "strike as thunder" against those responsible, and the US has declined to comment on the incident.

site_title: 68-year-old Singaporean man dies of Covid-19 complications
summary: A 68-year-old Singaporean man with a history of hypertension and heart disease has died from COVID-19 complications, marking the 29th fatality in Singapore. The man, who had traveled to Indonesia, was admitted to the hospital upon return to Singapore on November 17 and confirmed with COVID-19 on November 18. Six new cases were reported, including a locally transmitted community case, bringing the total to 58,205. The Ministry of Health is extending assistance to the man's family and has notified close contacts of the new cases.

site_title: US finalises new rules sought by airlines on consumer protections
summary: The US Transportation Department finalized new rules aimed at protecting consumer protections for airlines, following a request from the industry. The new rules require a three-pronged analysis and evidentiary hearings before adopting new rules deeming airline practices unfair or deceptive. The move was opposed by many Democrats, who said it would weaken enforcement and allow airlines to delay action. The rules, modeled on FTC standards, are set to become final 30 days after publication in the Federal Register.

site_title: UK's strict Covid-19 tiers system to remain in place until Easter Monday
summary: The UK's strict Covid-19 tiers system is expected to remain in place until Easter Monday, according to a report. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is prioritizing the NHS and believes it will be necessary to wait until after the winter peak in February and March to ease restrictions.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise for fourth straight week; Spain's BBVA jumps
summary: European shares rose for a fourth consecutive week, with the Stoxx 600 index gaining 0.4% on Friday. Tech and banks led gains, while energy stocks rose on rising oil prices. Spanish lender BBVA gained 4.2% after ending merger talks with Banco Sabadell, which fell 13%. Investors are optimistic about a quicker economic revival next year, despite near-term virus damage and rising infections in some European countries.

site_title: Sport pays tribute to Maradona with tears, applause, silence, banners and song
summary: Sporting events worldwide paid tribute to Argentine football legend Diego Maradona on the first weekend after his death, aged 60. Tributes included minute's silences, applause, banners, and songs. Former teammates and players, such as Diego Simeone, added emotional moments to the commemorations. The tributes were held in empty stadiums, but still conveyed the respect and admiration for Maradona's legacy.

site_title: Fintech company founder Chng stages event to help local playing pros
summary: Fintech company founder Chng staged an event to help local professional golfers in Singapore. The event, taking place on November 28-29, aims to provide support to golfers amid the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. The initiative is a low-key attempt to boost the competitive spirit of Singapore's top golfers.

site_title: Black Friday gets busted by Covid-19 in sign of retail's future
summary: Black Friday shopping is shifting online due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with consumers avoiding in-person events and instead opting for online services. Retailers are stress-testing their new options, including extended promotions and curbside pickup, which are expected to continue growing. Despite weaker-than-expected results, the holiday season is still expected to top last year's sales, driven by increased savings rates and disposable income. Some retailers saw significant gains, including GameStop and Etsy, while others reported lackluster in-store visits, with many consumers preferring the convenience of online shopping.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia agree to US$210m US auto safety civil penalty
summary: Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors' US units agreed to a record $210 million civil penalty for failing to recall 1.6 million vehicles with engine issues in a timely manner. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) found inaccuracies in the companies' reports regarding the recalls. Hyundai agreed to a $140 million penalty, while Kia agreed to a $70 million penalty. The companies will implement new safety measures and invest in a safety field test laboratory to address the issue.

site_title: Oil prices post weekly gain ahead of Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices rose for the fourth consecutive week, with Brent crude gaining 7.2% and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rising 8% ahead of an Opec+ meeting. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, is expected to delay the planned 2 million barrel per day increase in oil output in January. Rising Libyan output and concerns about oversupply also contributed to the price gains. Market analysts predict limited price increases if Opec+ delays the planned supply increase.

site_title: Credit Suisse restructures in Latin America
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG is restructuring its Latin America wealth-management regions, merging some client groups and reassigning countries to optimize service delivery. The "Andean" group, spanning Peru to the Caribbean, will be split, with some countries moving to Mexico & Central America and the rest to a South American grouping excluding Brazil. The move aims to boost revenues from ultra-rich clients and cut costs, with a target of 80 million Swiss francs in gross savings in 2021. Key hires from rival UBS Group AG will join the new structure.

site_title: US dollar falls to lowest level in almost three months
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest level in almost three months, dropping 0.24% against a basket of major currencies. This decline follows strong economic data from China, favorable commodity currencies, and a surge in global market sentiment after Joe Biden's election victory and positive Covid-19 vaccine progress. The Australian dollar rose to its highest level in nearly three months, while the British pound declined against the euro amid Brexit trade deal differences. Market participants are balancing portfolios after solid monthly gains for equities, with investors looking to the US Federal Reserve's potential guidance on bond-buying.

site_title: Biolidics jumps 22.6% on news of Covid-19 test kit distribution
summary: Biolidics' shares surged 22.6% on Friday after the company announced plans to distribute Covid-19 test kits in Indonesia, Singapore, and the Philippines. The move comes after receiving regulatory approval, with distribution expected to contribute positively to revenue. The company has also partnered with China-based JOYSBIO to distribute its test kits, with potential for exclusive distribution in Singapore and the Philippines if certain sales targets are met. This is Biolidics' third consecutive day of gains.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records, extending November rally
summary: US stocks closed at records on Friday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the way, up 0.9% to a record 12,205.85. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also reached new highs, as investors focused on a potential economic recovery in 2021 despite rising coronavirus cases. The market's optimism was fueled by expectations of effective COVID-19 vaccines and a new administration under President-elect Joe Biden. A busy week of economic data and policy announcements is expected, with the November jobs report and an OPEC meeting on the calendar.

site_title: US agency opens probe into 115,000 Tesla vehicles over suspension issue
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has opened a formal investigation into around 115,000 Tesla vehicles due to a front suspension safety issue, with 43 complaints alleging failure of the left or right front suspension fore links. The issue was first reported in 2017 and has seen a recent increase in complaints, with some incidents occurring at highway speeds. Tesla has issued a service bulletin addressing the issue, and a class-action lawsuit has been filed against the company over suspension issues in Model S and X vehicles.

site_title: Post-US elections certainty and vaccine optimism drag gold lower
summary: US Treasury Secretary reassured markets that the Treasury and Federal Reserve have enough firepower to support the US economy, reducing election-related risk. The announcement of President-elect Joe Biden's transition and nominations for top positions, including Janet Yellen as Treasury secretary, was seen as dovish by the gold market. Gold prices dropped through $1,850 as investors turned to riskier assets, but optimism about economic recovery and vaccine news boosted the market. Despite this, gold prices remained lower, dragged down by post-election certainty and vaccine optimism.

site_title: Pocket perfection
summary: Junior The Pocket Bar has reopened in its new location on Ann Siang Hill, maintaining its signature traits of cosiness and creativity. The bar now seats 25 and offers a wider selection of drinks, including core menus Homebrews & Highballs and Eat the Rich. The latter features decadent cocktails with luxurious bites, while the former showcases house-fermented drinks. The bar's owner, Joe Alessandroni, aims to balance the trend towards lighter, refreshing drinks with complexity and flavour.

site_title: Hong Kong, Singapore office Reits live on in post-virus world
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore office Reits are performing well in the post-pandemic world, outperforming their peers in Australia and Japan. Relatively small homes, short commutes, and new tech firm tenants in these cities are boding well for property trusts. Despite companies giving up office space, Singapore's office Reits are expected to rise, driven by a rotation to economically sensitive stocks and attractive dividend yields. Analysts predict yields of 4-5% for Reits in these cities, higher than those in Japan, and lower than those in Australia.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LHN Ltd reported a 192% increase in full-year net profit to S$24.1 million, driven by a 20.8% rise in revenue and a 15.7% decrease in cost of sales. The company also won a joint tender for 33 public carparks in Singapore. In contrast, Melco Resorts Finance Ltd posted a loss of US$203.4 million for the third quarter, citing softer performance in gaming segments.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics to cost extra 200b yen: Yomiuri
summary: The Tokyo Olympics' organising committee estimated an additional 200 billion yen (S$2.57 billion) in costs due to the one-year postponement to 2021. The costs don't include COVID-19 countermeasures, which are primarily handled by the Japanese government. The shift has caused logistical headaches, but is less painful than cancellation for host, sponsors, and others with billions invested. The committee will discuss the plan with the Japanese and Tokyo metropolitan governments to split the costs next month. The initial estimate was as high as 300 billion yen, but was simplified to save money.

site_title: Proxy advisers Glass Lewis, ISS recommend proposed merger of Sabana and ESR-Reit
summary: Proxy advisers Glass Lewis and ISS recommend the proposed merger of Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, citing a more diverse portfolio and added scale for the businesses, resulting in a "more resilient and secure income stream". The merger could give Reit better positioning and bargaining power. The recommendations are set to be voted on at the upcoming extraordinary general meeting and scheme meeting on December 4.

site_title: US and China need to start talking again
summary: The US and China need to resume dialogue despite their increasingly bitter rivalry, as the two countries' competition has led to a lack of communication and cooperation. The Trump administration's trade war has left both countries worse off, and a more practical approach is needed, focusing on hard-nosed bargaining and improving communications between the two militaries. A frank dialogue between US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping is essential to prevent a wider conflict and change Chinese behavior, particularly in Hong Kong and the South China Sea.

site_title: Who will miss the coins when they're gone?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift away from cash and towards digital payments, with many countries and companies exploring alternatives to coins. The US Federal Reserve is conducting research on a digital currency, while China has plans for a digital yuan. Facebook is also developing a digital currency, and Bitcoin advocates see it as a solution to financial system problems. However, the decline of coins poses challenges for small businesses and archaeologists, who value coins as historical artifacts. Experts warn that the trend could lead to a bifurcation of the economy, with some segments thriving while others struggle.

site_title: Clubs act to ease online booking woes
summary: Singapore golf clubs are taking steps to ease online booking woes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. With the ban on golf travel to Bintan, Batam, and Johor, clubs are facing heavy demand for flights, causing frustration among members. To address this, clubs are introducing online booking systems and partnering with travel agencies to provide members with more convenient options. This move aims to increase play frequency and alleviate the strain on the golf industry.

site_title: From just a social player, then club captain and board member to SGA president
summary: Ross Tan, 64, rose from being a social player to becoming the Singapore Golf Association president in 2016. He also served as a club captain and board member. Tan's career progression highlights his leadership skills and dedication to the golfing community.

site_title: China to end all waste imports on Jan 1
summary: China will ban all waste imports from January 1, 2021, marking the end of its three-year phase-out of accepting overseas junk. The country, once the world's largest importer of rubbish, aims to no longer be the world's "rubbish bin." China's solid waste imports have decreased by 42.7% year on year, from 22.63 million tonnes in 2018 to 13.48 million tonnes last year. The ban will cover all types of waste, including plastics, car parts, paper, textiles, and scrap steel or wood, and will also prohibit dumping, stacking, and disposal of waste products.

site_title: Forget the bargain basement. Bet on the next big thing
summary: Value-stock enthusiasm may be gaining traction, but experts like Hiro Mizuno argue that growth stocks will continue to outpace value stocks. Mizuno, a former chief investment officer of Japan's $1.6 trillion Government Pension Investment Fund, cites the success of FAANGs (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix, and Google) as evidence. He believes that entrepreneurs' disruptive visions will drive growth, outpacing the potential for value stocks to uncover undervalued assets. As the pandemic recedes, Mizuno expects growth stocks to remain a better investment option, driven by productivity gains and dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Services sector sees reprieve in Q3, but revenue 9.5% lower than last year
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 9.5% year-on-year decline in revenue in Q3 2020, but a 5.4% quarterly growth. All industries except information and communications services took less revenue compared to last year, with recreation and personal services recording the largest drop at 41.3%. However, some sectors like information and communications services reported growth, with economists expecting a likely increase in year-end spending amid the festive season.

site_title: Brave new world of ESG bonds can sometimes leave investors cold
summary: A new type of bond, sustainability-linked bonds, is raising concerns among investors about the ethics of profiting from companies missing social and environmental targets. These bonds offer extra coupons if the issuer fails to meet goals, sparking debate about whether the booming ESG investment market skews incentives for issuers. site_title: For the love of science

She relocated to Singapore, the pharma giant's Asia Pacific headquarters, and accepted increased responsibility. Henderson, a licensed psychologist, attributes her decision to Merck's supportive culture, which encourages women to take risks and step into top roles. As regional VP, Henderson faces the challenges of supplying medicine to diverse markets, including a possible cure for cancer.

site_title: Singapore revs up for transportation of Covid vaccines
summary: Singapore has set up a taskforce to identify logistics risks and challenges in transporting Covid-19 vaccines, with a focus on Changi Airport. Airlines like Singapore Airlines and ground handlers like Sats have been identified as strong in cold-chain transport. Both companies have met safety and security standards for handling pharmaceuticals. Changi Airport has the Asia-Pacific's largest CEIV Pharma-certified community, and companies like Pfizer are working with Changi to distribute vaccines. Airlines and logistics operators are being engaged by the UN's Unicef to transport the vaccines, with Singapore expected to play a key role in the distribution network.

site_title: Q3 profit for Malaysia's top banks falls as pandemic takes toll
summary: Malaysia's top two banks, Maybank and CIMB, reported smaller third-quarter profits due to the pandemic's impact. Maybank's net profit fell 2.3% to RM1.95 billion, while CIMB's plummeted 80% to RM194.4 million. Maybank attributed the decline to lower interest rates and increased loan loss provisions, while CIMB cited elevated credit losses. Despite the losses, both banks expressed confidence in their risk management capabilities and plans to drive business growth in the coming year.

site_title: Is insurance dispensable when times are hard?

Cutting back on insurance can leave individuals vulnerable to unexpected medical expenses. Instead, experts recommend restructuring policies to maintain coverage, exploring options such as premium holidays or taking out loans against surrender values. Cancellation should be a last resort, and individuals should prioritize cashflow management to avoid making permanent decisions in times of financial stress.

site_title: Japan's ANA issuing shares to raise US$3.2b for 787 jet purchases
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings plans to issue 14 million new shares, raising US$3.2 billion, to fund its Boeing 787 Dreamliner jet purchases. ANA expects a quicker rebound in leisure travel, with some planes configured with fewer business-class seats. The airline forecasts a record operating loss of 505 billion yen for the year to March 31, and its cash reserves were replenished with US$3.8 billion in subordinated loans last month.

site_title: HDT pulls plug on electric-taxi business in Singapore on 'debilitating' Covid-19 hit
summary: HDT Singapore Holding, an affiliate of Chinese EV giant BYD Co., is shutting down its electric taxi business in Singapore due to a "prolonged, debilitating impact" from the COVID-19 pandemic. site_title: Jumbo to buy 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle for S$2.1m
summary: Jumbo Group will acquire a 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle for S$2.1 million, marking its first inorganic expansion since listing in 2015. site_title: ThaiBev cautious on recovery, offering wider product range
summary: ThaiBev, a major beverage company, expressed caution on its recovery from the pandemic, citing softness in the Vietnam market due to lockdowns. site_title: UOB, Vietnam's Foreign Investment Agency secure over S$3b of direct investments into country
summary: UOB has secured over S$3 billion of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Vietnam in partnership with the country's Foreign Investment Agency (FIA). Under an expanded Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), the bank will facilitate an additional pipeline of over S$1.5 billion, supporting more than 2,000 jobs to be created in Vietnam. The partnership aims to increase FDI and trade between Vietnam and Southeast Asia, focusing on sectors such as sustainable energy, manufacturing, and technology.

site_title: Reits (Nov 28-29, 2020)
summary: Real estate investment trusts (REITs) experienced fluctuations in November 2020, with US mortgage rates climbing after five consecutive weeks of declines. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Meanwhile, Manhattan rents reached a record high, with further increases anticipated. summary: The Audi A5 Cabriolet 2.0 review highlights the car's glamorous appearance and gentle disposition, making it a stylish and comfortable convertible. The 2.0-litre turbocharged engine produces 190 horsepower and 320 Newton-metres of torque, allowing the car to sprint from 0-100km/h in 7.9 seconds. site_title: Three executives leave JLL's Hotels & Hospitality Group to start family office
summary: Three JLL executives, David Marriott, Daniel Yip, and Giuliano Esposito, have left the company's Hotels & Hospitality Group to start a family office, High Street Holdings Singapore, which will focus on investing in hotels and real estate across the Asia-Pacific. The trio, formerly senior vice-presidents, left JLL to explore new opportunities. A JLL spokesperson confirmed their departure, stating it will not impact the company's business strategy and operations. The family office will be a boutique real-estate investment and asset-management company, with the executives now partners at High Street Holdings Singapore.

site_title: Body blow: Singapore fitness players still reeling from Covid suckerpunch
summary: Singapore's fitness industry remains reeling from the COVID-19 pandemic, with gyms and studios operating at reduced capacity due to safe distancing measures. A survey of 64 gyms and studios found that 40.6% are operating at 30-50% capacity, while 15.2% are at full capacity. Many have taken to offering online classes to make up for lost revenue, but physical classes remain in demand. Industry players say that online classes are a temporary fix and that physical classes are preferred due to limitations of online classes and working out at home. The industry is facing uncertainty, with some gyms and studios having to let employees go or take on debt to stay afloat.

site_title: SPH to invest in digitalising media business, seek new recurring income
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) plans to further invest in digitalizing its media business to address declining print advertising and subscription revenue. The company has seen a 22.8% decline in media business revenue due to the Covid-19 pandemic. To counter this, SPH will continue to digitalize its offerings, including news websites, apps, and tablets, while also improving data analytics to boost subscriptions. The company aims to increase recurring income from its property segment, as well as growth in aged care and digital media businesses.

site_title: Construction firms urged to call for safety time-out after 3 workplace fatalities in 2 days
summary: Construction firms in Singapore are urged to conduct a safety time-out exercise after three workplace fatalities occurred in two days, citing complacency and overlooked safety processes. The Workplace Safety and Health Council and the Singapore Contractors Association Ltd recommend reviewing safety protocols, refresher training, and addressing potential lapses. The exercise aims to ensure robust safety measures, especially during the year-end festive period when construction projects face tighter deadlines. Companies must complete the exercises by Dec 23 or indicate their schedules by Dec 11.

site_title: China to charge 12 from Hong Kong caught fleeing by boat
summary: Chinese authorities plan to charge 12 Hong Kong residents with border violations for attempting to flee by speedboat over three months ago. The 12, who faced charges related to anti-government protests, have been held incommunicado in a mainland prison. They face up to seven years in jail for charges of illegal border crossing and organizing an illicit border crossing. A relative of one detainee questioned the fairness of the legal process.

site_title: COE supply to drop 11% for Feb-April: sgCarMart
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) is expected to issue 11% fewer COEs (certificates of entitlements) for passenger cars in February to April 2021, with a projected average of 610 COEs per month. COE supply for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp is expected to drop by 7%, while for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp, it's expected to drop by 4%. This is attributed to lower deregistration numbers and an expected rise in buying interest for new cars in December.

site_title: SoftBank hits new 20-year high as Uber gains; DoorDash plans IPO
summary: SoftBank Group reached a 20-year high, closing at 7,250 yen, driven by a surge in Uber Technologies and improving prospects for portfolio companies, including DoorDash, which plans to go public. The company's 13% stake in Uber is worth about $11 billion, with shares gaining over 70% this year. Analysts have raised their target prices, citing improved earnings prospects, and brokerages have a "buy" rating on SoftBank.

site_title: US: Wall St gains on recovery hopes after Thanksgiving holiday
summary: Wall Street's main indexes rose on Friday as investors remained optimistic about an economic rebound in 2021 despite concerns over a surge in coronavirus infections. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.13%, 0.25%, and 0.54% respectively, reaching fresh records. The economic recovery hopes outweighed concerns, with the market brushing off recent tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: VW speeds up work on small electric car, culls combustion models
summary: Volkswagen is accelerating the development of a compact electric car, priced under 30,000 euros, to be introduced as early as 2023. The car will join the ID.5 crossover and an electric minibus in 2022, along with a fully electric station wagon, Aero, with a 700 km range. VW will discontinue combustion models, including the Passat sedan in the US, to free up funds for its electric push, and aims to reach break-even in South America and the US by next year, with a global market share target of 8.6% in 2021.

site_title: Gold drops below US$1,800 to lowest since July on vaccine
summary: Gold prices dropped below US$1,800 an ounce, the lowest since July, due to positive vaccine news and a clearer economic outlook, leading investors to swap into risk assets. This decline accelerated after gold fell below its 200-day moving average. Applications for US state jobless benefits unexpectedly rose, and AstraZeneca's vaccine is set to undergo an additional global trial. images.alt_text: Gold slid below US$1,800 an ounce to the lowest since July as positive vaccine news and a clearer political picture continued to undermine the haven.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.52 points to 1,607.59. Volume reached 10.359 billion lots worth RM5.479 billion. Gainers narrowly outweighed losers 621 to 604.

site_title: Four new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Four new Covid-19 cases were reported in Singapore on November 27, all of which are imported. The cases, including a Singaporean woman and two permanent residents, were placed on stay-home notice upon arrival. The total number of cases in Singapore has risen to 58,199, with 58,096 patients having fully recovered.

images.alt_text: There were four new coronavirus cases reported as of Friday noon, all of which are imported, with no new community cases and none from worker's dormitories, said the Ministry of Health (MOH).

site_title: Petronas warns of challenging Q4 amid volatile oil prices
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy giant Petronas warned that the fourth quarter of 2020 will be challenging due to volatile oil prices and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported a third-quarter loss of 3.4 billion ringgit, citing higher impairment losses and tax expenses. Petronas will maintain a cautious outlook and focus on preserving liquidity to ensure business sustainability. The company expects to operate its Pengerang Integrated Complex by early next year and has plans for several upcoming projects.

site_title: China targets Australian wine, says ties have taken 'nosedive'
summary: China is set to impose anti-dumping duties of over 100% on Australian wine, effective November 28, in response to the country's ban on Chinese telecommunications company Huawei. The move escalates tensions between the two nations, which have been in a deadlock since 2018. China has also barred imports of coal, barley, copper, and other products from Australia. The duties will impact Australian wine exports worth A$1.2 billion to China, with the country's trade minister labeling them "grossly unfair, unwarranted, and unjustified."

images.alt_text: Beijing will impose anti-dumping duties of more than 100 per cent on Australian wine from this weekend.

site_title: Adios to a football original
summary: Diego Maradona, the legendary Argentine footballer, has passed away at the age of 60 due to a heart attack. Known for his exceptional skills and larger-than-life personality, Maradona is a football original who took the global game to new heights. Despite his flaws as a human being, including drug addiction and a notorious "Hand of God" incident, Maradona's talent and charisma earned him a place among the greatest footballers of all time. His legacy will be remembered for his incredible achievements on the pitch, including leading Argentina to the 1986 World Cup victory and inspiring generations of football fans worldwide.

images.alt_text: Argentinian superstar Diego Maradona was a textbook example of a maverick. He was someone who took the global game to another level.
Flowers left by fans at a mural depicting Maradona in Buenos Aires.

site_title: LHN's full-year net profit up nearly three times to S$24.1m
summary: LHN Limited reported a full-year net profit of S$24.1 million, a nearly threefold increase from S$8.2 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 20.8% to S$134.2 million, driven by increases in residential properties and facilities management. Cost of sales fell 15.7% and other income more than tripled to S$17.1 million. The company proposed a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share, up from 0.5 cents last year.

site_title: Q3 profit for Malaysia's top banks falls as pandemic takes toll
summary: Malaysia's top two banks, Maybank and CIMB, reported smaller third-quarter profits due to the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic. Maybank's net profit fell 2.3% to 1.95 billion ringgit, while CIMB's net profit dropped 80% to 194.4 million ringgit. Revenue declined 57% for Maybank and 3.7% for CIMB. Despite this, Maybank expects loan loss provisions to remain elevated and is focusing on cost management to mitigate income losses. CIMB remains cautious on the rest of 2020 due to ongoing economic disruption.

images.alt_text: The top two lenders in Malaysia posted smaller third-quarter profits on Friday, both attributing poorer performances to the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week in the red; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week down 0.1%, marking the third consecutive decline. The STI fell 1.66 points to 2,855.82, despite a year-on-year 9.5% decline in receipts in the third quarter of 2020. Sembcorp Industries was the top gainer, adding 2.2%, while Dairy Farm was the biggest loser, falling 3.5%. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, and comes as investors await GDP data ahead.

site_title: Thai protesters target would-be coup makers as rumours swirl
summary: Thai protesters held a "Rehearsal to Oppose a Coup" rally, calling for an end to coups in the country. Hundreds of protesters, including a 18-year-old student, gathered in Bangkok, demanding Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's resignation and criticizing the monarchy for enabling decades of military domination. The protesters also accuse the monarchy of supporting a potential future coup. The royal palace has remained silent on the protesters' demands, while at least seven prominent protest leaders face charges of insulting the monarchy, which could carry up to 15-year jail terms.

images.alt_text: Thai anti-government protesters called for an end to coups in the Southeast Asian country on Friday as months of street protests fuel rumours of another military takeover.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 falling 0.9% to 6,307.55 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 remained flat. In contrast, Asian markets continued their upward momentum, boosted by the prospect of coronavirus vaccine rollouts. The US markets were closed for the Thanksgiving holiday, allowing Asian stocks to gain momentum.

site_title: UOB and Vietnam's Foreign Investment Agency secure more than S$3 billion FDI
summary: UOB has secured over S$3 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in Vietnam, in partnership with the country's Foreign Investment Agency. The bank aims to double its FDI facilitation under an expanded Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). This will create over 2,000 new jobs in Vietnam, on top of the 17,000 already created. The partnership focuses on sustainable energy, manufacturing, infrastructure, healthcare, and technology sectors, and will provide companies with advisory support and local insights.

site_title: India enters recession, worst among major economies
summary: India's economy contracted 7.5% between July and September, entering a technical recession for the first time since independence in 1947. This is the worst performance among major advanced and emerging economies. The two consecutive quarters of contraction indicate a tough fight for the country to revive demand and create jobs amid rising coronavirus infections.

images.alt_text: India's economy contracted 7.5 per cent between July and September, performing worst among major advanced and emerging economies and entering a technical recession for the first time since independence, official data showed Friday.

site_title: PropertyGuru buys Malaysian property data company MyProperty Data
summary: PropertyGuru is acquiring Malaysian property data company MyProperty Data through a share purchase agreement with TechnoDex and Real Estate Solutions. The deal aims to provide comprehensive data and insights to various stakeholders in the Southeast Asian property market. MyProperty Data offers property data analytics and insights leveraging six million unique records, covering sales, rentals, and new developments. The acquisition will enable PropertyGuru to become the leading provider of data and insights to agents, financial institutions, and property developers in the region.

site_title: More partners keen to join RCEP: Singapore's chief negotiator
summary: Singapore's chief negotiator Sulaimah Mahmood said several countries are interested in joining the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), despite India's withdrawal from negotiations last November. The pact, signed by 10 Asean member states, China, Japan, South Korea, Australia, and New Zealand, will consider new members' free trade agreements (FTAs) with Asean. India, which had expressed interest, can rejoin at any time, and prospective new members must wait 18 months after the RCEP enters into force. The pact's Trade Negotiating Committee will discuss criteria and process for admitting new members.

site_title: No bonus for civil servants this year; 2,400 lower-wage workers to get S$1,200
summary: Singapore's government will not be giving year-end bonuses to its 85,000 civil servants due to the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. However, around 2,400 lower-wage workers will receive a one-time payment of S$1,200. The government will continue to pay a non-pensionable annual allowance to all civil servants. The decision comes as the economy faces a significant impact, with the unemployment rate rising in the third quarter and a forecasted contraction of 6-6.5% in 2020.

site_title: A Thai-Singapore 'travel bubble' could boost Thai economy: US-Asean Business Council
summary: A travel bubble between Thailand and Singapore is expected to boost the Thai economy by accelerating investment, opening tourism to international visitors, and providing relief to a "critically hit part" of the economy. The US-Asean Business Council's chairman, Alexander Feldman, stated that the bubble will demonstrate that travel can return when conditions are right. This move is seen as a positive step for the Thai economy, which has been impacted by the pandemic. The travel bubble is expected to bring in much-needed revenue and support economic growth.

site_title: Japan ruling party calls for major green investment in draft plan
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has proposed a decade-long spending program to promote environmental investment, aligning with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The plan involves creating a fund to support companies investing in green technology, with a size comparable to global standards. The recommendations will serve as a basis for the government's deliberations on a fresh stimulus package.

site_title: CAAS, CAG establish private-public task force to airlift Covid vaccines into Singapore and region
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and Changi Airport Group (CAG) have established a private-public task force to airlift Covid-19 vaccines into Singapore and the region through Changi Airport. The task force aims to identify and address risks and challenges in air transportation of vaccines, involving key industry players and government agencies. This move is crucial for effective vaccine delivery, requiring collaboration among air cargo industry members.

site_title: Tesla recalls 870 cars in China over defective roofs
summary: Tesla is recalling 870 Model X cars in China due to defective roof trim, which may fall off during driving, posing a safety hazard. The recall affects cars produced between March 16 and July 31, 2016. If the trim falls off, it could increase the risk of collision or injury to vehicles behind, particularly motorcycles. Tesla will inspect the cars for free and perform a test to check the primer's adhesion. This is the second recall in China in two months, following a previous recall of nearly 30,000 imported cars due to suspension defects.

images.alt_text: US electric car maker Tesla is recalling 870 vehicles in China over defective roofs, part of which could fall off, China's market regulator said on Friday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HDT Singapore Holding scraps its electric-taxi business due to the debilitating impact of COVID-19. The government has decided not to provide a year-end annual variable component payment for civil servants this year. The service sector in Singapore collected more revenue in Q3 than Q2 but saw a 9.5% year-on-year drop. UOB and Vietnam's Foreign Investment Agency secured over S$3 billion in foreign direct investment. The COE supply is expected to drop 11% in Feb-April next year. Meanwhile, MYP completed the sale of ABI Plaza to a CapitaLand fund entity and Hong Leong Asia's shares surged 7.9% after a query from SGX.

site_title: Suspected North Korean hackers target Covid vaccine maker AstraZeneca: sources
summary: Suspected North Korean hackers have targeted AstraZeneca, a British drugmaker working on a Covid-19 vaccine, by posing as recruiters on LinkedIn and WhatsApp. They sent fake job offers with malicious code to gain access to staff computers. The hacking attempts targeted a broad set of people, including Covid-19 research staff, but are not thought to have been successful. AstraZeneca is racing to deploy its vaccine as the company works to secure its systems.

images.alt_text: Suspected North Korean hackers have tried to break into the systems of British drugmaker AstraZeneca in recent weeks, two people with knowledge of the matter told Reuters, as the company races to deploy its vaccine for the Covid-19 virus.

site_title: SPH to invest in digitalising media business, seek new recurring income
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) plans to further digitalize its media business to "rejuvenate, reinvent and reposition" its product offerings. The company, which publishes The Business Times, has seen a decline in print advertising and subscription revenue. In response, SPH will invest in digital initiatives, including enhanced news websites and apps, data analytics, and a new subscription e-shop. The company aims to increase recurring income from its property segment and grow its digital media business. Resolutions were passed at the annual general meeting, with shares trading flat.

site_title: Hot stock: Biolidics jumps 22.6% on news of Covid-19 test kit distribution
summary: Biolidics shares surged 22.6% on the Singapore bourse after the company announced plans to distribute Covid-19 test kits in Indonesia, Singapore, and the Philippines. The company received authorization to use its test kits in Indonesia and partnered with JOYSBIO to distribute its antigen rapid test kits. Biolidics expects the agreement to contribute positively to its revenue after FY2020 and plans to expand its sale and distribution of third-party medical and healthcare-related products.

site_title: Hard-won RCEP trade pact draws queue of potential new partners
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade pact, signed in November 2020, has drawn interest from several potential new partners, including Canada and Hong Kong. The pact's Trade Negotiating Committee will discuss criteria and processes for admitting new members, with questions surrounding whether new members need to have a free trade agreement (FTA) with Asean first. India, which withdrew from negotiations in 2019, is still welcome to rejoin at any time. The RCEP has been criticized for a lack of ambition, with some partners seeking more ambitious chapters, such as e-commerce, but others lacking domestic regulations.

images.alt_text: The RCEP team includes (from far left) Giselle Lee, RCEP services and movement of natural persons chapter, and policy officer; Regina Tan, RCEP e-commerce chapter; Sulaimah Mahmood, RCEP chief negotiator; Janice Cai, RCEP goods chapter; Faridah Mohd Saad, RCEP investment chapter; and Tay Lide (image on tablet), RCEP goods, services and investment chapters.

site_title: South Korea foils North Korea attempt to hack Covid-19 vaccine makers
summary: South Korea's intelligence agency foiled North Korean attempts to hack into companies developing coronavirus vaccines, according to lawmakers. The hacking attempts were part of a broader effort by Russian and North Korean hackers to breach the networks of pharmaceutical companies and vaccine researchers worldwide. Despite the attempts, no damage was caused. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has been taking "unreasonable" actions due to COVID-19 paranoia, including banning fishing and stranding rice shipments, lawmakers said. The incident highlights the ongoing cybersecurity threats posed by North Korea and its allies.

site_title: Three executives leave JLL's Hotels & Hospitality Group to start family office
summary: Three former JLL executives, David Marriott, Daniel Yip, and Giuliano Esposito, have left the company to start a family office in Singapore, High Street Holdings Singapore. The trio will focus on investing in hotels and real estate across the Asia-Pacific region. They departed JLL's Hotels & Hospitality Group after more than a decade, with Marriott and Esposito having spent over a decade and Yip around five years at the firm. The departure will not impact JLL's business strategy and operations. The family office aims to source, develop, and manage mid-market and institutional-grade assets.

site_title: Taiwan raises 2020 GDP forecast on better-than-expected exports
summary: Taiwan raised its 2020 GDP forecast to 2.54%, surpassing the initial 1.56% estimate, driven by strong international demand for technology products and exports. The island's overseas shipments grew 11.2% in October to a record high of $32.2 billion, boosted by the delayed launch of Apple's iPhone 12. The National Development Council's Monitoring Indicator, a forward-looking economic signal, reached its highest level since May 2018, indicating a strong economic rebound in Taiwan, despite forecasts of 3.82% GDP growth in 2021.

site_title: Opec+ calls last-minute talks to prepare for oil-cuts decision
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia summoned Opec+ ministers for last-minute talks ahead of a decision on January's oil output increase. Despite a clear majority expecting the group to maintain current production cuts, public complaints from Iraq and Nigeria, and private discord with the UAE, pose uncertainty. The talks come before a full Opec ministerial meeting on Nov 30 and Opec+ talks on Dec 1, with Algeria's energy minister warning the group must remain cautious amid the recent surge in oil prices. The 23-nation Opec+ coalition is set to ease 7.7 million barrels a day of production cuts from Jan 1.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia and Russia summoned Opec+ ministers who oversee their oil production cuts for last-minute talks on Saturday, as the cartel prepares for a decision on whether to delay January's output increase.

site_title: HDT scraps electric-taxi business in Singapore on 'debilitating' Covid-19 hit
summary: HDT Singapore Holding, an electric taxi operator in Singapore, has decided to shut down its taxi business due to the prolonged impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, affiliated with BYD Co., has laid off around 90 taxi drivers and four back-end staff, following consultations with the National Taxi Association. HDT will provide retrenchment benefits to affected staff, including a one-time payment and annual wage supplement. The company will focus on other green transportation solutions, such as car-hailing, electric-bus services, and EV leasing, with plans to promote the electrification of transportation in Singapore.

site_title: Argentina bids chaotic final farewell to favourite son Maradona
summary: Argentina held a grief-filled farewell ceremony for Diego Maradona, a 1986 World Cup winner and one of the greatest football players in history, who died on November 27, 2020, at 60. The public wake was chaotic, and the burial took place on the outskirts of Buenos Aires. Maradona had battled cocaine addiction for decades. The ceremony was attended by family and close friends in the Bella Vista cemetery, marking the end of a mourning process that sparked widespread tributes around the world.

images.alt_text: Huge crowds bade a grief-filled farewell to Argentina's favourite son Diego Maradona before the football legend was buried on the outskirts of Buenos Aires after a chaotic public wake.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for fourth straight week on vaccine hopes, exports outlook
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fourth straight week, driven by optimism over coronavirus vaccine development and an improving exports outlook. The Kospi index gained 0.29% to 2,633.45, with foreigners net buyers of 76.8 billion won. The benchmark bond yield fell, and the Korean won held steady against the US dollar. The positive sentiment is expected to continue, with focus on Korea's exports data and US economic indicators next week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the week higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week higher, extending a six-day winning streak, driven by vaccine optimism. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.28% to 26,894.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index rallied 1.14% to 3,408.31. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.34% to 2,253.12. This follows a strong week in Asia, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% on Thursday, and US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: LMIRT to hold virtual dialogue on proposed Jakarta mall acquisition
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) will conduct a virtual dialogue session on December 2 to discuss its proposed acquisition of Lippo Mall Puri in Jakarta. The session will be open to all, including non-unitholders, and will be facilitated by the Securities Investors Association Singapore. LMIRT's executive director James Liew will present on the planned acquisition and proposed rights issue. The trust had previously announced a S$281 million rights issue and a proposed loan facility of up to S$40 million to acquire the mall.

site_title: Malaysia inks pact with Pfizer to vaccinate 6.4 million citizens
summary: Malaysia signed agreements with Pfizer to vaccinate 6.4 million citizens, about 20% of the population, with Pfizer delivering 1 million doses in the first quarter of 2021. The vaccine will be available for free to locals, while foreigners will have to pay. Malaysia also signed an accord with the Covax facility to provide vaccines for 10% of the population. The government plans to conduct a phase-III trial in December, involving 3,000 participants, to assess the safety and efficacy of the vaccine.

images.alt_text: Malaysia signed an agreement with Pfizer to obtain its Covid-19 vaccine for 20 per cent of the population, or about 6.4 million people, according to the nation's Science, Technology and Innovation Minister Khairy Jamaluddin.

site_title: ECB signals bank dividend ban could be cautiously lifted in 2021
summary: European Central Bank policy makers are considering lifting the ban on bank dividend payments in 2021, with Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau suggesting a cautious approach. Executive Board member Fabio Panetta argued that banks should be prudent but a case-by-case approach could be reasonable. The ECB will make a decision within weeks, amid concerns about the economic outlook and the need for banks to maintain profitability. The move could benefit European banks, which have lobbied to scrap the restriction, but also risks cutting them off from investment.

site_title: Fists and pig guts fly in Taiwan as Parliament debates US pork imports
summary: Legislators from Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) party violently clashed with ruling party lawmakers in Parliament over easing US pork imports. The KMT opposed the decision, citing concerns over food safety, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supports the move, which aims to ease a roadblock to a US free trade deal. The violence escalated with KMT lawmakers throwing pig guts and punching other lawmakers, with Premier Su Tseng-chang withdrawing and later re-entering the session. The DPP condemned the protests as "disgusting" and called for rational debate.

site_title: Whiteley's 'Henri's Armchair' smashes Australian art auction record
summary: Brett Whiteley's painting 'Henri's Armchair' sold at auction for A$6.25 million, setting a new record in Australia and reflecting the appeal of art investments during the pandemic. The chaotic depiction of Sydney Harbour was last sold in the mid-1970s after the artist refused to paint over a matchbook suggesting drug use. The sale underscores the importance of Whiteley's "Lavender Bay" period, when he was perfecting his craft on the harbour. The buyer remains unidentified, and the sale confirms the value of Whiteley's work from this period.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for four straight days
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a fourth consecutive day, despite rising coronavirus cases in Japan. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.40% to 26,644.71, while the Topix index advanced 0.47%.
