The gains came despite no fresh leads from Wall Street, which was closed for a holiday. The rally continues despite global market uncertainty, including US-EU trade talks and rising tariffs.

site_title: Bitcoin steadies after biggest slump since March's meltdown
summary: Bitcoin prices steadied on Friday after a 14% decline, reaching above US$17,400. The slump was attributed to fears of tighter crypto regulations and profit-taking after a recent rally. Despite this, proponents argue that growing institutional interest and a broader investor base could sustain the boom. Bitcoin's year-to-date gain of 140% has split opinion, with some seeing it as a durable trend and others predicting an inevitable reckoning.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent pause talks to buy stake in streaming service iQiyi: sources
summary: Alibaba and Tencent have paused talks to buy a stake in video streaming service iQiyi due to a valuation of around $20 billion demanded by Baidu, and heightened scrutiny by China's antitrust regulators. The companies are also concerned about the financial struggles of cash-burning iQiyi, which has lost nearly a fifth of its value in the last two weeks. Another Chinese tech giant, ByteDance, has also explored acquiring iQiyi, but Baidu's feud with ByteDance makes this unlikely. iQiyi plans to raise at least $1 billion in the coming months, potentially through a share offering or convertible bond.

site_title: ECB's Villeroy says debt cancellation would be a dangerous path
summary: European Central Bank policy maker Francois Villeroy de Galhau has rejected the idea of debt cancellation, stating it would be a "very dangerous path" that could backfire. Villeroy, the Bank of France governor, emphasized the importance of honoring Treaty commitments to repay the central bank. This comes after Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte's adviser suggested the ECB could cancel or hold onto sovereign bonds bought during the pandemic to aid the eurozone recovery.

site_title: COE supply expected to drop 11% in Feb-April next year
summary: Singapore-based online car marketplace sgCarMart predicts an 11% drop in certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the February to April 2021 quota period, with 610 COEs estimated for the open category per month, down 34% from 926. This is based on the Land Transport Authority's passenger car lower deregistration numbers in October, which fell by 2%. COE premiums are expected to continue their upward trend, with prices increasing for most dealers, particularly for brands like Honda, Renault, and Volkswagen.

site_title: SGX queries Hong Leong Asia on rising stock price; shares climb 7.9%
summary: Hong Leong Asia's shares surged 7.9% to S$0.68, drawing a query from SGX over "unusual price movements". Despite no large transactions, the company's stock price rose due to "married deals" of smaller trades. The unusual price movements have raised concerns about potential insider trading or market manipulation.

site_title: Japan's ANA to raise US$3.2b in shares to weather pandemic, pay for planes
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings plans to raise $4.2 billion in new shares to pay for Boeing 787 jets and weather the pandemic slump. The airline is cutting costs by asking staff to take furloughs or accept pay cuts, with the Japanese government also providing a landing fee waiver. This move aims to help ANA cope with the significant decline in air travel caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Amazon to give US$500m in holiday bonuses to front-line US workers
summary: Amazon is giving US$500 million in holiday bonuses to its front-line US workers, including full-time and part-time employees, to recognize their efforts during the Covid-19 pandemic. Full-time employees will receive a US$300 bonus, while part-time workers will get US$150. This is part of Amazon's ongoing efforts to support its staff amid intense scrutiny from US lawmakers and unions. The company has previously spent US$500 million on one-time bonuses in June.

site_title: Vickers Venture Partners leads US$13.2m Series B round in UK biopharma startup
summary: Vickers Venture Partners led a US$13.2 million Series B funding round for UK biopharma startup SiSaf, matched by the UK government's Future Fund. The funds will accelerate SiSaf's RNA therapeutic programmes for rare genetic conditions and expand its pipeline. The startup's Bio-Courier technology aims to deliver siRNA, a promising treatment for diseases, by overcoming delivery challenges. With the funding, SiSaf plans to bring safe and effective treatments to patients with limited options, according to founder Suzanne Saffie-Siebert.

site_title: Unilever single-minded about challenges ahead as dual-headed era ends
summary: Unilever's dual-headed structure is ending, with the Dutch and British corporate arms merging into one entity based in London. The move aims to improve the company's flexibility, reduce complexity, and enhance corporate governance. The change is not expected to impact day-to-day operations, but will bring benefits in acquiring and exiting businesses. This comes amid a challenging macroeconomic environment, including a pandemic-fuelled recession and looming Brexit. The merger marks the end of 90 years as a hybrid company.

site_title: Blackstone, Carlyle, others line up initial bids for Fancl Asia business: sources
summary: More than 10 private equity firms, including Blackstone and Carlyle, have submitted initial bids for Fancl's Asia business, valued at around $1 billion. Bain Capital, MBK Partners, Sequoia Capital, and Citic Capital are also bidders, with Chinese online retailer JD.com joining the list. Some firms are looking to team up with strategic partners, with Alibaba and Tencent Holdings reportedly interested in joining a bidding group. A shortlist is expected by the end of next week, with binding bids due by January. The strong interest indicates confidence in Asia's consumption recovery, particularly in China.

site_title: Singapore's service sector collects more revenue in Q3 than Q2, but receipts drop 9.5% yoy
summary: Singapore's service sector collected 9.5% less revenue in Q3 2020 compared to the same period last year, despite a quarterly improvement from Q2. The sector's performance was affected by the "circuit-breaker" period and the Covid-19 pandemic, with industries like recreation and personal services experiencing a 41.3% drop in revenue. However, information and communications services showed growth, with a 3.5% year-on-year increase, driven by demand for software and information services.

site_title: Tokyo: Key Nikkei index opens flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened flat on Friday, weighing on the market due to a rise in new coronavirus cases in Japan. The benchmark index fell 0.01% or 2.90 points at 26,534.41, while the Topix index rose 0.22% or 3.84 points at 1,782.09. This comes despite a mixed US close and no fresh leads from the market.

site_title: Senegal's coronavirus success divides experts
summary: Senegal's coronavirus response has been widely praised, with the country reporting fewer than 16,000 cases and 331 deaths despite lifting anti-virus measures. Experts attribute this to herd immunity, suggesting that a substantial part of the population has already acquired immunity, estimated at around 60%. However, the World Health Organization and some health experts caution against an overly optimistic interpretation, warning of a potential second wave of infections. The government continues to urge vigilance, working under the "pessimistic hypothesis" that the situation could deteriorate.

site_title: Europe: Shares move little as focus turns to economic damage from Covid-19
summary: European shares ended little changed, with the Stoxx 600 index down 0.1%, as the focus shifted to the economic damage caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Germany, France, and the UK imposed tougher restrictions, including closing restaurants and gyms, amid rising coronavirus infections and deaths. Despite a grim UK growth forecast, European equities are still on track for their best month on record, with promising vaccine trial results expected to boost markets next year.

site_title: Australia to 'vigorously defend' wine industry from China tariffs: minister
summary: Australia's agriculture minister vows to "vigorously defend" the country's multi-billion-dollar wine industry from new Chinese tariffs, which could lead to World Trade Organisation (WTO) counter-measures. The tariffs, announced by Beijing, require wine importers to pay deposits of 107.1-212.1% due to "substantive harm" caused by allegedly mispriced Australian products. Australia has 10 days to appeal and may seek WTO help, which could allow the country to impose countervailing duties on Chinese goods if found unfair.

site_title: Tokyo's core consumer prices post biggest annual drop in over 8 years
summary: Tokyo's core consumer prices fell 0.7% in November, marking the largest annual drop in over 8 years. This decline, following a 0.5% drop in October, suggests inflation will remain distant from the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The data, a leading indicator of nationwide price trends, reinforces market expectations of deflationary pressure on the economy due to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Biker dog Bogie thrills fans as he cruises Philippine highways
summary: Bogie, an 11-year-old crossbreed dog, has become a neighborhood celebrity in the Philippines for his daily motorcycle rides with his owner Gilbert Delos Reyes. Bogie, who learned to ride a motorcycle at four months old, has become a magnet for attention and has even helped Reyes' motorcycle shop attract customers. As a guard dog, Bogie has proven himself useful by chasing away thieves. Reyes considers Bogie a lucky charm and a part of his life, saying he couldn't replace him after 11 years together.

site_title: Gold set for third weekly decline as vaccine optimism weighs
summary: Gold prices are set for a third weekly decline, falling 0.2% to US$1,807.86 per ounce, amid growing optimism over a coronavirus vaccine, driving investors into riskier assets. Asian shares stalled near record highs as AstraZeneca faces questions about its vaccine's success rate. Investors are shifting focus to the economic recovery in 2021, driving gold sales. Silver fell 1% to US$23.21 per ounce, while platinum dropped 0.7% to US$954.93.

site_title: EU considering stopgap measure for UK financial services post Brexit, says diplomat
summary: The European Union is considering a stopgap measure to grant market access to UK financial services after Brexit, as assessments by the European Commission are not completed in time for January. Britain's access to the EU under transition arrangements ends on December 31, affecting the City of London's exports. The EU's direct financial market access system, known as equivalence, will be evaluated, and a stopgap measure may be implemented to maintain access. This move aims to mitigate the impact of Brexit on UK financial services.

site_title: Sales bookings to start on Saturday at The Landmark; about 120 units for Phase 1 launch
summary: Sales bookings for The Landmark condominium in Singapore will begin on Saturday, with an initial batch of about 120 units available in the 396-unit project. The average price is expected to range between S$2,000 and S$2,300 per square foot, with indicative prices starting from around S$970,000 for a one-bedroom unit. The project's breakeven cost is estimated at about S$2,000 psf, making it "priced to sell," according to Savills Singapore executive director Alan Cheong.

site_title: Asia: Markets ease back as investors take breath after rally
summary: Asian markets eased on Friday after a month-long rally fueled by vaccine optimism and easing US political uncertainty. Despite hopes for a post-pandemic recovery, a surge in virus infections in the US and Europe, and concerns over a further acceleration, investors took a cautious approach. Markets in Hong Kong, Singapore, and other countries fell, while Sydney dropped 0.7% due to tensions with China. AstraZeneca's vaccine also raised concerns over its effectiveness.

site_title: Scotland's Sturgeon wants independence referendum as soon as 2021: The Times
summary: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced plans to hold a second independence referendum as soon as 2021, with the potential vote taking place in the "earlier part" of the next Scottish Parliament. Sturgeon stated that Scotland should have the opportunity to choose independence in the earlier part of the next Parliament, rather than the later part. This move comes after the Scottish National Party leader expressed her desire for a second referendum in the past. The decision is seen as a significant development in the ongoing debate over Scotland's independence from the UK.

site_title: Battered by virus and oil slump, biofuels fall out of favour
summary: Biofuel demand has declined 11.6% in 2020, the first fall in 20 years, due to the coronavirus pandemic and sharp drop in oil prices. The production of biofuels for transport is expected to continue struggling to recover. Despite environmental benefits, biofuels face challenges, including reliance on politicians for policy support and competition from electric cars and hydrogen engines. Industry experts suggest focusing on aviation as a key sector for sustainable biofuels.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.12 points, or 0.38%, to 1,618.23. The index saw 269 gainers compared to 85 losers, with a total trading volume of 399.23 million lots worth RM148.55 million.

site_title: China imposes anti-dumping measures on Australian wine
summary: China has imposed anti-dumping measures on Australian wine, requiring importers to pay deposits of 107.1% to 212.1% starting Saturday. This move escalates tensions between China and Australia, following China's economic retaliation over Canberra's call for a Covid-19 inquiry. The measure affects wine exports worth A$1.3 billion to China last year, with shares in Treasury Wine Estates Limited plummeting over 11%. China's commerce ministry cited "substantive harm" to the domestic wine industry as the reason for the measure.

site_title: China's industrial profits rise 28.2% y-o-y in October
summary: China's industrial profits surged 28.2% year-over-year in October, marking a sixth consecutive month of growth. The January-October period saw a 0.7% annual increase in profits, following a 2.4% decline in the first nine months of 2020. The data suggests a steady recovery in the manufacturing sector, driven by resilient demand for exports. Premier Li Keqiang expects Chinese economic activity to return to a reasonable range next year.

site_title: Trump says coronavirus vaccine deliveries to begin next week
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that deliveries of the coronavirus vaccine would begin next week and the week after, initially targeting front-line workers, medical personnel, and senior citizens.

site_title: Robinsons creditors appoint KordaMentha as liquidators
summary: Robinsons, a 162-year-old Singapore department store operator, has appointed KordaMentha as liquidators following an online creditors' meeting. The majority of 442 creditors, owed S$31.7 million, approved resolutions including the appointment of a committee of inspection and the liquidators' ability to distribute recovered funds to creditors between April and June next year. Robinsons' assets total S$26.1 million, with liabilities of S$203.7 million, resulting in a net deficit of S$161.1 million. The company's final closing-down sale will feature hundreds of international brand offers.

site_title: Huawei founder urges Honor subbrand to become competitor after split
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei urged Honor employees to surpass their parent company after the budget brand was sold to a new entity to maintain Huawei's supply chains. The sale comes after the US government imposed sanctions on Huawei, claiming it's a national security threat. Ren called on Honor to become Huawei's biggest competitor, saying toppling Huawei should be a motivation for employees. The move aims to retain market share and overcome difficulties caused by the sanctions.

site_title: VW's ID.3 quickly climbs to top of Europe's electric-car market
summary: Volkswagen's ID.3 electric hatchback surpassed Renault's Zoe subcompact in Europe's electric car sales charts, selling 10,475 units in October. This marks a significant rise, beating Tesla's Model 3 sales by about 700 units. The trend is expected to continue as battery prices decrease, with analysts attributing the ID.3's success to its relatively affordable price. The ID.4 crossover, set to be released, is predicted to further boost VW's electric vehicle sales, potentially challenging Tesla's market lead.

site_title: ICP eyes 5% stake in proposed 10.65b yen Osaka hotel deal
summary: ICP Ltd is set to acquire a 5% stake in the b Osaka Midosuji Hotel in Japan for approximately 532.5 million yen (S$6.9 million). The 306-room hotel will be managed by ICP's subsidiary Travelodge Hotels (Asia) after the deal is completed, allowing the brand to establish its presence in Japan and diversify its operations. The total acquisition cost will be 543.3 million yen, funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with the remaining 95% stake held by Plenitude Osaka.

site_title: Evergrande's spinoff no windfall for chairman Hui's poker pals
summary: China Evergrande Group's spinoff, Evergrande Property Services Group, raised HK$14.3 billion in a Hong Kong IPO, but for chairman Hui Ka Yan's allies, it was a modest success. The sale priced in the lower half of its marketed range, with retail investors showing little interest, and pre-listing investors making only about 5% on their investment. The spinoff is part of Evergrande's efforts to pare down its $120 billion debt pile amid government oversight.

site_title: ThaiBev cautious about recovery, stays competitive with wider offerings
summary: ThaiBev reports a 2% dip in net profit to 22.75 billion baht for the full year ended Sept 30, 2020, due to ongoing pandemic impact. The company's spirits business remains resilient through off-trade channels, but sales from beer, NAB, and food segments continue to suffer. Despite caution about future sales, ThaiBev stays competitive with wider offerings to maintain its market position.

site_title: Thai Oct factory output falls 0.54%, less than forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) fell 0.54% in October, lower than forecast, due to decreased production of cars and clothes amid the coronavirus pandemic. The capacity utilization rate was 63.2% in October, down from 63.46% in September. The industry ministry now forecasts an 8% decline in MPI this year, with a 4-5% rise expected next year. Industrial goods account for 80% of Thailand's total exports, a key driver of the country's growth.

site_title: Australia: Vaccine optimism sets shares for best month on record
summary: Australian shares are on track for their best month on record due to optimism over Covid-19 vaccines and Joe Biden's transition to the White House. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.2% on Friday, but is still up for its fourth straight weekly gain. Despite a rise in global coronavirus cases, the benchmark is supported by easing lockdowns and a positive vaccine outlook. Energy and mining stocks are set for a fourth straight weekly gain, while healthcare stocks fell 0.7% due to concerns over the efficacy of AstraZeneca's vaccine.

site_title: Brexit Britain's food supply is imperiled by Christmas and Covid
summary: Brexit Britain is facing a food supply crisis due to the end of the EU's single market, with Christmas demand and the pandemic putting pressure on warehouse space. Manufacturers such as Unilever and Nestle are warning of potential shortages of key food products, prioritizing stock building and maintaining supply over production. With just five weeks to go before the UK leaves the EU, the food supply chain is at its peak capacity, making it vulnerable to further shocks, according to industry groups. A trade deal between Britain and the EU remains deadlocked, exacerbating the issue.

site_title: Japan's ruling party to propose big spending on green investment: draft
summary: Japan's ruling party is set to propose a decade-long spending program to promote green investment, aligning with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050. The plan includes creating a fund comparable to global standards to support high-risk green technology investments, as well as deregulation and tax breaks to promote green investment. The proposal also aims to expand electric vehicles, battery development, and state-backed loan schemes to support firms affected by the pandemic.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no relevant information about a "smart car buying guide" in the provided articles. However, key events include Tesla's formal entry into India, the expansion of its robotaxi services, and the launch of robot delivery systems by FedEx and Nissan's potential record-high bond sale.

site_title: Mitsui Fudosan offers US$1.2b to acquire Tokyo Dome
summary: Mitsui Fudosan has made a US$1.2 billion bid to acquire Tokyo Dome, the operator of the Japanese baseball stadium. The Japanese real estate company plans a tender offer of 1,300 yen (S$16.7) a share, with Yomiuri Shimbun seeking a 20% stake after the deal. Tokyo Dome has supported the offer, following pressure from activist investor Oasis Management, which has called for changes to improve the stadium's business. Shareholders are set to meet on December 17 to vote on the proposed changes.

site_title: Billionaire Ray Dalio set to open family office in Singapore
summary: Billionaire Ray Dalio is opening a family office in Singapore to manage his investments and philanthropy in the region. Dalio, with a net worth of over $15 billion, has long held ties to Asia and Singapore, and has had excellent relationships in both countries. The office, led by CEO Janine Racanelli and COO Tom Waller, will focus on personal investments, philanthropy, and trust structures. This move follows a trend of other wealthy business leaders, including James Dyson and Shu Ping, opening family offices in Singapore to tap into the city-state's tax incentives and access to the Chinese market.

site_title: Halcyon Agri Q3 revenue recovers from Q2 on improved rubber demand
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp reported a 11% increase in Q3 revenue to US$396.4 million, driven by improved rubber demand and higher sales volume of 296,184 tonnes. Despite a 22.7% year-on-year decline, the company's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) reversed to US$10.9 million, a 4.5 times increase from the previous year. The company's CEO, Li Xuetao, expressed confidence in the company's ability to scale up operations and capitalize on post-pandemic opportunities.

site_title: Dyson to invest £2.75b in Singapore, Philippines and UK
summary: Dyson plans to invest £2.75 billion over five years in Singapore, the Philippines, and the UK, expanding its research and development, hiring more engineers and scientists, and commercializing its solid-state battery technology. The company will establish new research programs, facilities, and manufacturing hubs in these countries, aiming to double its product portfolio and take its scope of business beyond the home. This investment is expected to drive performance and sustainability in its products, benefiting customers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Far East Orchard, Jumbo, Biolidics, SPH
summary: Keppel Corp's subsidiary won a $100 million contract, causing its shares to fall 0.2% to $5.23. Far East Orchard acquired a $70.5 million UK property, resulting in a 0.9% decline to $1.05. Other stocks to watch include Jumbo, Biolidics, and SPH, but no specific developments were mentioned for these companies.

site_title: Oil rally stalls on signs of more supply, demand doubts
summary: Oil prices stalled at seven-month highs due to growing supply concerns, halting a rally driven by optimism over Covid-19 vaccine-driven fuel demand. Brent futures rose to nearly $50 a barrel before slipping 74 cents, or 1.5%, to $47.87 a barrel. The decline followed reports of increasing oil supplies and doubts over vaccine effectiveness. Despite a 1.6% gain in the previous session, oil prices remained volatile amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Former Berlin airport gets new life as vaccination centre
summary: Germany is transforming its former Berlin airport, Tegel, into a vaccination centre, with Terminal C set to open as a hub for COVID-19 vaccinations in mid-December. The facility will vaccinate 3,000 to 4,000 people daily, with 200-250 staff members per centre. The country aims to ramp up its immunisation drive, with 60 hubs planned across Germany, and Chancellor Angela Merkel sees vaccines as a "light at the end of the tunnel." Strict rules, including mask-wearing and social distancing, will be enforced to prevent infection spread.

site_title: Britain to curb Google and Facebook with tougher competition rules
summary: Britain is set to introduce a new competition regime in 2022 to curb the dominance of Google and Facebook, which account for 80% of £14 billion in digital advertising. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will enforce the code, aiming to prevent tech giants from pushing out smaller firms and disadvantaging consumers. This move follows the CMA's recognition that new laws are needed to keep Google and Facebook in check. The new regime will be enforced by a dedicated unit within the CMA.

site_title: Hong Kong, Singapore office Reits live on in post-virus world
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong office Reits are outperforming their peers in Australia and Japan, driven by the cities' relatively controlled virus spread, small living spaces, and increasing demand from tech firms. Despite some companies giving up office space due to remote work, Reits in these cities have beaten benchmarks, with attractive dividend yields and relatively cheap prices. Analysts expect Singapore's Keppel Reit and Mapletree Commercial Trust to yield 5.4% and 4.1%, respectively, in 2021, outperforming Japanese Reits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin slightly lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading slightly lower on Friday, easing 0.23% to 26,758.49, following five days of gains. Despite this, traders remain optimistic about a potential vaccine rollout within weeks, supporting the market. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up.

site_title: America celebrates scaled-back Thanksgiving as Covid-19 surges
summary: The US celebrated a scaled-back Thanksgiving Day due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with many families gathering virtually or mourning loved ones lost to the disease. The Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York was significantly reduced, with only a one-block route and no spectators. Despite concerns about a potential spike in cases, nearly 6 million Americans traveled by air for the holiday, with many planning to attend "risky gatherings" or connect with loved ones over video calls. The holiday coincides with severe economic strain for millions of Americans, with over 20 million receiving unemployment benefits.

site_title: MYP completes sale of ABI Plaza to CapitaLand fund entity
summary: MYP has completed the sale of ABI Plaza in Tanjong Pagar to a CapitaLand fund entity, Artemis Ventures, for S$200 million. The sale was initially put on the market with a guide price of above S$280 million, but was ultimately finalized at the lower price after a few parties made submissions below S$200 million. MYP sought a waiver from the Singapore Exchange to avoid prior shareholders' approval due to the sale being time-sensitive, and will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder ratification within three months.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Friday's open; STI falls 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks slipped at the open on Friday, falling 0.3% to 2,850.27, as a public holiday in the US and an unexpected 0.9% year-on-year decline in factory output weighed on sentiment. Local stocks took a hit on Thursday, with banking stocks mostly down in early trade. Biolidics rose 17.7% after receiving approval to distribute Covid-19 antibody test kits in Indonesia, while medtech firm JOYSBIO's test kits were also announced. European shares closed little changed, and Asian markets, including Tokyo, opened flat.

site_title: Jumbo to buy 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle; posts full-year S$8.2m loss
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, plans to acquire a 75% stake in Kok Kee Wanton Noodle for S$2.1 million in cash and shares. The acquisition will be Jumbo's first inorganic expansion since listing in 2015, and aims to expand Kok Kee's network locally and introduce its "heritage local dish" to geographies beyond Singapore. The deal comes as Jumbo reported a full-year net loss of S$8.2 million, reversing from a net profit in the previous year, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Sabana Reit's proposed merger with ESR-Reit
summary: Sabana Reit has proposed a merger with ESR-Reit, a Singaporean real estate investment trust (REIT). The proposed deal aims to create a leading player in the Asia-Pacific region. The terms of the merger were not disclosed. No further information is available on the proposed merger, and no conclusion has been reached on its outcome.

site_title: Venezuela resumes direct oil shipments to China despite US sanctions
summary: Venezuela has resumed direct oil shipments to China after a nearly two-year hiatus due to US sanctions. The shipments were resumed despite the Trump administration's efforts to oust President Nicolas Maduro. The sanctions, imposed in August 2019, failed to completely halt Venezuela's oil exports. China's state-owned companies, CNPC and PetroChina, have resumed loading crude and fuel at Venezuelan ports. The move suggests China's continued interest in Venezuelan oil, despite US efforts to isolate the country.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds rate, upgrades growth outlook
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) maintained its interest rate at 0.5% and upgraded its growth forecasts, predicting a 1.1% contraction this year and a 3% growth next year. Despite tightening social distancing rules due to rising coronavirus cases, the BOK believes the economy's recovery trajectory remains intact. The decision comes as South Korea's recovery faces headwinds from worsening outbreaks in major economies and a strong won, which threatens to undermine a rebound in Korean exports.

site_title: Foreigners still needed in clean energy manual roles
summary: Despite a shift towards renewable energy, Singapore's reliance on foreign workers for low-wage, manual roles in the clean energy sector is unlikely to change in the near term. According to industry experts, 50-60% of workers in the process sector are work permit holders, filling roles such as construction and maintenance of specialized equipment and machinery. Experts expect a reliance on foreign manpower for lower-paid, manual tasks to continue for the medium term, likely 5-10 years, as locals tend to focus on higher-paying roles in engineering and finance.

site_title: Biolidics inks deal to distribute Chinese biotech's Covid-19 test kits
summary: Biolidics has entered into a non-exclusive one-year agreement to distribute JOYSBIO's Covid-19 test kits worldwide, starting from November 26. JOYSBIO's test kit, known as the "SARS-CoV-2 antigen rapid test kit (colloidal gold)", will be made available through Biolidics. The partnership aims to increase global access to the test kit, helping to combat the spread of Covid-19.

site_title: Premier League clubs given green light for return of fans
summary: Premier League clubs in tier-two areas, including Liverpool, Chelsea, Brighton, and West Ham, are allowed to welcome up to 2,000 fans into their stadiums starting next month under a new system to combat coronavirus in England. However, Manchester United, Manchester City, and Leeds United are categorized in tier three and will not be permitted to have fans due to higher infection rates. This tier system aims to balance fan attendance with public health concerns.

site_title: Singapore October industrial output falls 0.9%
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 0.9% year-on-year in October, contrary to economists' expectations of a 7.3% growth. The decline was mainly due to a drop in electronics output and poorer biomedical performance. However, economists view this as a "blip" rather than a change in trend, citing a strong Purchasing Managers' Index and a relatively high year-ago base. The electronics cluster's decline is attributed to a possible stockpiling of chips ahead of US sanctions on Huawei, with some economists predicting a temporary disruption.

site_title: SPH Reit to focus on 'providing sustainable rental income'
summary: SPH Reit has shifted its focus to providing sustainable rental income by minimizing vacancies for FY2021. The Reit manager aims to support tenants through the challenging Covid-19 period and position assets for recovery. Rental relief totaling S$39.9 million has been granted to tenants, and the Reit's portfolio has maintained its occupancy rate at 97.7%. A multi-pronged growth strategy includes optimizing tenant mix, asset enhancements, and proactive marketing plans to provide unit holders with regular, stable distributions.

site_title: AstraZeneca says its vaccine needs 'additional study'
summary: AstraZeneca, the manufacturer of a Covid-19 vaccine, is seeking additional study on its vaccine's effectiveness after questions emerged over its 70% protection rate. The vaccine showed a 90% effectiveness rate when a half-dose and full dose were given, similar to rival vaccines. This additional testing is unlikely to affect regulatory approval in Europe, according to the company.

site_title: Trump says he will leave the White House if Electoral College votes for Biden
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he will leave the White House if the Electoral College votes for President-elect Joe Biden. Trump made the comments during a Thanksgiving Day address to US troops, following the Electoral College's scheduled meeting on December 14. Trump has refused to concede the election, claiming widespread fraud despite Biden winning 306 electoral votes to Trump's 232, and a 6 million-vote lead in the popular tally. Trump's comments mark a concession, but his refusal to accept the election outcome remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday he will leave the White House if the Electoral College votes for Democratic President-elect Joe Biden.

site_title: Clean energy pivot will yield green jobs, but time needed to fill them
summary: Singapore's oil and gas industry is shifting towards cleaner energy, with major companies like Shell and Chevron cutting jobs and investing in employee training and new assets. However, this transition may take time, and the workforce will need to adapt to new skill sets. Industry players expect more job cuts, but also note that renewable energy jobs are becoming more attractive, with companies like Sembcorp Solar and Engie investing in local talent and offering better wages. The mismatch between available roles and labor will need to be ironed out, but experts say the transition is necessary for Singapore's economic future.

site_title: France, Singapore adopt roadmap to deeper AI cooperation
summary: France and Singapore have adopted a roadmap to deepen their cooperation in artificial intelligence (AI), covering research, development, and governance. The bilateral partnership aims to drive AI deployment in sectors such as health, transport, and education. The two countries will jointly develop ambitious projects, focusing on four research fields: data, verifiable AI, natural language processing, and human-machine interaction. The partnership also involves the business community, with companies encouraged to adopt a model framework for AI applications and institutions contributing to discussions on ethics and governance.

site_title: Meng's defence levels new allegations of Canada police 'cover up'
summary: Meng Wanzhou's defence lawyers have made new allegations of a "cover up" by Royal Canadian Mounted Police Sergeant Janice Vander Graaf, who oversaw Meng's arresting officers. The defence claims Vander Graaf's subordinate officer, Constable Gurvinder Dhaliwal, told her that the RCMP had shared Meng's electronic device information with the US Federal Bureau of Investigation. However, Dhaliwal denies making this statement, and Sergeant Ben Chang has refused to testify, denying the allegation.

site_title: Festive feasting
summary: Several hotels in Singapore are offering festive takeaways and dining options for the holiday season. Sheraton Towers Singapore features a range of Asian-inspired dishes, including a Masak Merah Roasted Turkey and a Lavender Honey-Glazed Semi Bone-In Gammon Ham. The Fullerton Hotel Singapore and Fullerton Bay Hotel Singapore offer traditional and local-inspired Christmas meals, including a Roasted Turkey Sapit and a Honey-Glazed Champagne Ham. Pan Pacific Singapore features festive goodies, gift hampers, and luxurious dining experiences, including a Lifestyle Christmas Bundle and an extensive a la carte buffet at Edge.

site_title: Lauder as leader
summary: Leonard A. Lauder, the former CEO of Estee Lauder Companies, has released his autobiography "The Company I Keep." The book chronicles his journey from his mother's modest skincare brand to a global empire, with annual revenue exceeding $14 billion. Lauder joined his mother's company in 1958, and over the years, he expanded the brand through strategic launches, including Aramis, Clinique, and Origins. Lauder's approach to business is characterized by his love of taking counter-intuitive routes to resolve problems, as seen in his decision to release his memoir on the same day as Barack Obama's "A Promised Land."

site_title: Outcry grows in France after police filmed beating music producer
summary: A video of French police beating a black music producer, Michel, in Paris has sparked outrage and condemnation, leading to the suspension of several officers and a public backlash. The incident occurred after Michel entered his studio, where he was repeatedly subjected to racist abuse, before being beaten by police for five minutes. Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin has vowed to press for the dismissal of the officers, while politicians and footballers, including Kylian Mbappe, have denounced the violence. The incident has raised concerns over police methods and new legislation proposed by the government that would restrict the right to film and publish images of police on duty.

site_title: Fugging hell: Tired of mockery, Austrian village changes name
summary: Austrian village Fugging, known for its signposts that have been the subject of ridicule on social media, will change its name to Fugging starting January 1, 2021. The village, home to about 100 residents, had grown tired of the constant jokes and theft of signposts. The decision was made after a majority of villagers voted to rename the village, citing a desire for an end to the media frenzy. The village's name dates back to the 11th century, and it had previously gained attention for its appearance in a book and film.

site_title: OUE C-Reit confirms talks with Allianz entity for OUE Bayfront deal
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) confirmed talks with an Allianz entity for a potential deal to buy a partial stake in its Grade A office asset OUE Bayfront. The deal, valued at approximately S$1.28 billion, would price the asset at S$3,200 per square foot. Negotiations are ongoing, and no binding agreement has been reached. OUE C-Reit's manager advised unitholders and investors to exercise caution, and the trust will make an announcement if any material developments occur.

site_title: Debunking some bribery myths
summary: A study analyzing 195 documented bribery incidents across 60 countries over 40 years found that bribery can indeed pay, with each additional $1 in bribes achieving a $6 to $9 increase in the value of the firm. However, the benefits of bribery are significantly reduced in countries with public disclosure of politicians' sources of income, which limits the ability of officials to hide bribes. This effect is only seen in democratic countries, not autocratic ones, where officials are not concerned with securing votes. The study rejects the common perception that bribing higher-ranking officials leads to greater rewards, and highlights the need for further research into the mechanisms of bribery.

site_title: Ex-classmates team up to build company powered by smart technology
summary: A group of entrepreneurs, including co-founder Gary Kwang, have teamed up to build SkyLab, a data courier company powered by smart technology. The idea was sparked by a 2015 dinner meeting with the management team of Sunseap Group, which needed a way to deliver data from its solar panels to a central source. Within a year, SkyLab was incorporated and developed an IoT solution to package and deliver data quickly and securely. With the advent of 5G technology, SkyLab is poised to capitalize on the growing demand for sophisticated data management systems, with revenue expected to double year-over-year.

site_title: Charting the way forward for Putien
summary: Fong Chak Ka, vice-president of Putien restaurants, shares the story of his family's food business. Born in Fujian, China, and immigrating to Singapore in 2000, Fong joined Putien at 21 as an assistant to the head of operations and later became vice-president in 2018. Under his father's open-minded leadership, Putien has expanded globally with over 70 outlets, known for its Fujian Lor Mee and Sweet & Sour Pork. The company has adapted to the Covid-19 pandemic, with outlet managers taking ownership of their restaurants. Fong plans to expand internationally and launch a new dining concept, Yum Sing!, to celebrate Singapore food culture.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia to sell 58m shares at S$0.93 each in mainboard flotation
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) has lodged its final prospectus for an initial share offering, raising S$53.9 million through the sale of 58 million shares at S$0.93 each. The net proceeds will be used for strategic investments, regional expansion, and acquisitions, with a theoretical market cap of S$214.3 million upon listing. CBA's cornerstone investors include asset managers Aberdeen Standard Investments and Eastspring Investments. The company's executive chairman, Kevin Koo, believes an IPO is the "dream" for the company, citing its long history, strong database, and robust systems.

site_title: SPH plans to increase recurring income from property segments
summary: SPH plans to increase recurring income from its property segments, including retail and student accommodation businesses, to complement growth in aged care and digital media. This strategy aims to boost overall income. The move was announced ahead of the company's annual general meeting.

site_title: US new home sales dip in Oct; Sept figures revised higher
summary: US new home sales decreased 0.3% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 999,000 units, but remained higher than expected amid low mortgage rates and demand for space. Sales surged 41.5% year-on-year. The pandemic has led to a shift from city centers to suburbs, with new home sales increasing in the Northeast and Midwest, but decreasing in the South. The median new house price rose 2.5% to $330,600, and it would take 3.3 months to clear the supply of houses on the market.

site_title: Lendlease targets absolute-zero carbon emissions by 2040
summary: Lendlease, a Sydney-based property and infrastructure group, has set new sustainability goals. The company aims to become a 1.5 degrees Celsius-aligned company by 2025, with net-zero carbon emissions by 2025 and absolute-zero carbon emissions by 2040. To achieve this, Lendlease will take five key steps, including creating A$250 million of social value by 2025. The company has also ranked top in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark rankings in the Asia Retail category. Lendlease's commitment to sustainability aligns with its role as a signatory to the United Nations Global Compact.

site_title: Fitness players still reeling from body blow
summary: Fitness players are struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic shutdowns, with many gyms and studios operating at half-capacity or closing due to social distancing measures. Online classes are a temporary solution, and the road to recovery is expected to be long. Meanwhile, vaccines are being distributed, and the insurance industry is being reevaluated, with some questioning whether to prune insurance payments during tough times.

site_title: CDL venture Sincere sees recovery in sales at Chengdu project
summary: CDL venture Sincere sees a strong recovery in sales at its TianFengHe Mansion project in Chengdu, China, with 430 units sold out of 540 launched units, generating 150 million yuan (S$30.6 million) in sales. This marks an 8.7% increase in average selling price to 13,700 yuan per square meter compared to March 2020. Sincere Property also secured a bid to operate over 100,000 sq m of retail space in the Kunming Transportation Hub.

site_title: Will cryptocurrencies endure?
summary: Cryptocurrency prices plummeted on Thursday, with Bitcoin sliding 8.7% and the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index falling over 6%. Experts predict a correction, citing overbought conditions. Despite the retreat, Bitcoin has more than doubled this year and is near a record high. Crypto believers attribute the boom to retail and institutional investments, as well as a search for dollar hedging during the pandemic. The downturn may raise concerns about the durability of the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: All eyes on whether Opec will raise production
summary: OPEC's meeting at the end of November is expected to determine whether to raise oil production, influencing the global oil market. Despite low demand and high inventories, oil prices have surged by 30% in less than a month due to speculation and vaccine-related news. The International Energy Agency (IEA) estimates global demand at 95.4 million barrels a day, but the impact of vaccines on demand is uncertain. Opec's agreement to reduce supplies has already led to a decrease in global oil production from 100.2 million barrels a day in 2019 to 91 million a day in the third quarter.

site_title: STI drops 0.4% as October's factory output falls against expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output declined 0.9% in October, lower than expected, due to a fall in electronics output and biomedical performance. The decline weighed on local shares, with the Straits Times Index ending 0.4% lower. Economists had predicted a 7.3% growth.

site_title: Struggling retailers rack up US$52 billion in missed rents
summary: US retailers have racked up $52 billion in missed rent payments since April, adding to lost sales during shutdowns and the shift to e-commerce. Overdue rent could drive businesses into bankruptcy, with some, like Signet Jewelers and Bed Bath & Beyond, deferring payments and others, like Francesca's Holdings, planning store closures. Landlords and lenders are considering accommodations, such as rent reductions and debt conversions to equity, as promising vaccine news suggests a return to normalcy is near.

site_title: Design by nature
summary: Biophilic design, which incorporates natural elements into buildings, is gaining popularity as people seek a more human connection to nature. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated this trend, with many cities experiencing increased demand for green spaces and open areas. Architects are responding by designing buildings that incorporate natural elements, such as plants, daylight, and water features, to promote wellbeing and reduce stress. Examples include the Eden condominium in Singapore, which features a lush greenery-covered facade, and the Okamura office, which incorporates natural light and greenery into its design. Biophilic design is not limited to residential spaces, with commercial buildings such as the Ginger hotel buffet also incorporating natural elements. The trend is expected to continue, with clients prioritizing biophilic aspects in their projects.

site_title: Malaysia PM wins budget vote, survives key leadership test
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin successfully won the budget vote, securing enough support to remain in office. The vote was held in a voice vote after a bloc vote was deemed insufficient. The Budget will enter a second round of debates next week, ensuring Mr. Muhyiddin's leadership remains intact for now.

site_title: Thai central bank fights uphill battle against strong baht
summary: Thailand's central bank is struggling to combat a strong baht, which has appreciated 3% against the US dollar in the three weeks following the US presidential election. A strong currency is typically a positive sign, but it can hurt the competitiveness of Thai exports, which are already struggling due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a trade surplus, economists expect the baht to remain strong due to Thailand's current account surplus, but warn that a vaccine could boost tourist arrivals and put pressure on the currency. The Bank of Thailand is under pressure to intervene, but experts predict a gradual appreciation to 29.25 to the dollar by the end of 2021.

images.alt_text: The recent US presidential election has had an immediate impact on Thailand's economy, causing the baht to spike vis-a-vis the dollar, and economists say this is bad news for Thai exports.

site_title: Far East Orchard buys third student accommodation property in Bristol
summary: Far East Orchard has acquired its third student accommodation property in Bristol, Kings Square Studio, for £39.3 million. The property, with 301 beds, is operating at near full occupancy for the 2020/21 academic year. This acquisition brings the group's total portfolio to 3,561 beds across 12 properties in the UK, in line with its strategy of building a lodging platform.

images.alt_text: The freehold property is operating at near full occupancy for the current academic year 2020/21.

site_title: NTUC Income travel insurance covers Covid-19
summary: NTUC Income customers who buy its travel insurance will now receive Covid-19 coverage for medical-related expenses while overseas, including hospitalization costs of up to US$100,000 and medical evacuation or repatriation costs of up to US$100,000. This coverage is automatically included in single-trip insurance plans starting from Thursday, including plans for pre-existing conditions. However, benefits may be excluded for high-risk countries deemed by the World Health Organization.

site_title: Sabana Reit sheds new light on ID's dealings with ESR group
summary: Sabana Reit provided new information about its independent director Ng Shin Ein's dealings with ESR group in 2018 and 2019, addressing concerns from activist funds Quarz Capital and Black Crane about a potential merger. However, no credible evidence was found to support claims of a concert party action. This new information aims to alleviate concerns and pave the way for the proposed merger between Sabana and ESR-Reit.

site_title: How three CEOs helped their companies thrive in a pandemic
summary: Three CEOs - Soren Skou of AP Møller-Maersk, Poul Weihrauch of Mars Petcare, and Magnus Ahlqvist of Securitas - successfully navigated the COVID-19 pandemic by accelerating strategy, scaling innovation, and deepening customer engagement. Maersk invested in digital technologies, tripling blockchain transactions, while Mars Petcare scaled its telehealth service from 20 to 2,000 veterinary hospitals. Securitas leveraged its digital security solutions to manage customer uncertainty. These efforts enabled the companies to thrive despite the pandemic, demonstrating that crises can be turned into opportunities with effective leadership.

images.alt_text: The pandemic accelerated Maersk's technological transformation efforts, which led to new digital products and services while modernising assets such as ships and terminals.

site_title: Planting the seeds for the future of farming
summary: Agritech startup I.F.F.I. is revolutionizing farming through precision technology, aiming to produce 30% of Singapore's nutritional needs by 2030. The company's mega indoor farm, set to launch by the end of next year, will churn out 800 kg to 1,000 kg of produce per day. I.F.F.I. uses IoT software, customised light spectra, and robotic arms for optimal growth and quality control. The startup plans to expand globally, serving as consultants and designers for urban farms and partnering with educational institutions to promote research and talent in the sector.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim (left) saw a big business opportunity in urban agriculture and its importance in food sustainability. He decided to start I.F.F.I. with Mr Tham (right), who now heads the subsidiary as its chief executive.

site_title: DBS gets sizeable India branch network as bank bailout gets nod
summary: DBS has secured a formal nod from India's central bank to take over cash-strapped Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB), paving the way for DBS to gain full control of a sizeable branch network in India. All LVB branches will operate under the DBS brand name starting November 27. The merger will add 563 branches, over 2 million retail accounts, and 4,400 employees to DBS India. DBS will take over LVB's 20,973 crore rupees in deposits and 13,505 crore rupees in net advances. The deal is a bailout for LVB, which has been struggling with governance issues and mounting bad debt.

images.alt_text: The takeover of LVB will add 563 branches to DBS India's current 34 branches in 24 cities, over two million retail accounts, more than 150,000 non-retail clients and about 4,400 employees.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Cold Storage releases its classic Christmas spread featuring traditional favorites such as smoked turkey, ham, sausage platters, and duck pate truffle. The company also offers a contemporary twist with dishes like Christmas meatloaf wreath, colonial chicken casserole, and turkey mala pot pie. The spread also includes international options like Swedish meatballs and a fragrant pandan-infused kueh salat, typically Singaporean.

site_title: Euro rises to near 3-month high as US dollar falls
summary: The euro rose to a nearly three-month high against the US dollar, reaching US$1.1941, due to downbeat US economic data and optimism about coronavirus vaccines. The Federal Reserve minutes signalled the central bank may strengthen its quantitative easing program, putting pressure on the US currency. Other currencies, including the British pound and Australian dollar, also rose against the US dollar, while the Canadian dollar remained neutral.

site_title: In art, old is gold
summary: Georgette Chen, a pioneering Singaporean artist, is celebrated in a retrospective exhibition at the National Gallery Singapore. The show features 69 artworks and 74 archival materials, showcasing Chen's talent and ambition as a painter. Born in 1906 to a wealthy family in China, Chen studied art in Paris and New York, and later became a prominent figure in the Nanyang art movement. Her works, including still lifes, en plein air paintings, and portraits, demonstrate her unique blend of Western and Asian influences. The exhibition runs until September 26, 2021.

images.alt_text: Georgette Chen's paintings Hakka Family and Malay Wedding on display at National Gallery Singapore.
Affandi's canvas At The Beach showcased at Art Agenda SEA.
Sujak Rahman's batik work Neighbours at ArtSpace @ Helutrans.

site_title: Lead through anxiety with peace, purpose, preparedness
summary: Leaders can help their teams navigate crisis situations by sharing information, imparting purpose, and developing response capabilities. Over-communication is key to reassuring employees and reducing fear and anxiety. Building a shared sense of purpose can also help employees feel connected to the larger goal and more engaged. Additionally, preparing for a new operating environment by developing response capabilities and a crisis network is crucial for survival. By focusing on peace, purpose, and preparedness, leaders can help their teams navigate uncertainty and thrive in crisis situations.

site_title: Scoot will continue cargo charters after pandemic if profitable
summary: Scoot, a Singaporean airline, will continue cargo charters if profitable, despite the pandemic. The carrier has operated over 300 cargo planes between 11 cities since March, transporting medical supplies, small packages, and fresh flowers. CEO Campbell Wilson stated this in a media preview of Scoot's new inflight portal. The airline's dedicated charters will continue post-pandemic if profitable, offering an alternative to traditional cargo transport services.

images.alt_text: The ScootHub portal allows customers to order food, shop for duty-free items, play games and browse travel content among a suite of functions.

site_title: Lee Foundation unit sells Haig Road property
summary: CASUARINA Properties, a unit of the Lee Foundation, has sold 11 landed homes on a 25,054 sq ft freehold site in Singapore's Haig Road for S$32.8 million. The sale price represents a premium of around 6.8% over the reserve price. The property, currently a three-storey development of 10 terrace houses and a bungalow, can be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment project with up to 32 units.

images.alt_text: Located at the corner of Haig Road and Haig Lane, the site can be redeveloped into a five-storey apartment project.

site_title: Indonesia's biggest banks resist pressure to lower lending rates
summary: Indonesia's largest banks are resisting pressure from the central bank to lower lending rates, citing a lack of demand for borrowing. Loans shrank 0.47% in October, the first time on record, as people limit spending due to high unemployment and the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The central bank has cut interest rates by 225 basis points, but banks have only eased rates by 100-125 basis points, citing risk perception and non-performing loans. This poses a hurdle for President Joko Widodo's plan to lift the country out of recession.

site_title: Kimly's FY20 net profit rises 25.8%
summary: Kimly, a coffee shop operator, reported a 25.8% rise in net profit to S$25.2 million for FY20, driven by a 1.2% increase in revenue mainly from food delivery sales. Gross profit rose 38.9% to S$56.5 million due to cost savings from government grants and rental rebates. The company declared a total dividend of 1.12 cents per share, representing a 52.6% payout of its net profit.

site_title: ECB sounds alarm on worrying financing conditions
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is sounding the alarm on strained financing conditions in the euro-area economy, citing worrying signs from survey data on lending, investment, and access to finance for small- and medium-sized businesses. ECB chief economist Philip Lane stated that the bank will recalibrate its instruments to respond to the situation and ensure favorable financing conditions for economic recovery. The Governing Council is expected to increase and extend its US$1.6 trillion pandemic asset-purchase program and offer more long-term funding to banks during its policy meeting on December 10.

images.alt_text: The euro-area economy is seeing initial signs of strained financing conditions, European Central Bank chief economist Philip Lane said in remarks just two weeks before policy makers meet to reset their monetary stimulus.

site_title: UK will not accept a Brexit trade deal at any cost
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak says Britain won't accept a Brexit trade deal at any cost, amid negotiations with the EU. Officials on both sides agree on a clear deal shape but remain stuck on fair competition guarantees and fisheries. The EU is prepared for Britain to leave without a new trade accord, despite "genuine progress" in talks. A deal is possible but unlikely before the weekend, with negotiations to resume face-to-face next week.

site_title: Evergrande's Hong Kong IPO meets with lukewarm reception, raises US$1.8 billion
summary: Evergrande Property Services Group's Hong Kong IPO priced at HK$8.80 per share, raising US$1.8 billion, with lukewarm demand underscoring concerns about the financial health of its debt-laden parent, China Evergrande Group. The offering comes after a series of setbacks, including a secondary share sale and the dropping of a plan to inject property assets into a Shenzhen company. The IPO price represents a 5% increase from a private funding round in August and values the company at HK$95.06 billion.

site_title: Singapore's financial sector is hiring, but tech skills are key
summary: Singapore's financial sector created 1,900 net jobs in the first half of the year, with the majority being tech-related roles. However, the sector's growth may slow due to a skills gap, as demand for higher-level tech roles outstrips the ability to build up relevant skills. This trend was highlighted by Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore. To address the issue, the sector may need to invest in upskilling and reskilling programs to meet the changing demands of the industry.

site_title: Aviation bodies seek airport slots waiver for much of 2021
summary: Global aviation bodies IATA, ACI, and slot coordinators propose waiving airport slot access rules for much of 2021, allowing airlines to use 80% of their take-off and landing windows without ceding slots to rivals. This would have significant implications for airline competition and market access for low-cost carriers. The waiver would be extended until October 2021, addressing concerns from budget airlines.

site_title: Move aside, Paris and Milan: luxury brands are pivoting to Asia-Pacific as China splurges
summary: Luxury brands are shifting their focus to the Asia-Pacific region, particularly China, as the country recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic and domestic tourism surges. From January to October, Asia-Pacific accounted for 38.9% of global luxury store openings, surpassing Europe's 31.8% share. China saw a 64.7% surge in openings, driven by retailers expanding their physical footprint to meet demand, while Singapore is emerging as a hub for sneakers, with luxury boutiques benefiting from domestic spenders. This trend is expected to continue, with China's luxury spending projected to surge 30% in 2020 and potentially account for half of global luxury spend by 2025.

images.alt_text: Key openings of late in the Greater Bay Area included Burberry's first digital-centric "social retail store" in Shenzhen in partnership with Tencent.

site_title: Singapore's 2019 income gap improves, but could widen in 2020 due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore's 2019 income gap decreased, with the Gini coefficient falling to 0.398, the lowest in at least a decade. However, economists predict the gap could widen in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's disproportionate impact on low-income workers. Despite the pandemic, Singapore's strong economic fundamentals and government interventions, such as the Jobs Support Scheme, are expected to help the country recover and capture new opportunities, with businesses showing confidence in the city-state's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: High-wage jobs have been relatively buffered from the pandemic as technology allows such workers to work remotely, said economist Walter Theseira.

site_title: Salted & Hung ups its culinary game
summary: Chef Drew Nocente's new tasting menu at Salted & Hung marks his foray into A-list fine dining. The full menu, priced at S$128++ or S$168++, features a range of creative dishes, including umami panna cotta, wagyu brisket, and a signature grouper dish. The menu showcases Nocente's attention to detail, technique, and minimization of waste. The meal concludes with a pavlova-inspired dessert, solidifying Nocente's under-rated status as one of Singapore's top chefs.

site_title: It's time to put the noble grapes in their place
summary: The traditional concept of "noble" grapes in wine, consisting of six French varieties, is being reevaluated. Grapes from non-traditional regions, such as Spain, Sicily, and the US, are producing exceptional wines that rival those of more well-known varieties. The focus on site, farming, winemaking, vintage character, and producer intent is more crucial in determining wine quality than the social standing of grapes. A more inclusive approach to wine appreciation recognizes the potential of a wide range of grapes, rather than relying on a rigid caste system.

site_title: SPACs are back
summary: SPACs, or Special Purpose Acquisition Companies, have seen a resurgence in 2020 with over $30 billion raised, including major acquisitions of Virgin Galactic and electric vehicle manufacturers Lordstown Motors and Nikola. These companies are listed cash shell companies backed by a sponsor with investors typically being hedge funds. If an acquisition is not completed, investors receive their capital back with a small return. The incentives for both the sponsor and investors to complete an acquisition have led to a "bang" in the SPAC market, but the question remains whether things will go wrong again.

site_title: Singapore sees its first Covid-19 community case in 16 days
summary: Singapore reported its first Covid-19 community case in 16 days, with a 33-year-old service engineer testing positive after dining with 12 family members at Seoul Garden at Tampines Mall. The man had developed symptoms on November 23 and is being isolated and tested, with his family and close contacts placed on quarantine. The case brings Singapore's total to 58,195, with 58,089 patients recovered and 43 in hospital. Experts warn that even with low community cases, vigilance is necessary to prevent imported infections.

site_title: URA, HDB release Ang Mo Kio condo plot and Tengah EC site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) released two residential land parcels, one in Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 and the other in Tengah Garden Walk, under the 2020 government land sales (GLS) programme. Analysts expect a strong turnout of bidders due to improved market sentiment and developer confidence. The Ang Mo Kio site is expected to yield 370 units, while the Tengah site can yield 615 executive condominium units, with top bids ranging from S$273 million to S$352 million. Tender periods for both sites will close on May 25, 2021.

images.alt_text: The Ang Mo Kio land parcel has a site area of about 12,679 sq m, and a maximum gross floor area (GFA) of 31,699 sq m.
The Tengah parcel, designated for EC development, has a site area of 22,021 sq m and a maximum GFA of 61,659 sq m.

site_title: Accrelist drops proposed acquisition of F&B software firm
summary: Accrelist has scrapped its proposed acquisition of Liaoning Mealplus Technology, a food and beverage software firm, after over two years of negotiations failed to reach an agreement. The deal, announced in April 2018, had a cash consideration of 4 million yuan and the issuance of Accrelist shares. Despite extended discussions, both parties could not come to terms on the acquisition terms. The decision marks a significant setback for Accrelist, which had initially signed four documents to extend the deadline to execute a subscription agreement.

site_title: Muhyiddin secures key victory after parliament approves 2021 budget
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin secured a key victory as parliament approved the 2021 budget by a voice vote, ensuring his survival amid a health and economic crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The budget aimed to bring the economy out of recession and manage the health fallout from Covid-19. Muhyiddin's administration secured cross-party support, despite dissent within his ruling coalition, and opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's attempts to capitalize on the situation were unsuccessful. The vote marked a crucial test of Muhyiddin's leadership and wafer-thin majority.

site_title: LTA awards S$932.8m contract for Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded a S$932.8 million contract to Penta-Ocean Construction for the construction of the Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link, a standalone Light Rail Transit system. Construction is set to start in Q1 next year, with passenger service expected to commence in end-2026. The project will connect Singapore's Woodlands North station to Malaysia's Bukit Chagar station, supporting a peak capacity of 10,000 passengers per hour. The second civil contract will be awarded in Q1 2021.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of RTS Link Woodlands North station and CIQ building in Singapore.

site_title: Biolidics' Covid-19 test kits to be distributed and used in Indonesia
summary: Biolidics, a medtech firm, announced that its Covid-19 antibody test kits have obtained authorisation from Indonesian health authorities for distribution and use in Indonesia, valid until November 25, 2021. The test kits should be used in conjunction with clinical presentation and supplementary testing. Biolidics' shares rose 3.33% to close at S$0.31.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit secures S$100m contract for FPSO project
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine's subsidiary, Keppel Shipyard, secured a S$100 million contract for fabrication and integration work on a floating production storage and offloading vessel (FPSO). The project, valued at S$100 million, is scheduled for delivery in the fourth quarter of 2022. The scope of work includes fabrication, installation, and integration of topside modules, riser balconies, and spread mooring support structures.

site_title: DBS supports social enterprises through S$9m in grants and loans
summary: DBS Bank has provided S$9 million in grants and loans to social enterprises in Asia to support them during the COVID-19 pandemic. The DBS Foundation has awarded S$1.4 million in grants to 13 social enterprises, including Ento Industries and ElderAid, which focus on food waste and elderly care. The grants, along with other initiatives, aim to support social enterprises in hiring and retaining people from disadvantaged communities, and to address social issues.

site_title: China points overseas as source of coronavirus
summary: China is shifting the focus of the COVID-19 origin narrative to overseas sources, citing scientific papers and evidence of the virus's presence in Europe and imported frozen food packaging. State media and experts suggest that the virus may have originated outside China, with some pointing to Italy and Barcelona as possible sources. However, experts remain skeptical, citing the lack of concrete evidence and the close genetic similarity of the virus to one found in bats in China.

site_title: Amazon's cloud service back up after widespread outage
summary: Amazon's cloud service, Amazon Web Services (AWS), experienced a widespread outage affecting various users, including Roku, Adobe, Flickr, and the Baltimore Sun, before being restored. The company identified the cause of the outage and took corrective action to prevent a recurrence. AWS operates normally, with Kinesis Data Streams restored via all endpoints.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia's IPO to sell 58m shares at S$0.93 each
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) has lodged its final prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise S$53.9 million by selling 58 million shares at S$0.93 each. The company plans to use the funds for strategic investments, regional expansion, and acquisitions, as well as organic growth initiatives. CBA's net profit grew 16.3% over the last two years, and its board intends to recommend dividends of at least 90% of net profit for FY21 and FY22. The IPO comes just a month after Nanofilm Technologies made its debut on the Singapore Exchange mainboard.

site_title: Riksbank expands QE; says more steps possible between meetings
summary: Sweden's central bank, Riksbank, expanded its quantitative easing program to 700 billion kronor, exceeding its initial target by 200 billion kronor. Governor Stefan Ingves said there's room for more stimulus between scheduled meetings. The repo rate remained at zero, and the bank expects it to stay there in the coming years. The expansion aims to combat the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on the global economy, with growth forecasts revised down and inflation prospects seen as weaker.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish the day with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.56% on Thursday, driven by optimism over vaccine rollouts, despite rising coronavirus infections. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 26,819.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.22%. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and despite US-EU trade talks in focus, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Philippines, private firms to sign vaccine supply deal with AstraZeneca
summary: The Philippines is set to sign a deal with AstraZeneca for 2 million doses of its potential Covid-19 vaccine, with private firms aiming to procure more doses. The private sector will pay for the vaccine and donate half to the government and half to their employees. This deal is part of the government's efforts to inoculate around two-thirds of its 108 million population. The vaccine, which has shown up to 90% effectiveness, still needs to be approved by regulators.

site_title: Investors pledge US$800m for Vietnam startups
summary: Vietnam's startup ecosystem received a significant boost with a pledge of US$800 million from 33 venture capital firms over three to five years. Despite a 22% decrease in investment in the first half of 2020 due to the pandemic, the new pledge is comparable to the US$861 million invested in 2019. The commitment is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the shift of manufacturing and foreign direct investment into Vietnam, driven by trade tensions between the US and China. This is the perfect time to invest in Vietnam, according to a venture capital firm.

site_title: LTA awards S$932.8m contract to build Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded a S$932.8 million contract to Penta-Ocean Construction to build the Johor Bahru-Singapore RTS Link, a cross-border train service between Singapore and Malaysia. Construction is expected to start in Q1 2021, with passenger service set to begin in 2026. The RTS Link will have a peak capacity of 10,000 passengers per hour and will feature co-located Customs, Immigration and Quarantine facilities, allowing passengers to clear both Singapore and Malaysia immigration authorities once.

site_title: China will make monetary policy more flexible, targeted: PBOC
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced it will make monetary policy more flexible and targeted to address concerns over corporate bond defaults. The bank will maintain "normal" monetary policy as long as possible and improve the bond default risk prevention and disposal mechanism. The move aims to stabilize the corporate bond market and support China's nascent economic recovery. The PBOC reiterated it will not resort to flood-like stimulus, keeping the macro-leverage ratio basically stable.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 14.53 points to 1,612.11. The market saw 816 gainers for every 412 losers, with a total trading volume of 8.869 billion lots worth RM4.677 billion.

site_title: SPH plans to grow its recurring property income
summary: SPH plans to increase recurring income from its property segments, including retail and student accommodation, and aged care and digital media businesses. Despite the pandemic, its PBSA segment saw a 29% year-on-year increase in net operating income in FY2020. The group has achieved 88% of its FY2021 target revenue and is considering listing its PBSA assets. SPH's investments in PBSA have returned a cumulative operating profit of about S$20 million since 2018, while the group has made several divestments totaling a gain of about S$293 million.

site_title: Pound near three-month high as US dollar struggles; Brexit talks weigh
summary: The British pound held near a three-month high due to US dollar weakness and uncertainty over Brexit talks. Despite the UK's finance minister announcing unprecedented spending plans, the pound has largely shrugged off concerns. EU officials reported "genuine progress" in Brexit talks, but fears persist of a no-deal exit on December 31. Traders are watching for news on the Brexit talks, expecting a positive outcome. Sterling's value is influenced by Brexit uncertainty and dollar softness, with a trade deal being a major factor in the pound's recent performance.

site_title: AstraZeneca faces more vaccine questions after manufacturing error
summary: AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford face questions over their Covid-19 vaccine trial results after acknowledging a manufacturing error. The vaccine showed a 70% average efficacy in a late-stage study, but details of the error, including a half-dose given to some participants, were not disclosed. Regulators may scrutinize the results, and experts question the true efficacy of the vaccine. Despite this, the vaccine remains near the front of the pack, with other vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna showing higher efficacy rates.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford, among the front-runners in the quest to deliver a Covid-19 vaccine, face mounting questions about their trial results after acknowledging a manufacturing error.

site_title: Disney to lay off 32,000 workers in first half of 2021
summary: Disney to lay off 32,000 workers in the first half of 2021, primarily at its theme parks, due to limited customers due to the coronavirus pandemic. This increase from the 28,000 layoffs announced in September. The company has been struggling financially and has taken measures to reduce costs, including furloughing additional workers.

site_title: SPH Reit to focus on 'providing sustainable rental income'
summary: SPH Reit has committed to focusing on providing sustainable rental income by minimizing vacancies for FY2021. The company aims to support tenants during the challenging Covid-19 period and position its assets for recovery. CEO Susan Leng Mee Yin emphasized the need for a targeted approach to work with tenants to be ready for recovery.

site_title: Plaintiffs' lawyer questions Exklusiv's intention of telling members about club sale
summary: Plaintiffs' lawyers questioned Exklusiv Resorts' intention to inform The Pines club members about the sale of the club's Stevens Road premises to Oxley Holdings in March 2013.
