Exklusiv's general manager, Jeffrey Leong, testified that he was informed by Peter Kwee that the club would continue to operate, but no notice was given to members. The defendants argue that the sale was public knowledge and no deceit was involved, while plaintiffs claim that Exklusiv failed to inform members about the sale, potentially causing them harm.

site_title: Singapore shares falter even as regional markets advance; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,857.48 points, despite regional markets advancing, due to a 0.9% year-on-year decline in factory output for October. Economists had expected a 7.3% growth. Top advancers included glove makers and Thai Beverage, while lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the biggest losers. Analysts advise investors to buy on dips, citing cheap central bank cash and vaccine candidates, which will continue to drive asset price appreciation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's industrial production fell 0.9% in October, contrary to economists' expectations of a 7.3% growth. The country remains competitive despite the Covid-19 crisis, with S$13 billion of fixed asset investment commitments secured in the first four months of 2020. The Monetary Authority of Singapore noted a skills mismatch for tech roles, while a job gain in the financial sector may not translate to skills in tech. The Straits Times Index ended Thursday down 0.4%, and a vendor was fined S$120,000 for exposing blood donors' personal data.

site_title: Most Singapore residential consumers satisfied with service by power retailers: survey
summary: A recent survey by the Energy Market Authority found that nearly half of Singapore's 1.4 million household accounts have switched to buying electricity from a retailer other than the incumbent provider SP Services. Over 90% of consumers are satisfied with the service, with 97% reporting satisfaction before signing up or contract renewal, and 91% after. This suggests that the Open Electricity Market (OEM) has been successful in promoting competition and improving customer satisfaction.

site_title: South Korea's central bank leaves policy rate unchanged, as widely expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, maintained its key policy rate at a record low of 0.50% amid economic recovery and concerns over rising household debt. The decision was widely expected by economists. The central bank will soon release revised growth and inflation forecasts, while Governor Lee Ju Yeol will address the public via live YouTube conference.

site_title: Geraldine Chin to take over as ExxonMobil APAC boss as Gan Seow Kee retires
summary: ExxonMobil Asia Pacific is set to undergo a leadership change as chairman and managing director Gan Seow Kee retires on January 1, 2021. Geraldine Chin, director of ExxonMobil Asia Pacific, will take over the top job. Chin has been with the company for 32 years, holding various positions in Singapore and the US. Gan's retirement marks the end of a nearly four-decade tenure with ExxonMobil, during which he held multiple leadership roles and served on various boards.

site_title: Europe: Stocks narrowly mixed at open
summary: European stock markets experienced a narrow opening session, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.1% to 6,384.76 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.2% to 13,312.97 points and Paris' CAC 40 also gained 0.2% to 5,582.16 points. The mixed performance was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, as well as US-EU trade talks taking center stage.

site_title: Singapore industrial production sees surprise 0.9% fall in October
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 0.9% year-on-year in October, contrary to economists' expectations of a 7.3% growth. The decline was attributed to a decrease in electronics output and poor biomedical performance. However, JPMorgan analyst Ong Sin Beng views this as a "blip" rather than a change in trend, citing continued expansion signals from the Purchasing Managers' Index. The unexpected drop follows a revised 25.6% growth in September, which was boosted by the biomedical cluster and electronics.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as investors shun risk on bleak US jobs data
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.7% on Thursday, snapping a three-session winning streak, as a surprise uptick in US jobless claims weighed on sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6636.4, with heavyweight financials and energy stocks falling. However, gold stocks and tech stocks gained, driven by fears of a swift economic recovery and the safe-haven appeal of gold. The market reaction was muted to news of Telstra agreeing to pay a penalty for selling indigenous consumers.

site_title: Foxconn to shift some Apple production to Vietnam to minimise China risk
summary: Foxconn, a major electronics manufacturer, plans to shift some Apple production to Vietnam, starting with iPad and MacBook assembly, to minimize the impact of the Sino-US trade war. This move follows US President Donald Trump's encouragement for US firms to diversify production out of China. Foxconn is building assembly lines in Vietnam's Bac Giang province, with production expected to come online in the first half of 2021. The shift aims to reduce dependence on China and support Apple's diversification efforts.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit secures S$100m contract for FPSO project
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) subsidiary Keppel Shipyard secured a S$100 million contract for a floating production storage and offloading vessel (FPSO) project. The project, valued at 220,000 barrels of oil per day and 400 million cubic feet of gas per day, is scheduled for delivery in 2022. Pre-fabrication work will begin in 2023, and the company has implemented safety measures to maintain operations amid the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: Broker's take: UOBKH initiates 'buy' on Nanofilm due to unique tech, superior margin
summary: UOB Kay Hian initiated coverage on Nanofilm with a "buy" call and a target price of S$4.07. The brokerage cited the firm's unique tech and superior margin as reasons for the recommendation. Nanofilm's stock was trading at S$3.34 at the time of the announcement, with a 7.7% increase. The company provides surface vacuum coating technology solutions to blue-chip customers, giving it a strong competitive advantage.

site_title: Singapore remains competitive despite Covid-19: MOF
summary: Singapore remains a competitive and pro-business economy despite the Covid-19 crisis, with businesses showing confidence in the country. The Economic Development Board secured S$13 billion of fixed asset investment commitments in the first four months of 2020, and a total of S$90 million was donated to charities between January and May. The country's strong sense of community and collective effort in fighting the pandemic have fostered a strong sense of unity among Singaporeans.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump on Samsung boost, economic recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.94% on Thursday, driven by gains in Samsung Electronics and economic recovery hopes. The Kospi index increased 24.37 points to 2,625.91, outweighing concerns over the coronavirus. Shares in Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and LG Chem also rose, with Samsung up 2.1% and LG Chem up 3.6%. The gains were despite ongoing economic uncertainty and US tariff threats, with investors focusing on economic recovery prospects.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.77 points, or 0.24%, to 1,593.81. Trading volume was 399.23 million lots worth RM148.55 million. Gainers beat losers 226 to 142.

site_title: US Supreme Court backs religious groups over New York virus curbs
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of Christian and Jewish houses of worship challenging New York state's virus curbs, granting requests from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and two Orthodox Jewish congregations. The decision, made with Justice Amy Coney Barrett's deciding vote, marked a significant shift in the court's stance on religious freedoms during the pandemic. The ruling comes as the court has taken a more conservative turn under Barrett's appointment.

site_title: LMIRT draws SGX query after volume surge
summary: LMIRT's units surged 10.8% to 9.2 cents on Wednesday, with a record 57 million units traded. The counter jumped from 8.4 cents on Tuesday. No married trades were found, suggesting a genuine buying interest. The volume is more than nine times the average daily trading volume.

site_title: Scoot to offer inflight portal for low-touch travelling experience
summary: Scoot, the low-cost arm of Singapore Airlines, is launching a new inflight portal called ScootHub in phases starting from December. The portal allows passengers to order food, shop duty-free items, play games, and browse travel content on their own devices, even without internet connectivity. This shift reduces surface contact and paper consumption, resulting in a lighter weight plane, which can lead to fuel savings and reduced carbon emissions. The move aims to provide a low-touch travelling experience, better meeting passenger expectations during the pandemic and post-Covid world.

site_title: Evergrande Property's Hong Kong IPO raises HK$14.3b: sources
summary: Evergrande Property Services Group's initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong raised HK$14.3 billion, exceeding the marketed range of HK$8.50 to HK$9.75 per share. The sale of 1.621 billion shares, equivalent to a 15% stake, was priced at HK$8.80. Half of the funds will go to the company, while the other half will be allocated to its debt-laden parent China Evergrande Group.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.91% to 26,537.31 and the Topix index rising 0.60% to 1,778.25. Investors bought back major shares, shaking off worries over rising coronavirus cases. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: South-east Asia green economy may see US$1t in annual opportunities: report
summary: South-east Asia's green economy could generate up to $1 trillion in annual opportunities by 2030, according to a report by Bain & Company. The region lags behind others in green initiatives, but offers significant opportunities in sustainable energy, food and agriculture, efficient industries, and urban development. These opportunities include shifting to renewables, adopting circular economy practices, and digitizing supply chains. Financial institutions can accelerate the shift to sustainable investing by deploying capital to green projects and startups.

site_title: Job gains in financial sector may belie skills mismatch for tech roles
summary: Singapore's financial services sector created 1,900 net jobs in the first half of 2020, but rising demand for tech roles may outstrip the ability to build relevant skills, according to Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Tech-related roles account for 49% of new jobs, with "advanced" roles requiring years of training and experience in limited supply. To address this, MAS and the Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore are launching new measures, including a Work-Study Support Programme to develop job-ready graduates and extend training allowance grants for company-sponsored trainees.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands adds mixed-reality tech to hybrid event studio
summary: Marina Bay Sands has added mixed-reality technology to its hybrid broadcast studio, enhancing its capabilities for event organizers in Singapore. The studio features a 3D stage with LED walls and hologram functionalities, allowing presenters to incorporate virtual elements into their presentations. The technology addition was launched at TravelRevive, Singapore's first hybrid trade show since the pandemic, and is expected to drive digital transformation in the hybrid event experience. The investment in the studio and its new capabilities is not disclosed, but the company emphasizes the importance of upskilling staff and prioritizing their development.

site_title: Gold gains as weak US jobs data, virus worries dim recovery hopes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,811.31 per ounce amid weak US jobs data and COVID-19 concerns, bolstering its safe-haven appeal. US jobless claims rose for the second straight week, undermining labor market recovery. The US Federal Reserve discussed adjusting asset purchases to provide more market support. Gold is seen as a hedge against inflation resulting from large stimulus. The bank maintained its 12-month target of $2,100 per ounce for gold, citing accommodative central bank policy and dollar weakness.

site_title: URA, HDB release sale sites at Tengah, Ang Mo Kio
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) released two residential sites in Singapore, one at Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 and the other at Tengah Garden Walk. The sites, launched under the 2020 government land sales programme, have a total lease period of 99 years and are expected to yield approximately 985 residential units. The tender for the sites will close on May 25, 2021, with a six-month tender period to accommodate the ongoing COVID-19 situation.

site_title: Covid vaccine rush in China raises fears of booming black market
summary: A growing black market for COVID-19 vaccines in China is raising concerns. A business owner in Beijing, Cheng, plans to pay up to $91 for two doses of an experimental vaccine from Sinopharm, a state-backed developer. To access the vaccine, Cheng's friend will pretend to be employed by a cold-chain logistics company, and Cheng will pay via Alipay, a digital payments platform. This black market sale is feared to be widespread in China, highlighting the need for increased regulation to prevent the exploitation of vulnerable individuals.

site_title: Bitcoin price drops more than US$1,000 in Asian trade
summary: Bitcoin's price dropped more than US$1,000 in Asian trading, reaching US$17,700 and falling 6% from its previous close. The price correction comes after the cryptocurrency failed to reach record highs. Analysts attribute the drop to a rapid correction after the price failed to hit the all-time highs, with more institutions such as hedge funds and family offices trading cryptocurrencies. Despite the drop, experts believe bitcoin still has upside potential, with this year's rally rising 358.6% from its year's low.

site_title: NTUC Income adds Covid-19 insurance coverage for overseas travel
summary: NTUC Income has added Covid-19 insurance coverage to its single-trip travel insurance plans, providing protection for medical-related expenses, medical evacuation, and repatriation costs of up to US$100,000 for the first 90 days of overseas travel. The coverage is automatically included in plans starting Thursday, but excludes high-risk countries deemed by the World Health Organization. Existing policyholders can contact the insurer to add the benefits to their annual travel plans, and the move aims to provide peace of mind for Singapore residents traveling overseas.

site_title: DoctorxDentist wipes platform of reviews after SMC issues advisory to doctors
summary: DoctorxDentist, a popular online platform for doctors, has removed all reviews of doctors from its site after the Singapore Medical Council (SMC) warned against associating with SEO platforms that use patient feedback and ratings. The SMC deemed such reviews as patient testimonials, forbidden under its Ethical Code and Guidelines. DoctorxDentist had offered SEO subscription packages, sparking concerns of conflict of interest and payment for reviews. The platform now has about 300 remaining profiles, with the SMC considering legal action against the startup.

site_title: Tesla raises prices for Model S across Europe
summary: Tesla has raised prices for its Model S sedan across Europe, with rates varying by country. The price increase ranges from 2,000 euros in Spain to 5,000 euros in France and the UK. In contrast, the Model S costs US$67,920 in the United States, following recent price cuts. This price hike also affects Model X and Model 3 sedans, according to reports.

site_title: Over 2,400 US Covid-19 deaths in 24 hours, a six-month high: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported a six-month high of 2,439 Covid-19 deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total to 262,080 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country also registered nearly 200,000 new cases. Travel appeared to be down ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday, contrary to concerns of crowded airports. US President-elect Joe Biden appealed for Americans to stay hopeful, citing accelerating vaccine plans, and assured that life would return to normal.

site_title: CDL venture Sincere sees recovery in sales at Chengdu project
summary: CDL's venture Sincere Property Group reported a 150 million yuan (S$30.6 million) sales figure for its TianFengHe Mansion project in Chengdu, China, on its third phase launch. This represents about 80% of the 540 units launched. The project saw strong demand, with Singaporean property developer City Developments Limited (CDL) acquiring a 51% stake in Sincere Property for 4.39 billion yuan in April. The successful launch marks a positive recovery for the project's sales.

site_title: Japan bird flu outbreak spreads to farm in third prefecture
summary: Japan has reported a bird flu outbreak in a third prefecture, with an egg farm in Hyogo prefecture west of Tokyo infected. The 146,000 chickens will be slaughtered and buried, and a 3km radius around the farm will be restricted. This brings the total number of culled chickens to over 1.8 million since the outbreak began. The government has also detected an outbreak in Fukuoka prefecture, adding to eight already reported in Kagawa prefecture. Japan's last major outbreak occurred between 2016 and 2017, when 1.67 million chickens were culled due to the H5N6 strain of bird flu.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars pause to give thanks for bumper gains
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars paused at US$0.7369 and US$0.7006, respectively, after significant gains in November. The Aussie reached a three-month high of US$0.7373, driven by a strong domestic economy and rising house prices, while the kiwi dollar reached its highest since June 2018. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is now less likely to lower interest rates in the near term, according to Westpac chief economist Dominick Stephens, as the country aims to contain house price growth.

site_title: Lendlease targets absolute-zero carbon emissions by 2040
summary: Lendlease, a Sydney-based property and infrastructure group, has set ambitious sustainability goals. The company aims to become a 1.5 degrees Celsius-aligned company by 2025, with net-zero carbon emissions by 2025 and absolute-zero carbon emissions by 2040. To achieve this, Lendlease will implement five key steps, including creating A$250 million of social value through shared-value partnerships. The company has also ranked top in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark rankings in the Asia Retail category.

site_title: Europe's largest tech conference to return as in-person event in 2021
summary: Europe's largest tech conference, the Web Summit, will return to Lisbon in 2021 as an in-person event after going fully online in 2020 due to the pandemic. The conference, which typically attracts 70,000 participants, will host 100,000 online attendees and feature hundreds of speakers, including the head of the European Commission and Zoom's CEO. The event aims to attract more people from different locations by offering a mix of in-person and virtual experiences. A South American Web Summit is also planned for 2022 in either Rio de Janeiro or Porto Alegre, Brazil.

site_title: Negative bond yield arrives in Singapore with UOB's 1b-euro issue
summary: UOB has issued the first negative-yielding bond out of Singapore, with a 1 billion-euro issue yielding less than its face value. Market watchers predict this trend will continue among Singaporean banks.

site_title: Telecom major Telstra to pay A$50m fine for mis-selling to indigenous customers
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecom firm, agreed to pay a A$50 million fine for mis-selling post-paid mobile products to 108 indigenous customers between 2016 and 2018. The company admitted to "unconscionable conduct" and took full accountability, with CEO Andrew Penn stating that the impact on these vulnerable customers has been significant. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission found that the affected customers suffered financial hardship, with one running up debts of over A$19,000, due to difficulties understanding written contracts and limited financial resources.

site_title: Exxon, Total in talks over Mozambique LNG resource-sharing deal: sources
summary: ExxonMobil and Total are in negotiations over a resource-sharing deal for their massive LNG projects in Mozambique, aiming to cut costs and increase efficiency. The two companies are seeking to extract more gas from a shared field, which contains cheaper reserves, to boost their projects' annual LNG production. The talks also involve the Mozambican government, which must give final approval to any new agreement. The deal could impact Exxon's delayed final investment decision (FID) on its $30 billion Rovuma LNG project, now expected in early 2022.

site_title: Nintendo adds Sharp as assembler of popular Switch console: sources
summary: Nintendo has partnered with Sharp to assemble its popular Switch console, with production shifting from China to Malaysia, as the company aims to stabilize production and hedge against US-China trade tensions. This move comes as Nintendo struggles to keep up with demand for its consoles, with sales momentum showing no signs of slowing. The partnership with Sharp is part of Nintendo's efforts to diversify its supply chain, and the company is expected to raise its fiscal-year sales target.

site_title: Japan's export credit agency to lend US$2b to Nissan for US sales financing
summary: Japan's state-owned export credit agency has agreed to lend Nissan up to $2 billion to finance US car sales, as part of a $4.1 billion credit agreement. This will help Nissan provide customers with loans in monthly installments, supporting its business in the US market, which is crucial for the Japanese automaker. Nissan is focusing on US, China, and Japan to raise market share after a demand slump triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank-backed US property brokerage Compass taps banks for IPO
summary: Compass, a US-based real estate brokerage backed by SoftBank, has selected Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley as underwriters for a potential initial public offering (IPO) in 2021. The company, founded in 2012, has expanded through acquisitions and uses technology to give its agents an advantage. With investors including SoftBank, Goldman Sachs, and Fidelity, Compass is poised to capitalize on the US housing rally fueled by low mortgage rates. The IPO listing is expected to be one of the largest real estate brokerages in the US.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tick higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.10% to 26,695.25, due to a vaccine-inspired rally. However, the recent rally slowed due to profit-taking and concerns over rising virus cases in the city. Other Asian markets also saw slight changes, with the Shanghai Composite Index easing 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipping 0.11%.

site_title: Move over, Paris and Milan: Luxury brands pivot to Asia-Pacific as China splurges
summary: Luxury brands are shifting their focus to the Asia-Pacific region, particularly China, as the country recovers from the coronavirus pandemic and experiences a surge in spending and domestic tourism. In the first 10 months of the year, China accounted for 18.8% of global luxury store openings, with the Greater Bay Area seeing 11% of new stores globally. This trend is expected to continue, with China's luxury spending projected to surge 30% above last year's levels in 2020. Europe, traditionally a leader in luxury retail, is seeing a decline in physical store openings, while Asia-Pacific is emerging as a key contributor to the global luxury market.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as virus, weak data subdue vaccine rally
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul rising, while Shanghai, Sydney, and Singapore fell. The Dow and S&P 500 ended lower, while the Nasdaq hit a new all-time high. The US economy faces ongoing challenges, with jobless aid applications rising and the Federal Reserve warning of a tougher recovery without stimulus. Analysts remain optimistic about the vaccine-fueled market rally, but Fed officials express concern about the impact of Covid-19 cases and the need for a new spending package.

site_title: US economic suffering may rise without stimulus: Federal Reserve minutes
summary: US economic officials expressed concerns that the economy may suffer renewed pain without additional stimulus, according to Federal Reserve minutes released Wednesday. The minutes from the November 4-5 meeting revealed that Fed Chair Jerome Powell and other officials have been urging lawmakers for more stimulus spending to aid the recovery from the pandemic. The central bankers also considered future changes to its asset-buying strategy.

site_title: US: Dow retreats from 30,000-point record, Nasdaq at new high
summary: The US stock market experienced a mixed day, with the Dow retreating from a record high of 30,000 points, while the Nasdaq Composite Index reached a new high at 12,094.40, up 0.5%. The tech-rich Nasdaq's gain was driven by the promise of a vaccine and the Federal Reserve's liquidity lines. The US economy continues to suffer unevenly from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Maradona dead at 60: spokesman
summary: Argentine football legend Diego Maradona has died at the age of 60 due to a heart attack, following brain surgery earlier this month. Renowned as one of the greatest footballers of all time, Maradona won the World Cup as captain. President Alberto Fernandez announced three days of national mourning in Argentina.

site_title: Hedge-fund copycats rally as academics defend embattled strategy
summary: Hedge-fund copycats, investing products mimicking hedge-fund strategies, are on track for a strong performance this year, with a 2.3% gain in November, their highest in nine months. A study by researchers from the National University of Singapore found that liquid alternatives can successfully replicate trades from institutional managers with lower fees, sparking optimism. Despite underperforming hedge funds and 60/40 portfolios over the past decade, liquid alternatives have outperformed during major selloffs, such as the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Qantas offers fast-track to higher status to lure corporate travellers
summary: Qantas is offering a fast-track to higher status for top-tier members of rival frequent flyer programmes, including Virgin Australia, in an effort to boost market share in lucrative corporate and high-end leisure travel. The airline will fast-track these members to Gold status, which includes access to airport lounges, priority check-in and boarding, and preferential seating. This move comes as Qantas ramps up domestic flights and prepares for a potential increase in revenue by Christmas. The airline expects to reach 60% of pre-pandemic domestic capacity by then, which could lead to positive net cash flow.

site_title: Indonesia's biggest banks resist pressure to lower lending rates
summary: Indonesia's biggest banks are resisting pressure from the central bank to lower lending rates, citing a risk-averse attitude among lenders and the current reluctance of people to borrow. Despite the central bank cutting interest rates by 225 basis points since June 2019, banks have only eased rates for customers by 25-125 basis points this year. The contraction in loan growth, down 0.47% in October, is attributed to the banks' cautious approach, which could hinder President Joko Widodo's plan to lift the economy out of recession.

site_title: Former World Bank president James Wolfensohn dies aged 86
summary: Former World Bank president James Wolfensohn has died at the age of 86. He served as president from 1996 to 2005 and helped focus the World Bank on poverty reduction and combating corruption. Wolfensohn also led major cultural institutions, including Carnegie Hall and the John F. Kennedy Center, and was a global champion of human rights and economic justice. Tributes from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund praised his commitment to fighting poverty and putting people first.

site_title: Ikea investment arm in talks to buy prime retail property in big European cities
summary: Ikea's investment arm, Ingka Investments, is in talks to buy prime retail properties in major European cities, following its first acquisition in Paris' Rue de Rivoli. The company is pushing into the real estate market as part of Ikea's shift towards city-center stores, despite wider retail market uncertainty caused by the pandemic. Ingka Investments aims to acquire properties with space for Ikea stores, as well as other retail, office, and residential space, and plans to take over as landlord.

site_title: Trump pardons former adviser Flynn, who pleaded guilty in Russia probe
summary: US President Donald Trump pardoned former national security adviser Michael Flynn, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI during the Russia probe investigation into the 2016 presidential election. Flynn, a retired Army general, had previously admitted to lying about interactions with Russia's ambassador in the weeks leading up to Trump's inauguration. The pardon drew condemnation from Democrats and other critics. It is Trump's first major post-election pardon.

site_title: Europe: Shares end four-day winning streak as vaccine rally cools
summary: European shares ended a four-day winning streak as investors booked profits after sharp gains earlier this month. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 0.1% due to surging coronavirus cases and capping demand for risky assets. Energy stocks declined 1.2% after a 10% gain in the past three sessions, driven by crude price gains fueled by vaccine hopes and US political scenarios.

site_title: Australia: Shares trade flat as gloomy US jobs data blunts vaccine cheer
summary: Australian shares traded flat on Thursday as US jobless claims rose unexpectedly, casting a gloomy shadow on the global stock market. The data, released amid renewed coronavirus lockdowns in the US, raised concerns about the recovery in the labor market. Despite optimism over a third potential vaccine, the surprise weakness in jobless claims and other economic data halted a recent rally. The sentiment took a hit, with CMC Markets chief strategist Michael McCarthy stating that the data "reversed the recent re-opening inspired trading."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.11% at 26,266.70, and the Topix index down 0.40% at 1,760.56. The market lacked fresh leads after a mixed close on Wall Street.

site_title: US extends TikTok sale deadline to Dec 4
summary: The US Treasury has extended the deadline for Chinese owner ByteDance to sell its American TikTok business to December 4, 2020, from the original November 27 deadline. This decision comes after a revised submission was received by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). President Trump's administration has expressed national security concerns over TikTok, citing potential espionage risks. The extension allows time for review of the revised submission.

site_title: Exxon to cut up to 300 jobs in Canada
summary: ExxonMobil Corp plans to reduce up to 300 positions in Canada as part of its cost-cutting plan due to the coronavirus-driven slump in oil prices. The reductions will be implemented at Imperial Oil, ExxonMobil Canada, and ExxonMobil Business Centre Canada ULC. Exxon had earlier outlined more than $10 billion in budget cuts this year, following other oil producers' cost-cutting measures. This move comes as Canadian energy companies face challenges from scarce capital, pipeline congestion, and high emissions.

images.alt_text: US oil major Exxon Mobil Corp said on Wednesday it plans to reduce up to 300 positions in Canada as part of an ongoing cost-cut plan due to a coronavirus-driven slump in oil prices.

site_title: Australia Q3 business investment falls by more than expected
summary: Australian business investment fell 3% in the September quarter to A$25.85 billion, exceeding forecasts of a 1.5% decline. This follows a 5.9% decline in the June quarter. Despite this, spending plans for 2020/21 were upgraded to nearly A$105 billion, 6.3% higher than the previous estimate. However, plans for the current financial year-ended June 2021 barely improved, with mining spending plans revised downward. Economists warn that business investment, a key driver of productivity, may take longer to recover than expected.

images.alt_text: Australian business investment fell by more than expected last quarter as coronavirus lockdowns forced firms to delay purchases of equipment, but future spending plans were upgraded in a hopeful sign of recovery.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, ThaiBev, Top Glove, SPH Reit, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: DBS has formally approved a proposed scheme to take over cash-strapped Lakshmi Vilas Bank, which will allow DBS to acquire a significant branch network in India. ThaiBev reported a 2% dip in net profit due to the Covid-19 pandemic, while Top Glove shares sank to a 2.5-month low after factory closures. SPH Reit and Dasin Retail Trust also reported revenue drops. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines' share price jumped 8.2% on heavy volumes, and analysts warn that the recent run-up in OCBC, UOB, and DBS shares may be unsustainable.

site_title: Oil rallies past eight-month high on US crude inventory draw, vaccine hopes
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% to their highest in over eight months, driven by hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine boosting fuel demand. US crude inventories dropped, and Brent crude rose 1.6% to $48.61 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.8% to $45.71 a barrel. This rally follows data showing a surprise drop in weekly US crude inventories.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed nearly 2 per cent to their highest in more than eight months on Wednesday, as data showing a surprise drop in weekly US crude inventories extended a rally driven by hopes that a Covid-19 vaccine will boost fuel demand.

site_title: US visitors from developing nations to pay thousands in visa bonds
summary: The US will temporarily require visitors from 23 countries, including Iran, Myanmar, and several African nations, to pay up to $15,000 in visa bonds to prevent overstaying. The rule, effective December 24 for six months, aims to offset the costs of deporting foreigners. The measure applies to citizens with over 10% overstay rates, primarily from Africa, and does not affect students or travelers from developed countries. The Trump administration implemented the rule without public comment, citing diplomatic efforts, but its effectiveness remains uncertain under President-elect Joe Biden.

images.alt_text: The United States will temporarily require visitors from Iran, Myanmar and a number of African nations to pay up to US$15,000 in visa bonds in a new hardline immigration measure enacted late in Donald Trump's presidency.

site_title: South Korea unveils AI chip to maintain semiconductor leadership
summary: South Korea has unveiled an AI chip, the Sapeon X220, as part of its decade-long push to broaden its semiconductor dominance. The chip is designed to speed up servers for AI operations in mobile devices, drones, and self-driving vehicles. The move is part of the country's plan to invest over $1 trillion in AI and data-processing chips over the next decade. The chip is the first commercialized Korean ASIC for data centers and represents a push by the nation's largest carrier, SK Telecom, to expand beyond traditional mobile and broadband businesses.

images.alt_text: SK Telecom's Sapeon X220 is designed to speed up servers that cater to a growing number of mobile devices that perform better with AI.

site_title: Developing a trade portal to source for financing options
summary: Singapore E-Business (SGeBiz) is developing a trade portal to connect suppliers, buyers, and financiers, offering SMEs financing options in addition to its existing procurement-to-payment platform. The company has already launched a pilot project in Indonesia with Mastercard, N-Frnds, and Finastra, aiming to onboard 5,000 retailers by the end of 2021. SGeBiz is cautious about expansion due to the pandemic, focusing on strategic alignment with investors and expanding into Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Mr Nathan's background as a former member of the Republic of Singapore Air Force contributed to the company having a business continuity plan in place even before Covid-19 emerged.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' mandatory offer has turned unconditional as RMDV Investments, the bid vehicle, now controls over 50% of the firm's shares. DBS has formally approved taking over cash-strapped Indian bank Lakshmi Vilas Bank, injecting S$454 million to support the transaction. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Salesforce plans to buy Slack: report
summary: Salesforce plans to acquire corporate messaging platform Slack, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal. Slack's shares surged 32% after the announcement, while Salesforce's stock fell nearly 3%. The deal could value Slack at over $17 billion and set off a chain reaction of cloud software mergers in 2021. The acquisition could also position Salesforce as a competitor to Microsoft's Teams, a rival platform. This move follows Salesforce's previous acquisitions of MuleSoft and Tableau, and comes as remote working has gained cultural significance during the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: US software firm Salesforce plans to buy corporate messaging platform Slack, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, leading to a jump in stock prices for the young company.

site_title: Sunright's test of new ID rule vexes minorities
summary: Sunright, a Singapore-listed semiconductor firm, failed to read minority shareholders' sentiments at its annual general meeting, despite voting against reappointing long-serving Francis Lee as an independent director. The company redesignated Lee's role as a non-independent, non-executive director, citing his expertise and years of contribution. The move has deepened disenchantment among minority investors, who have questioned the firm's dividend policy and governance practices, citing a lack of transparency and a box-ticking compliance mindset.

site_title: Argentines mourn Maradona, 'the most human of Gods'
summary: Argentineans mourned the death of soccer legend Diego Maradona, who died at 60 from a heart attack. The country's favorite son, Maradona was seen as "the most human of Gods" by fans, who gathered at the Obelisk in Buenos Aires to pay their respects. President Alberto Fernandez declared three days of national mourning, and fans showed their grief with banners and tributes, including a play on Maradona's jersey number "D10S". The news fell on a nation already struggling with economic crisis and the pandemic, but soccer remains a source of comfort and solace.

images.alt_text: Stunned Argentines were plunged into grief on Wednesday by the death of the country's favourite son Diego Maradona, a sublimely gifted sporting hero they saw as "the most human of Gods."

site_title: UK restaurants offer DIY meal kits to survive lockdown
summary: UK restaurants are offering DIY meal kits to survive the lockdown, turning customers into cooks who recreate favorite meals at home. Michelin-starred restaurant Kitchen Table and Pizza Pilgrims are among those offering the kits, which range from £150 to £250 for two meals. The initiative has been successful, with Kitchen Table handling 80 home delivery orders per week and Pizza Pilgrims selling over 1,000 kits daily. The business models show promise for long-term survival despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Driving the world via data analytics, AI
summary: Azendian, a 5-year-old data analytics company, leverages machine learning to deliver solutions for educational institutions, buildings, and estates. Its modules predict student performance, resource allocation, and energy use, aiming to enhance educational outcomes and reduce carbon footprints. The company has seen a 25-30% increase in customers since the pandemic, and is now exploring a physical-virtual workforce to manage costs and expand its skilled resources. Azendian is currently in talks for a Series A-plus fundraising and plans to enter markets in South-east Asia and beyond, with a target initial public offering in five years.

site_title: Facebook struggles with US election disinformation
summary: Facebook continues to struggle with disinformation surrounding the US presidential election, with "super spreaders" - including Donald Trump Jr, Eric Trump, and conservative commentators - sharing unfounded claims of election fraud. These accounts have generated over 77 million likes, comments, and shares since November 3, according to a study by Avaaz. Despite increased efforts to stop the spread of disinformation, Facebook's algorithm has inadvertently helped these accounts reach a wider audience, and the platform remains criticized for its reluctance to take a more rigid stance on fact-checking.

images.alt_text: The US presidential election is finished: votes cast, the transition - though delayed - begun.

site_title: US GDP skyrockets by unrevised annual rate of 33.1% in Q3, matching estimates
summary: The US economy experienced a 33.1% surge in GDP in the third quarter, matching initial estimates, after a 31.4% decline in the second quarter. The report attributed the growth to upward revisions in non-residential fixed investment, exports, and consumer spending, while state and local government spending and private inventory investment were revised downward. Despite this, economists downgraded their GDP growth forecasts for the first quarter of 2021, citing rising Covid-19 infections and business restrictions.

site_title: Improved risk appetite keeps US dollar down
summary: The US dollar experienced losses due to improved risk appetite, triggered by progress in developing a Covid-19 vaccine and expectations for a fiscal boost from the new US government. The dollar teetered near a two-month low against the Australian and New Zealand dollars, while Bitcoin traded near an all-time high. Experts expect the US dollar to continue falling as the Federal Reserve prioritizes fiscal impact over monetary policy, with potential quantitative easing in December.

site_title: Eurokars Group donates new ambulance to TTSH, NCID
summary: Eurokars Group donated a new, fully-equipped ambulance to Tan Tock Seng Hospital and National Centre for Infectious Diseases, becoming the first private sector corporation to do so. The donation was made in response to the pandemic, with the hospital requiring 2,500 additional ambulance trips per month. The new ambulance will be used to shuttle patients within the hospital campus or to other hospitals for treatment, supporting patient movement.

site_title: Indonesia's maritime and fisheries minister nabbed by anti-graft body
summary: Indonesia's maritime and fisheries minister Edhy Prabowo was arrested by the country's anti-graft agency, Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), on Wednesday in connection with alleged corruption in the export of baby lobsters. He was detained along with 16 others, including private-sector individuals and government officials, at various locations in Jakarta. The arrests were part of a coordinated probe into the export of baby lobsters, which was banned until mid-2020 to replenish stocks. President Joko Widodo expressed support for the anti-graft body's work, despite concerns about its effectiveness during his presidency.

site_title: China set to be lone major economy to show growth this year
summary: China is expected to be the only major economy to show growth this year, with a predicted GDP growth rate of over 8%. The country's strong V-shaped recovery, driven by domestic demand, has been fueled by the severity of its lockdown and stringent measures to control the coronavirus. However, questions remain about the sustainability of the recovery, including concerns over inventories, bond defaults, and inflation. Despite these challenges, China's economy is outperforming other major economies, with foreign investors piling back in and domestic demand driving growth.

images.alt_text: China's over one billion consumers means that unlike smaller countries, it can afford to remain closed in the short term.

site_title: UK car output falls 18% in October amid Covid-19
summary: British car production fell 18.2% in October, with 110,179 vehicles rolled off assembly lines, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders. This brings total output for the first 10 months of the year down 33% to 743,003 vehicles. The decline is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and lockdown measures. The automotive sector is also awaiting clarity on trading terms with the European Union and faces a ban on new petrol and diesel car sales from 2030.

site_title: Singapore shares fall despite Wall Street advance
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, closing at 2,869.55, despite an advance on Wall Street where the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.5%. The benchmark Straits Times Index was hurt by a decline in advancers to decliners 288-227. The market was also affected by a decrease in investor optimism.

site_title: Gold falls from its all-time high on Covid-19 vaccine breakthrough
summary: Gold prices have dropped 12.8% from its all-time high of $2,074.70 in August, currently trading at around $1,823 an ounce. Despite this, long-term holders and central banks are expected to maintain and potentially increase their gold holdings due to concerns over monetary ease, inflation, and geopolitical uncertainty. Analysts, including Ross Norman, predict that gold will remain in a long-term bull market and could reach $2,000-$3,000 an ounce in the second half of next year.

site_title: Singapore shares decline as global rally cools; STI opens 0.6% lower
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times (STI) Index fell 18.34 points or 0.6% to 2,851.21 at the open on Thursday, following a mixed close on Wall Street overnight due to disappointing US economic data. Local shares ended in the red on Wednesday as investor optimism waned. Thai Beverage Public Co rose 2.1% and Rex International gained 5.2%, while Singtel, DBS, OCBC, and UOB declined. The US market saw a mixed finish, with the Nasdaq closing at a new high and the Dow shedding 0.6%.

site_title: Top Glove sinks to 2.5-month low on news of phased closure of its factories over Covid-19 spread
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest rubber glove maker, saw its shares sink to a 2.5-month low after announcing the phased closure of its factories due to a Covid-19 outbreak among over 2,400 workers. The company reported expected delivery delays and potential sales shortfalls, citing a 3% shortfall in projections for the 2021 financial year. The Malaysian government has ordered a full probe into Top Glove's working and housing conditions, described as deplorable by the Human Resource Minister.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust Q3 revenue drops by 7.5 per cent
summary: DASIN Retail Trust reported a 7.5% drop in Q3 revenue to Sept 30, 2020, compared to the same period last year. The decline was attributed to revenue excluding rental income.

site_title: HSA vendor that exposed blood donors' personal data fined S$120,000
summary: A Singaporean HSA vendor, Secur Solutions Group, has been fined S$120,000 for exposing the personal data of about 800,000 blood donors after it accidentally put the information online. The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) found that the company failed to secure its server, which was accessible through the Internet, and did not patch or update the system. The company had taken remedial actions after a cyber security specialist discovered the breach in March. The fine is the highest the PDPC can impose under the current law, which is set to be amended to allow for harsher fines.

site_title: Singapore's a small red dot, but a global node
summary: Singapore aims to become a global hub for technology, innovation, and finance, leveraging its small size to its advantage by promoting neutrality and attracting capital, talent, and cutting-edge technologies from around the world. The country has established a clear regulatory framework for digital tokens, and its innovative policies, such as the "regulatory sandbox" and TradeTrust, are expected to promote inclusive digital finance and digital trade. Singapore also plans to use its digital strengths to champion digital finance and trade globally, and has partnered with international organizations and tech startups to launch initiatives and promote financial democracy and inclusiveness.

site_title: Allianz-linked entity moves to buy stake in OUE Bayfront
summary: An entity linked to Allianz Real Estate is in exclusive due diligence to acquire a partial stake in OUE Bayfront, a prime Grade A office asset in Singapore, valued at around S$1.28 billion or S$3,200 psf. The deal, if successful, would see Allianz Real Estate, possibly acting on behalf of South Korea's National Pension Service, pick up a 50% stake in the asset. The acquisition would leverage Allianz's US$4.6 billion Asia-Pacific Core I fund, which targets equity investments in Singapore, Japan, and other regions.

site_title: JD Health plans to raise US$3.5b in HK's biggest IPO of 2020
summary: JD Health International Inc, a major Chinese online healthcare platform, plans to raise up to $3.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, valued at nearly $29 billion when a greenshoe option is included. The company, which is the largest online healthcare platform in China by revenue, aims to sell 381.9 million shares at a range of HK$62.80 and HK$70.58. Six cornerstone investors, including GIC, Tiger Global, and BlackRock, have taken up to $1.35 billion worth of stock in the deal, which is set to begin on Wednesday and end on Tuesday, December 8.

site_title: RBI nod for DBS' LVB takeover paves way for branch expansion: analysts
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, has received approval from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to take over Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB), a cash-strapped Indian bank. The merger will add 563 branches and over 2 million retail accounts to DBS India's operations, with DBS injecting 2,500 crore rupees to support the transaction. Analysts believe the deal will pave the way for DBS to expand its presence in India, despite concerns over LVB's governance issues and bad debt. The deal is seen as a small-scale takeover, with LVB's assets making up less than 1% of DBS's group assets.

site_title: US support of climate action under Biden may be a tipping point
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's plans to rejoin the Paris Agreement and achieve net zero emissions by 2050 may be a turning point in global climate action. The US withdrawal under President Trump led to a vacuum, with China and European countries stepping in. Biden's proposed $2 trillion investment plan aims to build a clean energy economy and create jobs. Global carbon dioxide emissions need to be cut by 45% by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050 to meet the 1.5 degree Celsius target. The Biden administration's climate action could bring the world "within striking distance" of the Paris Agreement's goal, according to Climate Action Tracker.

site_title: HK cuts stamp duty on commercial property
summary: Hong Kong's government has cut the extra stamp duty on commercial property purchases, aiming to revive the sluggish market, which has declined 62% since the start of the year. The levy, introduced in 2013 to cool the market, will be abolished for non-residential properties, while standard duty remains at 4.25%. This move follows previous measures, including a loan-to-value ratio increase, to stimulate transactions amid a recession and pandemic. The city's commercial property market is seeking recovery after a record slump.

images.alt_text: The extra levy of as much as 8.5 per cent of a property's value was introduced in 2013. Commercial deals will still be subject to a standard duty of as much as 4.25 per cent.

site_title: UOL chief joins plea to help genuine HDB upgraders with ABSD remission
summary: UOL Group CEO Liam Wee Sin has called for the government to grant additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) remission to genuine first-time HDB upgraders buying private condos, similar to EC buyers. This would help ease their cash flow and address logistics of finding interim accommodation. Wee Sin believes the policy tweak would promote the aspirations of Singaporeans and make logical sense, given the demand for private condos from HDB upgraders.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of UOL's Clavon, situated along Clementi Avenue 1. The 640-unit development has a pair of 37-storey-tall towers housing 1 to 5-bedroom units. Prices start at S$1,475 per sq ft.
UOL group CEO Liam Wee Sin says the current market is stable, and estimates 2020's total new-home sales to be at 9,000-10,000 units.

site_title: ThaiBev full-year profit dips 2% to 22.75b baht
summary: ThaiBev's full-year profit dropped 2% to 22.75 billion baht due to the pandemic's impact on Thailand's beverage industry. Revenue fell 5.2% to 253.48 billion baht, with the food business segment recording a net loss of 38 million baht. However, the spirits segment remained resilient, with a 15.4% increase in net profit to 21.94 billion baht. The company proposed a final dividend of 0.36 baht per share, down from 0.48 baht previously.

site_title: Wider shared framework will cut quarantine
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing called for a shared framework for safe travel among countries to reduce the need for long-term quarantine periods disrupting business travel. He believes this would be a competitive advantage for countries globally, supporting the tourism industry. Business travel, including Mice events, is essential for Singapore's regional hub position and generates more benefits for the economy. Industry experts agree, citing the potential for a significant improvement in business travel and the need for digitalization and reskilling of staff to revive the hospitality sector.

site_title: Logistics players ramp up for booster shot from Covid vaccines
summary: Logistics companies are preparing for the distribution of Covid-19 vaccines by enhancing their cold chain capabilities. Many firms are investing in upgrading their supply chains and last-mile delivery systems to meet the logistical demands of vaccine distribution. This move is seen as a significant opportunity for the industry, with companies positioning themselves for success in the market.

site_title: China construction machinery industry expects sales to rise 15%
summary: China's construction machinery industry expects sales to rise 15% this year, driven by a building spree to bolster the economy following the Covid-19 pandemic. The growth is attributed to unexpectedly robust sales of excavators. However, industry executives warn that any slowdown in Beijing's infrastructure investment drive could impact sales, which are expected to continue until early next year.

site_title: Australia's investment in forging closer regional ties
summary: Australia has reaffirmed its commitment to regional ties, particularly with South-east Asia, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced A$500 million in investment to support vaccine access, health security, and regional recovery. This includes funding for the Asean Centre for Public Health Emergencies and Emerging Diseases and A$24 million to the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria. Additionally, Australia is investing A$46 million in the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and A$232 million in the Mekong region to support economic integration and development.

site_title: SPH Reit to maintain its acquisition approach
summary: SPH Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, will maintain its acquisition approach despite the pandemic's disruption to the retail real estate market. The trust will continue to exercise care and consider opportunities, prioritizing Singapore-based assets. Its Australian acquisitions, Figtree Grove and Westfield Marion Shopping Centres, were made with a minority joint venture partner and local property manager to ensure alignment of interests. The trust's manager stated that it actively participates in day-to-day management and values its role as a co-owner.

site_title: ECB-backed body studies Euribor exit for 180t euros in assets
summary: A European Central Bank-backed committee is exploring options for a transition if Euribor, a cornerstone of the EU's financial system, ceases to exist. The committee is testing fallback provisions to help the market shift away from Euribor, using methodologies based on the euro short-term rate, ESTR. While there are no plans to discontinue Euribor, regulators are focusing on reform rather than scrapping the benchmark. The ECB has already begun phasing in ESTR, which is preferred due to its more robust trading and lower susceptibility to corruption.

site_title: Business travel still low, stay-home notice a hurdle
summary: Singapore's essential business travel remains low despite the Ministry of Trade and Industry's moves to pilot larger-scale meetings and exhibitions. The number of non-resident visitors for such activities remains low, with only 65 foreign delegates from 14 countries attending the TravelRevive trade show this week. The recovery in visitor arrivals is expected to be gradual due to stay-home notice rules and quarantine measures, and the government's reliance on negative Covid-19 test results for arrivals.

site_title: In touch with nature
summary: People are reconnecting with nature through biophilic design, incorporating green spaces in condominiums and restaurants to boost mental well-being. The National Gallery in Singapore is showcasing a retrospective of Georgette Chen's life and work, highlighting her as a visual arts pioneer. Meanwhile, Fong Chak Ka shares his journey in taking the family restaurant business to the next level, and the memoirs of Leonard Lauder are reviewed, detailing his mother Estee Lauder's beauty business success.

site_title: IBM planning 10,000 job cuts in Europe ahead of unit sale
summary: IBM plans to cut approximately 10,000 jobs in Europe, affecting around 20% of its staff, as part of its efforts to lower costs and prepare for a spinoff of its slow-growth services unit. The UK and Germany will be most impacted, with cuts also planned in Poland, Slovakia, Italy, and Belgium. The job cuts are part of IBM's efforts to simplify and streamline its business, with the goal of completing the spinoff as a tax-free spinoff to shareholders by the end of 2021.

site_title: Harnessing strength, resources to support one another during crisis
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, Singaporean businesses innovated and led by example to support each other and the community. The Company of Good, a group of organisations nationally recognised as Champions of Good 2020, collaborated across sectors to create greater social impact. Companies like Abry, Boxgreen, and Mitsubishi Electric Asia showcased their commitment to CSR, sustainability, and community service. Through partnerships and initiatives, these businesses demonstrated the importance of collaboration and collective action in addressing societal and environmental challenges. By working together, they aim to create a better, more sustainable world for all.

site_title: Reimagining the supply chain in a post-pandemic world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the weaknesses of the modern supply chain, disrupting industries and businesses worldwide. To build back better, businesses must rethink their supply chain structures to avoid future disruptions. A digital supply chain model provides end-to-end visibility, enabling proactive actions to remedy potential bottlenecks and disruptions. Visibility and agility are key to supply chain resiliency, allowing businesses to make informed decisions and quickly adapt to changing dynamics. By adopting a digital supply chain, businesses can reduce operational costs and become more resilient in the face of future disruptions.

site_title: US Q3 home prices gain most on record as low rates drive demand
summary: US home prices surged 3.1% in Q3, the largest gain on record since 1991, driven by record-low mortgage rates and a surge in demand. Compared to 2019, prices rose 7.8%. The housing market has boomed during the pandemic, fueled by cheaper borrowing costs and a desire for more space. Low inventory of houses for sale also contributed to the gains, with the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index rising 6.6% from a year earlier in 20 metropolitan areas. Demand remains strong, despite economic uncertainty from Covid-19.

site_title: Twitter to revive controversial account verification system
summary: Twitter plans to revive its account verification system in early 2021, allowing users to request verification for a coveted blue check mark. To qualify, accounts must be active, notable, and associated with a prominent individual or brand. Six initial types of accounts will qualify, including government, companies, news, and entertainment organizations. Twitter is seeking public feedback on the requirements for the verification process.

site_title: Sunak warns of 2.6m unemployed as UK faces historic recession
summary: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak warned the UK will experience its deepest recession in over 300 years due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 2.6 million unemployed. Sunak stated the government's priority is to protect people's lives and livelihoods, as the health emergency is not yet over. The UK's economic emergency has only just begun, and the Chancellor's spending plans aim to address this challenge.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to acquire logistics park in Italy for 52.6m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has agreed to acquire a logistics park in Italy for 52.6 million euros (S$84.2 million), adding 10% to its portfolio's net lettable area. The freehold intermodal logistics park has 156,888 sq m of net lettable area and is 99% leased to 24 different occupiers, including Spinservice and Tod's. The acquisition is expected to generate stable cash flows and increase Cromwell E-Reit's exposure to the logistics sector, with a net operating income yield of 7.4%.

site_title: Negative bond yield arrives in S'pore with UOB's 1b-euro issue
summary: UOB has successfully issued a 1 billion-euro covered bond, marking the first negative-yielding bond in Singapore. The deal achieved a tight seven-year spread and was subscribed twice over, with investors including European pension funds and USD-based investors seeking a positive yield. The issuance is the largest euro-denominated covered bond from Singapore and the deepest negative-yielding covered bond in Asia-Pacific. UOB hit cost savings of 27 basis points, allowing it to lengthen its debt tenor in a cost-efficient manner.

site_title: China's Xi congratulates Biden on US election victory
summary: China's President Xi Jinping congratulated US President-elect Joe Biden on winning the 2020 US presidential election, expressing hope for the "healthy and stable development" of bilateral relations. Chinese Vice President Wang Qishan also congratulated Biden's running mate Kamala Harris. The congratulatory messages were reported by the official Xinhua news agency.

site_title: Pandemic a surprise boon for women in world's back office
summary: India's technology services industry, worth $200 billion, has seen a shift towards flexible work arrangements due to the pandemic, benefiting women who previously faced job losses and childcare challenges. New rules have allowed employees to work from home permanently, and companies like WNS and Tata Consultancy Services are embracing a hybrid model with satellite offices and gig workers. This change is expected to bring more women into the workforce, with Tata Consultancy's "25-by-25" strategy aiming to reduce office presence to 25% by 2025, and potentially 100 million women with secondary degrees finding employment.

site_title: Code is law and law is code - can Blockchain be without ethics?
summary: Blockchain technology's potential impact on daily life raises concerns about ethics. The technology's cultural attitudes and social issues will involve ethical considerations. Despite this, companies are not prioritizing ethical literacy, as seen in a recent class on emerging technologies and the law. The development of smart contracts powered by AI is a notable example. As Blockchain adoption grows, its implications on businesses and society must be considered, including the need for ethical considerations as part of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) practices.

site_title: Malaysia proposes changes to KL-Singapore High Speed Rail, Singapore remains committed to project
summary: Malaysia has proposed changes to the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) Project, which Singapore remains committed to. The changes will be discussed in good faith with Malaysia, with a deadline of December 31, 2020, to conclude discussions. If Malaysia does not proceed with the project, it will bear the costs incurred by Singapore in fulfilling the HSR Bilateral Agreement. Singapore remains committed to the project, which it believes is beneficial for both countries.

site_title: Boeing's grounded 737 Max gets tentative nod from European regulator
summary: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has published a proposed airworthiness directive for Boeing's 737 Max, paving the way for the aircraft's return to service. The 28-day public consultation will determine if the changes made by Boeing are sufficient for safe flight. If approved, the Max could return to service globally by early 2021, following the FAA's recent clearance. EU approval would also help build support for the aircraft outside the US, after the Max crisis damaged the FAA's reputation.

site_title: Corporate America's deal with the devil
summary: Thirty top US CEOs met to discuss US President Donald Trump's claims of election fraud, aiming to ensure a peaceful transition of power. The executives sought to leverage their influence to calm the situation, with some feeling a potential coup was overblown. Business leaders, however, emphasized the importance of liberal democracy and the need for an end to election turmoil. Many big business groups had previously supported the Trump administration's policies, sparking criticism that their concern was "too little, too late".

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as labour market recovery slows
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones rising 12.63 points to 30,058.87, and the S&P 500 opening flat at 3,635.50. The Nasdaq Composite gained 17.11 points to 12,053.89. The labor market recovery is slowing, with a surprise jump in weekly jobless claims, amid a surge in Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Thai protesters call on king to give up control of royal fortune
summary: Thai protesters are calling on King Maha Vajiralongkorn to relinquish control of a royal fortune valued in the tens of billions of dollars. The protesters, who have broken a taboo by criticizing the king, are demanding greater accountability under the constitution. The king's 23% stake in the Siam Commercial Bank has sparked controversy, with protesters arguing that the shares should be managed by the finance ministry rather than the king. The palace has remained silent on the issue, while the government has defended its use of charges against protest leaders, citing the need to maintain order.

site_title: Despite pandemic, Thailand is set to lead the region with 30 IPOs
summary: Thailand is expected to lead the region with 30 initial public offerings (IPOs) by the end of 2020, according to the Stock Exchange of Thailand's president, Pakorn Peetathawatchai. This would be a record-breaking year in terms of new IPO valuations. In 2021, the bourse anticipates another 30 new listings, including "two or three big" listings. This positive outlook suggests a strong market performance despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Thai protesters call on king to give up royal fortune
summary: Thai protesters have called on King Maha Vajiralongkorn to give up control of a royal fortune valued in the tens of billions of dollars, amid months of demonstrations focused on the monarchy. The protesters, who have broken a taboo by criticizing the king, face charges of insulting the monarchy, which can result in up to 15 years in prison. The protesters seek to make the king more accountable under the constitution and reverse changes that gave him personal control of army units and crown assets estimated to be worth over $30 billion.

site_title: Half of labour force in big US cities working from home
summary: About half of the labor force in major US cities is working from home, with 37% of employees teleworking between late October and early November, according to the US Census Bureau's Household Pulse Survey. Rates vary by city, with tech-heavy San Francisco at 56.2% and the nation's capital area at 55.6%. Nearly two-thirds of US employees who have worked from home during the pandemic want to continue doing so due to personal preference or concerns about catching Covid-19.

site_title: US trade gap widens as imports rise to highest in a year
summary: The US merchandise-trade deficit widened to $80.3 billion in October, the highest in over a year, as imports rose 2.2% to $206.3 billion and exports increased 2.8% to $126 billion. The data suggests the trade imbalance will not narrow as previously hoped, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic's disruption to supply chains and demand. Retail inventories climbed 0.8% and wholesale inventories advanced 0.9% in October, ahead of the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Financial sector claims for dispute resolution up 18%
summary: The Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre (FIDReC) in Singapore received 18% more claims in the 2020 financial year, with 1,227 total claims, a third consecutive year exceeding 1,000. Complaints against general insurers increased 21% and travel insurance claims rose significantly. FIDReC concluded 89% of claims within six months, with 52% settled through mediation. The majority of claims involved disputes on liability, with 79% against general insurers and 47% against life insurers.

site_title: Eurozone house prices set for reality check as pandemic bites: ECB
summary: Eurozone house prices are expected to face a reality check due to the pandemic-induced recession, according to the European Central Bank. Despite rising 5% in the first half of 2020, prices may decline due to declining GDP, consumer confidence, and employment expectations. The ECB warns of stretched valuations, particularly in Luxembourg, and concerns over ballooning government debt in southern Europe. Banks have already tightened credit access, and demand is easing, leading to a less rosy outlook for residential property prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 19.19 points to 1,597.58 on Wednesday, driven by a gain of 653 stocks to 496 losers. The index closed with a volume of 8.910 billion lots worth RM4.223 billion.

site_title: Chinese buyers look to cancel US soybean orders as processing margins shrink
summary: Chinese soybean importers and processors are considering canceling US soybean orders for December and January shipments due to shrinking processing margins following a surge in Chicago futures prices. This marks a slowdown in Chinese demand after a five-month buying spree, which contributed to a record increase in benchmark Chicago futures since the crop year began. The move is largely driven by small private importers who bought US soybeans without setting prices in the futures market, as the current prices would result in losses.

site_title: US core capital goods orders beat expectations in October
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 0.7% in October, beating expectations of a 0.5% increase, but momentum is slowing as economic growth is expected to slow in the fourth quarter. Shipments of core capital goods jumped 2.3% in October, while durable goods orders rose 1.3% after a 2.1% increase in September. The economy grew at a 33.1% rate in the July-September quarter, but growth estimates for the fourth quarter are below a 5% rate.

site_title: York Capital to spin off US$2.7b Asia hedge fund firm
summary: York Capital Management plans to spin off its US$2.7 billion Asia hedge fund firm, MY Alpha Management, in 2022. The new firm will be led by Hong Kong-based regional chief investment officer Masahiko Yamaguchi and will retain York's Asia-based employees. The move is part of York's exit from most of its hedge fund business, amid a global hedge fund industry experiencing the fewest new funds in 20 years. MY Alpha has returned an annualized 12% since Yamaguchi took charge in 2014, and York will retain a "meaningful" economic interest in the new firm.

site_title: East Coast pre-war bungalow for sale with S$19m guide price
summary: A conservation bungalow in Singapore's East Coast area is for sale with a guide price of S$19 million. The 1932 art deco-style home, restored in 2009, features five ensuite bedrooms, a covered patio, and a 12-meter lap pool. The property spans 10,712 sq ft and is supported by brick piers, with parking space for up to five cars. The bungalow is within walking distance to Tao Nan School, Parkway Parade mall, and the upcoming Marine Parade MRT station, slated for completion in 2023.

site_title: DBS' Lakshmi Vilas Bank deal gets formal nod from India's central bank
summary: DBS Bank has received formal approval from India's central bank to acquire Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB) through a proposed scheme. The amalgamation will be effective as of November 27, with DBS injecting 2,500 crore rupees into its Indian unit. The deal will see DBS take over LVB's deposits, advances, branches, and employees. DBS will also absorb LVB's network of 563 branches and over two million retail accounts.

site_title: Indonesia's coal gasification programme needs subsidy: industry experts
summary: Indonesia's coal gasification program to produce liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) substitute dimethyl ether (DME) is facing challenges due to high production costs. Industry experts, including Cirebon Power and PT Adaro Power, suggest that the government should subsidize the production of DME to make it economically viable. The estimated cost of DME production is nearly twice the price of imported LPG, making it unfeasible without government support. The government aims to reduce LPG imports and create jobs in the downstream coal industry, but experts recommend alternative solutions, such as transitioning households to electric stoves.

site_title: ViacomCBS selling Simon & Schuster to Penguin Random House for US$2.18b
summary: ViacomCBS is selling its publishing unit Simon & Schuster to Penguin Random House for $2.18 billion in cash. The deal, expected to close in 2021, marks a significant shift in the publishing landscape. Simon & Schuster, home to authors such as Stephen King and Barack Obama, will remain a separate entity under Penguin Random House's umbrella. The sale will allow ViacomCBS to focus on streaming and debt reduction, with proceeds used for strategic growth priorities. The deal must first receive approval from US competition regulators.

site_title: IT firm Tata Consultancy Services offers SGUnited traineeships to 100 fresh graduates
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) has offered 100 SGUnited traineeships to fresh graduates in Singapore, with 75 already benefiting from the program. The nine-month traineeship aims to develop industry-relevant skills and boost employability in the post-coronavirus economy. Trainees will receive foundational and specialized training in areas like cloud adoption, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity, with opportunities to work on projects with TCS clients and be considered for full-time positions. The company has also launched a new digital acceleration centre in Singapore to provide training opportunities and technological solutions for businesses.

site_title: Hot stock: Top Glove sinks to 2.5-month low on workers' Covid-19 outbreak, factory shutdowns
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest rubber glove maker, saw its stock price drop to a 2.5-month low due to a Covid-19 outbreak among over 2,400 factory workers and subsequent factory shutdowns. The Malaysian government has ordered a full probe into the company's working and housing conditions, described as deplorable by Human Resource Minister M Saravanan. The company expects delivery delays and sales to fall short of projections for the 2021 financial year, with some deliveries potentially delayed by four weeks.

site_title: High Court dismisses Singapore firm's bid to release millions to pare Wirecard 'loans'
summary: The Singapore High Court has dismissed a bid by oCap Management, a firm linked to Wirecard, to release millions of seized funds to repay "loans" and cover expenses. The court rejected oCap's motion, stating that the company had failed to show it was necessary to release the funds under the law. oCap had claimed the seized funds were for staff salaries, taxes, and other expenses, but the prosecution argued that the company had access to "sizeable revenue streams" that it had not accounted for. The decision comes as oCap is being investigated for suspected falsification of accounts and has been linked to a $1 billion "funnelled to opaque partner companies" under the guise of unsecured loans.

site_title: Malaysia's Top Glove sees supply shortages boosting latex glove prices
summary: Malaysia's Top Glove Corp, the world's largest latex glove maker, expects supply shortages due to a Covid-19 outbreak among its workers to boost prices of medical rubber gloves. The company has shut some factories and erected barbed wire fences to screen and quarantine workers, with 40% of its production capacity affected. Despite this, the Malaysian Rubber Glove Manufacturers Association says there won't be a disruption to supply, citing new capacity available to make up for the shortfall.
