site_title: Dairy's latest entrant in snack wars: ice cream with vegetables
summary: The dairy industry is introducing new products to appeal to younger consumers, particularly ice cream infused with vegetables, as sales have declined in recent years. An innovation competition hosted by the California Milk Advisory Board and VentureFuel resulted in the winner, which will help the industry shift consumer focus from traditional snacks to dairy products. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to increased demand for dairy products, with sales rising 10-fold in direct-to-consumer business, but it remains to be seen if this trend will be sustained.

site_title: Covid-19 testing of Tekka Centre stallholders to be conducted on Thursday: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore will conduct COVID-19 testing for Tekka Centre stallholders on Thursday. This is part of the community surveillance testing rollout. There were 7 new imported cases reported, bringing the total to 58,190. No new community cases were reported for the 15th day in a row, the longest stretch since the first case was reported in January. 12 cases have been discharged, with 58,076 fully recovered patients.

site_title: US jobless claims post first back-to-back increases
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly rose for a second straight week, with initial claims increasing by 30,000 to 778,000 in the week ended Nov 21, according to Labor Department data. The consecutive increases suggest a new wave of layoffs due to soaring coronavirus cases and fresh lockdowns. Continuing claims fell by 299,000 to 6.07 million, but the number of Americans on extended assistance programs continued to rise. Economists predict a contraction for the first quarter, with the job market facing additional hurdles due to state and city restrictions.

site_title: Deutsche Bank weighs move to two-days-a-week remote working
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering a new policy allowing most employees to work from home two days a week, a move influenced by the coronavirus pandemic. The bank is still awaiting regulatory approval and will likely implement different policies for various staff and countries due to concerns about confidentiality and enforcement. The decision comes as lawmakers in several countries finalize new remote-work legislation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish on a positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.31% to 26,669.75, driven by positive vaccine news and easing US political uncertainty. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.74%.

site_title: Japan PM Suga trips up with messy reversal on tourism campaign
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's decision to partially pause a domestic travel campaign amid rising COVID-19 cases has sparked criticism, potentially harming his support and chances of a long-term tenure. The reversal, made after Suga initially insisted the campaign would go ahead, was seen as too little, too late and risked leaving him with an image of a leader who is stubborn and indecisive. Suga's ratings are expected to decline, with critics arguing that he prioritizes the economy over public health.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE downgrades DBS, OCBC, UOB to 'sell' on 'unsustainable' rally
summary: Maybank KE downgraded the Singapore banking trio, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, to "sell" due to an "unsustainable" rally. Analyst Thilan Wickramasinghe cited concerns over rising non-performing loans, under pressure net interest margins, and dividend caps. The banks' recent 20% climb since end-October is seen as overdone, with NPLs expected to rise to 2.1% in 2021. The analyst prefers Singapore Exchange's stock, citing market volatility and structural trends driving demand for its risk management products.

site_title: Emirates sees 2022 return of jumbo A380s as travel recovers
summary: Emirates predicts a sharp recovery in air travel demand in 2022, driven by the distribution of coronavirus vaccines. The airline's president, Tim Clark, expects the full fleet of jumbo Airbus A380 jets to return to service by early 2022, with three new aircraft set to be delivered by the end of the year. Clark notes that the cost of storing and maintaining the A380 fleet has been "very expensive" for Emirates, which has seen a significant loss due to the pandemic. The airline's optimism contrasts with the industry's overall outlook, which estimates a record $157 billion loss for carriers this year and next.

site_title: Google must disclose emails in Russian oligarch's divorce
summary: A US judge ordered Google to disclose emails of Temur Akhmedov, son of Russian oligarch Farkhad Akhmedov, to his former wife Tatiana in a £450 million divorce judgment. The emails were sought to determine if Temur assisted his father in transferring assets to avoid paying the London court's judgment. Google argued that US law prohibits disclosing email contents without user consent, but the judge ruled that Temur had consented to the disclosure. The ruling does not set a precedent for compelled disclosure of user content in discovery proceedings.

site_title: Hin Leong founder OK Lim denies HSBC's forgery claim
summary: Oil tycoon OK Lim, founder of troubled Singaporean oil trader Hin Leong, denies allegations by HSBC that he used forged documents to obtain financing, worth US$85.3 million. Lim claims the documents were "mistakenly" issued and he wasn't aware of the process. He and his family, as well as a Hin Leong employee, deny the accusation. HSBC's suit comes amid the company's biggest commodities trading scandal, with creditors battling to recover funds from the insolvent firm.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose in opening deals on Wednesday, with the FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 6,442.80 points, while the DAX 30 index rose 0.2% to 13,312.07 points and the CAC 40 added 0.3% to 5,574.26 points. This follows a rally in Asian markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite US-EU trade tensions. The gains are attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust Q3 revenue down 7.5%
summary: DASIN Retail Trust reported a 7.5% decline in revenue for the third quarter ended Sept 30, excluding rental income from certain malls. The trustee-manager attributed this to the exclusion of revenue from newly acquired malls and the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on 4% of the Trust's gross rental income. Despite this, the portfolio occupancy remained at 96.1%. The Trust is in active negotiations to refinance debt maturing in January next year and will continue to optimise the tenant mix to mitigate the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: UOB issued one billion euros in 0.01% covered bonds, two times subscribed. Minister Chan Chun Sing urged countries to adopt a shared travel protocol to reduce quarantine periods. UOL Group CEO Liam Wee Sin said demand for private residential market is genuine, particularly from HDB upgraders. The mandatory offer for Lum Chang Holdings turned unconditional with 51.8% stake. Cromwell E-Reit acquired an Italian logistics park for 52.6m euros. Singapore shares fell 0.8% due to Wall Street's advance.

site_title: Amazon will conduct counterfeit inspections with US agency
summary: Amazon is partnering with the National Intellectual Property Rights Coordination Center to conduct inspections of suspected counterfeit goods at US ports of entry. The initiative, Operation Fulfilled Action, aims to prevent counterfeit products from entering the US supply chain. Amazon has been working to combat counterfeit products, including the creation of its Counterfeit Crimes Unit, and has reported that 99.9% of products viewed by customers do not have a valid counterfeit complaint. The partnership with the government agency will help Amazon to more effectively identify and remove fake goods from its platform.

site_title: Singapore shares fall despite Wall Street advance; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 2,869.55, despite a 1.5% gain on Wall Street. The decline was attributed to waning investor optimism, with Asian markets mostly ending in the green. Notable advancers included Singapore Airlines and Nanofilm Technologies, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings were among the biggest losers. Analysts expect markets to struggle to push on from here, with potential month-end selling pressure and a shift towards profit- and loss-defensive strategies in December.

site_title: Green is good for power traders chasing US$430b market
summary: Power traders are flocking to Europe's $430 billion power market as governments push for renewable energy and electrification, creating new opportunities for profit. The market is expected to nearly double in size over the next decade, with traders earning six-figure salaries and guaranteed compensation ranging from $2 million to $3 million. Companies like Royal Dutch Shell and BP are expanding their power trading operations, while Denmark is emerging as a hub for short-term trading. The shift is driven by the need for complex data analysis and programming skills, and is seen as a key element in the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: China vaccine maker applies for public use of Covid shot
summary: A leading Chinese vaccine developer, China National Biotec Group (CNBG), has applied to Chinese regulators for public use of its Covid-19 shot. The application, submitted by Sinopharm's vice-general manager Shi Shengyi, is based on interim data from Phase III human testing in the Middle East and South America. The move is seen as a bid to get a head start on Western rivals in the race for a Covid-19 vaccine, with Sinopharm's Hong Kong unit experiencing a surge in stocks following the announcement.

images.alt_text: China National Biotec Group (CNBG) has submitted an application to Chinese regulators, reported state media Xinhua Finance on Wednesday, citing parent company Sinopharm's vice-general manager Shi Shengyi. The application likely includes interim data from the company's Phase III human testing conducted in the Middle East and South America.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher tracking US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, following US rallies, as investors took heart from receding US political uncertainty. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.50% to 26,296.86, while the Topix index advanced 0.30% to 1,767.67. This upward trend was attributed to the US stock market's gains, which saw the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday as investors took heart from rallies on Wall Street thanks to receding US political uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by vaccine optimism and a record lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.87% to 26,819.96, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.43% and 0.14%, respectively. The rally follows a strong performance on US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rallied at the open Wednesday morning, extending their winning streak into a fourth day as investors tracked another record lead from Wall Street fuelled by vaccine optimism.

site_title: Philippine Airlines plans court protection as pandemic hits finances
summary: Philippine Airlines plans to seek court protection from creditors as it battles financial losses due to the pandemic. The airline, which reported a net loss of 28.9 billion pesos in January to September, has already reduced 2,700 jobs and halted operations in March. The company is pursuing debt restructuring with government help, but no details on the assistance needed have been disclosed. As of end-September, Philippine Airlines had 198 billion pesos in lease and long-term debts.

site_title: South Korea unveils AI chip to maintain semiconductor leadership
summary: South Korea unveiled the Sapeon X220 AI chip, designed to speed up servers for mobile devices and self-driving vehicles. The chip is part of the country's decade-long push to expand its semiconductor dominance, with a focus on data-processing chips and 5G wireless networks. The government has invested over 600 billion won in chip development, with plans to invest another trillion won over the next decade to automate factories and improve competitiveness. The Sapeon X220 is the latest product in South Korea's efforts to maintain its semiconductor leadership in the global tech market.

site_title: Help genuine HDB upgrader with ABSD remission: UOL chief
summary: UOL Group CEO Liam Wee Sin urged the government to grant additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) remission to genuine first-time HDB upgraders to private condos, allowing them six months to sell their HDB homes. Demand for private residential market is genuine, mainly from HDB upgraders seeking better living conditions. This move aims to support genuine buyers and alleviate the financial burden of ABSD payment.

site_title: China weighs legal steps against 'diehard' supporters of Taiwan independence
summary: China is considering a blacklist of "diehard" supporters of Taiwan independence, which may lead to legal steps against President Tsai Ing-wen and other senior Taiwanese officials. The list is aimed at a small number of independence supporters and those who fund them, according to China's Taiwan Affairs Office. Beijing plans to "severely punish" those on the list under the 2005 Anti-Secession Law and national security legislation, but it's unclear how this will play out due to lack of jurisdiction in Taiwan. Taiwan has condemned the plan, calling it a threat to democracy.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as Biden transition, vaccine cheer lift risk assets
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,683.300 points, driven by the start of US President-elect Joe Biden's transition and optimism over coronavirus vaccine progress, which is expected to lead to a swift economic revival.

images.alt_text: Australia shares finished higher on Wednesday, lifted by the formal start of US President-elect Joe Biden's transition to the White House and as investors also expect a swift economic revival on coronavirus vaccine progress.

site_title: Payments startup Stripe seeks funding at more than US$70b valuation
summary: Stripe, a payments startup, is in talks to raise a new funding round valuing it higher than its last private valuation of US$36 billion, potentially over US$70 billion. The company, founded by Irish brothers John and Patrick Collison, has benefited from the pandemic's shift to e-commerce and recently expanded into Africa. Stripe has over 2,500 employees and 14 global offices. Talks are at an early stage, and there's no guarantee the funding round will be completed. A representative for Stripe declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Indonesian minister among 17 arrested in corruption probe
summary: Indonesian Minister Edhy Prabowo and 16 others were arrested by the Corruption Eradication Commission in a simultaneous operation related to alleged corruption in the export of baby lobsters. The minister and his wife, a lawmaker, were detained at a Jakarta airport upon their return from the US. The arrests are part of an ongoing investigation into the export of lobster larvae, which was banned to replenish stocks. President Joko Widodo expressed support for the anti-graft body, but concerns have been raised about the clout of the agency during his presidency.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's maritime and fisheries minister was arrested on Wednesday by the country's anti-graft agency, among 17 people detained in simultaneous swoops as part of a probe into alleged corruption in the export of baby lobsters.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam says restoring 'political system from chaos' is priority
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam stated that restoring the city's constitutional order and "political system from chaos" is the government's top priority. This comes after months of pro-democracy protests and the imposition of a security law by the Chinese government. Lam made the announcement in her annual policy address, following talks with Beijing on economic recovery. The central government's role in Hong Kong has been a subject of controversy, particularly with regards to the security law and Lam's request for China's assistance.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam said on Wednesday the government's urgent priority was to restore the Chinese-ruled city's constitutional order and its "political system from chaos".

site_title: Digital B2B lender Cash-IN-Asia bags S$5m funding in DeClout-led round
summary: Cash-IN-Asia, a Singapore-based digital B2B lender, has secured S$5 million in funding from DeClout-led round. The platform, which operates a fully digital financing platform for micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in the Asia-Pacific, aims to provide access to business financing for underserved MSMEs. With AI-powered data analytics, the platform can onboard clients with limited track records and review their credit profiles to build credit history. The funding will support the startup's expansion into Malaysia and the rest of South-east Asia within the next year.

site_title: Hong Kong cuts stamp duty on commercial property amid slump
summary: Hong Kong's government has abolished an extra stamp duty on commercial property purchases, effective Thursday, in an effort to revive the lackluster market. The 8.5% levy, introduced in 2013, will be replaced by a standard 4.25% duty. This measure, combined with a previous loan-to-value ratio increase, aims to stimulate transactions amid a recession and pandemic. The decision is the latest in a series of government efforts to boost the property market.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong government is scrapping an extra stamp duty levied on commercial property purchases in an effort to bring the lacklustre market back to life.

site_title: SPH Reit says it will maintain its approach to acquisitions
summary: SPH Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, will maintain its approach to acquisitions despite the pandemic's disruption to the retail market. The manager stated that while the market presents opportunities, it will exercise caution due to uncertainty. The Reit's portfolio will remain primarily Singapore-based, and it has not set a targeted capital allocation by geography. SPH Reit has successfully invested in Australian retail malls, including Figtree Grove Shopping Centre and Westfield Marion Shopping Centre, with a local property manager overseeing day-to-day operations.

site_title: AI startup Pulsifi raises US$1.8m in angel funding to boost Europe expansion
summary: AI startup Pulsifi has raised US$1.8 million in angel funding to boost its expansion into European markets and enhance its product offerings. The funding, part of its total US$4 million investment, will focus on strengthening its platform's predictive capabilities to improve talent acquisition and management for enterprises. With a strategic partnership with SAP SuccessFactors, Pulsifi aims to expand its market coverage from South-east Asia to Europe, leveraging its people data platform to predict outcomes and enhance quality and efficiency in talent management.

site_title: New venture firm The-Wolfpack on the hunt for Asia-Pacific consumer startups
summary: A new venture firm, The-Wolfpack, has launched a fund targeting early-stage consumer startups in the Asia-Pacific region. The Wolfpack Pioneer VCC, its debut fund, is fully subscribed with a US$5 million investment and will focus on direct-to-consumer sector startups. The team plans to deploy investments in eight to 10 companies and is considering expanding into Thailand. A second fund, targeting over S$20 million, is in the pipeline, and the firm aims to bring portfolio companies and invest in early-stage startups in Thailand.

site_title: Boeing's 737 MAX gets tentative nod from European regulator
summary: The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has published a proposed airworthiness directive, paving the way for Boeing's 737 MAX to return to service in Europe. The directive, which will be subject to a 28-day public consultation, requires changes to the aircraft's design and functionality. EASA's executive director, Patrick Ky, has expressed confidence in the aircraft's safety, stating that a thorough review has been conducted. The move is seen as a major step towards the global return of the 737 MAX, with Boeing expecting to begin deliveries to European customers in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Europe's aviation safety regulator kicked off the process of bringing Boeing's 737 MAX back into service, in a major step toward the grounded jet's global return.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.22% and the Topix index advancing 1.08%. The rally followed US political uncertainty receding, boosting investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday as investors took heart from rallies on Wall Street, thanks to receding US political uncertainty.

site_title: Trump planning to pardon ex-aide Flynn: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to pardon former national security advisor Michael Flynn, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his Russian contacts, according to US media. Flynn's secret talks with the Russian ambassador in 2016 were a key part of the Mueller investigation. The Justice Department withdrew its case against Flynn in May, but a federal judge has demanded a judicial review. A pardon would take the matter out of the courts, following Trump's claim that the investigation was a "witch hunt."

site_title: Bank of Japan digital currency will help boost cryptocurrency trading: Monex head
summary: The Bank of Japan's plan to issue a central bank digital currency (CBDC) is expected to boost cryptocurrency trading by providing a more convenient platform for converting cryptocurrencies into legal tenders. According to Monex Group's head, Oki Matsumoto, CBDCs will enhance the interoperability of cryptocurrencies, making the market more lively. This move is part of Japan's efforts to move towards a more efficient, digitalized economy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi plans 448b dirhams in oil spending to boost output
summary: Abu Dhabi has approved a 448 billion dirhams (S$163.68 billion) budget for oil and natural gas investments over the next five years, aiming to boost output capacity. The plan includes increasing daily oil production to five million barrels by 2030 and exploiting potential supply shortages. The move comes as the UAE seeks to diversify its economy and bolster income despite Opec+ restrictions on supply. The investment plan also includes developing hydrogen as a low-carbon energy source.

site_title: For vaccine maker shares, smaller is proving to be better
summary: Investors in smaller pharmaceutical companies, such as BioNTech and Moderna, are seeing significant gains due to their success in developing coronavirus vaccines. Shares of BioNTech have nearly tripled this year, while Moderna's have increased fivefold. In contrast, larger companies like Pfizer and AstraZeneca have experienced modest gains or remain unchanged. Analysts attribute this disparity to the smaller companies' lower valuations and more significant vaccine-related success. The impact on smaller companies' valuations is also influenced by their relative starting points and drug pipelines.

images.alt_text: Investors who bet on success in the race to develop coronavirus vaccines are finding that smaller is better.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines gains nearly 17% on the week
summary: Singapore Airlines' share price surged 8.2% on the day to S$4.77, up 15.7% from Monday's close and 16.6% from Friday's close, driven by heavy volumes and large trades. The stock's rally follows the postponement of the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble and the positive outlook for Covid-19 vaccines. The airline's cash call and recent financing activities have also contributed to the stock's gains.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open, tracking Wall Street advance; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,910.21. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged to 30,000 points, while banking stocks and telcos also gained. The rally was driven by receding political uncertainty and hopes for coronavirus vaccines, offsetting worries over rising Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip from record high on profit-taking, snap five-day rally
summary: South Korean stocks slipped from a record high on Wednesday, ending a five-day rally as investors booked profits. The benchmark Kospi fell 16.22 points or 0.62% to 2,601.54. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix dropped 1.6% and 1.4%, respectively. Foreigners were net buyers for a 15th straight session, purchasing 134.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares. Analysts expect investors to book more profits before the year-end, citing losses from sectors that foreigners have invested in.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing urges more countries to adopt shared travel protocol
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing urged more countries to adopt a shared travel protocol to ensure safe travel amid the Covid-19 pandemic, emphasizing the need for a competitive advantage in the global market. He also called for the tourism industry to reimagine the experience and mass-customize it for leisure, business, and Mice visitors. Singapore is adopting a "risk management" approach to travel, and the country is expected to host more Mice events in the months ahead, with agreements with global organizers and the establishment of regional headquarters in Singapore.

site_title: Mandatory offer for Lum Chang turns unconditional
summary: A mandatory offer for construction firm Lum Chang Holdings has turned unconditional, with the offeror and its concert parties owning around 51.8% of total shares. The offer was triggered after the firm's managing director purchased a 0.2% stake on the open market. The offeror, RMDV Investments, is the bid vehicle for engineering solutions firm Ellipsiz, and will make an offer for the remaining 57.3% of shares at S$0.38 apiece, while keeping the company listed.

site_title: Nestle sells Yinlu business in China amid portfolio cleanup
summary: Nestle has agreed to sell its Yinlu peanut milk and canned rice porridge businesses in China to Food Wise Co, a company controlled by the founder of Yinlu, for an undisclosed amount. The deal, expected to close by the end of the year, allows Nestle to focus on its core categories in China and retain its Nescafe coffee business. Yinlu brands generated 700 million Swiss francs (S$1.03 billion) in sales in 2019. The transaction does not affect Nestle's presence in China, where the company remains committed to its second-largest market.

images.alt_text: Nestle has agreed to sell its Yinlu peanut milk and canned rice porridge businesses in China to Food Wise Co, a company controlled by the family of Yinlu founder Chen Qingshui, the world's largest packaged food group said on Wednesday.

site_title: At China's premier Internet conference, few address the regulatory elephant in the room
summary: China's World Internet Conference discussed pressing issues, but few addressed the country's plans to regulate tech companies, including Alibaba Group and Tencent, which analysts describe as the first serious attempt by Beijing's antitrust authorities. The central government announced the plans in November, aiming to rein in anti-competitive behaviors. The move marks a significant shift for the industry, which has been characterized by a lack of regulatory oversight. The conference's focus on other topics suggests the regulatory elephant in the room remains unaddressed.

site_title: Biden transition, vaccine hopes keep gold near four-month low
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's transition to the White House and hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine have boosted riskier assets, keeping gold near a four-month low. Spot gold eased 0.2% to $1,803.51 per ounce, its lowest level since July 17. Investors await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, while China's net gold imports contracted for the steepest monthly drop since June. Analysts expect gold to find support near $1,750-$1,770.

site_title: US oil industry group pledges to fight possible Biden fracking limits
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's proposed ban on new gas and oil permits, including fracking, on federal lands has drawn opposition from the American Petroleum Institute (API). The API's CEO, Mike Sommers, vowed to use "every tool at its disposal" to fight the proposal, citing potential job losses and economic impact on states reliant on oil and gas production. Sommers expressed willingness to work with the Biden administration on energy issues, but emphasized the need for industry involvement in discussions on methane emissions and other regulations.

site_title: China steelmaker Jiangsu Shagang to enter new business area, buy big data assets
summary: China's Jiangsu Shagang Co plans to diversify into the data centre industry through a 18.8 billion yuan (S$3.84 billion) deal to reduce operational risks and increase profits. The company will acquire a Suzhou investment firm that owns a 51% stake in UK-based data centre operator Global Switch Holdings. This transformation aims to enhance Jiangsu Shagang's profitability and risk resistance amid fierce competition in the ferrous sector. The company's main business will shift from special steel to both special steel and data centre operations.

site_title: HSBC shares surge on optimism turnaround will build steam
summary: HSBC shares surged 8% in Hong Kong trading, reaching HK$42.45, amid optimism a turnaround is gaining steam. The rally comes after the bank beat profit estimates, eased credit losses, and signaled a possible resumption of dividend payments. Analysts attribute the rise to improved market expectations, attractive valuation, and potential expansion plans in the Greater Bay Area. Goldman Sachs reinstated HSBC with a buy rating, while JPMorgan Chase & Co cited better-than-expected results and a rising probability of dividend resumption.

site_title: Tokyo to call for shortened hours for bars, restaurants: report
summary: Tokyo is urging bars and restaurants to operate shortened hours, from 10:00 p.m. until December 18, amid sharp rises in COVID-19 infections. The city has seen over 500 new daily infections, the most since a state of emergency was lifted in May. A Tokyo government committee will discuss coronavirus measures, and the city may also halt a travel subsidy campaign. Japan has paused a domestic travel promotion campaign in Sapporo and Osaka, citing concerns of spreading the virus.

site_title: German firm &ever to set up Changi indoor vertical farm with R&D centre
summary: German firm &ever is setting up a global research and development (R&D) centre in Singapore, co-located with its Changi indoor vertical farm. The facility will focus on reducing energy consumption and optimizing yield in indoor vertical farms. &ever has partnered with Signify, A*STAR, and local academic institutes to explore research collaborations. The R&D centre aims to support the company's goal of producing 30% of Singapore's nutritional needs locally by 2030, with plans to produce up to 500,000 kilogrammes of leafy greens annually.

site_title: Japan criticises UN finding that Nissan's Ghosn was detained unfairly
summary: Japan's Justice Minister Yoko Kawakami criticized a UN panel's written opinion stating that former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn was unfairly detained under Japan's legal system. The opinion claimed Ghosn's repeated arrests were "fundamentally unfair" and an "abuse of process." Kawakami disputed the claims, stating that the Japanese government has filed a complaint and will work with the UN to "correct misunderstandings." Ghosn was charged with financial misconduct in 2018 and fled to Lebanon in 2019, sparking international scrutiny of Japan's judicial practices.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally as optimism abounds on vaccine, US politics
summary: Asian markets rallied on November 25, 2020, driven by vaccine successes and easing US political uncertainty. Russia's Sputnik V vaccine showed a 95% effectiveness, while similar positive announcements from Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca boosted investor confidence. The US transition process paving the way for Joe Biden's presidency also contributed to the optimism. As a result, Asian markets extended their rally, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Jakarta rising over 1%, while Shanghai and Sydney also saw gains.

site_title: Visa-backed Marqeta targets US$10b valuation in 2021 IPO
summary: Marqeta, a payments startup backed by Goldman Sachs and Visa, is planning a 2021 initial public offering (IPO) with a potential valuation of around $10 billion. The Oakland, California-based company is working with Goldman and JPMorgan Chase on the listing. Marqeta has recently secured partnerships with Uber and JPMorgan, and added independent directors to its board. The company has previously raised $150 million at a $4.3 billion valuation. A final valuation for the IPO has not been finalized and may change pending investor feedback.

site_title: BRI Ventures closes first round of new Indonesia tech fund
summary: BRI Ventures, the corporate venture arm of Bank Rakyat Indonesia, has completed the first close of a 300 billion rupiah (S$28.4 million) tech fund, known as the Sembrani Nusantara Fund. The fund raised over 150 billion rupiah from investors, including Grab Holdings and prominent Indonesian investor Pandu Sjahrir. BRI Ventures plans to invest in early-stage companies in Indonesia's tech sector, focusing on education, agro-maritime, retail, transportation, and healthcare, aiming to finance small and medium-sized companies and help them go digital.

site_title: Thai pro-democracy leaders summoned over royal defamation
summary: Thai pro-democracy protest leaders have been summoned by police to face charges of royal defamation under Thailand's draconian law, which bars criticism of the royal family and carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison. The move comes as Bangkok gears up for another major rally, amid rising tensions and clashes between protesters and royalists. The charges are the first use of the law in almost three years and are seen as a response to months of youth-led protests demanding a new constitution and reform of the monarchy.

site_title: Faded K-pop star competes for comeback
summary: A faded K-pop star, Ryu Sera, is competing on a new television show, Miss Back, six years after being dismissed from her management company. She spoke out against the K-pop industry's "factory-like mass-production system," criticizing its ruthless competition and lack of mental health support. Ryu, who was once part of the girlband Nine Muses, described her intense training and constant criticism, which led to her struggling with depression and contemplating suicide. The show aims to provide a platform for failed and former idols to share their struggles and showcase their talents.

site_title: RBNZ to tighten mortgage lending as for prospects for negative rates dim
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), plans to re-impose mortgage lending curbs by March next year and work with the government to address a housing crisis. The RBNZ will consider the government's proposal to factor property prices into its policy remit, which could limit deeper cuts to interest rates into negative territory. The move aims to maintain financial stability and address concerns about housing affordability, which have prompted a surge in home prices.

site_title: UOB to issue one billion euros of 0.01% covered bonds
summary: UOB successfully issued one billion euros (S$1.6 billion) in seven-year covered bonds at a 0.01% yield, the deepest negative-yielding covered bond in the Asia-Pacific and the first from Singapore. The deal was about two times subscribed and priced 17 basis points above mid-swap, resulting in a reoffer yield of -0.21%. The new bonds will mature on Dec 1, 2027, and are guaranteed by Glacier Eighty, securing cost savings of 27 basis points for the bank.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil revival includes return of US shows next year
summary: Cirque du Soleil has emerged from court protection with new owners and a focus on major cities. The company plans to resume US shows as early as next summer, with Las Vegas-based shows and a new production at Walt Disney Co's Florida resort likely to reopen first. Cirque aims to return to pre-pandemic levels in 2022, with a vaccine distribution strategy to ensure a safe return. The company is injecting $375 million into its relaunch and has new owners, including Catalyst Capital Group, Sound Point Capital Management, and Benefit Street Partners.

site_title: Amazon's US$3,000 signing bonuses irk workers who got US$10 coupons
summary: Amazon is offering signing bonuses of up to $3,000 to attract workers for the holiday season, despite existing employees receiving tax-free $10 turkey coupons. The move reflects a growing concern about labor shortages, with the US unemployment rate at 6.9% and seasonal work searches dropping 25% from 2019. Amazon's strategy aims to ensure timely deliveries during the busy holiday season, but existing workers feel undervalued and resentful towards new hires receiving higher bonuses. The company's efforts to combat Covid-19 risks and retain workers will likely be costly, with Amazon spending over $10 billion on safety measures this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.31 points or 0.34% to 1,583.70. The index saw 428.78 million lots traded worth RM153.69 million, with 325 gainers out of 135 losers.

site_title: Lame duck Trump pardons turkey but dodges elephant in room
summary: US President Donald Trump pardoned a turkey named Corn at a live ceremony, but avoided discussing his election loss to Joe Biden. The event, a decades-old tradition, was marked by Trump's typical brevity and lack of answers to journalists' questions. Trump's failure to concede defeat and his reluctance to address his post-election plans remain a point of contention.

site_title: Watchdog criticises poor planning that left UK without enough PPE as Covid-19 struck
summary: The UK's National Audit Office criticized the government's poor planning for the COVID-19 pandemic, stating that the stockpile of personal protective equipment (PPE) was insufficient and led to high prices being paid. Only about a third of medical staff received adequate PPE, and the government spent £12.5 billion on equipment, 10 billion pounds more than usual. The focus on preparing for a flu pandemic, rather than a more infectious coronavirus, contributed to the shortage. The government scrambled to buy equipment as prices skyrocketed, and hospitals never ran out of PPE, according to a junior health minister.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to acquire logistics park in Italy for 52.6m euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has agreed to acquire a logistics park in Italy for 52.6 million euros, adding around 10% to its overall portfolio. The freehold intermodal logistics park, with 156,888 sq m of net lettable area, is expected to generate stable cash flows and increase the Reit's exposure to the resilient logistics sector. The acquisition is expected to be completed in December 2020 and funded from available cash reserves and committed debt facilities. The asset has a 7.4% net operating income yield and will increase the Reit's weighting in the light industrial and logistics segment to 32.3%.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at near nine-month high on potential easing of virus curbs
summary: European shares ended at a near nine-month high on Tuesday, driven by optimism over potential easing of lockdowns in France and the deployment of a coronavirus vaccine as early as 2021. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8%, its strongest close since late February, with oil & gas stocks leading the gains. Strong gains in these stocks, which are set for their best month on record, contributed to the market's positive sentiment.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Singapore Airlines, ST Engineering, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday include UOB, which priced one billion euros of seven-year covered bonds at 0.01%, and Singapore Airlines, which priced S$500 million worth of 3.5% notes due 2030. ST Engineering saw The Capital Group Companies become a substantial shareholder after purchasing 1.38 million shares. Cromwell E-Reit entered into an agreement to acquire a logistics park in Italy for S$84.2 million. Shares of Broadway Industrial hit a near 3.5-year high after receiving a US$50 million offer for its hard disk business.

site_title: Zimbabwe losing US$1.5b gold a year to smuggling: report
summary: Zimbabwe is estimated to lose at least $1.5 billion annually through the smuggling of gold, mainly to traders in Dubai. This figure surpasses the government's own estimates of $1.2 billion. The gold sector, which accounts for 60% of Zimbabwean exports, is plagued by a centralized payment system that underpays producers, leading to smuggling and eroding industrial mining profits. The sector is also facing poverty and the fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic, driving more people to artisanal mining, which has become a safety net for nearly 10% of the population.

site_title: Buyout titans fire up LBO machine with US$1.6 trillion to spend
summary: The US private equity industry is ramping up leveraged buyouts (LBOs) and debt-funded dividends, with $1.6 trillion in available capital. Despite a slow start to 2020, buyout activity is now only 32% behind last year's pace. Interest rates are at record lows, and demand from bond and loan buyers is high, making it an ideal time for deal-making. Private equity firms are targeting sectors such as healthcare and technology, and are using creative financing strategies, including selling partial stakes in companies. Industry experts predict a "year of the sponsor" in 2021, with buyout firms poised to make significant investments.

site_title: Luxury fans in China chase neat shot of investment with vintage Moutai liquor
summary: Luxury consumers in China are investing in vintage Moutai liquor as a collector's item, with prices for limited editions skyrocketing amid the country's economic recovery from the pandemic. Demand is outpacing supply, making it difficult for individuals like Yang Nan to afford the liquor. The trend is driven by the rapidly appreciating value of the 'baijiu' spirit, with re-sale prices increasing by 190% or more. This new habit is part of China's luxury spending rebound, with consumers seeking alternative investments beyond traditional luxury goods.

site_title: France, Britain ease lockdowns as second virus wave subsides
summary: Britain and France plan to ease COVID-19 restrictions ahead of Christmas, as a second wave of infections subsides. France's President Emmanuel Macron announced that shops can reopen this Saturday and nationwide stay-at-home orders will be lifted from December 15. Travel restrictions will also be lifted, allowing people to spend Christmas with their families. However, some restrictions will remain in place to avoid a third wave of infections.

site_title: Don't miss Forrest for the trees
summary: Forrest Li, founder of Sea, prioritizes big-picture thinking and adaptability amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Sea, a homegrown company, started with a video game distributor in 2009 and made a high-stakes bet on e-commerce with Shopee five years ago. Now, Sea is focusing on fintech with its digital financial services unit and an ongoing bid for a full digibank license in Singapore. Li has been named Businessman of the Year for 2019/2020 in the Singapore Business Awards, showcasing his vision and entrepreneurial journey.

site_title: Look beyond traditional 60/40 portfolio into alternative assets, says JP Morgan study
summary: A new study by JP Morgan Asset Management suggests that investors need to rethink their traditional 60/40 bond/equity portfolio due to the lasting implications of COVID-19-related fiscal and monetary support measures. The study forecasts modestly higher real growth globally, but expects public asset market returns to fall, with low yields affecting government bonds and high equity valuations a headwind for stocks. Investors are advised to consider alternative assets, such as Asian emerging markets debt, income-generating alternatives, and higher returning emerging equity markets, to harvest returns without unacceptable portfolio risk.

site_title: Others to get vaccine first as Canada lacks production capacity: Trudeau
summary: Canada can expect its first COVID-19 vaccine doses in early 2021, likely later than countries with domestic production capacity. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that Canada no longer has domestic vaccine production capacity, unlike countries like the US, Germany, and the UK. Trudeau acknowledged that Canada will prioritize helping its citizens first, citing the lack of domestic facilities.

site_title: After borrowing surge, UK's Sunak to announce more spending
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak will announce extra spending to ease a backlog in the health system, counter a surge in unemployment, and build new infrastructure in a one-year Spending Review. The spending plans are expected to be dwarfed by borrowing forecasts, which indicate a record economic crash this year. Britain's budget deficit is expected to surge to 20% of economic output, and Sunak is unlikely to rein in spending or raise taxes to address the deficit. A freeze on public sector pay and a reduction in foreign aid budget may be announced to offset some spending.

site_title: Relook training, job design, to address workers' Covid-19 stresses: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizes the need for businesses to redesign jobs and reskill their workforce to address worker stresses and strains caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. He notes that digital transformation has accelerated, putting more strain on workers, and encourages business leaders to prioritize worker well-being alongside the bottom line. Companies that have prepared for digital transformation are better equipped to deal with the pandemic's impact, and Heng stresses the importance of adaptability and risk management in navigating the uncertain global climate.

site_title: US: Dow hits 30,000 points for first time as stocks boom
summary: The US stock market reached a milestone, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossing 30,000 points for the first time. The Dow surged 1.3% to 29,987.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.5% and 1.2%, respectively. The gains were driven by receding US political uncertainty and hopes for coronavirus vaccines, offsetting concerns over spiking Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Ucare.ai's systems can predict if you have Covid-19
summary: Ucare.ai has developed a system that can predict if someone has Covid-19, alert them before falling ill, and estimate hospital bills. The medtech startup's risk algorithms have been applied to create a model that forecasts Covid-19 infection risk, with co-founders Christina Teo and Neal Liu building another model to identify individuals at higher risk. This technology aims to provide early warnings and financial insights, potentially improving health outcomes and reducing hospital costs.

site_title: Thanksgiving travellers give US airports busiest weekend since March
summary: US airports saw over 3 million airline passengers during the Thanksgiving weekend, the busiest air-travel weekend since March, despite CDC calls to avoid travel. The Transportation Security Administration screened 1.047 million passengers on Sunday, the highest number since mid-March. Airlines are still burning through millions of dollars daily due to the pandemic, with travel demand down 62% from last year. The CDC urges Americans to consider Covid-19 testing before and after international travel to make travel safer.

site_title: Oil closes at highest level since March on vaccine trials, Biden transition
summary: Oil prices rose about 4% on Tuesday to touch their highest level since March, driven by a third promising coronavirus vaccine and US President-elect Joe Biden's transition to the White House. AstraZeneca's vaccine was 70% effective in trials, giving hope for fuel-demand recovery. Oil benchmarks settled at their highest close since March 5, with Brent crude at $47.86 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $44.91 a barrel. The market expects the vaccine to slow the spread of the disease, potentially leading to increased fuel demand.

site_title: China's bond defaults show Beijing's war on debt is back
summary: China's bond defaults by three state-owned firms, including a coal miner, chipmaker, and automobile company, have shaken local markets and raised concerns about Beijing's efforts to reduce debt. Defaults by Huachen Automotive Group, Yongcheng Coal & Electricity Holding Group, and Tsinghua Unigroup have left investors stunned, as state support for struggling state-owned enterprises (SOEs) appears to be dwindling. The defaults highlight the complexities of China's corporate bond market and the risks of investing in SOEs. Beijing's war on debt is back, and investors are left wondering about the implications for the economy and the role of the state in supporting struggling firms.

site_title: Dell posts surprise revenue rise on booming demand for remote-work tools
summary: Dell Technologies Inc reported a surprise 3% increase in third-quarter revenue to $23.48 billion, driven by strong demand for remote-work tools. The company's client solutions group saw a record $12.29 billion in revenue, up 8% from a year earlier. Global shipments of traditional PCs jumped 14.6% year-over-year to 81.3 million units, while the data center business fell 4%. Net income rose to $832 million, exceeding analyst estimates. Dell plans to spin off its 81% stake in VMware to reduce debt.

site_title: Sea's Forrest Li credits Singapore in Businessman of the Year win
summary: Forrest Li, head of Sea, was named Businessman of the Year at the 35th Singapore Business Awards. In his acceptance speech, Li credited Singapore for his success, recalling his humble start. He expressed gratitude to the Economic Development Board (EDB) for its support. This win highlights Li's journey from a small beginning to becoming a prominent businessman.

site_title: US will distribute 6.4 million Covid-19 vaccine doses in first tranche
summary: The US plans to distribute 6.4 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in the first week after it is cleared for emergency use, likely in December. A FDA committee will meet on December 10 to decide on the vaccine's clearance. Additionally, General Gustave Perna stated that 40 million doses of vaccine will be available by the end of December.

site_title: JD unit seeks up to US$3.5b in Asia's biggest health IPO
summary: JD Health International, the healthcare unit of China's JD.com, is set to raise up to US$3.5 billion in its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), the largest healthcare listing in Asia. The company is selling 381.9 million shares at a price range of HK$62.8 to HK$70.58 each, valuing it at US$25.3 billion to US$28.5 billion. The IPO is backed by six cornerstone investors, including GIC and BlackRock, and is expected to surpass Japan's Ostuka Holdings Co's US$2.3 billion offering as Asia's biggest listing in the sector.

site_title: Apple security chief allegedly tried to bribe police with iPads
summary: Apple's global security director, Thomas Moyer, has been charged with bribery for allegedly offering 200 iPads worth $70,000 to the Santa Clara County sheriff's office in exchange for concealed weapons permits for company employees. The proposed deal was abandoned at the last minute. This incident raises concerns about the ethics of security officials using their power to influence law enforcement. Moyer's actions are seen as a clear breach of professional conduct and may have implications for Apple's corporate culture.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit nine-month high as Biden transition lifts risk appetite
summary: Australian shares reached a nine-month high on Wednesday, driven by a US presidential transition and optimism over a potential vaccine, lifting the S&P/ASX 200 index 0.8% to 6,697.1. Energy stocks surged, with Woodside and Santos climbing 4.2% and 5.2%, respectively. Heavyweight financials also gained, while gold stocks fell to their lowest in 6.5 months. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.1% as Westpac and ANZ Banking Corp gained 3.4% and 3.3%, respectively.

site_title: Digital Colony teams up with ex-Edotco CEO for Asia towers bet: sources
summary: Digital Colony, a Singapore-based platform, has formed a partnership with former Edotco CEO Suresh Sidhu to invest in mobile towers in the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership aims to grow Edgepoint Infrastructure, which could amass 20,000 to 50,000 towers in the next five to seven years. Digital Colony has committed US$1 billion or more in equity capital to the venture, with discussions ongoing for a potential acquisition of Centratama Telekommunikasi Indonesia. This investment is part of the growing trend of institutional investors focusing on digital infrastructure, such as towers, data centers, and fiber.

site_title: High Court dismisses Singapore firm's bid to release funds to pare Wirecard 'loans'
summary: A Singaporean firm, oCap Management, linked to Wirecard, was denied a High Court's permission to release millions of seized funds to repay "loans" from the scandal-tainted fintech. The firm claimed the funds were necessary to pay staff salaries, taxes, and accounting services. However, the court dismissed the motion, stating that oCap had failed to show it was necessary to release the funds under the law. The seized funds, totaling $8.63 million, were seized by the Commercial Affairs Department in August. Investigations into oCap and Wirecard's operations are ongoing, with several individuals and companies facing charges related to the accounting scandal.

site_title: Top Glove expects delays in deliveries after virus outbreak shuts plants
summary: Top Glove Corp, the world's largest rubber glove maker, expects delivery delays and sales shortfalls due to a virus outbreak that forced the shutdown of some factory operations in Malaysia. The company's shares fell 7.5% as it allocates sales orders to unaffected factories and reschedules deliveries. The closure of 28 factory buildings affects around 16,000 employees and could reduce production capacity by 50%. Analysts predict a 2% hit to annual profit, with tight supply potentially pushing prices up.

site_title: Qantas passengers must be vaccinated when vaccine is available
summary: Qantas becomes the first major airline to require international travellers to be vaccinated against Covid-19, with the vaccine available, as a condition of flying. The airline's CEO Alan Joyce stated that the rule is likely to become standard practice globally as governments and airlines consider electronic vaccination passports. Other major regional airlines, such as Korean Air and Japan Airlines, have not yet announced similar requirements, but the International Air Transport Association is developing a digital health pass to support safe border reopenings.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KrisEnergy, a debt-hit oil-and-gas company, reached a US$15.3 million settlement with Rubicon Vantage International and its affiliate, withdrawing a winding-up petition against a key subsidiary. The settlement also resolves claims related to a 2014 bareboat charterparty. In other news, Singapore Airlines priced S$500 million worth of notes due 2030, while HC Surgical Specialists won a defamation case against surgeon Julian Ong. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss below targets.

site_title: Mapletree to invest over S$550m in jumbo logistics site in Japan
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based property giant, plans to invest over S$550 million in a 2.5 million sqft logistics site in Japan's Kyushu island. The project will develop two Grade A, four-storey logistics facilities with a combined gross floor area of 2.5 million sqft, set to be the largest warehouse space in Kyushu upon completion. Construction will start in early 2023, with the first warehouse opening in 2023 and the second in Q2 2024.

images.alt_text: The site is in Fukuoka prefecture and is well-connected to major transportation infrastructure. The city of Fukuoka is home to Japan's youngest population, said Mapletree.

site_title: Bright future for tech stocks in post-Covid world
summary: Tech stocks are poised for a bright future despite the end of the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies like DocuSign, Shopify, and Zoom had strong pre-Covid growth due to their innovative products and services. Even if vaccines become widely available, these tech companies are likely to continue growing due to their superior offerings. Long-term investors should focus on the companies' business performance and growth potential, rather than short-term market fluctuations. With or without Covid-19, the future looks promising for technology stocks.

site_title: CIMB Singapore names three new business heads to replace axed trio
summary: CIMB Singapore has named three new business heads to replace three axed executives. Merlyn Tsai, Benjamin Tan Wee Chuan, and Foo Tsiang Wei will take over as head of consumer banking, commercial banking, and corporate and investment banking, respectively. The appointments will take effect from December 1, 2020. The new executives bring over 23 years of experience in local and international financial institutions, with leadership roles in preferred banking, micro-lending, and digital banking. The moves come as part of a restructuring effort to optimize the bank's structure and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: CIMB Singapore on Tuesday announced replacements for the three banking heads who were cut, in another internal memo to Singapore staff seen by The Business Times.

site_title: Collaborators make Trump's subversion efforts alarming
summary: Donald Trump's allies are making efforts to subvert the election results, with lawyers Rudy Giuliani and Sidney Powell claiming widespread voting conspiracy and the Republican National Committee supporting false claims. This could lead to lasting damage to American democracy, as insiders undermining the system can have a more significant impact than external attacks. The efforts may damage faith in democracy among both Republican and Democratic voters, potentially leading to a spiral of distrust and destruction, and turning the US federal system into an unworkable confrontation between two hostile camps.

site_title: Time is ripe to produce new generation of MNCs: Chan
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing says Singapore has a "historic opportunity" to turn local companies into global champions, creating better jobs for Singaporeans and uplifting SMEs. He cites success stories like Sea Group, which has a US$89 billion market capitalization, and notes three unique advantages: Singapore's neutrality in geopolitics, its ability to turn a lack of a large domestic market into a strength, and the trust premium of the Singapore brand.

images.alt_text: Companies who make it big in Singapore generate spillover benefits for the economy, such as better wage growth and prospects for employees in the same industry, says Mr Chan.

site_title: Using AI to solve problems before they happen
summary: Predictive maintenance software firm Avanseus expects strong demand for its AI-powered solutions, particularly with the rise of remote work. Founded by Bhargab Mitra, a telecommunications veteran, Avanseus' software, Cognitive Assistant for Networks (CAN), predicts faults up to 15 days in advance, reducing operational costs by up to 30% and minimizing service disruptions. The company has seen its revenue double year-over-year since 2017 and expects to be profitable in 2020, with a growth forecast for 2021.

images.alt_text: Mr Mitra says that once deployed, the aim for CAN is to reduce operational costs of telecommunications providers by up to 30 per cent.

site_title: Broadway Ind surges 34% on US$50m offer for its hard disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial's shares surged 33.8% on Tuesday after the precision manufacturer announced a US$50 million offer for its hard disk business from Seksun Technology (Suzhou) Co. The counter reached a near 3.5-year high of 16.6 Singapore cents, with 103.8 million shares traded. The proposed purchase price is subject to certain assumptions, and the deal is expected to be finalized. The offer is seen as a significant development for Broadway Industrial, which is one of the few remaining Singapore-listed hard disk drive component makers.

site_title: Prominent businessman Ameerali Rajabali Jumabhoy dies at 94
summary: Ameerali Rajabali Jumabhoy, a prominent businessman and founder of Scotts Holdings Limited, passed away at 94. He was a forward thinker and pioneer, creating Asia's first purpose-built serviced apartment building, The Ascott Singapore. Born in 1925, Jumabhoy was a visionary and a sportsman, instrumental in securing the land for the Singapore Polo Club. He founded Scotts Holdings in 1982, which grew into a multinational hospitality, property, food, and retail group. Jumabhoy was also a devoted follower of Mahatma Gandhi and was involved in public service and various organizations.

images.alt_text: Under Mr Ameerali's leadership, the family business grew into a multinational hospitality, property, food and retail group, with several concepts and brands under its wing.

site_title: Asia-Pac's stubbornly-high property prices may correct next year
summary: Asia-Pacific property prices may correct next year due to growing concerns of a market correction, despite the Covid-19 pandemic having a limited impact on local real estate markets. A regional forecast report by ULI and PwC notes that artificially high asset prices are due for a fall as hopes for a V-shaped economic recovery fade. Stress in the form of forced sales may surface soon in China, India, and Australia, with smaller developers in China and India likely to liquidate assets to finance land purchases.

site_title: Home prices gain most on record with low rates driving demand
summary: Home prices in the US surged 3.1% in the third quarter, the largest gain on record, driven by record low mortgage rates and a desire for more space during the pandemic. Prices rose 7.8% compared to 2019, the biggest jump since 2006. The housing market has been booming, with cheaper borrowing costs fueling a surge in purchases. This marks the latest in a series of positive housing market trends, with many cities experiencing record-breaking rent increases and a rebound in homebuyer demand.

site_title: US dollar falls on Biden transition, vaccine hopes
summary: US President Donald Trump accepted the transition to a Joe Biden presidency, potentially leading to former Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen as Treasury secretary. This move boosted optimism about a quicker global economic revival, driving up stocks and oil prices. The US dollar fell 0.4% to a nearly three-month low, while the Australian dollar rose to a two-and-a-half-month high, and the euro gained 0.4%. Market analysts expect Yellen to pursue conventional policies and push for increased government spending to lift the economy.

site_title: Investors would be better served if IFAs were to widen the scope of their advice
summary: A financial advisor's independent review of Sabana Reit's proposed merger with ESR-Reit found the terms to be "fair and reasonable," but did not assess the merger's merits relative to alternative options or the target Reit's standalone growth prospects. The advisor compared the deal to precedent transactions but did not evaluate the pro forma DPU and NAV numbers against those deals. This raises concerns that investors may be treated poorly in the merger. Regulators may need to scrutinize the terms of reference of financial advisors in intra-group deals to ensure they provide investors with meaningful advice.

site_title: Aramco says domestic supplies unaffected by attack on Jeddah plant
summary: Saudi Aramco's domestic fuel supplies remain unaffected by an attack on its North Jeddah Bulk Plant by Yemen's Houthi group on Monday. The facility, which distributes fuel to western Saudi regions, suffered minor damage and a fire was extinguished in 40 minutes with no casualties. Operations resumed three hours after the attack, and the company is assessing the scale and cost of the damage. The attack comes amid ongoing conflict between Saudi Arabia and Yemen's Houthi forces.

site_title: Singapore, other Asian markets up on progress in Biden transition
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.5% on Tuesday, driven by news of President-elect Joe Biden's transition to the White House, boosting economic recovery hopes. Markets in other Asian countries also gained, with transport-related counters leading the gains. Singapore Airlines and Sats rose 8.4% and 7.4% respectively, while ComfortDelGro edged up 7.3%. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,891.63, with transport-related counters performing well.

site_title: Met Opera seeks 30% pay cuts in exchange for pandemic salaries
summary: The Metropolitan Opera has proposed a deal to its employees, offering partial paychecks of up to $1,500 a week in exchange for a 30% pay cut, with half of the reduction restored once the box office recovers. The proposal, made by General Manager Peter Gelb, aims to help the company recover from pandemic-related losses. However, unions have opposed the deal, citing concerns that the pay cuts will be permanent and affect workers long after the pandemic subsides.

images.alt_text: Part of union opposition to the requested concessions is that half of the salary cuts will be restored only when the box office recovers, which could easily take years.

site_title: US consumer confidence down to a three-month low
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a three-month low in November, dropping to 96.1 from October's revised 101.4. The decline was attributed to the coronavirus resurgence and decreased expectations for the economy and job market. The gauge of expectations dropped 8.7 points, while sentiment about current conditions eased 0.3 point. The figures coincide with the start of the holiday shopping season, suggesting slower retail sales and hiring. Consumers remain uncertain about the economy's strength, but more expect their incomes to increase.

site_title: Maybank KE upgrades Singapore, Malaysia tech stocks on 5G, IoT wave
summary: Maybank KE upgrades its recommendation on Singapore and Malaysia's tech sector to "positive" due to the adoption of 5G, artificial intelligence, and electric vehicles. The global semiconductor market is expected to grow 6.2% in 2021, driven by the rollout of 5G networks. Top picks include Frencken, Venture, UMS, and Inari Amertron, with Frencken and Venture favored for their medium-term margin expansion potential and UMS expected to benefit from semiconductor spending recovery.

site_title: Subsidies better for Covid-19 prevention than lockdowns
summary: European governments are considering alternative measures to combat the second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic, including subsidies for businesses to close temporarily, rather than imposing "lockdown light" restrictions. A recent paper suggests that such subsidies could be more effective and less costly than mandated closures, which have led to strong protests from small shop and restaurant owners. By providing income compensation to struggling businesses, governments can reduce social distancing goals while maintaining a reasonable fiscal cost. This approach could also encourage small shop owners to modernize or quit the market, overcoming structural resistance to change.

site_title: Healthtech use surges amid pandemic; now to put the brakes on costs
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of technology in the healthcare sector in Singapore, boosting productivity and efficiency. Telehealth solutions and digital health technologies have become essential, with a 67% reduction in hospital stay for heart failure patients and a 42% reduction in care costs in a pilot program. However, the long-term impact on medical costs remains uncertain, with some experts warning that initial investments may offset benefits, while others suggest that more advanced technologies could lead to greater cost savings in the long run.

site_title: DoctorxDentist culls at least 9,700 doctors' names from its platform
summary: DoctorxDentist, a medical-review website, has removed the profiles of at least 9,700 doctors from its platform after regulatory bodies criticized the startup for lack of transparency and potential copyright infringement. The website now lists around 300 doctors, mostly paying practitioners. DoctorxDentist's general manager has promised to implement more stringent processes to address transparency concerns. The final list of medical practitioners is expected to be confirmed in two weeks after verification.

images.alt_text: Doctorxdentist, a medical-review and consumer-education Web site, has removed the profiles of at least 9,700 doctors after regulatory and industry bodies criticised the startup and said they may take legal action.

site_title: Patriarch of Scotts Holdings, Ameerali R Jumabhoy, dies at 94
summary: Ameerali R Jumabhoy, founder of Scotts Holdings Limited, died at 94. He was a forward-thinking businessman who created Asia's first purpose-built serviced apartment building, The Ascott Singapore. The family described him as a "visionary and a pioneer" who was a loving husband, father, and great-grandfather.

site_title: Sim Leisure gets RM7m loan from controlling shareholder for KidZania deal
summary: Sim Leisure Group obtained a loan of up to RM7 million from its controlling shareholder Tan Boon Seng to fund the acquisition of KidZania's operator in Kuala Lumpur. The loan includes a term funding of RM5.3 million for the acquisition and a funding portion of RM1.7 million for general working capital purposes. Sim Leisure plans to acquire Rakan Riang, KidZania's licensee, for RM3.8 million. The loan has an 8% interest rate and was deemed an interested-person transaction due to Tan Boon Seng's significant stake in the company.

site_title: Value investing in Asia set to outperform in near term
summary: Value investing in Asia is expected to outperform in the near term due to progress on the coronavirus vaccine front and the expectation of mass inoculation, leading to a return to economic normalcy. However, this trend is unlikely to last as growth will decelerate once stimulus effects fade and unemployment rises. Meanwhile, growth and tech sectors are likely to flourish in such an environment. Investors should consider buying value stocks on dips, particularly in sectors heavily impacted by the virus, such as financials, airports, and traditional retail, which are expected to be re-rated first.

site_title: China's move on digital currency secures it an edge, but ...
summary: China's central bank digital currency (CBDC) experiment has secured an edge in the digital economy, with over 2 million citizens in Shenzhen applying to participate. The lottery scheme, which offered 50,000 citizens a wallet containing around US$30, created momentum. China's state-owned banks will distribute the digital yuan, and the central bank may re-lend DCEP deposits to commercial banks, giving it more control. This move could make the yuan a more viable alternative to the US dollar in international payments, potentially disrupting the global monetary system.

site_title: ST Engineering gets new substantial shareholder in US-based investment manager
summary: ST Engineering has gained a new substantial shareholder after US-based investment management company The Capital Group Companies (CGC) acquired 1.38 million shares, increasing its stake to 5.01% as of November 20. CGC, parent company of Capital Research and Management Company, purchased the shares via a market transaction. This acquisition bumped ST Engineering's share price by 1.76% to close at S$4.04 on Tuesday.

site_title: UK law may fine carriers 10% of sales for breaching Huawei ban
summary: The UK government proposes a law that could fine phone carriers up to 10% of their sales or £100,000 a day if they breach new telecom security rules, including a ban on Huawei's 5G equipment. The Telecommunications Security Bill will oversee 5G networks and be enforced by Communications regulator Ofcom. Carriers must remove existing Huawei equipment by 2027. The move aims to protect the UK from hostile cyber activity by state actors or criminals, following attributed cyber attacks to Russia and China. Lawmakers will debate the bill next week.

site_title: Will digital banking licences increase credit access here?
summary: Singapore is set to issue up to five digital banking licenses by the end of the year, with a focus on innovative use of technology to serve under-served segments of the market. The move is expected to increase credit access to the underbanked population, who make up 38% of the population and are often forced to rely on high-interest pawnshops and moneylenders. Artificial intelligence and data analytics can potentially improve credit screening, addressing issues of asymmetric information and adverse selection. However, regulatory challenges and the need to balance financial viability with fairness principles remain, with Singapore regulators closely monitoring developments in this space.

site_title: IMO's stance on greenhouse gases angers environmental lobby
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) approved a draft of new mandatory regulations to cut the carbon intensity of existing ships, but environmental organizations criticized the proposal as insufficient, allowing the shipping sector's greenhouse gas emissions to continue rising for the rest of this decade. The shipping industry has proposed a $5 billion fund to accelerate research and development of zero-carbon technologies, but experts warn that short-term reductions of shipping's carbon emissions are unlikely and that a massive injection of investment and political will is needed to achieve a zero-carbon shipping industry.

site_title: Tesla market value crosses US$500b as shares surge six-fold this year
summary: Tesla's market value surpassed $500 billion, with shares surging six-fold this year, reaching a record high of $542.35. CEO Elon Musk's net worth increased to $127.9 billion, surpassing Bill Gates to become the world's second-richest person. Tesla's valuation surpasses that of Toyota Motor, Volkswagen, or General Motors, despite a lower production rate. The company's rise is linked to President-elect Joe Biden's plan to promote clean energy and zero-emission vehicles.

site_title: Japan and China agree to restart business travel, coordinate on East China Sea
summary: Japan and China agreed to restart business travel and coordinate on the East China Sea dispute, with a focus on maritime tensions, trade, and pandemic response. The two-day visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi included talks on disputed isles, with China reaffirming its sovereignty claims. Japan and China also made progress on a free trade deal and a hotline between their defense authorities. The agreement aims to promote mutual understanding and contribute to the revitalization of the economies of Japan and China.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps on Biden transition, Tesla tops US$500b in market cap
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday as President-elect Joe Biden's transition to the White House ended weeks of uncertainty. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.52%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Tesla surged 3.3% to surpass $500 billion in market capitalization for the first time. The positive market reaction followed the formal start of Biden's transition, lifting investor confidence.

site_title: E-payments the key to powering a smart nation
summary: Singapore's fintech industry is thriving due to a supportive regulatory environment, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) providing significant funding and initiatives to foster innovation. The country's goal to become a "Smart Nation" has led to the development of e-payments, with digital banking and mobile payments becoming increasingly popular. The government's efforts to create a streamlined and secure backend framework for e-payments have contributed to its success. As a result, Singapore is set to be a leader in cross-border e-payments, with its fintech industry recording a record high in equity funding in 2020.

site_title: Making the most out of every drop of Singapore's water
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector, particularly electronics semiconductors, is a significant contributor to the country's economy, but it's also water-intensive. To address this, PUB, the national water agency, aims to reduce water consumption by up to 70% through water recycling. Despite efforts such as the Water Efficiency Fund and certification programs, the lack of motivation among water-intensive companies remains a challenge. Recent initiatives, including a S$26 million fund for on-site water solutions, have shown promise in encouraging companies to adopt more water-efficient practices. As a result, some companies are already using less potable water and implementing recycling plants to reduce their water consumption.

site_title: Pines' case rests on whether club owner has right to amend the club's rules, says court
summary: A court in Singapore is determining whether Exklusiv Resorts, the owner of The Pines country club, has the right to amend the club's rules, including changing the location of the clubhouse. 162 members are seeking damages after the club closed for renovations in 2013, and the land parcel was sold to a property developer. The court considers that the club's Constitution and bylaws allow for amendments, and the club owner's decision to sell the land parcel was not a breach of contract. The court will decide if the club owner's actions constituted deceit or negligence, with damages ranging from S$37,400 to S$117,000.

site_title: EU secures 160m doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine
