summary: The European Union has secured up to 160 million doses of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine candidate, taking the EU's potential stock to nearly 2 billion doses. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, allows the EU to buy the vaccine if it is approved by the EU's drug regulator. The vaccine has shown 94.5% effectiveness in preventing Covid-19 in a late-stage clinical trial.

site_title: Thai protest leaders to face royal insult charges
summary: Thai police have summoned seven protest leaders to face lese-majeste charges over comments made at anti-government protests demanding monarchy reforms. The charges, which carry up to 15 years in prison, are the first brought under these laws in over two years. The protest leaders have until November 30 to respond to the summonses, which were issued over comments made on September 19 and 20. This move has raised concerns about freedom of speech and the monarchy's influence in Thai politics.

site_title: DoctorxDentist removes at least 9,700 doctors from its platform, aims to be more transparent
summary: DoctorxDentist, a medical-review website, removed at least 9,700 doctor profiles after regulatory bodies and industry critics expressed concerns and considered legal action. The site now lists around 300 doctors, with those remaining paying or opting-in. General Manager Tyr Ding stated that the startup is still revamping its directory, but the number of doctors listed is expected to be lower than the original 9,700. The move aims to increase transparency and compliance with industry standards.

site_title: MAS launches grant to drive adoption of sustainable financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a grant scheme to encourage the adoption of sustainable financing, with the Green and Sustainability-Linked Loan Grant Scheme effective from January 1, 2021. The scheme will cover up to S$100,000 per loan for corporates to validate their green and sustainability credentials, and up to 60% of expenses for banks to develop frameworks for green and sustainability-linked loans. MAS also expanded the Sustainable Bond Grant Scheme to include sustainability-linked bonds, and banks such as OCBC, UOB, and BNP Paribas introduced targeted frameworks to support sustainable development.

site_title: Biden expected to pick former Fed chair Janet Yellen as Treasury secretary
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is expected to nominate Janet Yellen, the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve, as the next Treasury secretary. If confirmed, Yellen, 74, will be the first woman to lead the Treasury in its 231-year history, bringing a long-held preference for government help for struggling households and slightly tighter financial regulation. She will face a politically divided Congress and must navigate a stimulus deal, but her experience and connections make her well-placed to broker a deal. Yellen has been a champion of continued government support for workers and businesses during the pandemic.

site_title: Thai central bank concerned about baht leap, but no pressing need for QE
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput expressed concern over the country's baht currency's rapid rise, but downplayed the need for unconventional measures like quantitative easing. The baht jumped 3% in recent weeks due to a better-than-expected third quarter economic drop and hopes for post-Covid-19 vaccine tourism recovery. Tourism accounts for 12% of Thailand's economy and 20% of jobs, with the central bank forecasting fewer than a quarter of pre-pandemic tourist numbers in 2021. The central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0.50% for a fourth consecutive meeting.

site_title: Next year's Chinese New Year Bazaar at Chinatown called off
summary: The Chinese New Year Bazaar at Chinatown in Singapore has been cancelled for the first time in its history due to concerns over crowd control during the ongoing pandemic. Organisers cited uncertainties over when Phase 3 of Singapore's re-opening will begin as the reason for the decision.

site_title: No active Covid-19 clusters in Singapore for the first time since Feb 3
summary: Singapore has not seen active Covid-19 clusters for the first time since February 3, according to the Ministry of Health. The Cassia @ Penjuru cluster was closed after 28 days without new cases. The country reported 18 new cases, all of which were imported, marking 14 consecutive days without community cases. The total number of cases stands at 58,183, with 58,064 patients fully recovered and 37 remaining in hospital.

site_title: Tiffany beats profit estimates on soaring China demand
summary: Tiffany & Co. exceeded Wall Street expectations with a quarterly profit boost driven by a 70% surge in sales in China and a recovery in US demand. The jeweller's results are positive for the upcoming holiday season and underscore the growing importance of China sales. CEO Alessandro Bogliolo attributed the success to the Tiffany brand's strength and the successful completion of the merger with LVMH, which was finalized in early 2021.

site_title: ECB warns of economic hit if pandemic-support is phased out
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns that phasing out pandemic-support measures could lead to a 2-4% decline in the euro zone's GDP by the end of 2021, with a more significant impact in the first half of the year. The ECB cautions that this could trigger a downward shift in the recovery path, but also notes that prolonged support could hinder long-term growth and financial stability.

site_title: Scepticism, independence essential qualities for sponsors, issue managers
summary: Singapore's Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has announced new due diligence standards for issue managers and full sponsors of companies going public on Catalist, a second board for high-growth firms. The new rules require firms to assess clients' businesses, internal controls, and operations in specialized industries. To properly implement these guidelines, issue managers and sponsors must emphasize "substance over form" and exhibit professional scepticism, avoiding conflicts of interest and maintaining independence. The new rules aim to improve the quality of IPOs in the local market and address concerns about companies' attractiveness and promise.

site_title: Over 12,000 openings in ICT sector; 95% of them in PMET roles
summary: Singapore's ICT sector has over 12,000 job openings, with 95% in PMET roles. The sector has the highest placements under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, with 7,190 jobseekers placed into jobs, traineeships, and attachments. The Ministry of Manpower and Infocomm Media Development Authority plan to add 750 more places for SMEs over the next three years to reskill workers. Salaries for ICT roles range from S$3,750 to S$7,500, with more than 1 in 3 job openings in "tech-lite" roles.

site_title: China to maintain continuous, stable macro policy
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced that the country will maintain a continuous and stable macroeconomic policy, with a focus on reform measures and promoting economic activity to a reasonable range. China will continue to implement active fiscal policy and a steady monetary policy. This statement comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Ikea furnishes strong results despite pandemic
summary: Ikea's holding company, Ingka, reported a 5.0% drop in revenue to $44.4 billion for its 2019-2020 financial year, despite the pandemic. Net profit fell by a third to $1.2 billion. The strong demand for home furnishings helped Ingka to withstand the economic impact of the pandemic, with 90% of its sales coming from Ikea stores.

site_title: Airlines see losses swelling to US$157b before virus clears
summary: Airlines predict record losses of nearly US$157 billion by 2021 due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, more than double the June forecast. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) attributes the increase to anticipated vaccination programs taking time to revive travel demand. The industry has already accumulated a US$118.5 billion deficit in the current year, surpassing losses from the 2008-2009 recession. IATA forecasts the industry will turn cash positive again in the fourth quarter of 2021, earlier than previously predicted.

site_title: Germany's DAX to get bigger, stricter after Wirecard fiasco
summary: Germany's DAX index is set to expand with 10 new companies and stricter quality controls after the Wirecard scandal. The index will add 40 members from 30, with new criteria including quarterly statements and audited annual results. Existing members will have until August 2022 to adapt to the new rule, and new members will need to have been profitable for the past two years. The changes aim to make the index a better proxy for the economy and reduce its vulnerability to sharp market moves.

site_title: KrisEnergy unit to dodge winding-up petition after US$15.3m settlement with Rubicon
summary: KrisEnergy's subsidiary, KrisEnergy (Gulf of Thailand) (KEGOT), will avoid a winding-up petition after reaching a $15.3 million settlement with Rubicon Vantage International. The settlement resolves claims related to a 2014 bareboat charter, and both parties will stop all legal action. KrisEnergy shares remain suspended from trading. The company is seeking to restructure $476.8 million in debts through a scheme of arrangement in the Singapore High Court.

site_title: Now's the time for Singapore to grow the next crop of homegrown MNCs: Chan
summary: Singapore has a "historic opportunity" to grow more local companies into global champions, said Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. The country's unique advantages, including its neutrality in geopolitics, lack of a large domestic market, and strong intellectual property regime, make it fertile ground for growth. Companies like Sea Group, a US$89 billion market capitalization e-commerce platform, are leading the charge, with success stories in the tech and healthcare sectors. Growing local companies into global champions can create better jobs for Singaporeans and uplift small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Covid-19 could worsen income inequality for fiscally weak countries in South-east Asia
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that the COVID-19 pandemic could exacerbate income inequality in fiscally weak countries in South-east Asia, particularly Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines. The report notes that these countries have weak social protection systems and limited fiscal capacity, leading to increased vulnerability for lower-income groups. While some countries, such as India and Indonesia, are using cash transfers to support vulnerable groups, the overall social protection coverage is low, and tax policies have limited effectiveness in addressing income inequality.

site_title: Nail salons, lifeline for immigrants, have lost half their business
summary: Nail salons, a crucial lifeline for immigrant women in New York City, have lost half their business due to the pandemic. Owners like Juyoung Lee, who runs a salon in Queens, are struggling to stay afloat with dwindling appointments and customers seeking cheaper services. The beauty industry, once poised for a strong recovery, is now on the verge of collapse, leaving a significant economic impact on immigrant women who rely on these businesses. Many salons have been forced to close, leaving owners uncertain about their future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed slightly higher on Tuesday, driven by Joe Biden's transition into the White House. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.39%, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.34%. The gains were tempered by concerns about a potential virus spike in Hong Kong.

site_title: Tech giants ask Malaysia PM to reinstate foreign ship cable waiver
summary: Tech giants Microsoft, Google, and Facebook have asked Malaysia's Prime Minister to reinstate a 2019 waiver allowing non-Malaysian ships to repair submarine cables in the country's waters. The waiver, overturned by the Transport Ministry, would enable foreign vessels to work more efficiently, reducing repair times. The companies claim longer repair times will result from the new requirements, which would force foreign vessels to apply for domestic shipping licenses. The Malaysian premier was asked to reconsider the decision, which would benefit the companies and the country's telecommunications industry.

site_title: More than 12,000 ICT openings, 95% in PMET roles
summary: Singapore has over 12,000 ICT job openings, with 95% in PMET roles, offering salaries ranging from S$3,750 to S$7,500. Local employment in the sector has expanded by 17,000 since 2015, forming 71% of the sector's total employment. To address the growth, the government and industry have implemented a three-pronged approach, including placement programs, traineeships, and nurturing a pipeline of talent in Institutes of Higher Learning.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets advance at open
summary: European stock markets advanced at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.7% to 6,379.44 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 0.8% to 13,236.63 points, and the Paris CAC 40 jumping 1.0% to 5,544.43 points. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong to shut bars, nightclubs for third time as new Covid-19 cases jump
summary: Hong Kong is shutting bars, nightclubs, and entertainment venues for the third time this year due to a surge in COVID-19 cases, with 80 new infections reported on Tuesday. The measures will last until at least December 3. Over 180 cases are linked to dance clubs, and authorities have tightened social distancing measures, citing a severe pandemic. This decision has also postponed a travel bubble between Hong Kong and Singapore for at least two weeks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 19.09 points lower on Tuesday at 1,578.39, with a trading volume of 8.361 billion lots worth RM4.284 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,093 to 250.

site_title: STI up 1.5%, sentiment boosted by Biden transition and hopes of economic recovery
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% to 2,891.63, boosted by news of President-elect Joe Biden's transition and hopes for economic recovery. Analysts say a Biden administration is expected to be less isolationist, positively affecting Asia and global trade. Transport-related counters, such as Singapore Airlines and ComfortDelGro, were the best-performers on the STI, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the worst-performer.

site_title: Credit Suisse to take US$450m charge on hedge fund York
summary: Credit Suisse expects to book a $450 million impairment charge on its stake in hedge fund York Capital Management as the US firm winds down most of its hedge-fund strategies. The charge, to be booked in the fourth quarter, follows a tough year for the bank, marked by fund closures, losses on loans, and lackluster trading results. York Capital is retooling to focus on long-term products after a year of disruption, and Credit Suisse will take a 30% stake in the firm, which had previously offered to pay at least $425 million for access to alternative investments.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group expects to book a US$450 million impairment on its stake in York Capital Management as the US firm winds down most of its hedge-fund strategies, the latest blow for the bank after a series of setbacks this year.

site_title: Sea's Forrest Li named SBA's Businessman of the Year
summary: Forrest Li, founder, chairman, and CEO of Sea Ltd, was named Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards 2019/2020. The award recognizes his vision in building a consumer Internet giant with a strong global presence, including its digital entertainment arm Garena, e-commerce platform Shopee, and fintech unit SeaMoney. Li was honored alongside other award winners, including NTUC Enterprise and FairPrice Group's CEO Seah Kian Peng and Ping An Insurance's co-CEO Jessica Tan Sin Yin.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends up 2.5% as Biden gets transition help
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 2.5% on Tuesday, closing at 26,165.59, after US President Donald Trump dropped opposition to government aid for Joe Biden's transition team. Markets were also boosted by new vaccine news. The broader Topix index added 2.03%, playing catch-up after a long weekend.

site_title: Indonesia to tap global markets more to finance 2021 deficit
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo announced plans to increase bond sales in global markets in 2021 to fund the government's fiscal deficit. The move aims to reduce reliance on domestic markets and mitigate volatility. Governor Warjiyo stated that the government's finance minister will allocate more funds to global issuance, indicating a shift in financing strategy. This plan is expected to help Indonesia manage its 2021 deficit and take advantage of lower volatility in global markets.

site_title: Novartis plans US$2.5b share buyback as pipeline grows
summary: Novartis plans to buy back up to $2.5 billion of shares as its pipeline of new drug candidates is expected to drive sales growth. The company anticipates key data on five experimental cancer medicines in mid- to late-stage clinical trials next year. Novartis estimates it has the pharma industry's second-largest pipeline, with projected revenue from new treatments set to be launched through 2026. The company also raised its forecast for the year, driven by new products, including a gene therapy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at record high on vaccine hopes, Biden transition
summary: South Korea's Kospi index closed at a record high, up 0.58%, driven by gains from Samsung Electronics and foreign investors, who bought for the 14th straight session. The rally was boosted by news of a potential 90% effective Covid-19 vaccine from AstraZeneca and US President-elect Joe Biden's formal approval for his White House transition. Foreigners have bought a total of 7.09 trillion won worth of shares over the past 14 sessions.

site_title: 'Alone in the dark': South Korea's small businesses reel from new virus clampdown
summary: A new round of social distancing rules in South Korea's capital Seoul has dealt a blow to small businesses, with measures including closures of nightclubs and curbs on dining in restaurants. Despite economic recovery efforts, owners of small businesses and street shops are struggling to stay afloat, with many considering permanent closure due to revenue drops. The government has yet to propose new stimulus measures, and opposition parties are calling for billions of dollars in aid to those affected by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: A new round of social distancing rules took effect on Tuesday in the South Korean capital of Seoul, dealing a blow to small business owners despite brighter hopes for economic recovery after earlier success in battling the coronavirus.

site_title: Bountiful monsoon rains set to boost India's agriculture growth
summary: India's farm sector growth is expected to reach its highest level in three years, driven by better-than-normal monsoon rains. Agriculture growth is projected to surpass 4% in 2020-21, the highest since 2017-18. Key crops like rice, sugar cane, and soybeans are expected to see significant increases in production, with sugar cane output rising to almost 400 million tons. This is the first time India is witnessing bumper crops and good commodity prices, benefiting the country's position as the world's second-largest producer of rice, wheat, and sugar.

images.alt_text: India's farm sector growth will likely be the highest in three years as better-than-normal rain helped farmers to boost output of crops, including rice, sugar cane and soybeans.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CIMB Singapore has appointed three new business heads: Merlyn Tsai for consumer banking, Benjamin Tan Wee Chuan for commercial banking, and Foo Tsiang Wei for corporate and investment banking. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a grant to support green and sustainability-linked loans. Mapletree is investing over S$550m in a Japan site to develop logistics facilities. DBS has partnered with JD Logistics to offer supply chain financing to Hong Kong-based SMEs. Meanwhile, Ameerali R. Jumabhoy, patriarch of Scotts Holdings, has passed away at 94.

site_title: Tokyo governor says best case for Olympics is with venues full of spectators
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike stated that the best case scenario for the 2020 Summer Olympics is having venues full of spectators, amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Tokyo has seen record-high daily cases, with a rise in infections among older residents, including those who contracted the virus while eating out. This scenario would allow the Games to proceed with minimal disruptions, but organizers are still debating the best plan.

images.alt_text: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike said on Tuesday the best case scenario for the Summer Olympics next year is to have venues full of spectators, as organisers debate how to plan for the Games amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank-led round values Uber-like truck startup at US$12b
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund, along with other investors including Tencent Holdings and Sequoia, has raised US$1.7 billion for Full Truck Alliance, a Chinese trucking startup, valuing it at around US$12 billion. The funding will be used to expand the company's services into same-city deliveries. Full Truck Alliance, formed by the merger of two truck-sharing platforms, has attracted significant backing, including Alphabet's CapitalG. The startup has reportedly broken even and handles transactions for 10 million truckers and 5 million shippers.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to start Paris trading venue as Brexit approaches
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to launch a Paris-based trading venue, SIGMA X Europe, to ensure clients can continue to buy and sell EU shares post-Brexit. The venue will operate a private stock market and accept firms regulated under MiFID II rules. Goldman joins rivals Cboe Europe and London Stock Exchange Group in forming European trading platforms to mitigate disruption. The move aims to protect clients from potential trading volume losses in London, where about a third of EU share trading takes place. Regulatory approvals are needed before the venue's launch on or before January 4.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc is planning a European stock trading platform to ensure its clients can still buy and sell shares even without a post-Brexit agreement to allow dealing in London.

site_title: Mapletree buys sprawling Japan site for warehouses, to invest over S$550m
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired a 116,319 sq m land plot in Fukuoka, Japan, for over S$550 million to develop two Grade A logistics facilities. The project will be the largest warehouse space in Kyushu upon completion, with construction expected to start in 2022 and finish in 2023 and 2024, respectively. The acquisition marks Mapletree's entry into the Kyushu logistics market, driven by the growing demand for logistics facilities in Japan, particularly in the regions of Fukuoka and Kyushu.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the logistics development. This is set to be the largest warehouse space in Kyushu upon completion, Mapletree said.
Artist's impression of the logistics development. This is set to be the largest warehouse space in Kyushu upon completion, Mapletree said.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as vaccine euphoria fuels recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares closed 1.3% higher on Tuesday, driven by a third promising vaccine candidate from AstraZeneca, which could be up to 90% effective. Energy stocks led the gains, advancing 3.6% to their highest in over five months. Financials also rose, hitting their highest in over eight months, with the "Big Four" banks climbing between 3.1% and 2%. The S&P/ASX 200 benchmark index closed at 6,644.1 points. The market is optimistic about the impact of the vaccine, but experts warn that its implementation will take time.

site_title: Try a red wine from the nation of Georgia
summary: A Georgian red wine blend called Lost Eden, made with an 11th-generation winemaker, is now available in the US. The blend, dominated by saperavi, is dark and earthy with brambly flavors of wild berries. It's aged in traditional Georgian qvevris and sold in a unique bottle with a vinous relief pattern. Georgia, considered the birthplace of wine, is emerging on the world's wine lists, with this wine marking a significant step in its global presence.

images.alt_text: The country of Georgia considers itself to be the birthplace of wine, with a tradition going back about 8,000 years. Wine drinkers elsewhere are still just discovering it, as Georgia's emergence on the world's wine lists really began with the fall of the Soviet Union.

site_title: New Zealand government asks RBNZ to include taming red-hot housing in remit, NZ$ jumps
summary: The New Zealand government has asked the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to include house price stability as part of its monetary policy remit, amid concerns about a property bubble. The move has boosted the local dollar, with the NZD reaching its highest level since mid-2018. Finance Minister Grant Robertson believes the rapid escalation in house prices poses a financial stability risk to the economy and may affect the government's ability to meet its economic objectives. The central bank may resist moving towards negative interest rates next year, as policymakers seek to restrain the booming property market.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand government has asked the central bank to consider factoring house price stability as part of its broad monetary remit, Finance Minister Grant Robertson said, boosting the local dollar on market bets of less stimulus over the next year.

site_title: South Korea's exports extend recovery despite worsening pandemic
summary: South Korea's exports showed a 11% rise in the first 20 days of November, with average daily shipments increasing 7.6%. The recovery is attributed to tech demand and improved trade with China, the US, and Europe, despite record coronavirus cases. Semiconductor shipments surged 22% and wireless communications devices jumped 36%. The boost is seen as a sign of a patchy global trade recovery until vaccines become available, with the pandemic-driven demand for tech products supporting exports.

images.alt_text: South Korea's early trade data showed exports extending their recovery in November, as tech demand remained resilient amid record coronavirus cases in major economies.

site_title: JTC launches Jalan Papan industrial site for application
summary: JTC has launched an industrial site at Jalan Papan (Plot 5) for application, offering a 0.56-hectare land plot with a 20-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The site is zoned B2 for heavy industrial use and is the last of three reserve list sites available for the 2020 industrial government land sales programme. The launch aims to provide more choices for industrial development, following the government's efforts to offer a range of options for industrial development.

site_title: Americans defy virus guidelines for high-risk Thanksgiving
summary: US authorities have urged Americans not to travel for Thanksgiving despite the high risk of exacerbating the coronavirus pandemic. With over 150,000 new cases daily, the US has the world's highest coronavirus death toll. Most state governors have warned citizens against turning their dining rooms into hotbeds of coronavirus, but many plan to celebrate with extended family despite the guidelines. The US government has stopped short of issuing an outright ban.

site_title: Tech startups drive 100% jump in IPOs on Tel Aviv Stock Exchange
summary: Israeli startups drove a 100% surge in initial public offerings on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, with 14 companies worth $650 million listed through October, a three-year high. The growth is attributed to reforms by the exchange and local regulators, bolstering the local tech sector, and the shift in tech funding dynamics during the Covid-19 pandemic, which saw foreign investment drop and local investment jump. This shift has encouraged more tech companies to list at home, with some opting for dual-listing in other markets.

site_title: DBS partners JD Logistics to offer supply chain financing to Hong Kong-based SMEs
summary: DBS has partnered with JD Logistics to offer supply chain financing to Hong Kong-based small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the cross-border e-commerce import business. Through this partnership, DBS will provide financing to SMEs that place their inventory in JD Logistics' bonded warehouses and sell imported goods on JD Worldwide. The financing will improve cash flow for merchants and enable real-time data exchange between DBS and JD Logistics. The partnership aims to strengthen DBS' Greater Bay Area strategy and grow its cross-border SME franchise.

site_title: Thai police to deploy thousands for royal protest
summary: Thai police will deploy nearly 6,000 officers to a demonstration at the Crown Property Bureau, where protesters are demanding King Maha Vajiralongkorn give up personal control of royal assets. The protesters, who want a new constitution and reforms to curb the king's powers, have broken taboos by making these demands. The previous day's violent clashes between police and protesters resulted in over 50 injuries, and police are prepared to take measures to keep the two groups apart. The king has not commented on the protests, but said protesters are "loved all the same".

site_title: German economy grew by 8.5% in third quarter, but recession fears grow
summary: Germany's economy experienced a record 8.5% growth in the third quarter, driven by higher household spending and exports. This rebound partly offset the 9.8% decline in the second quarter caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. However, recession fears grow due to a second wave of coronavirus infections and a partial lockdown, which may lead to a 1% decline in GDP in the fourth quarter. Chancellor Angela Merkel and regional state premiers plan to extend the lockdown until Dec 20, and a contraction in the service sector is expected to weigh on the economy.

images.alt_text: Germany's gross domestic product grew by a record 8.5 per cent in the third quarter as Europe's largest economy partly recovered from an unprecedented plunge caused by the first wave of the Covid-19 pandemic in spring, the statistics office said on Tuesday.

site_title: Woman in defamation case filed by HC Surgical doctor fails again to overturn court decision
summary: Serene Tiong, a minority shareholder of HC Surgical Specialists, has failed in her application to the Court of Appeal to overturn the High Court's decision that she is liable for defamation against surgeon Julian Ong. The High Court ordered Tiong to pay S$40,000 in costs and S$5,000 in application costs to Ong. Tiong had claimed that Ong and psychiatrist Chan Herng Nieng colluded to take advantage of vulnerable patients, but the Court of Appeal dismissed her application for leave to appeal on October 15.

site_title: Gold mining emissions draw scrutiny after price surge
summary: Gold miners face increased scrutiny over high greenhouse gas emissions, with investors pushing for transparent reporting and emissions reductions. The sector emits 32,689 tonnes of CO2 equivalent per tonne of gold produced in 2018, with heavy haul trucks and power supplies being major sources of emissions. Investors, such as George Cheveley, are considering the environmental impact of their investments, with some companies committing to reduce emissions by 2030. The World Gold Council estimates emissions will continue to rise, prompting calls for governments to implement stricter controls on emissions.

site_title: Japan eyes tighter virus steps as severe cases in Tokyo jump
summary: Japan is considering tighter virus restrictions as severe cases in Tokyo surge, with the city reporting a 24% increase in severe cases overnight to 51. The metropolitan region of Osaka plans to ask bars and restaurants to close early, while Tokyo may also implement similar measures. Japan's government lacks the legal means for a harsh lockdown but is urging businesses and citizens to voluntarily take measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

images.alt_text: As Japan returned to work Tuesday following a holiday weekend, regional and national authorities moved toward boosting restrictions designed to contain the spread of a coronavirus surge.

site_title: Pair of adjoining shophouses along Bukit Pasoh Rd up for sale with S$35m guide price
summary: A pair of adjoining shophouses along Bukit Pasoh Road in Singapore have been put up for sale with a guide price of S$35 million. The freehold properties, with a built-up area of 10,078 sq ft, are zoned commercial/conservation and have a combined land area of 4,745 sq ft. They are open to both local and foreign purchasers, and the ground and second floors are leased to two restaurants. The property can potentially be converted into a hotel, subject to authorities' approval.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.33 points, or 0.27%, to 1,593.15 on Tuesday. The market opened lower with 484.30 million lots traded worth RM218.44 million. The day's results show 219 gainers versus 216 losers.

site_title: Hundreds of flights cancelled as Shanghai tackles virus outbreak
summary: Hundreds of flights at Shanghai's Pudong International Airport were cancelled due to a local coronavirus outbreak linked to cargo handlers. Over 500 flights were cancelled, with nearly half of scheduled inbound flights also affected. Thousands of staff have been tested, including employees from FedEx and UPS. The city is also testing around 2.6 million people in Tianjin to control a local cluster. Authorities have shifted focus to imported shipments blamed for a resurgence of local infections, with experimental vaccines being provided to high-risk workers.

images.alt_text: More than 17,700 people had been swabbed by Monday morning at part of a drive to test airport cargo staff.

site_title: India first priority for vaccine delivery: Serum Institute
summary: The Serum Institute of India, the world's largest vaccine manufacturer by volume, has announced that India will be given first priority for the delivery of the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine. The vaccine has shown a 70% effectiveness rate in stopping the virus after testing 23,000 people. The Serum Institute has already produced 40 million doses and aims to produce 100 million by January. The vaccine will be sold to the Indian government at a price of 250 rupees (S$4.03) for 90% of doses, with the remaining 10% sold in the private market at a higher price.

site_title: Air travellers most concerned about catching covid from fellow fliers, survey shows
summary: A survey by J D Power found that air travelers are most concerned about contracting COVID-19 from fellow passengers on aircraft, despite the airline industry's claims that flying is safe. The survey of over 50,000 respondents showed that nearly a quarter weren't worried about the virus, while only 10% expressed "great concern." In contrast, hotel rooms and rental cars were considered safer than the cabin of a passenger plane, where travelers can control their own personal space and minimize interaction with strangers.

site_title: Australia opens up more borders in domestic travel boost, eyes vaccine
summary: Australia is lifting internal border restrictions, allowing visitors from New South Wales and Victoria to travel to Queensland, as new coronavirus infections slow. The moves aim to boost tourism and revive the economy, which shrank 7% in the past quarter. Health Minister Greg Hunt expects the country to complete a vaccination program by March, with AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine potentially 90% effective.

site_title: Millions of Americans expect to lose their homes as Covid rages
summary: Millions of Americans expect to lose their homes due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. A survey by the US Census Bureau found that 5.8 million adults are at risk of eviction or foreclosure in the next two months, with 17.8 million households behind on rent or mortgage payments. The CARES Act's temporary suspension on evictions is set to end on December 31, coinciding with the expiration of unemployment benefits for millions of people. The threat of eviction is most pressing in major cities like New York City, Houston, and Atlanta.

site_title: CIMB Singapore names three new business heads to replace axed trio
summary: CIMB Singapore has named new business heads to replace three axed executives. Merlyn Tsai, Benjamin Tan Wee Chuan, and Foo Tsiang Wei will lead consumer banking, commercial banking, and corporate and investment banking, respectively. They will replace Josandi Thor, Yong Jiunn Run, and Lai Ven-Li.

site_title: MAS launches grant to support green and sustainability-linked loans
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a grant scheme to support green and sustainability-linked loans, effective January 1, 2021. The scheme aims to encourage banks to develop frameworks for these loans, with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and individuals. The grant covers up to 90% of expenses for SMEs and up to 60% for banks, with a cap of S$180,000 and S$120,000 respectively. The scheme also expands the existing Sustainable Bond Grant Scheme to include sustainability-linked bonds.

site_title: Correction looming for 'stubbornly high' real estate prices in APAC
summary: A market correction is looming for Asia-Pacific (APAC) real estate, which has remained resilient amid the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a 38% year-on-year decline in property investment volumes in Q3 2020, prices and cap rates have remained stable. However, stress is expected to surface in China, India, and Australia, which may lead to forced sales next year. Buyers and sellers are in a standoff over asset pricing, with conviction growing that artificially high asset prices are due for a fall. The report warns of a potential economic downturn and reduced investor profitability, with expectations approaching 2009 lows.

site_title: Study calculates cost of US business shutdowns
summary: Researchers from HEC Paris and Bocconi University have calculated the cost of US business shutdowns during the COVID-19 pandemic. The closures, from March to May, saved 29,000 lives at a cost of $169 billion, or $6 million per person. The shutdowns reduced economic activity, with governors prioritizing lives over economic impact. The study highlights the trade-off between saving lives and reducing economic activity during the pandemic.

site_title: Japan's ramen bars struggle to stay open as Covid hammers small firms
summary: Japan's ramen bars are struggling to stay afloat due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 34 noodle businesses filing for bankruptcy nationwide in the first nine months of 2020. Small and mid-sized businesses, which employ 70% of Japan's workers, are particularly affected, with bankruptcies rising 4.5% in restaurants and 137% in those with less than 10 million yen in liabilities. Industry insiders estimate that the true number of closures may be higher, with some shops closing without official filings, and a new platform is helping match businesses looking to shut down with firms hoping to move in.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange plans smart contract solution for Stock Connect problems
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) plans to introduce a smart contract solution to resolve issues with its Stock Connect scheme, which allows overseas investors to trade Chinese shares. The new platform aims to synchronize information in real-time, addressing problems caused by China's "T+0" trading and settlement schedule, which conflicts with the "T+2" schedule used by many international investors. The system will be trialed with pilot users in 2021 and launched in early 2022, following a previous attempt with distributed ledger technology.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) on Tuesday said it will introduce a new platform with so-called smart contracts to resolve long-standing inconveniences for overseas investors trading Chinese shares via its Stock Connect scheme.

site_title: Chicago latest city to cap delivery fees to aid restaurants
summary: The Chicago City Council approved a measure to cap delivery fees charged by third-party delivery services to restaurants at 10% of the purchase price and 15% of monthly net sales. This move aims to assist restaurants struggling financially due to the pandemic, with Chicago joining cities like New York City and Los Angeles in implementing the cap. The measure is in response to the financial stress caused by a drop in business and the reliance on services like DoorDash amid indoor dining bans.

site_title: Top Glove shares tumble after government says factories to be shut
summary: Malaysia's Top Glove shares plummeted 7.5% in early trade after the government announced plans to shut 28 factory buildings in phases for Covid-19 screening and quarantine. The shutdowns follow a sharp rise in cases among Top Glove workers and dormitory residents, with 2,453 out of 5,767 screened testing positive for the virus. The government did not specify when the shutdowns would begin.

site_title: Sweden's Scania to start making trucks in China after acquisition
summary: Scania, a unit of Volkswagen AG, has acquired Nantong Gaokai, a Chinese truck company, to start manufacturing trucks in China for the first time. The acquisition allows Scania to obtain a truck manufacturing license in China, where overall truck sales jumped 24% to 3.87 million vehicles from January to October. Scania plans to produce models in the market, which is dominated by local automakers offering more price-competitive vehicles. The move aims to tap into China's growing truck market, driven by government investment in infrastructure and stricter emissions rules.

site_title: China's e-yuan solves one stimulus problem
summary: China's e-yuan digital currency has seen transactions totaling over $300 million in trials across the country, surpassing expectations. The central bank's virtual money has shown promise in encouraging spending among consumers, potentially boosting consumption and helping to stimulate the economy. This could be a key factor in the government's stimulus efforts, which have faced mixed success in the past, including with cash handouts and discount vouchers. The e-yuan's success may lead to a more significant upgrade to the country's stimulus package.

site_title: Online luxury retailer Mytheresa says it has filed for IPO
summary: Mytheresa, a luxury online retailer, has filed confidentially for a US initial public offering (IPO). The company, backed by Ares Management Corp and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, plans to seek a valuation of $1 billion to $1.5 billion. Mytheresa, which sells over 250 brands, including Gucci and Prada, is taking advantage of the boom in online sales during the coronavirus lockdowns. The IPO is expected to take place in early 2021, pending US Securities and Exchange Commission review.

site_title: Nuclear to cost UK S$1.18b a year more than flexi power
summary: A report by Wartsila OYJ Abp found that building a new large nuclear plant alongside renewable power would cost the UK S$1.18 billion more annually. The UK government has pledged 500 million pounds to support small modular reactors. In contrast, installing flexible energy technologies and battery energy storage could rapidly boost renewable energy to 2030, with costs comparable to nuclear power.

site_title: Senior Chinese diplomat visits Japan amid regional tensions
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi is visiting Japan, marking the first high-level trip since Japan's new leader, Yoshihide Suga, took office. The visit comes amid regional tensions and concerns over Beijing's growing assertiveness. Suga aims to balance Japan's economic reliance on China with addressing security worries, including Beijing's claims over the disputed East China Sea isles. The visit is seen as a test of Suga's diplomatic approach, which has sought to deepen ties with Australia and counter US influence.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says no immediate need to overhaul policy framework
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that there is no immediate need to overhaul the central bank's monetary policy framework, citing the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the economy and keeping inflation distant from its 2% target. However, Kuroda left room for future debate, noting that other major central banks, such as the US Federal Reserve, are re-examining their frameworks. This decision comes as the BOJ continues to monitor inflation and economic conditions, potentially paving the way for a review of its policy framework in the future.

site_title: Cheese prices plunge as lockdowns bite into dining business
summary: Cheese prices in the US are plummeting due to the second COVID-19 lockdown, which is forcing diners to stay away from restaurants. California's curfew and New York City's indoor dining ban are expected to cut into prices for dairy products. Cheese blocks have slipped 13% this year to $1.66 a pound, while barrel cheese is down 18%. Experts predict prices may drop as low as $1.41 a pound by March, but fast-food outlets and take-out restaurants may help cushion the impact for dairy producers.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE upgrades Singapore, Malaysia tech sectors to 'positive'
summary: Maybank KE has upgraded its rating on Singapore and Malaysia's tech sectors to 'positive' from 'neutral', citing the rollout of 5G networks and the growth of semiconductor components and equipment. The analysts expect the sector to ride an upcycle, driven by Industry 4.0, the Internet of Things, AI, and electric vehicles. The global semiconductor market is projected to grow 6.2% in 2021, with equipment sales expected to grow 11%. Maybank KE has identified Frencken Group, Venture Corp, and Inari Amertron as top picks in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: theAsianparent bags funding from Siam Commercial Bank's venture capital arm
summary: theAsianparent, a parenting community platform, has secured a "seven-figure sum" in funding from Siam Commercial Bank's venture capital arm, SCB 10X. The investment is part of the platform's Series C round, which also included other investors. theAsianparent aims to improve financial literacy among young families in Thailand through curated financial information and analysis. The platform's founder, Roshni Mahtani, expressed excitement about the partnership, citing the opportunity to work on financial innovation for young parents.

site_title: Corporate services startup Sleek raises US$4m in round led by SEEDS Capital
summary: Sleek, a Singapore-based corporate services platform, has raised US$4 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by SEEDS Capital. The funding brings the startup's total to US$11 million, which will be used to expand to new markets in Asia and develop digital tools. The goal is to provide high-quality corporate and financial services to entrepreneurs, investors, and small to medium enterprises.

site_title: Australia: Shares at near nine-month peak as vaccine news spurs recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares reached a near nine-month peak as a potential Covid-19 vaccine's positive news and US business activity data boosted optimism about a global economic recovery. AstraZeneca's vaccine was reported to be up to 90% effective and cheaper to distribute, sparking hopes for the end of the pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1% to 6,631.6, driven by energy stocks and heavyweight financials. Australia's Victoria state reported zero active coronavirus cases, further fueling the rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Tuesday's session on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.54% to 26,630.34, following news of Donald Trump's agreement to begin the transition to President-elect Joe Biden, easing post-election uncertainty.

site_title: Bitcoin at US$100,000 in 2021? Outrageous to some, a no-brainer for backers
summary: Bitcoin investors, including top hedge funds, are betting the virtual currency could more than quintuple to US$100,000 in a year, with some predicting it could reach US$100,000 to US$288,000 by end-2021. The surge is driven by strong institutional demand, scarcity, and the recent halving of new coins created. Analysts point to limited supply and ease of movement across borders as key factors. However, some experts, like Kevin Muir, argue that modeling Bitcoin's price is impossible due to its "mania" nature, and that the actual price could be much lower.

site_title: Artivision a step closer to proposed reverse takeover
summary: Artivision Technologies has completed pre-clearance consultation and submitted a pre-admission notification for its proposed reverse takeover (RTO) of electronic payment and online retail business Mobile Credit Payment (MC Payment). The company plans to seek shareholder approval by December 31 for the transaction, which was first announced in May 2018. Artivision has until February 28, 2021, to complete the transaction and meet requirements for a new listing on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Nissan to sell redesigned Note compact car in Japan as it looks to restore profitability
summary: Nissan Motor Co Ltd will sell a redesigned Note compact car in Japan from December, featuring new hybrid drive technology and autonomous drive functions. The redesign is part of a plan to revamp its aging vehicle lineup and return to profitability, shifting focus from international expansion to domestic sales. The "e-Power" hybrid technology uses a gasoline engine to charge a battery, while new autonomous drive functions help slow down on curves. The move aims to win market share from Toyota and Honda in Japan.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens sharply up after Trump agrees to transition aid
summary: US President Donald Trump agrees to transition aid for Joe Biden's team, boosting Tokyo shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.91% to 26,014.19, while the Topix index added 2.00% to 1,761.90. Markets were also influenced by new vaccine news, playing catch-up after a long weekend.

site_title: US: Stocks end up on vaccine progress, Yellen nomination
summary: US stocks rose on Monday following news of a new coronavirus vaccine's 90% effectiveness and President-elect Joe Biden's selection of Janet Yellen as treasury secretary. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.1%, the S&P 500 advanced 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.2%. Analysts cited optimism over the holiday shopping season and Yellen's expected appointment, which is seen as favorable to fiscal stimulus.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks advanced on Monday following another upbeat announcement about a new coronavirus vaccine and President-elect Joe Biden's selection of Janet Yellen to be treasury secretary.

site_title: PayPal CEO sees staff working from home more often after virus
summary: PayPal CEO Dan Schulman predicts that employees will spend more time working from home even after the pandemic ends. He envisions a hybrid model of working from home and office, with the majority splitting their time between the two. Schulman believes it may take until late summer 2021 or early fall for the company to bring more workers back to the office due to ongoing Covid-19 vaccine trials. The company is also expanding its cryptocurrency service, which has seen overwhelming demand and interest.

images.alt_text: PayPal employees will probably spend more time working from home even after the coronavirus pandemic is over.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.7% to 2,869.88, its third consecutive day of gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 126 to 30, with aviation-related counters such as SATS and Singapore Airlines trading higher following positive news on Covid-19 vaccines. Sembcorp Marine and Broadway Industrial Group shares also rose, while Top Glove fell 5.4%. The gains follow overnight gains on Wall Street, where stocks rose following more positive news on Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: UK to double renewables capacity eligible for next subsidy auctions
summary: The UK government announced plans to double the capacity of renewable energy projects eligible for support in its next round of subsidy auctions. The new allocation round will increase the capacity from 5.8 gigawatts to up to 12 gigawatts, enough to power 20 million electric cars per year. Floating offshore wind projects, solar, and onshore wind projects will be eligible to bid for the first time. Former coal-burning power stations converted to biomass will be excluded from future auctions. The next allocation round is expected to open late next year.

images.alt_text: The next allocation round for renewable energy technologies such as offshore wind will open late next year.

site_title: Japan's third extra budget to total more than 20t yen: newspaper
summary: Japan's third extra budget is likely to exceed 20 trillion yen (S$255.3 billion), according to the Sankei newspaper. The budget, aimed at revitalizing the coronavirus-hit economy, may be bigger than 15 trillion yen, with lawmakers calling for up to 40 trillion yen. The government plans to finalize the stimulus package in early December, focusing on digitalization and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This marks the third stimulus package, with the previous two totaling US$2.2 trillion.

site_title: Qantas to require Covid vaccine on international flights
summary: Qantas plans to require COVID-19 vaccination for international flights, with CEO Alan Joyce stating the rule will likely become common across the industry once a vaccine is available. The airline will update its terms and conditions to ask international travelers to have a vaccination before boarding. This move comes as Australia's international borders remain closed, and the country seeks to create "travel bubbles" with other nations. The airline has already taken significant measures to mitigate the pandemic's impact, including grounding planes and firing staff.

site_title: Broadway Industrial receives US$50m offer for hard disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial Group has received a binding letter of intent from Seksun Technology (Suzhou) Co to acquire its hard disk drive business for US$50 million. The proposed deal includes substantially all assets used in the actuator arm and related parts manufacturing operations, subject to certain assumptions. The purchase price is expected to be finalized, with Broadway Industrial's shares closing 2.5% higher at 12.4 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Biden to get his delayed presidential transition aid: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump said he no longer opposes government aid for Joe Biden's transition team, following a statement from the General Services Administration's head Emily Murphy, who released the delayed assistance. Trump had spent three weeks claiming election fraud without evidence, but his statement suggests he is finally conceding defeat. Murphy denied acting under political pressure, and the aid package includes standard assistance for Biden's incoming team.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said on Monday he no longer opposes government aid for Joe Biden's transition team in his closest statement yet to finally conceding he lost the US election.

site_title: GM quits Trump lawsuit against California auto emissions rules
summary: General Motors (GM) has withdrawn from a lawsuit challenging California's fuel economy rules, a move backed by President-Elect Joe Biden's policy for boosting electric autos. GM joined Toyota and Fiat Chrysler in the challenge, arguing for federal regulation. CEO Mary Barra, who has clashed with former President Trump, said she's confident in the Biden administration's ability to collaborate on an all-electric future, citing the administration's "Build Back Better" plan. GM also announced a $7 billion investment in electric and autonomous vehicle technology.

site_title: Semi-detached house near Orchard Road up for tender
summary: A freehold two-storey semi-detached house at 61 Jalan Kelawar, near Orchard Road, is up for tender with expected offers around S$7.8 million (S$2,529 per square foot). The property is rare to find in close proximity to Orchard Road, attracting keen interest from wealthy buyers. This marks the strongest quarterly figure for landed homes since Q2 2018, with over 540 homes sold in the third quarter. The tender will close on Dec 22.

site_title: Biden to nominate ex-Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen to Treasury: source
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is set to nominate former Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen as Treasury Secretary, a move that would make her the first woman to hold the position. Yellen, 74, will be tasked with steering the US economy through the COVID-19 pandemic and mass layoffs. Her nomination, supported by left-wing Democrats, requires Senate confirmation and comes as the US faces a deadlock over a new stimulus spending bill. Yellen, known for her dovish stance on interest rates, will succeed Steven Mnuchin and likely face breaking the congressional deadlock.

site_title: Australia hits back at 'needless' worsening of China ties
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison criticized China's worsening relations with Australia, calling it "needlessly deteriorating relationships." China has imposed economic sanctions and complaints over Australian policies, including banning Huawei in 5G rollout and investigating the coronavirus pandemic's origins. Morrison urged smaller nations not to be caught in the crossfire of the Sino-US rivalry, emphasizing the need for mutually beneficial relations with both the US and China. He warned of coercive diplomacy and urged greater latitude for countries to pursue their own interests.

images.alt_text: Australia has hit out at "needlessly" worsening relations with China, with the country's prime minister appealing for smaller nations not to be caught in the crossfire of Sino-US rivalry.

site_title: Tensions mount in Thai protests as Bangkok braces for major rally
summary: Tensions rise in Thailand as protesters prepare for a major rally in Bangkok, calling for Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's resignation, constitutional changes, and monarchy reform. The student-led movement has gained momentum, with slogans and insults against the monarchy becoming more common. Authorities have taken a cautious approach, but have hardened their tone, threatening to use the kingdom's strict royal defamation laws. The royal family has launched a charm offensive, but King Maha Vajiralongkorn's popularity remains low. Experts warn of a potential violent climax, with some predicting a possible coup, and a constitutional court case against Prayut Chan-O-Cha expected to bring some relief to the unrest.

images.alt_text: Tensions are rising around Thailand's pro-democracy protests, with police shooting six people last week and using tear gas and water cannon on the streets of Bangkok.

site_title: UK considers whether to remove British judges from Hong Kong court
summary: Britain is considering removing its judges from Hong Kong's highest court, the Court of Final Appeal, amid concerns over China's breaches of its international obligations in the territory. The decision comes after China imposed a national security law that punishes dissent with up to life in jail, sparking international concern over the erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has begun consulting on the issue, and Britain has already taken steps to distance itself from Hong Kong, including suspending its extradition treaty and extending its China arms embargo.

images.alt_text: Britain is considering pulling its judges out of Hong Kong's highest court, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said on Monday, in its latest response to what it considers China's breaches of its international obligations in the territory.

site_title: Tencent invests another US$150m in Waterdrop for expansion
summary: Tencent Holdings is investing US$150 million in Chinese startup Waterdrop, bolstering the insurance tech firm's expansion in healthcare crowdfunding. The funding, on top of a US$230 million series D round, will help Waterdrop compete against Ant Group and expand its online platform. The four-year-old Beijing firm aims to offer healthcare protection for pennies and plans to go public with a valuation of around US$4 billion. Waterdrop's business model involves investors contributing to a collective, receiving payouts when needed, with the company taking an 8% commission.

site_title: International virus sleuths expected to go to China soon: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has received reassurances from China that international experts will soon be able to travel to the country to investigate the animal origins of COVID-19. The WHO has been working to send a team of international experts to China for months, and the agency's emergencies director, Michael Ryan, said the trip will be facilitated as soon as possible. The team aims to verify data and outcomes of Chinese studies on the ground, addressing concerns about the quality of the science.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization said on Monday it had received reassurances from Beijing that international experts would soon be able to travel to China to help investigate the animal origins of Covid-19.

site_title: Low-tech employees should cheer the next stage of automation
summary: Automation technologies are transforming the workforce, empowering workers, and making them more valuable. Low-code application development and process task mining are democratizing access to automation, allowing non-technical employees to automate daily tasks and connect applications. AI-powered robots will proactively identify repetitive activities for automation, positioning tech as a help rather than a threat. As a result, the power to automate will shift from senior leadership and IT teams to workers, leading to profound changes in innovation, productivity, and employee perception.

site_title: Oil prices settle over 2% up on Covid-19 vaccine news
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Monday, extending last week's gains, following encouraging news on coronavirus vaccine trials. The latest report from AstraZeneca on its vaccine's 90% effectiveness prompted traders to anticipate a recovery in demand. The contango structure in the market narrowed to its smallest since mid-June, reflecting traders' views that a sustained glut is receding. Opec+ is expected to extend its deal to restrain output, bolstering sentiment.

site_title: No-deal Brexit would have a more lasting effect on UK than Covid-19: Bank of Engaland's Bailey
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey stated that a no-deal Brexit would have a more lasting effect on the UK economy than the Covid-19 pandemic, potentially causing damage that could last for decades. He attributed this to the long-term adjustments required for trade and openness, citing estimates that it could take 30-40 years for the economy to adapt to a shift in currency. Bailey expressed optimism about the impact of Covid-19, but warned that the effects of a no-deal Brexit would be more severe.

site_title: UK's Johnson says 'escape route in sight' from coronavirus
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that the UK is nearing an "escape route" from the coronavirus, citing breakthroughs in treatment and testing vaccines. He stated that restrictions in England will not be extended beyond December 2, and a tiered system of regional restrictions will be reintroduced, allowing for some easing of restrictions, including public gatherings and leisure activities. Johnson also announced a "time-limited" dispensation for families to gather for Christmas, but warned of a "long road to spring" and the need for caution to prevent a flare-up of the virus.

site_title: SingPass required to redeem SingapoRediscovers vouchers, says STB
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has announced that SingapoRediscovers vouchers can only be redeemed by Singaporeans using their SingPass accounts to prevent fraud and resale. The vouchers, worth S$320 million, aim to support local tourism by stimulating domestic consumption of hotels, attractions, and tours. Eligible Singaporeans can redeem vouchers online through authorized booking partners or at physical counters, with a redemption period from Dec 1, 2020, to June 30, 2021.

site_title: Biden pushes new approach to EU in calls to leaders
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden made calls to EU leaders and Nato officials, aiming to repair strained transatlantic ties. He expressed commitment to deepening the US-EU relationship and cooperating on common challenges, marking a contrast with his predecessor Donald Trump's divisive rhetoric. European leaders, including Ursula von der Leyen and Charles Michel, welcomed the new approach, citing a desire for smoother ties and cooperation on global issues. Biden also discussed Brexit and Nato's collective defense with von der Leyen and Jens Stoltenberg, respectively.

site_title: Freaky still the top movie at quiet US box office
summary: Freaky, a body-swap horror comedy starring Vince Vaughn and Kathryn Newton, remained the top movie at the quiet US box office with $1.2 million at 2,057 locations over the weekend.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Broadway Industrial, Top Glove, Sembmarine, Starburst
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean stocks experienced significant changes on Tuesday. Broadway Industrial Group's stock rose 2.5% after receiving a US$50 million offer to buy its hard disk drive business. Top Glove Corp suspended operations after 2,453 workers tested positive for Covid-19, leading its shares to gain 0.4%. Sembmarine's shares surged 12.8% due to "beaten down cyclicals" and rising crude prices. Starburst Holdings' shares dropped 2.4% after its executive chairman surrendered travel documents in a CPIB investigation. Sing Holdings and SPH Reit also saw price movements following bourse filings and announcements.

site_title: French users sue Muslim prayer app over alleged US army links
summary: French users of the Muslim Pro app are suing the company over alleged links to the US army, claiming data was shared with US companies connected to the military. The app, used by 95 million users worldwide, was accused of selling geolocation data to a company called X-Mode, which then sold it to the US army. The lawsuit alleges data protection offences, abuse of trust, and conspiracy to commit murder. The case follows a report by Vice media group revealing the US army's purchase of users' data from various apps, including the Muslim Pro app.

site_title: Blackstone suited to be Crown buyer of last resort
summary: Blackstone, a private equity firm, is considered a potential buyer of Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator, amid regulatory concerns over its gaming license. The company's license has been suspended, and it is trying to appease regulators by shaking up its board, pay practices, and corporate culture. Moody's downgraded its credit rating, and local gaming officials have expressed concerns over Crown's anti-money laundering protocols. Blackstone has a track record in the gaming industry and could help reposition Crown as it faces fewer Chinese VIPs.

site_title: US business leaders move on from Trump to Biden
summary: US business leaders, including some who backed Donald Trump, are moving on to work with Joe Biden's administration, urging a new economic stimulus plan to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Corporate heavyweights like United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby and Walmart CEO Doug McMillon have congratulated Biden, while others, such as General Motors CEO Mary Barra, are ready to collaborate with the new administration. Despite Trump's claims of a "rigged" election, business leaders are pushing for a peaceful transition, with some calling for bipartisanship to address the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: UK economy shrinks in Nov as new lockdown hits services
summary: The UK economy contracted in November, with a 5-month low in business activity due to new coronavirus restrictions on services. The IHS Markit/CIPS UK Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 47.4, below the 50.0 growth threshold. However, the forward-looking component of the PMI reached its highest in over five years, boosted by progress on COVID-19 vaccines. Manufacturing accelerated, while services PMI declined. The economy is expected to contract in the fourth quarter, but some long-term damage is inevitable, according to Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane.

site_title: Huawei's Chinese mobile rivals looking to capitalise on its US woes
summary: Chinese mobile rivals, including Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo, are capitalizing on Huawei's US sanctions, which have hindered its supply chains and made it difficult to source essential components. Huawei has sold its budget Honor brand to safeguard its supply chain, but its Chinese rivals are raising forecasts for next year, believing the sanctions will hurt Huawei in the international market and allowing them to take a share of the market. Huawei's mid- to high-end phone production has also been impacted, with orders for its flagship processors expected to be halted.

site_title: Vaccine rollout hopes keep US dollar down
summary: AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine showed 90% effectiveness, while Moderna's vaccine was 94.5% effective, and Pfizer's vaccine was 95% effective. This positive news lifted riskier currencies, keeping the US dollar down 0.1% versus a basket of currencies. The New Zealand dollar surged to a two-year high after strong retail sales data, while the Australian dollar also rose. Eurozone flash PMI data is expected to show a positive impact on the euro.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as jump in virus cases offsets vaccine hopes
summary: European shares declined by 0.2% as investors weighed the positive news on a potential Covid-19 vaccine against the threat of economic damage from lockdown measures. Despite a 90% effective AstraZeneca vaccine, shares fell due to its lower efficacy rate compared to rivals. The euro zone business activity contracted sharply in November, while manufacturing activity remained strong. The market is optimistic about a synchronous economic recovery next year, with British domestic stocks gaining 0.4% after the government eased Covid-19 restrictions over Christmas.

site_title: Singapore retailers' reliance on local demand may not be sustainable: Amex
summary: A recent American Express survey of 300 Singaporean SMEs with annual revenues of S$100 million or less found that about half of retailers experienced higher sales from September to October this year compared to the same period last year. However, the survey suggests that relying solely on local demand may not be sustainable in the long term.

site_title: NTU staff donate over S$10m worth of unused leave
summary: More than 1,800 NTU staff donated an average of 11 days of unused annual leave, totaling S$10.25 million, to support student aid and endowments. The highest donation was 15 days, with a collective 20,145 days of unutilized leave given.

site_title: G-20 stymied by lack of US leadership
summary: G-20 leaders made progress in addressing the Covid-19 crisis, committing to fair and affordable access to vaccines, therapeutics, and diagnostics. However, the summit's ambition was stymied by US President Donald Trump's absence and divisions between powerful members, including China and the US. The G-20 vowed to work together to minimize economic and social damage from the pandemic, but critics argue that the lack of US leadership and enforcement mechanisms hinders the forum's effectiveness. Despite this, the G-20 remains a crucial platform for global economic cooperation, with 90% of global GDP and 80% of world trade represented among its members.

site_title: HK records 73 Covid-19 cases, with situation 'worsening rapidly'
summary: Hong Kong reported 73 new Covid-19 cases on November 23, 2020, as the situation worsens rapidly with silent transmission chains feared due to a rise in asymptomatic infections. The densely populated city has managed to avoid widespread outbreaks, but the recent increase in cases is a concern.

site_title: A third of home loan borrowers face repayment challenges: poll
summary: A survey by OCBC found that about a third of home loan borrowers in Singapore face repayment challenges, with 31% of respondents struggling to pay off their housing loans. The OCBC Financial Wellness Index has dipped to 61, down from 63 in 2019, due to the pandemic's impact on financial health. Despite financial challenges, Singaporeans are saving more, with 28% of income saved each month, and are showing signs of becoming more prudent and confident in managing their finances.

site_title: Broadway Industrial still in talks with buyer for hard disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a Singaporean precision manufacturer, is still in talks with a potential buyer for its hard disk drive business after receiving a draft binding letter of intent. The company halted trading of its shares on November 18, but lifted the halt on Monday after further negotiations with the buyer. The buyer intends to retain key management and technical staff. No binding agreement has been reached yet, and the group's strategic review remains ongoing.

site_title: China SEC's olive branch to US is sturdier than it looks
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has made a fresh offer to improve access for US auditors to review the financials of New York-listed Chinese companies. This move comes after the June delisting of Luckin Coffee for accounting fraud and amid US threats to delist Chinese companies worth over $2 trillion. Beijing is seeking to address concerns over Chinese companies' accounting practices and secure better audit access for US investors. The CSRC's offer may be a genuine attempt to improve cooperation, but its sincerity remains uncertain.

site_title: MAS chief proposes full digitalisation of China-Asean trade route
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon proposes fully digitalizing the New International Land-Sea Trade Corridor (ILSTC) connecting Western China and Asean to promote trade flows. The initiative aims to enhance trade efficiency and reduce costs. Menon made the remarks during a virtual keynote address at the Singapore-China (Chongqing) Connectivity Initiative (CCI) Financial Summit. This digitalization could benefit trade between China and Southeast Asia, and Singapore is seen as a potential hub for this initiative.

site_title: New Bridge Road shophouses up for sale
summary: A shophouse at 11 New Bridge Road in Singapore has been listed for sale with a guide price of S$16.9 million, translating to S$3,174 per square foot. The property houses the flagship outlet of the popular Bak Kut Teh chain, Song Fa.

site_title: Pandemic challenges help accelerate growth
summary: SWAT Mobility, a mobility software startup, has seen accelerated growth due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company now operates in seven countries, including Australia, Japan, and the Philippines, providing solutions to traditional transport scheduling inefficiencies. SWAT's algorithm optimizes and plans transport routes, aggregates demand and bookings, and tracks individual passengers for contact tracing. The pandemic has also led to increased scrutiny of employee transport spending, prompting companies to reevaluate their arrangements. SWAT aims to help companies analyze their spending and provide safer journeys for employees, with plans to expand into new verticals and markets.

site_title: Headline, core inflation down in Oct after marginal increases
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation both fell to -0.2% in October, after two months of marginal increases, defying economists' expectations of neutral inflation. Core inflation declined due to lower services costs, while food inflation was also lower at 1.7%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintained their forecasts for 2020 inflation at -0.5% to 0%, and 2021 forecasts for core inflation at 0% to 1%.

site_title: Will Mar-a-Lago become Trump's Colombey?
summary: US President Donald Trump is reportedly considering withdrawing from public life and relocating to Mar-a-Lago, his Florida resort, after a humiliating electoral defeat. This move mirrors the pattern of French statesman Charles de Gaulle, who would often retreat to his country retreat, Colombey, before returning to power. Trump, however, is unlikely to experience a similar resurgence in popularity, with his approval ratings and public perception having deteriorated significantly. His plans for a 2024 comeback are also unlikely, with the Republican Party's leaders distancing themselves from him and facing lawsuits and investigations.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's supporters boating off the shore of his home at Mar-a-Lago ahead of the 2020 presidential election. Americans do not like losers, and in particular, they loathe sore losers.

site_title: Bullish mood sweeps through Australian housing market
summary: Australia's $7.1 trillion housing market is defying economists' predictions of a 10% price drop, instead experiencing gains of 5-15% in the next two years. The market is passing its "ultimate stress test" of the first recession in nearly three decades. Policymakers are now concerned about excessive exuberance rather than plummeting prices, reversing their previous warnings of a sharp decline. The housing market's resilience has caught economists off guard, forcing them to reassess their forecasts.

site_title: STB monitoring commission fees on SingapoRediscovers Vouchers booking platforms
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) will monitor and penalize booking platforms that charge excessive commission rates for SingapoRediscovers Vouchers redemption. The vouchers, worth S$100, aim to support the local tourism industry. Some platforms were reportedly charging 8% to 25% commission, sparking industry concerns. The STB will ensure that only authorized platforms are used, and those that violate the rules will face penalties.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has said it will monitor the commission rates charged by the booking platforms handling the SingapoRediscovers Vouchers redemption and penalise errant platforms, following concerns from the industry over reportedly eye-watering fees proposed by some.

site_title: STI ends higher as Singapore economy shows signs of recovery
