summary: Singapore shares ended Monday at 2,848.78 points, up 1.27% due to signs of economic recovery in 2021. The Straits Times Index narrowed its 2020 growth forecast contraction to 6-6.5%, with a projected 4-6% GDP growth in 2021. Across the broader market, 331 advancers outpaced 149 decliners, with 5.2 billion shares worth S$1.63 billion changing hands.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considered raising fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a veteran DBS executive. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Hyflux JMs seek parties keen to take part in firm's revamp
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment company, has invited parties to invest in its restructuring process as part of judicial management. The firm, along with its unit Hydrochem, was placed under judicial management by the Singapore high court on November 16, 2020. The judicial managers are seeking expressions of interest from interested parties by December 4. The restructuring process aims to address debt of S$1.83 billion owed by Hyflux and its unit to creditors and retail investors.

images.alt_text: The judicial managers of Hyflux and its unit Hydrochem (S) Pte Ltd are inviting expressions of interest (EOI) from parties keen to invest in the embattled water treatment player, as part of a restructuring process.

site_title: MAS chief proposes full digitalisation of China-Asean trade route
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon proposes the full digitalisation of China-Asean trade route, specifically the New International Land-Sea Trade Corridor (ILSTC), to enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and build trust. A digitalised ILSTC would enable faster, cheaper, and smoother trade flows between the regions. Menon suggests exploring digitalising Bills of Lading and creating a sandbox for fintechs to develop innovative solutions for an end-to-end digitalised trade platform. This move is seen as a response to the importance of digitalising trade, as reinforced by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Taking its position on the global stage, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise after US President Donald Trump announced a tariff reduction, but with a lower rate than expected. The tariff rate, which was previously 10%, will decrease to 6.5%. This move aims to boost trade between the two countries. Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh stated that the country had been seeking a lower rate, but was still concerned about the potential impact on its economy. The tariff reduction is part of a broader trade deal between the US and Vietnam, which also includes investments, labor standards, and intellectual property protections.

site_title: KL closes some Top Glove plants after workers test positive
summary: Malaysia's Top Glove, the world's largest latex glove maker, will close 28 factory buildings in phases after 2,453 workers tested positive for coronavirus. From 5,767 screened workers, the company has reported 2,524 positive cases, with 2,360 being foreigners and 164 Malaysians. The closures are part of a government-mandated screening and quarantine effort to prevent further infections. Top Glove has temporarily stopped production at 16 facilities and operates 12 at reduced capacities. The closures are expected to be implemented in stages to allow further screening and quarantine.

site_title: World's famed shopping streets prepare for worst this Christmas
summary: Luxury shopping districts worldwide are bracing for a socially distanced holiday season due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Stores in prominent locations such as Bond Street, Champs-Elysees, Ginza, and Fifth Avenue are preparing for the season with Christmas displays and socially distanced efforts, despite travel restrictions and declining consumer confidence. To salvage the holiday season, some stores are offering virtual events and promotions, while others are focusing on in-store experiences with limited capacity and enhanced hygiene measures.

images.alt_text: Shops on Bond Street ranging from Cartier to Chanel are not waiting for their reopening to get ready for the holiday season: Christmas lights are up earlier than usual.

site_title: Achieving breakthroughs in cancer treatment
summary: Local biotech firm ImmunoScape is advancing cancer treatment through immunotherapy, a body-based approach that utilizes the immune system to combat cancer. Despite significant progress, the treatment's effectiveness varies, with a success rate of 20-30% among patients. ImmunoScape's technology, developed by co-founder Evan Newell, provides immunological insights to pharmaceutical companies, aiming to boost treatment success rates to 50-70%. The firm recently raised US$11 million from investors to support its research and development of a Covid-19 vaccine and cancer treatments. ImmunoScape plans to list on the market to secure additional funding and resources to continue its innovative work.

images.alt_text: From left: ImmunoScape's chief financial officer, Romi Chandiramani; director of scientific affairs Michael Fehlings; chief operating officer Alessandra Nardin and chief executive officer Ng Choon Peng.

site_title: Shortsellers target Ping An fintech unit after Ant IPO halt
summary: China's Ping An Insurance (Group) is facing headwinds after Ant Group's IPO halt, with Lufax Holding Ltd, a fintech unit, being targeted by shortsellers. Short interest in Lufax has increased to 34% as of Nov 17, up from 5% when Ant's deal was pulled. Regulatory changes in China and the US threaten Ping An's plans to pivot from a finance group to a tech giant, with the company's valuation potentially affected. Ping An owns 39% of Lufax after the IPO and has pledged to invest $22 billion in research and development to make it more tech-oriented.

site_title: QT Vascular shares see sell-off after proposed reverse takeover falls through
summary: QT Vascular's share price dropped 33.3% to 0.6 cents after a proposed reverse takeover involving Mongolian mining and energy firm Tengri Coal and Energy fell through. The deal's conditions precedent were not met by the deadline, resulting in the cancellation of the conditional sale and purchase agreement. QTV will continue to explore other corporate opportunities to enhance shareholder value, with no expected material impact on its 2020 earnings per share.

site_title: Los Angeles home sales soar as housing market defies Covid-19
summary: Los Angeles home sales have surged despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with interest rates at their lowest levels ever and many renters reassessing their housing options. The housing market defied recession expectations, with national lenders issuing a 25% increase in home-purchase mortgages in the third quarter. Younger buyers, particularly millennials, are entering the market, competing for a tight supply of homes, driving month-over-month and quarterly home-value growth to levels not seen since 2005.

site_title: The siren song of austerity
summary: The article revisits the 2010 State of the Union address by then-US President Barack Obama, in which he advocated for austerity measures, freezing government spending for three years. The author argues that this decision had a detrimental effect on the economy, with the prime-age employment rate remaining below pre-2007 levels for 12 years. The article draws parallels between then and now, as the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a similar economic downturn, with the prime-age employment rate now at 76% and millions of people left without jobs. The author concludes that the federal government should prioritize spending to stimulate demand and support employers in rehiring the unemployed, rather than worrying about the cost of borrowing.

site_title: Virtual events pose monetisation challenge for MICE industry
summary: The MICE industry is struggling to turn a profit from virtual and hybrid events due to reduced client budgets and lower participant willingness to pay. Despite eliminating traditional costs, virtual events require the same level of preparation as physical ones, leading to a perception that they are less valuable. Organizers face challenges in justifying high prices, with clients viewing virtual events as "easy to organize" like a Zoom webinar. The industry must adapt to these changes to ensure long-term survival.

images.alt_text: Hybrid events, such as this one at the Singapore International Energy Week, involve complex planning since the onsite and online experience have to run in precise synchrony.

site_title: Achieving a delicate balance, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise and concern over US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on Vietnamese goods, which could significantly impact the country's economy. The tariffs, which include $300 billion worth of goods, will take effect on July 6. Vietnamese officials have called for a lower tariff rate, stating that the current rate could cause substantial losses for the country's businesses. The move has sparked concerns about Vietnam's economic stability and its trade relationship with the US. Vietnam's government is seeking to negotiate a reduction in the tariff rate to minimize the negative impact on its economy.

site_title: Keppel handpicks 'young guns' to refresh top jobs in key units
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, has announced a major leadership shake-up, promoting six "young guns" in their 40s to top roles across key business units. The move, part of succession planning and leadership renewal, aims to steer and execute the company's 2030 plan. Key appointments include Louis Lim as head of Keppel Land, Cindy Lim as head of Keppel Infrastructure, and Anthea Lee as head of Keppel DC Reit Management. The moves are seen as a positive step for the company, which has been facing challenges, including record losses and a strategic review of its offshore & marine business.

site_title: SingapoRediscovers vouchers can help make domestic tourism a habit
summary: Singapore's domestic tourism sector is expected to benefit from the Covid-19 pandemic, with anecdotal accounts suggesting increased spending on local activities. However, statistics indicate that retail sales and food-and-beverage services have declined month-on-month in September. The October figures will provide further insight into spending habits. Despite the uncertainty, SingapoRediscovers vouchers may help drive domestic tourism, potentially making it a habit for Singaporeans.

site_title: China regulator gives approval for Baoshang Bank to file for bankruptcy
summary: China's Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) approved Baoshang Bank to file for bankruptcy, ending a takeover that began in May 2019. The central bank will liquidate remaining assets. Mengshang Bank and Huishang Bank, which took over Baoshang's assets and operations, will manage the bank's affairs. This move comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Winning friends and influencing people, Singapore Business Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise over the US decision to impose a 10% tariff on $365 billion worth of Vietnamese goods, citing a 25% rate previously imposed. The tariff announcement came after the US Trade Representative's office stated that the higher rate was necessary to protect American industries. Vietnam's government has sought to negotiate a lower rate, emphasizing the impact of tariffs on its economy. The country's exports to the US, valued at $29 billion in 2020, are expected to be significantly affected by the new tariff. Diplomatic efforts are underway to resolve the issue.

site_title: GM must recall 5.9m vehicles for air bag issue, says safety agency
summary: General Motors must recall 5.9 million vehicles with Takata air bag inflators due to a risk of explosion after long-term exposure to high heat and humidity. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration rejected GM's petition to avoid the callback, which could cost the company $1.2 billion to replace air bag inflators. The affected vehicles are 2007-2014 trucks and SUVs.

site_title: US-China trade spat had mixed impact on Singapore exports: MTI
summary: Singapore's domestic exports to China and the US have remained relatively stable despite US-China trade tensions, according to a report by the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). US tariffs affected shipments of plastic goods and chemicals, while China grew its import share of petroleum and chemical goods from Singapore. The report concludes that US-China trade tensions have resulted in both opportunities and competition for Singapore's exports, but hurdles remain due to anti-globalization measures.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP is forecasted to contract 6-6.5% in 2020, but is expected to rebound with a 4-6% growth in 2021 as major economies recover from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fund managers hate working from home as much as the rest of us
summary: Fund managers are among the finance professionals who dislike working from home, despite benefiting from the pandemic's "thinking time." Many cite the lack of interaction with colleagues, difficulty in executing trades, and missed opportunities for junior staff training as reasons they want to return to the office. They value the informal discussions and knowledge sharing that occur in an office setting, which can lead to better investment insights and local acumen. However, some acknowledge the benefits of remote work, such as reduced commuting time and increased flexibility.

site_title: US business activity expands most since 2015, IHS Markit says
summary: US business activity expanded at its fastest pace since 2015 in November, according to IHS Markit, with a composite index of 57.9. This growth was driven by stronger service providers and manufacturers, and despite a surge in coronavirus cases, recent vaccine developments boosted optimism. The euro area saw a contraction in service activity for the third month, with the US measure standing in contrast. Hiring also increased as demand strengthened, with additional staff taken on at a rate not seen since 2009.

site_title: Q3 total merchandise trade shrinks; full-year forecast upgraded
summary: Singapore's authorities upgraded their full-year projection for total merchandise trade and non-oil domestic exports (NODX), citing a slower pace of decline in the third quarter. Total merchandise trade declined by 6.3% year-on-year in Q3, easing from a 15.3% fall in the April-June period. This upgrade is a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: Asean can afford larger budget deficits, public debt levels without causing instability
summary: ANZ Research suggests that Southeast Asia's external position is stable enough to sustain larger budget deficits and public debt levels without causing macroeconomic instability. The region's fiscal metrics have deteriorated due to large fiscal stimulus programs, but policymakers can afford to maintain expansionary fiscal policies. The report notes that the region's external situation is solid, with current accounts in surplus and growing FX reserves. Low funding costs and supportive monetary policies also support debt sustainability, making it justifiable to run larger deficits and public debt ratios.

site_title: Qatar identified parents of dumped baby in airport scandal
summary: Qatar has identified the parents of a baby girl who was found in a trash can at the Doha airport in October 2020. The mother and father are from Asian countries, likely South Asia, and are believed to be migrant workers. The mother allegedly threw the newborn in the trash can and boarded a plane to her destination. The father admitted to a relationship with the mother and received a photo of the baby immediately after birth. The mother faces 15 years imprisonment for the crime, and efforts are underway to arrest her.

site_title: Sharp rebound in 2021 won't take economy to pre-Covid levels: MTI
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to rebound sharply in 2021, with a forecasted 4-6% year-on-year growth, driven by a low base from the ongoing recession. However, the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) warned that the economy will still be weaker in dollar terms than before the COVID-19 pandemic, with GDP not expected to return to pre-Covid levels until the end of 2021. The MTI cited global uncertainty and the slow pace of COVID-19 vaccine development as key factors in its forecast.

site_title: Evergrande gets 30b yuan investment from state firms as debt fears ease
summary: Evergrande Group secured a 30 billion yuan investment from state-linked companies, easing debt fears and restoring confidence in its finances. The investment, worth $4.6 billion, comes as the developer lines up 23 cornerstone investors for the spinoff of its property services arm. Evergrande also announced plans to pare debt through a Hong Kong initial public offering, seeking $2 billion to address short-term liquidity strains. Despite the support, concerns remain about the firm's long-term financial health, with analysts warning that Evergrande may cut its dividend and seek spinoffs to meet China's debt limits.

site_title: Five-room BTO flats in Toa Payoh six times oversubscribed
summary: The five-room Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Toa Payoh's Bartley Beacon project were six times oversubscribed, with 144 flats receiving over 720 applicants. Prices range from S$627,000 to S$726,000. In contrast, four-room flats in other projects were less popular, with only three first-time applicants for some units. The oversubscription is attributed to the high price tag and limited supply, with the last BTO flats launched in the Bidadari estate in May 2017.

site_title: Wealthy Europeans join Spac club in record year for listings
summary: Wealthy Europeans are joining the trend of listing "blank-cheque companies" or special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs) to raise funds for takeovers, following the US's record-breaking year of $60 billion in Spac listings. European business tycoons, such as Investindustrial's Andrea Bonomi, are raising $350 million to target European businesses with an enterprise value of $1-5 billion in various sectors. Investment banks expect a surge in European Spac listings, with Deutsche Bank advising on several deals, and Spacs are expected to "certainly" stay, despite concerns about potential deal failures.

site_title: Merck buys OncoImmune for US$425m to gain Covid drug
summary: Merck has agreed to acquire OncoImmune, a biopharma company, for $425 million upfront to gain a potential therapy for severe COVID-19. OncoImmune's lead candidate, CD24Fc, has shown positive interim findings in a late-stage study evaluating its effectiveness in treating patients with severe COVID-19. The therapy aims to reduce inflammation caused by virus-induced damage to human cells. The acquisition comes as multiple COVID-19 vaccines and treatments are becoming available, and Merck is preparing for a new era of leadership.

site_title: AstraZeneca says Covid-19 'vaccine for the world' can be 90% effective
summary: AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine has shown 90% effectiveness in preventing the disease, according to late-stage trials in Britain and Brazil. The vaccine can be transported and stored at normal fridge temperatures, making it cheaper and easier to distribute, especially in poor countries. AstraZeneca plans to produce up to 200 million doses by the end of 2020 and 700 million doses by the end of 2021. The vaccine's cost to governments is a few dollars per shot, significantly cheaper than rivals Pfizer and Moderna.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca said on Monday its Covid-19 vaccine could be around 90 per cent effective, giving the world's fight against the global pandemic a new weapon, cheaper to make, easier to distribute and faster to scale-up than rivals.

site_title: Smelling blood, Huawei's Chinese mobile rivals look to capitalise on its US woes
summary: Chinese mobile rivals Huawei's Chinese rivals, including Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo, are capitalizing on Huawei's US woes by raising their forecasts for next year and targeting its market share. Huawei's sale of budget brand Honor and its struggles to source components due to US sanctions have made its rivals more optimistic about their prospects. Industry insiders say Xiaomi has placed orders for up to 100 million phones, while Oppo and Vivo have raised their forecasts by around 8% each. Despite analysts' concerns that the companies may be too optimistic, Realme's executive Derek Wang believes the sanctions will hurt Huawei in the international market and they may want to take a share of the market.

site_title: Credit Agricole offers US$875m for Credito Valtellinese
summary: French lender Credit Agricole offered US$875 million to buy Italy's Credito Valtellinese, representing a 21.4% premium to the Nov 20 closing price. The acquisition would strengthen Credit Agricole's position in Italy's north and consolidate its role as the sixth-biggest retail bank. This is part of a series of mergers driven by the pandemic and low interest rates, with regulatory obstacles hindering cross-border transactions. The deal would align with Credit Agricole's strategy of integrating mid- and small-sized banks in Italy.

site_title: Sembmarine surges partly on renewed merger hopes
summary: Sembmarine shares surged 12.8% on Monday, driven by robust turnover and analysts attributing the gain to "beaten down cyclicals" and rising crude prices. The stock outperformed the Straits Times Index, with 337 million shares traded. Some speculate that the latest leadership shifts at Keppel Corp, particularly the appointment of Chua Hsien Yang as director of group M&A, may also contribute to the surge, potentially fueling speculation of a mega merger between Sembmarine and Keppel Offshore & Marine.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC upgrades CDLHT to 'buy' on rapid vaccine progress
summary: OCBC Investment Research has upgraded CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) to "buy" with a fair value estimate of S$1.39, citing rapid vaccine progress boosting the stapled group's stock price. The counter rose 0.8% to S$1.21, gaining 1.7% since November 19.

site_title: AstraZeneca's Covid vaccine 90% effective but cheaper to make
summary: AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine has shown 90% effectiveness in preventing the virus, with a lower dose followed by a full dose being more effective. The vaccine is also potentially cheaper to produce, easier to distribute, and can be stored at normal fridge temperatures. The company plans to produce 200 million doses by the end of 2020 and 700 million by the end of 2021. Experts say the world will need multiple vaccines to meet global demand, and the AstraZeneca vaccine's success may contribute to a return to normal life sooner in countries that pre-bought the vaccine.

site_title: Sabana Reit says 'no' to EGM requisition from Quarz Capital, Black Crane
summary: Sabana Reit manager has rejected a requisition for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) from Quarz Capital and Black Crane, citing the merits of a proposed merger with ESR-Reit. The manager argued that the proposed merger was first explored in April after Ms Ng, a former Blackwood Investment director, had divested her interests in the company. The manager also addressed concerns over the hiring of former ESR employees and Ms Ng's independence, stating that she had no business relationship with the ESR group and had divested her interests in Blackwood Investment. Sabana Reit will proceed with the proposed merger and intends to declare a cleanup distribution if it is approved.

site_title: Top Glove to temporarily shut 28 factories as over 2,000 workers test positive for Covid-19
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove-maker, will temporarily shut 28 factories due to over 2,000 workers testing positive for Covid-19. The company has already stopped production at 16 facilities and reduced capacities at 12 others. The decision was made after consulting with the health ministry. Top Glove tested 5,700 workers and will cooperate with authorities to implement the temporary stoppage. The company's shares rose 0.42% after the announcement.

site_title: Snap to pay US$1m a day to creators for Spotlight videos
summary: Snap is launching Spotlight, a new tool featuring popular videos that will pay out $1 million daily to top creators, regardless of their followers or public profiles. The algorithm-based feature will showcase videos based on frequent views, aiming to reward quality content without relying on likes and followers. This move is part of Snap's effort to compete with Instagram and YouTube, and may attract creators away from TikTok. The feature will initially be available in the US, Canada, and several European countries, with Snap aiming to attract makers of quality content.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Making sense of the current market with BT's new podcast series (Ep 84)
summary: BT's new podcast series, "BT Money Hacks," discusses useful financial tips and market insights during the Covid-19 era. The latest episode, hosted by Ernest Luis, Chris Lim, and Ben Paul, covers topics such as the Business Times News Tablet Edition, password-free experiences, and the Mark To Market Podcast. The series aims to help readers make better sense of their money and the market, with new episodes released fortnightly on Mondays. The podcast is available on various platforms, including BT's website and popular audio apps.

site_title: America must mend many fences on trade
summary: The US has damaged its global standing under President Donald Trump's presidency, reversing longstanding policies that promoted multilateralism and global institutions. Trump's administration prioritized unilateralism, abandoning the Trans-Pacific Partnership and imposing tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, violating international trade law. These decisions eroded trust among other countries and undermined the US's soft power. The Trump administration's one-on-one deal-making has failed, and the US should pursue multilateralism to restore its leadership in the global economy, including negotiating with China on trade issues and addressing outstanding issues such as e-commerce and cybersecurity.

site_title: Trendlines unit expands MOU with National Healthcare Group
summary: TRENDLINES Medical Singapore (TMS), a unit of Catalist-listed The Trendlines Group, has renewed and expanded its Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the National Healthcare Group (NHG) to co-develop innovative healthcare solutions. The renewed MOU aims to focus on dermatology, infectious diseases, and other areas, with objectives to establish knowledge exchange and leverage lab capabilities on upstream research projects. Since their initial MOU in 2017, the partnership has led to the establishment of nine companies and upcoming clinical studies at NHG Institutions.

site_title: Starburst chairman surrenders travel documents to CPIB
summary: Starburst Holdings' executive chairman Edward Lim Chin Wah has surrendered his travel documents to the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) amid a probe. Lim is out on bail after being embroiled in the CPIB investigation, which also involves other Starburst executives. The company had previously stated that CPIB did not request Lim's travel documents at the time. The move follows an interview by Lim with CPIB in relation to Starburst Engineering, a wholly-owned unit of the company.

site_title: SPH Reit manager defends not disclosing key personnel salaries
summary: SPH Reit's manager defended its decision not to disclose salaries of key management personnel in the latest annual report, citing confidentiality and sensitivity. The manager stated that remuneration is paid directly by the private company, not from the deposited property of SPH Reit, and that disclosure could negatively impact talent attraction and retention. The manager also claimed there is no misalignment between the remuneration of directors and key management personnel with the interests of unitholders, as their remuneration is not linked to the gross revenue of SPH Reit.

site_title: Productivity grew by 2.8% a year in last decade on capital investments
summary: Singapore's labour productivity grew 2.8% a year from 2009 to 2019, driven mainly by capital intensity improvements in non-residential construction and R&D. This growth was largely fueled by public infrastructure investments and R&D commitments. Despite this, productivity gains were largely offset by a small shift in hours worked towards less productive sectors. Singapore's productivity level stood at 46% of Switzerland's in 2019, comparable to Spain, Italy, and Japan, but lower than Germany, Britain, and the US.

images.alt_text: Labour productivity grew by 2.8 per cent a year from 2009 to 2019, according to a report released on Monday.

site_title: Semi-detached house near Orchard put on market for S$7.8m
summary: A freehold semi-detached house in Singapore's Orchard area is being sold for S$7.8 million, approximately S$2,529 per square foot. The two-storey property is located near Orchard Road and offers easy access to the Orchard MRT stations. The sale is by tender, with offers expected to be submitted soon.

site_title: China prepares moon probe to bring back lunar rocks
summary: China is preparing to launch the Chang'e-5 probe, its first attempt to bring back lunar rocks in four decades. The probe aims to collect samples from the moon to study its origins, formation, and volcanic activity. Beijing is investing billions in its space program, with plans for a crewed space station by 2022 and sending humans to the moon in the future. The Chang'e-5 probe is a significant step in China's space exploration efforts, showcasing its capabilities in lunar research and paving the way for future space endeavors.

site_title: The world's famed shopping streets are preparing for the worst
summary: World-famous shopping districts are preparing for a holiday season unlike any other due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and travel restrictions. Luxury stores are filling windows with socially-distanced Christmas displays in an effort to salvage the holiday season. Consumers remain wary of visiting stores, and travel restrictions will significantly impact tourist spending. Despite these challenges, luxury stores are putting forth their best efforts to attract customers.

site_title: Barclays keeps 2021 oil price outlook, supported by vaccine boost
summary: Barclays has maintained its "above consensus" 2021 oil price forecast, predicting Brent at $53 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate at $50 per barrel. The forecast is driven by OPEC's output discipline and a potential vaccine boost in the second half of the year, which could lead to a more sustainable economic recovery.

site_title: UK economy shrinks as new lockdown shuts services firms
summary: The UK economy contracted in November, with a "flash" reading of the IHS Markit/CIPS UK Composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 47.4, a five-month low. This is the first time the index has gone below the 50.0 growth threshold since June, due to new coronavirus restrictions on services firms. However, news of possible vaccines has boosted hopes for 2021, with hopes for economic recovery.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance on vaccine news
summary: European stock markets rose on Monday, driven by positive news on a coronavirus vaccine trial. The FTSE 100 index in London gained 0.5%, the Paris CAC 40 index rose nearly 1%, and the Frankfurt DAX index increased 0.6%. The rally helped offset concerns over soaring case numbers.

site_title: US moves to ban tech exports to 89 Chinese firms, Reuters says
summary: The US Department of Commerce is close to issuing a list of 89 Chinese aerospace and technology companies that would be restricted from accessing US technology exports due to their military ties. Companies such as Comac and Aviation Industry Corp of China Ltd, which are involved in the production of commercial aircraft and military technology, would be affected. The move could escalate tensions between the US and China as President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take office.

site_title: Euro zone business activity shrink sharply in Nov as lockdowns bite
summary: Euro zone business activity has contracted sharply in November due to renewed coronavirus restrictions, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 45.1 from 50.0 in October. This suggests the bloc's economy is on track for its first double-dip recession in nearly a decade. The sharp decline in business activity raises concerns about the economic health of the euro zone.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.73 points to 1,597.48 on Monday, with volume reaching 9.426 billion lots worth RM4.516 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 674 to 540.

site_title: Oxley Holdings provides further information on lawsuits
summary: OXLEY Holdings has provided more information on lawsuits involving four of its entities. The company disclosed that its wholly-owned subsidiary, Oxley Gem, accepted a letter of intent from Gracious Land to purchase two hotels for S$950 million in January 2019. However, Gracious Land decided not to proceed, and Oxley Gem rejected the deposit, leading to arbitration. Oxley Gem is seeking the return of the S$9.5 million deposit.

site_title: South Korea reports 271 new Covid-19 cases as tighter curbs to take effect
summary: South Korea reported 271 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, a day before tighter social distancing rules take effect. The daily tally fell from 330 on Sunday, with officials attributing the drop to less testing on weekends. The measures aim to curb a third wave of infections, which have surged in recent days, with some experts accusing authorities of failing to act sooner. Authorities have strengthened distancing rules, closing bars and nightclubs, and restricting dining at restaurants and cafes, amid concerns of an impending national college entrance exam.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit near three-year high on Samsung Elec, SK Hynix boost
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.7% to a 34-month high, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix surging 3% on recovering demand and optimistic 2021 earnings outlook. The Kospi index rose 44.20 points to 2,597.70, while the won strengthened and the benchmark bond yield fell. South Korean exports grew 11.1% in November, driven by strong chip sales and overseas demand, as the country battles a third wave of COVID-19 infections.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported; no local patients for 13th day
summary: Singapore reported five new Covid-19 cases, all imported, on November 23, marking the 13th consecutive day without a local patient. This is the longest stretch without a community case since January 2020. The new cases bring the total to 58,165. All five cases were asymptomatic upon arrival and were placed on stay-home notices. Four cases were discharged, leaving 58,056 patients recovered and 36 in hospital.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished higher on Monday, driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine rollout in the coming months. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.13% to 26,486.20, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.09% to 3,414.49. However, gains were tempered by concerns over a local spike in infections.

site_title: Indonesia says US DFC will invest US$2b in new sovereign wealth fund
summary: The US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) has signed a letter of intent to invest US$2 billion in Indonesia's new sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority. The fund is expected to be launched soon. The DFC will also engage with partners in Japan, UAE, and Singapore to persuade them to invest in the fund. This investment is part of Indonesia's efforts to diversify its economy and reduce its reliance on foreign aid.

site_title: STI up 1.27% as economic data show signs of recovery
summary: Singapore shares ended Monday at 2,848.78 points, up 35.77 points or 1.27% on the Straits Times Index (STI). Economic data showed signs of recovery in 2021, with the Ministry of Trade and Industry narrowing its 2020 growth forecast contraction to 6% to 6.5%. The GDP is projected to grow 4% to 6% in 2021 as major economies recover. The STI rose across the broader market, with advancers outpacing decliners 331 to 149.

site_title: Drying habitat makes Australia's platypus vulnerable, scientists say
summary: Australian scientists recommend listing the platypus as a vulnerable species due to habitat shrinkage caused by climate change, land clearing, and dam-building. The platypus habitat has shrunk by over 20% in the last 30 years, threatening the species' survival. Researchers warn that without conservation efforts, platypus populations may halve or disappear from some rivers. The University of New South Wales recommends more resources to protect habitats once the species is listed as vulnerable.

images.alt_text: Australian scientists pushed on Monday to list the platypus as a vulnerable species after a report showed the habitat of the semi-aquatic native mammal had shrunk more than a fifth in the last 30 years.

site_title: Danone to cut up to 2,000 jobs, aiming to save S$1.6b
summary: Danone plans to cut up to 2,000 jobs, approximately 2% of its total staff, in an effort to revive profitability amid the pandemic. The company aims to save S$1.6 billion by 2023 through cost savings from moving global headquarters closer to Paris and more efficient purchasing. CEO Emmanuel Faber is shifting the organization to focus on geographical zones rather than product categories to become more agile. The job cuts are part of a broader restructuring plan to improve the company's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Danone will cut as many as 2,000 jobs, including one in four positions at its global headquarters, as the world's largest yogurt maker attempts to revive profitability amid the pandemic.

site_title: SGX-backed iSTOX to set up digital securities exchange in Chongqing
summary: Singapore Exchange-backed iSTOX has signed a strategic agreement with the Chongqing Monetary Authority to set up a digital securities exchange in Chongqing, part of a proposed Chongqing-Singapore financial hub. The agreement aims to bring innovative products and attract technology companies to the city, providing an international platform for raising funds. iSTOX, a regulated provider of digitised securities, will work with state-owned companies to develop the city's private capital market, allowing Chinese companies access to international capital and Chinese investors to diversify globally.

site_title: Shanghai airport mass testing staff after virus cases reported
summary: Staff at Shanghai's Pudong International Airport are undergoing mass testing after six local Covid-19 cases linked to cargo handlers were reported. The testing, which began on Sunday, involved over 17,700 people, with 11,500 results coming back negative. Cargo workers in high-risk jobs will receive regular tests and Covid-19 vaccines, according to the Shanghai Airport Authority. The outbreak is linked to two cargo handlers who entered and cleaned a container from North America without wearing masks in late October. Mass testing campaigns have been rolled out in response to local cases, with 2.6 million people in Tianjin also being tested.

site_title: A third of Singaporeans facing difficulty in home loan repayments: poll
summary: A recent survey by OCBC found that a third of Singaporeans are struggling with home loan repayments, with 61% of the country's financial wellness index dipping to 61 this year. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the global economy. The survey, which polled 2,000 working adults between ages 21 and 65, also highlighted the strain on passive income, with 45% of respondents experiencing a decline in their income. The findings are a cause for concern, highlighting the financial challenges faced by Singaporeans during this time.

site_title: Shanghai links two of latest virus cases to cargo container from abroad
summary: Shanghai authorities have linked two recent coronavirus cases to a cargo container from North America, handled by airport cargo handlers who were not wearing masks. The container, which was damp and sealed, is believed to be the source of infection. Authorities have tested 17,719 employees at the airport's cargo handling area and are offering emergency use of vaccines to high-risk workers. China reported 11 new infections on Monday, including two local cases in Shanghai, bringing the country's total cases to 86,442.

site_title: Blackstone seeking at least US$5b for second Asia fund
summary: Blackstone Group is seeking at least $5 billion for its second Asia-focused private equity fund, more than double the size of its first, amid the region's faster-than-global recovery from the pandemic. The firm aims to increase its Asian investment proportion to 20% by 2023, targeting Japan, Australia, Korea, and emerging markets like China and India. With 66% of its 2018 fund already invested, Blackstone is betting on a continued appetite for Asia investments and deal flows picking up in 2021.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as biggest states lift border curbs
summary: Australian shares ended 0.3% higher as New South Wales and Victoria reopened their borders after over four months, boosting risk appetite. Energy and mining firms led the charge, with oil prices extending gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose as much as 0.8% during the session. A surge in air traffic is expected, benefiting travel and tourism stocks. Mining sub-index recorded its best session in two weeks, with BHP and Rio Tinto climbing 2.5% and 1.5%, respectively.

site_title: Broadway Industrial still in talks with buyer for hard disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial Group is still in talks with a potential buyer for its hard disk drive business after receiving a draft binding letter of intent. The company halted trading of its shares on November 18, but later lifted the halt and resumed trading on Monday. No binding agreement has been reached yet, and further negotiations are required. The potential buyer intends to retain key management and technical staff. Broadway Industrial had initially planned to complete the sale by December 30.

site_title: Alibaba CEO says China's draft anti-monopoly rules 'timely and necessary'
summary: Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang has praised China's draft anti-monopoly rules, calling them "timely and necessary" for the country's internet giants. The draft rules aim to prevent monopolistic behavior by platforms, following increased government scrutiny. Zhang noted that the industry's development and government supervision rely on each other, promoting healthy society growth. The rules may impact Alibaba's e-commerce marketplaces and payment services, which face greater oversight under the new regulations.

site_title: UK's richest man partners with Hyundai to make hydrogen happen
summary: UK's richest man, Jim Ratcliffe, is partnering with Hyundai to make hydrogen fuel cell vehicles more mainstream. Ineos Group will explore hydrogen production and supply opportunities, while potentially using Hyundai's fuel cell system in Ineos' upcoming Grenadier SUV. The collaboration aims to set up hydrogen infrastructure in Europe, with Hyundai targeting 15% of the hydrogen truck market by 2030. This move could also boost Ineos' auto market entry plans, as Ratcliffe's company develops an SUV similar to the Land Rover Defender.

site_title: Gold edges up on softer US dollar, Fed stimulus bets
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,872.76 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar and hopes of further monetary stimulus. The US Treasury Secretary's reassurance that the Fed and Treasury have tools to support the economy contributed to the increase. The weaker US dollar reduced the cost of purchasing gold, making it more appealing to investors. Meanwhile, rising Covid-19 cases in the US and Germany fueled concerns about potential lockdowns, supporting the appeal of gold as an inflation hedge.

site_title: Germany braces for extension of lockdown until Dec 20
summary: Germany is set to extend its lockdown measures until December 20 due to ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, according to a draft proposal and senior politicians. The current "lockdown-lite" measures, which include closing bars and restaurants but keeping schools and shops open, have not shown a decline in infection numbers. Chancellor Angela Merkel will meet with state leaders on November 25 to discuss extending the restrictions, which may include further closures and restrictions on gatherings.

site_title: Iceland wants to restart tourism, but only for the wealthy
summary: Iceland is introducing a new remote-work visa program for high-earning foreign nationals, requiring a minimum monthly salary of $88,000. The program aims to attract wealthy individuals to spend their money in the country, filling empty tables at restaurants and renting out Airbnbs. The goal is to foster investment without straining Iceland's healthcare system, which has been burdened by the pandemic. The program excludes lower-income individuals, prioritizing luxury tourism for the wealthy.

site_title: Sabana Reit not convening EGM requisitioned by fund managers
summary: Sabana Reit, a shari'ah-compliant industrial real estate investment trust, will not convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) as requested by fund managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital. The fund managers proposed five resolutions, including a request for further study of the proposed merger with ESR-Reit, but Sabana Reit's manager said it has "carefully considered" the requisition notice and urged unitholders to focus on the merits of the proposed merger and trust scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close at record high as Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix surge
summary: South Korean shares reached a record high on Monday, closing at 2,602.59, driven by gains from chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The Kospi rose 1.92% with heavyweights surging 4.33% and 3.31% respectively. Foreigners bought net US$890.21 million worth of Kospi shares for the 13th consecutive session. Despite tighter social distancing rules due to a surge in COVID-19 cases, the rally extended for a fourth consecutive session.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, up 4.17 points or 0.3% to 1,597.92. The index saw 848.2 million lots traded worth RM276.8 million. The market had a gainer-to-loser ratio of 380 to 190.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine shoots up 9%, partly led by renewed merger hopes
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares surged 9% on Monday, driven by robust turnover and optimism over crude prices, which rose 0.4% amid vaccine developments. Analysts attribute the surge to "beaten down cyclicals" and a rise in crude prices. The company's shares outperformed the Straits Times Index, with trading activity higher than usual. Speculation about a potential merger between Sembcorp Marine and Keppel Offshore & Marine, fueled by Keppel's recent leadership changes, has also contributed to the stock's rally.

site_title: New Bridge Road shophouse, home to Song Fa Bak Kut Teh, up for sale
summary: A 99-year leasehold shophouse at 11 New Bridge Road in Singapore, home to Song Fa Bak Kut Teh, is up for sale with a guide price of S$16.9 million. The four-storey property has a land area of 1,452 sq ft and an existing GFA of 5,324 sq ft. The site is zoned for commercial use, allowing for potential expansion to increase the GFA. The property's incoming owner will have flexibility to maximize the GFA or explore alternative uses, and foreigners are eligible to purchase without additional stamp duties.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day with gains, driven by positive comments from a top US official on vaccine distribution. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.8% to 26,659.79, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.2%. The gains followed a rally in Singapore stocks and US indices, which edged to fresh records despite trade uncertainty. The positive sentiment was also influenced by a successful funding round for eSIM platform Airalo, which valued the company over $1 billion.

site_title: Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine could get UK approval this week: Telegraph
summary: The UK is set to approve Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine by this week, ahead of the US FDA's scheduled discussion on December 10. The National Health Service has been told to be ready to administer the vaccine by December 1, with Britain ordering 40 million doses. The vaccine's approval process is independent of the government and will take as long as needed to review the final data. If approved, 5 million people will be protected.

site_title: More business travel on the cards: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore is poised to reopen its borders further, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing announcing plans for more travel, citing the country's resources to contain the economic impact of the virus. Despite the economy shrinking 5.8% in the third quarter, Chan emphasized the need for sustainable government measures, warning that business support schemes must taper off in the coming year. The government will focus on targeted support for businesses and workers, balancing infection risks and restoring economic activity.

site_title: Uptick in local demand for Singapore retailers may be unsustainable: poll
summary: A recent American Express survey of 300 Singaporean SMEs found that about one in two retailers experienced higher sales from September to October this year than last year, with 32% reporting a 50% year-on-year increase. However, the sustainability of this trend is uncertain, as many retailers still rely on tourist demand, which may not return by mid-2021. To address this, American Express is launching a "Shop Small" campaign to encourage local spending, offering cashback rewards at over 2,000 participating businesses.

site_title: Singapore headline, core inflation fall in October after two months of marginal rises
summary: Singapore's headline and core inflation both fell to -0.2% in October, after two months of marginal increases. Core inflation declined due to a steeper fall in services costs, with food inflation at 1.7% and the only positive year-on-year inflation in core components being in food, communication, and household durables. Economists expect MAS to maintain its forecasts for inflation to remain between -0.5% and 0.5% in 2021.

site_title: Biden to name longtime aide Blinken as US top diplomat: reports
summary: President-elect Joe Biden plans to nominate Antony Blinken, a longtime aide, as his secretary of state. Blinken, 58, is a seasoned diplomat fluent in French and a former deputy secretary of state under Barack Obama. The nomination signals a return to multilateralism after Donald Trump's shunning of traditional allies. Blinken, a committed Europhile, could help reassure US allies and is expected to take a more collaborative approach to foreign policy. The nomination, along with Jake Sullivan as national security advisor, is set to be announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia's Bega Cheese plans S$539m buyout of Kirin dairy arm: source
summary: Australia's Bega Cheese Ltd is planning to acquire the local dairy arm of Japan's Kirin Holdings Co Ltd for approximately S$539.47 million. The deal, which would be valued around A$550 million, aims to accelerate Bega's transformation into a food giant. Bega, which has already acquired several Australian brands, including Vegemite and Kraft peanut butter, would gain Lion's 6% share of the Australian dairy market. The deal would relieve Kirin of an underperforming asset, which it has been trying to sell since 2018.

site_title: Keppel's business units get new leaders
summary: Keppel Corp announced leadership changes at its property, infrastructure, and investment arms, effective February 15, 2021. The "next generation" leaders, part of the team that formulated the Vision 2030 plan, will bring new ideas and perspectives to the business units. Keppel Corp CEO Loh Chin Hua expressed confidence in the new leaders, who are ready to take on bigger roles. The changes are part of the conglomerate's succession planning and leadership renewal.

site_title: SingPass authentication required in order to redeem SingapoRediscovers Vouchers: STB
summary: Singaporeans aged 18 and above can redeem SingapoRediscovers Vouchers online, requiring SingPass authentication, through five authorized booking partners. The vouchers, worth S$100 each, can be redeemed from Dec 1, 2020, to June 30, 2021, and are non-transferable. Eligible citizens will receive a letter with redemption information. The scheme aims to support Singapore's tourism sector and complements the S$45 million SingapoRediscovers marketing campaign, with about S$320 million worth of vouchers to be given out.

site_title: Hong Kong activists including Joshua Wong plead guilty at protest trial
summary: Prominent Hong Kong dissident Joshua Wong and two other leading activists, Ivan Lam and Agnes Chow, pleaded guilty to charges related to last year's protests, with Wong expecting jail time. The trio, who were involved in a protest outside the city police headquarters, said they would continue to fight for democracy despite the guilty plea. The charges carry up to five years in jail, and the trio's decision to plead guilty may lead to lighter sentences. Wong has previously been jailed for his involvement in democracy protests, and the guilty plea is seen as a significant development in the ongoing crackdown on democracy supporters in Hong Kong.

site_title: WTO aiming to net fishing deal
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is racing against time to reach a deal on banning billions of dollars in fisheries subsidies, with a non-binding deadline of the end of 2020. Despite years of negotiations, disagreements persist over the impact on developing countries, with some countries, including India, calling for exemptions. The deadline to net a deal is fast approaching, with WTO members working on a confidential document, but progress has been slowed by the coronavirus pandemic and differing views on subsidies.

site_title: MAS to fund banks with up to 25b yuan to back offshore renminbi market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will provide up to 25 billion yuan (S$5.1 billion) in funding to banks in Singapore to deepen the offshore renminbi market. The funding will be channelled through primary dealers to enhance market liquidity. The move will discontinue the overnight yuan liquidity facility, but the MAS RMB Facility will remain in operation to provide additional term funding. The initiative aims to strengthen banks' ability to meet growing renminbi business needs and support the development of the offshore RMB market in Singapore.

site_title: Local tourism keeps 'Symbol of Hong Kong' junk boat afloat
summary: The traditional Chinese junk boat, Dukling, has adjusted its tour routes to cater mainly to locals in Hong Kong due to the coronavirus pandemic. Built in 1955, the boat now offers tours to attract local residents, rather than foreign tourists, with a 96-99% decline in visitor arrivals since February. The current operator has preserved about a third of the business by offering Cantonese-language tours and sailing to more distant locations. The Dukling is considered a symbol of Hong Kong, with its wooden structure and historical significance.

site_title: Covid-19 and the rise of corporate socially-distanced responsibility
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, corporate social responsibility (CSR) has taken on a new meaning, with companies prioritizing community support and digital initiatives. Amidst social distancing mandates, companies are adapting CSR programs to go digital, leveraging technology and gamification to engage participants and provide support to vulnerable communities. Examples include GrabCare, Enrich's financial health tips for migrant domestic workers, and digital volunteering platforms like Missing Maps, which enable remote volunteers to create maps of physical locations. As digital activity surges, companies are recognizing the importance of sustainable, long-term partnerships and adapting to the changing climate to effectively address the needs of those in need.

site_title: Abu Dhabi plans S$164b in oil spending to boost output
summary: Abu Dhabi plans to invest S$163.7 billion over five years to boost oil production, aiming to raise daily output to 5 million barrels by 2030. The investment will contribute to growth in production, refining, and trading, despite Opec's output restrictions. The UAE's total recoverable oil reserves have increased to 107 billion barrels, with an additional 2 billion barrels discovered at conventional fields and 22 billion barrels of unconventional oil found. The move aims to maximize value from every barrel of oil produced.

images.alt_text: Abu Dhabi will invest 448 billion dirhams (S$163.7 billion) in oil and natural gas over the next five years as it seeks to raise production capacity, even while Opec restricts its output.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise as investors count on vaccine relief
summary: Asian shares rose on Monday, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index reaching a record high, driven by hopes for imminent coronavirus vaccines and easing of lockdowns. The US government's vaccine development official said vaccines could be distributed by mid-December, boosting optimism. Despite rising Covid-19 infections in the US, investors are focusing on vaccine relief and central bank support, leading to gains in markets such as South Korea, Australia, and China. However, US stimulus uncertainty and rising yen prices capped gains, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling on Friday.

images.alt_text: Japanese markets were closed for a holiday, but Nikkei futures added 0.2 per cent to 25,795.

site_title: QT Vascular scraps S$1b RTO plan; shares fall amid heavy volume
summary: QT Vascular has scrapped a proposed S$1 billion reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Mongolian mining company Tengri Coal and Energy (TCE) due to unfulfilled conditions precedent. The deal's conditions, including a compliance placement and Singapore Exchange approval, were not met by the deadline. QT Vascular's shares fell 33.3% amid heavy volume trading after the announcement. The company will continue to explore other corporate opportunities to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Ascendas Reit opens preferential offering; completes US office acquisition
summary: Ascendas Reit has launched a preferential offering to unitholders, offering 37 new units for every 1,000 existing units held at Nov 18 at 5pm. The offering will raise about S$396.5 million, part of a S$1.2 billion equity fundraising to finance potential US, Europe, Australia acquisitions worth S$2 billion. The Reit has completed the S$560.2 million purchase of two office buildings in San Francisco, adding to its portfolio of 96 properties in Singapore, 36 in Australia, 38 in the UK, and 30 in the US.

site_title: Britain, Canada agree on deal to keep trading under EU terms
summary: Britain and Canada have agreed to continue trading under existing EU terms after the Brexit transition period ends, maintaining a £20 billion relationship. The deal sets the stage for further negotiations and "locks in" the existing trade relationship.

site_title: Australia: Shares at near nine-month high as biggest states reopen borders
summary: Australian shares rose to a near nine-month high on Monday as New South Wales and Victoria reopened their borders after four months, boosting hopes for a speedy economic revival. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.7%, with travel-related stocks and heavyweight miners leading gains. Qantas Airways rose 3%, while BHP Group and Fortescue Metals Group jumped 3.7% and 5.6%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose to a near nine-month high on Monday, as the country's two most populous states reopened borders after more than four months, bolstering hopes of a speedy revival from the coronavirus-induced economic fallout.

site_title: OCBC to list tech-focused ETF on SGX
summary: OCBC will list the Lion-OCBC Securities Hang Seng Tech ETF on the Singapore Exchange, tracking the Hang Seng Tech Index, which comprises the top 30 Hong Kong-listed technology companies by market capitalization. This move aims to provide investors with easier access to Hong Kong-listed technology stocks.

site_title: Siemens, Deutsche Bahn launch local hydrogen trains trial
summary: Siemens Mobility and Deutsche Bahn have launched a trial of hydrogen-powered fuel cell trains, aiming to replace diesel engines on German local rail networks. The prototype, built by Siemens, can be fueled by a battery, fuel cell, or overhead lines, and has a range of 600 km and top speed of 160 km/h. The trial is set to begin in 2024, with a market potential of 50-150 billion euros for the 10,000-15,000 trains that will need to be replaced over the next 10-15 years. The technology is seen as a key solution for decarbonizing rail transport.

site_title: US dollar pinned near major support as vaccine progress weighs
summary: The US dollar remained stable on Monday, pinned near major support levels, as concerns about economic restrictions to combat the coronavirus pandemic weighed on the currency. The prospect of an early vaccine rollout offered some optimism, but the uncertainty surrounding the US Federal Reserve's next monetary policy move kept investors cautious. The euro hovered near a resistance level, with analysts predicting a rise in the single currency's value over the next few years.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore upgrades 2020 forecast for trade, non-oil domestic exports
summary: Singapore's authorities have upgraded their full-year forecast for total merchandise trade and non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to -7.5 to -7 per cent and 4 to 4.5 per cent, respectively. The country's total merchandise trade declined by 6.3 per cent in Q3, with oil trade decreasing by 39.5 per cent and non-oil trade growing by 0.8 per cent. NODX grew by 6.5 per cent, driven by a 9.5 per cent increase in electronic product exports.

site_title: In US, booming real estate market highlights rich-poor divide
summary: The US real estate market is booming, with soaring home prices and demand pushing out potential first-time buyers. Despite the novel coronavirus crisis, the US Federal Reserve's low interest rates have boosted buying power for those with jobs. However, this has meant that families with modest incomes are struggling to enter the market, with the percentage of first-time buyers dropping to 31% in 2020. Experts say that increasing supply, such as through homebuilding, and incentivizing real estate investors to sell their properties are needed to make it easier for first-time buyers.

site_title: Covid-19 and the rise of corporate socially-distanced responsibility
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, corporate social responsibility (CSR) has taken on a new significance, with companies feeling a sense of urgency to support vulnerable communities. To adapt to social distancing mandates, companies are turning to digital initiatives, such as online volunteering, gamification, and financial inclusion programs. Examples include Grab's GrabCare service, Enrich's online quizzes for migrant domestic workers, and the Grameen Foundation's app for accessing credit. Digital CSR initiatives enable companies to reach a wider audience, promote empathy and support, and provide essential services to those in need.

images.alt_text: Mr Aloysius Lee, who is deaf, has gone from only transporting passengers for Grab to delivering food and parcels as well as being part of the company's GrabCare service ferrying healthcare professionals to and from hospitals. ---- GrabCare is one of the ways companies in Singapore are offering their CSR in innovative ways.

site_title: US hopes to start virus vaccines in December as pandemic surges
summary: US officials hope to start coronavirus vaccinations in early December, despite cases surging globally, with over 1.4 million deaths reported worldwide and 255,000 in the US since emerging last year. Encouraging results from vaccine trials have bolstered hopes for an end to the pandemic, with nations reimposing restrictions to slow the spread. This could mark a crucial shift in the battle against the virus, which has had a significant impact on lives and economies worldwide.

site_title: Biden team, pushing quick stimulus deal, prepares for renewed recession
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's team is preparing for a potential "double-dip" recession in 2021, pushing for a quick stimulus deal with Senate Republicans. The Biden administration is considering a smaller package of $500 billion, but top Democrats remain adamant that Republicans need to meet their $2.4 trillion opening offer. The team is also exploring policy options, including executive orders, to mitigate the economic impact, and is urging lawmakers to pass a bipartisan emergency aid package in the lame-duck session. Economists warn that a delay in stimulus could lead to a significant economic contraction, with some predicting a double-dip recession unless lawmakers act quickly.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Ascendas Reit, Keppel, Sabana Reit, ESR-Reit, OCBC, SPH
summary:

The Singapore Exchange launched five new futures contracts, and City Developments Limited appointed new non-executive directors. Isetan expects a negative impact from the pandemic on its financial performance.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly shipping market report for November 20, 2020, shows a resilient Capesize market, with prices increasing in Asia and the North Pacific. The North Atlantic market underperformed, while the North Pacific and US Gulf saw gains. The Ultramax and Supramax markets also showed improvement, with rates rising in the US Gulf and south-east Asia. The Handysize market recovered in East coast South America, while the VLCC, Suezmax, and Aframax markets remained stable. Clean cargo rates also gained, with the MR market showing significant growth.

site_title: Only the best London offices thrive in emerging Covid divide
summary: London's new office buildings are commanding near-record rents, while second-hand spaces are declining in value. The pandemic has created a divide, with top-rated buildings attracting investors due to their green credentials and amenities. Companies are downsizing by selling unused space, further depressing second-hand values. The trend suggests that only the best new office buildings are thriving in the current economic climate.

site_title: Economic recovery in 2021 possible, but requires greater regional cooperation: PECC
summary: The Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) warns that a recovery in 2021 is possible but requires greater regional cooperation to counter the risk of protectionism, which holds back investment in new jobs and innovation. Asia-Pacific economies are expected to shrink by 3.1% in 2020 and 5% in 2021, with a decline in trade growth and a potential loss of poverty reduction achievements due to the pandemic. Foreign direct investment is also expected to drop below $1 trillion, and a fresh look at trade integration is needed to boost growth.

site_title: Astra-Oxford vaccine is key to escaping pandemic for many nations
summary: AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine, developed with the University of Oxford, is crucial for escaping the pandemic in many nations, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The vaccine has shown promising results and will be manufactured in multiple countries, including India and Brazil. With over 50 countries relying on it, the vaccine's success is crucial for global access. However, concerns remain about the vaccine's efficacy, pricing, and distribution, which could impact its ability to meet demand and prevent the spread of the pandemic.

site_title: Kazakh fintech star Kaspi a pandemic bright spot
summary: Kaspi.kz, Kazakhstan's fintech leader, has seen its rapid rise accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's valuation soared to $6.5 billion on the London stock exchange in October, making it the Central Asian country's most valuable firm. This surpassed its previous attempt to reach a $4 billion market cap valuation the previous year. Despite being valued at $6.5 billion, the company's headquarters still feels sleepy due to most staff working from home, a contrast to its impressive growth during the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher Monday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 2,828.67 on Monday, driven by positive economic data showing a 5.8% year-on-year decline in the third quarter, beating expectations. The index had risen 3.75% last week, with four days of gains and one day of loss. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also traded higher, while Singapore Airlines fell 1.7% after the travel bubble was deferred due to Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong.

site_title: Last-minute pause in air travel bubble will inspire trust and confidence
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have suspended their air travel bubble, a quarantine-free travel arrangement, just hours before its scheduled launch due to a recent spike in novel coronavirus cases in Hong Kong. The decision was made to err on the side of caution and protect the health of travelers and residents. The bubble was set to launch on November 22, with flights from Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific carrying a maximum of 200 passengers each. The suspension will be re-evaluated after a two-week pause, with the possibility of resuming if the number of unlinked cases drops below a certain threshold.

site_title: US sectoral stocks taking turns on vaccine headlines
summary: US stocks are tracking a vaccine against the Covid-19 pandemic, with most economically sensitive sectors, such as energy and financials, rising despite a surge in cases. Vaccine makers Moderna and Pfizer have reported high efficacy rates, and a vaccine is expected to be ready for emergency distribution by the end of the year. This has led to a shift in sectoral trends, with companies benefiting from a full US reopening, such as airlines and theme-park operators, gaining favor, while tech companies lag. However, market observers warn that a second wave of Covid-19 could still disrupt the economy and markets.

site_title: Medtecs CEO buys 1 million shares on open market
summary: Medtecs CEO buys 1 million shares on open market, but no further details on the company's financial performance or the reasons behind the buyback are provided. The Straits Times Index gained 2.4% over the past five sessions, while the iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index declined 0.7%. The article does not provide a direct link between the CEO's buyback and the market trends.

site_title: China derivatives suite continues to grow
summary: SGX launches five new futures contracts based on Net Total Return and Price Return Indices, focusing on China, with the SGX FTSE Emerging Market Index and SGX FTSE China 50 Index being key components. China stocks make up 48% of the SGX FTSE Emerging Market Index, while the SGX FTSE China 50 Index comprises China stocks listed in Hong Kong, including major tech brands.

site_title: Biggest Australian states reopen borders as coronavirus cases ease
summary: Australia's New South Wales and Victoria states reopened their borders on November 23, 2020, after four months, following the containment of a second coronavirus wave in Melbourne. The borders, which had been closed since early July, were lifted at midnight, triggering joyful scenes and celebrations. This move raises prospects for a quicker return to normal and a speedy economic recovery, marking the first time in over a century that the borders were closed due to a pandemic.

images.alt_text: Australia's two most populous states reopened their borders on Monday after more than four months, as Victoria stamped out a second coronavirus wave, raising prospects of a quicker return to normal and speedy economic recovery.

site_title: From 'haves' to 'have-nots': how Covid-19 is swelling UK's subprime ranks
summary: The UK's credit score amnesty on Covid-19 debt relief is set to expire, potentially affecting thousands of Britons who relied on payment holidays. Those with more than six months of relief may be re-rated as subprime, making it harder to access credit. The move is expected to disproportionately impact low-income individuals and those who have historically struggled with debt. Industry experts warn of dire consequences, including loan defaults and a potential rise in loan-sharking, as lenders tighten criteria and some subprime lenders shut their doors.

site_title: Singapore Medical Council may take legal action against DoctorxDentist
summary: The Singapore Medical Council (SMC) may take legal action against DoctorxDentist, a medical review website, after the platform failed to remove listings of registered medical practitioners taken without permission. The SMC had demanded the removal by Friday, but no action was taken by Saturday. The Ministry of Health (MOH) stated that the SMC is "presently exploring avenues of legal recourse" against the platform. This move follows the SMC's failure to meet the MOH's demands.

site_title: BOE expected to take case-by-case approach to dividend payouts
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) is expected to consider a case-by-case approach to dividend payouts for banks, taking into account economic conditions and the impact of a vaccine. The PRA will review lender fourth-quarter books and assess the wider economic backdrop before making a final view. Any progress on a vaccine is also likely to influence the regulator's thinking. This move is seen as a softening of resistance to dividend payouts, which could ease pressure on lenders. The PRA's decision is expected to be made early next year.

site_title: US dollar up versus euro and yen
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro and yen on Friday, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and mixed economic signals. The dollar ended the week on a loss against a currency basket, but surged against the yen. The possible resumption of US stimulus talks and positive vaccine news have weighed on the dollar as a safe haven. The euro and Australian dollar posted gains, while the New Zealand dollar hit new two-year highs.

site_title: Indonesia gets 550m euro loan from Germany's state bank for Covid fight
summary: Indonesia secured a 550 million euro loan from Germany's state bank KfW to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. The loan will be used to upgrade hospitals and procure medical equipment. This comes as Indonesia's government expects a 6.34% budget deficit this year, the largest in decades, due to increased spending to combat the pandemic. The country has also recently signed a 1.5 billion dollar loan agreement with Australia and has been seeking bilateral and multilateral loans to finance its deficit.

site_title: Crossing the PMET divide: Can every job be a good job?
summary: Singapore's workforce is increasingly divided between Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMET) and non-PMET jobs, with 56% of the workforce now classified as PMETs. The pressure to place more Singaporeans into PMET jobs is expected to rise, with 2/3 of the workforce predicted to hold such jobs by 2030. Experts argue that increasing wages for non-PMET positions may be a better solution, as it would provide a more stable income for workers, regardless of their job skills.

site_title: Singapore Medical Council threatens legal action against DoctorxDentist
summary: The Singapore Medical Council (SMC) has threatened to take legal action against DoctorxDentist, a medical review website, for listing medical practitioners without permission. The SMC had asked the startup to remove the listed doctors by Friday, but no attempts were made. In response, DoctorxDentist will remove all medical practitioners who do not wish to be listed, but those who want to remain can disable the patient review function or request to have their contact information published. The Singapore Medical Association has also listed over 1,100 doctors who do not wish to be associated with the platform.

site_title: Spanish banks seek mergers as outlook darkens
summary: Spanish banks are seeking mergers to address low interest rates, growing competition from fintech startups, and a pandemic-induced recession. CaixaBank and Bankia approved a merger, creating the nation's largest domestic lender, while BBVA is in talks with Banco Sabadell. Mid-sized lenders Liberbank and Unicaja are also exploring tie-ups. These operations aim to strengthen solvency and avoid future problems, unlike during the 2008 financial crisis when banks faced solvency issues. Experts say low interest rates and competition from fintech have made it difficult for traditional banks to be profitable.

site_title: Do China fintech giants pose a risk for European banks?
summary: European banks remain wary of Chinese fintech giants, such as Ant Group and WeChat Pay, which have disrupted traditional banking services with digital offerings. Despite the setbacks for Ant Group, European banks are concerned about the long-term impact of Chinese tech giants' investments and capabilities, which could lead to increased competition. European banks are struggling to adapt to digital services, with cultural barriers, such as QR code payments, hindering their efforts. Chinese companies' planned investments of $70 billion over five years are expected to accelerate the shift towards digital banking.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 58,160. All 12 cases were placed on stay-home notices on arrival and tested while in Singapore. There were no locally transmitted cases for the 12th consecutive day. 58,049 people have fully recovered, and 22 confirmed cases remain in hospital, with 34 isolated at community facilities.

site_title: A coronavirus Christmas in Hungary - chocolate Santas in marzipan masks
summary: Hungarian confectioner Laszlo Rimoczi created chocolate Santas with marzipan masks to lift spirits during the coronavirus pandemic. The unusual design became a hit, with orders surging online, and Rimoczi now produces about 100 Santas a day. He simplified the design and uses gluten-free Italian chocolate to meet demand.
