While the masked Santas have been a boost, Rimoczi expects sales to decline once vaccines help defeat the pandemic, predicting he'll only sell a fraction of them next year.

site_title: Singapore's solar firm Sun Electric feels more heat from fraud allegations
summary: Singapore solar firm Sun Electric Group faces mounting woes, including S$15 million in claims from partners-turned-creditors, contempt proceedings, and a patent fight with Sunseap Group. Founder Matthew Peloso is accused of alleged fraud by creditor RCMA Asia, with the Singapore Police Force investigating. The firm's JTC contract, a key business linchpin, is under threat due to the electricity retail business's liquidation risk. Four to five creditors are in talks to recoup their monies, with no plan in motion. The case has become entangled with scandal-hit coal miner Agritrade Resources, with Agritrade claiming US$5 million in damages for alleged fraudulent misrepresentations.

images.alt_text: Sun Electric's financial dilemma could jeopardise its JTC contract, given that its electricity retail business faces liquidation threat. Mr Peloso and his firm are facing mounting woes.
Sun Electric's financial dilemma could jeopardise its JTC contract, given that its electricity retail business faces liquidation threat. Mr Peloso (above) and his firm are facing mounting woes.

site_title: Do China tech giants pose a risk for European banks?
summary: European banks are concerned that Chinese tech giants, particularly Ant Group and its rival Tencent, may pose a significant threat to their business. These companies have invested heavily in developing digital services, including payments and financial services, and have gained widespread adoption in China. With a combined investment plan of $140 billion over the next five years, they are likely to accelerate their expansion into European markets, forcing traditional banks to adapt and invest in digital services to remain competitive.

site_title: Hong Kong to give HK$5,000 to those testing positive for Covid-19: RTHK
summary: Hong Kong will provide a one-time HK$5,000 payment to those testing positive for Covid-19 to encourage testing, Health Secretary Sophia Chan announced. The city reported 43 new cases, the highest in three months, and will impose new social restrictions. The government is also setting up five new community testing centres and has issued a compulsory testing order for people who visited 14 dance centres linked to a cluster of fresh cases.

site_title: How disagreement about price for Sabana Reit turned its merger with ESR-Reit into a spectacle
summary: Sabana Reit's proposed merger with ESR-Reit has become contentious, with proponents and opponents intensifying their efforts ahead of a December 4 vote. The merger's standalone potential has been downplayed by Sabana Reit, alienating unitholders. Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, which hold 11% of Sabana Reit's units, have requisitioned an EGM to discuss the appointment of an independent director and personnel hiring. The dispute highlights disagreement over the deal's value, with Sabana Reit's efforts to counter criticism seen as counterproductive. The vote's outcome is uncertain.

images.alt_text: The manager of Sabana Reit has fired back with righteous scepticism, stating that it is "unable to determine the workability and benefits of the internalisation proposal".

site_title: China vows zero tolerance for misconduct after recent bond defaults
summary: China vows "zero tolerance" for misconduct following recent bond defaults by state firms, including Yongcheng Coal & Electricity Holding Group and Huachen Auto Group Holdings. Regulatory probes have been launched, and severe punishment will be given to "debt evasion" behaviors. Strengthened prevention and warning systems will be implemented to forestall systemic risks and maintain liquidity. The move aims to boost investor confidence and alleviate pressures on China's nascent economic recovery.

site_title: S Korea restricts restaurant hours, gatherings
summary: South Korea has restricted restaurant hours and social gatherings amid a surge in coronavirus cases, raising its social distancing alert level to 2 in the greater Seoul area. Restaurants are now prohibited from serving customers after 9 pm and can only operate takeouts and deliveries. The measures follow a previous increase in alert level just four days prior, as the country struggles to contain the pandemic. The surge in cases has raised concerns over the annual college entrance exam, with officials urging citizens to stay home and cancel gatherings.

images.alt_text: Stricter social distancing measures are imposed as a surge in coronavirus cases threatens to undermine earlier efforts to contain the pandemic. Restaurants are prohibited from serving customers after 9 pm and can only operate takeouts and deliveries.

site_title: After Pennsylvania court defeat, Trump faces new pressure to concede election
summary: President Donald Trump faces increased pressure from fellow Republicans to concede the US presidential election after a Pennsylvania court dismissed his lawsuit, citing "strained legal arguments without merit." The ruling, which occurred as Pennsylvania was set to certify its results, leaves Trump with an 81,000-vote lead to overcome to remain in office. Fellow Republicans, including Senator Pat Toomey and Representative Liz Cheney, have called on Trump to concede, citing the sanctity of the electoral process.

site_title: SGX Bull Charge community raises S$3.63m for charity
summary: The SGX Bull Charge community raised S$3.63 million for charity through a virtual fundraiser, surpassing its collective target of 100,000 km. The event, which took place from October 30 to November 18, was supported by corporate sponsors, individual donors, and SGX staff. The funds will be channelled to beneficiaries including AWWA Ltd, Autism Association (Singapore), Fei Yue Community Services, and Community Chest, with SGX committing an additional 1,000 volunteer hours to charity.

site_title: US recovery waits for delivery of vaccines and relief
summary: The US stock market is in a limbo as investors await the delivery of COVID-19 vaccines and relief measures. Pfizer and BioNTech announced a 95% effective vaccine, while Moderna also announced a potentially effective vaccine. Despite positive developments, markets experienced corrections due to rising COVID-19 cases and new restrictions. The economic blow from restrictions worldwide could be softened by concentrated spending, with optimism in the US recovering and a slight increase in spending reported. A deal is needed for a second relief bill to aid small businesses and families, with bipartisan cooperation being elusive.

site_title: Britain and Canada agree post-Brexit rollover trade deal
summary: Britain and Canada have agreed on a rollover trade deal worth $27 billion, protecting post-Brexit trade between the two countries. The deal paves the way for a bespoke agreement covering digital trade, small businesses, the environment, and women's economic empowerment. The UK's international trade secretary, Liz Truss, said the deal locks in certainty for thousands of jobs, while Canada's trade minister, Mary Ng, signaled a desire for an ambitious trade agreement with the UK. The deal must be approved by the Canadian Parliament before coming into effect.

site_title: US retailer Guitar Center files for bankruptcy
summary: US retailer Guitar Center filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, citing financial struggles during the coronavirus pandemic. The company has secured $375 million in debtor-in-possession financing and plans to raise $335 million in new senior secured notes. Guitar Center has over 300 stores across the US and has negotiated a restructuring agreement with stakeholders, reducing debt by nearly $800 million and raising up to $165 million in new equity. Operations will continue without interruption.

site_title: Evergrande, property management unit seek HK$15.8b in IPO
summary: Evergrande Group and its property management arm, Evergrande Property Services Group Ltd, are seeking HK$15.8 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO). The offering size could be increased by up to 15% to meet demand, with 23 cornerstone investors securing 789.5 million shares. The cash raised will help Evergrande pare down its US$120 billion debt pile, with 65% of net proceeds going towards acquisitions and investment. The IPO is set to begin trading on December 2.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical gains from tumble in raw material price
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group, a Henan-based producer, has become the world's second-largest dimethylformamide (DMF) producer after a competitor exited the business. The company's gross profit margin improved to 31% for the three months to September, driven by a 20.5% decline in methanol prices and a 36% year-on-year increase in DMF prices. Jiutian's profit rose to 51.9 million yuan (S$10.5 million) in the quarter, up from a loss of 6.9 million yuan a year ago. The company expects this situation to continue for some time due to the correlation between methanol and crude oil prices.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee is seizing the opportunity of increased interest in the company to raise its profile and build up a bigger institutional investor base.

site_title: On a mission to tackle food and packaging waste
summary: TreeDots, a Singapore-based social enterprise, aims to reduce food and packaging waste by offering discounted food items and groceries to suppliers who would have otherwise discarded them. Founded by three university graduates, the platform has gained traction since its inception in 2018, with major suppliers and buyers on board. However, the COVID-19 pandemic posed a challenge, prompting the company to pivot and expand its consumer arm. TreeDots has since launched initiatives such as group-buys and a Virtual Foodbank app to address food waste and support households in need.

site_title: World leaders affirm Paris climate pact as Trump justifies exit
summary: World leaders, including Chinese President Xi Jinping, have reaffirmed their commitment to the Paris climate pact despite US President Donald Trump's exit from the accord. The Group of 20 (G-20) leaders agreed to "endorse" the circular carbon economy plan, while acknowledging the need to reduce emissions. Trump justified his decision to withdraw from the Paris accord, claiming it would harm the US economy. The G-20 leaders also pledged to support equitable vaccine distribution and multilateral trade, but the summit's closing document lacks firm details on these issues.

site_title: Iraqi Christians still hoping to live in beloved homeland
summary: Iraq's dwindling Christian population, estimated to be around 400,000, remains hopeful for a better future despite years of sectarian warfare and violence. Many, like 17-year-old Mariam, attend services at St Joseph's Cathedral in Baghdad, where hardliners have targeted ancient Christian communities. The US-led invasion in 2003 paved the way for bloody conflict, leading to widespread emigration. With no reliable statistics on the number of Christians who fled, the community faces a bleak future, with some considering emigration due to day-to-day discrimination and a lack of economic opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong strives to join RCEP trade deal: finance chief
summary: Hong Kong aims to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) after its agreement takes effect, according to Finance Secretary Paul Chan. The city's total trade with RCEP member states accounts for 71% of its total trade in goods. Chan believes joining RCEP will benefit trade in services and investment. China supports Hong Kong's inclusion, while Chan also emphasized the importance of improving society's understanding of "one country, two systems" following last year's social unrest.

site_title: Give it a shot
summary: Experts in Singapore weigh in on whether everyone should be vaccinated against COVID-19, with varying opinions on priority groups. Ideal candidates include all adults, with priority given to those 65 and above, those with chronic illnesses, and frontline workers. Some argue that vaccinations should be made compulsory once proven safe and effective, while others advocate for voluntary vaccination and equitable access across developing and developed countries. Key priority groups include healthcare workers, the elderly, and those with underlying medical conditions. A tiered approach is suggested to achieve herd immunity, with frequent travelers also being considered for vaccination.

site_title: GE signs agreement to develop Vietnam LNG power plant
summary: General Electric has signed a memorandum of understanding with a Vietnamese company to develop a liquefied natural gas (LNG) power plant near Ho Chi Minh City, providing 3,600 megawatts of power. GE will install gas turbine technology and take an equity stake in the project, valued at over $1 billion. The Long Son LNG power complex, in collaboration with Pacific Corporation and Mitsubishi, aims to be operational by 2025 if the project is approved by the Ba Ria-Vung Tau province.

site_title: Moderna to charge US$25-US$37 for Covid-19 vaccine: CEO
summary: Moderna CEO Stephane Bancel announced that the company will charge US$25-US$37 per dose of its Covid-19 vaccine candidate to governments, depending on the amount ordered. This price is comparable to the cost of a flu shot. The European Commission is in talks with Moderna to secure millions of doses at a price below US$25 per dose, with a deal expected to be finalized in a matter of days. Moderna's vaccine has shown a 94.5% effectiveness in preventing Covid-19 based on interim clinical trial data.

site_title: US dividends are down, but they are vastly better than expected
summary: US dividends have declined by less than 1% to 0.67% for the year, defying predictions of a 20% drop. The decline is attributed to corporations holding onto cash due to low interest rates and monetary stimulus programs. Despite depressed corporate earnings, dividend payouts have recovered, with some companies increasing payouts by over 9%. Analysts expect dividend payments to continue to recover, potentially reaching a record next year, but caution that the economy remains vulnerable to another crisis.

site_title: Ex-private banker goes all out to battle income inequality
summary: A private banker, Leon Qiu, left his job to co-found Daung Capital, a fintech firm in Myanmar, aiming to combat income inequality. The firm was acquired by Get All, a digital commerce platform, in 2020. Get All offers micro-services solutions to Myanmar's working class, including credit and insurance products, to help them start businesses and earn extra income. The company has seen success with over 18,000 provision-shop owners and agents, and works with 125 motorcycle dealers across the country, aiming to bring digital payments and services to the excluded segment.

site_title: European regulator to lift Boeing 737 MAX grounding in January
summary: European regulators, led by the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), are set to lift the 20-month grounding of Boeing's 737 MAX passenger jetliner in January. The decision comes after US regulators ended the grounding in December, following changes to the jet's design. EASA's head, Patrick Ky, stated that the aircraft is safe to fly after conducting independent analysis and flight tests. The lifting of the grounding in Europe will depend on pilot training and airlines' upgrades, while commercial flights in the US are scheduled to resume on December 29.

site_title: BlackRock, T Rowe said to lead US$200m funding in Byju's
summary: Byju's, an Indian online education startup, is reportedly raising $200 million in funding from investors including BlackRock and T Rowe Price Group. The round, which could close by end-November, values the company at $12 billion. Byju's aims to double its revenues to $1 billion in the current financial year, with over 70 million users and 4.5 million paid users. The company is targeting the growing demand for online education amid the coronavirus pandemic. Byju's is already India's second-most valuable startup, backed by investors such as Mark Zuckerberg's Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and Tiger Global Management.

site_title: OCBC to list tech-focused ETF on SGX
summary: OCBC is set to list a tech-focused exchange-traded fund (ETF) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) next month. The Lion-OCBC Securities Hang Seng TECH ETF will track the Hang Seng TECH Index, comprising the top 30 technology companies in Hong Kong by market capitalisation. The ETF's initial offering period runs from Nov 23 to Dec 7, with an issue price of S$1.34 per unit, allowing for trades as low as 10 units at a time. The fund will be managed by Lion Global Investors, with OCBC Securities as a participating dealer and strategic partner.

site_title: Holmes says her wealth has no place in Theranos fraud trial
summary: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes is arguing that her wealth and lifestyle should not be used as evidence in her upcoming trial for fraud. Her lawyers claim that her luxurious lifestyle is comparable to that of other CEOs and does not necessarily indicate her guilt. Prosecutors plan to introduce evidence of her luxury travel, high-end SUV, and association with wealthy and powerful people to show she had a financial incentive to commit fraud. Holmes and her former boyfriend, Ramesh Balwani, face allegations of bilking investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars.

site_title: HK, S'pore to decide in December on new date for travel bubble flights postponed over HK Covid-19 cases
summary: The travel bubble flights between Singapore and Hong Kong have been postponed due to the escalating COVID-19 cases in Hong Kong. The flights were originally scheduled to start on Sunday but were suspended after the seven-day moving average of daily unlinked local cases exceeded five for either city. The two governments will announce a new date in early December for the flights to resume, with airlines offering refunds or rescheduling at no cost to affected passengers. Tightening social distancing measures have been implemented in Hong Kong, including a ban on dancing in bars and pubs, as the city struggles with a "severe" pandemic stage.

site_title: Mizuho to cut Singapore office space on work-from-home success
summary: Mizuho Financial Group is set to cut about 16% of its office space at Asia Square Tower 2 in Singapore, equivalent to less than one floor, as it revamps its workplace in global financial centers post-pandemic. The move follows the success of work-from-home arrangements.

site_title: Luminar to supply lidar sensors for Intel subsidiary's self-driving fleet
summary: Luminar Technologies will supply laser-based lidar sensors to Intel's Mobileye subsidiary for its self-driving vehicle test fleet. The deal, terms of which were not disclosed, will incorporate Luminar's lidar into Mobileye's self-driving hardware and software system. This partnership is part of Intel's initiative to build a multimodal Mobility as a Service (MaaS) business. Luminar's lidar technology has been used by Volvo in self-driving vehicles since 2022, and the company is set to go public through a reverse merger with Gores Metropoulos later this quarter.

site_title: US approves Covid therapy, G-20 pushes for global vaccine access
summary: The US has approved an emergency use of a Covid-19 antibody therapy, Regen-COV2, which was previously used to treat President Donald Trump. The therapy aims to reduce hospitalizations and alleviate the healthcare system burden. Meanwhile, the G-20 nations emphasized the need for global access to vaccines, citing concerns that countries may have insufficient access to the life-saving tools. Despite vaccine developments by Pfizer, BioNTech, and Moderna, the summit highlighted worries about affordability and equity.

site_title: Hong Kong adds 45 virus cases, highest in three months: HK01
summary: Hong Kong reported 45 new coronavirus cases on Saturday, the highest daily toll in three months, amid a surge in infections. The city has imposed new social restrictions, including suspending classes for primary school levels one to three and banning live performances in catered premises. Despite this, Hong Kong is set to proceed with its high-profile air-travel bubble with Singapore, requiring passengers to take a Covid-19 test on arrival. The bubble's precariousness raises concerns about the futility of global travel efforts while the coronavirus remains rampant.

site_title: In US, booming real estate market highlights rich-poor divide
summary: The US real estate market is booming, with home prices soaring 12% year-over-year to a median of $313,500. The pandemic has fueled demand, with many white-collar employees considering long-term shifts to telework. However, this has led to a widening gap between rich and poor, as those with modest incomes struggle to enter the market. Experts say the only way to make it easier for first-time buyers is by increasing supply through homebuilding and incentivizing real estate investors to sell their properties.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte ends overseas travel ban on healthcare workers, minister says
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has approved lifting a temporary ban on deploying healthcare workers overseas, allowing 5,000 nurses to leave each year. The decision comes as the country's COVID-19 cases and deaths have slowed down. The ban was imposed in April to combat the pandemic at home, but healthcare workers felt underpaid and underappreciated. The government has promised to improve pay and benefits if nurses stay, but critics say more must be done to retain them.

site_title: Delta, WestJet scrap planned joint venture after US demands
summary: Delta Air Lines and WestJet have scrapped a proposed US-Canada joint venture after the US Transportation Department demanded changes the airlines deemed "unreasonable and unacceptable". The US government required the removal of Swoop, an ultra-low-cost carrier affiliate of WestJet, and divestiture of 16 takeoff and landing slots at New York's LaGuardia Airport. The airlines opposed these demands, citing arbitrary and capricious requirements, and instead plan to explore deepening the alliance.

site_title: China says carbon trading scheme will cover 2,267 power plants in phase one
summary: China's nationwide emissions trading scheme (ETS) will cover 2,267 power plants in its first phase, according to government consultation papers. The scheme, which aims to reduce emissions, includes coal and gas-fired power plants with annual emissions of at least 26,000 tonnes. Firms will receive allowances based on historical emissions and must buy additional permits if they exceed their quota. The scheme's launch has been delayed multiple times, but President Xi Jinping's "carbon neutral" by 2060 announcement has injected urgency into the market construction process.

site_title: Nikon to cut workforce on slump in camera business: Nikkei
summary: Nikon plans to reduce its workforce by 10% due to a slump in its core camera business, impacting around 2,000 employees. The company aims to move its camera production to Thailand and discontinue domestic output. Nikon posted an operating loss of 26.1 billion yen for the second quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. The move is part of the company's reform agenda, which also considers cutting its sales force.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic and Nadal fall as Thiem and Medvedev advance to London finale
summary: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal's bids for the ATP Finals title were thwarted by Dominic Thiem and Daniil Medvedev, respectively. Thiem, seeking a second title, edged Djokovic 7-5 6-7(10) 7-6(5) in a three-hour contest. Medvedev then defeated Nadal 3-6 7-6(4) 6-3, advancing to the final. The ATP Finals will feature the first-time winner, with Medvedev or Thiem set to face each other on Sunday.

site_title: US cloud storage provider Backblaze eyes US$1b valuation in IPO: sources
summary: Backblaze, a US cloud storage provider, is reportedly seeking a US$1 billion valuation in its planned initial public offering (IPO) in 2021. The company, based in San Mateo, California, is backed by venture capital firm TMT Investments and aims to complete its IPO early next year. The plans are subject to change and market conditions, according to sources familiar with the matter.

site_title: Apple, AT&T ask for tough protection for data in Google lawsuit
summary: Apple and AT&T asked a judge to designate certain data in the Justice Department's lawsuit against Google as "highly confidential" to prevent Google from accessing it. The Justice Department's antitrust case centers on Google's billions of dollars paid to be the default search engine on Apple's iPhones. Google had proposed a secure method to access confidential data, but Apple and AT&T want only Google's outside counsel to see it. The trial could last for months, with Apple and AT&T designating sensitive data as "highly confidential".

site_title: Twitter to hand @POTUS account to Biden on inauguration day
summary: Twitter will hand control of the @POTUS account to Joe Biden on inauguration day, January 20, 2021, even if President Donald Trump has not conceded his election loss. The social media giant is collaborating with the National Archives to transfer the accounts, which will be archived and then reset to zero. This move comes as Twitter has long struggled to curb President Trump's use of the platform to spread misinformation and conspiracy theories. Biden's Twitter usage will be a departure from Trump's frequent and often provocative tweets.

site_title: South Korea medical groups urge stricter Covid steps as third wave continues
summary: South Korea's third wave of Covid-19 continues with 386 new daily cases reported, bringing total infections to 30,403 and 503 deaths. Medical groups urged stricter social-distancing curbs to contain the outbreak, warning that daily cases could reach 1,000 in two weeks if measures are not taken. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency reported the highest number of cases since August, with new cases topping 300 for the fourth consecutive day.

site_title: In pandemic Christmas, US rivals aim to challenge Amazon under the tree
summary: US retailers, including Walmart and Best Buy, are bolstering their online gift features to challenge Amazon's dominance during the pandemic Christmas season. The new services aim to simplify gift-giving by offering features such as online wrapping, personal messages, and price-free receipts. Amazon has been expanding its services in response, but the shift to online shopping due to the coronavirus has drawn attention to the growing competition.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines seeks aid from shareholder as creditor talks continue: report
summary: Malaysia Airlines is seeking financial aid from its sole shareholder, Khazanah Nasional, as debt restructuring talks with creditors continue. The airline could receive up to US$500 million in cash, amid a struggling financial situation following the coronavirus pandemic. The talks are in final stages, with a commercial agreement targeted for early December. The airline has restructured before, receiving RM6 billion (S$1.97 billion) from Khazanah in 2014 after two deadly crashes, but this time the government has stated it will not bail out the company.

site_title: Wind-down of loan programmes seen raising odds of more Fed action
summary: The US Treasury Department's request to wind down several emergency lending programs at the end of the year has raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's potential for more economic support. Without the facilities, Fed officials may consider providing additional support due to heightened downside risks, particularly amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and fiscal relief stalemate. Analysts see rising odds of the Fed making changes to its large-scale bond-buying program at its December meeting, with some suggesting the Treasury's request strengthens the case for more action.

site_title: UK to launch infrastructure bank to boost investment
summary: The British government plans to launch a national infrastructure bank to boost investment in infrastructure projects, aiming to deliver over £600 billion in investment over the next five years. The bank will co-invest alongside the private sector in vital projects such as transport, renewable energy, and digital connectivity, helping to meet the government's Net Zero commitments and levelling up across the country. Finance minister Rishi Sunak will announce tens of billions of pounds of infrastructure investment next week.

site_title: Billionaire UK investor aims to force hundreds of companies to act on climate
summary: British billionaire Chris Hohn is launching the "Say on Climate" campaign to force hundreds of US and European companies to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by holding annual shareholder votes on their climate plans. Hohn, founder of the TCI hedge fund, set a precedent by using a shareholder resolution to require Spanish airport operator Aena to draft a new climate plan. He aims to replicate this model at many more companies over the next two years, mobilizing investors to sponsor similar resolutions.

site_title: Tennis: Australian Open crowds at 10% capacity would be a boon, says Djokovic
summary: Novak Djokovic expressed hope for Australian Open spectators despite COVID-19 pandemic restrictions. Fans are allowed at select events with social distancing protocols, but Djokovic believes 10% capacity crowds would be a "boon" for the tournament. He noted that even 50% capacity would be significant, considering most events have been played in empty stadiums since the tour resumed. Djokovic's comments come as he moves into the semis of the ATP Finals in London.

site_title: Dairy's latest entrant in snack wars: Ice cream with vegetables
summary: The California Milk Advisory Board partnered with VentureFuel to host an innovation competition, resulting in the creation of ice cream infused with vegetables as a new dairy product to appeal to younger consumers. This effort aims to boost sales in a market where dairy products have experienced declines in recent years. The competition follows a surge in direct-to-consumer business during the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw a 10-fold increase in dairy sales. The goal is to make dairy products "cool again" and turn around years of weak sales.

site_title: Huawei lawyers question if Canada border agent had reasonable grounds to issue CFO's warrant
summary: Huawei lawyers are questioning a Canadian border agent's decision to detain CFO Meng Wanzhou in 2018, alleging abuse of process. The agent testified that he did not have reasonable grounds to deny her entry, but believed the warrant to detain her was justified. Meng's lawyers seek to have her extradition to the US thrown out, citing the investigation and arrest followed usual procedures. Prosecutors and witnesses from the Canada Border Services Agency and RCMP countered that the procedures were followed, and Meng's lawyers must prove abuse of process.

site_title: Donald Trump Jr infected by coronavirus and in isolation
summary: Donald Trump Jr tested positive for coronavirus and is in isolation, according to three people familiar with the matter. He is asymptomatic, adding to the dozens of people associated with President Donald Trump who have been infected. This comes as the pandemic surges, with new cases topping 150,000 per day, and over 254,000 Americans having died from the virus since February.

site_title: Vornado shelves effort to sell offices co-owned with Trump
summary: Vornado Realty Trust has shelved its effort to sell stakes in two office towers co-owned with the Trump Organization, citing investor caution in commercial-property markets amid the coronavirus pandemic. The New York landlord had been marketing its 70% interest in the properties in San Francisco and Manhattan, but now plans to focus on refinancing and potentially re-offering the assets in 2021. The decision comes as the commercial-property market continues to recover from the pandemic, with many office employees still working remotely.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees K-shaped recovery for commercial real estate
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts a K-shaped recovery in commercial real estate, with industrial properties likely to outperform others. This means some commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) will experience high realised losses, while others will fare better. Lodging and retail properties are expected to struggle, with delinquencies of 22.6% and 11.8%, respectively. The bank projects a 5-7% average expected-loss range for CMBS conduits, with some deals potentially exceeding 10% or even 15%. Despite the challenges, CMBS issuance in 2021 may surprise investors with sales of $60-70 billion.

site_title: Lockdown is giving people a crack at extreme saving
summary: During the UK's second lockdown, some individuals are using the closure of pubs and shops to save aggressively, with one person, Laura Purkess, saving £32,000. This trend is attributed to a combination of government support, luck, and prudent spending. According to the Bank of England, British households saved an average of £17.3 billion per month between March and June, with many redirecting income to pay off debt. This phenomenon highlights the potential for some individuals to benefit financially from the pandemic, particularly those who have been able to cut back on expenses and prioritize saving.

site_title: Air travel bubble will go on, Hong Kong visitors to take Covid-19 test on arrival: CAAS
summary: Singapore will proceed with its air travel bubble arrangement with Hong Kong, but Hong Kong visitors will now be required to take a Covid-19 test upon arrival. The test will be waived for the first week, and travellers must self-isolate while waiting for results. The arrangement, which allows one flight a day between the two cities, has been in place since the pandemic. The move comes after a rise in Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong, with the city reporting 26 cases on Friday.

images.alt_text: Travel will be suspended for two weeks if the seven-day moving average of the daily number of unlinked Covid-19 cases is more than five in either Singapore or Hong Kong.

site_title: G-20 to discuss post-pandemic world, back debt relief
summary: Leaders of the 20 largest world economies (G-20) will discuss post-pandemic strategies this weekend, focusing on global cooperation to address the Covid-19 pandemic. The agenda includes investing US$4.5 billion in vaccines, drugs, and tests for low-income countries. The European Union will urge the G-20 to support the effort. The summit, chaired by Saudi Arabia, aims to step up global cooperation to manage the recovery once the coronavirus is under control.

site_title: Grab to add platform fee after Singapore competition watchdog drops restrictions
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has dropped its two-year hold on Grab, allowing the ride-hailing operator to adjust its prices according to market forces. Grab's first step will be to implement a platform fee of about S$0.30 for its ride-hailing service in the next few months, potentially allowing it to cash in on its created value. This move could benefit Grab and other ride-hailing services in Singapore.

site_title: Jaguar seeks to block US imports of Porsche, Audi SUVs
summary: Jaguar Land Rover Automotive has asked the US International Trade Commission to block imports of Porsche, Audi, Lamborghini, and Volkswagen SUVs that use its patented Terrain Response system without permission. The system, used in Jaguar's F-Pace and Land Rover Discovery vehicles, helps negotiate a "broad range of surfaces" for off-road driving. Jaguar claims the technology is a key feature in its vehicles and seeks to protect itself from companies that have used it without licensing. The move is part of a broader battle between luxury automakers in the highly profitable SUV market.

site_title: Trump to take part in virtual G-20 summit: US official
summary: US President Donald Trump will participate in the virtual G-20 summit hosted by Saudi Arabia on Saturday. This is Trump's second virtual summit appearance, following his participation in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit. The meeting, held due to the coronavirus pandemic, will focus on pressing global issues such as climate change and economic revival. Trump's attendance comes as he refuses to accept his presidential election defeat, and discussions are expected to be dominated by pandemic implications and economic recovery efforts.

site_title: Mobile e-commerce startup Wish files IPO, claims 108m users
summary: US-based mobile e-commerce startup Wish has filed documents for an initial public offering (IPO), revealing a user base of over 100 million. The platform, which connects Chinese merchants with global consumers, has shipped over 640 million items and operates in more than 100 countries. Wish aims to expand its business and has become the most downloaded shopping app.

site_title: Zurich Insurance nears US$4b deal for MetLife unit: sources
summary: Zurich Insurance Group is in advanced talks to acquire MetLife's US property and casualty (P&C) car and home insurance unit for around US$4 billion, according to sources. The deal would expand Zurich's P&C business and allow MetLife to exit a competitive market. If successful, the deal could be announced by early December. This move comes as MetLife faces a 68% drop in third-quarter adjusted earnings at its US P&C division, driven by catastrophe losses.

site_title: Manchester United says systems hit by cyber attack
summary: Manchester United confirmed a cyber attack on its systems, but stated that its critical systems remain secure and operational. The club's media channels, including the website and mobile app, were unaffected, and no personal data breach was reported. The affected systems were shut down to contain the damage and protect data. The club's game against West Bromwich Albion will proceed as scheduled.

site_title: Europe: Commodity rally leads stocks to third straight week of gains
summary: European stocks rose for the third straight week, driven by a jump in commodity-linked stocks, including miners and oil and gas companies, amid strong demand in China and potential supply disruptions. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% as investors bet on a vaccine-led economic recovery, despite concerns over US stimulus and lockdown fears. Positive Covid-19 vaccine updates led to buying in sectors such as banks, travel, and leisure, but US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments on expiring pandemic lending programmes weighed on markets.

site_title: AstraZeneca starts new Covid-19 prevention trials of antibody cocktail
summary: AstraZeneca began late-stage trials of its long-acting monoclonal antibody combination drug, AZD7442, to prevent Covid-19 infection in at-risk individuals for up to 12 months. The Phase III international clinical trial will recruit 5,000 people in Europe and the US to assess safety and effectiveness. This prophylactic treatment differs from vaccines by introducing antibodies, which may be beneficial for those with weakened immune systems or who don't respond to vaccination.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street to gain 1.3%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.3% to 2,813.01 on Friday, driven by a modest rebound in US tech stocks. Jardine Matheson was the largest gainer, adding 4.8% to US$53.68, while Oceanus and Blumont also saw significant price increases. The STI has gained 3.75% over the past week, with four days of gains and one day of loss.

site_title: Trump administration to add four more Chinese firms to Pentagon blacklist: sources
summary: The US is set to designate four more Chinese companies as backed by the Chinese military, bringing the total to 35, in a move aimed at curbing their access to US investors. The additions include giants like Hikvision China Telecom and China Mobile. The decision comes as the Trump administration seeks to cement its hawkish China legacy before leaving office. The move is expected to add to tensions between the US and China, and is part of a broader effort to target Chinese companies seen as enlisting in emerging technologies for military purposes.

site_title: Singapore's PDPC investigating allegations that Muslim Pro developer sold user data to US military
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) is investigating Bitsmedia, the developer of Muslim Pro, after allegations that the company sold user data to the US military. The allegations surfaced in a US news outlet, Vice, which reported that user data, including location details and phone information, was sold to X-mode, a US-based data broker with US military defence contractors as customers. Bitsmedia denied the allegations, stating it has terminated relationships with data partners and that users' data is secure.

site_title: Panic buying of toilet paper hits US stores again with new pandemic restrictions
summary: Panic buying of toilet paper and cleaning supplies has resurfaced in the US as states impose pandemic restrictions, leading to shortages and purchase limits at retailers. As of Friday, 22 states have restricted gatherings, causing shoppers to scramble for essentials like toilet paper and disinfecting wipes. Retailers, including Walmart and Target, have reported pockets of lower-than-normal availability, while some stores like Walgreens and Dollar Tree have maintained stock levels. To meet demand, Charmin maker Procter & Gamble is running plants 24/7.

site_title: Plotting future, US biofuel industry seeks federal clean fuel programme from Biden
summary: US biofuel companies are urging President-elect Joe Biden to impose a nationwide standard to reduce carbon emissions from transport fuels, aiming to preserve ethanol's role in the fight against climate change. The industry plans to ask for a "clean fuel standard" as the current Renewable Fuel Standard nears expiry. The move reflects growing concern about the future of biofuels amid Biden's plans to slash emissions.

site_title: SGX consults public on proposed processes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking public feedback on its proposed process for managing outstanding securities transactions when a clearing member defaults. The proposed process involves liquidating a member's outstanding trades, setting off trades to reduce transactions, and acquiring or selling securities to close out net outstanding trades. The goal is to improve efficiency, speed, and protection of the financial system from contagion risks. The public consultation is open until December 21.

site_title: US, Taiwan hold talks on strengthening economic ties
summary: The US and Taiwan held talks on strengthening their economic relationship, a move seen as a response to China's increasing pressure on the island. The talks, led by US Undersecretary of State Keith Krach and Taiwanese Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Chern-chyi, aimed to enhance cooperation and deepen ties. This step forward was welcomed by Taiwan, which hailed it as a success. The Economic Prosperity Partnership Dialogue was established to facilitate dialogue on economic issues between the two nations.

images.alt_text: The United States and Taiwan held talks on Friday on strengthening their economic relationship in the face of increasing pressure on the island from China, which the Taiwanese side hailed as a successful step forward.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes lower as surging Covid-19 cases offset vaccine hope
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday as investors weighed the impact of surging Covid-19 cases and vaccine developments. Despite a rise in Pfizer's shares after its Covid-19 vaccine application, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.75% and the S&P 500 lost 0.68%. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.42%, with stay-at-home plays like Zoom Video Communications helping curb losses. The US Treasury Secretary announced the expiration of pandemic-relief lending programmes at the end of the year, citing the need for Congress to reallocate funds.

site_title: Oil rises about 1%, posts third week of gains on vaccine hopes
summary: Oil prices rose about 1% on Friday, marking a third consecutive weekly gain, driven by successful Covid-19 vaccine trials and hopes for effective vaccines. Brent crude futures rose to $44.96 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) January crude contract gained 1.2% to $42.42 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is expected to delay a planned production increase, bolstering sentiment. However, Libya's raised production and oversupply concerns continue to weigh on the market.

site_title: Three ways to overcome investing inertia
summary: DBS NAV Financial Health research highlights the risks faced by financially unprepared individuals during the Covid-19 pandemic, including lack of savings and inability to make money work harder. To overcome investing inertia, three tips are recommended: investing in oneself first by acquiring financial knowledge and overcoming loss aversion by understanding the reasons behind losses and adopting a diversified investment approach. Additionally, starting small and building investments over time through regular savings plans or robo-advisors can also help build investing discipline and potentially lower average investment costs.

site_title: China mulls joining trade pact dumped by Trump: Xi
summary: China is considering joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a free trade pact initially backed by former US President Barack Obama, following its abandonment by Donald Trump. China's President Xi Jinping stated that the grouping must promote regional economic integration and establish an Asia-Pacific free trade zone. This move comes as China signs the world's largest trade deal, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, excluding the US. Xi's comments could encourage other countries to follow, with trade expert Deborah Elms saying it would lead to questions about potential membership.

site_title: Wall Street banks can't snub certain industry sectors under proposed new rule
summary: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) has proposed a new rule requiring Wall Street banks to provide fair access to financial services, credit, and capital to all types of businesses, regardless of industry sector. The rule aims to prevent banks from discriminating against certain sectors, such as oil and gas, gun-makers, and others, based on their perceived political affiliations. The proposal applies to the nation's largest banks and seeks to ensure that they meet their responsibility to provide services fairly, given their special privilege and powers.

site_title: Nine non-obvious ways to have deeper conversations
summary: A list of non-obvious ways to have deeper conversations, learned from experts, includes: approaching conversations with awe, asking elevating questions, and not fearing pauses. Open-ended questions, such as "What was it like..." or "Tell me about a time...", can help people share their experiences and emotions. Making others the authors of their own stories, rather than witnesses, and giving them control over the conversation, can also facilitate deeper connections. Additionally, using "gem statements" to find common ground and acknowledging underlying disagreements can help resolve conflicts and strengthen relationships.

site_title: Alpha Bank picks Davidson Kempner as preferred bidder for US$12b bad loans: sources
summary: Alpha Bank has selected Davidson Kempner as its preferred bidder to purchase a $12 billion portfolio of non-performing loans, valued at 10.8 billion euros. Davidson Kempner's bid surpassed a rival offer by Pimco, and the sale is expected to reduce Alpha's non-performing exposure ratio to 24% and its non-performing loan ratio to 13%. The deal is part of Alpha Bank's efforts to clean up its balance sheet amid fears of a surge in soured loans due to the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: US existing home sales rise for fifth straight month in October
summary: US existing home sales rose 4.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.85 million units in October, marking a fifth consecutive month of gains. Despite this, record-high house prices due to tight supply could slow momentum. Existing home sales jumped 26.6% on a year-on-year basis, concentrated in the upper price end of the market. The US housing market is driven by record low mortgage rates, and housing supply remains inadequate, pushing home prices out of reach for many first-time buyers.

site_title: Tesla shatters records in climb to Nasdaq's top performing spot
summary: Tesla shattered records, becoming the top-performing stock on the Nasdaq-100 Index, with a 21% weekly gain. The electric-vehicle maker's market value reached $470 billion, and its shares reached a new intraday high of $508.61. Analysts predict $8 billion in additional demand from US mutual funds, driven by Tesla's upcoming entry into the S&P 500 Index on December 21. The electric vehicle sector is experiencing a buying frenzy, with smaller companies like Nio, Lordstown Motors, and XPeng also seeing record-breaking gains. Governments worldwide are committing to clean energy and electric vehicles, fueling the sector's momentum.

site_title: Celebrating the passion behind local brands
summary: A new campaign, "Made with Passion," launched by the Singapore Brand Office and Singapore Tourism Board, aims to promote local lifestyle brands showcasing the Singapore spirit. 48 brands, including Eu Yan Sang, Bynd Artisan, and Prima Taste, will carry the Made with Passion mark, highlighting the stories behind their creation. The initiative also aims to facilitate collaboration among brands and trade associations, with partnerships already formed between Brass Lion Distillery and Gryphon Tea Company. The campaign will be promoted through various channels, including online marketplaces and retail stores.

site_title: Lee Suet Fern suspended from practising law for 15 months
summary: Senior lawyer Lee Suet Fern has been suspended for 15 months by the Court of Three Judges for misconduct unbefitting an advocate and solicitor, specifically for preparing and executing the last will of her late father-in-law, Lee Kuan Yew, which benefited her husband, Lee Hsien Yang. A disciplinary tribunal had found her guilty of grossly improper professional conduct, but the court disagreed with some of the tribunal's findings. The court ruled that Mrs Lee's actions were misconduct, but did not agree with the tribunal's conclusion of an implied retainer between Mrs Lee and the senior Mr Lee.

site_title: S Korea set to crack down on chaebols with corporate reform
summary: South Korea is set to introduce significant corporate reform, dubbed "fair economy acts," aimed at increasing transparency in top decision-making at large conglomerates, known as chaebols. The proposed revisions would limit the voting power of the largest shareholders and make it harder for them to appoint auditors who share their interests. The move is part of President Moon Jae-in's efforts to overhaul chaebol business practices and promote fair competition, but has faced strong opposition from businesses.

site_title: Temasek launches vehicle to super-charge agriculture, food deals
summary: Temasek International is launching a new platform to accelerate and manage agricultural and food investments. The platform aims to help agrifood companies build operational capabilities and upscale production. Temasek has already invested over US$5 billion in the agrifood industry, backing companies such as Impossible Foods and Bayer. The platform will have two main missions: helping companies scale up production and building operational capabilities. This move is part of Singapore's goal to get 30% of its food requirements from local sources by 2030.

site_title: Trump and Xi join virtual Asia-Pacific summit as trade spat endures
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping attended a virtual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit, discussing the coronavirus crisis and global economic recovery amidst lingering trade differences. The summit, hosted by Malaysia, emphasized the need for open and multilateral trade to support economic recovery, with leaders warning against protectionist policies. Trump's participation marked the first time he joined an Apec summit since 2017, amid a trade spat with China and his administration's lower engagement in Asia.

site_title: SPH shares soar 22% on heavy volumes on restructuring talk
summary: SPH shares surged 22% on Friday, reaching an intra-day high of S$1.28 and a four-month high, amid rumors of restructuring. The stock ended at S$1.25 on a cum-dividend basis, with 85.6 million shares changing hands, representing over 5% of issued shares. The Singapore Exchange queried SPH about the unusual price and volume movements, to which the company replied that it regularly evaluates opportunities to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Hong Kong's new Covid cases raise concerns over Air Travel Bubble
summary: Hong Kong reported 26 new Covid-19 cases, including 21 local cases and 9 untraceable cases, prompting concerns about the upcoming travel bubble with Singapore. The Singapore-Hong Kong Air Travel Bubble, set to launch on November 22, may be suspended if the seven-day moving average of local, untraceable cases in either city rises above five. The Hong Kong government is working closely with Singapore to gather facts and contain the outbreak, which has been described as "severe" by the city's Secretary for Food and Health.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to resume flights to San Francisco, Nagoya from Dec
summary: Singapore Airlines and SilkAir will resume flights to San Francisco and Nagoya between December 2020 and January 2021, with non-stop flights from Singapore to San Francisco International Airport starting on December 17. Jetstar Asia passengers from six South-east Asian cities will be able to transit through Changi Airport to nine onward destinations as long as their connection is within 48 hours. The reinstated flights aim to increase the SIA group's reach to about 19% of its pre-Covid-19 levels by the end of January 2021.

site_title: Board changes at Axington
summary: Axington, a Catalist-listed company, has seen changes to its board with 3 members after 1 resigned and 2 directors appointed. This comes after cousins Nelson Loh and Terence Loh became controlling shareholders earlier this year. The changes took effect on November 20, 2020.

images.alt_text: Axington Inc office in Fortune Centre. Axington Singapore is said to have rented a small space in the same unit as an unrelated accounting management consultancy there.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KrisEnergy's key subsidiary, KrisEnergy (Gulf of Thailand) (KEGOT), will face a court hearing on November 24 in the Cayman Islands regarding a winding-up petition. The court previously dismissed an appeal by KEGOT, and the appeal was also denied. Meanwhile, Singtel has named Anna Yip as deputy CEO of its Singapore consumer business, effective December 17. City Developments has appointed two new non-executive directors, Daniel Marie Ghislain Desbaillets and Chong Yoon Chou, to its board, effective November 20.

site_title: Olam to take 51% stake in Togo state-owned cotton firm for 15.3m euros
summary: Olam International has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Nouvelle Société Cotonnière du Togo (NSCT), Togo's state-owned cotton company, for 15.3 million euros. The deal will be funded by internal accruals and existing debt facilities. NSCT is responsible for all cotton-related activities in Togo, and Olam will complete the acquisition in December 2020, subject to customary closing conditions. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Olam's financials.

site_title: CIMB Singapore axes three business heads amid shake-up
summary: CIMB Singapore has axed three business heads, Josandi Thor (consumer banking), Yong Jiunn Run (commercial banking), and Lai Ven-Li (corporate banking), as part of a restructuring effort amid dismal results. The decision, made by CEO Victor Lee, aims to refocus on sustainable growth, streamline leadership, and drive cost efficiency. The bank will announce its new leadership team "shortly." The restructuring follows a review of the business model and direction, which was prompted by the severe impact of the pandemic on the economy.

images.alt_text: CIMB Singapore has dropped three long-time banking heads, as the lender restructures its business amid dismal results in the Republic.

site_title: Gold drifts lower as vaccine optimism, Asia-Pacific trade deal erode safe-haven appeal
summary: Gold prices dropped as vaccine optimism and a newly signed Asia-Pacific trade deal reduced its safe-haven appeal. The pandemic's uncertainty continued, with central bankers warning of ongoing spread and potential need for fiscal support. Despite this, a Covid-19 vaccine's delayed availability may provide some support. As interest rates remain low and the US dollar weakens, gold is expected to remain a favorite among investors in 2021. Gold futures ended the week at $1,850, with support at $1,850 and resistance at $1,980.

site_title: Sim Leisure's KidZania deal seeks shareholders' nod only after completion
summary: Sim Leisure, a Singapore-based theme park developer and operator, has proposed to acquire KidZania, a family attraction, for RM3.8 million (S$1.2 million). The acquisition must be ratified at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) within three months after completion, as the company is seeking a waiver from strict Catalist rules requiring prior shareholder approval. The deal is time-sensitive due to the target's circumstances, and Sim Leisure's substantial shareholders have irrevocably committed to voting in favor of the acquisition.

site_title: Keeping SMEs in business: How alternative lenders are plugging the financing gap, and are now put to the test
summary: Alternative lenders are helping plug the financing gap for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, with advancements in technology allowing for more efficient credit assessments. Goldbell Financial Services, Validus Capital, and Finaxar are three SME lenders that are adapting to the changing market, with Goldbell's Polaris initiative and Validus' partnerships with corporates enabling them to finance SMEs in various sectors. Despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, these lenders are maintaining a cautious approach and are confident that they can weather the storm. With the emergence of digital banks, the lenders see opportunities for collaboration, with some predicting that industry practices will be enhanced through data sharing and open banking.

site_title: Will big tech jump higher on Biden optimism?
summary: Tech stocks may continue to rise despite regulatory risks and US-China tensions, driven by long-term digitalization trends. The recent US presidential election has generated uncertainty, but Joe Biden's presidency is expected to be favorable for the market, aiding in a gradual economic recovery. China's "dual circulation" strategy is also expected to drive investments, with a focus on domestic innovation and technology development. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated global tech adoption, and companies with resilient balance sheets and stable businesses are favored.

site_title: Glow up for Christmas
summary: A radiant, youthful glow is considered the epitome of beauty in Asia, but can be achieved through specific clinic treatments and a healthy lifestyle. Causes of dull skin include a build-up of dead skin cells, poor blood circulation, and dehydration. Effective treatments include HydraFacial, which clears pores and hydrates the skin, and Quadrostar Pro Yellow Laser, which breaks down pigmentation and stimulates collagen. Additionally, Profhilo, a skin injectable treatment, delivers hyaluronic acid to hydrate and remodel the skin. Maintaining a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep, can also improve skin tone and radiance.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager questions internalisation proposal
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has questioned the claims made by fund managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital, who are advising unitholders to reject the proposed merger with ESR-Reit and internalise the Reit's management. The manager has asked the fund managers to substantiate their claims, stating that the proposed merger is the only offer on the table and that internalisation would require consent from banks. The Reit manager has also expressed skepticism over the fund managers' estimates, including a potential cost savings from internalisation and increased standalone DPU.

site_title: Factory output, export growth tipped to boost Q3 GDP
summary: Singapore's Q3 GDP is expected to contract 5.5% year-on-year, better than the initial 7% decline forecast, driven by a 24.2% surge in September's industrial production and better-than-expected services growth. Manufacturing remains positive, but its growth is expected to cool, while construction and services sectors continue to normalize. Analysts predict a gradual recovery, with Maybank Kim Eng projecting a 4% decline in Q4 and a full-year contraction of 5.7%.

site_title: On eve of G20, EU hopes for US return to multilateralism
summary: The European Union hopes US President-elect Joe Biden will adopt a more multilateral stance when taking office, reversing President Donald Trump's withdrawal from international agreements. EU President Ursula von der Leyen expressed optimism that the new administration will increase cooperation on climate change and engage in global health issues. The EU and Italy will co-host a global health summit next year, a topic the US has resisted so far. Biden's election has been welcomed by Europe, and von der Leyen expects new momentum on these issues.

site_title: Australia's Crown readies high-stakes casino tower yet pledges remain outstanding
summary: Crown Resorts, a major Australian casino operator, is set to launch its $1.6 billion Sydney casino tower in December, despite significant delays and doubts over its corporate governance. The company has failed to deliver on several promises made during the planning approval process, including a community college to train disadvantaged youths and a VIP ski resort perk. The regulator has suspended Crown's licence until February, citing evidence of money laundering, and analysts predict the company may run the tower as a luxury hotel and entertainment hub to recoup some of its investment.

site_title: Japan's JTB to lay off 6,500 as coronavirus batters travel
summary: Japan's JTB travel agency plans to cut its workforce by 6,500 members, reducing its staff to 22,500, due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on the travel industry. The agency will also close 115 outlets and freeze new graduate hires, and slash personnel costs by 30% annually. This move is part of a broader trend of travel agencies being severely affected by the pandemic, with Japan seeing a recent resurgence of infections and new cases reaching 2,027 on Friday.

site_title: Connecting Cloud to Asean
summary: Alibaba Cloud's Lancelot Guo sees a "no regrets" decision in adopting cloud technology amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Established in 2009, Alibaba Cloud provides cloud computing services worldwide, including startups, corporations, and public services. Guo aims to nurture tech talent in South-east Asia, particularly in the Philippines, and has announced plans to train 50,000 IT workers and assist 5,000 businesses with digital migration. Alibaba Cloud sees a blue ocean opportunity in South-east Asia, with Indonesia's Garuda Indonesia adopting its systems for greater efficiency. The company is also developing the local tech ecosystem in Singapore, partnering with universities and launching cloud and tech courses.

site_title: Mizuho to cut Singapore office space on work-from-home success: sources
summary: Mizuho Financial Group plans to trim its Singapore office space by 16% or less than one floor at Asia Square Tower 2, amid the pandemic's impact on flexible work arrangements. The bank is also reviewing its use of its backup office at Changi Business Park. This move follows similar plans in New York and London, where Mizuho has determined that employees can remain productive while working from home. The bank aims to redesign its Singapore office with a more open, communal space, while implementing safe management measures to avoid crowding.

site_title: Reits (Nov 21-22, 2020)
summary: Reits (Nov 21-22, 2020) reported mixed trends. S-Reits saw a rebound in demand, while US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Global markets also saw record Manhattan rents and increased homebuyer demand in the UK. Meanwhile, New World sold China property assets after a loan deal, and WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy space. These developments indicate shifting market trends in the real estate sector.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain for third straight week on vaccine cheer
summary: South Korean shares rose for a third straight week, driven by optimism over potential Covid-19 vaccine breakthroughs. The Kospi index gained 2.4% for the week, closing at 2,553.50. US officials said vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna could be ready for US authorization within weeks, bolstering hopes for a pandemic-induced economic recovery.

site_title: Making the most of the coming Biden boom
summary: The US is poised for a potential economic boom under President-elect Joe Biden, driven by the expected control of the COVID-19 pandemic and a subsequent surge in spending. Despite pessimistic forecasts from many economists, the author believes that households' lower debt and pent-up demand will lead to a faster recovery, similar to the 1982-1984 post-Reagan boom. Biden should capitalize on this good news, celebrate it, and call out Republican efforts to sabotage the economy. However, he should also prioritize long-term investments to rebuild infrastructure and address pressing issues like climate change.

site_title: Unfreezing the Everest economy
summary: Nepal has lifted its seven-month travel ban for Mount Everest climbers, but the country is unlikely to meet its ambitious target of 2 million visitors for 2020. International arrivals totalled just 180,131 through October, down from 795,199 in the same period last year. The Everest economy, which supports over 1 million jobs and generates $300 million annually, is struggling due to the pandemic. Many Sherpas, who rely heavily on tourism, have barely had income this year, with some resorting to fundraising campaigns to support their communities.

site_title: SGX opens public consultation on default management process
summary: SGX is seeking public feedback on its proposed default management process for clearing members. The process would involve liquidating a member's outstanding trades in the event of default. The public consultation, which runs until Dec 21, aims to gather market views on the proposed process. SGX's current method is to suspend the defaulting member's trading privileges, but the new process would provide more clarity on how to manage outstanding transactions. The move aims to improve market stability and efficiency.

site_title: China's crucial role in the pursuit of global net zero emissions
summary: China, the world's top GHG emitter, has pledged to reach net zero emissions by 2060, a significant step towards the 2015 Paris Agreement's temperature goals. The announcement, made by President Xi Jinping, will require massive effort and investments to achieve. China's coal power sector, the single largest GHG emitter annually, must undergo significant energy transition challenges. The green bond market is expected to grow, with China's removal of "clean utilisation of coal" from its green bond projects likely to further rally investors. However, financing for the net zero transition is still scarce, with estimates suggesting $2.8 trillion in investments needed by 2027.

site_title: Pfizer to submit US emergency use application for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Pfizer plans to submit a US emergency use application for its Covid-19 vaccine, which showed a 95% effectiveness rate in preventing the disease in a Phase 3 trial. The application comes after final trial results were released, with no major safety concerns. The FDA is expected to grant the emergency use authorization by mid-December, with Pfizer expecting to begin shipping doses immediately. The vaccine's efficacy was found to be similar across different ages and ethnicities, providing hope for an end to the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia to lift movement controls in some states
summary: Malaysia is lifting movement controls in states of Melaka, Terengganu, and most of Johor and Kedah starting Nov 21, according to Defence Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob. Domestic tourism is now allowed within states under the conditional movement control order (CMCO). However, movement curbs will remain in Kelantan, and tighter controls will be imposed in Penampang, Sabah. Foreign workers in certain states are also required to take swab tests.

site_title: Germany's latest football prodigy set to make history
summary: Youssoufa Moukoko, 16, is set to make history as he makes his debut for Borussia Dortmund's first team this weekend, potentially becoming the youngest debutant in the history of Germany's top football league. Born in Cameroon, Moukoko has already broken goal records in German youth football and has been touted as a prodigy by Germany's national coach Joachim Loew. He has already scored 47 goals in 25 matches for Dortmund's under-19 side and is expected to earn up to €3 million per season.

images.alt_text: Moukoko has already trained with Dortmund's first team on the back of his goalscoring feats for the youth team.
Germany national coach Joachim Loew says: "Youssoufa Moukoko has a talent that you don't come across that often."

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs imposed by the US on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2, similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing the current CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks rose in a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Trump and Xi join virtual Asia Pacific summit as trade spat endures
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping participated in a virtual Asia Pacific summit, discussing the coronavirus crisis and global economic recovery. Despite lingering trade differences, the leaders called for more open and multilateral trade to support economic recovery. Asia-Pacific leaders warned against protectionist trade policies, with Xi emphasizing unilateralism as a global economic risk. The summit, hosted by Malaysia, comes two weeks after Trump's re-election loss, highlighting the ongoing trade spat between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore tightens border measures for travellers from Malaysia and Japan
summary: Singapore has tightened border measures for travellers from Malaysia and Japan, requiring a 14-day stay-home notice for those with a travel history in the past 14 days to either country. This rule applies to travellers entering Singapore under various arrangements, including work and return schemes. The measure aims to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: Airbus Singapore's S$38m campus opens in Seletar
summary: Airbus Singapore has officially opened its S$38 million campus in Seletar, nearly a year behind schedule due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The 51,000 square meter facility will serve as the company's regional hub for Airbus' commercial aircraft, defence, space, and helicopter businesses in the region. The campus features a three-storey office building, a warehouse, and a branch of Airbus' global leadership university. The move is seen as a statement of confidence in Singapore, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing noting that the campus will help Airbus recover from the pandemic's devastating impact on the global aviation industry.

site_title: WHO says no to remdesivir for coronavirus treatment
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has concluded that the anti-viral drug remdesivir has "no important effect" on survival chances for Covid-19 patients, regardless of the severity of their illness. The WHO's Guideline Development Group stated that there is no evidence to support its use in treating severe cases, contrary to initial research that suggested it may shorten recovery time. The US and European Union have granted temporary approval for remdesivir use, but the WHO's guidance reverses hopes in this treatment option.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open on concerns over fading stimulus
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Friday due to concerns over fading stimulus and the impact of increasing coronavirus infections on the US economy. The Dow Jones fell 0.15%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.07%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.10%. These losses followed a previous day's gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.07 points to 1,593.75 on Friday, driven by a gain of 690 to 504 gainers-to-losers ratio. The market closed with 9.008 billion lots worth RM5.156 billion.

site_title: Vodafone Idea sells Indus Towers stake for US$506m
summary: Vodafone Idea sold its 11.15% stake in Indus Towers for US$506 million, part of efforts to shore up its finances. The sale, which includes a debt of 24 billion rupees (S$434.8 million), will leave Vodafone Idea with 28.1% ownership. The move aims to raise cash for the debt-strapped carrier, which has been struggling financially and hasn't reported an annual profit since 2017.

images.alt_text: Vodafone Idea, the debt-strapped Indian wireless carrier, sold its stake in a telecommunications tower firm for US$506 million, as part of efforts to shore up its strained finances.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the week on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.36% to 26,451.54, and the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increasing. Optimism over a vaccine was tempered by concerns about the global coronavirus surge. The gains were attributed to positive market sentiment despite uncertainty over the US-China trade situation.

site_title: Two new independent directors replace resigning director on Axington's board
summary: Axington's board has undergone significant changes following the resignation of two independent directors. The two new independent directors, Teo Choon Kow and Ang Chiang Meng, have been appointed, bringing the total board membership to three. Roberto Dona, an independent director, has been re-designated as non-executive chairman and will join the remuneration committee. The changes aim to facilitate board renewal and focus on primary work commitments. The three board members will now be part of the remuneration, nominating, and audit committees.

site_title: Revolut Singapore loses heavyweight compliance chief
summary: Revolut Singapore has lost its heavyweight compliance chief, Rayson Tan, who left the firm in October after just over a year of service. Tan, a former Credit Suisse banker, was one of Revolut's most senior hires, joining in 2019. He has since joined Pictet Group as its new chief risk officer for Asia. A Revolut spokesperson said Tan's departure was to "pursue other opportunities" and that the firm wishes him success in his new role. Tan's duties are being shared by senior counsel Shulin Tay and head of risk and compliance Celestia Tan.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by gains in retail, oil stocks
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by gains in retail and oil shares, despite US politics and stimulus uncertainty. The STOXX 600 index reached February highs due to Covid-19 vaccine progress. Retail sales in the UK bounced in October, supporting the FTSE 100, while Italy's BPER Banca rose 3.1% after a merger proposal. Despite global mood remaining subdued, sectoral gains from oil, travel, and leisure stocks offset concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong virus cases surge again, threatening travel bubble with Singapore
summary: Hong Kong reported 26 new Covid-19 cases, including 21 local cases, with 9 cases untraced. This surge threatens the upcoming travel bubble with Singapore, set to launch days later. The high-profile bubble was expected to boost tourism and trade between the two cities. The sudden increase in cases raises concerns about the safety of travel and may force the Singaporean government to reconsider the launch of the bubble.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's CIMB bank fired three business heads amid a shake-up. Grab will add a platform fee after Singapore's competition watchdog lifted restrictions. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is investigating allegations that Muslim Pro sold user data to the US military. IBM plans to hire 300 Singaporean professionals in emerging tech. Singtel appointed Anna Yip as deputy CEO of its Singapore consumer business. Olam acquired a 51% stake in a Togo state-owned cotton firm for $24.4 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes lower ahead of long weekend
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed 0.42% lower at 25,527.37 on Friday, amidst concerns over rising coronavirus cases. The broader Topix index inched up 0.06%. The decline occurred ahead of a long weekend, with investors cautious about the impact of the weekend on market sentiment.

site_title: IBM to hire, train 300 Singaporeans in emerging tech
summary: IBM will hire and train 300 Singaporean professionals in emerging tech areas over the next four years, including digital consultants, big-data engineers, and full-stack digital developers. The initiative is under a memorandum of intent signed by IBM and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA). The move aims to enhance the country's tech capabilities and competitiveness. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran witnessed the signing.

site_title: Ex-CEO of Hong Kong telco to become deputy CEO of Singtel's Singapore consumer business
summary: Singtel has appointed Anna Yip, former executive director and CEO of Hong Kong telco Smartone Telecommunications, as deputy CEO of its Singapore consumer business, effective December 17.
