Yip will oversee Singtel's consumer business as 5G goes mainstream, leveraging her experience in financial services and management consulting. She will report to the Singapore consumer business' CEO and Group CEO-designate Yuen Kuan Moon, aiming to drive digital innovation and superior customer service.

site_title: Global economy is at a make-or-break moment, warns G-20 veteran
summary: The global economy is at a critical juncture, with governments nearing their fiscal limits to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, warns OECD chief Angel Gurria. Without greater coordination, the next stage of crisis could lead to a fragmented global economy, widening gaps between rich and cash-strapped nations. The warning comes as world leaders gather for a G-20 meeting, amid concerns the pandemic-induced recession recovery could be derailed.

site_title: Amazon bows to French pressure to push back Black Friday sales
summary: Amazon has agreed to postpone its Black Friday sales in France until after the country's nationwide lockdown, following pressure from Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire. The decision aims to level the playing field for local shopkeepers struggling to compete with online retailers. Black Friday sales in France will now take place from November 30 to December 2, allowing shops selling non-essential goods to reopen during the lockdown. This move is seen as a compromise between Amazon's global sales growth and the need to support French retailers.

site_title: Gold dips as US Treasury Secretary recalls pandemic-related funds
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called for an end to some pandemic-related funds, sparking uncertainty about stimulus programs. Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,864.54 per ounce, heading for a second week of decline. The comments weighed on equities and helped the US dollar halt its slide. Gold has gained 23% this year due to stimulus measures, but promising vaccine trials may dim its appeal. Analysts predict gold could reach $1,900 by year-end.

site_title: Aviva Singlife sees hot demand for S$550m notes as orders exceed S$3.5b
summary: Aviva Singlife Holdings (ASH) has seen a strong demand for its S$550 million, 10.25-year unsecured notes, with orders exceeding S$3.5 billion across 143 accounts. The notes, priced at 3.375%, are the first bridge-to-bond transaction denominated in Singapore dollars and the first acquisition funding for a Tier-2 issuance in the SGD market. The deal is expected to finance the merger of Aviva Ltd's Singapore operations with Singlife, with the merger anticipated to be completed by January 2021.

site_title: Singapore Manual & Mercantile Workers' Union assisting Robinsons staff in liquidation process
summary: The Singapore Manual & Mercantile Workers' Union (SMMWU) is assisting Robinsons staff in the liquidation process following the closure of the Singapore branch. SMMWU's secretary-general David Yeo stated that the union is prioritizing worker interests, providing assistance with claims and filing outstanding debts. The union is also partnering the Employment and Employability Institute to offer training and job-matching support to retrenched workers. Payments to employees are capped at S$13,000, with claims in excess to be separately assessed by the liquidator.

site_title: IBM to hire and train 300 Singaporean professionals in emerging tech
summary: IBM has signed a memorandum of intent to hire and train 300 Singaporean professionals in emerging tech areas over the next four years. The roles include digital consultants, big-data engineers, and UX designers. The program, called Future-Ready Intelligent Digital Workforce Programme, aims to meet the demand for technology consulting and deep technical skills. The training will be provided under the TechSkills Accelerator Company-Led Training programme, and mid-career professionals will also be supported. The move is in support of the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package.

site_title: China maintains ban on Boeing 737 MAX flights
summary: China's aviation regulator, the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC), has ruled that Boeing's 737 MAX jet will not resume flights in the country due to lingering safety concerns. The decision comes despite the US lifting a ban on commercial flights, and China was the first to suspend flights of the aircraft following two fatal crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. The CAAC requires clear results from investigations and effective design improvements before allowing flights to resume, with no set timetable for resumption.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas steps ups investments in hydrogen as part of carbon-free energy goals
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas plans to step up investments in hydrogen as part of its goal to produce carbon-free energy by 2050. The company aims to manage supply chain and logistics challenges through partnerships and memoranda of understanding. Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry has also formulated its hydrogen strategy, with the goal of making hydrogen a key player in achieving carbon neutrality. The push towards hydrogen comes as energy companies increase investments in renewables and low-carbon alternatives amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: HSBC veteran hired to head Singapore operations of China's CreditEase
summary: HSBC veteran Kenneth Yeo has joined Chinese fintech CreditEase as CEO of its Singapore wealth management arm. Yeo aims to develop CreditEase's wealth business globally, leveraging its parent company's technical advantages in Big Data and AI. He replaces Jeffrey Yap, who moved from his previous role at HSBC. Yeo's appointment comes as CreditEase seeks to become the top Chinese-based wealth management brand for ultra-high net worth individuals and family offices worldwide.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street to gain 1.3%, sealing 3.7% gain over the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.3% to 2,813.01 on Friday, driven by a US tech stocks rebound. About 2.78 billion shares changed hands, with Jardine Matheson being the largest gainer, adding 4.8% to US$53.68. The week's gain now stands at 3.7%.

site_title: Four new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported for the 10th day
summary: Singapore reported four new COVID-19 cases, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices. The cases bring the total to 58,143, with 57 active cases and 58,043 recoveries. No new community cases were reported for the 10th day in a row. The cluster at Blue Stars Dormitory in the Upper Jurong area has been closed, with no new cases linked to it for 28 days. One patient is in critical condition in the intensive care unit, and six cases were discharged on Friday.

site_title: CDL appoints two non-executive, independent directors
summary: City Developments (CDL) has appointed two new non-executive, independent directors, Daniel Marie Ghislain Desbaillets and Chong Yoon Chou, effective November 20, 2020. Desbaillets, 70, has a background in hospitality, holding senior positions in international hotel chains. Chong Yoon Chou brings experience in asset and fund management. The appointments aim to enhance CDL's board composition.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager disputes fund managers' internalisation proposal
summary: Sabana Reit's manager disputes fund managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital's proposal to internalize the Reit's management, calling their claims "unrealistic" and "highly uncertain". The Reit manager has asked the fund managers to provide more details on their proposal, which would require consent from banks to avoid defaulting on existing obligations. An extraordinary general meeting on the proposed merger is set for December 4, with unitholder voting already underway.

site_title: Lawyer Lee Suet Fern suspended from practising law
summary: Senior lawyer Lee Suet Fern has been suspended for 15 months by the Court of Three Judges in Singapore for her handling of the last will of her late father-in-law Lee Kuan Yew, which benefited her husband Lee Hsien Yang. The court found her guilty of misconduct unbefitting an advocate and solicitor, disagreeing with some of the disciplinary tribunal's findings, particularly regarding an implied retainer and solicitor-client relationship. The decision was made after a virtual hearing in August, where the Law Society argued that Mrs. Lee had misled her father-in-law into signing a new will without his usual lawyer's advice.

site_title: Singapore's PDPC investigating allegations that Muslim Pro sold user data to US military
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) is investigating Bitsmedia, the developer of the Muslim Pro app, after allegations that the company sold user data to the US military. The data allegedly included location details, names of WiFi networks, and timestamps, and was sold to a US-based data broker, X-mode, which has customers including US military defence contractors. Bitsmedia has denied the allegations and launched an internal investigation, but has terminated its relationships with data partners, including X-mode. The PDPC is requesting more detailed information from Bitsmedia.

site_title: Seadrill sees depressed drilling rig demand until late 2021
summary: Seadrill, an offshore oil drilling contractor, expects depressed drilling rig demand until late 2021, citing significantly lower activity levels compared to 2019. The company, controlled by Norwegian-born billionaire John Fredriksen, is engaged in debt restructuring talks with creditors and has $851 million in cash and cash equivalents. Seadrill plans to scrap idle rigs pending creditor approval, and believes the depressed market will persist throughout 2020 and into 2021. The company's $7.3 billion liabilities remain unchanged.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap four-day rally as virus outbreaks weigh
summary: Australian shares snapped a four-day winning streak, closing 0.12% lower at 6,539.2 points, due to losses in the gold sector outweighing gains in financials. The resurgence of the virus globally, with major cities reporting outbreaks and shutdowns, dampened prospects of a broader reopening. The S&P/ASX 200 index added 2.1% for the week. Authorities in South Australia relaxed restrictions earlier than planned after a "lie" triggered the six-day lockdown. The central bank raised concerns over trading systems, while vaccine optimism kept demand for gold muted.

site_title: Temasek launches vehicle to super-charge agriculture, food deals
summary: Temasek International is launching a new platform to accelerate and manage agricultural and food investments, as part of a multibillion-dollar push into the market. The platform aims to help agri-food portfolio companies build operational capabilities and manufacturing scale. Temasek has invested over $5 billion in the agri-food industry in the past five years, backing companies like Impossible Foods and Bayer. The platform's goal is to support the growth of local food production, with Singapore aiming to source 30% of its food requirements from local sources by 2030.

site_title: Olam to acquire 51% stake in Togo state-owned cotton firm for 15.3m euros
summary: Olam International has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Togo's state-owned cotton firm, Nouvelle Société Cotonnière du Togo (NSCT), for 15.3 million euros. The deal is expected to be completed in December 2020, subject to customary closing conditions. Olam will fund the acquisition through internal accruals and existing debt facilities, and the transaction is not expected to have a material impact on its financials. The Togolese Republic and the national cotton farmers cooperative will hold 24% and 25% of the joint venture, respectively.

site_title: Indonesia posts first current account surplus since 2011 in Q3
summary: Indonesia recorded its first current account surplus since 2011 in Q3, driven by suppressed imports due to pandemic curbs. The 0.4% surplus was $1 billion, following a 1.2% deficit in the previous quarters. The capital and financial accounts also posted a $2.1 billion surplus, bringing the balance of payments to $2.1 billion. This marks a significant improvement in the country's economic performance.

site_title: Thailand's central bank announces measures to contain baht rise
summary: Thailand's central bank has introduced measures to contain the rapid appreciation of the baht, citing concerns it undermines the country's fragile economic recovery. The new rules allow Thais to freely hold and transfer foreign currency deposits and directly invest in overseas securities. The baht traded at 30.31 per US dollar, a 10-month high. The central bank aims to balance capital flows and support economic growth, following Governor Chatchai Surin's warning that the baht's rise is too fast.

site_title: Sim Leisure's KidZania deal needs shareholder ratification after completion
summary: Sim Leisure will seek shareholder ratification after completing its acquisition of loss-making KidZania operator Rakan Riang, rather than prior approval. The company was granted a waiver by the Singapore Exchange due to the transaction's time-sensitive nature. The acquisition is valued at RM3.8 million (S$1.2 million) and has been backed by substantial shareholders with a 79.9% stake, who have committed to voting in favor of the deal. The transaction must be ratified at an extraordinary general meeting within three months.

site_title: Bharti Infratel, Indus Towers complete merger: Singtel
summary: Singtel announced that the merger between Indus Towers and Bharti Infratel, a subsidiary of Bharti Airtel, has been completed. The combined entity, Indus Towers Limited, is listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and BSE. The merger creates a US$14.6 billion telecom tower giant with over 163,000 structures. As a result of the merger, Bharti Airtel's shareholding in the combined entity will decrease to 36.73% from 53.51%.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices fall at fastest pace in decade, reviving deflation fears
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.7% in October, the fastest annual pace in nearly a decade, sparking deflation fears. This decline is attributed to sluggish consumption, a high base effect from last year's sales tax hike, and energy costs. Analysts predict further annual declines, potentially stoking fears of deflation and prompting households to delay spending. The COVID-19 resurgence also clouds the economic outlook, threatening Japan's fragile recovery and the government's stimulus measures.

site_title: Jetstar Asia to resume South-east Asia transit flights via Singapore from Dec 1
summary: Jetstar Asia will resume South-east Asia transit flights via Singapore's Changi Airport starting December 1. Passengers from six cities (Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Penang, and Phnom Penh) can transit to nine destinations with a connection within 48 hours. Passengers must book the full journey and check entry requirements for their final destination. Measures include wristbands, seating at the front of the plane, and airport staff guidance to a transit area. The move aims to support essential travel and boost local economies.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise but virus surge darkens mood
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Friday, but traders were cautious due to surging COVID-19 cases and the uncertainty of a US stimulus package. Long-term optimism over a vaccine and the election of Joe Biden have fueled a rally in global equities, but the recent surge in cases has raised concerns about the economic impact. The US Treasury and Federal Reserve are at odds over extending lending measures, and Tokyo has raised its virus alert to the highest level.

site_title: Grab to add platform fee after Singapore competition watchdog drops restrictions
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing operator, will add a platform fee of about S$0.30 to its services in Singapore after the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) lifted restrictions imposed on the firm. The fee will be used to cover operating costs and support drivers through welfare benefits. Grab's managing director, Andrew Chan, stated that the introduction of the platform fee will be the only change to fares for at least six months.

images.alt_text: Grab will add a platform fee of about S$0.30 to its ride hailing in the next few months.

site_title: Japan aims to expand CPTPP trade pact as UK, China eye membership
summary: Japan aims to expand the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade pact, potentially catering to China's and Britain's interest in joining. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said Japan will strive to conclude the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and expand CPTPP as the Asia-Pacific region's free trade area. China has expressed interest in joining the CPTPP, while Britain has announced its intent to pursue accession. This move could strengthen Japan's position in the Asia-Pacific region and address its economic concerns.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to resume flights to San Francisco, Nagoya from December 2020
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir will resume flights to San Francisco and Nagoya starting December 17, 2020, and January 2021, respectively. The reinstated flights aim to reach about 19% of pre-Covid-19 levels by the end of January. SIA and SilkAir will also increase frequencies on selected services, while Scoot's services to Kuala Lumpur, Manila, and Perth will be temporarily suspended. These changes are subject to regulatory approval and are part of a review to meet evolving customer and cargo demand.

site_title: Revolut Singapore loses heavyweight compliance chief
summary: Revolut Singapore has lost its heavyweight compliance chief, Rayson Tan, who left the firm in October after a year of service. Tan, a former Credit Suisse banker, held multiple senior roles at Revolut, including chief compliance officer, chief risk officer, and head of legal. He has since joined Pictet Group as its new chief risk officer for Asia. The firm is sharing his duties with senior counsel Shulin Tay and head of risk and compliance Celestia Tan in the interim.

site_title: BuzzFeed to acquire HuffPost from Verizon Media
summary: BuzzFeed is set to acquire HuffPost from Verizon Media in a deal that will see the two digital media outlets remain distinct, with BuzzFeed founder Jonah Peretti serving as CEO. The acquisition is aimed at bolstering BuzzFeed's operations, which have struggled with declining revenue. As part of the deal, Verizon Media will become a minority shareholder in BuzzFeed, but will not have a seat on the company's board. The merger is seen as a bid to tap into the strength and creativity of Verizon Media Immersive, with the two outlets complementing each other's editorial and consumer audiences.

site_title: DBS seeks to wind up Novena Global Healthcare founded by Loh cousins
summary: DBS Bank has filed a winding-up application with the Singapore High Court to dissolve Novena Global Healthcare Pte Ltd (NGHPL), a subsidiary of the Cayman Islands-incorporated Novena Global Healthcare Group (NGHG), co-founded by Singaporean cousins Terence and Nelson Loh. NGHPL is believed to have owed DBS millions of dollars, following Ernst & Young's allegations of forged audit signatures on NGHG's financial statements. DBS has appointed RSM as joint and several liquidators, while Terence Loh claims he will continue to engage with RSM to recover value for stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Terence Loh said RSM was recently appointed as special accountant for NGHG.

site_title: BTS releasing new album after historic success of 'Dynamite'
summary: K-pop sensation BTS is releasing their new studio album "BE" after historic success with their all-English single "Dynamite", which became the first South Korean act to top the US singles chart. The eight-track record, set for a simultaneous worldwide release, is the group's fifth Korean-language studio album and contains their most "BTS-esque" music yet. The album aims to deliver a "message of healing" amidst the Covid-19 pandemic, with tracks like "Life Goes On" and "Dynamite" scheduled to perform at the 2020 American Music Awards.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.36 points, or 0.02%, to 1,584.04 on Friday. The index had 700.21 million lots traded, worth RM252.98 million. Gainers outpaced losers 304 to 170.

site_title: CIMB Singapore axes three business heads amid shake-up in bank
summary: CIMB Singapore has announced the departure of three long-time business heads, Josandi Thor, Yong Jiunn Run, and Lai Ven-Li, amid a restructuring effort following dismal results in the Republic. The decision, made by CEO Victor Lee, aims to focus on sustainable growth by reshaping business portfolios, driving cost efficiency, and streamlining the leadership structure. The bank had conducted a "detailed analysis" of its business and will announce its new Singapore leadership team "shortly." The trio's departures mark a significant shake-up in the bank's senior management team.

site_title: Winding-up petition against KrisEnergy unit to be heard next week
summary: A winding-up petition against KrisEnergy's subsidiary, KrisEnergy (Gulf of Thailand) (KEGOT), will be heard in the Cayman Islands on Nov 24. The petition was filed by Rubicon Vantage International, which claims damages related to a 2014 bareboat charterparty. The Court of Appeal dismissed KEGOT's appeal to restrain the petition, with costs awarded to Rubicon. KrisEnergy is seeking legal advice on the next steps. The company's shares have been suspended since August last year, and it faces a scheme meeting to vote on its proposed restructuring plan in January.

site_title: Trump's daughter-in-law considering Senate run, says US media
summary: US President Donald Trump's daughter-in-law, Lara, is considering a Senate run in North Carolina in 2022, according to reports by the New York Times and Politico. Lara Trump, married to Eric Trump, has told associates she is considering a run, potentially joining a crowded Republican field that includes Mark Meadows, Pat McCrory, and Dan Forest. North Carolina is historically Republican but voted for Trump by a smaller margin than in 2016, making it a possible swing state.

images.alt_text: Lara Trump, married to the president's second-eldest son Eric, "has been telling associates she is considering a run for Senate in 2022," the New York Times said, citing three unnamed "allies."

site_title: Coronavirus measures hit London black cab business
summary: London's iconic black cabs are facing an unprecedented crisis due to the coronavirus lockdown, with many drivers unable to pay for their vehicles, resulting in thousands of cabs being parked in fields. The crisis has led to a significant decline in the number of licensed black cabs, from 19,000 to 15,000, and has left drivers struggling to make ends meet, with some earning only 20% of their usual income. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association is calling for financial support from the government to help the industry recover.

site_title: Cyclical stocks to lead earnings recovery when vaccines roll out
summary: Analysts expect cyclical stocks to lead earnings recovery once vaccines roll out globally, with Singapore's valuations poised to narrow the gap with regional and global peers in 2021. UBS forecasts a 7-7.5% gross domestic growth for Asia ex-Japan in 2021, driven by a cyclical rebound. Cyclical companies such as UOB, City Developments, and Thai Beverage are favored by Morgan Stanley, while a more cautious approach is taken towards travel-related names like Genting Singapore.

site_title: Level up the drinking game
summary: Singapore's festive season is seeing a surge in spending on premium wines, with consumers opting for fewer but higher-quality bottles. The annual Cold Storage International Wine Fair is a key driver of this trend, with customers seeking savings on iconic wines from regions like the New World and Old World. Everyday drinking wines, such as Sauvignon Blancs and rosé, are also in high demand. Prosecco and champagne are among the top-selling categories, with prices starting from S$13 and reaching up to S$100 for award-winning wines.

site_title: Hershey is behind the big cocoa trade that upended New York markets
summary: Hershey Co has made a significant move in the New York cocoa market, directly sourcing a large amount of cocoa through the ICE Futures US exchange to obtain cheaper supplies. The massive trade, valued over 30,000 tonnes, has sent December-delivery futures to a record premium over the next contract. Hershey purchases cocoa from a variety of suppliers and sources, supporting initiatives to improve farmer livelihoods in Ghana and Ivory Coast, and paying a $400-a-tonne premium to support their income.

images.alt_text: One of America's top chocolate makers is upending the New York cocoa market.

site_title: Judges rule against Trump and allies in three US election lawsuits
summary: US President Donald Trump and his allies lost three court rulings on their efforts to stop President-elect Joe Biden from taking office. A judge in Georgia denied a request to halt certification of Biden's victory, citing lack of basis in fact and law. A similar ruling was made in Pennsylvania, rejecting the Trump campaign's bid to invalidate ballots due to alleged defects. In Arizona, a state court judge tossed a Republican-backed lawsuit seeking to halt certification of Biden's win. These losses underscore Trump's dwindling options as he continues to claim a viable path to victory.

site_title: Vietnam threatens to shut down Facebook over censorship requests: source
summary: Vietnam has threatened to shut down Facebook if the company does not comply with its demands to censor more local political content. Facebook has already restricted access to 834 items in Vietnam, following government requests, but the country's government has asked for more censorship. Facebook has refused to increase restrictions, with a senior official stating that shutting down the platform in Vietnam is a possible consequence. The threat comes as Facebook faces mounting pressure from governments worldwide, with the company earning nearly $1 billion in revenue from its Vietnam operations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East Orchard, Straits Trading, Koufu, DBS, Singtel
summary: Far East Orchard and Straits Trading saw developments on Friday, with Far East Hospitality expanding its markets and Straits Trading gaining due to its joint venture. Koufu Group expects lower operating profits for the second half of 2020, while DBS shares fell despite a proposed takeover of Lakshmi Vilas Bank. DBS also applied to wind up scandal-hit Novena Global Healthcare. Singtel's Indian associate completed a merger, and shares rose. Bukit Sembawang Estates' CEO tendered his resignation, while City Developments Limited responded to a commentary on its leadership change.

site_title: Santa, barred from malls and chimneys, enters homes via interactive video
summary: Technology company Storyfile has created an interactive website, AskSanta.com, where children can video chat with Santa Claus via artificial intelligence, bypassing mall visits and chimney entries. The website, launched in response to the pandemic, has received positive reactions from children who believe they are having a real video call with Santa. The AI database can handle over 180 questions, including the most popular query, "Am I on the naughty or nice list?" The technology company plans to expand Santa's skills to read out children's letters next year if the app is well-received.

images.alt_text: Santa cannot sit with children in shopping malls this year, but they can still tell him their Christmas wish list in a video chat at home.

site_title: Hot stock: SPH climbs 10.5% on heavy volume, hits four-month high
summary: Shares of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) surged 10.5% on Friday, hitting a four-month high, amid rumors of corporate restructuring. The stock gained 17.1% on a cum-dividend basis, with 69.5 million shares changing hands. The Singapore Exchange queried SPH about the unusual price and volume movements, and the company replied that it regularly evaluates opportunities to enhance shareholder value. Brokerage UOB Kay Hian predicted the stock could break through resistance levels, with a potential upside target of S$1.17.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 2,788.83 on Friday, reversing Thursday's decline. The index was driven by gains from local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, as well as Jiutian Chemical, Genting Singapore, and Singapore Press Holdings. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively, amid optimism over revived US stimulus talks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Friday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.19% to 26,406.87, following a positive lead from Wall Street. However, gains were tempered by concerns over surging virus infections. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat.

site_title: Australia's Crown readies high-stakes casino tower yet pledges remain outstanding
summary: Crown Resorts, a major Australian casino operator, is set to launch its $1.6 billion Sydney casino tower in December, despite remaining pledges to deliver on promises made seven years ago. These promises include a community college for disadvantaged youths, a VIP ski resort experience, and a $1.4 billion tax contribution. However, several of these promises have been delayed or voided due to changes in the market, including a Chinese anti-gambling campaign and the sale of the ski resort. The regulator has suspended Crown's license until February, citing money laundering concerns, and analysts warn that the company's future is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Pledges Crown Resorts made to win approval for a US$1.6 billion casino tower are far from materialising on the eve of its launch, highlighting its shaky position as a regulator decides if it can run the business on which it has bet its future.

site_title: Travel recovery on the horizon: DBS
summary: DBS analysts predict the recovery of Asean airports from lockdowns, with airport throughputs recovering at a gradual pace. Positive vaccine news from Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna brings forward the recovery of air travel, potentially reaching pre-COVID levels earlier than forecast. Countries with low daily COVID-19 cases, such as Australia, New Zealand, Vietnam, Singapore, and Hong Kong, are considered potential candidates for travel bubbles, particularly if air travel between Singapore and Hong Kong is successful.

site_title: Global tax evasion costs US$427b per year: NGO
summary: Tax evasion worldwide costs an estimated US$427 billion annually, according to the Tax Justice Network. This figure is based on records from multinationals and individuals, with US$245 billion committed by businesses and US$182 billion by individuals. The study found that the Cayman Islands, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, and low-tax US states are among the leading tax havens responsible for the greatest global tax loss. The network urges global action to combat shadowy tax havens and reprogram the global tax system to prioritize people's health and livelihoods over corporate interests.

site_title: Switch to electric vehicles could 'end oil era': analysis
summary: A switch to electric vehicles in emerging markets could save $250 billion annually and reduce global oil demand by 70% by 2030, according to industry analysis. China and India, major adopters of EVs, are expected to reduce their reliance on imported oil, with EVs forecasted to become cheaper to produce and run than fossil-fuel vehicles. This shift could fund itself as component costs fall and governments abandon fossil fuel infrastructure, potentially ending the "oil era."

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares edge lower on rising US virus cases, lockdowns woes
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 6,538.30 on Friday, driven by rising US virus cases and lockdown worries, despite a report of potential US economic stimulus talks. Asian markets await stimulus details, putting pressure on major trading partners. Energy and financial sub-indexes fell 0.5% each, while mining stocks also pulled back. Regis Healthcare jumped 23% on a buyout offer, while Mesoblast rose 21% on a collaboration deal with Novartis. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.5% to 12,497.56.

site_title: Canada government seeks carbon neutrality by 2050
summary: Canada's government has submitted draft legislation aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stating it's "ambitious, but it's possible, it's necessary, and it's exactly what we're going to do." However, his opponents have dismissed the initiative as "smoke and mirrors." The plan is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to reach this target.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ease from recent peak on global virus worries
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Thursday, easing from an eight-month high, as investors worried about another round of shutdowns due to rising coronavirus cases globally. Growth-linked cyclical stocks, including miners, travel, and oil and gas, led losses, shedding almost 2%. The decline followed positive Covid-19 vaccine data in November.

site_title: Biden denounces 'irresponsible' Trump fight to reverse election
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden denounced Donald Trump's efforts to reverse the election, calling Trump's actions "irresponsible" and labeling him "one of the most irresponsible presidents in American history." Trump continues to push baseless claims of widespread fraud despite Biden's significant margin of victory and the Electoral College votes. Trump's strategy has shifted to asking states to overrule the will of voters, including a reported call to a Michigan official to withdraw certification of the election result. Biden remains confident of being sworn in on January 20th, while Trump's campaign is preparing to file a new lawsuit in Georgia, where a hand recount is expected to confirm Biden's win.

site_title: Trump to take part in virtual Apec summit on Friday: US official
summary: US President Donald Trump will participate in the virtual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit on Friday, according to a US official. The summit, held online due to the Covid-19 pandemic, brings together 21 Pacific Rim countries accounting for about 60% of global GDP. This marks Trump's continued participation despite the US presidential election results, which he has rejected.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday ahead of long weekend
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, Nov 20, 2020, due to cautious trade ahead of a long weekend, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.60% and the Topix index down 0.38%. Rising coronavirus cases continue to worry investors.

site_title: Biden says won't order 'national shutdown' despite Covid surge
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden stated that he won't order a nationwide shutdown to combat the Covid-19 pandemic despite a surge in cases. He believes a total national shutdown would be counterproductive. Instead, states and cities are imposing their own restrictions, including home confinement and gathering limits. Biden's stance comes as infections soar across the country, but he plans to take office on January 20.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing expected to turn to hybrid engine technology for new planes: lessor
summary: Airbus and Boeing are expected to adopt hybrid electric technology in their next-generation planes due to limitations in improving current engines. Airbus is already working on a hybrid solution, while Boeing may be more cautious due to its ongoing challenges with the 737 MAX and 777X. Hybrid engines would offer a lighter aircraft weight and a technology transition, rather than a step change. Airbus aims to produce a hybrid plane by 2035, while Rolls-Royce Holdings expects commercial hybrid planes to enter service by 2029, and Boeing's hybrid-powered regional planes may enter service in the 2030s.

site_title: Fear for 4,700 jobs as two UK retailers go into administration
summary: UK fashion chains Peacocks and Jaeger have gone into administration, putting 4,700 jobs at nearly 500 shops under threat. The decision follows the expiration of a two-week High Court deadline for finding a buyer, citing the "continuing deterioration of the retail sector" due to coronavirus closures and restrictions. Joint administrator Tony Wright says they are in "advanced discussions with a number of parties" to secure a future for both businesses.

site_title: EU says could approve two coronavirus vaccines this year
summary: The European Union may approve two coronavirus vaccines, developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, as early as December, according to EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The European Medicines Agency has received successful data from the vaccines' clinical trials, and von der Leyen expressed confidence in a conditional marketing authorization by the end of the month. This development could bring much-needed relief to the EU in its fight against the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The European Union could approve two coronavirus vaccines being tested by Pfizer-BioNTech and by Moderna before the end of next month, EU Commission president Ursula von der Leyen said on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on revived stimulus talks
summary: US stocks gained on Thursday, reversing a two-session decline, as optimism over revived US stimulus talks boosted investor sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively. The market rebounded despite concerns about rising coronavirus cases and tariff uncertainty, with investors focusing on potential economic stimulus measures.

site_title: Apple to pay US$113m to resolve claims over iPhone battery
summary: Apple Inc. will pay US$113 million to settle claims from over 33 US regulators that the company misled consumers about iPhone battery power and performance. The allegations stem from software updates that slowed the devices' performance. The settlement resolves claims by states and the District of Columbia, marking a resolution to the long-standing issue. The payment does not imply any wrongdoing by Apple, as it was agreed upon as a settlement to avoid further litigation.

site_title: Oil prices slip as surge in virus cases raises concerns about demand
summary: Oil prices declined on Thursday as a surge in coronavirus cases globally raised concerns about crude demand. Brent crude settled at $44.20 a barrel, down 14 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $41.74 a barrel, 8 cents lower. The decline in oil prices comes as hopes for a vaccine are overshadowed by the rising number of virus cases, sparking fears about the outlook for crude demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Thursday as hopes for a vaccine were overshadowed by a surge in new cases of the coronavirus around the world, which raised concerns about the outlook for crude demand.

site_title: Adapting to the future - using science-fiction movie plots
summary: Organisations are using science fiction movie plots to adapt to future crises, such as the Covid-19 pandemic. By analyzing 140 science-fiction films, researchers identified six "macro-scenarios" of the future, including a decadent society and a world controlled by other species. These scenarios can be used as "ready-to-use tokens" to prepare for potential disruptions in various industries, and have been applied in a real-world project in Indiana to imagine disruptive futures of work.

site_title: German MPs to grill ex-Wirecard boss over massive fraud
summary: German lawmakers will grill Markus Braun, the former CEO of Wirecard, over the massive accounting fraud that led to the company's collapse in June. Wirecard admitted 1.9 billion euros missing from its accounts did not exist, prompting a full parliamentary inquiry into possible regulatory failings. Braun's public grilling comes as lawmakers investigate possible failures that allowed the cheating to go unnoticed for years.

images.alt_text: Markus Braun (above) and other top Wirecard executives stand accused of inflating revenues and profits to hide years of losses.

site_title: Don't fear the robots, and other lessons from a study of the digital economy
summary: Researchers from a task force at MIT published a 92-page report on the digital economy, concluding that technological advancements will lead to evolutionary changes in the workforce, rather than revolutionary ones. The report, "The Work of the Future: Building Better Jobs in an Age of Intelligent Machines," offers labor market analysis, field studies, and policy suggestions to address skills-training programs, tax codes, labor laws, and minimum wage rates. The authors emphasize the need for adaptable policies to create opportunities for Americans in the digital economy, rather than fearing the impact of robots.

site_title: Alibaba Pictures Group H1 net loss narrows to 162.1m yuan
summary: Alibaba Pictures Group reported a narrowed net loss of 162.1 million yuan for the half-year ended Sept 30, 2020, down from 390.4 million yuan in the year-ago period. Revenue declined to 926.7 million yuan, down from 1.5 billion yuan. Loss per share was 0.61 fen, compared to 1.48 fen in the year-ago period, with no dividend declared.

site_title: US housing starts beat expectations; building permits flat
summary: US housing starts rose 4.9% in October to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 1.530 million units, beating expectations, driven by record-low mortgage rates. Single-family homebuilding surged 6.4% to its highest level since April 2007, while multi-family starts remained unchanged. Despite a weak labor market and rising Covid-19 cases, the housing market continues to be sustained by low mortgage rates, with builders taking advantage of strong demand and lean inventories.

site_title: As travel bubbles kick off, don't expect a miracle
summary: The world's first Covid travel bubble is set to launch between Hong Kong and Singapore, allowing pre-screened passengers to bypass two-week quarantine upon arrival. However, the experiment is unlikely to restore the pre-pandemic air travel industry, as it will likely lead to a more expensive and rarefied era of travel. The bubble's success depends on strict testing and adherence to protocols, but even if it works, it may not be enough to support an industry that relies on cheap flights.

site_title: December vaccine rollout possible: BioNTech CEO
summary: BioNTech CEO Ugur Sahin stated that his company's Covid-19 vaccine, developed with Pfizer, could be rolled out in the US or Europe before the end of the year, with plans to apply for emergency use authorization in the US on Friday and submit additional data to European regulators next week. Sahin expressed optimism that the companies could receive approval from both regions this year.

images.alt_text: BioNTech co-founder Ugur Sahin said on Thursday the frontrunner Covid-19 vaccine his German firm is developing with Pfizer could be rolled out before the year is over in the United States or Europe.

site_title: US lawmakers discuss stimulus again as Federal Reserve warns of growth slump
summary: US lawmakers are discussing a new stimulus spending package to aid the economic recovery from the coronavirus downturn. The talks, led by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, come as the Federal Reserve warns of a potential growth slump in the fourth quarter. The discussions aim to address pandemic relief, following a surge in Covid-19 cases nationwide. The package would address the economic recovery, as the US economy faces uncertainty and the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: The discussions, confirmed to AFP by a senior Democratic aide, come as Covid-19 cases surge nationwide and as the president of a regional Federal Reserve bank warned the United States could see growth contract again in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Apple to press ahead on mobile privacy, despite Facebook protests
summary: Apple confirmed it will proceed with mobile software changes limiting tracking for targeted advertising, despite Facebook's objections. The iPhone maker aims to give users more control over tracking by apps on Apple devices, citing concerns over users being tracked without consent. Apple's updates, originally delayed, will focus on supporting online ads without "unfettered data collection." The company's privacy chief, Jane Horvath, criticized Facebook's approach to targeting, stating it disregards user privacy and collects data across multiple products.

site_title: Keeping SMEs in business
summary: Alternative lenders are stepping in to provide financing for smaller businesses (SMEs) in Singapore, leveraging technology, data, and liquidity. However, the ongoing pandemic poses a significant challenge to these lenders, who must continue to support SMEs despite immense strain on companies. The alternative financing sector is expected to face difficulties, but it has opened up opportunities for SMEs to access capital. Experts are bracing for the downturn ahead, while the need for digitalization has become a crucial element of business operations.

site_title: Thai central bank intervenes to curb rapid rise in baht
summary: Thailand's central bank intervened to curb the rapid rise of the baht, citing concerns that the currency's appreciation was impacting exporters and exacerbating the country's fragile economic recovery. The baht has risen due to optimism over a coronavirus vaccine, which is expected to boost tourism and the country's currency. However, the reality of vaccine availability and usage is uncertain, and the bank is concerned about the currency's strength. The Bank of Thailand has lifted interest rates to deal with the baht's strength and will hold a briefing on measures and capital movement on Friday.

site_title: Three ways Singapore, EU can work together to unlock Asean's potential: Chan
summary: Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for greater integration between Singapore and the European Union (EU) to unlock Asean's potential. Key areas of collaboration include healthcare, digitalization, and sustainability. The two regions aim to improve outcomes globally through joint efforts, particularly in managing the Covid-19 pandemic. A new digital economy agreement (DEA) and a free trade agreement (FTA) are also being pursued, with the EU supporting Singapore's bid for a region-to-region FTA.

site_title: Fewer employers in Singapore plan to freeze salaries in 2021: surveys
summary: Singapore-based employers plan to freeze salaries slightly less in 2021, with 22% of respondents intending to continue or introduce freezes, down from 36% in 2020. Only 3% plan pay cuts, compared to 29% in 2020. The overall projected salary increase for 2021 is 3.5%, down from 3.6%, with PMETs and non-PMETs expected to see 3.6% and 3.4% increases, respectively.

site_title: From Lebanon, bottles that reward diving below the surface
summary: In Lebanon, a wine industry has thrived despite decades of conflict and strife. A documentary, "Wine and War," explores this resilience through the story of Chateau Musar and its winemaker, Serge Hochar. The film highlights the importance of patience and attention to detail when tasting wine, as it can change and evolve over time. Three Lebanese wines, Massaya Bekaa Valley Le Colombier 2018, Chateau Musar Bekaa Valley Musar Jeune 2018, and Domaine des Tourelles Bekaa Valley Cinsault Vieilles Vignes 2017, were found to have complex flavors and aromas, with the Tourelles standing out for its elegance and subtlety.

site_title: What must we teach The Next Generation?
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of teaching the next generation fundamental skills beyond technology, as rapid advancements in technology can render current methods obsolete. The author advocates for a return to basics, focusing on disciplines such as understanding the importance of fundamental principles, digitization, and personal discipline. They caution against over-reliance on measurement and quantification, which can oversimplify complex aspects of life, such as love, pain, and sustainability. Instead, the author recommends teaching individuals to "read" others, understand personality, and develop personal discipline to determine the basic rules of life.

site_title: Freestyle cooking at Hathaway
summary: Hathaway, a cafe-bistro in Dempsey village, Singapore, shows promise but needs improvement in its cooking style. The relaxed atmosphere and wood-wicker interiors create a cozy space, with a bread and pastry display inspired by its sister bakery, Bread Yard. The menu offers a wide range of dishes, from Asian to Spanish and Italian, but some dishes, such as the octopus bakar and sambal udang, fall short in terms of flavor and texture. With good intentions but a need for restraint and harmony between flavors and textures, Hathaway is a promising but inconsistent dining experience, rated 6 out of 10.

site_title: Facebook content moderators say office push risks lives
summary: Facebook content moderators claim their lives are at risk due to requiring them to work in offices in global hotspots during the pandemic. Over 200 moderators, including Facebook employees and contractors, wrote a letter to executives stating that working in offices poses a significant risk of Covid-19 exposure. The company had initially shifted to remote work but has now brought back some moderators to offices, citing the need for human judgment to replace AI moderation. Facebook disputed the claims, stating that the majority of content reviewers have been working from home.

site_title: Covid-19 ravaging long-term care centres at fastest pace since May
summary: COVID-19 is ravaging long-term care centers in the US at the fastest pace since May, with over 29,000 new cases reported in nursing homes and assisted-living facilities. The Midwest accounts for half of new cases, with Ohio leading the increase. Despite making up only 1% of the population, COVID-19 fatalities in these facilities account for 40% of the national death toll. The US reported 155,835 new cases, with 76,823 people hospitalized for COVID-19, a record.

site_title: Guillemard site sold for S$93m in year's biggest private residential deal
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired a freehold residential development site in Singapore for S$93 million, the largest private residential transaction in the year to date. The site, located at 217-223A Guillemard Road and 1-21A Jalan Molek, will be redeveloped into a part-five, part-eight-storey residential development of 137 units. The sale signals a return of developer confidence, with property consultants predicting a recovery in primary-market private home sales.

site_title: Will Biden appoint a US ambassador to Singapore?
summary: The US Embassy in Singapore has been without an ambassador since 2016, sparking speculation about a potential appointment by President-elect Joe Biden. Diplomats believe the role is symbolic, reflecting the quality of US-Singapore relations. Victor Mills, CEO of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, and Angela Mancini, partner at Control Risks, expect an ambassador to be named during Biden's term, reflecting a return to traditional diplomacy and increased US engagement in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: The new BMW 4 Series Coupe noses into town
summary: BMW has unveiled the new 4 Series Coupe in Singapore, featuring a striking new design with an unmissable nose and aggressive headlights. The car boasts smooth lines and elegant curves, staying faithful to BMW's typical proportions while growing in size to accommodate a more spacious cabin. Two versions, the 420i Coupe M Sport and 430i Coupe M Sport Pro, are available, both powered by a 2.0-litre turbo engine with an eight-speed automatic gearbox. The car's design has received mixed reviews, with some critics praising its characterful look while others find it too radical.

site_title: Supervising digital banks in a Covid-19 world
summary: Financial supervisors in the Asia-Pacific region are strengthening their surveillance and supervisory capabilities to address emerging risks in the digital banking sector, particularly in the post-Covid-19 landscape. Digital banks, which are often startups with heightened risks, need to balance their "fail-fast" culture with stability expectations. Supervisors are expected to adopt a "fail-safe" mentality, with a focus on risk management and regulatory compliance. The regulatory landscape for digital banks is evolving along three dimensions: forward-looking and risk-based supervision, operational resilience, and enhanced cooperation and coordination.

images.alt_text: New digital banks fuel innovation and encourage incumbent banks to respond to the new competitive landscape, and the resulting economic growth spurs further investments in technology and data analytics, thereby contributing to further development and competitiveness of the financial services industry.

site_title: Seizing a juicy opportunity
summary: Bruce Zhang, CEO of Fruits Vending, transformed his career as an engineer to launch a premium smart vending machine business after high rental rates in Singapore's central business district. He launched his first vending machine in 2016, which dispenses orange juice, and the company now operates over 1,000 machines across 28 countries. Zhang's success can be attributed to his IoT-based solutions, reduced manpower needs, and ideal machine placement strategies. Despite disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, Fruits Vending's business has shown significant increase in sales, and the company is poised for further expansion plans.

site_title: DoctorxDentist's headache grows as MOH, medical bodies lean on platform
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) and Singapore Medical Council (SMC) have corrected statements made by review platform DoctorxDentist, which was at odds with over 1,000 medical community members. The Academy of Medicine, Singapore (AMS) has expressed strong disapproval of the startup's practices. The corrections were made after MOH and SMC issued statements to address inaccuracies on the platform's website. The dispute highlights the tension between the medical community and review platforms, with AMS voicing its disapproval of the startup's practices.

images.alt_text: Since Nov 3, SMA has been collating a list of medical practitioners who do not want to be associated with the platform. SMA is considering making the list, now comprising over 1,000 doctors, publicly accessible.

site_title: Standard created to gauge finance-related emissions
summary: Financial institutions, including Morgan Stanley and Bank of America, are introducing a global accounting standard to measure the climate impact of financial transactions. The standard, developed by the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF), will help companies assess their greenhouse gas emissions from loans and investments. Eighty-seven firms with $17.8 trillion in assets have joined PCAF and committed to reporting finance-related emissions, with a goal of expanding to 100 firms by the end of the year and 250 firms in 2022. The standard aims to integrate climate disclosures into financial reports.

site_title: UK extends £3 billion green homes grant amid application pile-up
summary: The UK government has extended its £3 billion Green Homes Grant scheme by a year, allowing homeowners to apply until March 2022, due to a backlog of 42,000 applications. The grant, which offers up to £10,000 for home insulation, was initially set to expire in March next year. The extension aims to meet the UK's goal of net-zero carbon emissions and support the economy's recovery from the pandemic. The government has issued only 267 vouchers so far, sparking concerns about the scheme's slow progress.

site_title: S. Korea to convert buildings into apartments to tackle rental home shortages
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Hong Nam-ki, announced plans to convert 114,000 properties into public housing to address the country's rental home shortage. The proposal, part of the government's efforts to cool soaring home prices, aims to add homes for lease within the next two years. The move follows previous measures, including easing building height limits and converting military sites into residential areas, which failed to address the shortage. The government plans to focus on increasing the supply of rental homes, rather than restricting demand, to meet the demand for jeonse properties.

site_title: Art returns with a vengeance
summary: Singapore's first Gallery Weekend is taking place from November 20 to 22, featuring 32 galleries and art organizations with a range of exhibitions, demos, performances, and a block party. The event, organized by the Art Galleries Association Singapore (AGAS), aims to boost the art scene despite the pandemic's impact. With increased online shopping behaviors and a growing interest in art among collectors, galleries are expecting a surge in attendance. The event is self-funded by AGAS, which saw membership skyrocket by 50% in 2020, and is expected to draw thousands of visitors.

images.alt_text: Michelle Chan's collage is inspired by an old bus driver she knew who died, leaving behind his photographs, magazines and other objects. Chan took the objects and turned them into whimsical collages, now on display at Chinatown MRT station, as part of the Singapore International Photography Festival.

Mike HJ Chang's painting Sea's Guts is inspired by his time at sea aboard an oil tanker. His solo showcase is now on at Yeo Workshop in Gillman Barracks. Yeo Workshop is throwing a block party on Nov 20 and Nov 21 with the nearby galleries and restaurants.

(Left) Melisa Teo's artfully blurred photographs of Paris are on display at Alliance Francaise. The artist will be present to meet visitors this weekend. (Right) Jamie Tan You Ken's colour field paintings are showcased at Art Porters Gallery in Spottiswoode Park.
A painting by Nyein Chan Su, one of the Myanmarese artists featured in Intersections Gallery showcase at Fullerton Hotel.

site_title: Carrefour agrees to suspend Black Friday sales
summary: Carrefour, Europe's largest retailer, has agreed to suspend its Black Friday sales event from November 27 to 29 due to ongoing lockdown restrictions, as advised by Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire. The decision was made after Carrefour's chairman and CEO Alexandre Bompard spoke with Le Maire, who urged retailers to postpone non-essential sales during the lockdown. This move comes as other retailers, including Amazon France, have not indicated any plans to cancel their Black Friday events.

site_title: STI slips 0.4% as vaccine fever cools
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,777 on Thursday, marking a cooling of "vaccine enthusiasm" and potentially setting up a pullback further below the key resistance level of 2,800, according to analysts. The index had previously seen a surge in institutional investment and positive vaccine news, but technical indicators suggest it may be temporarily overbought.

site_title: SMBC invests in fintech OakNorth
summary: SMBC has invested US$30 million in fintech OakNorth, a UK-headquartered challenger bank, to drive data-backed lending in emerging markets such as Indonesia. The investment comes after Indiabulls Housing Finance sold 5% of its OakNorth shareholdings, reducing the bank's valuation to US$2.1 billion. OakNorth is backed by Japanese conglomerate SoftBank and will use SMBC's credit intelligence software to automate and efficiency in portfolio monitoring, aiming to enhance corporate lending platforms in South-east Asia.

site_title: Audi RS4 Avant review: A wunder wagon
summary: The Audi RS4 Avant is a high-performance wagon that combines luxury, practicality, and speed. Based on the recently-facelifted A4, it features a 450-hp twin-turbo V6 engine, 8-speed automatic gearbox, and a generous 495-1,495-liter boot. The car's cockpit layout is cleaner and more spacious, with a 10.1-inch touchscreen and a new "RS" button on the steering wheel. The RS4 Avant is fast, with a 0-100km/h time of 4.1 seconds, and offers a unique blend of heritage, ability, and practicality, making it a standout in its class.

site_title: Reits must address issues related to independent directors, overseas assets: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has urged Reits to address concerns over the independence of their directors and the valuations of their overseas assets. The regulator emphasized the need for transparency and addressing perceived conflicts of interest. SGX RegCo is also working on addressing concentration risks and the difficulty of enforcing rules on overseas entities, particularly in the hospitality sector. The regulator is exploring possible solutions to these issues, including capping the number of properties leased to a sponsor and requiring comprehensive disclosures.

site_title: US dollar up on worries over rising Covid-19 cases
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Thursday due to worries over rising Covid-19 cases, despite optimism about Covid-19 vaccines. The dollar rose 0.2% against the euro to US$1.1833, while the yen fell 0.2% against the greenback. Speculation about the Federal Reserve loosening monetary policy in December and fiscal stimulus plans falling by the wayside also supported the dollar. However, Scandinavian currencies and the Australian dollar lost strength, and analysts say market participants are confused about the balance of positive and negative factors.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang Estates' acting CEO resigns
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' acting CEO Ooi Chee Eng, 48, has resigned "for personal reasons" and will leave the company on February 17, 2021. He had assumed the role of acting CEO in September 2019 and was previously CFO and company secretary since August 2018. The board is searching for potential candidates to fill the positions vacated by Mr Ooi, expressing appreciation for his past services and contributions.

site_title: Singapore cannot keep borders closed forever: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country's economy outlook remains "very guarded" due to the Covid-19 pandemic. While the situation has stabilized, Lee emphasized the need to gradually phase out support schemes for businesses to achieve a sustainable recovery. He noted that it's impossible to keep borders closed indefinitely, as there must be traffic and business, and new cases will inevitably occur. Lee predicted that normalcy may return in 2022, but warned of lasting changes, including a shift towards remote work and travel. The government will support businesses that need to transform or pivot, but those in industries like tourism may face challenges.

site_title: 74 organisations named Champions of Good 2020
summary: Seventy-four organisations have been named Champions of Good 2020 by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) for their efforts to uplift vulnerable members of society and collaborate with partners and stakeholders. This year's list includes 23 first-time Champions and 28 three-time Champions, such as Maybank and Singapore Press Holdings. The recognition acknowledges the organisations' contributions to the community and sets a precedent for robust corporate citizenship, with NVPC chairman Mildred Tan stating that the Champions are building a "City of Good" in Singapore.

site_title: Biden administration can help US gain ESG leadership
summary: The newly elected Biden administration is seen as an opportunity for the US to regain its leadership in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. The Trump administration's stance on ESG has been out of step with the global movement, and a new era of cooperation between government and the private sector is expected. Key priorities include addressing climate change, promoting green jobs, and strengthening accountability and shareholder rights. Mandatory ESG disclosure for publicly traded companies, integration of ESG factors into investment processes, and cooperation on global sustainability are also expected.

site_title: Globalisation is not on the decline, says Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam says globalisation is not declining, but rather undergoing a reconfiguration due to China's emergence. China's growing middle class and increasing domestic capabilities are contributing to this trend. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, globalisation remains the future, with big tech companies maintaining international presence. The pandemic has also accelerated real-time global management and created a need for resilient hubs, with Singapore aiming to be a multifaceted hub for businesses. Tharman emphasizes the importance of civic-mindedness and respecting the public good in managing the pandemic.

site_title: How to build your dream home
summary: Entrepreneurs Richard Koh and Ong Bee Yan, who own a handcrafted beverage company, have finally achieved their dream home after 20 years of marriage and three homes. They designed the two-storey house themselves, incorporating features such as a courtyard to brighten and ventilate the home naturally and a staircase leading to a roof terrace for their pets and themselves. The house is filled with upcycled items, including old metal window grilles, a Singer sewing machine, and a family heirloom dining table, showcasing the couple's commitment to sustainability and sentimental value.

images.alt_text: The staircase that leads from the courtyard to the roof terrace. "The animals use it, but so do we," says Ms Ong.
The modest intermediate terrace house off Braddell Road given an A&A job.
The dining table has been in the family for decades.

The master bedroom on the second floor overlooks the courtyard and has direct access to the roof terrace (above). The roof terrace is Ms Ong's favourite space where she spends mornings reading or tending to her rooftop garden filled with lemongrass, pandan and mint plants.

The master bedroom (above) on the second floor overlooks the courtyard and has direct access to the roof terrace. The roof terrace is Ms Ong's favourite space where she spends mornings reading or tending to her rooftop garden filled with lemongrass, pandan and mint plants.
An old Singer that has been in Ms Ong's family for a long time is now converted into a vanity.
A vintage window grille, used as a decorative feature on the facade of the house, is a treasured piece from Mr Koh's past. Five decades on, he still remembers climbing on it when he was a child.

site_title: Kia Motors workers in S Korea to stage partial strike over wages, EV plans
summary: Kia Motors workers in South Korea are set to stage a partial strike from Nov 24-27 over wages and job security concerns related to the company's plans to produce electric vehicles (EVs). The union is protesting the introduction of EV production, citing potential job losses, and is seeking longer-term job security. Kia aims to produce 11 EVs by 2025 and 25% of global sales in EVs by 2029. The labor action comes amid ongoing negotiations between the union and the company over wages and benefits.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival to feature global satellite events from over 40 cities
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival (SFF) x Singapore Week of Innovation & TeCHnology (SFF x SWITCH) 2020 will feature over 40 global satellite events from cities worldwide, including Warsaw, Nairobi, and Washington DC, from December 7-11. The event will have a hybrid format combining online and physical events, with a digital city featuring over 800 speakers, including industry leaders and policymakers. This year's event aims to create a truly global and inclusive experience for the fintech community despite the pandemic, with organizers expecting the biggest turnout yet.

site_title: Ferrari SF90 Spider: the S$2m convertible with an electric kick
summary: Ferrari unveiled the SF90 Spider, a convertible version of its range-topping SF90 Stradale, priced at S$2 million. The car boasts a 1,000 horsepower petrol-electric, plug-in hybrid drivetrain, with a 0-100km/h time of 2.5 seconds and a 0-200km/h time of 7 seconds. The SF90 Spider features a 25km electric range on a single charge and a folding hardtop that can be opened in 14 seconds. Ferrari's chief commercial and marketing officer Enrico Galliera stated that the company sees electric drive as a supplement to traditional petrol power, with plans to produce 60% hybrid cars in less than three years.

site_title: Indonesia, Philippines cut rates to record lows
summary: Indonesia and the Philippines cut their benchmark interest rates to record lows, with Bank Indonesia lowering its key rate to 3.75% and the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas cutting to 2%. The moves were unexpected by most analysts and aimed to support economic recovery amid the worst coronavirus outbreaks in South-east Asia. Both countries pledged to keep policy supportive for growth, with policymakers citing recent currency strength and low inflation as factors. The rate cuts are seen as a step to boost credit growth and stimulate demand.

site_title: Far East Hospitality positions itself for the long haul as it expands footprint
summary: Far East Hospitality, a joint venture between Far East Orchard and The Straits Trading Company, is expanding its footprint despite the ongoing pandemic. The company has signed three new management contracts in Singapore, Australia, and Japan, aiming to capitalize on long-term opportunities in the tourism industry. CEO Arthur Kiong expects increased intra-Asia travel and a shift towards high-value tourism, with potential opportunities in medical tourism. Far East Hospitality plans to open new properties, including its fourth Sentosa hotel, and will leverage surrounding precincts to deliver unique experiences for guests.

site_title: Thanksgiving food prices sink as Americans scale down their feasts
summary: US Thanksgiving food prices have dropped to their lowest level in a decade, driven by grocers discounting turkey and other ingredients to attract customers. The average cost of a traditional Thanksgiving dinner for 10 people is down 4% from last year to $46.90, with turkey prices being the main contributor to the decline. Many Americans are expected to scale back their feasts due to the pandemic, with over a third planning to spend less on Thanksgiving this year. Retailers are preparing to sell a greater variety of food, including more affordable options.

site_title: Jefferies Equity upgrades Cathay Pacific to a 'buy'
summary: Jefferies Equity Research upgraded Cathay Pacific Airways to a "buy" rating and raised its price target to HK$8.70 from HK$6.30 due to expected growth from the Hong Kong-Singapore air travel bubble, cargo demand, and easing quarantine policies. The airline's passenger traffic has declined 97-99% since April 2020, but Jefferies expects a limited near-term impact and a rebound in air travel yields next year. Cargo remains a cash generator, and the global air cargo market is expected to benefit from global vaccine distribution.

site_title: Sony, Microsoft consoles run into supply crunch
summary: Sony and Microsoft's new gaming consoles, the PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S, saw poor debut sales in Japan due to supply bottlenecks caused by the pandemic. The PlayStation 5 sold 118,085 units in its first week, while the Xbox Series X/S sold 20,534 units, both lower than their predecessors. The poor sales suggest that the available supply is the main issue, rather than demand, and both companies are working to increase production.

images.alt_text: Sony is also introducing its new consoles to 65 nations, doubling the 32 that the company covered with the PlayStation 4.

site_title: Nasdaq to buy financial fraud detection firm Verafin for US$2.75b
summary: Nasdaq is acquiring financial fraud detection firm Verafin for $2.75 billion in cash, expanding its regulatory technology and anti-financial crime solutions. Verafin's cloud-based platform helps detect and report money laundering and financial fraud for over 2,000 institutions. The deal will increase Nasdaq's earnings per share starting in 2022, financed by $2.5 billion of debt and cash.

images.alt_text: Exchange operator Nasdaq said on Thursday it would buy anti-financial crime management products firm Verafin for US$2.75 billion in cash.

site_title: Pandemic may send global debt to US$277t by year's end, says IIF
summary: Global debt soared to $272 trillion by the end of September, a $15 trillion increase since the start of the pandemic, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). This represents 365% of global GDP and could reach $277 trillion by year's end. The majority of the increase came from governments in developed markets, with the US, Canada, Japan, and the UK experiencing the largest increases in non-financial sector debt. Economists warn that high debt levels could lead to another financial crisis and hinder economic growth.

site_title: As regulators prepare to weigh in on 737 MAX, FAA's global dominance fades
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) decision to unground the Boeing 737 MAX has sparked concerns among foreign regulators, leading to a shift in the global regulatory landscape. Many countries, including Canada and Brazil, are delaying their approval, citing the FAA's lax oversight and the need for more resources. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has emerged as a stronger peer to the FAA, with greater scrutiny of future projects. China's approval of the MAX remains uncertain, with some analysts speculating that Beijing could use the aircraft as a political bargaining chip.

site_title: Singapore FinTech Festival to feature over 40 global satellite events
summary: The Singapore FinTech Festival (SFF) x Singapore Week of Innovation & Technology (SFF x SWITCH) 2020 will feature over 40 global satellite events from December 7-11, combining a 24/7 online event platform with physical events in selected cities. The hybrid format aims to deliver a truly global and inclusive event for the fintech community, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Key speakers include Sundar Pichai, Satya Nadella, and Abhijit Banerjee, and the event is expected to have the biggest turnout yet, with attendees able to tune in from anywhere in the world.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 21.07 points lower to 1,583.68 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 9.532 billion lots worth RM4.483 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 730 to 462.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The London Philharmonic Orchestra has released a symphony inspired by Singapore, titled UTOPIA Symphony, recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London. The symphony was commissioned by former Singapore Ambassador to Russia Michael Tay and composed by Vladimir Martynov. It captures the essence of Singapore's vision of striving for betterment and self-improvement. The symphony is available on major digital platforms and in CD format. Additionally, Majulah Live 2020, a digital entertainment experience, will feature music and stand-up comedy performances by Singaporean artists, available for streaming on September 19-20, 2020.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corp will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange's Mainboard on Nov 24 following a successful privatisation bid by Clementine Investments, which exercised its right of compulsory acquisition after a 95.9% acceptance rate. Koufu Group expects significantly lower operating profits for the second half of 2020 due to Covid-19, but expects a "significant improvement" in the final quarter. The company will also record higher impairment losses due to the pandemic.

site_title: All aboard the Orient Express
summary: The Orient Express, a luxury train that once connected Europe and the Middle East, is set to make a stop in Singapore for an exhibition titled "Once Upon A Time On The Orient Express." The 2,000-square-metre exhibition, featuring the train's locomotive and carriage, will be held at Gardens By The Bay from December 12 to June 13, 2021. The show includes restored objects and furnishings, a pop-up restaurant with gourmet French cuisine, and an escape room experience. The exhibition marks the first time the show has traveled outside of France and aims to evoke the romance and wonder of travel, despite travel restrictions still in force around the world.

site_title: Japan's Orix invests US$60m in Israeli venture firm
summary: Japanese leasing and financial services group Orix Corp has invested US$60 million in Israeli venture firm OurCrowd, marking Orix's first collaboration with Israel's startup sector. The deal provides Orix with access to innovative technologies and companies, while OurCrowd aims to offer financial products and investment opportunities suited for the Japanese and global markets.

site_title: ST Engineering remains a defensive, safe-haven pick, analysts say
summary: ST Engineering remains a defensive pick due to better-than-expected order wins in the third quarter, with S$1.7 billion in new orders, particularly strong for its electronics division. The company's new, leaner organisational structure is seen as a key factor in its improved focus. Analysts view this as a safe-haven pick amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang acting CEO resigns for personal reasons
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' acting CEO, Ooi Chee Eng, has resigned for personal reasons, effective February 17, 2021. Ooi, 48, had held the positions of CFO and company secretary since 2018 and took over as acting CEO in 2019. The company is actively searching for new candidates to fill the vacant positions, with plans to announce suitable candidates when identified. The news did not impact the company's shares, which closed at S$3.91 on Thursday.

site_title: Former Wirecard boss Braun stonewalls German lawmakers' inquiry
summary: Former Wirecard CEO Markus Braun declined to answer over 50 questions from German lawmakers on the company's demise, citing confidence in the German legal system. Braun, who has denied wrongdoing, claimed Wirecard was a victim of a wider fraud. He made no comment on allegations of improper behavior by German officials. Braun is in jail awaiting trial and faces charges related to the company's collapse.

site_title: 70 firms penalised for unfair hiring in H1; double the whole of 2019
summary: Singapore authorities penalised 70 firms for unfair hiring practices in the first half of 2020, more than double the number for the whole of 2019. The Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices used data analytics to investigate 260 cases, up from 160 in 2019. This increase in investigations reflects the authorities' efforts to address discriminatory hiring practices in the country's job market.

site_title: Teckwah to delist from mainboard on Nov 24
