SPH Reit non-executive director David Chia Chay Poh resigned to pave the way for renewal, while Trina Loh was appointed as non-executive director. Aspen Holdings completed its placement of 100 million new shares to meet minimum shareholding requirements and strengthen its financial position. Rich Capital Holdings' indirect subsidiary Oxley Batam issued a letter of demand against a joint venture partner, PT Karya Indo Batam, over alleged breach of agreements.

site_title: Singapore housing market a safe haven amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's housing market has defied expectations, with new homes sales exceeding 8,021 units in the first 10 months of 2020, driven by a lower-for-longer rates environment and low unemployment rate. Projections for full-year sales range from 9,000 to 9,500 units, with some expecting private residential property prices to end in positive territory for 2020. The market's resilience is attributed to measures such as loan deferment and temporary relief, which have prevented price corrections. Wealthy buyers are also driving demand for outside-central region (OCR) homes, with 168 non-landed units sold at S$2 million and above in Q3 2020.

site_title: 'MasterChef Junior' star Ben Watkins dies at 14 from cancer
summary: Ben Watkins, a 14-year-old star of the TV show 'MasterChef Junior', died from a rare form of cancer after a year-and-a-half-long battle. His family released a statement saying he went home to be with his mother, citing that his suffering is finally over. The cause of death was not specified in the article.

site_title: Luxury apartments in hot demand despite economic woes
summary: Wealthy investors continue to drive demand for luxury condominiums in Singapore, with over 2,000 units sold in the first three quarters of 2020. Despite the pandemic, prices surged 27.0% compared to the same period five years ago, with median prices reaching S$2,288 per square foot. Small luxury apartments, priced below S$2 million, also saw a significant increase in sales, with 731 units sold in the first nine months of 2020. The luxury market is expected to remain strong, with consumer confidence returning as more sectors of the economy reopen, and foreign buyers flocking to Singapore due to its safe-haven status and excellent healthcare system.

images.alt_text: Interior of an apartment at Wallich Residences. In the first nine months of this year, 2,182 non-landed private homes in the Core Central Region (CCR) were sold- a number that surpasses pre-pandemic periods such as 2014 and 2015, when 2,091 units and 1,654 units respectively were transacted for the full year.

site_title: COE prices close mostly higher across the board
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mostly higher across the board in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$37,690, up from S$35,990. The premium for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$41,101, and the Open COE premium ended at S$41,503. The Land Transport Authority announced a 5.8% increase in COE quotas for the November to January period, with a total of 6,649 COEs available.

site_title: Arguing the case for an EU development bank
summary: The European Union should establish a development bank to strengthen its global role and promote multilateralism. A powerful EU voice in development is crucial to address global challenges, including climate change, poverty, and security threats. The current EU development finance activities are insufficient, and unilateral actions by individual EU countries would be counterproductive. An EU development bank would leverage the EU's existing asset, the European Investment Bank, and bring a coordinated, transparent, and European approach to development financing. The institution would ensure that finance ministries have overall oversight, while national development ministers would be in the driver's seat, and the European Commission and European External Action Service would guarantee the bank's strategy serves the EU's development policy targets.

site_title: JPMorgan indices exclude new debt from sanctioned China firms
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has announced that its widely followed debt indices will exclude new bonds from Chinese companies sanctioned by the US government, following President Donald Trump's executive order. Existing bonds will remain in the indices, but JPMorgan will re-evaluate their eligibility. This move is expected to impact benchmark replication and could lead to reduced liquidity in bonds of sanctioned companies, potentially causing significant impairment. The decision affects 72 securities linked to sanctioned companies, with the JACI index expected to be most impacted, according to JPMorgan.

images.alt_text: Existing bonds of sanctioned companies will remain in the indices for now, but JPMorgan will re-evaluate their eligibility "once there is more clarity on the impact to benchmark replication".

site_title: STI up for third straight session on economic recovery hopes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose for a third consecutive day, gaining 10.04 points or 0.36% to 2,788.59. The index benefited from an optimistic outlook for Singapore's 2021 economy, driven by GDP recovery, accommodative monetary policy, and a fiscal budget. Real estate developers CapitaLand and City Developments led the gains. However, the Jardine duo suffered losses, and regional markets finished mixed.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher on vaccine bets, Boeing approval
summary: Wall Street's main indexes rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes for a faster economic recovery and vaccine updates. The S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and Nasdaq Composite increased, with Boeing surging after US approval to resume 737 MAX flights. The market optimism was fueled by vaccine bets and the latest economic data, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Homebuilder confidence hits another record on US buying boom
summary: US homebuilder confidence reached a record high of 90 in November, the third straight month, driven by a surge in buyers taking advantage of low mortgage rates. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Market index surpassed economists' median forecast of 85. Home construction has been a bright spot for the US economy, with Americans flocking to suburbs for new homes amidst scarce existing listings. However, affordability concerns persist due to rising construction costs and expected interest rate hikes.

site_title: US to approve 737 MAX return as Boeing faces strong headwinds
summary: Boeing's 737 MAX jet is set to resume commercial flights after a 20-month grounding following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people. The US Federal Aviation Administration will require software upgrades and new pilot training changes for Boeing to operate the aircraft safely. The return comes amid strong headwinds, including a resurgent coronavirus pandemic and new European tariffs, and faces scrutiny from regulators globally.

site_title: Boom in demand for friendly hackers as 5G era approaches
summary: The demand for "friendly hackers" is surging as the 5G era approaches, with companies offering record-breaking rewards to ethical hackers who discover vulnerabilities in their cybersecurity systems. The Internet of Things (IoT) is expected to pose a significant threat to digital security, prompting organizations to engage with hackers. HackerOne, a leading bug-bounty platform, has seen a 87% increase in payouts, with hackers earning up to $44 million in cash rewards this year. Companies are now recognizing the value of co-opting hackers to test their systems, with the French and UK governments even opening up coronavirus tracing apps to friendly hackers.

site_title: Top banks create standard to report emissions linked to finance
summary: A group of top financial institutions, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, and Citigroup, have introduced a global accounting standard to measure greenhouse-gas emissions linked to their loans and investments. The standard, developed by the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials, will help companies track their climate impact and enable comparisons between firms. Eighty-seven financial firms with $17.8 trillion in assets have joined the initiative, with the goal of expanding to 100 firms by the end of the year and 250 firms in 2022.

site_title: SPH Reit non-executive director resigns for board renewal; new director appointed
summary: SPH Reit's non-executive director David Chia Chay Poh, 65, has resigned, effective Dec 1, to pave the way for board renewal. He has been replaced by Trina Loh, 61, who will take over his committee roles. Loh brings experience from various roles, including Temasek Foundation Ecosperity and Singapore Pools. The appointment takes effect on Dec 1.

site_title: Pfizer, BioNTech plan filing as vaccine proves 95% effective
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech reported a 95% effective Covid-19 vaccine, based on a final analysis of clinical-trial data. The vaccine showed protection for all ages and ethnicities with no significant safety issues. The companies plan to apply for US regulatory authorization within days. The news led to a surge in stock prices for both companies, with Pfizer's shares rising 2.7% and BioNTech's American depositary receipts increasing 7.3%.

site_title: RSA agrees to £7.2b takeover by overseas rivals
summary: British insurance group RSA agrees to a £7.2 billion takeover by Canadian insurer Intact Financial and Danish insurer Tryg, marking one of Europe's largest financial bids this year. Despite reputational damage from business interruption claims, insurers have become attractive propositions due to home-working reducing claims and commercial insurance rates rising sharply. RSA's CEO, Stephen Hester, plans to step down after the deal's completion, expecting small job losses as businesses are integrated. The takeover is expected to complete in the second quarter of 2021.

site_title: Malaysia declares emergency in eastern region to stop polls amid pandemic
summary: Malaysia's king declared a state of emergency in Sabah, eastern state, to prevent a by-election amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision comes after a sharp spike in cases in the region, with nearly half of the country's infections linked to an election held in September. The move aims to prevent a potential fresh outbreak. Malaysia has reported over 50,000 COVID-19 cases, with Sabah being the worst-hit region.

site_title: Norwegian Air's top owner cuts stake amid debt crisis
summary: Norwegian Air's top owner, AerCap Holdings, has cut its stake in the crisis-hit carrier to 9% amid a debt crisis. The move comes after AerCap's representative resigned from Norwegian's board in June. The airline had converted debt into shares earlier this year, making AerCap its largest shareholder. The reduction in stake follows staff demonstrations against the government's decision to deny more aid to the struggling airline.

site_title: Centre opens in Jiangsu to help Singapore biomed startups tap Chinese market
summary: A new centre in China's Suzhou Industrial Park has been launched to help Singaporean biomedical startups tap into the Chinese market. Nine firms will receive grants, cost savings, and guidance on the Chinese market through the A*Star Partners' Centre. Minister Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of cooperation in healthcare and biomed between Singapore and Jiangsu, citing the potential for both sides to work together to commercialize biomedical research and innovation. The centre aims to help Singapore's rapidly growing biomedical industry expand into the Yangtze river delta region.

site_title: Maersk confident about shipping recovery beyond 2020
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, expressed confidence in shipping recovery beyond 2020 despite a second wave of coronavirus infections. The company reported higher retail sales in the US, which has boosted its earnings. Maersk raised its full-year earnings forecast, citing increased momentum in the fourth quarter, and announced a new share buy-back program of up to $1.6 billion. Despite forecasting a 4-5% contraction in global container volumes this year, the company expects a return to normal levels next year.

site_title: Nearly a third of US museums remain closed by pandemic: survey
summary: Nearly a third of US museums remain closed due to the pandemic, according to a survey by the American Alliance of Museums. The financial state of the country's museums is deteriorating, with 85% of museum directors reporting less than 12 months of financial operating reserve. Institutions are operating at only 33% of their capacity, and nearly 70% of frontline employees have been furloughed or laid off. Many museums rely on donations and ticket sales, which have decreased or dried up since March, putting them at risk of permanent closure if they don't find additional funding.

site_title: Hottest India Internet stock surging despite valuation fears
summary: Info Edge India Ltd, the parent company of Naukri.com, surged to a record high, driven by optimism about a Covid-19 vaccine and potential returns from its investments in startups. Despite missing quarterly profit and revenue forecasts, the stock has gained 187% over two years and is trading at 125 times analysts' 12-month forward earnings. The company's niche position in India's internet media and services sector, as well as its investments in Zomato and policybazaar.com, are seen as key drivers of its success.

site_title: Saudi to host online G20 summit
summary: Saudi Arabia will host the virtual G20 summit, the first for an Arab nation, on Saturday. The two-day online meeting aims to address the pandemic's implications and revive the global economy, with global economic output projected to contract by 4.5% this year. Despite contributions of over $21 billion to combat the pandemic, critics argue the G20's response is inadequate, with a "common framework" for debt restructuring deemed insufficient by campaigners. The virtual format may limit spontaneous discussions among leaders, and US President Donald Trump's attendance is uncertain.

site_title: Pelosi wins House Democratic leadership to vie again for Speaker
summary: House Democrats have reaffirmed Nancy Pelosi as their leader and nominee for speaker, despite losses in the November election that have emboldened congressional Republicans. Pelosi, 80, must secure a majority of votes from the full House to remain as speaker. The party will shrink its majority from 232 to around 221 seats in January, complicating her path to securing enough support. Pelosi's leadership will be tested as the caucus grapples with questions about its electoral strategy following the losses.

site_title: Amundi and BNP vie for SocGen asset manager Lyxor: sources
summary: Societe Generale is exploring the sale of its 150 billion euro Lyxor asset management business to Amundi, BNP Paribas, JPMorgan, and State Street. The sale is expected to be worth 500-700 million euros, with Amundi seen as the natural buyer. The final price will depend on the specific products to be sold. The move is part of Societe Generale's efforts to overhaul its retail and market activities and sell underperforming businesses, with the bank's CEO Frederic Oudea under pressure to make changes.

site_title: Robinsons owes S$31.7m to 442 creditors
summary: Robinsons Singapore, a department store under provisional liquidation, owes S$31.7 million to 442 creditors, including landlords, employees, and international brands like Simmons and L'Oreal. The retailer, which has been operating for 162 years, has been struggling due to the rise of e-commerce and specialist retailers, recording losses of S$54.4 million in 2018. A creditors' meeting will be held on Nov 26, and potential employee claims are pegged at about S$4.4 million.

images.alt_text: Many of the other creditors are brands that stock their products with Robinsons, with claims ranging from tens of thousands of dollars to the hundred thousands.

site_title: Rich Capital unit issues letter of demand against JV partner
summary: Rich Capital Holdings' indirect subsidiary Oxley Batam has issued a letter of demand to joint-venture partner PT Karya Indo Batam (PT KIB), alleging S$8 million in advance payments made by Oxley Holdings to PT KIB director Poni Madjukie. The JV, PT Oxley Karya Indo Batam (PT OKIB), was formed for a project at Oxley Convention City in Batam. PT KIB has denied the allegations in the letter, which was issued on November 4.

site_title: Modi seeks funding to build smarter Indian cities post Covid-19
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks foreign investment to modernize the country's urban centers, aiming to develop technology and transport to address growing urbanization post-Covid-19. The government plans to raise funds for 800 million square meters of urban development by 2030, with a focus on smart cities. Modi has completed two-thirds of its planned $30 billion projects and aims to complete 10 million urban homes and 1,000 kilometers of railway lines in the next two years, offering investment opportunities in urbanization.

images.alt_text: "We are looking at a future where a major chunk of education, healthcare, shopping, may happen online," said Mr Modi, adding that "our cities need to be ready".

site_title: Prudential plans to hire up to 500 more financial consultants in 2021
summary: Prudential Singapore plans to hire up to 500 new financial consultants in 2021, with a focus on mid-career individuals and fresh graduates. The new hires will undergo training programs, including a two-year competency and skilling course, and receive a monthly allowance. The move comes amid growing awareness of insurance due to the COVID-19 downturn, with the life insurance industry seeing a 2% decline in new business sales in the first nine months of the year. Other industry players, such as AIA Singapore and China Life Insurance, have also announced plans to hire more consultants.

site_title: Bukit Pasoh shophouse up for sale with S$10.5m guide price
summary: A 2.5-storey shophouse at 6 Bukit Pasoh Road in Singapore's Central Business District is up for sale with a guide price of S$10.5 million, translating to S$3,750 per square foot. The property, located near Outram Park MRT interchange, has a total floor area of 2,800 sq ft and is zoned for full commercial use. Foreigners are eligible to buy, and the sale will not incur additional buyer's stamp duty. The property is currently leased to two tenants, with the ground floor leased to a bakery cafe and the upper floors leased to a fintech firm.

site_title: Delfi Q3 topline falls 16.4% yoy, but sees uptick from Q2
summary: Delfi Ltd, a Singapore-based chocolate confectionery company, reported a 16.4% year-over-year decline in revenue to US$93.8 million in its third quarter, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's negative impact on global economies. However, revenue showed a 25.4% increase from the second quarter, driven by growth in its premium format category and the relaunch of value products. Despite a 58.4% year-over-year decline in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA), the company remains optimistic about its future growth prospects.

site_title: Japan Airlines raises more than expected US$1.8b in new share sale
summary: Japan Airlines has raised more than expected $1.8 billion in a new share sale, exceeding its initial target of $1.7 billion. The airline issued 100 million new shares, equivalent to 30% of its existing shares, to strengthen its finances amid the coronavirus pandemic. The shares rose 7% since the announcement, driven by hopes for a swift global economic recovery. The sale priced at 1,916 yen, 3% lower than the previous close, and will help offset the dilution of existing shares.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index losing 0.3%. The decline followed a mixed showing in Asia. The drop was attributed to increased British inflation data, which saw an increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.40 points to 1,604.75. The index saw 14.414 billion lots traded worth RM5.088 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 731 to 473.

site_title: UK, EU inch closer to Brexit deal as yet another deadline looms
summary: The UK and EU are inching closer to a Brexit trade deal as the deadline to strike an agreement looms. EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is set to brief ambassadors on Friday, with speculation that a deal will be reached. The UK's Business Secretary Alok Sharma hopes to secure a free trade agreement, while the EU is pushing for level playing field guarantees. A major breakthrough is needed in the next seven to 10 days for the European Parliament to ratify the deal, with the UK parliament also required to debate and ratify the agreement before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: UK's chief negotiator David Frost was reported to have said that the deal could be agreed by Tuesday.

site_title: Aviva Singlife to issue S$550m subordinated notes
summary: Aviva Singlife Holdings Pte Ltd, a newly formed holding company, has priced S$550 million of 10.25-year callable subordinated notes at 3.375% per cent. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on November 24, 2020, with a first call date of February 24, 2026. The proceeds will be used for funding the purchase price and capital adequacy purposes. The notes have a 101% redemption option if the acquisition is not completed within three months of the issue date. Fitch Ratings has assigned ASH a BBB+ long-term issuer default rating with a stable outlook.

site_title: Centurion Corp secures master lease for 5,000-bed dorm in Selangor
summary: Centurion Corp secured a master lease for a 5,000-bed dormitory in Selangor, Malaysia, through Knight Frank Malaysia from the Selangor State Development Corporation. The lease, starting Dec 1, 2020, for 21 years, expands the group's purpose-built workers accommodation portfolio to eight properties with 35,700 beds under its Westlite Accommodation brand.

site_title: Flexible work, the new normal, should spur, not hamper, productivity
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is driving companies to adopt flexible work arrangements, with many adopting remote work options. Two local banks, UOB and DBS, have announced plans to offer flexible work arrangements, with UOB's 26,000-strong workforce able to work remotely two days a week and DBS's 29,000-strong staff able to work from home up to 40% of the time. Standard Chartered has also planned to offer flexible work arrangements to 90% of its 85,000 staff. Companies must rethink their work design and management approach to accommodate flexible working, with a focus on trust, empowerment, and performance-based direction.

site_title: US housing starts beat expectations in October
summary: US housing starts rose 4.9% in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.530 million units, beating expectations. This uptick suggests the housing market remains resilient despite economic strain and a resurgence of new Covid-19 infections. The October increase was partly attributed to a revised September pace of 1.459 million units, which was initially reported as 1.415 million. The increase in housing starts is attributed to historically low mortgage rates.

site_title: UN recruits 40 airlines to deliver vaccine to poorest nations
summary: The UN's humanitarian agency Unicef is recruiting 40 airlines to help distribute a coronavirus vaccine to the world's poorest nations through a global airlift. Unicef held a call with the airlines to identify their commercial tasks and plan the airlift. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) helped arrange the meeting. This effort aims to increase vaccine accessibility to underserved areas.

site_title: CDL hotel arm reviewing portfolio, assessing at least three offers for assets
summary: CDL's hotel arm, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), is reviewing its portfolio and may sell assets to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. At least three offers have been received, with some subject to re-zoning and regulatory approval. M&C expects to conclude at least one sale by 2021, based on current offers. This move aims to drive growth and recovery for the company.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to buy Institutional Shareholder Services
summary: Deutsche Boerse agreed to buy a majority stake in Institutional Shareholder Services for $2.3 billion, valuing the corporate governance provider. The deal aims to capitalize on the growing demand for sustainable investing and will pair ISS's services with Deutsche Boerse's index business. Revenue synergies are expected to generate an additional 15 million euros in earnings by 2023. The acquisition is expected to boost Deutsche Boerse's earnings and shares rose 3.6% to 138.40 euros after the announcement.

site_title: HSBC lets Hong Kong staff work up to four days a week from home
summary: HSBC is allowing Hong Kong staff to work up to four days a week from home, offering greater flexibility as the pandemic transforms office work. The move is part of a larger trend among global and regional lenders adapting to a new normal. HSBC joins rivals like Standard Chartered and DBS Group Holdings in offering flexible work options, with some predicting that staff will work about half their time from home even after the pandemic passes.

site_title: Regional centres take centre stage
summary: Regional centers in Singapore, including Paya Lebar, Buona Vista, and Jurong East, are becoming key commercial hubs. Decentralization plans, accelerated by the pandemic, have led to increased investment in these areas, with residential homes and employment nodes growing together. Average unit prices in these areas have risen significantly, with Paya Lebar up 18.6% and Buona Vista up 29.5% from 2015 to 2020. Jurong East, conceptualized as Singapore's second CBD, also shows potential for growth, with existing projects showing price appreciation. The story of growth is far from finished, with prospects for new development and existing homes remaining positive.

site_title: Apple to cut App Store fees in half for most developers
summary: Apple is cutting the App Store fee in half for most developers, from 30% to 15%, for those who earn up to $1 million annually. The change, effective January 1, aims to help small developers financially amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The new structure applies to the "vast majority" of developers who charge for apps and in-app purchases, except for major apps like Netflix and Spotify. The move is part of Apple's App Store Small Business Programme, designed to support small businesses and enable them to invest in their businesses.

site_title: BBC appoints former judge to lead Princess Diana interview inquiry
summary: The BBC has appointed a former senior judge to lead an inquiry into how the broadcaster secured a 1995 interview with Princess Diana, following accusations from her brother that she was tricked into taking part. The inquiry comes after Charles Spencer alleged the BBC used forged documents and deceit to secure the interview. The 1995 interview, watched by 20 million viewers, saw Diana admit to an affair and intimate details about her marriage to Prince Charles. The inquiry aims to investigate the BBC's handling of the interview.

site_title: Sharp to return to Japan's blue chip index, replacing Docomo
summary: Sharp will return to Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average, replacing NTT Docomo, effective December 2. This move comes after Docomo's delisting, following a US$40 billion tender offer by Nippon Telegraph & Telephone. Sharp, which was removed from the index in 2016, has undergone a turnaround under Foxconn Technology Group's management, posting largely consistent profits. The addition is seen as a surprise, with some analysts expressing doubts about Sharp's suitability.

site_title: Lloyds resumes plan to axe 56 branches
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has resumed plans to close 56 branches across its brands, impacting 160 jobs. The decision, which was initially shelved due to the Covid-19 pandemic, was met with criticism from union Unite, calling it "unjustified and damaging." This move comes after the bank cut over 1,000 jobs earlier this month.

images.alt_text: Lloyds Banking Group has resumed plans to close 56 branches across its own, Halifax and Bank of Scotland brands, impacting 160 jobs, union Unite said in a statement on Wednesday.

site_title: Thai protesters mass again despite violence
summary: Thousands of Thai protesters gathered in Bangkok on November 18, 2020, despite the violence from the previous day, when police used water cannon and tear gas, injuring at least 55 people. The youth-led protests, demanding the ousting of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, a new constitution, and reforms to curb the monarchy's powers, continued. A proposal to discuss the monarchy's role in the constitution failed to gain enough votes in parliament, with protesters vowing to resist peacefully.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.49% to 26,544.29, driven by lingering optimism over strong vaccine trial results and hopes for a return to normalcy in the new year. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.22%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.34%.

site_title: Bigger BTO flats in Bishan and Toa Payoh heavily oversubscribed in one day despite website glitches
summary: In Singapore, the Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 5,700 BTO flats and 5,220 Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) on November 17, despite website glitches. Despite issues, the bigger flats in Bishan and Toa Payoh were oversubscribed just one day after launch. The most in-demand flats were five-room units in Toa Payoh's Bartley Beacon, with over 5 applicants per unit, while four-room flats in Bishan Ridges drew 2,606 applicants. Applications close on November 23, and flats will be allocated through balloting.

images.alt_text: Bigger Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Bishan and Toa Payoh (Bidadari) have been oversubscribed just one day after their launch, even as buyers faced issues submitting applications on the Housing Board website.

site_title: Bitcoin breaks US$18,000 as rally powers on, all-time high in sight
summary: Bitcoin reached a new year-to-date peak of US$18,175, breaking through the US$18,000 barrier, as its rally shows no signs of slowing. The cryptocurrency has gained over 160% this year, with a 17% surge in the last three days. It is now close to its all-time high of just under US$20,000. The price increase is driven by demand for Bitcoin as an inflation hedge and expectations of mainstream acceptance.

site_title: GM warns labour unrest making South Korea untenable
summary: General Motors (GM) has warned that persistent industrial unrest in South Korea could drive it out of the country, just two years after receiving a state-backed rescue package. The strikes, which began on October 30, have resulted in 17,000 lost vehicles in production, with a total of 20,000 by the end of the week. GM Korea's operating loss was 332 billion won in 2019, and the company is struggling to meet production targets due to the strikes. GM management wants a two-year labor deal, while the union wants a one-year deal.

site_title: Health Check: Lung cancer, what you need to know (Ep 48)
summary: Lung cancer remains a major health concern in Singapore, being the No. 1 killer among all cancer types globally. Dr. Philip Eng, a senior consultant respiratory physician, discusses advancements in lung cancer treatment, including keyhole surgery, stereotactic radiotherapy, and immunotherapy. He also emphasizes the importance of minimizing risk factors, such as quitting smoking, and highlights innovations like proton beam therapy. The episode aims to educate listeners on how to protect themselves against the high costs of treatments, with advice to buy extra insurance coverage when young and fit.

site_title: Aviva Singlife to issue S$550m subordinated notes
summary: Aviva Singlife Holdings Pte Ltd (ASH) has priced S$550 million of 10.25-year callable subordinated notes at 3.375% per cent, with the first call date set for Feb 24, 2026. The proceeds will fund the purchase price and capital adequacy purposes. ASH, formed through the merger of Aviva Ltd's Singapore operations with Singapore Life, expects to maintain a strong capital buffer to withstand market competition. The deal mirrors a global trend of private equity firms investing in insurance businesses.

site_title: Petronas seeking deal ideas for US$23b stock portfolio
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil and gas major, is seeking deal ideas for its US$23 billion stake in its Kuala Lumpur-listed companies. The company has asked banks to submit proposals for secondary share placements or issuing exchangeable bonds. Petronas owns stakes in five listed companies and is unlikely to reduce its stakes below 50%. This move comes after the company raised RM6 billion last year by cutting stakes in three other companies. Deliberations are still early, and there is no guarantee that Petronas will proceed with the transaction.

site_title: Boeing MAX cleared to fly as FAA lifts long grounding
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has cleared Boeing's 737 MAX to fly after an extensive package of fixes, ending the longest grounding of a jetliner in US history. The 20-month hiatus was prompted by fatal crashes, and the FAA's decision allows airlines to resume passenger service with the plane. Boeing shares rose 5.3% to $221.27 in pre-market trading, marking a significant turnaround from a 50% loss in value since the 2019 crash. The move sets the stage for global regulators to also lift the grounding.

site_title: Probe into Starburst Holdings chairman, MD related to corrupt transactions with agents
summary: Starburst Holdings' chairman, Edward Lim Chin Wah, and managing director, Yap Tin Foo, are being investigated by Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) for "corrupt transactions with agents". The investigation, related to wholly-owned unit Starburst Engineering Pte Ltd, has led to the trio being arrested and placed on bail. The CPIB is also investigating senior project manager Josiah Lawrence Ng Eng Long for abetting an offence under the Prevention of Corruption Act. The company has handed over records and documents to the CPIB and will continue to monitor the investigation's progress.

site_title: National Australia Bank closes all branches over 'security threat'
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) temporarily closed all its branches and attached offices in Australia due to a "physical security threat". The closures were made after several branches in Queensland reported bomb threats. Police are investigating the incidents, and NAB is inspecting all branches to ensure their safety before reopening. The bank's online banking services remain operational, and it plans to reopen branches progressively once deemed safe.

site_title: Singapore Customs launches electronic Bankers' Guarantee programme
summary: Singapore Customs has launched an electronic Bankers' Guarantee (eBG) programme on the Networked Trade Platform (NTP), allowing banks and traders to experience a paperless process for BG transactions. The programme, piloted since March, has seen a high conversion rate and now accounts for 65% of BGs issued by participating banks. The eBG programme guarantees data authenticity, reduces processing lead time to one day, and improves efficiency, with all BGs issued since its launch being electronic. This move aims to facilitate smoother transactions and increase productivity through digitalisation.

site_title: Delfi Q3 topline falls 16.4%, but sees uptick from Q2
summary: Delfi, a chocolate confectionery company, reported a 16.4% decline in Q3 revenue to US$93.8 million, down from US$112.2 million in the same quarter last year. The company attributed the decline to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on economies and businesses globally. Revenue from Indonesia and regional markets also fell, with declines of 22.2% and 2.9%, respectively. The company described the year as "turbulent" due to the pandemic.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 5 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, for the 8th consecutive day. The cases, 3 work permit holders from Myanmar, 1 student pass holder from India, and 1 short-term visit pass holder from Bangladesh, were asymptomatic when tested. All close contacts have been isolated and will be tested during their quarantine period. 7 cases were discharged, leaving 58,031 recovered and 33 in hospital. The total cases in Singapore now stand at 58,135.

site_title: Waste management startup Blue Planet bags US$10m from Sysma
summary: Singapore-based waste management startup Blue Planet Environmental Solutions has secured a US$10 million investment from construction and property development firm Sysma Holdings. The investment will accelerate Blue Planet's efforts to deploy sustainable waste management solutions across Asia. The partnership marks Sysma's entry into the sustainability sector, with plans to integrate environmental, social, and governance considerations into its business strategy. Blue Planet aims to create an accessible platform of technologies to upcycle or recycle different streams of waste, recovering valuable resources and mitigating carbon emissions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on hopes of Fed's policy support; rising virus cases weigh
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.26% on Wednesday, closing at 2,545.64, driven by hopes of additional stimulus from the US Federal Reserve. However, rising Covid-19 cases and tougher coronavirus-related curbs at home capped gains. The benchmark Kospi reversed a 0.15% decline in the previous session. Foreigners were net buyers for the 10th straight session, purchasing 5.2 trillion won worth of shares. The won gained, while the benchmark bond yield fell, closing at 0.951% after falling 0.9 basis points.

site_title: New centre in Jiangsu to help Singapore biomed startups tap Chinese market
summary: Singapore has launched a new centre in the China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park to help biomedical firms tap the Chinese market. The A*Star Partners' Centre aims to facilitate collaboration between Singapore and Jiangsu, with nine firms setting up operations there. The centre offers cost savings, funding support, and market access programs to help Singaporean biomedical startups expand into the Yangtze River Delta region. The move is seen as a way for Singapore to deepen collaboration with Jiangsu post-Covid-19, with bilateral trade between the two growing 1.6% year on year to reach $9 billion.

site_title: Australia: Financials push shares to near nine-month high; NZ snaps 11-day rally
summary: Australian shares reached a near nine-month high, closing 0.5% higher at 6,531.1, driven by a strong financial sector after Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe assured rising house prices aren't a cause for concern. New Zealand's benchmark index snapped an 11-day winning streak, falling 1.2% after a2 Milk's revenue forecast uncertainty weighed on the market.

site_title: COE prices close mostly higher
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mostly higher in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$37,690, up from S$35,990. The premium for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$41,101, and the Open COE premium ended at S$41,503. The Land Transport Authority announced a 5.8% increase in COE quotas for the November to January period. Commercial vehicle COE prices dropped, while motorcycle premiums rose slightly. The average monthly quota increased by 7.1% to 6,649.

site_title: Robinsons owes S$32m to creditors; largest claims from landlords, employees
summary: Robinsons Singapore, under provisional liquidation, owes S$31.7 million to 442 creditors, with the largest claims from landlords (S$7.2m to Swee Cheng Holdings) and employees (S$4.4m). Other notable creditors include mattress brands (tens of thousands of dollars) and the publisher of The Business Times (S$60,000). A creditors' meeting will be held on Nov 26 to discuss the debt.

site_title: Three landed homes in Telok Kurau up for collective sale with S$25m reserve price
summary: Three freehold landed homes in Telok Kurau will be put up for collective sale via tender with a S$25 million reserve price. The sites have a combined land area of 18,507 sq ft, zoned for residential use with a plot ratio of 1.4. The reserve price translates to a land rate of S$902 per sq ft per plot ratio, with a total gross floor area of 27,724 sq ft. The site, near East Coast Road, is expected to attract strong interest due to its location and potential for a boutique private residential project.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as virus cases soar
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on November 18, 2020, after Japan's capital logged a record daily number of coronavirus cases. The Nikkei 225 index lost 1.10% to 25,728.14 and the Topix index slipped 0.81% to 1,720.65.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday after the Japanese capital logged a record daily number of coronavirus cases.

site_title: Aspen, eyeing promotion to mainboard, completes share placement
summary: Aspen Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has completed a share placement of 100 million new ordinary shares at 23.8 Singapore cents per share, raising S$23.8 million. The placement aims to meet minimum shareholding spread requirements for promotion to the Singapore Exchange's mainboard and strengthen its financial position. Funds will be used for glove manufacturing facility construction and general working capital, with production expected to start by the subsequent quarter. Aspen's total issued share capital now stands at 1.08 billion shares, with the placement shares representing 9.23% of this.

site_title: Cases of wine piling up in Australia as China shuns imports
summary: Australia's wine exporters face a critical period as China, its largest market, clamps down on shipments due to trade probes and a sweeping ban on imports. Wine stockpiles are piling up in warehouses, with orders from China being cancelled and shipments delayed at customs. The ban, which affects 80% of Royal Star Wine's clients, has resulted in a financial hit of A$200,000 to A$300,000. The situation is a worst-case scenario for exporters, who are already reeling from the impact of Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Thai central bank keeps key rate at record low but says economic recovery fragile
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, kept its key interest rate at a record low of 0.50% for a fourth consecutive meeting, citing a fragile economic recovery due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a better-than-expected third quarter, the economy is expected to contract by a record 7.8% this year, with limited policy room to act. The recovery remains fragile and uncertain, with a ban on foreign tourists and a strong baht expected to weigh on the tourism-reliant economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore civil servants were underpaid by S$10 million due to HR errors, the Public Service Division said in a statement. Prudential Singapore plans to hire up to 500 more financial consultants in 2021. Department store Robinsons Singapore owes S$31.7 million to creditors, including landlords and employees. Fund managers Quarz and Black Crane are pushing for Sabana Reit unitholders to vote against a proposed merger. The Singapore Customs has launched an electronic Bankers' Guarantee programme. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for a third consecutive day, driven by hopes of Singapore's economic recovery.

site_title: Indonesia minister hopes Q4 GDP to be within -1.6% to +0.6% range
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister Airlangga Hartarto forecast the country's GDP to be within -1.6% to 0.6% for the fourth quarter, indicating a continued recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The economy shrank 5.32% and 3.49% in the second and third quarters, respectively. Hartarto expressed optimism about the fourth quarter, citing a potential increase in investment as a key factor.

site_title: Bukit Pasoh shophouse for sale with S$10.5m guide price
summary: A shophouse in Singapore's Bukit Pasoh Road is up for sale with a guide price of S$10.5 million, translating to about S$3,750 per square foot. The 2.5-storey property has a total floor area of 2,800 sq ft and is zoned for full commercial use. Foreigners are eligible to buy, and the sale will not incur additional buyer's stamp duty. The property is within walking distance to residential development Pinnacle@Duxton and is currently leased to two tenants. The tender closes on Dec 17.

site_title: Nissan's UK business tough to sustain without Brexit trade deal: COO
summary: Nissan's UK business is at risk of becoming unsustainable without a Brexit trade deal, according to the company's COO. A no-deal Brexit could lead to increased tariffs, higher production costs, and potential delays in parts supply, threatening the livelihoods of 7,000 Nissan employees at its Sunderland plant. Nissan has urged for an "orderly balanced Brexit" and is not seeking compensation from Britain for costs incurred from a no-deal Brexit. The company remains committed to its UK operations, including a £52 million expansion plan, but a deal is essential to sustain its business.

site_title: Amundi and BNP vie for SocGen asset manager Lyxor: sources
summary: Amundi and BNP Paribas are vying for Societe Generale's asset management business, Lyxor, worth 500 million to 700 million euros. The sale is expected to start this year and will see Societe Generale hand over its 150 billion euro ETF business. French asset manager Amundi is seen as the natural buyer, but BNP Paribas Asset Management will face competition on its home turf. The sale is part of Societe Generale's efforts to overhaul its retail and markets activities and sell non-core businesses under pressure from its CEO, Frederic Oudea.

site_title: STI up for third straight session on Singapore's economic recovery hopes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for a third consecutive day, gaining 10.04 points or 0.36% to 2,788.59. The gains were driven by DBS' optimistic outlook for Singapore's 2021 economy, which cited a GDP recovery, accommodative monetary policy, and a fiscal budget. Real estate developers CapitaLand and City Developments led the gains, while Jardine Matheson and Jardine Strategic were among the biggest losers. Regional markets finished mixed, with Asian markets showing resilience despite a wait-and-see mode.

site_title: Financial comparison site GET.com takes a holiday
summary: GET.com, a financial comparison site, has ceased operations due to a refocusing of time on other projects. The site, which allowed users to compare credit cards and rewards, had been active since 2011 and had expanded to include articles on travel, property, and entertainment. The company's CEO, Pedro Pla, cited the Covid-19 pandemic as a reason for the site's demise, stating that plans for a travel-oriented site were scuppered. The site's website and app are no longer accessible, and users are redirected to a message stating that "something new is cooking".

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane plan EGM requisition to approve internalisation of Sabana Reit manager
summary: Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital plan to requisition an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for Sabana Reit to approve the internalisation of its manager. The move comes after the proposed merger of Sabana Reit with ESR-Reit falls through. The internalisation aims to increase the distribution per unit (DPU) by 7.5% and align the interests of all unitholders by removing ESR conflicts. The fund managers also plan to close the substantial NAV discount by improving Sabana Reit's performance or selling its portfolio and returning surplus capital to unitholders.

site_title: Unilever eyes 1b euros in sales for plant-based food boom
summary: Unilever aims to boost plant-based food sales fivefold to €1 billion in the next five to seven years through its Vegetarian Butcher brand and vegan versions of popular products. The company also plans to halve food waste by 2025 and double nutritious products by 2025. This move comes as consumers increasingly seek healthier and environmentally friendly foods, driven by climate change and health concerns. Unilever's president, Hanneke Faber, believes plant-based options are becoming a key area of focus for consumers, with the company set to expand its offerings and use its brands to encourage sustainable eating habits.

site_title: Singapore civil servants underpaid by S$10m due to HR errors
summary: Singapore's Public Service Division (PSD) has discovered that around 3,000 civil servants, 2% of the total, were underpaid by approximately S$10 million due to human error in HR records over the past two decades. The errors were primarily related to inaccuracies in Full-Time National Service (FTNS) duration records and IT algorithms used to calculate medical leave wages. The PSD will rectify the errors and make good the shortfalls, with affected individuals to be notified and contacted through various means, and will also review HR records of statutory boards to ensure accuracy.

site_title: South Australia announces six-day 'circuit-breaker' lockdown
summary: South Australia has announced a six-day "circuit-breaker" lockdown to contain a coronavirus cluster in its capital city, with nearly 2 million residents affected. The lockdown, which started on November 18, 2020, includes closing schools, restaurants, and factories, while stay-at-home orders are in place. Mandatory mask-wearing and ban on weddings and funerals are also enforced. The state aims to halt transmission chains and avoid a lengthy Melbourne-style lockdown, with international flights suspended and thousands of close contacts self-isolating.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher, with the Hang Seng Index edging up 0.07% to 26,434.24, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The gains were tempered by profit-taking, and Asian markets saw mixed results with the Shanghai Composite Index easing 0.08% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipping 0.17%.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher Wednesday morning, though the gains were tempered by profit-taking following a negative lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Green finance gains among developers as CapitaLand, Tong Eng obtain loans
summary: Singapore property developers are turning to green finance as more companies seek to support sustainability-related properties. CapitaLand and Tong Eng obtained green loans totaling S$323 million to finance their green-certified business park developments in India. DBS Bank and HSBC issued the loans, which align with the Asia Pacific Loan Market Association's Green Loan Principles. This trend is seen as a significant step towards Singapore's goal of becoming a regional sustainable financing hub, with DBS' group head of institutional banking stating that the bank sees "immense potential" for growth in Asia's sustainable financing market.

site_title: UK green bonds offer belated boost to London's ESG ambitions
summary: The UK is set to enter Europe's booming green sovereign bond market with its first green gilt, expected to be issued in the first quarter of 2021. This move aims to boost London's ambitions of becoming the continent's ethical investing hub. The UK government's plans, including a 10-point "green industrial revolution" plan, are expected to kick-start debt sales in sterling, which currently make up less than 3% of the global green bond market. The UK's entry is seen as a catalyst for broader corporate issuance and could provide cheaper financing for the government's plans.

site_title: Australia: Shares at nine-month high as cenbank comments lift financials
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to a nine-month high, reaching 6,532 points, after Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe said the country was "on the road back" from the pandemic. Lowe also stated that rising home prices are not a cause for concern due to weak demand. Gold stocks advanced as global Covid-19 cases surged, lifting bullion prices.

site_title: At least 55 hurt in Thailand's most violent protests since new movement emerged
summary: At least 55 people were injured, with 32 suffering from teargas and six with gunshot wounds, in clashes between protesters and police outside Thailand's parliament. The protesters, demanding constitutional reform and the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, clashed with royalist counter-protesters and police using water cannons and teargas. The protest movement, which emerged in July, is the biggest challenge to Thailand's establishment in years.

images.alt_text: At least 55 people were hurt, some with gunshot wounds, when demonstrators marching on the Thai parliament clashed with police and royalist counter-protesters, in the worst violence since a new youth-led protest movement emerged in July.

site_title: Covid-19 insurance now available for inbound travellers to Singapore
summary: Foreign visitors entering Singapore can now purchase inbound travel insurance coverage for Covid-19 related costs, with three insurers offering plans starting from S$5.35. The insurance provides at least S$30,000 in coverage for medical treatment and hospitalization costs. This move aims to encourage traveller confidence and provide peace of mind as Singapore reopens for safe travel. The insurance plans can be purchased directly from the insurers through their websites.

site_title: HKTDC pushing for transition to digital-sourcing models
summary: The Hong Kong Trade Development Council (HKTDC) is pushing traders to transition to digital-sourcing models with its newly upgraded sourcing platform, hktdc.com Sourcing. The move comes as the COVID-19 pandemic has led to the cancellation or rescheduling of over 4,000 physical exhibitions worldwide, affecting deals worth an estimated US$296 billion. The platform, which has attracted over 130,000 suppliers and 2 million buyers, aims to enhance suppliers' visibility and facilitate buyers' sourcing activities. The HKTDC has also seen a 20% increase in buyers visiting the platform from April to July 2020.

site_title: JPMorgan indices exclude new debt from sanctioned Chinese firms
summary: JPMorgan Chase has announced that its widely followed debt indices will exclude new bonds from Chinese companies sanctioned by the US government, following President Donald Trump's executive order on November 12. Existing bonds of these companies will remain in the indices, but their eligibility will be re-evaluated. The move aims to avoid new investments in companies linked to the Chinese military, potentially impacting global investors and liquidity in sanctioned bonds. The US Department of Defense has added 16 Chinese firms to its list of companies with links to the military, with JPMorgan estimating that its JACI index will be most impacted.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co's widely followed debt indices will exclude new bonds from Chinese companies that fall under sanctions announced last week by Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Bitcoin hits nearly three-year peak, homes in on record
summary: Bitcoin reached its nearly three-year peak, reaching $17,868, with a 6.1% gain. The asset has climbed 150% this year and 360% from its March lows, driven by inflation hedge narrative and mainstream acceptance. Analysts, including Citi's Tom Fitzpatrick, predict it could reach $318,000. The cryptocurrency's scarcity and potential for widespread adoption as a means of payment are also contributing to its surge.

site_title: Crown asked to delay gaming operations at New Sydney casino
summary: Crown Resorts' US$1.5 billion Sydney casino opening has been put on hold due to concerns about the company's suitability to run the gaming operation. The New South Wales Independent Liquor and Gaming Authority has urged Crown to postpone gaming activities until a money-laundering inquiry concludes in February. The inquiry has revealed "extremely concerning" evidence about Crown's governance and anti-money laundering controls, and the authority fears that gaming activity could pose unacceptable risks to the community. The license to operate the casino is at stake, and Crown shares have fallen 20% this year.

images.alt_text: Next month's opening of Crown Resorts' US$1.5 billion Sydney casino has been thrown into turmoil after authorities urged the company to postpone gaming operations while a money-laundering inquiry continues.

site_title: Food Market Hub raises US$4m in Series A funding from Go-Ventures and SIG
summary: Malaysia-based Food Market Hub has secured US$4 million in Series A funding from Go-Ventures and SIG. The platform, which automates F&B procurement and inventory management, plans to expand into Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam. Founded in 2017, Food Market Hub already supports over 2,000 F&B outlets in Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, with annual purchase orders exceeding US$200 million. The funding will help strengthen its position in Malaysia and facilitate rapid expansion into Southeast Asia.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% to 2,780.76. The gain was driven by a slight positive territory despite US equities retreating from recent highs. Gainers outpaced losers 72 to 46, with 136.1 million securities worth S$78.8 million changing hands. The STI has now recorded a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: SoftBank's Son wants to deploy cash on public and private firms
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son is liquidating assets to deploy approximately $80 billion in cash for investment opportunities and share buybacks. The move is partly due to concerns over the global spread of the coronavirus. This marks the first time SoftBank has quickly sold assets in its history. Son vowed to stick with his big bets on technology companies despite the move into cash.

site_title: Daimler to develop next-generation engines with China's Geely
summary: Daimler, a German car maker, has partnered with China's Geely to develop next-generation combustion engines for hybrid vehicles. The companies aim to share development costs amid the COVID-19 crisis and stricter fuel-efficiency and emission rules. The new modular engine is expected to be highly efficient and will be manufactured in Europe and China, primarily for use in hybrid drivetrains.

site_title: US travel spending will plunge in 2020, not fully recover until 2024: travel group
summary: US travel spending is expected to plummet by over $500 billion in 2020, with a decline of nearly 40% in business travel, according to the US Travel Association. The industry has lost 3.5 million jobs, and another 1 million could be lost by year-end without government relief. Travel spending is not expected to recover to pre-coronavirus levels until 2024.

site_title: Asia: Traders cautious as vaccine hopes offset by virus surge
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Wednesday, but traders remained cautious due to surging COVID-19 cases and concerns over a potential economic slowdown. Despite vaccine breakthroughs by Pfizer, BioNTech, and Moderna, analysts warned of a "challenging" few months ahead. US lawmakers' failure to agree on a stimulus package and rising virus cases in the US and Europe fueled concerns, leading to a mixed market with some gains and losses across Asia.

site_title: Hottest Internet stock in India surging despite valuation fears
summary: Info Edge India, the parent company of Naukri.com and Zomato, has surged to a record high despite valuation fears. The company's investments in startups are expected to pay off, driven by optimism about a coronavirus vaccine shifting away from technology shares. Info Edge's niche position in India and its bets on technology and e-commerce trends are attracting buyers, with the stock trading at over 125 times analysts' 12-month forward estimated earnings. Despite concerns over the stock's valuation, analysts see tremendous growth potential in the internet and technology theme.

site_title: Malaysia's PNB to sell 56% stake in chemicals firm for RM292.8m
summary: Malaysia's Permodalan Nasional Bhd (PNB) is selling its 56.3% stake in Chemical Company of Malaysia (CCM) to Batu Kawan Berhad for RM292.8 million. The deal is part of PNB's asset diversification strategy to rebalance its portfolio. CCM's shares rose 7.2% on the first day of trading after the announcement. The sale will trigger a mandatory general offer by Batu Kawan for the remaining shares, but the acquirer plans to maintain the listing status of CCM.

site_title: Elon Musk leapfrogs Mark Zuckerberg to become world's third-richest person
summary: Elon Musk has become the world's third-richest person after his electric carmaker Tesla was included in the S&P 500 Index, surpassing Mark Zuckerberg. Musk, 49, achieved this milestone amidst a busy few days, including testing positive for Covid-19 and launching four astronauts into space. The inclusion in the S&P 500 Index also marked Tesla's formal entry into the Indian market. Musk's net worth has increased significantly, making him the third-richest person globally, according to Forbes.

site_title: Economic recovery in 2021 possible, but requires greater regional cooperation: PECC
summary: The Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) predicts a possible economic recovery in 2021, but warns that regional cooperation is crucial to restore confidence for a sustainable recovery. Asia-Pacific economies are expected to shrink by 3.1% in 2020 and grow 5% in 2021, but the risk of protectionism and slowing trade growth may weigh on confidence. The pandemic has also exacerbated income inequality and hindered poverty reduction efforts, with the World Bank warning that it could wipe out all poverty reduction achievements over the past five years.

site_title: Taiwan grounds all F16 jets after one goes missing
summary: Taiwan has grounded all its F16 fighter jets for safety checks after one went missing during a training exercise. The incident is the latest in a string of air crashes involving the jets, which are old and outgunned by China. The grounding affects around 150 planes and leaves Taiwan relying on a limited fleet to deter Chinese jets that have been buzzing the island at an unprecedented rate. The incident is a concern for Taiwan, which lives under the threat of invasion by China and relies on its military for defense.

site_title: Prudential Singapore plans to hire up to 500 more financial consultants in 2021
summary: Prudential Singapore plans to hire up to 500 new financial consultants in 2021, exceeding this year's target. The move aims to capitalize on growing interest in insurance amid the Covid-19 downturn. The company will hire mid-career individuals and fresh graduates through a two-year training program, offering a monthly allowance of up to S$10,000. This announcement follows similar plans from other industry players, including AIA Singapore and China Life Insurance, to create new career opportunities in the face of economic uncertainty.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to host online G-20 summit amid pandemic, recession
summary: Saudi Arabia hosts the first-ever virtual G-20 summit, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic and economic recession, on November 21. The two-day online meeting will focus on pressing global issues, including the pandemic's implications and steps to revive the global economy. The summit comes amid criticism of the G-20's inadequate response to the crisis, with campaigners calling for more action to help developing nations. Despite concerns over security, human rights, and mistrust among member states, the event aims to promote "digital diplomacy" and showcase Saudi Arabia's modernization drive.

site_title: China's irritated trade partners push back on coronavirus food tests
summary: China's trade partners, including Canada, Australia, Brazil, Mexico, Britain, and the US, are criticizing China's aggressive testing for the coronavirus on imported food products, calling it "unjustified trade restrictions" and damaging to trade and reputations. Despite the lack of scientific evidence, China has found the virus on products from 20 countries, including German pork, Brazilian beef, and Indian fish. The World Trade Organization (WTO) has been called upon to intervene, with China arguing its actions are based on a scientific basis and designed to protect people's lives.

site_title: US Senate blocks Trump's controversial Federal Reserve candidate
summary: The US Senate blocked President Donald Trump's nomination of Judy Shelton to join the Federal Reserve board, with a vote of 50-47. Two Republicans joined Democrats in opposing her, citing concerns over her unconventional views on monetary policy and her potential to undermine the central bank's independence. Vice President-elect Kamala Harris cast the tie-breaking vote, while Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell voted against her, leaving the door open for a potential second vote. Shelton's nomination was seen as a threat to the Fed's ability to manage the economy during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Kuroda says Bank of Japan's bank aid scheme won't affect yield curve control
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank's new relief scheme for regional lenders will not affect its yield curve control policy. The scheme pays 0.1% interest to lenders that cut costs or consolidate, but Kuroda said it will not impact the BOJ's ability to set short-term interest rates at -0.1% and 10-year government bond yields at around 0%. The BOJ will maintain its massive stimulus program, expecting the economy to continue improving as the coronavirus pandemic recedes, with inflation likely to reach the 2% target.

site_title: Brokers' take: Jefferies downgrades DBS to 'hold' on proposed India deal
summary: DBS Bank has been downgraded to a "hold" by Jefferies Equity Research due to concerns over the proposed amalgamation of ailing Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB) into its wholly-owned India unit. The deal is expected to weigh on DBS's profitability and dividend trajectory in the near to medium term. Jefferies analyst Krishna Guha lowered the target price to S$22 and reduced dividend estimates by about 10%. In contrast, JPMorgan's research team sees the deal as positive, citing DBS's ability to consolidate the franchise and attract deposits.

site_title: CRCT prices preferential offering at S$1.17, upsizes placement
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) priced its preferential offering at S$1.17, an 8.6% discount to Monday's closing price. The non-renounceable offering, part of CRCT's equity fundraising, will raise about S$80.7 million in gross proceeds, with a total of 205.3 million new units issued under a private placement. The equity fundraising aims to partially finance CRCT's acquisition of interests in business parks and a Guangzhou mall, with gross proceeds expected to reach S$326.1 million.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia eyes mainboard listing on SGX
summary: Credit Bureau Asia (CBA) has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a mainboard listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company reported a net profit of S$7 million in FY2019, up 27.3% from the previous year, and revenue rose 8.6% to S$40.6 million. CBA believes it has strong growth prospects due to the issuance of digital banking licenses and the upcoming commencement of the Credit Bureau Act in Singapore. The IPO's net proceeds will be used for organic growth initiatives, strategic investments, and acquisitions.

site_title: Gold inches lower as Covid-19 vaccine optimism weighs on appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,877.39 per ounce, as optimism over a potential Covid-19 vaccine weighed on the market. Concerns over the economic impact of the US coronavirus resurgence limited the decline. Spot gold had dropped 1.3% on Monday after a vaccine trial showed a 94.5% effectiveness rate. Analysts cited a lack of catalyst for gold prices to rally, with the Federal Reserve expected to support the US economy. Gold prices are still up 24% this year due to global stimulus, but may face a break in support at $1,840.

site_title: UK to ban petrol, diesel cars from 2030 in green 'revolution'
summary: The UK will ban the sale of petrol and diesel vehicles from 2030 as part of a 10-point plan to achieve a "green industrial revolution" and become carbon neutral by 2050. The £12 billion plan includes investments in electric vehicles, offshore wind power, hydrogen production, and zero-emission public transport. Prime Minister Boris Johnson hopes the plans will create 250,000 jobs and align with US President-elect Joe Biden's climate priorities. The government will also invest in nuclear power and carbon capture technology, sparking criticism from environmentalists.

images.alt_text: Britain will ban petrol and diesel vehicle sales from 2030 as part of a 10-point plan for a "green industrial revolution" to be unveiled on Wednesday by Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

site_title: World's highest lift zips tourists up China's 'Avatar' cliff
summary: China's Zhangjiajie Forest Park has introduced the world's highest outdoor lift, zipping tourists up a 300-meter cliff face in 88 seconds. The three double-decker elevators deliver breathtaking views to the top of a sandstone rock face that inspired the movie Avatar. The lift, which costs 129 yuan (S$26.43) for a return ticket, is a significant improvement over the previous cable car, which tourists had to wait a long time for. With around 8,000 tourists taking the lift daily, it's a speedy attraction that's helping to boost domestic tourism in China.

site_title: Trump fires US election security official who rejected fraud claims
summary: President Donald Trump fired US cybersecurity official Chris Krebs, who led the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency. Trump accused Krebs of making a "highly inaccurate" statement on election security without evidence. Krebs had been a key figure in debunking election misinformation and ran a website called 'Rumour Control' to counter false claims. His firing was met with praise from security experts, who commended his bipartisan work.

site_title: Walmart reports strong US sales as it retreats from some overseas markets
summary: Walmart reported strong US sales, with the retailer's e-commerce growth accelerating amid the pandemic. The company's omnichannel retail strategy, which combines in-store and online shopping, is gaining traction. However, Walmart is retreating from some overseas markets due to the economic impact of the pandemic. Despite this, executives expect the retailer's e-commerce growth to continue, driven by consumer demand for online shopping. The company's focus on e-commerce and omnichannel retailing is expected to offset the impact of tariffs and economic uncertainty.

site_title: UN chief calls on G-20 for bolder, ambitious pandemic response
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres urged G-20 leaders to adopt a bolder and more ambitious pandemic response, emphasizing the need for debt relief and measures to support developing countries. He called for the recognition of further debt relief, stating that the global recession should not become a global depression. Guterres' letter comes ahead of the G-20 summit in Saudi Arabia this weekend.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engg, DBS, CRCT, Singapore Airlines, SATS, Singtel
summary: ST Engineering expects full-year revenue for 2020 to be near the midpoint of its earlier guidance, a 5-15% decline from 2019. The company will reorganize into two main clusters: Commercial and Defence & Public Security. DBS will invest S$463 million in Lakshmi Vilas Bank if the Reserve Bank of India approves the amalgamation. DBS also announced new work practices as Singapore banks adopt flexi-work.

site_title: Independent US hotels band together to keep giants at bay
summary: A group of independent US hotels, led by Pebblebrook Hotel Trust, is forming Curator Hotel & Resort Collection to reduce costs and prevent properties from being acquired by major hotel chains like Marriott International and Hilton Worldwide Holdings. The new company aims to offer lower fees and short-term contracts, giving owners flexibility and an alternative to joining a major brand. This move comes as the pandemic has severely impacted the hotel industry, with occupancy rates below 45% on average through September.

site_title: Virgin Australia to position itself as mid-market airline: new CEO
summary: Virgin Australia will reposition itself as a mid-market airline under US private equity firm Bain Capital's ownership, targeting around a one-third share of the domestic market. The airline will shift from full-service to mid-market, offering a great value airfare and better service. It will retain business-class seats and airport lounges, but introduce new on-board food purchase options in economy class and retain checked baggage in economy-class fares. The move is expected to give Qantas room to trim product expenses or introduce fees on cheaper fares while maintaining its premium market position.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia will position itself as a mid-market airline targeting around a one-third share of the domestic aviation market under the ownership of US private equity firm Bain Capital, the airline's new chief executive said on Wednesday.

site_title: Safer to freeze some sectors than open too early, says PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to prioritize economic sectors affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, rather than reviving them prematurely. He advised keeping some sectors "in suspended animation" to address risks and consequences, citing aviation, tourism, and entertainment as examples. The government will require spending to support the economy, jobs, and those in need, with a balanced budget unlikely in the near future.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 8.59 points lower, or 0.53%, at 1,601.56, as of 9:06 am on Wednesday. Volume was 722.51 million lots worth RM205.61 million. Gainers beat losers 259 to 176.

site_title: Oil edges lower after settlement as US stockpiles build, pandemic lockdowns loom
summary: Oil prices edged lower after the American Petroleum Institute reported a larger-than-expected increase in US crude stockpiles, fueling concerns about new coronavirus lockdowns. Despite hopes for a vaccine and tighter Opec+ supply policies, Brent futures fell 7 cents to $43.75 a barrel and US crude rose 9 cents to $41.43. The market is waiting for Opec+ to make a recommendation on production levels, which could impact the supply glut.

site_title: Singapore slips from joint top spot of world's costliest cities
summary: Singapore has slipped from its joint top spot as the world's costliest city, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit's Worldwide Cost of Living 2020 report. Paris and Zurich have joined Hong Kong as the costliest cities worldwide, while Singapore and Osaka have dropped due to the coronavirus pandemic weakening the dollar. Tehran jumped 27 places on US sanctions, marking the biggest mover. The pandemic's impact on the dollar was the main factor for cities switching positions, with Singapore and Osaka losing their joint top spot.

site_title: Biden names top White House aides as doctors urge Trump to cooperate on Covid-19
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden named several senior staffers for his White House, including campaign manager Jen O'Malley Dillon as deputy chief of staff. Meanwhile, top coronavirus advisers warned that President Donald Trump's stalling of the official transition could compromise the country's pandemic response. Biden has been preparing to take over the presidency on January 20, despite Trump's efforts to reverse the outcome of the November 3 election. The delay in transition may impact the country's ability to combat the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Joe Biden on Tuesday named several senior staffers for his White House, while his top coronavirus advisers warned that President Donald Trump's stalling of the official transition could compromise the country's pandemic response.

site_title: Singapore banks making flexi-work a permanent post-Covid feature
summary: Singaporean banks are adopting flexible work arrangements as a permanent feature post-Covid-19, with DBS announcing new work practices and UOB introducing a two-day work-from-home policy. This shift aims to adapt to the "new normal" and improve work-life balance. Other financial institutions, such as Citigroup, have also set targets for flexible work arrangements, with some predicting a significant impact on productivity and employee satisfaction.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse snaps up investor adviser ISS
summary: Deutsche Boerse, a German stock market operator, has acquired around 80% of US investor advice firm Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) for $2.3 billion. ISS, valued at $280 million, offers institutional investors recommendations on ESG criteria. The deal, pending regulatory approval, is expected to be completed by April 2021. Deutsche Boerse sees ISS's expertise and data capabilities as aligning with its business model, spanning share trading to data analytics. The acquisition is expected to bring in significant revenue growth for ISS.

site_title: Solomon Islands 'planning Facebook ban'
summary: The Solomon Islands is reportedly planning to ban Facebook amid criticism on the platform, with Communication Minister Peter Shanel Agovaka drafting plans for a temporary ban. The move has sparked outrage among rights groups and opposition figures, who argue it would represent unjustified censorship. Amnesty International warns that such a ban could cost lives, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic. The Solomon Islands would join China, North Korea, and Iran as the only countries to have totally banned Facebook, sparking concerns over human rights and democratic principles.

site_title: Key changes to Boeing's 737 MAX after fatal crashes
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration is set to detail changes for Boeing's 737 MAX jet, 20 months after it was grounded following two fatal crashes. The changes include updates to the stall-prevention system MCAS, which was triggered by faulty data from a single sensor. The FAA will mandate modifications to the system to prevent similar incidents. The 737 MAX is expected to return to commercial flights once the changes are implemented. The FAA's decision marks a significant step towards clearing the plane to fly again.

site_title: Ministers flag need for Apec members to keep supply chains open, work to reopen borders safely
