summary: Singaporean ministers emphasize the need for APEC economies to maintain open supply chains and borders during the Covid-19 pandemic, ensuring a resilient food supply chain and supporting regional economic recovery. The 21 APEC economies have reaffirmed their commitment to advancing regional trade and investment, and a joint statement calls for the safe reopening of borders while preventing the spread of the virus. The ministers also discussed the importance of digital economy transformation and fair access to vaccines.

site_title: US dollar dips as weak trend seen intact; offshore Chinese yuan rises
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-week low against major currencies, influenced by optimism over a second coronavirus vaccine and the Federal Reserve's potential actions to ease economic damage. The euro, sterling, Swiss franc, and yen rose against the US dollar, while the Chinese yuan hit its highest level since June 2018. The US retail sales data showed a less-than-expected rise, with economists attributing the dollar's decline to the ongoing pandemic and the Fed's commitment to supporting the economy.

site_title: Airbnb's IPO doesn't require head-in-sand moment
summary: Airbnb's IPO valuation of over $31 billion is not a stretch despite a 30% revenue drop in the first nine months of the year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's business has recovered relatively, posting a net income of $219 million in the third quarter. Airbnb's focus on vetting and longer-term rentals has helped it outperform rivals, with a lower enterprise-value-to-revenue multiple of 13 times. The company's share structure, which gives voting control to CEO Brian Chesky, may be a concern, but investors may be more accustomed to this in tech companies.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records amid Covid gloom
summary: US stocks retreated from new records on Tuesday, closing lower amid concerns over the spike in coronavirus infections and the impact on the economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6% to 29,783.35, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.5% and 0.2% respectively. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell highlighted the need for caution due to the challenges and uncertainties surrounding the COVID-19 vaccines. Retail sales data showed a disappointing 0.3% increase in October, and analysts noted that stocks have already risen significantly this month.

site_title: UK's Labour readmits Corbyn after brief suspension
summary: The UK's Labour party has reinstated former leader Jeremy Corbyn after a brief suspension, following a disputes panel's decision. Corbyn had been suspended over his response to a watchdog report on anti-Semitism within the party. He acknowledged that concerns were not "exaggerated" and had questioned the motives of an independent probe. Labour leader Keir Starmer expressed disappointment, stating it was "another painful day for the Jewish community." Corbyn's reinstatement has sparked fury within the party, with many lawmakers condemning the decision.

site_title: Troubled Indian bank may fold into DBS' India unit under RBI proposal
summary: DBS Group's India business may acquire troubled Indian bank Lakshmi Vilas Bank under a proposed RBI scheme. The RBI has announced a draft scheme to amalgamate the bank with DBS Bank India Ltd. DBS will inject INR 2,500 crore (S$463 million) into DBIL to support the amalgamation. The RBI has a presence in 24 cities across 13 states. If approved, the scheme will be fully funded from DBS's existing resources, with no additional funding required.

site_title: SIA, Sats climb as vaccine hopes spur rally
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and ground handler Sats saw significant gains as positive news from Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine trials boosted investor confidence. SIA's shares rose 4.91%, while Sats climbed 2.76% to an eight-month high. Analysts at DBS Group Research raised their target prices and earnings forecasts for Sats, citing the potential for international air travel to recover in 2022. Meanwhile, Genting Singapore also rebounded with a quarter-on-quarter earnings increase, with analysts upgrading their ratings to "buy" or "add".

site_title: Agribusiness bonds will do well, with or without vaccine
summary: Agricultural prices have risen sharply due to low production, dry weather, and high demand, supporting a positive outlook for agribusiness bond issuers. The Bloomberg Agriculture Sub-index has climbed 22% between end-June and November 11, outperforming the S&P 500 index. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, hoarding food and disruptions in the food supply chain have benefited companies in the agricultural sector. Asian bond issuers in the agricultural sector have seen an improvement in revenue from higher rubber and palm oil prices. The outlook for agricultural credits remains positive, with good institutional support and a reasonably decent credit profile, despite the uncertainty surrounding the vaccine's deployment and herd immunity.

site_title: StanChart Singapore CEO takes on more markets
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore CEO Patrick Lee will oversee more markets, including Malaysia, Vietnam, and Thailand, as cluster CEO for the Singapore and Asean markets starting January 1, 2021. This change is part of StanChart's new Asia region structure, which groups key markets into seven clusters. Lee's new role replaces Andrew Chia, who will cover other Asean markets. StanChart's other major changes include a new Consumer, Private, and Business Banking business led by Judy Hsu, and a new Europe and Americas region led by Torry Berntsen and Steve Cranwell.

site_title: ST Engineering expects around 10% decline in full-year revenue
summary: ST Engineering expects its full-year revenue to decline around 10% compared to FY2019, according to its third-quarter business update. The company secured S$600 million in aerospace orders and S$1.1 billion in electronics orders in the third quarter. Its order book stands at S$15.8 billion, and the group will focus on capitalizing on new demand from Covid-19, such as cybersecurity and sensors. ST Engineering will also be reorganized into two main clusters: Commercial and Defence & Public Security, starting from the new year.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering secured around S$1.1 billion in new orders for its electronics segment in the third quarter.

site_title: Europe: Stock rally halts as coronavirus restrictions weigh
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% on Tuesday, halting their eight-month rally, as tighter coronavirus restrictions raised doubts about a swift economic rebound. The Stoxx 600 index closed at its lowest level since late February, despite positive data on Covid-19 vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer. Travel stocks declined, while healthcare and tech sectors fell, while growth-linked sectors such as oil and gas and automakers reversed losses. Strategists warn that the economic weakness will persist for several months.

site_title: Special zones help to attract foreign investors
summary: Oman has established five special zones to attract foreign investors, including three free zones and two special economic zones. The zones are designed to leverage Oman's position as a regional manufacturing and distribution base, with incentives such as tax exemptions, subsidies, and custom duties relief. The Duqm Special Economic Zone is the largest in the Middle East region, with a focus on industries like manufacturing, logistics, and tourism. Oman and Singapore bilateral relations are strengthening, with plans to promote investment opportunities and tourism, and to build up bilateral ties through high-level visits and collaborations.

site_title: Indonesia's mass vaccination plan in December faces delay
summary: Indonesia's mass vaccination plan to combat COVID-19 has been delayed due to incomplete data from clinical trials in Brazil and China's Sinovac, according to Indonesia's food and drugs agency. The plan, aiming to start mass vaccinations in December, now may not be achievable until late January. The country needs 246 million vaccine doses for its 270 million population, with Indonesia reporting 15,390 deaths and 474,400 infections linked to COVID-19.

site_title: Asean travel bubble could spur growth, but governments must weigh risks
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is considering establishing a "travel corridor" for essential business travel to help the 10-member bloc recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Indonesian President Joko Widodo has pushed for the initiative, which would require member states to coordinate health and safety protocols. The travel scheme aims to revive Asean's faltering economy, but experts express concerns about the feasibility and timing of the plan due to varying COVID-19 cases across the region.

site_title: Twitter, Facebook defend election rules at heated US hearing
summary: Facebook and Twitter defended their handling of US election misinformation at a congressional hearing, with CEOs Mark Zuckerberg and Jack Dorsey testifying remotely. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham called for new regulations to hold social media giants responsible for content decisions, citing their role in limiting the distribution of a New York Post article about President-elect Joe Biden. Democrats also criticized the platforms for inadequate action against misinformation, with Senator Richard Blumenthal accusing President Donald Trump of using social media to spread false claims. Both CEOs expressed openness to reform of Section 230, which provides immunity to online services, but emphasized the need for careful consideration to avoid unintended consequences.

site_title: Millions of jobless Americans risk losing benefits
summary: Millions of Americans risk losing unemployment benefits at the end of the year unless Congress extends pandemic-related programs. The programs, which made benefits available to a wider workforce and for a longer period, are set to expire, leaving over 13 million people at risk of losing benefits. Economists warn that job losses could rise during the winter, increasing the need for support. Lawmakers must decide whether to extend two key programs, including pandemic unemployment assistance and emergency unemployment compensation, to prevent a significant reduction in living standards and increases in poverty.

site_title: Nasa-Boeing procurement bid under investigation: report
summary: NASA's inspector general and the US Justice Department are investigating allegations that Boeing received internal information during a contract bidding process for a lunar lander contract. The investigation follows the abrupt resignation of Doug Loverro, the head of NASA's human exploration directorate, in May. Loverro had informed Boeing's Jim Chilton that the agency was going to award the contract to another company, prompting Boeing to revise and resubmit its bid. NASA has denied any wrongdoing and maintains the integrity of the procurement process.

site_title: Aramco starts marketing five-tranche bonds
summary: Saudi Aramco began marketing a five-tranche US dollar-denominated bond sale to raise US$12 billion, aiming to pay dividends and fund a US$69.1 billion acquisition. The bond sale is the company's second foray into international debt markets, following a US$12 billion debut issuance last year. The bonds are expected to be priced around 10 basis points wider than Saudi Arabia's sovereign curve, reflecting investors' concerns about the impact of low oil prices on the company's finances.

site_title: Cortina plans to acquire Sincere Watch for S$84.5m
summary: Cortina Holdings has proposed to acquire Sincere Watch for S$84.5 million in cash, aiming to expand its presence in the region and gain exclusive distributorship rights to Franck Muller brands in 12 Asia-Pacific countries. The acquisition, conditional on shareholder approval, would give Cortina access to Sincere Watch's 40 combined outlets and create operational synergies. Sincere Watch has incurred a net loss of S$6.4 million for FY2020, while Cortina recorded a net profit of S$39.3 million for the same period.

site_title: Euro climbs on second vaccine optimism
summary: The euro rose against the dollar on Tuesday, boosted by optimism over a second coronavirus vaccine. Moderna reported positive results from trials, following a similar announcement from Pfizer last week. The euro climbed 0.2% to US$1.18770, while the British pound rose 0.5% to US$1.3266. The dollar index fell to 92.431, its lowest in over a week, as investors await US retail sales data and policymakers' response to rising coronavirus cases.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to raise at least S$300m for acquisition
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) is launching a private placement to raise at least S$300 million for the acquisition of interests in business parks and a Guangzhou mall. The offering has an indicative issue price range of S$1.193 to S$1.236 per unit, offering a discount of 3.4-6.8% to the closing price. The trust aims to raise S$822.4 million to finance the acquisition, with net proceeds to be used for the purchase of five business park properties and a 49% stake in the Rock Square mall.

site_title: G20 leaders must battle Covid-19 on a global scale
summary: G20 leaders are set to discuss Covid-19 at a virtual summit, aiming to secure access to life-saving tests, treatments, and vaccines for the world's largest economies. Investing now could drive long-term growth and stability, with the potential to expand access to medical tools and resources on a global scale. The G20 must move fast to ensure all countries can manage the pandemic and bring it to a swift conclusion, with the International Monetary Fund estimating a cumulative increase in global income of almost $9 trillion by the end of 2025.

site_title: China's irritated trade partners push back on coronavirus food tests
summary: Major food-producing countries, including Canada, Australia, Brazil, Mexico, Britain, and the US, are urging China to stop its aggressive testing of imported food products for the coronavirus, citing a lack of scientific justification. China has found the virus on products from 20 countries, but foreign officials argue that the testing is damaging trade and hurting the reputation of imported food without reason. China claims the measures are necessary to protect public health, but has not provided evidence to support its claims.

site_title: Sea's Q3 loss outpaces topline growth; group raises full-year revenue guidance
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, reported a wider Q3 net loss of US$425.3 million despite a 98.7% growth in topline revenue to US$1.2 billion. The group raised its full-year revenue guidance for digital entertainment and e-commerce, citing sustained revenue growth. Quarterly active users grew 78.3% to 572.4 million and quarterly paying users grew 123.6% to 65.3 million.

site_title: Non-traditional Reits - more than meets the eye
summary: Non-traditional Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) hold less familiar assets, including healthcare, self-storage, and data centers, which differ from traditional REITs that focus on retail, office, and industrial properties. The Singapore market has a smaller proportion of non-traditional REITs, possibly due to the Business Trust regime, which allows for retained business operations while allowing distributions to equity investors. Non-traditional REITs face unique risks, including Master Lease terms and counterparty credit risk, and require special consideration in asset valuation and governance.

images.alt_text: On the surface, investors may not be overly concerned about the differences between traditional and non-traditional Reits, especially if the Reit continues to deliver sustainable and stable income.

site_title: Tesla to join S&P 500 in December
summary: Tesla has been named to the S&P 500 index, set to debut on December 21, marking a significant milestone for the electric vehicle pioneer. The stock has surged nearly five-fold this year, driven by anticipation of the announcement, and will have a weighting comparable to that of Berkshire Hathaway and Johnson & Johnson. This inclusion is expected to bring institutional ownership and potentially ease trading volatility, as index-tracking investors and mutual funds will be forced to buy the stock.

site_title: Twitter names famed hacker 'Mudge' as head of security
summary: Twitter appoints Peiter Zatko, a renowned hacker known as "Mudge", as head of security, giving him a 45- to 60-day review mandate to recommend changes in structure and practices. Zatko, former head of security at Stripe, will examine Twitter's security, site integrity, and platform integrity, with a focus on abuse and manipulation. His appointment comes amid increased regulation threats and security breaches, including a recent data breach that allowed hackers to tweet from high-profile accounts. Zatko is seen as a creative solution to Twitter's security challenges.

site_title: Digital transformation: Is your company taking the right road?
summary: Digital transformation is crucial for businesses, but nearly 70% of initiatives fail to reach their goals. A recent IDC analysis found that $900 billion of the $1.3 trillion spent on digital transformation in 2018 went to waste. To succeed, businesses must adopt a holistic approach, integrating digital initiatives with overall business strategies. This requires a digital-first mindset, culture, and strategy, as well as investing in skills, tools, and resources for employees. A clear vision from the top and a focus on workforce development are key to achieving competitive advantage and building resilient business models.

site_title: US under Biden 'could have more constructive ties with China'
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden may face challenges in building a constructive relationship with China, according to Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Lee hopes Biden will focus on a framework for a relationship that balances competition and cooperation. However, the consensus in the US that sees China as a strategic threat may constrain efforts. Lee also expects some long-term impact from the Trump administration's narrower definition of US interests in Asia. Singapore hopes for a return to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership, but this is unlikely in the short term.

site_title: Sunburst goes virtual this year, with a dash of imagination
summary: The Sunburst Virtual Concert 2020 will be held online on November 18, 2020, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The concert, which raises funds for the School of the Arts Endowment Fund (Sota EF) and Muscular Dystrophy Association (Singapore), will feature performances by Sota students and MDAS beneficiaries. The show will be broadcast on Sota's YouTube channel and will include digital-editing effects. The concert aims to raise S$250,000 and promote inclusivity, with a focus on the theme of "Air."

site_title: US retail sales up 0.3% in October, missing expectations
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in October, missing expectations, as new Covid-19 infections and declining household income restrained growth. The decline in sales could slow further, with economists forecasting moderate growth for the rest of the year and a potential economic slowdown. Millions of unemployed Americans will lose government financial support, and a second rescue package is unlikely before President-elect Joe Biden takes office in January.

site_title: The next phase of the V
summary: The global economy is expected to reach pre-Covid-19 levels by the middle of 2021, driven by a synchronous recovery in developed and emerging markets. The forecast predicts 6.4% global GDP growth in 2021, with emerging markets experiencing a strong upturn due to macro stability, reflationary policies, and a weaker US dollar. Additionally, the US is expected to see an inflation regime change, with policymakers aiming to boost lower-income households and wage pressures, leading to 2% core personal consumption expenditure inflation by H2 2021.

site_title: Wake-up call to limit working hours at sea
summary: A new report from the World Maritime University (WMU) reveals systemic failures in implementing regulations for seafarers' working hours and rest, undermining the credibility of international regulations. The report, which analyzed 20 interviews and consulted with industry stakeholders, found that insufficient manning is the root cause of violations, particularly during peak workload conditions. The WMU recommends improving collaboration on safe manning models, reviewing the effectiveness of the International Safety Management (ISM) code, and addressing chronic mistrust between shore and ship personnel. The report's findings have significant implications for the maritime industry, highlighting the need for urgent attention to prevent fatigue and mitigate its effects.

site_title: Vaccine optimism lifts Singapore market again
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% to 2,778.55 points, led by Singapore Airlines' 4.9% gain, as vaccine optimism lifted markets. The S&P 500 hit a record high overnight, with investors rotating into cyclical and 'reopening' sectors. Regional indices were mostly up, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.13% and Malaysia's KLCI gaining 0.66%.

site_title: Danish bank staff getting more threats from angry clients
summary: Danish bank staff are experiencing a significant rise in verbal abuse and threats from angry clients, according to the Financial Services union. The harassment has taken the form of verbal abuse and in some cases, physical threats. This increase in harassment is linked to Denmark's struggling finance industry, which is still recovering from scandals and system failures. The union's vice-president, Michael Budolfsen, attributes the problem to critical language used by lawmakers and politicians, and calls for a more balanced approach to communication. The situation highlights the impact of customer dissatisfaction on frontline workers.

site_title: Time for Hyflux's PnP holders to move on as firm enters judicial management
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, has been put under judicial management (JM) by the court, a step towards restructuring its debt. The move aims to restructure the company's debt and prevent liquidation. Although this may be unwelcome news for 34,000 perpetual and preference share (PnP) holders, a judicial manager can work with a strategic investor, and no part of the process precludes the recovery of shareholder value. The JM process is seen as a fairer way to protect the interests of all parties involved, and may lead to new rescue deals, including going concern sales.

site_title: Covid-19 has created structural changes in the workplace
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to significant changes in the workplace, with many employers adopting remote work arrangements and employees benefiting from reduced commuting time and increased flexibility. This shift has been dubbed the "Zoom economy," and it has the potential to bring about long-term changes to the way economies function. While there are challenges to be addressed, including the need for improved digital infrastructure and cybersecurity measures, the benefits of telecommuting are likely to persist, leading to more productive, sustainable, and equal national economies.

site_title: Most fund managers ignore racial diversity in staff: study
summary: A study by Redington found that 56% of investment managers worldwide do not collect data on racial diversity among their staff, despite 52% having no black investment team members. The under-representation of minority groups is attributed to a lack of people in the pipeline, less diverse firms, and societal disparities. In response, the UK's markets regulator has urged the finance industry to increase diversity, and some firms are starting internships to promote hiring more diverse investment teams, with the goal of addressing these uncomfortable numbers.

site_title: Indonesia sovereign wealth fund aims to raise US$15b
summary: Indonesia's new sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority, aims to raise $15 billion in investment to finance infrastructure projects and stimulate economic growth. The fund will offer dedicated industry funds with various appetites for risk and return, and will operate under a master fund with investor flexibility. The government seeks to deepen access to global capital and address concerns of corruption and poor infrastructure, with the fund's management and supervisory board to be overseen by professionals and ministers, respectively.

site_title: Rise of sovereign digital currencies: domestic and global implications
summary: China's central bank has launched a digital currency, dubbed the Digital Currency/Electronic Payment (DCEP), with the potential to significantly impact the global financial system. The launch follows a draft law giving the currency legal status and comes amid growing interest in central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) globally. Around 80% of central banks worldwide are researching CBDCs, with many already testing their feasibility. The introduction of CBDCs could lead to a diminished role of commercial banks and private payments systems, but also promote financial stability. China's DCEP could potentially challenge the US dollar's dominance in the global economy, but its internationalization is uncertain.

site_title: Homebuilder confidence hits another record on US buying boom
summary: US homebuilder confidence reached a record high of 90 in November, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Market index. This marks the third straight month of record-high readings and exceeds economists' median forecast of 85. The surge in confidence is driven by low mortgage rates, with Americans taking advantage of sub-3% rates for 30-year mortgages to buy new homes in suburban areas. However, affordability concerns remain, with tight labor, rising materials costs, and expected interest rate increases.

site_title: Cortina's Sincere plan a timely move to dial into China's market
summary: Cortina Holdings has proposed a merger with Sincere Watch, a multi-brand luxury watch retailer, to expand its portfolio of 32 brands and gain access to Sincere's distributorship rights for Franck Muller in 12 Asia-Pacific countries. The deal, valued at S$84.5 million, will see Cortina acquire Sincere's network of independent brands and Franck Muller's distributorship rights, allowing it to enter the mainland Chinese market. The merger will also cement Cortina's position in the luxury watch e-commerce space.

site_title: Amazon expands push into health care with online pharmacy
summary: Amazon has launched Amazon Pharmacy, its digital pharmacy and online prescription ordering platform, offering discounts to Prime members and allowing customers to pay using their health insurance. The move puts Amazon into direct competition with pharmacy giants CVS Health and Walgreens Boots Alliance, and aims to bring the company's digital prowess to the $4 trillion US health care industry. The launch comes after Amazon's $753 million acquisition of online pharmacy PillPack, and marks the first time shoppers can order prescription drugs directly on Amazon.

site_title: Huawei sells budget phone brand after US cuts chip supply
summary: Huawei sells its budget phone brand Honor to a Chinese government-backed consortium after the US cuts off its access to American technology, ensuring the brand's survival. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, allows Huawei to focus on its core telecom equipment business. Honor, once a significant part of Huawei's smartphone business, will operate independently with no remaining shares in the company. The sale highlights the uneven impact of US sanctions on China's largest technology company, with its consumer business struggling despite its networking unit's success.

site_title: SIA applies self-disinfecting coating in planes as it prepares to carry more passengers
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has applied self-disinfecting coatings on planes, including toilets and overhead storage compartments, ahead of an increase in passenger numbers. The airline is also working on Covid-19 testing protocols and has implemented other safety measures such as contactless technology and mask-wearing requirements. SIA aims to create a safe environment for travelers, citing low risk of infection on flights due to air filters, seat barriers, and crew disinfection practices. The airline's efforts come as it prepares to launch air travel bubble flights to Hong Kong and addresses passenger concerns.

site_title: Walmart Q3 profits surge 56.2% on strong US sales
summary: Walmart reported a 56.2% surge in Q3 profits to $5.1 billion, driven by strong US sales and e-commerce growth. US sales increased 5.2% to $134.7 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. E-commerce sales jumped 79% in the quarter ending October 31.

images.alt_text: Walmart reported another strong quarter Tuesday behind higher US sales and surging e-commerce use amid the upheaval of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: US mall investors see hope with Simon deal, vaccine news
summary: US mall investors see a glimmer of hope with Simon Property Group's deal to acquire Taubman Centers Inc, a move expected to create a company focused on high-end properties better equipped to survive the pandemic and e-commerce shift. The deal, valued at $43 per share, is a lower price than initially agreed upon, providing a boost to mall owners' stocks. Positive news on vaccine developments also lifted mall owners' shares, with analysts noting that malls will continue to be a place for people to gather.

site_title: Looking at pharmaceuticals beyond Covid-19
summary: Pharmaceutical companies are expanding their focus beyond Covid-19 to address the growing needs of an ageing global population. Companies like Parkway Life Reit, Singapore Press Holdings, and Abbott are investing in healthcare solutions for the elderly, including nursing homes, nutrition supplements, and joint replacement technology. These investments have the potential for steady returns and growth, driven by the increasing number of older adults worldwide. As one-fifth of the world's population is expected to be 60 or older by 2050, these companies are poised to capitalize on the emerging trend of epidemiological transition.

site_title: ST Engineering to be reorganised into 2 main clusters
summary: ST Engineering to be reorganized into two main clusters: Commercial and Defence & Public Security. The change aims to position the group for growth and become a global technology and defence powerhouse. The Commercial cluster will drive international growth in commercial aerospace, urban solutions, and satellite communications, while the Defence & Public cluster will focus on serving customers in defence and public security. The reorganization is expected to have no material impact on the company's financial results for the current financial year.

site_title: Investcorp buys controlling stake in Singapore instant cereal maker Viz Branz
summary: Investcorp has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Singapore-based Viz Branz Holdings, an instant cereal and beverage maker, from its existing shareholder and CEO Ben Chng. The company generated S$170 million in sales in the year to June 30, with China accounting for over 65% of its revenue. This is Investcorp's 16th investment in the food and beverage industry, with the acquisition representing a partnership with the Asia Food Growth Fund I. The acquisition price was not disclosed.

site_title: Full-scale humanitarian crisis unfolding in Ethiopia: UN
summary: The UN reports a full-scale humanitarian crisis unfolding in northern Ethiopia's Tigray region, with thousands fleeing daily, including 4,000 people crossing the border into Sudan. Over 27,000 people have streamed into Sudan since the conflict began two weeks ago, with many arriving exhausted and with few belongings. The conflict, sparked by attacks on federal military camps, has left hundreds dead and raised concerns of massive displacement within Ethiopia. The situation is also affecting the Eritrean refugee population in Tigray, numbering nearly 100,000.

images.alt_text: The United Nations said Tuesday that thousands of people were fleeing northern Ethiopia's conflict-torn Tigray region and the border area with Sudan now faced a full-blown refugee emergency.

site_title: DBS joins the fray as more Singapore banks make flexi-work permanent post Covid-19
summary: Singapore's largest bank, DBS, has announced flexible work arrangements for its 29,000-strong workforce, allowing employees to work remotely up to 40% of the time. The bank also plans to introduce a formal job-sharing scheme and a "Living Lab" to blend physical and virtual workspaces. This move follows similar announcements from other Singaporean banks, including UOB, which has introduced a two-day work-from-home policy, and OCBC, which has no designated work-from-home days. The shift towards flexible work arrangements aims to boost employee well-being and productivity in the "new normal" post-Covid-19.

site_title: Oman's new Sultan deepens economic reforms
summary: Oman's new Sultan, Haitham Bin Tarik, has deepened economic reforms to hasten development and bring a sustainable future, focusing on increasing the standard of living for the Omani people. Following the passing of Sultan Qaboos, Haitham took over with a similar approach and views, aiming to preserve the late Sultan's achievements. Oman's 50th National Day marks a milestone in the country's history, with the Sultanate working towards its vision 2040, aiming to diversify the economy away from oil and gas, and increase income through investments in sectors such as manufacturing, tourism, and agriculture.

site_title: Home Depot to spend US$1b more on employees as sales surge
summary: Home Depot plans to spend an additional US$1 billion annually on employee compensation due to sustained demand for home improvement products since the Covid-19 pandemic. The surge in demand has led to a 23.2% increase in net sales to US$33.54 billion, beating analysts' average estimate. The company will change some temporary programs to permanent additional compensation, including weekly bonuses and paid time off, to support employees working through the health crisis. Net earnings rose to US$3.43 billion, exceeding expectations of US$3.06 per share.

site_title: How Europe can work with Biden
summary: The European Union can work with the Biden administration to advance cooperation and multilateralism. Following Biden's victory, Europe can increase its geostrategic cohesion and strategic autonomy while reaching out to others and supporting universal principles. Key areas of cooperation include supporting the global economy, particularly through a new Special Drawing Rights issuance and coordinating a common strategic approach on defence. The EU can also engage on climate change, trade, and taxation, and encourage reform of the United Nations Security Council. By taking these steps, Europe can boost its influence and vindicate its raison d'être, while the US can demonstrate its commitment to renewed and reformed multilateralism.

site_title: Singapore's Muslim Pro denies selling user data to US military, launches probe
summary: Singapore-based developer of the Muslim Pro app, Bitsmedia, has denied selling user data to the US military, according to a statement on its website. The company claims the allegations are "incorrect and untrue" and has launched an internal investigation into the matter. Muslim Pro's users' data allegedly includes location details, Wifi network information, and phone model, which were supposedly sold to US data broker X-Mode, potentially linked to US military defence contractors. Bitsmedia has terminated its relationships with all data partners, including X-Mode, and assures users' data is secure.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Covid-19 cases surge
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Tuesday, retreating from record highs, as US states increased measures to contain the Covid-19 pandemic. The Dow Jones fell 0.50% to 29,800.15, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.46% and 0.09% respectively. The decline came despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records the previous day.

site_title: Biden taps close campaign aides, US congressman for White House roles
summary: President-elect Joe Biden named several campaign insiders and a US congressman as senior White House aides, sticking with his tight inner circle. Campaign manager Jen O'Malley Dillon, close advisers Mike Donilon and Steve Ricchetti, and Ron Klain as chief of staff will join the White House. US Representative Cedric Richmond, a national co-chair of Biden's campaign, will vacate his House seat to join as a senior adviser and Director of the White House Office of Public Engagement. This move maintains Biden's close-knit team as he transitions to the White House.

site_title: Thai police fire water cannon at parliament protest
summary: Thai riot police fired water cannon at protesters attempting to breach parliament's razor wire barricades, where lawmakers discussed constitutional changes. Protesters, demanding reforms and Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's removal, clashed with police. The protesters, wearing helmets and masks, threw back colored smoke bombs, while police declared protests banned within 50 meters. The discussions centered on amendments to the constitution, including the monarch's role and Senate selection. The protesters, who do not intend to abolish the monarchy, are seeking accountability and reversal of changes giving the current king personal control of the royal fortune.

site_title: English Nouveau: a young red to rival Beaujolais
summary: The UK's first young red wine, English Nouveau, is being produced near the English border with Wales. Made by winemaker Simon Day, it's a Pinot Noir-based wine released on the third Thursday in November, similar to France's Beaujolais Nouveau. The English Nouveau has aromas of cherry, blackberry, and cranberry, and will be sold in upmarket supermarket chain Waitrose for £11.99. This marks a growing trend in British winemaking, with vineyards increasing by 150% in the past decade, and 770 vineyards now producing sparkling wines.

site_title: AirAsia Japan files for bankruptcy
summary: AirAsia Japan has filed for bankruptcy with the Tokyo District Court after ceasing operations due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on travel globally. The airline cited its current financial position as the reason for the decision, stating it was unable to settle outstanding refunds. A provisional administration order was received by the court, and the airline apologized for any inconvenience caused to customers.

site_title: Singapore Paincare to issue 18m shares to Sian Chay Medical Institution
summary: Singapore Paincare Holdings will issue 18 million new shares to Sian Chay Medical Institution at S$0.22 per share, valuing the investment at S$3.96 million. Sian Chay will hold a 10.02% stake in the enlarged share capital, becoming a substantial shareholder. The partnership aims to strengthen pain-care management services and provide steady returns for Sian Chay's patients. Singapore Paincare's CEO Bernard Lee sees the partnership as a strategic move to enhance the company's value proposition and expand its patient base.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, has announced that it will allow its 29,000-strong workforce to work remotely up to 40% of the time, and implement a formal job-sharing scheme. This move follows other Singaporean banks in adopting flexible work arrangements post-Covid-19. Meanwhile, Vietnam has expressed surprise and concern over the US announcement of tariffs on its garment industry, which could impact its economy.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia Group reviewing India investment, hints at possible exit
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group is reviewing its investment in AirAsia India, hinting at a possible exit. The airline cited draining cash and financial stress as reasons for the review, following the closure of its Japan business. The group owns 49% of AirAsia India and is considering consolidating its Asean foothold, which could include exiting India. Despite this, the airline remains confident of recovering and returning to pre-pandemic levels by mid-2021. Tata Sons' parent is reportedly in talks to buy AirAsia Group's stake in the Indian joint venture.

site_title: ST Engineering to reorganise into Commercial and Defence & Public Security clusters
summary: ST Engineering to reorganise into Commercial and Defence & Public Security clusters, replacing its current sector-based structure. The Commercial cluster will drive growth in commercial aerospace, urban solutions, and satellite communications, while the Defence & Public cluster will focus on digital systems, cyber, and defence aerospace. The reorganisation aims to position the group for growth and become a global technology and defence powerhouse, with no expected material impact on net tangible assets and earnings per share. The change will be reflected in its financial results starting from the first half-year to June 2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.49 points to 1,610.15 on Tuesday, driven by gains in the stock market. The index saw a high volume of 16.395 billion lots worth RM7.957 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 655 to 648.

site_title: Singtel's digital bank bid is also a push for reinvention
summary: Singtel and Grab are collaborating to launch a digital bank in Singapore, with plans to offer lending, insurance, and wealth management services. The entity aims to tap into the underserved market and address the need for financial services. Singtel CEO Arthur Lang believes the venture will enable the company to "consistently change and transform" and expand its revenue base. With an estimated S$600 million investment, the digital bank is expected to compete in Singapore's banking scene, where local and foreign banks dominate. The partnership is built on existing relationships and customer data, aiming to reduce customer acquisition costs and improve targeted banking services.

site_title: Indonesia's mass vaccination plan faces delay over emergency approval
summary: Indonesia's mass vaccination plan to start in December has been delayed due to incomplete data from the country's food and drugs agency. The agency warned it will not issue emergency authorization until late January, pushing back the timeline. President Joko Widodo had previously stated the plan aimed to vaccinate medical staff and frontline workers next month. The delay comes as Indonesia struggles with a surging Covid-19 caseload and a battered economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on a positive note on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.13% to 26,415.09, driven by news of a highly effective coronavirus vaccine candidate. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.90%. Despite global market fluctuations, investors remained optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Sea's Q3 loss outpaces its topline growth; group raises full-year revenue guidance
summary: Sea Ltd, the Singapore-based parent company of e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, reported a wider Q3 net loss of US$425.3 million, despite a 98.7% growth in topline revenue to US$1.2 billion. The loss was more than double the loss in the same period last year. The company raised its full-year revenue guidance for digital entertainment and e-commerce, citing sustained growth and strong bookings.

site_title: US manufacturing output up for sixth straight month in October
summary: US manufacturing production rose 1% in October for the sixth straight month, matching economists' forecasts. The increase was broad-based, driven by gains in consumer goods, business equipment, and construction supplies. Despite improving output, supply chain disruptions and capital investment cuts remain challenges for the industry.

site_title: Singapore makes another plea for top talent to drive tech goals
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the nation to welcome foreign tech talent to achieve its goal of becoming a technology centre, despite potential friction with locals. The "Tech.Pass" programme aims to draw 500 top tech individuals to start and operate multiple companies in Singapore. US tech giants and Chinese tech behemoths are already building presence in the country. Lee emphasized the importance of talent in driving the economy, which contracted 7% in the third quarter, and the government has pledged S$100 billion in stimulus to invigorate the economy.

site_title: LCT Holdings to delist as privatisation bid succeeds
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED LCT Holdings is set to delist after a successful privatisation bid by co-founder Du Junhong. The voluntary conditional cash offer closed with Superior Partners and concert parties holding 95% of total issued shares. The remaining shares will be acquired via compulsory acquisition, with documentation sent to dissenting shareholders. The delisting marks the end of LCT Holdings' time on the mainboard, following a successful privatisation bid.

site_title: Swedish MNCs team up with Singapore SMEs in partnership programme
summary: Swedish multinational companies in Singapore are partnering with local small and medium-sized enterprises through the SESG innovation programme, initiated by the Swedish Chamber of Commerce in Singapore and Forsman & Bodenfors. The programme includes an advertising campaign and regular meetings dubbed Fika4Good to promote local SMEs. The partnership aims to foster innovation and collaboration between the MNCs and SMEs.

site_title: Petra Diamonds reports annual net loss, revenue fall as pandemic bites
summary: Petra Diamonds reported a 36% fall in revenue and a net loss of $223 million for 2020 due to the pandemic's impact on production, sales, and prices. The company kept production guidance for 2021 on hold due to ongoing uncertainty and Covid-19 restrictions. CEO Richard Duffy described the challenges as "unprecedented."

site_title: About 5,700 of firm's workers affected by EMCO in Malaysia: Top Glove
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, reported that about 5,700 of its 21,000 employees in Meru, Klang, will be affected by an enhanced movement control order (EMCO) from Nov 17 to Nov 30. The affected workers are asymptomatic and will work under strict standard operating procedures. Top Glove plans to seek clarification from authorities and work to ensure employee safety amid the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: Europe: Equities steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady on Tuesday, following a vaccine-driven surge in the previous day. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 6,413.58 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices remained flat. The steady opening was attributed to a pause in trading following the previous day's gains, with mining and healthcare stocks contributing to the stability.

site_title: France regaining control over coronavirus but caution still needed: minister
summary: France's health minister Olivier Veran stated that the country is regaining control over the coronavirus, but a second national lockdown is still necessary. The less strict lockdown, imposed in October, failed to produce desired results. Veran warned that easing efforts too early could lead to a new epidemic surge, undoing the hard work done by the French people.

site_title: STI leads region with 1.1% rise on back of vaccine optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% to 2,778.55, leading the region, as markets reacted positively to the early success of Moderna's vaccine results and Wall Street's record high. The index saw 3.21 billion securities worth S$1.75 billion change hands, with advancers outnumbering decliners 284 to 199. This rally follows a 5-day streak for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore chips demand may last despite shock October export dip
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 3.1% year-over-year in October, reversing a 5.8% increase in September. The electronics sector, a key contributor to NODX, saw a 0.4% drop in exports, mainly due to a 12.8% decline in integrated circuits. Despite the surprise, analysts expect the electronics sector to continue driving growth, with some predicting a pick-up in Q2 or second half of 2021. Full-year NODX growth is still expected to be in positive territory, but uncertainty lingers due to ongoing trade tensions and the risk of novel coronavirus outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Shipments of integrated circuits ebbed in October, catching economy watchers off guard after earlier signs of an export growth rebound in Singapore's linchpin electronics cluster.

site_title: Apple supplier CN Innovations mulls US$1b unit sale
summary: CN Innovations Group, a Hong Kong-based supplier to Apple, is considering the sale of its cover glass business for up to $1 billion. The company, which manufactures glass for portable electronic devices, is working with an adviser to find a buyer and has called for non-binding bids. Industry players, including buyout firms, may be interested in the business. The sale could draw attention from companies looking to expand their presence in the electronic components market.

site_title: Pacific Radiance applies for extension of moratoria
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine services firm, applied for an extension of the moratorium on itself and its units, Pacific Crest and CSI Offshore, due to ongoing debt restructuring. The existing moratorium was set to expire on November 30 but will now be extended, providing the company with more time to restructure its debt.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at nine-month high; NZ up for 11th day
summary: Australian shares closed at a nine-month high, rising 0.2% to 6,498.2 points, driven by financial and energy stocks after a promising vaccine candidate result from Moderna. Travel stocks surged, while tech stocks fell 2.8%. In New Zealand, shares extended their winning streak to an 11th day, rising 0.2% to a record close of 12,765.03 points.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reverse early gains on stricter virus curbs, profit-taking
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index closed 0.15% lower at 2,539.15, reversing early gains due to tightened coronavirus-related curbs and profit-taking. The country reported 230 new infections and strengthened social distancing rules for the greater Seoul area. Despite a 94.5% effective vaccine from Moderna, optimism was dampened. Foreigners were net buyers for a ninth straight session, purchasing 359.3 billion won worth of shares, while the won strengthened and bond yields fell.

site_title: Samsung intensifies chip wars with bet it can catch TSMC by 2022
summary: Samsung is investing $116 billion in its next-generation chip business, aiming to mass-produce 3-nanometre chips in 2022 and potentially surpass industry leader TSMC. This move is part of billionaire Jay Y Lee's plan to establish tech leadership in advanced sectors like chipmaking and 5G networking. If successful, Samsung could become the preferred chipmaker for companies like Apple and Advanced Micro Devices, currently relying on TSMC. The investment and production target coincide with TSMC's expected milestone, making it a significant challenge for the Taiwanese company.

site_title: StanChart Singapore CEO to oversee some Asean markets in new organisation structure
summary: Stanford Chartered Bank Singapore CEO Patrick Lee will oversee the Singapore and Asean markets, including Malaysia, Vietnam, Thailand, and representative offices, as part of the bank's new Asia region structure. Lee's new role, effective January 1, 2021, comes after the bank's September announcement combining the Asean and South Asia region into a single "Asia" region led by Ben Hung. Andrew Chia will cover other Asean markets, including Australia, Brunei, and the Philippines.

site_title: UBS's Weber warns of prolonged economic weakness, polarization
summary: UBS Group AG Chairman Axel Weber warned of a prolonged period of economic uncertainty, citing unprecedented global events and diminished economists' ability to predict the economy. Weber stated that major economies will require ongoing ultra-loose fiscal and monetary policies, resulting in deepening social divisions. He urged policymakers, firms, and investors to prepare for potential surprises and make their economies "as robust as possible" to mitigate the effects of prolonged economic weakness. Weber's comments come as global central banks and governments continue to deploy stimulus packages to support their economies through the pandemic.

site_title: US retail sales miss expectations in October
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in October, missing expectations, due to spiraling new Covid-19 infections and declining household income. This decline in retail sales could slow further, impacting consumer spending and the economy. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and other non-essential items, increased 0.1% after a downwardly revised 0.9% increase in September. The data suggests ongoing challenges for the US economy, particularly for consumer spending, amidst the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund is making another splash but this time at home
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is investing $40 billion in the domestic economy, equivalent to 10% of government expenditure in 2021, to revive growth and achieve Vision 2030. The fund, chaired by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, will focus on underdeveloped industries like tourism and diversify away from oil. This move aims to offset the effect of government austerity measures and boost returns, with some investments yielding 140% in the past. The fund's domestic investments will help offset the erosion of Saudi Arabia's balance sheet strengths.

site_title: Hot stocks: SIA, SATS climb as vaccine hopes spur rally
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SATS shares climbed as investors gained confidence from promising Covid-19 vaccine trial data from Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech. DBS Group Research raised its target price for SATS to S$4.50, citing a 13% upside potential, while CGS-CIMB upgraded its rating on SIA to "add". The airlines and tourism-related stocks, such as Genting Singapore, benefited from vaccine optimism, with SIA upping its multicurrency medium-term note program limit to S$10 billion.

site_title: Six new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported six new Covid-19 cases on November 17, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. This marks the seventh day without local transmission, the longest streak since January 23 to February 3. The remaining two cases were asymptomatic and also imported, with close contacts isolated and tested. With six cases discharged, 58,024 patients have recovered, and 37 remain hospitalized. Globally, over 54.8 million people have been infected, with 1.32 million deaths.

site_title: Taylor Swift says her master tapes sold off for second time
summary: Taylor Swift's master recordings have been sold to private equity company Shamrock Holdings for over $300 million, denying her control over her first six albums. This marks the second time her music has been sold without her knowledge. Swift has begun re-recording her early songs, finding it "exciting and fulfilling." The sale follows her long-running feud with former record company Big Machine Group and music executive Scooter Braun. Swift's master recordings include hits like "Shake It Off" and "You Belong to Me."

site_title: Twitter names famed hacker 'Mudge' as head of security
summary: Twitter has appointed Peiter Zatko, known as 'Mudge', as its new head of security, aiming to tackle security breaches and misinformation. Zatko, a renowned hacker, previously worked at Google, Stripe, and the Pentagon's DARPA, and is tasked with recommending changes to structure and practices. He will oversee security functions after a 45-60 day review and focus on areas such as information security, site integrity, and platform integrity. Twitter faces numerous security challenges, including a recent data breach that compromised internal tools and allowed hackers to tweet from prominent accounts.

site_title: China should set growth target of around 5% for 2021-2025: think tank economist
summary: A Chinese state think tank economist recommends setting an average annual economic growth target of around 5% for the 2021-2025 period. This target aligns with a Reuters report and takes into account rising economic volatility caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The economist, Li Xuesong, suggests this growth rate is appropriate and reflects China's potential growth rate of 5-6% during the 14th five-year plan period.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hopes for new vaccine
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.42% on Tuesday, driven by global rallies fueled by a promising coronavirus vaccine candidate. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 26,014.62, while the Topix index gained 0.16%. The positive market sentiment was largely attributed to the vaccine announcement, which boosted investor confidence and helped to offset concerns about new waves of infections in major cities.

site_title: Medical benefits platform Mednefits raises S$8m led by B Infinite owner
summary: Mednefits, a Singapore-based employee medical benefits platform, has raised S$8 million in Series A funding led by B Infinite owner BLoyalty Sdn Bhd. The funding brings the startup's total to S$12 million. The platform aims to enhance and automate medical benefits for clients' employees in Singapore and Malaysia, with benefits expected to reach S$18 million by 2021. Mednefits connects companies and employees to 2,000 healthcare providers and has connected 50,000 employees from 500 companies, simplifying and automating reimbursements.

site_title: 'English nouveau': a young red to rival Beaujolais
summary: A young English red wine, dubbed "English Nouveau," is being produced near the English border with Wales, rivaling the French tradition of Beaujolais Nouveau. Released on November 19th, the wine is made from Pinot Noir grapes using carbonic maceration, and has aromas of cherry, blackberry, and cranberry. Winemaker Simon Day hopes the wine will bring a "little ray of sunshine" to the country during the pandemic, and aims to make English red wine a celebrated tradition.

site_title: Indonesia sovereign wealth fund aims to raise US$15b by offering multiple funds
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority, aims to raise $15 billion by offering multiple industry funds to attract global investors. The fund, which will be managed by professionals with a supervisory board of ministers, will have flexibility to invest in various sectors, including electricity, toll roads, and healthcare. The fund's success is crucial for Indonesia's goal to become a top-five economy in 25 years, as the country's shallow capital markets have limited its access to foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's new sovereign wealth fund will offer dedicated industry funds in a bid to drum up US$15 billion investment and deepen access to global capital by South-east Asia's biggest economy, Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati told Reuters.

site_title: Tricking the taste buds: flavour makers rise to meaty challenge
summary: Flavour makers are developing plant-based meat alternatives to meet growing consumer demand for healthier and sustainable options. Companies like Givaudan and International Flavors & Fragrances are creating meaty-tasting products using pea protein, aiming to replicate the taste and texture of meat. Despite initial concerns that plant-based products lack meaty flavor, innovators are making progress, with pea protein being a promising ingredient. The market is expected to continue growing as consumers increasingly prioritize health, sustainability, and animal welfare.

site_title: More than 5,700 BTO flats launched in last sale exercise of the year
summary: The Housing Board (HDB) has launched over 5,795 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats for sale in Singapore's final sales exercise for the year. The flats are spread across seven projects in five estates, with prices starting from S$108,000 for a two-room flexi flat and S$528,000 for a four-room flat. Applications close on November 23, with the estimated completion date set for the second quarter of 2026.

site_title: Fugitive businessman Jho Low says 1MDB millions taken by him were 'loans'
summary: Fugitive businessman Jho Low has claimed that millions of dollars siphoned from 1MDB were "loans" to him, according to recorded conversations with a Malaysian government representative. Low blamed former Prime Minister Najib Razak for the fund's downfall, saying Najib had the power to authorise the transfer of 1MDB monies. Low also claimed he spent $500 million on luxury items for Najib's wife, Rosmah Mansor, using 1MDB funds. The US Department of Justice estimates $4.5 billion was looted from 1MDB during Najib's tenure.

site_title: Tourism, engine for NYC economy, may not fully recover until 2025
summary: New York City's tourism industry, a vital pillar of its economy, is expected to not fully recover until 2025, four years after the pandemic triggered a free-fall in tourism. The city's tourism promotion agency predicts that it will reach only one-third of last year's total, with hundreds of restaurants and hotels closing due to the collapse of the industry. The city's unemployment rate is 14.1% and over 1.3 million residents are collecting unemployment benefits, highlighting the significant economic impact of the pandemic on the city.

site_title: Pandemic pushes EasyJet to annual loss of £1.27b
summary: EasyJet reported a £1.27 billion annual loss in the 12 months to September due to the pandemic's impact on travel. The airline, which has never before made an annual loss, flew around 20% of planned capacity and cited short-term uncertainty for its inability to provide financial guidance. To mitigate the loss, EasyJet extended its borrowing under a Covid Corporate Finance Facility, staggering repayments and relieving pressure on its balance sheet. The airline has raised over £1 billion from sale and leaseback deals and cut 4,500 jobs to survive the pandemic.

site_title: SIA doubles limit of medium-term note programme to S$10b
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has increased the limit of its multicurrency medium-term note programme to S$10 billion, up from S$5 billion. The airline plans to use the funds for general corporate or working capital purposes. This comes after SIA raised S$12.2 billion in total since the start of FY2020/2021, including a S$850 million five-year convertible bond issuance that was four times oversubscribed. The move is part of SIA's efforts to strengthen its financial position amid strong investor interest.

site_title: It's a good time to be 'the other' Alibaba
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce company, reported a 29% increase in net revenue for the third quarter of 2020, outpacing its larger rival Alibaba. Despite draft antitrust rules targeting Alibaba's practices, JD's shares have risen, trading at 39 times forward earnings, compared to Alibaba's 22 times. JD's inventory model has proven successful, and the company is poised for a longer-term boost as Beijing moves to rein in technology giants. Smaller rivals, including JD, are expected to benefit from increased scrutiny of the sector.

site_title: Lum family, Ellipsiz to make mandatory offer for Lum Chang at S$0.38 per share
summary: A mandatory conditional cash offer was triggered by Ellipsiz and the Lum family to acquire remaining shares of Lum Chang Holdings at S$0.38 per share, while keeping the company listed. The offeror cited low trading liquidity and the opportunity for shareholders to realize their investments at a premium. The offer is strategic in nature for Ellipsiz and does not aim to introduce major changes to Lum Chang's business. The consortium plans to maintain the company's listing status and fund the offer with external financing.

site_title: Gold inches higher on softer dollar, virus woes; vaccine hopes cap gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,890.27 per ounce as the dollar slipped, despite concerns over spiking coronavirus cases. Investors weighed the positive developments around a second Covid-19 vaccine against the prospect of lower fiscal stimulus. The dollar index was down 0.2%, providing near-term support for gold prices, which have gained 24% this year. Silver fell 0.1%, while platinum and palladium also declined.

site_title: Southwest CEO says airline is not looking to expand its fleet
summary: Southwest Airlines' CEO Gary Kelly stated the airline is considering Boeing 737 MAX-7 or Airbus A220 jets to replace its aging 737-700 fleet, but has no plans to increase its fleet size. The airline is debating the options due to the 737 MAX's safety concerns, with regulatory approval expected this week for the jets to fly again. Kelly emphasized the need for a solution within the next several years, with the sooner the better, but ruled out increasing the fleet size.

site_title: Advisory on employees' mental well-being launched in Singapore
summary: Singapore has launched a tripartite advisory on mental well-being in the workplace, aiming to support employers, employees, and self-employed individuals. The advisory sets out practical guidance on measures to promote mental well-being, including appointing mental wellness champions, providing access to counselling services, and training managers to spot signs of mental distress. The initiative comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to increased stress and burnout among employees. Employers are encouraged to establish a work-life harmony policy and provide clarity on after-hours work communication.

site_title: Home Depot to buy back HD Supply in US$8b deal
summary: Home Depot to acquire HD Supply Holdings Inc in a US$8 billion deal. The US home improvement chain will offer US$56 in cash for each share, a 24.5% premium to the stock's last close. The acquisition is expected to expand Home Depot's reach into building utility and maintenance products. With the deal, HD Supply's shares jumped 24.5% and is expected to be accretive to earnings in 2021. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth fiscal quarter and will be funded through a combination of cash and debt.

site_title: Malaysia's FGV posts quarterly profit, expects palm prices to remain strong
summary: Malaysia's FGV Holdings, the world's largest crude palm oil producer, posted a third-quarter profit of RM136.9 million, surpassing a year-ago loss of RM262.4 million. The company attributed the results to higher crude palm oil prices and lower sugar losses. FGV expects palm oil prices to remain strong until the end of 2020, despite weather uncertainties and partial lockdowns in Sabah, Malaysia's largest palm oil-producing state. Revenue rose to RM3.99 billion, from RM3.55 billion last year.

site_title: Swiss cheesed off over Covid threat to fondue conviviality
summary: Switzerland is grappling with the challenge of sharing fondue during the pandemic, a beloved national dish traditionally enjoyed with friends and family in a communal pot. Experts have weighed in, stating that the risk of contracting Covid-19 while enjoying fondue is negligible due to the high temperature of the melted cheese. However, they caution that the risk lies in the gathering, not the fondue itself, and recommend sticking to small groups or individual servings. Despite restrictions, fondue sales have seen a surge, with many believing the dish can help foster conviviality and community during difficult times.

site_title: New cruise ships are ready to sail with nowhere to go
summary: New cruise ships, such as Royal Caribbean's Silver Moon, are being launched with nowhere to go due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and border restrictions. At least 10 ships worth over $3.8 billion are stuck in holding patterns, with some debuting in 2021. The industry's investment in new tonnage has become a sunk cost, adding to quarterly losses. Executives are focusing on maintaining the ships' condition until travel restrictions ease, with some ships being showcased via video feed. New ships are expected to draw attention when travel resumes, but the industry must first prove safe operations.

site_title: Asia: Airlines boosted by new vaccine hope but markets struggle
summary: Asian airlines rallied on Tuesday after news of a 90% effective COVID-19 vaccine candidate and a 94.5% effective Moderna vaccine candidate boosted hopes for a return to normalcy. However, broader markets struggled, with investors shifting out of tech firms and those benefiting during the pandemic. The US and Europe continue to grapple with surging infections, and a stimulus package remains uncertain. Despite this, some airlines, such as Cathay Pacific and Qantas, saw significant gains, and analysts expressed optimism about the market's outlook.

site_title: Trump asked for options for attacking Iran last week, but held off: source
summary: US President Donald Trump asked for options on attacking Iran's main nuclear site but decided against it, a source said. Trump requested options during an Oval Office meeting with top national security aides, who persuaded him not to proceed due to the risk of a broader conflict. The decision came after Iran breached its 2015 nuclear deal by moving advanced centrifuges to an underground facility. Trump has been engaged in an aggressive policy against Iran throughout his presidency, but has shied away from broader military conflicts.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump, with two months left in office, last week asked for options on attacking Iran's main nuclear site, but ultimately decided against taking the dramatic step, a US official said on Monday.

site_title: SpaceX Crew Dragon 'Resilience' docks with ISS
summary: SpaceX's Crew Dragon "Resilience" successfully docked with the International Space Station (ISS) on Monday, marking the first routine mission by a US spacecraft. The crew of four, including three Americans and one Japanese astronaut, will spend six months on the station. The mission marks a significant milestone for NASA's Commercial Crew program, which aims to reduce reliance on Russian rockets. The successful docking comes after a 27.5-hour journey, during which the spacecraft overcame a cabin temperature control system issue. SpaceX is set to launch two more crewed flights for NASA in 2021.

images.alt_text: A SpaceX Crew Dragon carrying four astronauts docked with the International Space Station on Monday, the first of what Nasa hopes will be many routine missions ending US reliance on Russian rockets.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts to stop dealings with gambling tour operators without licences
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts to permanently stop dealings with unlicensed gambling tour operators unless licensed and approved by gaming regulators. The decision follows a review after media reports accused Crown of partnering with operators linked to organised crime. The company had previously suspended dealings with these operators in September 2020, with the review set to conclude in June 2021.

site_title: Bank of Japan's bank aid scheme may herald new era for monetary policy: ex-central banker
summary: The Bank of Japan has introduced a scheme offering 0.1% interest on deposits held by regional lenders that cut costs or consolidate, aiming to keep the banking system stable. Former BOJ executive Hideo Hayakawa believes this may mark a new era for monetary policy, shifting focus from ultra-low rates to boosting the economy's natural rate of interest. This approach, similar to the European Central Bank's green bond purchases, could be a breakthrough for the BOJ, which is struggling to support Japan's economy amid low rates and dwindling tools.

site_title: ADB allocates US$20.3m to help developing members access Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has allocated US$20.3 million in technical assistance to help developing members in Asia and the Pacific access COVID-19 vaccines and establish efficient distribution systems. The funds will support vaccine-related health system assessments, cold chain and logistics, infection control, and real-time data capturing. ADB, in partnership with UNICEF, the World Health Organization, and other organizations, aims to provide equitable and efficient vaccine distribution to ensure the fight against COVID-19. The assistance is part of the ADB's efforts to support its developing members in responding to the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 7.29 points, or 0.46%, to 1,592.45. Volume was 406.63 million lots worth RM135.19 million. Gainers beat losers 322 to 133.

site_title: Fortescue assessing green ammonia plant in Australia's Tasmania
summary: Fortescue Metals Group is assessing a project to build a 250-megawatt hydrogen plant in Tasmania, Australia, with a green ammonia production capacity of 250,000 tonnes per year. The plant, powered by Tasmanian renewable energy, is part of Fortescue's push to become a major renewable energy producer. The project, targeted for a 2021 investment decision, aims to compete with oil companies in providing low-cost green energy globally. The plant has the potential to be one of the world's biggest green hydrogen projects.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.51% at Tuesday's open, driven by a highly effective coronavirus vaccine candidate. The Hang Seng Index increased to 26,515.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. This follows a global stock rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: China's securities regulator hopes Sino-US ties better with Biden administration
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission Vice Chairman Fang Xinghai hopes Sino-US ties will improve under the Biden administration, citing a more collaborative approach compared to the Trump administration. Relations have been strained over technology, trade, and Hong Kong issues. Fang expects Beijing to resolve accounting issues with Chinese firms under a Biden administration. The planned US$37 billion initial public offering of Ant Group may proceed depending on regulatory changes. Beijing is concerned about banks using micro-lenders and third-party technology platforms like Ant for underwriting loans amid fears of rising defaults.

site_title: Federal Reserve official signals willingness to increase debt purchases
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice Chair Richard Clarida signals willingness to increase debt purchases to support economic growth, citing the critical role of bond buying in the economic recovery. The Fed has already cut its benchmark lending rate to zero and has pledged to keep it there until inflation and employment recover. Clarida stated that the central bank is committed to using all available tools, including large-scale asset purchases, to achieve its goals.

site_title: Baidu to buy YY for US$3.6b to get into Chinese live video
summary: Baidu agreed to buy Joyy's live-streaming business, YY Live, for US$3.6 billion, marking the search engine giant's biggest foray into the fast-growing digital video market. The deal will help Baidu catch up with rivals such as TikTok-owner ByteDance, and provide a US$1.8 billion business with four million paying users who spend on virtual gifts. The acquisition aims to diversify Baidu's revenue streams and adapt to the mobile era, following a late start in the live-streaming video market.

site_title: Biden warns 'more people may die' of virus if transition delayed
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden warned that "more people may die" of coronavirus if the transition to his administration is delayed, amid President Donald Trump's refusal to cooperate. Biden expressed frustration over Trump's obstruction, which leaves his team unable to coordinate on issues like vaccine distribution. The US has seen a surge in cases, with over 11 million confirmed infections and 246,000 deaths, and Biden emphasized the need for immediate coordination to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Pfizer to start pilot programme for Covid-19 immunisation in four US states
summary: Pfizer is launching a pilot program for its Covid-19 vaccine in four US states: Rhode Island, Texas, New Mexico, and Tennessee. The states were chosen for their diverse populations and varying immunization infrastructures. The pilot program aims to refine the plan for vaccine delivery and deployment. The program does not guarantee earlier access to the vaccine for the selected states. This comes after Pfizer reported a 90% effective rate in its vaccine candidate and rival Moderna reported a 94.5% effective rate in its vaccine.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts upbeat on Genting Singapore after Q3 recovery, vaccine news
summary: Analysts at DBS Group Research have upgraded Genting Singapore to a "buy" call, citing a sequential earnings rebound in the July-September quarter and the recent breakthroughs on the Covid-19 vaccine front, which they believe will lead to a swift turnaround in travel activity in the second half of 2021. The research team raised its target price to S$1.00, from S$0.70, and expects Genting Singapore's 2021 Ebitda to come in at around 74% of the S$1.19 billion figure in 2019.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on hopes for new vaccine
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday following overnight global rallies due to the announcement of a second promising vaccine candidate against the coronavirus, which has sparked hopes for new treatments. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.42% to 26,015.86, while the broader Topix index rose 0.22% to 1,735.70.

site_title: Australia: Stock exchange resumes trading after software glitch
summary: The Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) resumed trading on Tuesday after a software glitch halted trading the previous day. The glitch, affecting multiple securities, caused inaccurate market data. Trading resumed with a 0.4% gain, the highest level since March 3. The issue was linked to the new equity market trading platform, which went live despite over a year of testing. The ASX cited the issue as the reason for the halt, and trading resumed without further disruptions.

site_title: Natural gas is worst performer among top commodities on weather
summary: US natural gas futures plummeted 10% to $2.697 per million British thermal units, the largest decline in eight weeks, due to milder autumn forecasts that may lead to a warm winter and reduced heating demand.
