This marks the worst performance among major commodities, contrasting with oil's rise amid optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine. A recent supply glut and bullish bets on natural gas are being weighed down by the cooler-than-expected weather forecast, potentially limiting the fuel's price recovery.

site_title: Teckwah's offeror compulsorily acquires dissenting shareholders' shares
summary: Clementine Investments, a consortium of Teckwah Industrial Corp's three largest shareholders, has compulsorily acquired the shares of dissenting shareholders who did not accept its voluntary cash offer to take the company private at 65 Singapore cents per share. The offeror received valid acceptances of about 95.9% of the total number of issued shares, resulting in the privatisation bid turning unconditional. Teckwah shares have been suspended from trading and will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at a later date.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to raise at least S$300m for acquisition
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has launched a private placement to raise at least S$300 million for the acquisition of business parks and a Guangzhou mall. The trust aims to raise gross proceeds of S$822.4 million for the acquisition, with net proceeds to be partially used for financing the purchase. The private placement will raise S$220 million, and a pro rata and non-renounceable preferential offering of up to 69 million new units will raise about S$80 million.

site_title: Black Friday plus Covid add up to crunch time for retailers
summary: US retailers are bracing for a challenging Black Friday and holiday season due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Many have implemented new tools such as in-store and curbside pickup, but these haven't been battle-tested, and potential delays and snags could impact sales. Consumer habits are shifting towards e-commerce, with online sales expected to spike 33% to $189 billion, testing fulfillment networks. Retailers like department stores and apparel chains have struggled, and companies are concerned about losing customers if delivery experiences are unsatisfactory.

site_title: Barley trade routes redrawn as China tariff hits Australian farmers
summary: Australia's barley trade routes are being redrawn due to a 80.5% tariff imposed by China in retaliation for Australia's push for a UN probe into the COVID-19 pandemic. The tariff has halted barley trade between the two countries, prompting farmers to diversify their markets. China is seeking alternate supplies, benefiting grain farmers in countries like France, Ukraine, Argentina, and Canada. The disruption is expected to last for at least three months, affecting global barley supplies and prices.

images.alt_text: Out in Australia's grain fields, farmers have started harvesting one of their biggest ever barley crops, after drought-relieving rains convinced many to plant to the edges of their paddocks.

site_title: South Korea to tighten social distancing, warns of new Covid-19 crisis
summary: South Korea will impose stricter social distancing rules in the greater Seoul area due to a spike in new COVID-19 cases. Starting Tuesday, public gatherings of 100 or more will be banned, and high-risk facilities like clubs and karaoke bars will require increased distancing. The move comes as the daily case tally hovered above 200 for the fourth consecutive day, with cluster outbreaks emerging from offices and small gatherings. The stricter curbs aim to prevent a bigger crisis, with the KDCA warning that the daily tally could reach 400 within weeks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Cortina, Blumont, New Silkroutes, Wilmar, Top Glove
summary: Singapore stocks saw various developments on Tuesday, with SIA up 1% after upsizing its multicurrency medium-term note program to S$10 billion. Cortina Holdings proposed acquiring Sincere Watch for S$84.5 million, and Blumont Group faced a mandatory unconditional cash offer with an 80% discount. New Silkroutes appointed new executives and was included in the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices. Wilmar International was also included in the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices. Top Glove will seek clarification on the implementation of enhanced movement control orders.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on second vaccine progress; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, driven by progress on a second coronavirus vaccine candidate, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.9% to 2,772.67. Moderna's experimental vaccine showed a 94.5% effectiveness rate in preventing Covid-19, boosting investor confidence. The gains offset a shock fall in Singapore's October exports, which lost 3.1% year on year. US stocks also rose, with the Dow and S&P 500 ending at records, as investors look to vaccine progress for economic recovery.

site_title: Report names and shames countries cosy with Big Tobacco
summary: A report by watchdog groups has ranked 57 countries based on their willingness to curb the tobacco industry, with Japan and Indonesia at the bottom and the US, Malaysia, Spain, Germany, and India among the worst offenders. The report found that tobacco firms have lobbied governments to expand markets and blunt measures during the Covid-19 pandemic, resulting in the lifting of bans, lower taxes, and a voice in government-led deliberations. The industry has also handed out personal protective equipment and other goods, while suing to block plain packaging and challenging regulations.

site_title: New home sales set to rise after falling in Oct on fewer launches, options curb
summary: Singapore's private home sales are expected to rebound in November and December after falling 51.7% in October due to fewer new launches and curbs on re-issuance of options to purchase (OTPs) by developers. The October sales figure was 642 units, with only one project launched. Consultants predict a recovery in primary-market sales volumes with upcoming launches, including The Landmark and Ki Residences. Despite the curbs, buyers have the financial means to exercise OTPs, and interest remains firm due to a positive market outlook.

site_title: New Silkroutes appoints CEO as executive director, new finance director
summary: New Silkroutes Group has appointed VicPearly Wong as its executive director and Lincoln Kwok as its finance director. Wong, 44, will oversee overall management and operations, while Kwok, 44, will handle treasury, finance, and strategic planning functions. The appointments follow the resignations of non-independent, non-executive chairman Goh Jin Hian and finance director William Teo Thiam Chuan, who stepped down to focus on personal matters. The changes come after Deloitte issued a disclaimer of opinion on the company's financial statements due to alleged breaches of director's duties.

site_title: Huawei to sell Honor brand to consortium of agents and dealers in bid to save supply chain
summary: Huawei is selling its budget brand smartphone unit Honor to a consortium of over 30 agents and dealers in a bid to save its supply chain. The sale, valued at an undisclosed amount, will not impact Honor's development direction. The new company, Shenzhen Zhixin New Information Technology, will be established to make the purchase. Huawei will not hold any shares in the new company, and the change of ownership is seen as a "market-driven investment" to save Honor's industry chain.

site_title: Oil settles higher boosted by latest Covid-19 vaccine progress
summary: Oil prices rose by more than 2% on Monday after Moderna Inc announced its experimental Covid-19 vaccine was 94.5% effective, boosting investor hopes for reduced pandemic-driven damage to the global economy. Brent crude futures settled at $43.82 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $41.34 a barrel. The news comes as Opec+ is set to hold a ministerial committee meeting on Tuesday, which could impact production quotas and influence oil prices.

site_title: Biden calls for US stimulus after meeting with business leaders
summary: President-elect Joe Biden called for a US$2.2 trillion stimulus package to aid the US economy's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. Despite disagreement between Republicans and Democrats, Biden urged Congress to approve the measure, which includes investing in emerging technologies and increasing the national minimum wage to $15 per hour. Biden's economic plan aims to secure the US as a global leader in research and development, creating three million good-paying jobs.

images.alt_text: President-elect Joe Biden on Monday called for more stimulus spending to help the United States recover from the coronavirus pandemic after laying out his plans for the world's largest economy in a meeting with corporate and business leaders.

site_title: Tesla to join S&P 500, shares surge
summary: Tesla has officially qualified for the S&P 500, joining the prestigious market index on December 21. The California-based electric car company's shares surged 11.5% to $455.00 in after-hours trading, quadrupling this year's value. Tesla has reported $451 million in profits through the first nine months of 2020, marking its arrival as a consistently profitable company after nine years of losses. With a market capitalization of almost $387 billion, Tesla will be among the largest companies in the index, boosting its valuation and attracting more investment.

site_title: Volkswagen preparing Lamborghini, Ducati for possible ownership changes
summary: Volkswagen is preparing its Italian units, including Lamborghini and Ducati, for potential ownership changes, such as an initial public offering (IPO) or sale. CEO Herbert Diess has stated that the units will be folded into a structure that would allow the German manufacturer to act if a decision is made to change ownership. No decisions have been made, but the company is exploring options to streamline its conglomerate structure and boost market value to 200 billion euros. This move aims to challenge Tesla's electric-car leadership and achieve the company's goal of increasing its market value.

site_title: Court gives nod for KrisEnergy scheme meeting, extends debt stay to January
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted KrisEnergy permission to convene a meeting of its scheme creditors within three months from November 16, extending its debt moratorium to January 16, 2021. KrisEnergy, seeking to restructure $476.8 million in debt, proposes a debt-to-equity swap, with unsecured creditors owning 46.2% and zero-coupon noteholders holding 43.8%. The company's creditors include Keppel Shipyard, DBS, and Standard Chartered Bank. The meeting will be attended by only scheme creditors in a contractual relationship with KrisEnergy.

site_title: Australia's central bank ready to do more, coronavirus containment the key
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), is prepared to provide additional policy stimulus if needed, with interest rates already at record lows. The RBA cut rates by 15 basis points to 0.1% and launched a bond buying program to scoop up A$100 billion of longer-dated debt. The bank's focus will be on containing the coronavirus, with its success so far leading to a better outlook. The RBA emphasized that monetary and fiscal stimulus will be needed for a considerable time, with no interest rate hike expected for at least three more years.

site_title: Singapore exports post shock 3.1% drop in October as gold shipments recede
summary: Singapore's exports dropped 3.1% in October, snapping a four-month winning streak, due to a decline in non-monetary gold shipments. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 3.1% year-over-year, with electronics shipments declining 0.4% and integrated circuits dropping 12.8%. The drop was attributed to cooling gold prices and lower electronics shipments, with base effects expected to turn more favorable from December. Total trade declined 9% year-over-year, or 3.1% seasonally adjusted.

site_title: Mining magnate Gertler says he paid US$83m for royalties from Congo's Metalkol
summary: Israeli mining magnate Dan Gertler purchased $83 million in royalties from Congo's Metalkol copper and cobalt project in 2017 to help the state mining company Gecamines pay off its debts. Gertler bought the 2.5% stake from Gecamines, which owns 5% of the asset, to support its operations. The move was not previously public knowledge, and Gertler has denied allegations of corruption. The royalties would be worth $11.6 million and $13.7 million per year, with Gertler expected to recoup his investment in over three years.

site_title: One in 5 Aussie BNPL users missed payments
summary: A report by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) found that one in five consumers using buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) services in Australia were missing payments, with some cutting back on essentials or taking additional loans to stay on top of payments. The report warned that consumers were facing financial hardship, but did not call for regulation.

site_title: CapitaLand to grow China exposure in high-growth sectors
summary: CapitaLand plans to increase its China exposure in the "new economy" sector to S$5 billion over the next few years, up from S$1.5 billion. The company will redeploy capital from asset recycling into assets such as business parks, logistics, and data centers. This growth strategy aims to capitalize on China's high-growth sectors.

site_title: China lines up banks for record euro-denominated government bond sale
summary: China is set to sell its largest ever euro-denominated government bond, with a minimum of 5-8 billion euros, according to a deal finalized with several banks. The sale, due on Tuesday, follows a similar transaction last year and would surpass the 4 billion euro deal in 2020. The move aims to raise funds and diversify China's debt portfolio.

site_title: Austrian privacy NGO takes on Apple over 'tracking code'
summary: Austrian online privacy NGO NOYB has filed complaints with data protection authorities in Germany and Spain over Apple's use of a tracking code, IDFA, without user knowledge or consent. The code, introduced by Apple, allows tracking of user behavior across applications. NOYB claims this is a breach of EU privacy laws, stating the IDFA should be permanently deleted, not just restricted. The group, founded by privacy activist Max Schrems, has a history of winning online privacy cases, including striking down the EU's "Privacy Shield" agreement.

images.alt_text: An Austrian online privacy NGO said on Monday it was lodging complaints against Apple in two countries over the use of a code on its phones that allows tracking of user behaviour.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at over eight-month high on Moderna vaccine optimism
summary: European shares reached an eight-month high on November 16, 2020, due to positive data from Moderna Inc's Covid-19 vaccine, boosting investor confidence in a faster economic revival. The vaccine's high efficacy, reported by Moderna and previously by Pfizer, increased optimism about a pandemic recovery and normal economic activity. This news, combined with recovery signs in Asia, led to a surge in European shares.

site_title: US under Biden could have better ties with China, though constrained by politics: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong believes the US under President-elect Joe Biden could have better ties with China, but domestic politics may limit progress. Lee hopes Biden will focus on a constructive relationship with China, despite the prevailing view in the US that China is a strategic threat. On trade, Singapore hopes for a return to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) but acknowledges it will take time and domestic political alignment. Lee also expressed concerns about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the economy and called for a global institution and surveillance network to prepare for future pandemics.

site_title: Auto, tech stocks drive Asian markets' rally after RCEP pact
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, driven by news of a trade pact between China and 14 other Asia-Pacific countries and positive updates on vaccine development. Japan's Nikkei 225 surged 2.05%, while every market in the region finished higher. The RCEP pact and vaccine progress likely fueled the rally, which also saw the Singapore stock index notch a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: India's top retail trade body says Deepavali sales up 10.8% on-year
summary: India's top retail trade body, the Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), reported a 10.8% increase in sales during the Deepavali festive period, reaching over 720 billion rupees (S$13 billion). This indicates "good business prospects" for small businesses. Despite India's economy experiencing a contraction, CAIT's sales data suggests a possible return to growth in the ongoing quarter if momentum is sustained.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire invests in four big drugmakers
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has invested over $1.8 billion in each of four large drugmakers: Abbvie Inc, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Merck & Co, and Pfizer Inc, as of September 30. The investments were disclosed in a regulatory filing and were made in addition to a new $136 million stake in Pfizer. The move is seen as a positive endorsement by Buffett, who often increases the value of the companies he invests in. Berkshire also revealed a new $276 million stake in wireless phone company T-Mobile US Inc.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway said on Monday it has begun investing in the stocks of four large drugmakers.

site_title: Trump administration to seek bids on Arctic oil leases
summary: The Trump administration has invited oil companies to bid on proposed drilling territories in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a move aimed at opening up development of a target area long sought by petroleum interests. The Bureau of Land Management will accept nominations and comments on 650,000 hectares of land from November 17 to December 17. Environmentalists have long opposed the plan, citing potential harm to wildlife, and some major banks have said they won't finance projects in the refuge. The move comes in the administration's final days in office, with President-elect Joe Biden set to take office on January 20, 2021.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration on Monday invited oil companies to choose proposed drilling territories as it pushes ahead with a controversial Alaska leasing plan in its final days in office.

site_title: US Senate chief blasts Trump troop withdrawal plans
summary: US Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned President Donald Trump against accelerating troop reductions in Afghanistan and Iraq, citing it would give extremists a "big propaganda victory." The move would leave room for the Taleban to take control of Afghanistan and the Islamic State group and Al-Qaeda to rebuild. McConnell stated that the US would be "abandoning" partners, sparking concerns about the potential consequences of the troop withdrawal plans.

site_title: Airbnb's losses grow, as IPO tests appetite for post-Covid rebound
summary: Airbnb reported declining revenue and growing losses in a prospectus ahead of its potential $3 billion IPO, which could value the company at over $30 billion. The move tests investors' appetite for hospitality stocks in a year marked by industry uncertainty. The home rental service reported a major step toward its IPO, despite the novel coronavirus disrupting the travel industry.

site_title: Cortina plans to acquire Sincere Watch for S$84.5m
summary: Cortina Holdings proposes to acquire Sincere Watch for S$84.5 million in cash, gaining exclusive distributorship rights to Franck Muller in 12 Asia-Pacific countries. Cortina shares rose 11.1% after the announcement, trading at S$2.30. The acquisition aims to expand Cortina's luxury watch offerings.

site_title: 11 former Robinsons staff seek help from MOM and TADM
summary: Eleven former Robinsons employees in Singapore have sought assistance from the Ministry of Manpower and Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management over unpaid retrenchment benefits, salary, and leave. The employees, who were retrenched, are struggling to find new employment and need help with securing new jobs.

site_title: Universal tops faltering US box office with Freaky
summary: Universal Pictures' horror film "Freaky" topped the US box office with $3.7 million in North America, surpassing other films. The movie, a collaboration with Blumhouse Productions, is seen as a response to real-life fears. With this success, Universal Pictures aims to revitalize the struggling US box office.

site_title: Asia reaches crossroads in fight against virus as cases surge
summary: Asia faces a critical crossroads in its fight against the coronavirus as countries report record new cases and fresh outbreaks. Japan, South Korea, and Australia are among those struggling with surging infections, while India and Indonesia also report new spikes. The Asian region's gradual easing of travel restrictions may hinder efforts to boost the economy, particularly in Japan, where Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is under pressure to reimpose a state of emergency. The situation is being closely watched ahead of the postponed 2021 Olympic Games.

site_title: Oxley: Committed to providing shareholders, investors with regular disclosures
summary: Oxley Holdings has denied allegations of non-compliance with its disclosure obligations as a listed company, addressing inaccuracies in an article published by The Business Times. The company claims to provide regular disclosures to shareholders and investors, despite the article suggesting otherwise.

site_title: Ovo Energy, Shell unit to turn Spanish homes into virtual power plants
summary: Ovo Energy Ltd, a unit of Royal Dutch Shell Plc, has partnered to offer rooftop solar and batteries to homes in Spain, turning households into virtual power plants. This deal is similar to Tesla's UK tariff that combines solar panels and a battery. Ovo is also conducting a home battery trial in the UK with Sonnen. The partnership aims to provide complete energy systems, increasing energy independence for Spanish homes.

site_title: Medtecs climbs 12% as company eyes mainboard transfer
summary: Medtecs International shares rose 12% after the company announced plans to transfer its listing from Catalist to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange. The firm's stock closed at S$0.99, and it will be included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. This move comes as the company eyes a mainboard listing, which is seen as a step up for the medical products supplier.

site_title: Schubert's hidden depths
summary: Franz Schubert's song cycle Die Schöne Müllerin, composed 40 years ago, has a rustic allure and dark complexities that continue to fascinate audiences. The cycle tells the story of a young man's unrequited love and obsession, leading to jealousy and ultimately, his tragic death. A new recording by a tenor brings this hidden depth to light, offering a fresh interpretation of the cycle's complexities and emotional resonance.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records on Covid-19 vaccine progress
summary: US stocks reached records on Monday as the Dow Jones and S&P 500 surged due to progress on a coronavirus vaccine candidate, boosting confidence in the economic recovery. The Dow Jones ended at 29,950.44, a new high, while the S&P 500 reached 3,626.91, a second straight record. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced to 11,924.13. The gains come amid uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff concerns.

site_title: PNC to buy BBVA's US banking arm for US$11.6b
summary: PNC Financial Services Group agreed to purchase the US banking arm of Spanish lender BBVA for $11.6 billion in cash, creating a US bank with nearly $560 billion in assets and a presence in two dozen states. This is the second-largest US banking deal since the 2008 financial crisis, further consolidating the US banking sector. The acquisition is expected to strengthen PNC's position in the market and enhance its financial capabilities.

images.alt_text: BBVA in Charlotte, North Carolina. Investors have been growing impatient with the Spanish lender's efforts to tackle the poor performance of its US business after a US$1.5b writedown in Q4 2019 earnings.

site_title: Walmart sells majority stake in Japanese chain Seiyu
summary: Walmart is selling a majority stake in Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu to investment firm KKR and e-commerce company Rakuten for over $1 billion. The deal values Seiyu at 172.5 billion yen, below the $2.22 billion initially sought. Walmart retains a 15% stake, while KKR and Rakuten acquire 65% and 20% respectively. The move follows years of poor profitability and stiff competition in Japan, where Seiyu has shown signs of improvement with its e-commerce business.

site_title: Defending against virus risks with tech tools
summary: Singapore is utilizing various technologies, including blockchain, Bluetooth, and AI, to defend against COVID-19 threats and facilitate corporate tax filing for SMEs. A new simplified CIT Returns form and digital solutions will make the process easier. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz is taking control of a specialist healthcare center in Tokyo or Osaka, and a NUS researcher's startup aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel.

site_title: Iras simplifies corporate tax filing process for SMEs
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has introduced a simplified Corporate Income Tax (CIT) Return form for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), allowing companies with straightforward tax matters to file taxes in just six essential fields. This move aims to make the corporate tax filing process easier for SMEs, following the launch of the Form C-S (Lite) in July 2020.

site_title: China Evergrande feels the squeeze in key shadow financing market
summary: China Evergrande Group, the embattled developer, has seen a significant drop in its main source of non-bank financing, trust loans, over the past three months. This decline, which accounted for 41% of its total funding in 2019, adds to the company's challenges. Despite efforts to pare back debt and access new funding channels, Evergrande faces pressure to reduce its $120 billion debt pile. Authorities are keeping a close eye, and the company has been required to report its financing activities monthly, including shadow banking activities.

site_title: RCEP a shot in the arm for Singapore, Asean economies
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) has been signed, marking a new era of trade and investment openness for South-east Asia and its partners. After nearly a decade of negotiations, the pact eliminates tariffs and quotas on 65% of goods traded within the region, with the goal of increasing this to 90% over 20 years. RCEP involves 30% of the world's population and 29% of global GDP, and although it has some moderated provisions, it is considered an incredible achievement in aligning a diverse group of countries.

images.alt_text: "Given the need for growth boosting initiatives after the Covid-19 crisis, a fresh look at the role that trade integration can play in boosting growth needs to be taken. The recently signed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement provides welcome momentum for trade integration." - Professor Christopher Findlay, Vice Chair, Australia PECC.

site_title: Genting Singapore jumps to five-month high on surprise earnings rebound
summary: Genting Singapore's shares surged 8.1% to a five-month high, driven by a surprise earnings rebound in the third quarter, with net profit after tax reaching S$54.4 million, reversing a net loss of S$163.3 million in the previous quarter. The company's revenue and earnings beat market expectations, with Resorts World Sentosa generating higher-than-expected gaming revenue. Analysts upgraded the stock to "neutral" from "sell", citing brighter prospects and sufficient capital to fund expansion plans.

site_title: Why cracks are showing in the 'BRICS wall'
summary: The BRICS bloc, consisting of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, is experiencing cracks as differences between its member states become more apparent. Rising tensions between China and India, particularly over their border disputes, have hindered efforts to present a unified front. Economically, China is the only BRICS nation to expand in 2020, according to the IMF, while India, Brazil, and South Africa are expected to contract. Despite these challenges, the BRICS have driven global income equality, with their collective economic growth and large populations in China and India lifting millions out of poverty. The bloc's future remains uncertain, with growing income inequality within countries and a decelerating wave of emerging market growth.

site_title: Euro edges higher as vaccine, recovery hopes lift spirits
summary: The euro rose 0.3% to a one-week high of $1.1869, driven by investor hopes for a successful vaccine against Covid-19 and economic data from Asia showing signs of recovery. Currencies sensitive to global sentiment, such as the Norwegian kroner and Australian dollar, also gained. Despite trade talks between Britain and the EU resuming, initial optimism dissipated, and sterling slipped marginally. Analysts attributed the euro's rise to investor confidence in the euro region's ability to launch fiscal stimulus, outweighing concerns about a resurgence of global Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Supply chain players developing common infrastructure to share data
summary: Singapore is developing a common data infrastructure to share data across the supply chain ecosystem, reducing dependence on physical documents and instances of fraud. The initiative, spearheaded by the Alliance for Action on Supply Chain Digitalisation, connects data platforms of importers, exporters, shipping firms, and financial institutions. The goal is to ease congestion at container nodes, improve visibility of goods movement, and enable automation. Two trials have begun, focusing on digitizing trade documents and managing congestion at container nodes, to maintain Singapore's competitive edge as a trade and logistics hub.

site_title: More Covid-19 time relief for HP, property deals
summary: Singapore has extended temporary Covid-19 relief for options-to-purchase and sale and purchase agreements with property developers until March 31, 2021. This extension will assist property purchasers with minimal impact on developers' cash flow. Two other types of contracts, including hire-purchase and rental agreements for commercial equipment and vehicles, have also been extended to January 31, 2021. The move aims to provide temporary protection from being sued during the relief period.

site_title: Korean Air eyes top-10 world ranking with 1.8t won Asiana deal
summary: Korean Air is set to acquire Asiana Airlines for 1.8 trillion won (S$2.2 billion) via its parent, Hanjin Kal Corp, in a deal aimed at stabilizing South Korea's aviation industry and improving competitiveness. The acquisition, expected to be completed in 2021, will streamline route operations and lower costs, while potentially increasing joint ventures with global airlines and demand for transit flights. Korean Air plans to issue new shares to raise 2.5 trillion won, with Hanjin Kal participating in the issue and owning about 10% of the airline.

site_title: End of the road for Hyflux board as court appoints interim judicial managers
summary: The Singaporean water treatment company Hyflux has been placed under judicial management following a lengthy debt moratorium saga. The High Court appointed interim judicial managers Borrelli Walsh, taking over operations with immediate effect, and ending the board's control. The move comes after a nearly four-hour court hearing, where Justice Aedit Abdullah rejected a request for an adjournment of the judicial management application. The decision allows for an orderly dissolution of the company's affairs and sale of its assets, with a new restructuring plan set to be overseen by a new CEO.

site_title: Indonesia firms sign US$1b deal with Aussie healthcare providers
summary: Indonesian state-owned company Jasa Sarana signed a US$1 billion agreement with Australian healthcare providers Docta and Aspen Medical to build hospitals and clinics in West Java's province. The 23-year plan aims to construct 650 primary care clinics and 23 hospitals in cooperation with local authorities. This investment is seen as a priority by Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board, with chairman Bahlil Lahadalia praising the deal as a significant step for the country's healthcare sector.

site_title: Republicans' touted roadblock has five big holes in it
summary: The US election has passed with little surprise, and President-elect Joe Biden's prospects have improved due to a near-certainty of fiscal stimulus and pro-growth demand management. Despite conventional wisdom predicting gridlock, a Republican Senate majority may be less effective in blocking Biden's policies. Key factors include the likelihood of a "quick and dirty" compromise on a Covid-19 relief bill, Biden's ability to maintain public support for government spending, and the potential for Republican senators to defect from party unity. Additionally, a new kind of Trump disruption may soon hit US politics, potentially splitting the American right between Trump supporters and Republican politicians.

site_title: Singapore seen as one of most active capital sources in 2021
summary: Singapore is expected to be among the top five sources of active capital in 2021, with outbound investments projected to reach $3.82 billion to Australia, $3.12 billion to the UK, and $3 billion to China. Despite border closures and lockdowns, investors have found ways to work around restrictions, with virtual viewings and investment managers on the ground focusing on safe haven markets. The low interest rate environment is driving a barbell strategy of defensive and high returns, with a shift towards suburban office assets and industrial investments.

site_title: Covid crisis comes with challenges but also offers opportunities
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about both challenges and opportunities, with economies contracting by over 10% globally before experiencing rapid recovery. However, this recovery has been accompanied by widespread resurgence of the virus, highlighting the need for a balance between restarting economies and keeping populations safe. The crisis is accelerating trends such as digital innovation and the shift towards fiscal policy, but also generating new challenges like climate change and widening economic inequalities. Policymakers and investors must address these challenges by implementing effective government interventions, promoting sustainable returns, and recognizing opportunities in post-COVID structural changes.

site_title: China's thirst for luxury keeps eastern Europe cranking out cars
summary: Eastern European countries, particularly Slovakia and the Czech Republic, are experiencing a boom in the luxury car industry due to China's high demand for high-end vehicles. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, these countries' factories continue to produce luxury vehicles, including Porsche Cayenne SUVs, and lower-cost models for domestic markets. Volkswagen AG is investing over $1.6 billion in the region, and the auto sector accounts for a significant portion of industrial output in these countries, generating livelihoods for thousands.

site_title: Saudi Aramco turns to bonds to help fund US$75b dividend
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil company, plans to issue bonds to raise US$75 billion to fund its dividend commitment. The company needs to raise debt after profit fell 45% due to slumping crude prices. Aramco has already cut spending, jobs, and is considering selling assets to conserve cash. The state-controlled energy firm has a gearing ratio of 21.8%, above its target range of 5-15%. A dollar-denominated bond sale with tranches maturing in various years may follow, depending on investor demand.

site_title: Asian indices up on Monday on RCEP deal; STI finishes 1.4% higher
summary: Asian stock markets rose on Monday, driven by the announcement of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal, a mega free trade pact backed by China. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 1.35%, while the Hang Seng, Nikkei 225, and Kospi indices rose 0.86%, 2.05%, and 1.97%, respectively. Shares of Genting Singapore, Sats, and Keppel Corp gained significantly, with Genting Singapore's shares rising 8.1% and Keppel Corp's shares potentially reaching "overbought" territory.

site_title: Starburst chairman, MD, CFO interviewed in corruption probe
summary: Starburst Holdings, a Singapore-based company that designs and installs anti-ricochet ballistic protection systems, saw its shares plummet 68% to an intraday low of 12 cents after its co-founders, Edward Lim Chin Wah, Yap Tin Foo, and Josiah Lawrence Ng Eng Long, were interviewed by Singapore's anti-corruption watchdog, the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). The company's executive chairman and co-founders are out on bail amid the probe. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) said it will investigate the matter and take necessary regulatory action.

site_title: Thai central bank has tools to handle strong baht: minister
summary: Thailand's central bank has tools to manage the strengthening baht, according to Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapai-sith. The currency reached its highest level in over 10 months against the US dollar, driven by foreign inflows and optimism over the Thai economy. The central bank is expected to keep the key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.50% when it meets on Wednesday, and may encourage capital outflows to ease pressure on the baht. The economy is expected to perform better in the fourth quarter due to government stimulus and easing coronavirus curbs.

site_title: Moderna says experimental Covid vaccine 94.5% effective
summary: Moderna's experimental Covid-19 vaccine has shown a 94.5% effectiveness rate in preventing the virus based on interim data from a late-stage clinical trial. The vaccine, administered in two shots 28 days apart, has also been found to prevent severe cases of Covid-19. With the US government's Operation Warp Speed program, Moderna expects to produce around 20 million doses of the vaccine for the US this year. The company anticipates receiving FDA authorization in the coming weeks, paving the way for potential emergency use authorization and widespread distribution.

site_title: GIC enters into JV deal to acquire, develop logistics properties in Europe
summary: GIC has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Melcombe Partners to acquire and develop urban logistics properties in Europe, focusing on the UK, France, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands. The venture aims to capitalize on the growth of e-commerce and the shortage of logistics space in European cities. GIC believes the venture will generate resilient returns due to increasing occupier demand and changing supply chain management strategies. This deal follows GIC's interest in the logistics segment in Europe, with other notable acquisitions including a Polish postal locker firm and a German retail logistics portfolio.

site_title: Marie-Antoinette's silk slipper fetches 43,750 euros at auction
summary: A silk slipper worn by Marie-Antoinette, France's last queen before the 1789 revolution, sold for 43,750 euros (S$69,800) at an auction in Versailles. The 22.5-centimeter-long shoe, adorned with four ribbons, was in good condition and rose quickly to its final price from an initial reserve of 8,000 to 10,000 euros. The shoe had been held by Marie-Emilie Leschevin, a close friend of the queen's head chambermaid, for 227 years before being sold. The sale reflects ongoing fascination with Marie-Antoinette and her lavish lifestyle.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, will seek clarification from authorities regarding the implementation of enhanced movement control orders on foreign workers' dormitories. Meanwhile, Wilmar International announced its inclusion in the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices, scoring high in sustainability indicators. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: PBOC tries to soothe nerves after SOE debt shocks
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, injected over $120 billion into the country's banking system to calm market nerves after a series of debt shocks involving state-owned enterprises (SOEs) led to a bond selloff. Despite the injection, short-term interbank borrowing costs remained elevated, reflecting concerns about future debt surprises. The move follows a series of defaults and downgrades of SOEs, including a default by Yongcheng Coal & Electricity Holding Group Co and a downgrade of Huachen Automotive Group's bonds. Fitch Ratings expects the number of state-owned entity defaults to rise marginally in 2021.

site_title: Britain decouples from EU with delay to bank, investment rules
summary: Britain has delayed the implementation of new bank and investment capital rules from June 2021 to January 1, 2022, to give the industry more time to prepare. The decision, made by the Bank of England, Financial Conduct Authority, and the UK's finance ministry, comes as the UK decouples from EU financial regulations post-Brexit. The delay is a response to industry feedback and will push back the shift to a simpler capital regime for British companies, which EU rivals will benefit from six months earlier.

site_title: Simon Property cuts purchase price for Taubman stake as Covid hurts retail
summary: Simon Property Group Inc has cut its purchase price for an 80% stake in Taubman Centers Inc by 18% to $2.65 billion, settling a legal dispute over the transaction. The original offer price was $52.50 per share, but the deal now includes a cash payment of $43 per share. The revised terms also see the Taubman family selling about one-third of their ownership interest, leaving them with a 20% stake in the company. The deal is expected to close later this year or early next year.

site_title: China output, retail sales continue to grow in Oct with virus under control
summary: China's economy continued to grow in October, with factory output expanding 6.9% and retail sales growing 4.3% year-over-year. The country's consumer spending surged during Alibaba's 11.11 shopping festival, with sales nearly doubling from 2019. Analysts attribute the growth to the pandemic being largely under control and a V-shaped economic recovery. However, headwinds remain, including trade sanctions and uncertainty around US-China relations, which may slow down export growth and manufacturing investment.

site_title: The US election's done and dusted, time for Trump to make graceful exit
summary: US President Donald Trump has refused to concede the presidential election to Joe Biden, despite projections of a decisive win. Trump has mounted questionable legal challenges to overturn vote counts in several states, alleging mail-in ballot fraud without evidence. Federal election officials have deemed the 2020 election the "most secure in American history." Trump's actions are seen as damaging to US democracy and undermining global trust in the country's leadership. His refusal to concede has sparked international concern, with allies and nations watching with unease, and speculation that Trump may eventually accept the results and make a graceful exit.

site_title: Asean's digital economy offers potential in post-Covid world
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is poised to leverage its digital economy to drive post-pandemic economic recovery. The region's internet economy is expected to grow to US$300 billion by 2025, with Indonesia and Vietnam boasting growth rates of over 40% annually. To tap into this potential, Asean member states must develop smart policies, encourage innovation, and empower businesses to grow and invest. However, restrictions on data flow and unilateral digital taxation measures may hinder inclusive economic growth and restrict opportunities for local businesses. The new Asean chair, Brunei, must galvanize member economies to work together and create a balanced policy environment.

site_title: SIA's Covid cover for Singapore-HK flights may draw bubble flyers
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) now offers Covid-covered add-on travel insurance for flights under the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble. The insurance covers certain situations arising from Covid-19, including emergency evacuation and repatriation costs if the insured is diagnosed overseas. Coverage differs between one-way and round-trip trips, and SIA's insurance partner AIG excludes claims related to the coronavirus if the policy was issued after January.

site_title: China Oct new home prices cool, property investment accelerates
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.2% in October, the slowest monthly growth rate since March, as developers cut prices amid government scrutiny and tighter borrowing rules. Despite this, property investment accelerated 12.7% from a year ago, driven by home construction activity and robust sales. Analysts expect solid 5-10% year-to-date property investment growth, with strict buying restrictions and price caps likely to remain in place, especially in higher-tier cities.

site_title: Grab assures users platform is secure after police reports over unauthorised GrabPay transactions
summary: Grab has assured users that its platform is secure following police reports of unauthorised transactions made via its GrabPay e-wallet. Several cases involved one-time passwords sent to linked phone numbers, with transactions ranging from $100 to $260. Grab has implemented AI and machine learning to detect fraudulent activities, but experts warn that fraudsters may use malware or pose as users to access OTPs. The company urges users to stay vigilant and not share personal account information with others, especially during the festive shopping season.

site_title: Businessman makes offer for Blumont at 80% discount
summary: Businessman Mark Wee Liang Yee has triggered a mandatory unconditional cash offer to buy out Blumont Group after acquiring a 50.8% stake in the company. The offer, valued at 80% discount to Blumont's share price, aims to enhance the company's strategic direction and operations. Ultimate Horizon, owned by Malaysian businessman Siaw Lu Howe, has rejected the offer for its remaining 29.5% stake. Wee plans to review Blumont's business, potentially disposing of underperforming assets and redeploying employees.

site_title: Businesses still holding back on travel despite new green lanes
summary: Singapore's green lane (RGL) travel arrangements with six countries have seen a modest take-up rate among local businesses, despite the onerous application and approval process. The RGLs aim to facilitate short-term essential business and official travel, replacing quarantine periods with PCR tests and self-isolation. However, some companies, such as OSIM International, have successfully utilized the arrangements, while others, like Eastport Maritime and Patec, have faced difficulties in obtaining approval. The Singapore Business Federation has expressed concerns about the strict requirements, including quarantine periods, and advocates for a more efficient testing protocol as an alternative.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.97 points to 1,599.66, closing higher on Monday. The index gained 776 to 533 gainers to losers. Volume reached 16.276 billion lots worth RM6.715 billion.

site_title: Home Depot to buy HD Supply Holdings in US$8b deal
summary: Home Depot to acquire HD Supply Holdings in a deal valued at approximately US$8 billion. The home improvement chain will offer US$56 per share in cash to HD Supply shareholders, representing a 25% premium to the stock's last close. The acquisition aims to expand Home Depot's industrial goods offerings and create a more comprehensive platform for its customers.

site_title: Back in business, but with new management
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is expected to reverse many of Donald Trump's foreign policy actions, including withdrawing from the Paris climate accord and the World Health Organization. Biden aims to reassert America's role as a global leader, strengthening security alliances, and promoting liberal-democratic values worldwide. However, his approach will differ from Obama's, and he is unlikely to re-pivot the US back to the Middle East or launch new military interventions. Biden's China strategy will focus on a more assertive American line, while seeking cooperation on issues like climate change and North Korea.

site_title: Jumbo expects to post net loss in FY20; results due out by Nov 29
summary: Jumbo Group expects to report a net loss for FY20 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the global economy, with reduced dine-in crowds and travel restrictions affecting its business operations in Singapore and China. The group's financial performance will continue to be affected by the pandemic, but management has implemented cost and risk management measures and set aside reserves for future capabilities. The FY20 financial results will be released by November 29, 2020.

site_title: Tyson Foods beats sales estimates on strong pork, beef demand
summary: Tyson Foods reported stronger-than-expected quarterly sales of $11.46 billion, driven by increased demand for its beef and pork products during the Covid-19 pandemic. This recovery in sales volume follows temporary plant closures triggered by the pandemic. Net income also rose to $692 million, or $1.90 per share, from $369 million, or $1.01 per share, a year earlier. The company's sales exceeded analyst estimates of $11.01 billion.

site_title: Australian regulator says one in five buy-now-pay-later users missing payment
summary: Australian regulator ASIC reports that one in five consumers using buy-now-pay-later services are missing payments, with some experiencing financial hardship. The industry, which saw explosive growth since the COVID-19 pandemic, has led to increasing scrutiny. ASIC's latest report found a decline in missed payment transactions, but warned of harm to consumers. The regulator did not call for regulation, but the industry faces further review from Australia's central bank and the UK's Financial Conduct Authority.

site_title: US: Wall St up as Moderna says vaccine 94.5% effective
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as Moderna announced its experimental COVID-19 vaccine was 94.5% effective, boosting economic hopes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.65%, the S&P 500 rose 0.42%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.15%. The positive news follows recent stock market rallies, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China's JD.com posts 29% rise in quarterly revenue
summary: Chinese e-commerce company JD.com reported a 29% increase in quarterly revenue to 174.21 billion yuan (S$35.6 billion) in the third quarter, driven by strong online orders for groceries and essentials despite lifted coronavirus restrictions. This represents a significant jump from the same period last year, when net revenue was 134.82 billion yuan.

site_title: Britain expects to roll out Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine before Christmas
summary: Britain expects to start rolling out the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine in December, with health minister Matt Hancock stating it may be ready before Christmas, depending on its effectiveness. The country is working closely with the vaccine's manufacturer to ensure safe and timely distribution. The number of vaccines needed will depend on their ability to prevent transmission.

site_title: HBO Max ends Amazon standoff, reaches deal for Fire TV devices
summary: AT&T's WarnerMedia has reached a deal with Amazon to make its HBO Max app available on Fire TV devices, ending a standoff. The deal will allow HBO Max to grow faster, with the service now available on Amazon devices, smart TVs, and tablets. This comes after HBO Max finished the third quarter with 8.6 million active users, despite being unavailable on Roku devices with 46 million active accounts. An ad-supported version of HBO Max is planned for next year.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, according to recent data. In the US, Wall Street opened lower due to President Trump's new tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned that its second-quarter revenue may be lower than expected, with similar operating losses to the first half. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore's stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC set to deepen cooperation in green finance.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to shorten IPO settlement time to one day
summary: Hong Kong plans to reduce the time lag between an initial public offering (IPO) pricing and trading to one day from the current average of over five days. The proposed change aims to improve market efficiency, particularly in volatile markets, and has been welcomed by bankers and investors. The new digital platform will streamline communication and reduce the risk of market falls between pricing and trading. The changes are expected to launch in mid-2022 and are seen as a significant improvement for Hong Kong's competitiveness in the global market.

site_title: Sonova tops forecast on new products, customer confidence
summary: Sonova, the world's largest hearing aid maker, exceeded first-half core profit forecasts driven by cost control, new product launches, and growing customer confidence despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Arnd Kaldowski attributed the success to elderly customers being more comfortable visiting stores with proper safety measures. The company's hearing instruments business won new customers and maintained second-half targets. Adjusted first-half earnings reached 174 million Swiss francs, outperforming average analyst expectations.

site_title: Qantas looks to post-Covid future at subdued 100th birthday celebration
summary: Qantas, the world's third-oldest airline, marked its 100th birthday on November 16, 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. CEO Alan Joyce expressed optimism about the airline's future, citing its ability to reinvent itself every decade. Qantas had been in a strong financial position before the pandemic, but has since announced cuts to nearly 30% of its workforce and grounded most of its fleet. The airline expects to return to normal capacity by Christmas and is hopeful about resuming non-stop flights between Sydney and London in a post-Covid world.

images.alt_text: Mr Joyce is optimistic that the airline's plans for non-stop Sydney-London flights would be back on the table as its financial position improved.

site_title: Time is running out for Brexit deal, EU tells Britain
summary: The European Union warned Britain that time is running out for a Brexit deal, with talks resuming in Brussels amid concerns that it may already be too late to ratify one by the end of the year. Ireland's Foreign Minister says there are 7-10 days to find a way to unlock trade talks, while a senior EU official described the situation as "terribly late" and potentially irreversible. A "no deal" Brexit would disrupt supply chains and financial markets, with significant economic implications.

site_title: Support for vaccine and multilateral trading system crucial ahead of G-20 Summit: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of global support for a coronavirus vaccine and a rules-based multilateral trading system ahead of the G-20 Summit. Wong's three wishes for a successful summit outcome include rallying global support for the World Health Organisation, sending a strong signal for a multilateral trading system, and rebuilding the global economy in a sustainable manner. The G-20 summit, led by Saudi Arabia, aims to boost global recovery and address pressing issues such as economic growth, market stability, and climate change.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: Investors shouldn't ignore the underperforming Singapore market (Ep 1)
summary: Singapore's stock market has underperformed, but senior correspondent Ben Paul argues investors shouldn't ignore it. Despite the COVID-19 crisis, global stock markets like the S&P500 and Nasdaq have bounced back, while Singapore's market has lagged. Paul attributes this to a unique economic cycle, where companies in Singapore have ample value to unlock, despite being financially healthy. He highlights three companies, Sembcorp Industries, Keppel Corp, and Wilmar International, as examples of Singapore's leading companies that can drive growth.

site_title: Five shophouses on Tras Street, North Bridge Rd, Balestier Rd up for sale
summary: Five shophouses on Tras Street, North Bridge Road, and Balestier Road in Singapore are up for sale with a combined indicative price of S$33.3 million. The properties, ranging from 1,994 to 3,890 square feet, are zoned for commercial use and include a conservation shophouse fully tenanted and another pair with a gross plot ratio of 3.0. The sale closes on January 5, 2021, offering investors a diversification strategy in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust awards S$127.1m Kallang contract to Lum Chang
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has awarded a S$127.1 million construction contract to Lum Chang Building Contractors for a project at Kallang Way, part of the Geylang planning area. The 21-month project involves building two multi-user general industrial buildings, with a third building planned for a high-tech precinct. This award brings the total outstanding construction works for Lum Chang to S$1.9 billion, with earnings to be recognized progressively as the project completes.

site_title: Five shophouses, three Bukit Timah Plaza retail units for sale
summary: Five shophouses and three retail units in Singapore have been launched for sale, with a combined indicative price of S$33.3 million. The properties, located on Tras Street, North Bridge Road, and Balestier Road, offer a mix of commercial and residential use, and some have been fully tenanted. The expression of interest exercise for the portfolio closes on January 5, 2021, and buyers can purchase the properties individually or as a portfolio. The shophouses are zoned for commercial use and have a gross floor area ranging from 3,876 sq ft to 5,522 sq ft.

images.alt_text: One of the shophouses on Tras Street is a fully tenanted conservation three-storey shophouse with an attic and a land area of 1,994 sq ft and a total floor area of about 5,283 sq ft.

site_title: Defending against virus risks with tech tools
summary: Singapore is employing various technologies, including blockchain, Bluetooth, and artificial intelligence, to defend against COVID-19 risks. Local firm Accredify uses blockchain to create tamper-proof digital certificates for COVID-19 test results, while Zebra Technologies' MotionWorks Proximity solution uses Bluetooth and Wi-Fi to detect social distancing violations in workplaces. AI Singapore's FinePose app uses cameras to calculate physical distance and issue visual and verbal warnings. These technologies aim to prevent the resurgence of COVID-19 and support Singapore's cautious reopening of its borders and economy.

site_title: Moderna says its vaccine is 94.5% effective in preventing Covid-19
summary: Moderna's experimental COVID-19 vaccine has shown 94.5% effectiveness in preventing the disease based on interim data from a late-stage clinical trial. The vaccine, like Pfizer's, uses messenger RNA technology and does not require ultra-cold storage. Moderna expects to produce 20 million doses for the US this year and plans to ship immediately if it receives FDA authorization. The company's data also suggest the vaccine prevents severe cases of COVID-19 and has a relatively low side effect rate.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's new home sales dropped 51.7% in October to 642 units, the lowest since September. Hyflux, a water treatment company, was placed under judicial management. The Singapore government expanded support for precision engineering firms under the Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) scheme until March 2022. GIC invested in Europe's logistics properties, while ABB secured a US$30m contract for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. Foreign buyers remain attracted to Singapore property, with the STI finishing 1.4% higher on Monday.

site_title: UK shopper numbers plunge as English lockdown makes impact
summary: The UK shopper numbers plummeted 57.7% in the week to Nov 14, reflecting the impact of England's second national lockdown. Total shopper numbers across British retail destinations, including high streets, shopping centres, and retail parks, decreased by 64.7%, 65.7%, and 34.3%, respectively. The decline was attributed to non-essential shops and businesses being closed, as well as the encouragement to work from home. However, a recent trend in Wales suggests that footfall may rebound when the lockdown ends on Dec 2.

site_title: Nexi buys Nets in US$9.2b deal to create payment giant
summary: Nexi, an Italian payments processor, agreed to buy private equity-owned Nets in a $9.2 billion deal, creating Europe's largest payments firm by volume. The all-share deal values Nets at $12.4 billion and will generate about 170 million euros of synergies per year. The combined entity will have a presence in 25 countries and be uniquely positioned to catch further M&A opportunities. The deal is part of a wave of consolidation in the payments industry, following similar deals in the US and Europe.

site_title: Businessman Mark Wee makes offer for Blumont at 80% discount
summary: Businessman Mark Wee Liang Yee has triggered a mandatory unconditional cash offer to buy out Blumont Group after acquiring a 50.8% stake in the company. The offer is made at an 80% discount to Blumont's share price, with Wee intending to review the company's business and operations to enhance its strategic direction. Ultimate Horizon, owned by Malaysian businessman Siaw Lu Howe, has rejected the offer for its remaining 29.5% stake. Wee plans to keep Blumont listed and has no immediate plans to dispose of underperforming businesses or assets.

site_title: Vodacom resets targets with post-pandemic light on horizon
summary: Vodacom Group Ltd has reinstated growth targets for 2022, expecting mid-single digit growth in service revenue and operating profit over the next three years. The company has scrapped earlier forecasts due to the Covid-19 crisis and now sees a long-awaited auction of broadband spectrum in South Africa as a positive development. Vodacom has a strong balance sheet and plans to participate in the auction, which is expected to generate over 8 billion rand in revenue. The company has reported first-half gains in revenue, earnings, and customer numbers, and will pay an interim dividend of 4.15 rand.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore jumps to five-month high on surprise earnings rebound
summary: Genting Singapore shares surged 9.1% to a five-month high on Monday, driven by a sharp quarter-on-quarter turnaround in the company's earnings. The integrated resort operator's Q3 revenue and earnings beat market expectations, with local gamblers contributing to the rebound. Genting Malaysia Berhad also rose 8.7% to a four-month high. Analysts predict brighter prospects, with RHB upgrading Genting Singapore to "neutral" and raising its target price to 72 cents. A potential resumption of dividends and improved tourist demand are also expected to support the share price.

site_title: New Asean network to build logistics infrastructure
summary: Singapore logistics firm YCH Group and Vietnam's T&T Group are launching the Asean Smart Logistics Network (ASLN), a collaborative platform to support Asean's smart and sustainable growth. The ASLN aims to promote competitiveness and inclusiveness through a seamless and connected logistics infrastructure. The network's first project, the Vinh Phuc Inland Container Depot Logistics Centre, will integrate road, rail, air, and sea linkages, focusing on connectivity, sustainability, scalability, and agility. The project is expected to provide crucial infrastructure support for Vietnam's growing exports and contribute to human resource development goals.

site_title: Kissinger warns Biden of US-China catastrophe on scale of World War I
summary: Former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger warned President-elect Joe Biden that the US-China relationship is at risk of a catastrophic crisis comparable to World War I unless they restore communication lines. Kissinger expressed concern that the Trump administration's confrontational approach has driven the two nations toward a new Cold War. He urged the Biden administration to create an institutional system for leaders to remain in contact, and to avoid military conflict. Kissinger also noted that the COVID-19 pandemic could provide an opportunity for cooperation, but warned that differences in human rights and other issues will remain a challenge.

site_title: Russia focuses on freeze-dried vaccine doses as transport fix
summary: Russia plans to primarily produce freeze-dried Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine doses by spring, eliminating the need for ultra-low temperatures transport. Freeze-drying turns the liquid vaccine into a dry, white mass that can be stored at normal fridge temperatures, offering an advantage for export markets. Russia aims to produce 2 million doses this year, ramping up to 15 million per month by spring. The process is not significantly more expensive, but requires additional equipment and time. Freeze-drying could give Russia an edge in some export markets, particularly for mRNA vaccines.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.7%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.8%, and Paris' CAC 40 rebounding 1.1%. Optimism over a coronavirus vaccine and a pledge from President-elect Joe Biden's team against a nationwide lockdown contributed to the gains.

site_title: Merkel plans stricter contact rules to stem Covid-19 spread
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel plans stricter contact rules to slow the spread of COVID-19, amid concerns the virus is not easing quickly enough. Proposed measures include limiting public gatherings to 2 people from another household, making face masks mandatory in schools and for all age groups, and urging citizens to avoid private parties until Christmas. Merkel will discuss these measures with regional premiers on Monday.

site_title: Foreigners hold dear to Singapore property
summary: Foreigners, particularly Chinese buyers, are prioritizing property investments in Singapore, viewing them as a store of value and homes for their children. The 20% additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) on foreign purchases has made properties less attractive as speculative assets. Since 2011, China buyers have surpassed Indonesians as the largest group of foreigners buying homes in Singapore, with 39% of high-end purchases made by Indonesians and 14% by Americans. Cooling measures introduced in 2018 have contributed to this trend, and the removal of certain data sets on foreign buying has hindered analysis of their behavior.

site_title: Surprise cargo surge could surpass last year's holiday period
summary: Global demand for shipping and cargo is surging, potentially surpassing last year's holiday period, as consumers shop online to overcome coronavirus curbs. Container volumes are expected to dip only 2% in 2020, contrary to initial forecasts of a 15% slump. Freight carriers, including Hapag-Lloyd and Cargolux, are experiencing a surge in demand for goods such as toys, fashion items, and electronics. Online Christmas shopping is likely to benefit internet-focused businesses, potentially surpassing store sales in the UK for the first time.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Etihad to start direct flights to Israel next year
summary: Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways announced it will start daily flights to Tel Aviv in March, following the establishment of formal ties between the UAE and Israel earlier this year. The flights will connect with Etihad services to and from China, Thailand, India, and Australia, and will operate daily starting March 28. This move comes as the aviation industry faces its worst crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on trade bloc news
summary: South Korean shares reached their highest level in over two-and-a-half years, closing 1.97% higher at 2,543.03 on Monday, driven by foreign investors buying $415.20 million worth of shares on positive sentiment over the formation of a regional trade bloc.

site_title: Swiss tech firm ABB wins US$30m Tuas Water Reclamation Plant contract
summary: Swiss tech firm ABB has secured a US$30 million contract from Singapore's PUB to deliver a site-wide plant monitoring and control system for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant. The system will integrate over 100,000 input/output signals from various facilities, providing visibility of operations across the plant network. The system will also include alarm monitoring and security systems, as well as simulator training for operators. The contract aims to support Singapore's goal of closing the water loop and ensuring every drop is collected, treated, and reused, with the project expected to be completed in eight years.

site_title: Advanced material startup Krosslinker raises about US$1.3m in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based advanced material startup Krosslinker has secured about US$1.3 million in seed funding led by 500 Startups' South-east Asia-focused 500 Durians fund and Enterprise Singapore's SEEDS Capital. The funding will support the development of its patented aerogel technology, which is a lightweight, thermally insulating material. Krosslinker plans to use the funds to manufacture aerogels and validate its technology through pilot trials. The startup aims to introduce its aerogels in cold-chain biopharmaceutical packaging and subsequent applications in construction, reefer containers, and industrial insulation.

site_title: Endeavour to buy Teranga as gold dealmaking gathers pace
summary: Endeavour Mining has agreed to buy Teranga Gold in an all-share deal worth 5.1% premium, creating a top 10 gold producer with a combined entity set to list in London. Endeavour shareholders will hold 66% of the combined entity, while Teranga shareholders will hold 34%. The deal will add Teranga's Wahgnion mine in Burkina Faso and Massawa project in Senegal to Endeavour's portfolio. The acquisition, Endeavour's second this year, aims to improve portfolio quality and diversify in West Africa, with a production cost of around $850 per ounce.

site_title: Saudi Aramco turns to bonds to help fund US$75b dividend
summary: Saudi Aramco is returning to the bond market to fund a US$75 billion dividend commitment, seeking to raise debt after a 45% profit decline due to slumping crude prices. The company has reduced spending, cut jobs, and considered asset sales, but its gearing has risen to 21.8%, exceeding its target range. Aramco has hired Goldman Sachs to manage the bond sale, aiming to conserve cash and meet its investor payout obligations.

site_title: Finland's battery plans spark environmental fears
summary: Finland is planning to exploit its unique geology to become a major player in the electric vehicle battery industry, with the EU's largest nickel mine, Terrafame, producing over 50% of the country's turnover. However, this expansion has sparked environmental concerns, with campaigners warning that sensitive ecosystems will be destroyed. Despite this, Finnish companies claim to be at the forefront of sustainable practices, with Terrafame's methods producing a 60% smaller carbon footprint than traditional practices. The government has pledged €300 million in stimulus for the battery industry, but critics argue that the benefits will come at the cost of Finland's pristine environment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week with a 0.86% gain, following a record close on Wall Street fueled by hopes over a coronavirus vaccine. The Hang Seng Index rose to 26,381.67, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.11% to 3,346.97. This Asia-wide rally comes as investors look forward to developments in US-EU trade talks and the release of GDP data.

site_title: Australia: Stock market closes early on 'data issues', NZ at record high
summary: Australia's stock market closed early due to "market data issues" on Monday, but still managed to reach its highest close in nine months. The ASX 200 index ended up 1.2% after strong factory output from China boosted early trade. Trading resumed on Tuesday at 10am. Meanwhile, New Zealand's stock market extended its gains to a tenth session, reaching a record high. The halt in trading was due to underlying issues, which were identified and fixed.

site_title: Singapore's Oct new home sales halve on fewer launches, options curbs
summary: Singapore's new home sales in October dropped 51.7% to 642 units, the lowest since September. The decline is attributed to the authorities' clampdown on re-issuing options to purchase (OTPs) by developers and fewer project launches. On a year-on-year basis, sales were down 31.1% from 932 units in October 2019. The tighter OTP rules aim to foster financial prudence among buyers and prevent market distortion. Experts predict new sales may pick up in the next few months after the 'dust settles'.

site_title: NZ's Ardern says no Covid on meat exports; checking Chinese claims
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern stated she is confident no Covid-19 was found in meat exports, following Chinese claims of detection on frozen beef products from Brazil, Bolivia, and New Zealand. Ardern acknowledged positive tests on packaging of beef products from Argentina, which were in the same cold store as New Zealand products, but assured there was no Covid-19 on New Zealand's meat exports.

site_title: Hong Kong's exchange unveils proposal to speed up IPO process
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing has proposed an electronic platform, Fini, to shorten the time gap between IPO pricing and trading to one business day, aligning with rival bourses. The current five-day settlement process exposes investors to market risk, ties up pledged capital, and drains liquidity. The move aims to reduce market risk and improve liquidity in the system, bringing Hong Kong's listing venue in line with global standards.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's stock exchange unveiled a proposal to shorten the time gap between initial public offerings (IPO) pricing and trading to as little as one day, a move that will bring one of the world's busiest listing venues in line with rival bourses.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close at 29-year high on GDP rebound, vaccine race
summary: Japanese stocks reached a 29-year high, closing at 25,906.93 on the Nikkei 225 Index, driven by the country's first expansion in four quarters and progress in Covid-19 vaccine development. The economy grew 21.4% in July-September, reversing a 28.8% plunge in April-June. The Topix also gained 1.68% to 1,731.81. The rebound is seen as a boost to global markets, with shares rising worldwide despite US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: GIC ramps up interest in Europe logistics properties
summary: GIC has entered a joint-venture agreement with Melcombe Partners to acquire and develop urban logistics properties in Europe, focusing on the UK, France, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands. The venture will acquire last-mile distribution centers and urban logistics assets, driven by spiking e-commerce activity and tightening supply of logistics space in large European cities. GIC's chief investment officer believes the venture will generate resilient returns due to positive fundamentals and increasing occupier demand. This deal comes amid sustained interest from GIC in the logistics segment in Europe.

site_title: Thai central bank has tools to handle strong baht: Finance Minister says
summary: Thailand's central bank has the necessary tools to handle the strengthening of the baht, according to Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith. The baht reached its highest level in over 10 months against the US dollar, driven by foreign inflows fueled by optimism over the Thai economy. The finance minister expressed confidence in the central bank's ability to manage the currency's strength, citing the availability of policy tools.

site_title: Singapore government expands support for precision engineering firms
summary: The Singapore government has expanded its support for precision engineering firms through the Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) scheme, increasing financial support rates for large companies to 70% for manpower and 50% for other costs until March 2022. This expansion aims to build an ecosystem of precision engineering firms and support sectors like 5G, IoT, and biotechnology. The government also plans to enhance support for Singapore companies with manufacturing activities overseas and encourage the internationalization of their manufacturing footprint.

site_title: Asian indices up on Monday on RCEP deal; STI finishes 1.4% higher
summary: Asian stock markets rose on Monday following the announcement of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal, a mega free trade pact backed by China. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.35% to 2,748, driven by shares of Genting Singapore, Sats, and Keppel Corp, which rose 8.1%, 5%, and 3.7% respectively. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.86%, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index gained 2.05%. The RCEP deal is expected to boost Asian economies and investor sentiment.

site_title: Break the cycle of insomnia
summary: Insomnia rates may have increased due to the pandemic, with prolonged confinement altering sleep patterns in adults and children. Data from China and Europe suggests a link between confinement and disrupted sleep. In the US, doctors are also seeing an increase in insomnia cases. The exact causes of this phenomenon are still being researched, but evidence suggests that confinement is a key factor. As a result, individuals are advised to explore strategies to break the cycle of insomnia, such as establishing a relaxing bedtime routine and creating a sleep-conducive environment.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Red Sea signs utilities deal with ACWA Power led consortium
summary: Saudi Arabia's Red Sea Development Co has awarded a contract to ACWA Power to build and operate renewable power-based utilities for its luxury resort development. The project, valued in the billions, aims to generate 100% renewable energy, including solar and wind power, to supply the destination and other utility systems, with zero CO2 emissions.
