The deal marks the Red Sea Project as the region's first tourism destination powered solely by renewable energy, with the potential to expand in line with the development's growth.

site_title: NTUC LearningHub CEO Kwek Kok Kwong dies at age 53
summary: NTUC LearningHub CEO Kwek Kok Kwong, 53, died on November 14 after collapsing during a cycling session with friends. He had served in the Singapore Armed Forces from 1990 to 2012 and later held various roles, including chairman of the Singapore National Co-operative Federation. Kwek was remembered for his dedication to lifelong learning and his kindness and compassion. A wake will be held on Wednesday, and his family and colleagues are offering condolences.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported five new COVID-19 cases on November 16, all of whom were imported. The cases, including two Singaporeans and three long-term visit pass holders, had been placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. All were asymptomatic when tested. With no new community cases, the total number of cases in Singapore rose to 58,124, while 58,018 have recovered, and 40 remain in hospital. The government is monitoring close contacts and conducting tests at the start and end of quarantine periods to detect asymptomatic cases.

site_title: Growing fear: anxiety mounts over Vietnam's food staples
summary: Anxiety is growing in Vietnam over food safety, with millennials increasingly concerned about hygiene standards and pesticide use in street food. The country's food safety scandals have led to hospitalizations and even deaths, with some 70% of 16- to 30-year-olds citing food safety as their top concern. The World Bank estimates that food safety problems cost Vietnam around $740 million per year in productivity. In response, some Vietnamese are turning to "safe" farming and rooftop gardens to ensure they eat healthy food, with some farmers and consumers willing to pay a premium for pesticide-free produce.

site_title: Yinda Infocomm inks subscription agreement to issue new shares for S$5.8m
summary: Yinda Infocomm has signed subscription agreements with nine investors to issue 81.2 million new ordinary shares for S$5.8 million, representing a 7.2 Singapore cents per share price. The new shares will strengthen the company's financial position and improve cash flow, supporting its working capital requirements. The funds will also be used for new business opportunities, including a potential acquisition of International Biometrics.

site_title: Nissan explores possible sale of 34% stake in Mitsubishi Motors
summary: Nissan Motor is exploring the possibility of selling its 34% stake in Mitsubishi Motors, citing concerns over recovering from the coronavirus pandemic. The move would significantly alter the three-way alliance with Renault, which owns 43% of Nissan. Despite this, Nissan has stated there are no plans to change the capital structure with Mitsubishi. Both companies are cutting production and costs to return to profitability, with Mitsubishi Motors expecting an operating loss of 140 billion yen for the business year.

site_title: Australia agrees to A$1.2b settlement over 'robodebt'
summary: Australia's federal government has agreed to a A$1.2 billion settlement in a class action over the "robodebt" scheme, which affected over 370,000 welfare recipients. The scheme used automated algorithms with little human oversight, leading to wrongful debt recoveries. The settlement, subject to court approval, includes further payments to affected members, in addition to refunds received earlier. The move aims to address the issue and provide compensation to those impacted by the flawed program.

site_title: Australian bourse halts trading in longest outage in decade
summary: Australia's stock exchange, ASX Ltd, halted trading for the longest outage in over a decade due to a software issue, disrupting the debut day of an updated trading system. The outage occurred on Monday's trading session, with the market closing for the rest of the day. The cause has been identified and will be fixed overnight, allowing the market to reopen on Tuesday. ASX Managing Director Dominic Stevens apologized for the disruption, stating it "fell short of the high standards we set ourselves." The Australian Securities and Investments Commission has expressed significant concerns over the exchange's license obligations.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Masai calls for vigilance to side-effects of easy policy, ETF buying
summary: Bank of Japan board member Takako Masai warned of the need to address side-effects of prolonged monetary easing, including ETF purchases. With 10 years of easy policy, the BOJ's ETF holdings have increased significantly. Masai emphasized the importance of debating ways to maintain the effect of monetary easing while ensuring policy sustainability. Her comments highlight the BOJ's growing concern about the potential risks of prolonged easing, particularly with rising ETF holdings.

site_title: Construction in land-starved Hong Kong shrinks wild buffaloes habitat
summary: Construction on Hong Kong's Lantau Island is shrinking the habitat of its wild buffaloes, forcing them to forage in residential areas. The buffaloes, which have roamed the island since the 1970s, are crucial to the ecosystem, eating weeds and keeping wetlands fertile. Their presence also filters out pollution in the rivers. Activists warn that the construction will harm the ecosystem and the buffaloes, emphasizing the need for conservation efforts to protect this unique environment.

site_title: Korean Air to take over troubled Asiana Airlines for 1.8t won
summary: Korean Air will acquire Asiana Airlines for 1.8 trillion won, stabilizing the Korean aviation industry affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Asiana, already in financial trouble, reported operating losses of 268 billion won in the first six months of the year. The deal includes Asiana's affiliates, low-cost carriers Air Seoul and Air Busan, and aims to enhance competitiveness and minimize public funds. The acquisition is expected to rank Asiana as one of the world's top 10 airlines once completed.

site_title: UK house prices dip as sellers eye end of tax break: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices dropped 0.5% in November, the first decline in four years, as sellers anticipated the end of a tax break that benefits buyers of homes up to £500,000. The tax break, introduced in July, has fueled a housing market recovery. Analysts predict the market will slow in 2021 due to rising unemployment. The dip in prices may be a result of sellers pricing properties more realistically to secure a sale before the tax break expires in March.

site_title: Gazans take coastal walks to escape 'double confinement
summary: In Gaza, Palestinians are taking to the coastal path to escape the mental strain of living under a tight blockade. The Islamist group Hamas controls the enclave, imposing nightly curfews and restricting movement. Residents, like 40-year-old Walid al-Louh, are finding solace in walking to relieve stress. The coronavirus outbreak has exacerbated the hardship, but the coastal path has become a lifeline for those seeking a mental break. As the strip's population struggles under the blockade, this informal escape route is becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: Gold hits one-week peak as softer dollar, worsening pandemic lift appeal
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high on Monday, rising 0.5% to $1,896.85 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over the pandemic's impact on economic recovery. US coronavirus cases surpassed 11 million, prompting calls for urgent action from President-elect Joe Biden's top advisers. Central banks are expected to provide further monetary stimulus, supporting gold prices, which have soared 25% this year. Silver, platinum, and palladium also gained, while the dollar index fell 0.2%, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies.

site_title: China's new home prices rise 0.2% m-o-m in October
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.2% month-over-month in October, down from September's 0.4% growth, according to data released by the National Bureau of Statistics. This marks a slower pace of growth compared to the same month last year, when prices rose 4.3%. Policymakers are concerned about speculation and overheating, prompting regulators to roll out rules to prevent sharp price rises in many cities. The property market has been a key driver of China's economic recovery, with home sales and investment growing robustly after COVID-19 restrictions were lifted.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains on Wall Street. Japan's third-quarter GDP figures showed an exit from recession, supporting investor sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.13% to 25,671.98, while the Topix index gained 1.16% to 1,723.02.

site_title: Biden advisers urge immediate Covid-19 action as US infections close in on 11 million
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's top advisers are urging immediate action to address the nation's "deeply alarming" Covid-19 epidemic, which is nearing 11 million infections. They warn that a delayed transition could jeopardize vaccine distribution and call for Congress to pass bipartisan financial relief. Despite Republican President Donald Trump's resistance to mask mandates, several states have implemented new restrictions, including mask mandates and gathering limits. Experts warn that the situation is critical, with spikes in cases hitting every state and a record increase in hospitalizations.

site_title: Starburst's bosses interviewed in corruption probe; shares plunge 68%
summary: Starburst Holdings, a Singapore-based company that designs and installs anti-ricochet ballistic protection systems, saw its shares plummet 68% on Monday after its co-founders were interviewed by Singapore's anti-corruption watchdog. Co-founders Edward Lim Chin Wah, Yap Tin Foo, and Josiah Lawrence Ng Eng Long are out on bail amid the probe into the company's wholly-owned subsidiary, Starburst Engineering. The board believes the men should continue with their duties to ensure business continuity, but shares remain affected by the ongoing investigation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.76 points, or 0.17%, to 1,592.45 on Monday, driven by a higher opening. Volume reached 350.21 million lots worth RM73.43 million, with 298 gainers surpassing 64 losers.

site_title: Qantas celebrates subdued 100th birthday, looks to post-Covid future
summary: Qantas, the world's third-oldest airline, celebrated its 100th birthday on November 16, 2020, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite financial challenges, the airline's CEO Alan Joyce expressed optimism for the future, citing its ability to reinvent itself every decade. Qantas has grounded most of its fleet and reduced its workforce by nearly 30% but expects to return to normal capacity by Christmas in the domestic market. The airline also plans to resume non-stop Sydney-London flights once its financial position improves.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust awards S$127.1m Kallang contract to Lum Chang
summary: Lum Chang Holdings secured a S$127.1 million contract with DBS Trustee as trustee of Mapletree Industrial Trust for a 21-month industrial project at Kallang Way. The project involves the construction of two multi-user general industrial buildings. The contract is expected to be completed in late 2021 and is not anticipated to have a material financial impact on Lum Chang's current fiscal year. The company's total outstanding construction works valued at S$1.9 billion.

site_title: (Re)designing smart airports of the future
summary: Airports in the Asia-Pacific region are being urged to adopt creative strategies to ensure a safe and welcoming environment for travelers post-pandemic. The Airports Council International (ACI) Asia-Pacific suggests mega airports rethink their design process, incorporating "scalability-on-demand" solutions that integrate building systems, intelligent infrastructure, and digital technologies. Key design elements include virtualized cloud infrastructure, data analytics, and smart edge technology. Digital technologies can address safety concerns, improve passenger experience, and enhance sustainability. The use of digital twins, touchless entry systems, and real-time data analytics can help mitigate COVID-19 risks and create a healthier, safer, and more efficient airport environment.

site_title: Japan's economy rebounds from record slump as pandemic pain eases
summary: Japan's economy rebounded with a 21.4% annualized growth in the third quarter, exceeding forecasts, after a record postwar slump caused by the pandemic. The expansion marked the first increase in four quarters and followed a 28.8% decline in April-June. Private consumption and exports rebounded, but capital expenditure fell, suggesting ongoing uncertainty over the pandemic's impact. Despite recent signs of improvement, analysts expect the economy to shrink 5.6% in the current fiscal year and take years to return to pre-Covid levels.

site_title: Walmart nearly exits Japan after selling Seiyu stake to KKR, Rakuten
summary: Walmart is selling a majority stake in Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu to investment firm KKR and e-commerce company Rakuten for over $1 billion. The deal values Seiyu at 172.5 billion yen and comes after years of poor profitability amid stiff competition. Walmart will retain a 15% stake, while KKR and Rakuten will acquire 65% and 20% respectively. The move follows Walmart's divestment of underperforming assets in other markets, including Britain and Argentina.

site_title: Simon Property cuts purchase price for Taubman stake amid Covid hit
summary: Simon Property Group has agreed to cut its purchase price for an 80% stake in Taubman Centers by 18%, from $52.50 to $43 per share, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the retail industry. The deal, initially threatened to be walked away from, has been settled after a legal dispute and is expected to close later this year or early next year. The Taubman family will retain a 20% stake in the company after selling about one-third of their ownership interest.

site_title: Asia: Vaccine hopes help push equities higher
summary: Asian markets surged on Monday, driven by optimism over a virus vaccine and the US presidential election win, which lifted hopes for a return to normalcy. Tokyo led gains, rising 1.7%, while Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, and Singapore also increased. The news also boosted the signing of the world's largest free-trade deal by 15 Asia-Pacific countries. However, concerns about the US and Europe's rising COVID-19 cases tempered gains, with traders expecting a vaccine to be available in the new year.

site_title: Axington receives letter of demand from Kuala Lumpur landlord
summary: Axington, a Singapore-listed company, has received a letter of demand from its landlord Klang Valley Projects in Kuala Lumpur for approximately RM15,592 (S$5,905) in rent arrears and late interest charges for September and October. The company claims it is unable to make payments due to changes in its bank account's authorized signatories. If Axington fails to repay the outstanding sums by November 17, the landlord will initiate legal proceedings. The company's shares have been suspended since July amid changes in leadership and business plans.

site_title: Huge India oil well fire extinguished after five months
summary: A massive oil well fire in northeast India's Assam state has been extinguished after five months. The blaze, which began in June, killed two employees and injured a third, causing widespread damage and displacement. Experts from Singapore, the US, and Canada assisted in containing the fire, which was finally "doused completely" using a brine solution. The well has been killed but remains uncapped, and the area is still under observation. The disaster has cost Oil India over $30.5 million and poses long-term risks to local plant and animal life.

site_title: Vaccine scientist hopes for return to 'normal' by next winter
summary: Ugur Sahin, co-founder of BioN, predicts life could return to normal by next winter if widespread coronavirus vaccinations are rolled out. He anticipates a "hard winter" without major vaccination impact, but predicts a decrease in infection rates in summer. Sahin aims to deliver over 300 million doses by April next year, which could have an impact on the infection rate. A high take-up of vaccination by autumn is essential for this goal to be achieved.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Apac Realty to 'buy' on steady transactions, valuations
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded its recommendation on Apac Realty to "buy" from "hold", citing better-than-expected property transaction activities and "attractive valuations". The target price was raised to S$0.53, representing a 39% upside. The research team expects the overall market transaction value to ease 2.4% in FY2020, rebounding 3.4% in FY2021 and 7.9% in FY2022. Apac Realty's P/E ratio is now at 9.4 times, slightly below its five-year average.

images.alt_text: ERA, which is owned by Apac Realty, has launched 21 projects from January to October this year, DBS noted.

site_title: Sembcorp unit announces end of water concession in Batam
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit, Adhya Tirta Batam, has ended its 25-year water concession in Batam, Indonesia, after it expired on November 14, 2020. The concession allowed the company to supply potable water to residential and non-residential customers. The company has transferred assets to the local government entity, BP Batam, and does not expect the end of the concession to impact its earnings per share and net asset value. Sembcorp Industries' shares closed at S$1.69 on Friday, up 1.8%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.78% to 26,362.07, following a strong lead from Wall Street due to vaccine hopes and US officials' assurance against a nationwide lockdown. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also gained, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.47% to 3,325.62.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs jumps 13% as firm eyes mainboard transfer
summary: Medtecs International shares surged 13% to S$1.00 on Monday after the company announced plans to transfer its listing from the Catalist to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange, aiming to attract institutional investors and expand its investor base. The move comes after Aspen Holdings, another company eyeing a mainboard transfer, also saw a significant share price rise. Medtecs will be included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index on November 30.

site_title: Thai economy's decline slows on eased lockdown, stimulus steps
summary: Thailand's economy improved in the third quarter with a 6.4% contraction from the previous year, better than the median estimate of 8.8%. The government's easing of restrictions and stimulus measures helped control the Covid-19 outbreak, with Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha spending hundreds of billions of baht in cash handouts and stimulus measures. However, risks to the fragile recovery include a strengthening currency and political protests, with the central bank urged to temper the currency's rally to boost exports. Around 3 million workers were affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars join global risk rally as vaccine draws focus
summary: Australian and New Zealand dollars rose in a global risk rally as investors focused on the prospects of a Covid-19 vaccine, rather than new cases. The Aussie added 0.3% to US$0.7291, nearing a nine-week peak, while the kiwi dollar climbed 0.6% to US$0.6883, approaching a 19-month high. Analysts predict the kiwi could reach US$0.7400 or US$0.7500 due to New Zealand's robust economic recovery.

site_title: Parent of BMW's Chinese JV partner may undergo bankruptcy restructuring
summary: Huachen Automotive Group, a Chinese joint venture partner of BMW, may undergo bankruptcy restructuring after a creditor filed an application to a Chinese court. The company defaulted on a 1-billion-yuan bond and faces uncertain prospects for restructuring acceptance. Bondholders are concerned about unfavorable outcomes, and the restructuring could impact plans for Brilliance Automotive's expected privatization. The operation of Brilliance is unlikely to be affected by Huachen's bankruptcy, but the outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: MAS, Philippine central bank to enhance data connectivity between financial institutions
summary: MAS and the Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), have agreed to enhance data connectivity between financial institutions. The two central banks will now allow electronic data transfer, including personal information, between institutions for business purposes. The goal is to promote the development of the financial sector, increase efficiency, and support economic growth. The move also aims to facilitate risk management and compliance by making it easier to detect cross-border money laundering and terrorist financing patterns. The central banks hope to encourage other authorities to adopt similar policies.

site_title: CapitaLand to grow investments in business parks, logistics and data centres in China
summary: CapitaLand aims to increase its China investments in business parks, logistics, and data centers to S$5 billion over the next few years, from S$1.5 billion. The property giant plans to redeploy capital from asset recycling to these sectors, taking advantage of a supportive regulatory environment. CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) will explore opportunities from third parties and acquire from the market, with a target portfolio mix of 40% in integrated developments, 30% in retail, and 30% in new economy assets.

site_title: China's October factory output grows faster-than-expected
summary: China's industrial output rose 6.9% in October, exceeding expectations, as the country's economy continues to recover from the COVID-19 slump. Retail sales grew 4.3% year-over-year, missing forecasts but faster than September's 3.3% increase. The auto industry reported 12.5% growth in October vehicle sales, driven by demand for electric cars and trucks. China's economic recovery is accelerating, with a rebound in demand, strong credit growth, and stimulus measures expected to support growth in the fourth quarter. However, surging coronavirus infections in Europe and the US may cloud the global outlook.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher, tracking Wall Street; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20.50 points or 0.8% to 2,731.89, tracking a higher US market close on Friday. Gainers outnumbered losers 139 to 35, with shares in Genting Singapore and Medtecs International jumping 8.7% and 6.8% respectively. Singapore Telecommunications and local banks also rose, while BT announced plans to transfer its listing to the mainboard and be included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. The US market finished higher on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching new records.

site_title: Seven dead in Hong Kong apartment fire: officials
summary: A fire in an apartment in Hong Kong's Jordan district killed seven people and injured 17, making it the deadliest fire in the city in nearly a decade. The blaze broke out shortly after 8:30pm and paramedics and firefighters struggled to rescue victims. The incident occurred in one of Hong Kong's densely populated and tallest apartment blocks, where deadly fires were once a regular occurrence but have become less common due to increased safety measures.

site_title: Small UK manufacturers left in dark over Brexit plans: survey
summary: Nearly half of UK small and medium-sized manufacturers are uncertain about the impact of the end of the Brexit transition period, a survey found. 47% of respondents said they did not know how the transition would affect their business, while 32% believed it would hinder their recovery. Only 3% predicted a boost. The survey, conducted in October, comes as the UK economy faces challenges from the pandemic and Brexit uncertainty. Manufacturing output is 8% lower than pre-pandemic levels, but optimism is starting to return, with more manufacturers expecting turnover and employment to rise.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting, OUE, Medtecs, OCBC, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Lum Chang
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Genting Singapore reported a 65.7% slide in net profit, while OUE's third-quarter revenue tumbled 52.5% due to lower contribution from investment properties. Medtecs will transfer its listing from the Catalist to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange. OCBC announced the appointment of Wilson He as managing director of its stockbroking subsidiary. Lum Chang secured a S$127.1 million contract for an industrial project. Insurers' critical illness business outlook remains positive. Meanwhile, software company Medtecs will be included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index, and luxury watch retailer K6S reported lower sales and earnings for its half year.

site_title: IOC's Bach 'very confident' Tokyo Olympics will have fans
summary: IOC chief Thomas Bach expressed confidence that spectators will attend the Tokyo Olympics next year, citing coronavirus countermeasures being prepared by organisers and government officials. Bach praised Japan's efforts and pledged the IOC would work to ensure safe environments and vaccination for participants and spectators if a vaccine is available. Despite concerns over the pandemic, Bach stated he is "very, very confident" that spectators will be allowed to attend, with the Olympics being seen as a symbol of overcoming the virus.

site_title: China's recovery strengthens as consumer spending gains
summary: China's economic recovery strengthened in October, with industrial production rising 6.9% and retail sales expanding 4.3%. Consumer spending is catching up quickly after a slow start, supported by stimulus policies, strong export demand, and controlled virus outbreaks. Fixed-asset investment grew 1.8% in the first 10 months of the year, and the urban unemployment rate inched lower to 5.3%. The data suggests China's recovery is on track, with the central bank injecting liquidity into the financial system and officials considering withdrawing stimulus.

site_title: Australia: Bourse halts trading on 'data issues' after shares hit eight-month high
summary: Trading on the Australian Securities Exchange was halted on Monday due to "market data issues" shortly after shares reached an eight-month high. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 1.3% as vaccine optimism offset global lockdown worries. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, fueled the gains, while energy stocks rose on a 0.4% increase in Brent crude futures. The halt followed a report on the country's buy-now-pay-later sector, which showed one in five consumers were missing payments.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on hopes Opec+ maintains supply curbs
summary: Oil prices rose in early Asian trade on Monday, recouping losses as Opec+ is expected to maintain supply curbs, despite weaker fuel demand amid rising Covid-19 cases and higher production from Libya. Brent crude futures gained 0.6% to $43.05 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.9% to $40.48 a barrel. Opec+ is set to hold a ministerial committee meeting, which could recommend changes to production quotas, amid concerns about the impact of Libya's oil production and slowing fuel demand in Europe and the US.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged up in early Asian trade on Monday, recouping some losses from the previous session as hopes that Opec+ will continue to curb output offset concerns of weaker fuel demand amid rising Covid-19 cases and higher production from Libya.

site_title: Key areas under the RCEP
summary: The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement, signed on November 15, 2020, contains 20 chapters on trade, investment, and emerging areas. Key areas include trade in goods, services, investment, government procurement, intellectual property rights, e-commerce, and government procurement. The agreement aims to boost economic ties among 15 countries, including Singapore, in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Feuding in Downing Street as UK faces Covid, Brexit challenges
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces internal strife amid the COVID-19 pandemic and looming Brexit talks. Two of his closest aides, Dominic Cummings and Lee Cain, have resigned amidst reports of infighting. Johnson will work from Downing Street while in self-isolation after someone he was in contact with tested positive for COVID-19. The departures have been described as a "political pantomime" and may lead to a softer Brexit stance, but officials insist the talks will not be affected.

site_title: J&J starts two-dose trial of its Covid-19 vaccine candidate
summary: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) has started a two-dose trial of its Covid-19 vaccine candidate, enrolling up to 30,000 participants. The trial will run in parallel with a one-dose trial with up to 60,000 volunteers. The study aims to evaluate the duration of protection with a second dose and is being conducted in several countries with high Covid-19 cases.

images.alt_text: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) launched a new large-scale late-stage trial on Monday to test a two-dose regimen of its experimental Covid-19 vaccine and evaluate potential incremental benefits for the duration of protection with a second dose.

site_title: British PM Johnson self-isolating after Covid-19 contact
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is self-isolating after coming into contact with someone who tested positive for Covid-19. Johnson, who previously recovered from the virus, is well and symptom-free, but will follow the rules and continue working from Downing Street. The move comes after infighting among his top advisers and a recent drama in Downing Street. Johnson was set to make critical announcements on key issues, but the setback may impact his plans.

site_title: Sigh of relief as international organisations in Geneva await Biden presidency
summary: International organisations in Geneva breathed a collective sigh of relief with Joe Biden's presidential election win, marking a potential end to US disengagement and confrontation. The anticipated honeymoon could be short, however, as the Biden administration faces critical monitoring from the US. Despite Trump's relentless attacks on the WHO, Biden has promised to rejoin the organization and restore US leadership. The WTO also welcomes a changing of the guard, with optimism that discussions within international forums will become more constructive.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a stapled group, will likely not have income available for distribution for the year ending Dec 31 due to a net loss of US$556.9 million. Centurion Corp's third-quarter revenue fell 11.2% year on year, while Genting Singapore's net profit declined 65.7% year on year to S$54.4 million. These losses are attributed to weak performance in student housing operations and Resorts World Sentosa.

site_title: Albania's beloved brandy raises spirits, especially in time of Covid
summary: In Albania, the start of raki season is seen as a source of solace during the COVID-19 pandemic. Women, traditionally considered the primary producers of the fruit brandy, are playing a significant role in its production. Many families grow grapes and make wine and raki, which is often consumed at special occasions. Experts believe raki's popularity lies in its ability to offer comfort and hospitality, with its spiritual and symbolic significance.

site_title: Philippine mall titan quickens shift to China-style mixed retail
summary: SM Investments Corp, the largest mall operator in the Philippines, is accelerating its shift to a "China-style" mixed retail model, offering online and in-store options amid the pandemic. The company is expanding its virtual mall, boosting delivery services, and increasing its online presence. Sales at SM malls are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by the third quarter of next year, with foot traffic at 40% of its previous levels. The company plans to gradually restore rents in 2021 after waiving most tenant fees this year.

site_title: India set to have fewer rate cuts with high inflation, recovery
summary: India's central bank is unlikely to cut interest rates further due to high inflation, which has stayed above 7% for two consecutive months. Industrial production and economic growth indicators are showing signs of recovery, but the RBI may keep rates accommodative to manage inflation. Economists expect the RBI to focus on the long-term impact of negative real interest rates on the economy, rather than hiking rates. The RBI's recent statement that economic recovery prospects have brightened suggests it may not need to take further action to boost growth.

site_title: Australia back on outbreak alert as state reports jump in virus cases
summary: Australia has re-entered a state of outbreak alert after South Australia reported 14 new coronavirus cases, a significant increase from the previous day's three cases. Western Australia has introduced mandatory virus testing and a 14-day quarantine for interstate arrivals due to the border. The Australian federal government is offering assistance, including a national contact-tracing system and defense force personnel, to help contain the spread of the virus. The state of South Australia has ended a months-long streak of no local Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Medtecs seeks mainboard transfer, to be included in MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index
summary: Medtecs International plans to transfer its listing from the Catalist to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX), aiming to attract institutional investors and enhance visibility. The company will submit an application for transfer, subject to in-principle approval and shareholder approval. Additionally, Medtecs will be included in the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index from November 30, reflecting its market-leading position and expected higher trading liquidity. The proposed transfer and inclusion are seen as strategic moves to expand the company's business operations amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: The Linq @ Beauty World sells 96% of residential units in digital weekend launch
summary: The Linq @ Beauty World, a mixed-use development in Singapore, sold 96% of its 120 residential units in a digital weekend launch. Units fetched an average of S$2,150 to S$2,200 per square foot. The majority of buyers were Singapore citizens and residents from nearby areas. The launch, facilitated by a digital booking platform, marked a significant shift away from traditional, in-person sales methods. The project's developer, BBR Holdings, attributed the success to "sensitive and affordable" pricing.

site_title: Opec+ meets to discuss cuts despite vaccine hopes
summary: OPEC+ is considering delaying a planned supply boost of 2 million barrels a day due to a resurgence of the pandemic, despite hopes of a coronavirus vaccine reviving economic activity. The alliance, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, may postpone the increase by 3-6 months to support prices, which have rallied to a 10-week high. The decision comes as demand continues to suffer from lockdowns in Europe and a surge in supply from Libya, which has tripled its output to 1 million barrels a day.

site_title: Qualcomm gets US nod to sell 4G chips to Huawei
summary: Qualcomm has received a US license to sell 4G mobile phone chips to Huawei, an exemption to US trade restrictions imposed amid rising tensions with China. This comes after Qualcomm and other American semiconductor companies were forced to stop selling to Huawei in September. The license allows Qualcomm to sell related 4G products, including those for mobile devices, but analysts believe it will have a limited impact due to the shift to 5G devices. Other US companies, including Micron and Intel, have also applied for licenses to sell to Huawei.

site_title: Covid-19 pushes real estate into the future
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is driving the real estate industry into the future with emerging technologies. Robotic furniture, such as Ori's robotic office and Bumblebee Spaces' modular beds, is becoming increasingly popular in rental buildings. Healthier buildings are also being designed with systems to sanitize surfaces, diffuse viruses, and improve air circulation. Touchless technology, like key fobs and smartphone apps, is becoming more prevalent in managing communal spaces. Additionally, big data is being used to enhance resident experiences through apps and programs that track usage and monitor compliance with health guidelines.

site_title: Marie-Antoinette's silk slipper fetches 43,750 euros
summary: A white silk slipper once owned by Marie-Antoinette sold for 43,750 euros at an auction in Versailles. The 22.5cm-long, heeled shoe, adorned with four ribbons, was sold after a strong international bidding war, exceeding its reserve price of 8,000-10,000 euros. The shoe, which was in good condition apart from slight wear, is believed to have belonged to Marie-Antoinette at the age of 15, when she moved to Versailles.

site_title: Gulfport files for bankruptcy after M&A spree and price crash
summary: Gulfport Energy Corp, a natural gas producer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in US Bankruptcy Court in Houston, citing estimated liabilities of $2.5 billion as of September 30. The Oklahoma-based driller struggled due to low oil and gas prices, excessive debt, and a series of acquisitions over the past decade. The company had warned of potential bankruptcy in August after pressure from activist investor Firefly Value Partners. Gulfport's shares plummeted to 24 cents after the filing, following a decade-high of $3.38 in December 2019.

site_title: Moving more production onshore not sustainable approach to disruptions
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for cooperation to overcome supply chain disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, rather than solely relying on onshore production. The signing of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement marks a significant step towards broader regional integration, with 15 members spanning one-third of the world's economy and population. Chan urged countries to work together, citing the importance of multilateralism, as the RCEP is expected to be ratified by key countries in the coming months.

site_title: Johnson to unveil green plan that may halt sales of petrol cars
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to unveil a 10-point green plan, possibly banning the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2030. The proposal aims to meet the UK's net-zero emissions target by 2050, with the goal of creating two million green jobs by 2030. However, the car industry has expressed concerns that the ban could have a devastating impact, and research suggests that only a 2030 ban, including plug-in hybrids, would put the UK on track to meet its climate goals.

site_title: BOE's worst policy leak of 21st century tests regime of secrecy
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has faced its worst policy leak in nearly a quarter of a century, with The Sun newspaper revealing the institution's plans for a larger-than-expected expansion of quantitative easing (QE). The leak, which occurred between the decision and announcement, highlights the risks of leaving a time gap between taking decisions and publicly announcing them. The BOE's approach, instituted by former Governor Andrew Bailey's predecessor, Mark Carney, has been criticized as creating a "drip feed" of news, potentially leading to leaks.

images.alt_text: The BOE and the Treasury are investigating the leak, but Governor Andrew Bailey is unlikely to rush any changes as a sudden overhaul could be disruptive at a time when the country is battling the coronavirus and disentangling itself from the European Union.

site_title: Will Sunningdale minorities seize the chance to stay invested as the company goes private?
summary: Sunningdale Tech, a precision plastic components maker, is set to go private after its chairman and major shareholder Koh Boon Hwee, along with a unit of Novo Tellus PE Fund 2, offer S$1.55 per share to minority shareholders. This deal may reduce tension and criticism typically associated with such transactions, as minority shareholders can choose to remain invested in the company through shares in the holding company. The offer price is 22.5% less than Sunningdale's net asset value, but the company's revenue and earnings have declined in recent years.

site_title: Pandemic casts shadow over India's festival of light
summary: India's Diwali festival of light was marred by the COVID-19 pandemic, with millions celebrating amidst high pollution levels and social distancing measures. The country has the second-highest coronavirus infection count, and Delhi is experiencing a new surge. Traditional revelry was muted, with people opting for online shopping and avoiding crowded markets. Experts blame the rise in cases on Diwali crowds, while traders struggle to stay afloat due to the pandemic's economic impact, with millions losing jobs and the government announcing over $300 billion in stimulus measures.

site_title: Brexit talks must have breakthrough this week, say UK and Ireland ministers
summary: UK and Irish ministers urge a breakthrough in post-Brexit trade talks by December 31 to avoid US$1 trillion in trade disruption. British Environment Secretary George Eustice and Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney say time is running out for a deal, with negotiations stuck on issues like fishing quotas and state aid rules. Despite some progress, UK top Brexit negotiator David Frost warns of a possible failure to reach an agreement. US President-elect Joe Biden's comments on the Good Friday peace deal for Northern Ireland may also influence the UK's stance on a trade deal with the EU.

site_title: China in prime position to shape regional trade rules
summary: China has successfully finalized the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a mega free trade pact involving 14 Asia-Pacific countries, including Singapore. The agreement, covering 30% of the world's GDP, aims to speed up economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. China will use RCEP to cement its position as an economic powerhouse in the region, countering US influence and promoting globalization. The pact's completion marks a significant coup for China, with the US not participating and India withdrawing from the talks last year.

site_title: The Linq @ Beauty World sells 96% of residential units in digital launch
summary: The Linq @ Beauty World in Singapore sold 96% of its 120 residential units in a digital launch, with units fetching between S$2,150 and S$2,200 per square foot on average. The majority of apartments were bought by Singapore citizens and buyers from neighboring areas. The project's developer, BBR Holdings, attributed the successful sale to sensitive and affordable pricing, with BBR CEO Andrew Tan stating that the pricing was "practical and sold out."

images.alt_text: The bulk of the apartments went to Singapore citizens and buyers from neighbouring Hillview, Dairy Farm and Upper Bukit Timah.

site_title: Robo-adviser StashAway expands to UAE
summary: Robo-adviser StashAway has expanded to the UAE, launching in the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) to tap the growing mass affluent segment in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. The platform, now available to retail and accredited investors, is the first robo-adviser to receive an asset management licence from Dubai authorities with retail endorsement. Assets under management have grown 4.3 times in the last 12 months, with plans for continuous product development. StashAway aims to provide sophisticated, accessible global investment options to the UAE's large mass affluent segment.

site_title: China banking regulator vows to cut 'too big to fail' risk in innovation
summary: China's top banking regulator vows to cut the risk of companies becoming "too big to fail" in financial innovation. Chief risk officer Xiao Yuanqi said financial innovation should not form oligopolies and harm public interests. The comments reinforce the government's tightening stance on technology companies such as Alibaba and Tencent, and come after recent regulatory moves aimed at curbing their power. Regulators will subject companies to higher requirements, including capital and liquidity requirements, to ensure they bear the final risks. This move aims to promote fair competition and improve social well-being through financial innovation.

site_title: WHO registers one-day record in new Covid-19 cases
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reported a record daily number of new Covid-19 cases on Saturday, with 660,905 cases and 645,410 cases on Friday, surpassing the previous daily record high of 614,013. The Americas region registered a one-day record high of 269,225 new confirmed cases. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that the virus is not yet under control globally, stating that "a long way to go" remains in getting the virus under control. Total confirmed cases exceed 53.7 million and over 1.3 million people have lost their lives.

site_title: GM recalling nearly 69,000 Bolt EVs for fire risks
summary: General Motors is recalling 68,677 2017-2019 Chevrolet Bolt EVs worldwide due to a fire risk. The recall is related to five reported fires and two minor injuries, with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration investigating the issue. The vehicles are equipped with high-voltage batteries produced by LG Chem Ltd's Ochang, South Korean facility. To mitigate the risk, GM will update the vehicle's battery software to limit charging to 90% capacity. The recall includes 50,932 US Bolt vehicles and owners are advised to park their cars outside until repaired.

site_title: Billionaire Margarita Louis-Dreyfus finds a costly escape from debt drama
summary: Billionaire Margarita Louis-Dreyfus has secured a deal to sell 45% of the Louis Dreyfus Company to an Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund, ADQ, in a move to raise enough money to cover her debts. The deal, worth roughly based on the company's book value, caps over a decade of upheaval and will allow her to maintain control of the company. Despite buying out family members at high valuations, Louis Dreyfus will end up controlling a 55% stake in the trading house, which has struggled to compete with larger rivals.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust is still keen on acquisitions
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) remains optimistic about its suburban mall strategy despite the ongoing retail challenges. The trust has recently acquired 11 suburban retail properties for S$1.06 billion, following a S$1.34 billion fundraising exercise. CEO Richard Ng stated that FCT will evaluate any future acquisitions if they are yield accretive and beneficial to unitholders. The trust's gearing limit is set at 50% and can be temporarily increased if necessary. FCT expects suburban malls to benefit from the remote working trend, and will focus on improving operations and managing performance.

site_title: Philippines turns corner in Q3 but recovery may be slow: economists
summary: The Philippines' economy may have turned a corner in the third quarter with a 11.5% year-on-year GDP fall, but growth momentum is expected to remain weak due to weak overseas remittances and high unemployment. Economists predict a subdued recovery in domestic demand and export growth hindered by the Covid-19 resurgence in the US and Europe. The economy is expected to remain in contraction in Q4 with a 8.2% year-on-year GDP fall, resulting in a full-year growth of -9.5%. However, 2021 full-year growth is maintained at 7% due to base effects.

site_title: UK film industry healthy despite virus horror
summary: The UK film and television industry has seen significant growth despite the COVID-19 pandemic, thanks to a surge in online streaming and tax breaks. The sector has attracted global production teams and employed around 140,000 people, generating billions of pounds to the economy annually. Streaming platforms such as Netflix and Disney+ have benefited from the pandemic, while the UK government has supported the industry, allowing filming to resume quickly after lockdowns. New studios are set to open in 2022, including Sky Studios Elstree and Blackhall, further solidifying the UK's position as a major film production hub.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q3 net profit falls 65.7% on Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 65.7% decline in Q3 net profit to S$54.4 million due to weak demand at Resorts World Sentosa despite reopening in July amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's core integrated resort division saw a decline in earnings, despite investment and hospitality businesses returning to profitability. This marks a significant drop from the S$158.9 million in net profit during the same period last year.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust unlikely to have distributable income for the year; no Q3 payout to unit holders
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) is unlikely to have distributable income for the year due to loans and liquidity issues, as well as master lessees' inability to make rental payments. The trust's 18 US hotels are at risk if lenders take enforcement action. The prospects of a consensual restructuring remain uncertain. The trust's manager stated that it is highly unlikely to have distributable income for distribution in accordance with its distribution policy.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Dry Index, a key indicator of the shipping market, fell $2,350 to close at $12,498, erasing lingering doubts about the capesize market's short-term prognosis. The decline was largely attributed to the erosion in sentiment from the freight forward (FFA) market, despite potential relief from a Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Meet the Dec 15 Corporate Tax filing deadline with two new digital initiatives by IRAS
summary: Singapore's corporate tax filing deadline on December 15 is now more streamlined with two new digital initiatives by IRAS. Small and medium-sized companies can submit returns to both IRAS and ACRA simultaneously through an enhanced accounting solution, or file a simplified income tax return - Form C-S (Lite). This new system automates tax computation, simplifying the process for companies like GTCL, which previously had to file multiple returns separately.

images.alt_text: The new enhanced accounting solution makes the taxpaying experience seamless for SME owners.

site_title: Trump backtracks after tweeting that Biden won election
summary: US President Donald Trump initially accepted Joe Biden's election win, but later backtracked, claiming the election was rigged. Trump tweeted that Biden won due to widespread voting fraud, but later said he conceded nothing. Despite Trump's refusal to concede, Biden secured 306 Electoral College votes, exceeding the 270 needed to secure the White House. Trump's refusal to concede has locked up federal funds and blocked classified briefings, and his legal moves have been largely unsuccessful in overturning the result.

site_title: A boost for US stocks amid hopes of vaccine breakthrough
summary: US stocks surged last week after promising news from a Covid-19 vaccine trial, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average completing its strongest opening in post-World War II era. The vaccine developer Moderna is set to release more updates, and the US is grappling with a rapidly growing winter wave of coronavirus infections and deaths. Another round of emergency stimulus is also possible, leading to potential major market moves in the coming week.

site_title: Trafigura says employee detained in China over cargo shipment
summary: Trafigura says one of its employees has been detained in China over a cargo shipment with "high iron content" that customs rejected and launched a probe into. The detained employee was shown being marched away by customs officers in Shanghai. The incident occurred after a video was posted on China's General Administration of Customs Weibo account, showing officers inspecting documents and inspecting a handcuffed suspect. The detention is related to a solid-waste smuggling case in southern China's Guangdong province.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were three new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore on Sunday, bringing the total to 58,119. All three were imported cases who had been placed on stay-home notices upon arrival, marking the fifth consecutive day with no new community cases and none from workers' dormitories.

site_title: Freight firms report surge in shipments, and expect festive rebound
summary: Freight firms report a surge in shipments, with global demand expected to reach a seasonal peak that could outstrip last year's levels. Online consumer spending during the Covid-19 pandemic is driving the increase, with container volumes predicted to only dip 2% for 2020, contrary to initial forecasts of a 15% slump. This is attributed to shipping lines deploying more capacity, similar to the 2019 year-end holiday build-up. The rebound is expected to continue into the festive season.

site_title: Palm oil at 8-year high: Extend rally or reverse?
summary: The palm oil market has reached an 8-year high, with prices hovering above 3,200 MYR/MT. This marks a reversal from the market's decline in the first half of 2020, which was driven by bearish fundamentals, including increased production and poor demand expectations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The current rally is attributed to a combination of factors, including strong demand and limited supply, leaving the market uncertain about whether the rally will continue or reverse.

site_title: Insurers' critical-illness portfolios healthy, but risks lurk
summary: Singapore's life insurers reported mixed results for their critical illness (CI) portfolios in 2019, with four out of nine insurers incurring an underwriting loss. Despite this, the industry maintains that its CI portfolios are healthy due to growing demand for health insurance. The number of claims has more than doubled from 2018 to 11,535, highlighting the need for prudent management. Insurers face challenges in pricing and defining the terms of CI policies, with the potential for multiple claims within a single policy.

site_title: OCBC Securities boosts digital trading capabilities
summary: OCBC Securities has increased its digital capabilities by over 50% to enhance customers' digital experiences and offer greater access to global stock exchanges. The brokerage's online trading accounted for over 70% of total trade transactions in 2020, with trading volumes surging 80% since the virus outbreak. OCBC Securities aims to integrate its digital trading platform, iOCBC, with its retail banking platform to improve user experience. The company plans to boost digital infrastructure to offer customers greater access to global stock exchanges and tap into the younger investor market through targeted content and promotions.

site_title: ChariTrees light up the spirit of giving
summary: In Singapore, 27 specially designed Christmas trees lit up Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade on November 15, 2020, to support the fight against Covid-19. The annual fundraiser, ChariTrees 2020, raised about S$211,000 for charities focused on mental well-being and digital inclusivity, including the Samaritans of Singapore and TRCL's #ENGAGE Initiative. The event aimed to recognize the efforts of community heroes and individuals who have helped the underserved during the pandemic.

site_title: UK applies to be new dialogue partner of Asean
summary: The UK has applied to become a dialogue partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), aiming to strengthen its trading relationship with the bloc's 10 member states. UK Secretary of State for International Trade Elizabeth Truss stated that the move demonstrates the UK's commitment to cooperation with friends across South-east Asia and the wider Asia-Pacific. This application follows the UK's decision to leave the European Union, highlighting its desire to expand its international trade relationships.

site_title: Keppel associate Floatel's bonds forbearance agreement extended to Nov 30
summary: Keppel associate Floatel International has extended its forbearance and deferral agreement with ad-hoc committee of first-lien bondholders until November 30. The agreement, which was initially set to expire on November 15, has been extended numerous times since its inception in April. The Oslo-listed US$400 million senior secured, first-lien 9 per cent bonds are affected by the agreement, which aims to provide relief to the company amid ongoing creditor talks.

site_title: Dollar slips as vaccine rally peters out
summary: The US dollar slipped against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc on Friday, as investors became cautious about the risk of a new Covid-19 wave in the US and Europe. The yen strengthened, with a 0.46% gain against the dollar. This follows a 2% drop on Monday. The dollar's decline is a reversal of the recent rally driven by positive vaccine news.

site_title: Japan finds luring business from HK tough
summary: Tokyo is attempting to lure businesses from Hong Kong, spooked by protests and a security law, with promises of temporary office space, tax breaks, and streamlined bureaucracy. However, experts say Japan's high income taxes, low English fluency, and slow digital adoption may deter firms. Competitors like Singapore and Australia are also vying for the attention of Hong Kong businesses, with Singapore being the most obvious alternative due to its existing presence of international financial services firms. Tokyo's hopes for regional financial dominance may be uncertain.

site_title: Sias will work with all suitors to support Hyflux perp holders
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, will work with all investors to support Hyflux preference shares and perpetual securities (P&P) holders after a new rescue offer was proposed. American fund manager Strategic Growth Investments (SGI) has offered S$208 million in cash to buy and privatize Hyflux, which includes resolving debts owed to all stakeholder groups, including P&P holders. The SGI term sheet is non-binding and conditional, but the proposal aims to resolve debts owed to all stakeholders.

site_title: Conservatives flock to 'alt' social media in US election dispute
summary: Conservatives in the US are shifting to alternative social media platforms, such as Parler, Newsmax, and Rumble, due to frustration with Facebook and Twitter's content moderation policies. These platforms have allowed unverified claims of election malfeasance to spread, with Parler seeing a 3.3 million download surge since November 3. While some see this as a protest, others worry it could lead to the spread of misinformation and incitement to violence, as these platforms have become "filter bubbles" for conservatives.

site_title: Multilateral co-operation agenda continues after RCEP trade deal inked: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of multilateral cooperation, stating that shifting supply chains closer to home is unsustainable amid the global disruption of the Covid-19 pandemic. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade agreement, inked by 15 member countries, aims to eliminate tariff and non-tariff barriers on substantially all trade in goods within the bloc, covering one-third of the world's economy and population. The agreement is expected to take effect once ratified by six Asean countries and three non-Asean trade partners.

site_title: Airlines are making money selling everything but tickets
summary: Airlines are experiencing a surge in profits as they sell non-ticket items such as food, drinks, and baggage handling services. Singapore Airlines' shares jumped 21-year high after the country and Hong Kong announced a travel bubble, while Cathay Pacific Airways saw its largest gain since 2008. The Bloomberg World Airlines Index rose 9.7% amid hopes of a pandemic recovery, driven by successful COVID-19 vaccine trials. Airlines are expected to continue benefiting from the travel bubble and vaccine progress.

site_title: Asian borrowers close in on record for US dollar bond issuance
summary: Asian borrowers are nearing a record for US dollar bond issuance, with issuers from Asia ex-Japan selling over $323 billion so far this year. This surpasses the 2019 full-year record of $326 billion. The surge in debt sales is driven by ultra-low borrowing costs and investors seeking to hedge against the economic impact of the pandemic. However, the recent surge in coronavirus cases is keeping investors on edge. Analysts expect debt sales to remain elevated in 2021, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a record again next year. Asian dollar bonds offer higher premiums than US peers.

site_title: Critical illness cover: Read the fine print
summary: New critical illness (CI) insurance plans in Singapore offer enhanced benefits and pricing, but policyholders must carefully review the fine print. The Life Insurance Association's 2019 definitions have resulted in more exclusions for certain conditions, such as major cancer and stroke, with some cancers now considered minor or non-malignant. Standalone CI plans, which are not dependent on a whole life plan, have improved pricing and coverage. However, policyholders should be aware of benefit caps, exclusions, and surrender or maturity benefits, which may not be as straightforward as they seem.

site_title: Opec+ gets scant relief from vaccine as it meets to discuss cuts
summary: Opec+ is considering delaying its planned supply boost, citing a resurgence of the pandemic and a need to support prices above $43 a barrel. The alliance, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, had aimed to ease supply curbs in January, but ministers are now discussing a delay of 3-6 months. The decision comes as oil demand suffers from lockdowns in Europe and as Libya's production surges, adding to supply headaches.

site_title: Japan finds luring business from Hong Kong may be tough
summary: Tokyo is attempting to lure businesses from Hong Kong, which has been spooked by protests and a Chinese-imposed security law. The city is offering temporary office space, tax breaks, and streamlined bureaucracy, but faces challenges such as high income taxes, low English fluency, and a slow adoption of digital technology. Despite these obstacles, Tokyo's efforts may be hindered by fierce competition from Singapore, which is seen as a more obvious alternative. Experts say it's uncertain whether Hong Kong will experience an exodus, and many firms may instead reduce their presence in the city while increasing their operations elsewhere.

site_title: Centurion Corp Q3 revenue down by 11.2% as pandemic hits student housing market
summary: Centurion Corp, a mainboard-listed student housing operator, reported a 11.2% year-on-year decline in Q3 revenue to S$29.4 million. The drop was primarily due to a 39.4% decline in student housing revenue to S$6.16 million. However, worker accommodations contributed S$22.8 million, stable from the previous year. The decline in student housing operations was attributed to the impact of the pandemic on the market.

site_title: A breath of fresh air
summary: The Biden administration's potential return to repairing international trade alliances could positively impact countries in Asia, particularly Singapore, which has a trade-reliant, open economy. Businesses in the Asia-Pacific region have adapted to the pandemic by embracing digital transformation and new tools. China has urged Southeast Asian countries to support openness amidst looming US tariffs. Meanwhile, Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, and Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO. These developments suggest a mix of economic opportunities and challenges in the region.

images.alt_text: Wendy Johnstone, SVP & COO, APAC, Zendesk.

site_title: DoorDash got a big pandemic lift. Can it deliver again?
summary: DoorDash reported a significant surge in revenue, tripling to over $2.7 billion in the first nine months of 2020, driven by increased demand during the pandemic. The company has a growing cohort of loyal users through its DashPass program and has turned a profit for the first time. However, experts question whether this growth will be sustained, citing concerns about price sensitivity and intense competition in the market. DoorDash's co-founder Tri Tran predicts the growth will subside, but the company may still achieve profitability.

site_title: 'That's crazy': Kylie tops chart in five decades as 'Disco' hits No 1
summary: Australian singer Kylie Minogue has made pop music history by becoming the first female artist to have number one albums in Britain across five decades with her album 'Disco' topping the charts. The album, mostly recorded at home during lockdown, achieved the best opening week for any UK release in 2020 with 55,000 chart sales. Minogue shares this record with Bruce Springsteen and marks her eighth UK number one album, surpassing Cliff Richard, Elton John, and George Michael with seven each.

site_title: Elon Musk says 'most likely' has a moderate case of Covid-19
summary: Elon Musk announced he "most likely" has a moderate case of Covid-19, citing symptoms of a minor cold. He questioned the accuracy of his tests, stating he received wildly different results from different labs. Musk previously reported testing positive and negative twice on the same day using rapid antigen tests. His presence at a NASA launch event had been in question due to Covid-19, which was later rescheduled to Sunday evening. Musk's symptoms align with a typical cold, but his case highlights the uncertainty surrounding Covid-19 testing.

site_title: Freight firms report surge in shipments for festive rebound
summary: Freight firms report a surge in shipments for the festive season, with global demand expected to outstrip last year's due to online consumer spending surging during the Covid-19 pandemic. Container volumes may only dip 2% in 2020, contrary to initial forecasts of a 15% slump. Online shopping is expected to surpass store sales in the UK for the first time, with internet-focused businesses benefiting from the trend. Despite this, concerns remain over the longer-term impact of global economic growth weakening in the wake of the health crisis.

site_title: 15 countries including Singapore sign RCEP, the world's largest trade pact
summary: Fifteen Asia-Pacific countries, including Singapore, have signed the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), the world's largest free trade pact. Excluding the US, which left a rival Asia-Pacific grouping under President Donald Trump, RCEP aims to progressively lower tariffs across many areas. The deal is seen as a boost to China's economic influence in the region, while the US is absent from both RCEP and its successor to the Trans-Pacific Partnership. RCEP is expected to take effect once enough participating countries ratify the agreement domestically within the next two years.

site_title: New managing director of OCBC Securities to lead charge in boosting digital trading capabilities
summary: OCBC Securities has appointed Wilson He as its new managing director, tasked with boosting the company's digital trading capabilities. He joins from PhillipCapital Group and brings 18 years of experience in the financial industry. The company has seen a significant increase in online trading, with over 70% of total trade transactions now happening online. He will lead efforts to upgrade the digital trading platform, iOCBC, and expand access to global stock exchanges, with a focus on enhancing digital offerings and customer experience.

site_title: Wilmar, Riverstone and Neo chairs increase stakes
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Straits Times Index (STI) rallied 4.8% over five trading sessions from Nov 6 to 12, with the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index averaging a 3.2% gain. There were 13 share buybacks, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) and Neo Group leading the way. Wilmar chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increased his stake in Wilmar International to 12.76%, while Neo Group founder Neo Kah Kiat acquired 1 million shares, increasing his stake to 82.26%. Other notable transactions include Riverstone Holdings' executive chairman Wong Teek Son acquiring 170,000 shares, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' chairman Wee Ee-chao buying 27,000 shares.

site_title: Vodafone said to eye raising four billion euros in towers IPO
summary: Vodafone Group is considering raising approximately 4 billion euros (S$6.38 billion) from an initial public offering (IPO) of its European towers unit, Vantage Towers, in Frankfurt. The deal could value the business at around 20 billion euros, including debt, and make it the largest IPO on a European exchange in over three years. Discussions are ongoing, with strong demand for shares from institutional investors, and the final size and timing depend on market conditions.

site_title: SpaceX launches four astronauts to ISS on Sunday
summary: SpaceX launched its Crew Dragon "Resilience" spacecraft on Sunday, carrying four astronauts - three Americans and one Japanese - to the International Space Station (ISS) for a six-month mission. This marks the first operational flight to the ISS, following a successful demonstration mission in May. The launch, attended by Vice-President Mike Pence and second lady Karen Pence, was certified by NASA and paves the way for routine missions. The crew will join two Russians and one American on the ISS, with the goal of reducing reliance on Russia for ISS rides and paving the way for future missions to the Moon and Mars.

site_title: US refiner Citgo stops contributions to 401(k) retirement plans, will cut salaries
summary: US refiner Citgo has stopped contributions to employee 401(k) retirement plans due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the refining industry. The company will also reduce salaries on January 1. A message sent to employees cited the loss of demand resulting from the health crisis as the reason for the actions.

site_title: BOE's worst policy leak of 21st century tests regime of secrecy
summary: The Bank of England's (BOE) worst policy leak in nearly 25 years has raised concerns about its ability to keep secrets. A leaked article on November 5 revealed the BOE's plans for a larger-than-expected expansion of quantitative easing (QE) before it was announced. The leak, which involved the exact outcome, was attributed to the institution's practice of taking decisions and then releasing them after minutes were prepared. This approach, introduced by former governor Mark Carney, has been criticized as a "drip feed" of news, casting doubt on the BOE's ability to maintain secrecy.

site_title: Manhattan office glut grows as landlords face resurgent pandemic
summary: Manhattan office landlords are facing a growing glut of vacant space as the pandemic continues to empty offices. Despite some recent vaccine announcements boosting office landlord shares, the overall market remains uncertain. Leasing activity has dropped 45% in the third quarter, and sublease space is increasing, creating a market correction. Office rents have held up but are starting to fall, with asking rents dropping 3% to $80.29 per square foot. Many major tenants are signing new leases, but some are exploring subleasing or relocating due to employee dissatisfaction. The long-term outlook for rents is uncertain.

site_title: US urges Japan and South Korea to speak out on China
summary: The US has urged Japan and South Korea to speak out against China's treatment of minority Muslims and its actions toward Hong Kong and Taiwan, despite their trading relationships with Beijing. Deputy Assistant Secretary for Korea and Japan Marc Knapper emphasized the importance of protecting citizens' data from China, but stressed that Washington is not asking its allies to cut off or contain China. Instead, the US hopes its allies will "stand up and speak out" on behalf of democracy and freedom, as the two countries join a China-backed free trade agreement.

site_title: Rotation whiplash sends US$2.8 billion cycling through small caps
summary: A rotation trade in the US stock market sent $2.8 billion into small-cap ETFs, specifically the iShares Russell 2000 ETF (IWM), due to a potential coronavirus vaccine breakthrough. However, this inflow was followed by a $1 billion outflow over the next two days as US cases spiked. The trade whiplash reflects investors' difficulty in navigating the pandemic's end and economic reopening, with IWM set to outperform a tech-heavy ETF by 7.3% this week.

site_title: Australia, NZ should work with Asean to resume travel safely: Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Australia and New Zealand to lift travel restrictions on Asean countries, calling for cooperation in COVID-19 vaccine development and economic recovery. He suggested a gradual resumption of travel to facilitate economic activity and boost confidence in businesses. Lee also emphasized the importance of a rules-based system and open supply chains in promoting economic recovery, citing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and the Asean-Australia-New Zealand Free Trade Agreement as examples.

site_title: Battered by pandemic, Bali sees flicker of recovery as holiday season looms
summary: Bali, Indonesia, is experiencing a recovery from the pandemic, with a pick-up in activity ahead of the holiday season. The province's gross domestic product contracted 12.28% in the third quarter, the worst among Indonesia's 34 provinces. Despite a surge in domestic tourists, Bali's shores remain closed to foreign arrivals due to ongoing coronavirus cases. Governor Wayan Koster is weighing a reopening to international tourists, focusing on containing infections and increasing the recovery rate.

site_title: Covid pushes real estate into the future
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is driving the real estate industry into the 21st century with new technologies and innovations. Robotic furniture companies like Ori and Bumblebee Spaces are introducing futuristic takes on traditional features, such as robotic desks and modular beds that maximize floor space. Healthier buildings are incorporating systems to sanitize surfaces, diffuse viruses, and improve ventilation. Developers are also adopting touchless technology, apps, and data analytics to enhance resident experiences. These innovations have the potential to reshape the industry, but concerns about data collection and privacy remain.

site_title: Google is planning a new campus near Seattle
summary: Google is planning to build a new campus near Seattle, expanding its presence in the region. The company bought a 10-acre plot in Kirkland, Washington, and has also purchased another piece of land nearby. This move comes as tech firms continue to invest in the suburbs east of Seattle, seeking to be closer to their employees. Other companies, such as Amazon and Facebook, are also expanding in the area, with Amazon planning to employ 25,000 in Bellevue and Facebook leasing space at the Spring District.

site_title: Two new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, both imported
summary: Two new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 58,116, both of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. There were no community cases or cases in workers' dormitories. The Ministry of Health reported 12 new cases on Friday, also all of which were imported, and six more cases were discharged, leaving 50 patients in hospital.

site_title: Political security, economic ties key areas of cooperation for US and Asean, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of political security and economic ties with the US during the 8th Asean-US Summit. He urged the US to further deepen its presence in the region, supporting Asean's plans to develop the Indo-Pacific and uphold the rules-based international order. Lee also highlighted the benefits of strengthening Asean-US economic ties, including protecting supply chains and promoting open trade, with the US being a vital partner since World War II.

site_title: Wells Fargo ex-CEO and former top executive misled investors, says SEC
summary: Former Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf and ex-executive Carrie Tolstedt misled investors by signing off on false statements about the bank's community banking business, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) said. Stumpf agreed to a $2.5 million fine, while Tolstedt's case is ongoing. The SEC claims Tolstedt knowingly signed false statements and is seeking fines, disgorgement, and a ban on serving as a public company officer. This settlement follows earlier $3 billion and $1 billion settlements for Wells Fargo's consumer abuses.

images.alt_text: Former Wells Fargo & Co chief executive officer John Stumpf and ex-top executive Carrie Tolstedt harmed shareholders by signing off on misleading statements about the success of the community banking business, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) said.

site_title: Australia media giant Nine Entertainment's boss Hugh Marks quits
summary: Hugh Marks, CEO of Australia's largest locally-owned media company Nine Entertainment, has resigned after five successful years in the role. Marks didn't provide a reason for his departure and will ensure a smooth transition as the company embarks on its next stage of growth. A formal process for finding his replacement will be initiated. Marks has been in charge of Nine Entertainment since 2015, overseeing the merger with the Fairfax newspaper group and managing assets including an Australian television network, radio stations, and newspapers.

site_title: US states racing to buy ultra-cold vaccine freezers, fuelling supply worries
summary: US states and cities are racing to purchase ultra-cold freezers needed to store Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine, despite CDC advice to hold off, citing a lack of infrastructure. Specialized freezer makers are experiencing long waits, with some estimating months-long delays. The demand for ultra-low temperature freezers is driven by concerns over the vaccine's storage requirements, with at least half a dozen states purchasing units in anticipation of the rollout. The scarcity of freezers has raised concerns about waste and the potential to turn patients away due to storage limitations.

images.alt_text: US states, cities, and hospitals are scrambling to buy ultra-cold freezers that can safely store Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine, ignoring advice from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to hold off.
