WeWork's leadership believes the pandemic will recede, and companies will return to co-working spaces, aiming for profitability next year and a potential IPO after that. The company's membership ended the quarter at 542,000 across 859 locations.

site_title: Biden takes Arizona, cementing presidential win despite Trump's refusal to concede
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden is projected to win the battleground state of Arizona, securing 290 electoral votes and cementing his presidential win despite President Donald Trump's refusal to concede. Biden leads Trump by over 5.2 million votes in the popular vote, and a hand-count audit in Arizona found minor discrepancies. Despite Trump's claims of widespread fraud, Republican officials and lawmakers have backed his attempt to contest the election results, but some have urged Trump to allow Biden to receive intelligence briefings, acknowledging his potential to occupy the White House.

site_title: Singapore Airlines prices S$850m five-year convertible bonds at 1.625%
summary: Singapore Airlines priced S$850 million five-year convertible bonds at 1.625% interest, with a conversion premium of 45.8% over its last closing stock price. The bonds were fully subscribed and will mature on Dec 3, 2025. The company plans to allocate 60-80% of the proceeds for operating cash flow and debt service, and 20-40% for capital expenditure. The deal strengthens the airline's liquidity position and bolsters its ability to navigate the challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SATS, ComfortDelGro, Golden Agri, OUE C-Reit, Metro, UMS
summary: Singapore stocks were active on Friday, with SIA launching new S$850 million five-year convertible bonds. SATS reported a quarterly loss, but reduced the red ink to S$33.2 million. ComfortDelGro posted a net profit of S$21.7 million for the third quarter. Golden Agri Resources narrowed its net loss to US$5 million for the fiscal third quarter. OUE C-Reit's distributable income rose 15.8% year on year. Metro Holdings recorded a net profit of S$19.8 million for the first half. UMS Holdings saw its net profit rise 41% to S$12.9 million for the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares dip tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.6% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 2,695.60 at open on Friday, tracking Wall Street losses due to US Covid-19 case concerns. The benchmark index declined 16.3 points, with decliners outnumbering advancers 74 to 52. Key losers included Thai Beverage, Singtel, and DBS, while Medtecs International gained 4.5%. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq also retreated due to renewed coronavirus fears, overshadowing potential vaccine optimism.

site_title: Princess Diana makes dramatic debut in 'The Crown'
summary: Princess Diana makes a dramatic debut in the fourth season of Netflix's "The Crown," with Emma Corrin portraying the young princess. The season explores Diana's ill-fated marriage to Prince Charles, including her struggles with bulimia and the couple's eventual breakup due to infidelity. Royal expert Penny Junor says Charles felt powerless to help Diana, becoming "callous" in the process. The season also covers the late 1970s and 1980s, including the Falklands War and the queen's handling of a security breach at Buckingham Palace.

site_title: Pita patter at Miznon
summary: Miznon, a casual eatery in Singapore, serves authentic Israeli cuisine, introducing locals to its flavors. Created by Masterchef judge Eyal Shani, the restaurant offers a variety of dishes, including eggs, steak, rotisserie chicken, and cauliflower, all made with fresh and simple ingredients. The pita bread is a signature item, made with a secret recipe from Tel Aviv and is highly recommended. With a fast-paced and casual atmosphere, Miznon is a great introduction to Israeli food, but may not be suitable for those seeking a more refined dining experience. Rating: 7.

site_title: Oil falls on coronavirus surge, unexpected US crude stockpile rise
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday due to the surge in coronavirus cases and unexpected rise in US crude stockpiles. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude prices dropped 27 cents and 33 cents, respectively, to settle at US$43.53 and US$41.12 per barrel. Despite a promising experimental coronavirus vaccine, oil demand remains shaky, with the International Energy Agency predicting a slow rebound in 2021. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) also lowered its demand forecast, considering extending production cuts or deeper cuts if needed.

site_title: Golden Agri Q3 net loss narrows from previous quarter on higher CPO prices
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a narrower net loss of US$5 million in its fiscal third quarter, down 92% from US$61 million in the previous quarter, due to higher crude palm oil prices. Revenue fell 7% to US$1.61 billion, but the company's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) rose 19% to US$124 million. The company attributed the loss to foreign exchange translation and deferred tax expenses, but noted that long-term industry fundamentals remain in place despite supply chain challenges and price volatility.

site_title: Q&M Dental receives proposal for disposal of remaining stake in Aidite
summary: Q&M Dental Group received a non-binding proposal from Aidite shareholders to dispose of its remaining 9.19% stake in the associate. Talks are ongoing, with no definitive terms agreed upon. The company advised shareholders to exercise caution and noted no certainty of a transaction. Q&M Dental Group shares fell 1.06% after the announcement.

site_title: Sasseur Reit Q3 DPU rises 7.6% to 1.764 S cents
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), reported a 7.6% rise in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.764 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended September 30, 2020. The increase was mainly attributed to lower tax expense and interest expense. The REIT's rental income under entrusted management agreements was S$30.3 million, down 1% year-on-year. The distribution will be paid out on December 28, following books closure on December 14. The portfolio occupancy rate remained stable at 93.1% for the quarter.

site_title: 'No evidence' of lost or changed votes: US election officials
summary: US election officials stated there is "no evidence" of lost or changed votes, or voting systems being corrupted, in the presidential election. They rejected claims by President Donald Trump and Republicans that fraud and lost ballots led to his loss to Democrat Joe Biden. The officials, including heads of state and federal election security bodies, assured the security and integrity of the elections, saying they have confidence in the process.

site_title: UK regulators will intervene if full Brexit upends markets, says FCA's Delfas
summary: UK regulators will intervene if full Brexit upends markets, says FCA's Delfas. Britain's financial regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), is preparing for a smooth transition as the UK's full departure from the EU on December 31. FCA head Nausicaa Delfas warned of potential risks, including derivatives trading and customer service, and vowed to intervene if necessary. The FCA will work closely with the finance ministry and Bank of England to address any issues arising from the transition.

site_title: Foreign buying trends in Singapore property change
summary: Foreign buyers in Singapore's property market are shifting their focus from investment to living in the country, amid ongoing cooling measures. Industry watchers note a decrease in short-term investments and an increase in buyers purchasing homes to live in. This change is attributed to the changing dynamics of the market, with buyers prioritizing long-term stability over quick returns.

site_title: World leaders and NGOs press for vaccine cash at Paris Forum
summary: World leaders and NGOs are pressing for international funding to make COVID-19 vaccines available to everyone, with a $28 billion funding gap remaining for the ACT-Accelerator program. The Paris Peace Forum aims to raise $500 million to ensure fair access to tests, treatments, and vaccines. The World Health Organization estimates that only $3 billion of the needed $38 billion has been secured, with $4.5 billion urgently required to maintain momentum. The international community is urged to prioritize equitable access to vaccines, with leaders promising significant funding commitments, including $226 million from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

site_title: SingPost prices S$250m fixed-rate notes due 2030 at 2.53%
summary: SingPost issued S$250 million in 10-year fixed-rate notes with a 2.53% coupon, to be issued on Nov 19, 2020, and maturing on Nov 19, 2030. The notes are backed by SingPost and will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing borrowings. HSBC, OCBC, and UOB are joint lead managers and bookrunners. This is SingPost's first debt capital markets issue in eight years, and the notes were oversubscribed with an order book of over S$800 million.

site_title: Goldman Sachs highlights diversity in new partner class
summary: Goldman Sachs has invited 60 new partners, nearly half of whom are from diverse backgrounds, including 47% women, Black, Asian, or Latino. The new class includes 16 women and 43 partners based in the Americas, with seven in technology investment banking. Goldman aims to increase diversity among senior ranks, with CEO David Solomon setting specific goals to interview and hire more diverse candidates. The partnership ranks have nearly doubled since 1999, but have shrunk in recent years as part of a strategy to reduce the bank's top-heavy structure.

site_title: US won't enforce TikTok ban following court order: official
summary: The US government has delayed enforcement of a ban on TikTok, a Chinese-owned social media platform, due to a federal court order. The Commerce Department stated it would not enforce the ban as it was issued an injunction by a federal judge on October 30. The ban was ordered due to national security concerns raised by US officials. The ban remains enjoined and will not go into effect pending further legal developments.

site_title: Disney swings to loss as pandemic clobbers revenue
summary: Walt Disney Co reported a loss of $710 million in the quarter ending October 3, citing a 23% decline in revenue to $14.7 billion due to the global pandemic. However, its streaming service Disney+ reached 73 million subscribers, a positive sign for the company's shift towards competition with Netflix.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney on Thursday said it swung to a loss in the just-ended quarter as the global pandemic hit its theme parks and cinema operations.

site_title: Double, double oil and trouble as layoff axe falls on Jurong Island
summary: US oil giant Chevron is set to slash at least 10% of its jobs in Singapore operations, amid plans to cut global workforce and operating costs. This move comes just days after Shell announced it would cut 500 jobs in Singapore. Chevron's plan is to trim 10-15% of its global workforce to "match projected activity levels".

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 retreats after eight-day rally as recovery concerns weigh
summary: London's FTSE 100 index slipped 0.7% on Thursday, retreating from an 8-day rally, amid concerns about a faltering economic recovery from the coronavirus-driven recession. The UK economy grew by 1.1% in September, slower than expected. Bank and energy stocks were among the biggest losers, with Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc tumbling 8.6%. Analysts predict a stuttered recovery until a vaccine is widely available, and a challenging two months ahead in managing the virus.

site_title: Bank of England's Bailey hopes for 'goodwill' after Brexit transition ends
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey expressed hope for a 'spirit of goodwill' between Britain and the EU to ease trade disruptions when the post-Brexit transition period ends on January 1. The BoE estimated that border delays could cost Britain 1% of GDP, or around $5 billion, due to customs checks. Bailey also expressed concerns about economic uncertainty due to Covid, but felt encouraged by recent vaccine developments. He noted that Britain's financial sector is better prepared for the transition, regardless of a trade deal.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The Guinness Great Grill Out and Singapore Cocktail Festival are taking place in a hybrid format this year. The Guinness Great Grill Out features online grilling lessons, Guinness-infused dishes at partner restaurants, and a Spicy Sausage Experience with eating competitions. The Singapore Cocktail Festival offers signature cocktails at participating bars, online masterclasses, and bottled cocktails made according to recipes from around the world. The festival also features a Pisco Nights event in December.

site_title: PropNex net profit rises 10.6% in Q3
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a 10.6% increase in its net profit to S$6.8 million in its fiscal third quarter, despite a dip in revenue. This marks a significant improvement from the year-ago period. The company's bottom line growth is attributed to its strong performance in the current quarter.

site_title: Movers and shakers of the tech world: Singapore wants you
summary: Singapore launched a new Tech.Pass scheme to attract up to 500 top foreign tech talents, targeting founders and leaders with experience in hot tech firms. The initiative aims to draw talent away from countries like the UK and France. The Economic Development Board (EDB) will oversee the program, which is expected to benefit local companies.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell says too soon to gauge vaccine impact
summary: Federal Reserve Chief Jerome Powell stated it's "too soon to assess" the impact of a potential coronavirus vaccine on the economy in 2021, despite promising trial results. Despite the vaccine's efficacy of around 90%, significant challenges remain regarding production, distribution, and efficacy for different groups. Powell warned that the next few months could be challenging due to the virus's spread. The European Central Bank and Bank of England also cautioned against exuberant hopes for the vaccine's economic impact, emphasizing the need for central bank support.

site_title: Singapore calls for equitable, steady, affordable supply of Covid-19 vaccines to region
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for an equitable, steady, and affordable supply of Covid-19 vaccines in the region. He stressed regional cooperation to mitigate the pandemic's long-term impact, supporting global initiatives like the Covax Facility. Singapore will contribute $100,000 to the Covid-19 Asean Response Fund. Lee also called for Asean to enhance its competitiveness in the post-Covid world, leveraging existing frameworks and technology.

site_title: The art of wearing men's jewellery
summary: Men's jewelry has gained popularity as a stylish accessory, with strong, clean lines and darker gemstones being favored. A luxury watch on one hand is often complemented by a discreet bracelet or signet ring on the other. Experts advise choosing jewelry that complements the outfit, with minimalist designs suitable for minimalist clothing styles. Strong, bold pieces can create a sharp contrast with simple, monochromatic outfits, as seen in Arte Oro's bespoke jewelry designs.

site_title: Saudi prince vows 'iron fist' against extremists after attacks
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has vowed to strike against extremists with an "iron fist" after a bombing at a World War I commemoration in Jeddah, claimed by the Islamic State group. The attack, which left at least two people wounded, comes amid Muslim fury over French satirical cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. Prince Mohammed warned those seeking to carry out jihadist acts of a "painful and severe punishment," and said the kingdom will not tolerate extremism. The attacks have sparked international condemnation, with diplomats from France, Greece, Italy, Britain, and the US condemning the attack as "cowardly."

site_title: Higher due-diligence standards for IPO managers, sponsors with immediate effect
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced enhanced listings due diligence guidelines for issue managers and full sponsors, effective immediately. The guidelines focus on assessing internal controls, sustainability and viability of a business, and compliance, particularly in niche or higher-risk areas. The changes aim to boost investor confidence and quality listings, following cases such as Y Ventures' accounting error and Ayondo's regulatory issues. The guidelines also emphasize the importance of robust due diligence and professional scepticism, and may impact issuers operating in specialized or restricted industries.

site_title: US Oct CPI misses forecasts to remain flat
summary: US consumer prices remained flat in October, missing forecasts of a 0.1% increase, and rose 1.2% from a year earlier. The core index, excluding volatile food and energy costs, was also unchanged from the prior month. The data signals subdued inflation as the pandemic continues to weigh on demand. The Federal Reserve has indicated it plans to keep interest rates near zero through 2023, and inflation expectations have eased.

site_title: IMF eyes new relationship with biggest shareholder after Biden win
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva is seeking to reset the organization's relationship with the US, its largest shareholder, under the Biden administration. Biden's commitment to multilateral institutions and climate change should help the IMF advance its targets, including green initiatives and a potential increase in Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) to boost member countries' currency reserves. Georgieva also plans to emphasize fiscal stimulus spending to build a "greener, smarter and fairer" global economy during a meeting with global leaders at the Paris Peace Forum.

site_title: US: Renewed coronavirus fears sends Wall Street lower
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, November 12, 2020, due to concerns about spiking Covid-19 cases, overshadowing optimism from a potential vaccine. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 1.1% to 29,080.17, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 1.0% and 0.7% respectively. Renewed restrictions on economic recovery have investors on edge, with Wells Fargo analysts stating "vaccine optimism is being overshadowed." Despite this, some stocks, such as Disney+, jumped in after-hours trading, while Pfizer lost 2.5%.

site_title: Singapore market snaps three-day rally as vaccine euphoria subsides
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.05% to 2,711.90, snapping a three-day rally, as initial vaccine euphoria subsided. Aviation and tourism-related stocks continued to build on gains, but at a slower pace. The STI's biggest gainer was Keppel DC Reit, while Sembcorp Industries and DBS fell 2.4% and 1.8% respectively. The market was influenced by mixed sentiment across Asian markets and concerns about global Covid numbers and China's tech bounce.

site_title: Green shoots for Singtel, but virus recovery still unclear
summary: Singtel reported a 36.2% decline in underlying net profit to S$837m for the first half of the year, despite a quarterly increase. The company's management remains uncertain about its turnaround trajectory, but approved an interim dividend of 5.1 cents per share. Despite the decline, the board expressed "encouragement" from the latest quarter-on-quarter growth.

site_title: Temasek looks to health, edu-tech investments after pandemic
summary: Temasek Holdings is in talks to make its first direct investment in health care and education tech startups in South-east Asia, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's surge in demand for digital services. The state investment firm is reviewing potential targets to add to its $227 billion portfolio. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for digital health and education services in the region.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn's Q3 profit beats estimates ahead of new iPhones
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, also known as Foxconn, reported Q3 net income of NT$30.9 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company forecasts flat revenue growth in the October-December period, despite a potential boost from Apple's new iPhone lineup. Hon Hai's consumer electronics and components businesses are expected to grow, while its computer division will decline. The company is diversifying into emerging tech, including robotics and automotive, to reduce dependence on Apple.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to issue 300m euro notes due in 2025
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has priced an offering of 300 million euros (S$477.8 million) of five-year senior unsecured notes with a 2.125% coupon rate. The notes will be dual-listed on the Singapore Exchange and Luxembourg Stock Exchange, with net proceeds used to refinance existing debt. The move is expected to extend the trust's weighted average debt maturity profile to 3.9 years and will leave 90% of its debt unsecured. The deal was oversubscribed, with strong demand from global credit investors.

site_title: Blackstone, GIC said to be eyeing logistics firm InPost
summary: Blackstone Group and GIC are among the firms eyeing logistics firm InPost, controlled by Advent International. The Polish postal locker firm's owner is also considering an initial public offering (IPO) in 2021, which could value the business in the billions of euros. European private equity firms EQT and Hellman & Friedman, as well as the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, are also evaluating InPost and could team up with other bidders. Advent plans to list InPost in 2021, following the success of Allegro's IPO, which saw the e-commerce platform's stock nearly double since listing.

site_title: UK house price growth hits 21-year high: RICS
summary: The UK housing market experienced a 21-year high in house price growth, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) gauge rising to +68 in October, surpassing the previous high in September 1999. The surge is attributed to pent-up demand and a temporary cut to property sales tax. However, economists predict a quieter market in 2021, citing a challenging employment picture and withdrawal of government incentives. Despite this, housing sales expectations remain in negative territory, and the economy is expected to struggle through the next few months.

site_title: Hong Kong lawmaker resignations a 'challenge' to authority: China
summary: China has condemned the mass resignations of pro-democracy lawmakers in Hong Kong, labeling them a "blatant challenge" to its authority. Fifteen legislators, including half of the opposition group, have quit the chamber in protest over Beijing's ousting of four colleagues. The move has sparked international criticism, with the US, EU, and Canada urging the reinstatement of the lawmakers. China's national security law has led to a crackdown on dissent, with restrictions on gatherings and media, and analysts warn of a "final nail in the coffin" for Hong Kong's democratic rights.

images.alt_text: China warned on Thursday that the mass resignations of pro-democracy lawmakers in Hong Kong were a "blatant challenge" to its authority over the city.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q3 net profit falls 69% to S$21.7m
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported a 69% decline in Q3 net profit to S$21.7 million, down from S$70 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 16.3% to S$816.5 million, with public transport services and taxi segment posting significant losses. The company attributed the decline to the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit uncertainty. Despite a net loss in the first half, ComfortDelGro is still cash-generating and has a strong balance sheet, with a net cash position of S$115.5 million.

site_title: Expedia Singapore website operator stops false claims on promotions
summary: BEX Travel Asia, operator of the Expedia Singapore website, has ceased false claims on promotions, including the validity period for 'Daily Deals'. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) initiated an investigation in April 2020 and found 55 "Daily Deals" offers where prices remained the same after 11.59pm, contrary to BEX's representation. The false claims mislead consumers into believing a price benefit is only available for a limited time, creating unwarranted pressure. BEX has undertaken to comply with the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act and cease all unfair practices.

site_title: UAE's largest developer on the prowl for assets to boost income
summary: ALDAR Properties PJSC, the UAE's largest listed developer, is seeking to acquire assets to boost its management units amid market strains. The company's CFO, Greg Fewer, stated that "times of crisis and dislocation always give rise to opportunities for corporate action or combination." ALDAR's low cost of capital, attributed to its landlord status, positions it to take advantage of market opportunities. The move aims to enhance its management units and capitalize on the current market conditions.

site_title: Bottoms up for non-drinkers
summary: Non-alcoholic, "zero-alcohol" beverages are gaining popularity among cocktail enthusiasts, with demand increasing from one in 10 to one in five customers asking for such drinks in three years. This trend is driven by the growing market for zero-alcohol options, which is small but growing, according to industry experts. Consumers can now choose from a range of zero-alcohol beer, wine, and spirits, offering more sophisticated and flavorful alternatives to traditional mocktails.

site_title: Collapse in BTS label's shares sparks South Korean soul searching over IPO process
summary: BIG Hit Entertainment, the management label behind K-pop sensation BTS, experienced a significant collapse in its shares after a brief pop on its first day of trading. The sudden drop is prompting South Korean regulators to reconsider the IPO process, particularly for mom-and-pop investors. Mandatory holding periods may be imposed on institutional investors to prevent similar crashes. The incident raises concerns about the stability of the South Korean stock market and the need for stricter regulations to protect smaller investors.

site_title: No-frills festival focuses on great films
summary: The Singapore International Film Festival (SGIFF) has launched a no-frills event featuring great films, due to reduced cinema capacities. The festival, now a hybrid of in-cinema and online screenings, showcases 70 films, including the acclaimed drama "Nomadland" starring Frances McDormand. Tipped to be a top contender for the 2021 Oscars, the film's release was delayed by the pandemic. Despite reduced numbers, the festival's focus on quality films remains unchanged.

site_title: Tokyo's tiny noodle bars shut down rather than put up prices
summary: Tokyo's tiny noodle shops are struggling to adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic, with some owners choosing to shut down rather than increase prices. Despite the need to balance costs with customer affordability, many proprietors remain sensitive to price hikes due to Japan's deflationary mindset. However, some entrepreneurs, like Kazuhisa Tanaka, are taking a fresh approach by implementing dynamic pricing, adjusting prices based on demand and customer loyalty. This approach has been adopted by larger chains like Ippudo, allowing them to maintain revenue while adapting to the pandemic's impact.

site_title: US dollar steadies amid rising Covid-19 cases
summary: The US dollar steadied amid rising Covid-19 cases, with investors tempering expectations of a vaccine's impact on the economy. The dollar index hovered between 0.1% higher and flat, while the euro gained 0.1%. The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined 0.2% due to increased risk aversion. The US stock market opened lower, following a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada.

site_title: Suburban malls doing better than those in central region; FCT among top picks: OCBC
summary: Suburban malls in Singapore are outperforming those in central regions despite the rise of online shopping, according to OCBC. Online sales rose to S$479 million in June, accounting for 18.7% of total sales. OCBC analyst Seow Zhi Qi attributed suburban malls' success to their diverse tenant base and convenient locations. The trend contrasts with the decline of central malls, which face increased competition from online retailers.

site_title: Develop agility that outlasts the pandemic
summary: The pandemic has sparked numerous innovations, with companies like Dyson, Alibaba, and Chick-fil-A developing new products and processes to adapt to the crisis. This agility has been seen in various industries, showcasing the benefits of shedding bureaucratic constraints. By adopting agile management, companies can quickly innovate and respond to changing circumstances. This agility outlasts the pandemic, leading to long-term benefits and competitiveness.

site_title: Manhattan landlords woo apartment-seekers with record freebies
summary: Manhattan landlords are offering record freebies to attract renters, resulting in a 33% increase in newly signed leases in October compared to the same period last year. This is the first annual increase in leasing since July 2019, according to a report by Miller Samuel and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. The surge in leasing activity suggests that renters are becoming more attractive to landlords, leading to a shift in the balance of power in the rental market.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q3 distributable income up 15.8% after merger
summary: OUE C-Reit's distributable income rose 15.8% to S$34.2 million in Q3, driven by a 11.4% increase in net property income, mainly due to the merger with OUE Hospitality Trust in 2019. The increase was partially offset by S$5 million in rental rebates to retail tenants.

site_title: SIA proposes convertible bond issue with indicative size of S$850m
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) proposes issuing up to S$850 million in convertible bonds convertible into new shares, with proceeds to fund operating cash flow, debt service, and capital expenditure. The bonds are expected to be priced in the coming days, with a closing date of Dec 3. SIA's decision may be a cost-saving measure, as convertible bonds offer cheaper financing and accounting advantages.

site_title: Singapore gears up for cleaner cars with bigger rebates, EV battery leasing
summary: Singapore has announced two initiatives to encourage the adoption of cleaner cars and electric vehicles. Starting January 1, 2021, the Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) will offer bigger rebates for cleaner cars, while increasing surcharges for polluting models. Additionally, a new business model for electric vehicle battery leasing is being developed by Singapore utilities firm SP Group and South Korean car maker Hyundai Motor Group, with the goal of accelerating EV adoption and making low-carbon mobility solutions more accessible.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SingPost has established a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with HSBC as the arranger. The programme allows the company to access international debt markets and diversify its funding sources. This move is part of SingPost's efforts to strengthen its financial position and reduce its reliance on Singapore government guarantees. The programme's issuance is expected to provide SingPost with increased flexibility and liquidity in the future.

site_title: Standard Life Aberdeen's new CEO eyes deals in shift to passive products
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen's new CEO, Stephen Bird, aims to reverse investor exodus by shifting the company's focus to passive management, with plans to build a stable of passive products that could account for 30% of its assets. Bird plans to streamline the firm's brands, invest in data analysis and cutting-edge technology, and make acquisitions to build its offerings in areas such as ETFs and private markets. He believes that embracing passive management is essential for the company's growth and survival, saying "if you stay as an old traditional asset class asset manager, you will be extinct."

site_title: Gold market authority threatens to blacklist UAE and other centres
summary: The London Bullion Market Association (LBMA) is threatening to blacklist countries with large gold markets, including the UAE, unless they meet regulatory standards on money laundering and gold sourcing. The LBMA has identified China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Russia, Singapore, South Africa, Switzerland, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US as major gold centres. The UAE is under scrutiny due to serious issues in Dubai, including criticism from the Financial Action Task Force and non-governmental organizations over its controls and alleged smuggling of gold from Africa.

site_title: US initial jobless claims decline by the most in five weeks
summary: US initial jobless claims declined by 48,000 to 709,000 in the week ended Nov 7, the largest drop in five weeks, signaling a gradual recovery in the labor market. Continuing claims fell by 436,000 to 6.79 million, but the number of people claiming extended assistance increased. The data beat economists' projections and suggests the labor market is holding up despite record Covid-19 infections and a lack of government stimulus.

site_title: Founder of China property platform Beike is worth US$20b
summary: Zuo Hui, founder of China property platform KE Holdings Inc, is now worth US$20.5 billion, making him one of the 100 richest people on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His company, Beike, has become China's largest platform for housing transactions and services, with sales surging 80% to 46 billion yuan last year. Despite regulatory challenges and increased competition, KE's success is attributed to its use of artificial intelligence and big data to improve its service and provide market insights. The company's backers, including SoftBank, Hillhouse Capital, and Tencent, have seen their investments more than triple since KE's New York listing in August.

site_title: Renewables developer Equis raises US$1.25b from management and Abu Dhabi, Canada funds
summary: Equis Development, a Singapore-based renewable energy and waste infrastructure developer, has raised US$1.25 billion in capital funding from Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board, and its management team. The funding will be used for operational and investment activities, securing assets, and investing in its existing portfolio, primarily focusing on renewable energy, biomass, and waste recycling assets. Equis plans to commit over US$2 billion into renewable energy and waste infrastructure assets in Australia, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan over the next two years.

site_title: Restructuring helps Nissan trim whopping loss forecast
summary: Nissan Motor Co Ltd reduced its annual operating loss forecast by 28% to a still significant $3.2 billion, thanks to restructuring efforts and better-than-expected sales. The company plans to cut production and costs by 15% and 300 billion yen, respectively, to improve profits. Nissan aims to achieve its restructuring plans, with a focus on online sales and sales in China and the US. The automaker also plans to issue $8 billion in dollar-denominated bonds and consider euro-denominated debt to bolster its finances.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 drop at open as Covid-19 cases surge
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Thursday as coronavirus cases surged, leading to a drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500. The Dow fell 165.72 points, or 0.56%, to 29,231.91, while the S&P 500 opened 9.99 points lower, or 0.28%, at 3,562.67. Investors are weighing the timeline for an effective vaccine, contributing to the market's uncertainty.

site_title: Home prices in the US increase at the fastest rate since 2013
summary: US home prices rose 12% in the third quarter, the largest annual increase since 2013, according to the National Association of Realtors. This surge is fueled by low mortgage rates and a scarce supply of listings, with 117 regions experiencing double-digit gains. The median single-family home price reached $313,500. Despite favorable mortgage rates, affordability concerns persist due to rapidly rising housing prices, which may price out first-time buyers.

site_title: It is time for airlines to focus on digital transformation
summary: Airlines are being urged to focus on digital transformation to drive innovation and improve operational efficiency during the ongoing pandemic. By leveraging downtime, airlines can prioritize digitalization, enhance connectivity, and implement data analytics, biometrics, and artificial intelligence to drive post-pandemic growth. A recent industry poll suggests that most airlines believe digital technologies will be central to their recovery, with 84% predicting no long-term disruption to passenger experience investment. Airlines that prioritize digitalization will be better equipped to meet the needs of passengers seeking connectivity and will be more resilient in the long term.

site_title: Surbana Jurong buys into Jewel Changi designer
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean group, has acquired a majority stake in London-based Atelier Ten, the designer behind Changi's Jewel and Gardens by the Bay. The acquisition aims to enhance Surbana Jurong's focus on environmentally sustainable projects. Atelier Ten will continue to operate as an independent brand, with 300 employees across 11 offices worldwide. The partnership is expected to strengthen Surbana Jurong's presence in the US and European markets and Atelier Ten's involvement in Asia, promoting sustainable built environments.

site_title: A balm for troubled times
summary: Singapore Repertory Theatre (SRT) has seen a surge in ticket sales for its production of "Tuesdays With Morrie," a live show adapted from the bestselling non-fiction book. The show, starring Benjamin Chow and Remesh Panicker, has become a lifeline for the theatre company, which lost around S$2 million due to cancelled productions. The show's popularity has prompted SRT to add more shows, which are also selling quickly, offering a timely miracle for the theatre company. The production's success is a welcome relief after the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted live performances.

site_title: International institutions still matter to the US
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency has highlighted the importance of international institutions, contradicting his campaign rhetoric that they had let the US be taken advantage of. However, prior to 2016, American presidents generally supported these institutions, with exceptions such as covert actions under Eisenhower and Kennedy, and tariff levies under Nixon. Trump's approach has reminded the world of the need for effective and resilient international institutions, despite his own criticisms of them.

site_title: Get a fresh take on the market with BT's new podcast series
summary: The Business Times (BT) is launching its second podcast series, BT Mark To Market, hosted by senior correspondent Ben Paul, on November 16. The 10-minute episodes will offer insights and analysis of corporate stories and sector trends. BT Mark To Market is a natural extension of Paul's weekly column of the same name, which aims to simplify complex market sentiment and help listeners understand the overall market. The podcast follows the success of BT's Money Hacks podcast series, which has become the top podcast show in the SPH network with over 35,000 monthly downloads.

site_title: France says Japanese tyremaker Bridgestone to shut Bethune plant
summary: Japanese tyre maker Bridgestone has decided to close its Bethune plant in northern France due to low demand for its main product, low-profile tyres. The plant, which has 863 employees, will remain an industrial site, and the French government will work on possible new offers for the site. Junior Economy Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher stated that Bridgestone did not want to invest in the plant due to overcapacity, and the government aims to find the best possible solutions for the employees.

site_title: DBS to offer 24/7, self-service banking in at least a third of its branches soon
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, plans to overhaul at least a third of its 64 branches over the next 12-18 months to offer 24/7 self-service banking. The new "phygital" branches will feature digital ambassadors, enhanced services, and video teller machines, allowing customers to conduct transactions outside banking hours. This move aims to retain human touch while reducing cash transactions, which currently account for about one-third of DBS's transactions.

site_title: Good wines won't fix Thanksgiving, but they couldn't hurt
summary: A wine panel assessed eight wines for a Thanksgiving gathering, finding that good wine can enhance the experience without being a primary focus. The panel selected wines with acidity, balance, and relatively low alcohol, and praised their character and energy. Recommendations included white wines like a 2019 Côtes du Rhône blanc and a 2018 Mosel Riesling, and red wines like a 2018 Verduno Basadone and a 2017 Queen of the Sierra. The panel emphasized that the specifics of the wines don't matter as much as their overall quality, and that dozens of other wines could also be suitable for Thanksgiving.

site_title: One too many China property management IPOs?
summary: China's property developers are rapidly listing management units in Hong Kong, with at least 10 listings this year, including Evergrande. These asset-light businesses offer exposure to the Chinese property market without policy risk, but have drawn criticism for managers' high valuations. Despite early success, the market may become saturated, and the scarcity value of these listings will fade. Investors have taken stakes in these units, but the unpredictability of their performance poses a risk, particularly due to fluctuations in operating margins and acquisition strategies.

site_title: Revlon to avoid bankruptcy filing upon completion of debt deal
summary: Revlon has secured enough investor support to close its debt exchange, eliminating the potential for a bankruptcy filing. The company will pay off 69% of its $343 million in bonds due 2021 and $106.8 million of notes at 100 cents on the dollar plus accrued interest. This deal represents a step towards strengthening Revlon's capital structure and focusing on future growth, with CEO Debra Perelman stating it's an "important step towards strengthening our capital structure."

site_title: Sabana, ESR directors recommend voting for proposed merger of the 2 Reits
summary: Sabana Reit's directors and ESR-Reit's recommending directors recommend unitholders vote in favor of a proposed merger between the two real estate investment trusts (Reits) at a 0.94 ESR-Reit unit for one Sabana Reit unit. Unitholders must pre-register for the scheme meeting by Dec 4 and vote by Dec 1. The merger, if approved, would see the two Reits combine to form a new entity.

site_title: Yuletide dreams at Mandarin Orchard Singapore
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore is offering a range of festive gourmet treats for the holiday season, including oven-roasted Sakura chicken, roasted lamb roll, and traditional gammon ham. The hotel's kitchens are also providing innovative creations such as yule log cakes and decadent desserts. For those looking to dine in, Triple Three offers a Japanese-inspired international buffet with a variety of Christmas meats and seafood. A one-night package is also available, including breakfast and a set lunch at Chatterbox.

site_title: US consumer price index, core gauge unchanged in October
summary: US inflation remained unchanged in October, missing forecasts for a modest gain, driven by cheaper gasoline, declining medical-care costs, and lower clothing prices. The consumer price index rose 1.2% from a year earlier, while the core index, excluding food and energy costs, remained unchanged. This was the slowest reading in five months, following a 0.2% advance in September.

site_title: Catalist-listed Synagie Corporation now named V2Y Corporation
summary: Synagie Corporation has changed its name to V2Y Corporation after gaining shareholder approval and completing the disposal of its e-commerce business. The name change took effect on November 12, 2020, and the company's trading counter name on Catalist will be updated to V2Y Corp on November 17. The company also announced name changes for its various subsidiaries. The shares closed down 10.3 Singapore cents or 52.02% at 9.5 Singapore cents on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Luzhou Bio-Chem gets in-principle approval for delisting
summary: Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to delist from the mainboard, following a compulsory acquisition of its shares by founder Niu Ji Xing through investment holding company Starnova. Luzhou had applied for delisting on October 14. The Singapore Exchange stated that its decision is not an indication of the delisting's merits, and the acquisition is expected to take the firm private.

site_title: Five questions to ask about Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine has shown a 90% efficacy rate in a trial, but its long-term protection and effectiveness in vulnerable populations are unknown. The vaccine requires special storage and handling, which could impact its widespread distribution. The FDA is set to review the vaccine in December, and its approval could influence future vaccine development and usage. The announcement has raised concerns about the potential impact on future clinical trials and the development of other vaccines. Experts emphasize the need for continued study and scrutiny of the vaccine's safety and efficacy.

site_title: Indonesia pushes for SE-Asia travel corridor
summary: Indonesia is pushing for a travel corridor arrangement with South-east Asian countries to be implemented in the first three months of 2021. President Joko Widodo proposed the move to revive the region's economy, which is struggling with the largest coronavirus outbreak in the region and a technical recession. Thailand and Malaysia have expressed support for the arrangement, but other countries have not signaled their support. The proposed travel corridor would require the implementation of temporary fast lanes and health protocols to facilitate economic activity and alleviate the pandemic's impact.

site_title: IMF's Georgieva says G20 should synchronize investments to achieve faster growth
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva called on G20 countries to synchronize investments to rebuild from the coronavirus pandemic, saying this would achieve stronger growth at less cost. Countries can take advantage of idle investment capacity, available fiscal space, and low interest rates to boost jobs and growth, reducing economic inequality. By investing together, G20 countries would spend a third less to achieve the same output goal, according to Georgieva.

site_title: SIM launches new centre for systems leadership
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) has launched a new Centre for Systems Leadership to train youths, professionals, and organisational leaders in systems thinking. The centre, located at SIM Management House, will offer an 18-day programme for working professionals, youth leaders, and final-year undergraduates. The centre aims to build capacity in Singapore to address complex problems and develop enduring resilience against future disruptions. SIM president Seah Chin Siong committed S$1 million to fund up to 90% of programme fees for those working in the social sector.

site_title: Sats cuts loss in Q2; gears up to handle vaccines
summary: Sats, a Singaporean ground handler and food supplier, reported a Q2 loss of S$33.2 million, down from S$43.7 million in the preceding quarter. Revenue dropped 53.5% to S$231.1 million, but operating breakeven was achieved through cost-cutting measures. The company is gearing up to handle vaccines and has gained IATA CEIV Pharma certification for several facilities. Despite a challenging outlook due to the pandemic, shares rose 7 cents to S$3.60.

site_title: Sunpower net profit down in Q3, but would have risen without financial effects
summary: Sunpower Group reported a net profit of 36.6 million yuan (S$7.45 million) for Q3, down 66.8% from the year-ago period. Without financial effects, net profit would have risen 33.4% to 105.2 million yuan. Revenue increased 15.9% to 901.1 million yuan, driven by a 48.1 million increase from the manufacturing and services segment and a 75.2 million increase from "green investment" business. The company aims to invest 2.5 billion yuan in anti-pollution projects by 2021.

site_title: Manulife says Hong Kong market share doubled, eyes Asia, asset management for M&A
summary: Manulife Financial reported a 15% core earnings growth in its Hong Kong business, doubling its market share in the third quarter compared to the same period last year. The company is focusing on Asia and asset management for future mergers and acquisitions, with approximately C$32 billion in excess capital available for deployment. CEO Roy Gori sees Asia as a key growth area, citing the company's strong capabilities in the region and wealth management. Manulife's shares fell 2% in morning trading following a sharp rise earlier in the month.

site_title: Thai central bank agrees on cap for commercial banks' 2020 dividends payments
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) has agreed to cap commercial banks' 2020 dividend payments at 50% of this year's net profits and not exceeding last year's payout ratio, amid uncertainty from the coronavirus pandemic. This measure aims to prevent excessive payouts and support financial institutions in the long run, aligning with guidelines from overseas regulators.

site_title: UMS Holdings net profit up 41% in Q3 on back of strong semiconductor sales
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 41% increase in net profit to S$12.9 million in Q3, driven by strong semiconductor sales. Revenue rose 37% to S$45.2 million, with all core business segments growing, led by the core semiconductor business. The company recommended a dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share, citing operational resilience and ability to respond to customer demands despite pandemic disruptions.

site_title: Singapore moves up a notch to rank ninth in world talent ranking
summary: Singapore has moved up to rank ninth in the world's most competitive places for talent, according to a report by Swiss business school IMD. The country improved in investment and development, but its ageing population and high cost of living may pose future challenges. Singapore remains at the top of the ranking in readiness, but its ranking could be affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which may impact countries that rely heavily on foreign talent.

site_title: Heartland businesses see revenue growth as consumer spending shifts from city to suburbs
summary: Heartland businesses in Singapore are expected to see continued revenue growth as consumer spending shifts from city to suburbs, driven by work-from-home arrangements and safe distancing measures. Researchers at the Asia Competitiveness Institute found a 2% increase in spending in suburbs during the circuit breaker period, with areas like Changi Business Park and western Singapore seeing a boost in retail. Online spending also became a norm, with consumers opting for online payments even after stores reopened.

images.alt_text: Businesses in the heartlands are likely to see continued increases in revenue, as consumer spending has shifted from the city to the suburbs.

site_title: 11 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 11 new Covid-19 cases, all of whom were imported, for the second consecutive day. The cases were placed on stay-home notices upon arrival, with some being contacts of previous cases. The total number of cases in Singapore has risen to 58,102, with 57,987 patients fully recovered and 48 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: China deals 'severe blow' to Hong Kong freedoms, EU says
summary: The European Union has criticized China for a "severe blow" to Hong Kong's autonomy, calling for the reversal of new rules disqualifying elected legislators. The EU's 27 governments stated that these decisions further undermine Hong Kong's autonomy and freedom of opinion. The move comes after pro-democracy opposition lawmakers resigned in protest against the dismissal of four colleagues from the city assembly. The EU is urging Beijing and the Hong Kong government to reinstate the Legislative Council members immediately.

site_title: UK considering sanctions over Chinese breach on Hong Kong
summary: Britain is considering sanctions against Chinese officials in Hong Kong after accusing Beijing of breaching the Sino-British Joint Declaration. The declaration guarantees Hong Kong's autonomy, but China has imposed new rules disqualifying elected legislators, breaking the agreement for the third time. Britain's Minister for Asia, Nigel Adams, said the country will consider designations under a Magnitsky-style sanctions regime, aiming to hold China to its international obligations and protect Hong Kong's rights and freedoms.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap eight-day rally as vaccine euphoria begins to fade
summary: South Korean stocks ended an eight-session rally lower on Thursday, as investor sentiment waned due to concerns over a potential coronavirus vaccine's time lag for commercialization and production. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.41% to close at 2,475.62. Foreigners continued to buy shares for a sixth straight session, despite the decline. The Korean won also fell, ending at 1,114.8 per US dollar, as vaccine euphoria began to fade.

site_title: Singapore Institute of Management launches centre for systems leadership
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) has launched a Centre for Systems Leadership to train professionals and organisational leaders in systems thinking. The centre will offer 18-day on-site programs for working professionals and bespoke programs for leadership teams. It also plans to launch its first systems leadership conference and online options starting next year. Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the need for systems thinking to address complex problems and build resilience against future disruptions, citing examples of companies that have successfully applied systems thinking, such as Barnes & Noble.

site_title: Group of 165 Google critics call for swift EU antitrust action: letter
summary: A group of 165 companies and industry bodies, including Yelp and Expedia, has urged the European Union to take swift action against Google for unfairly favoring its own services in search results. The companies claim Google's preferential placement of its own services, such as accommodation and travel booking, artificially keeps users within its own services and prevents them from visiting competing services. This comes as the EU prepares to introduce new Digital Markets Act regulations, which would prevent dominant online platforms from favoring their own services.

site_title: STI snaps three-session rally, falls 0.05%
summary: Singapore shares retreated 0.05% on Thursday, snapping a three-day rally, as initial euphoria from elections and vaccine news subsided. Asia's sentiment was mixed, with Hong Kong and Seoul indexes ending lower, while Tokyo and Kuala Lumpur were in positive territory. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.38 points to 2,711.90, with Keppel DC Reit and Singapore Airlines gaining, while Sembcorp Industries and DBS fell.

site_title: Ninja Van partners Myanmar's NearMe to drive e-payments
summary: Ninja Van, a last-mile logistics firm, has partnered with NearMe, a digital-services platform in Myanmar, to drive e-payments in the frontier market. The partnership allows business and retail partners of Ninja Van Myanmar to accept payments via mobile wallets from customers. NearMe's platform, used by over 50,000 retailers, has seen exponential growth in transaction volumes during the Covid-19 lockdown. The partnership aims to accelerate Myanmar's transition to a cashless economy.

site_title: Sats reports Q2 loss of S$33.2m, with staff cost down 61.3%
summary: SATS reported a Q2 loss of S$33.2m, with a 61.3% drop in staff costs contributing to the decrease. Revenue fell 53.5% to S$231.1m, while loss per share was 3 cents. The company will not pay an interim dividend due to uncertain operating conditions. CEO Alex Hungate noted that flight and passenger volumes remain constrained by pandemic-related travel restrictions, but air cargo demand is more resilient.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on second virus wave fears
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Thursday, snapping an eight-month winning streak, as rising coronavirus cases raised concerns about a quicker economic rebound. The UK economy grew 1.1% in September, slower than expected, and several companies reported mixed earnings. Despite this, some sectors like mining and healthcare stocks rose. The decline in European shares overshadowed upbeat quarterly earnings reports, which had lifted the STOXX 600 index to its best monthly performance in eight months.

site_title: Catalist-listed M Development pursues voluntary liquidation
summary: M Development, a CATALIST-listed company, has announced its intention to pursue a members' voluntary liquidation to go private. Following a notification from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to delist, the company must provide a fair and reasonable exit offer to shareholders. M Development has been a cash company since 2017 and has "no other feasible exit strategy immediately available." The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval, with an indicative timeline subject to change.

site_title: Singapore Airlines proposes convertible bond issue with indicative size of S$850m
summary: Singapore Airlines is proposing to issue up to S$850 million in convertible bonds, convertible into new ordinary shares, with a closing date of December 3. The bonds are expected to be priced on or around Thursday, with HSBC as the sole book runner and lead manager. The issue is expected to fund operating cash flow, debt service, and capital expenditure. Analyst Brendan Sobie notes that the move may be a strategic choice to boost liquidity, given the airline's strong financial health and potential for future moves.

site_title: Britain's Rolls-Royce raises £2b with rights issue
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British engineering company, raised £2 billion from a rights issue to bolster its pandemic-hit finances. The company, which relies on airline customers for its engine sales, secured 94% of the new shares from shareholders. The equity raise unlocks new debt options, including a £2 billion bond and a £1 billion bank loan, as part of a £5 billion liquidity package. The company plans to cut costs, axe 9,000 jobs, and close factories to adjust to lower demand.

site_title: Indonesia pushes for South-east Asia travel bubble in early 2021
summary: Indonesia is pushing for a travel corridor arrangement with South-east Asian countries, aiming to establish a bubble in early 2021. The proposal was initially made in June, with Thailand and Malaysia backing the move, but other countries have not shown support. Indonesia is seeking to revive its economy, which is struggling with a large coronavirus outbreak and technical recession. A declaration on the travel corridor will be issued during the ongoing Asean Summit, with the aim of implementing temporary fast lanes and health protocols to facilitate travel and boost economic activity.

site_title: China says will quicken special funds spending to support economy
summary: China plans to accelerate spending of special funds allocated to local governments to support the economy. By the end of October, local governments had spent 1.198 trillion yuan (S$243.65 billion), accounting for 70.9% of allocated funds. The government aims to increase spending to 2 trillion yuan from special treasury bonds and budget deficits to support economic development and poverty alleviation. Despite a 4.9% GDP growth in the third quarter, China's economy is expected to slow to 2% this year, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Manhattan landlords woo apartment-seekers with record freebies
summary: Manhattan landlords offered record-breaking discounts and freebies to attract renters, resulting in a 33% increase in signed leases in October, the first annual increase since 2019. About 60% of new leases came with concessions, averaging 2.1 months of rent, and median rent with concessions fell 16% to $2,868. Despite a surge in leasing, Manhattan's vacancy rate remains high at 6.1%, and available apartments continue to pile up, with over 16,000 units available. The pandemic's work-from-home policies may keep the leasing environment unchanged for months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.70 points to 1,590.78 on Thursday, driven by a higher closing volume of 16.556 billion lots worth RM5.876 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 779 to 466. The stock market's gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore and a boost from mining and healthcare stocks in Europe.

site_title: Surbana Jurong acquires majority stake in environmental design consultancy Atelier Ten
summary: Surbana Jurong acquired a majority stake in London-based environmental design consultancy Atelier Ten as part of its focus on sustainability. Atelier Ten will continue to operate as an independent brand within the Surbana Jurong group. The partnership aims to expand Surbana Jurong's presence in the US and European markets, while Atelier Ten gains involvement in Asia. The two companies have collaborated on projects such as Jewel Changi Airport, and the acquisition is expected to help Surbana Jurong unlock greater value from its sustainability solutions.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust preferential offering oversubscribed, raises S$144.1m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's preferential offering was oversubscribed, raising S$144.1 million, exceeding the total units available. The offering was part of an equity fund-raising exercise, alongside a private placement that raised S$500 million. The trust's manager reported 1.78 times the total units available were taken up, with 72.4 million new units to be issued at S$1.99 per unit, expected to be listed on the SGX's Mainboard on November 18.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q3 distributable income up 15.8% with contribution from merger
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (C-Reit) reported a 15.8% year-on-year increase in distributable income to S$34.2 million for the third quarter, driven by the merger with OUE Hospitality Trust in 2019. Net property income rose 11.4% to S$55.8 million, while revenue increased 12% to S$70.9 million. Committed occupancy in the office portfolio rose to 94.5%, and average passing rents increased year-on-year. The Reit's semi-annual distribution policy will be announced with its full-year results.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics athletes won't have to isolate for 14 days on arrival
summary: Tokyo Olympics athletes arriving in Japan for the 2021 games will be exempt from the 14-day isolation period. Instead, athletes will undergo coronavirus testing within 72 hours of arrival. Decisions on foreign spectators have yet to be made, with tests before and upon arrival considered necessary due to the "impossibility" of a 14-day quarantine period. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government, national government, and Tokyo 2020 organisers will work together to iron out infection prevention procedures. Details on spectator measures will be announced next year, depending on pandemic developments.

site_title: India announces latest stimulus to boost jobs, credit, farm sector
summary: India's government announced a fresh stimulus of $16.1 billion to boost jobs, credit, and the farm sector amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The latest measures include additional funding for real estate developers and contractors, fertiliser subsidies, and a new employment scheme. The total stimulus package, including central bank measures, is expected to reach 15% of gross domestic product. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said the measures aim to generate jobs and stimulate the economy, despite concerns over the ballooning fiscal deficit.

site_title: Exxon says it remains committed to Singapore refinery expansion
summary: ExxonMobil reaffirmed its commitment to expanding its refining-petrochemical complex in Singapore, despite a global review of projects and cost-cutting measures due to the collapse in oil demand. The US oil company had initially planned to complete the $10 billion expansion in 2023, but now plans to adjust the timing and pace to capture efficiencies. The project aims to increase production of cleaner fuels with lower sulphur content, providing jobs for Singaporeans and improving the company's competitiveness. The expansion will convert fuel oil into higher-value products, increasing capacity by 48,000 barrels per day.

site_title: DHL Express pumps 750m euros into Asia-Pacific amid e-commerce surge
summary: DHL Express is investing €690 million (S$1.1 billion) over two years to expand facilities and air networks in Australia, Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea, amid a 30-40% surge in shipment volumes in the Asia-Pacific during peak season. The investments will include new gateway facilities in Malaysia, Bangladesh, India, and South Korea, as well as expanded infrastructure in Hong Kong and Australia. The company aims to keep global trade running as e-commerce and cross-border trade grow, and is also considering adding new aircraft to its fleet to meet growing demand for express deliveries.

site_title: Uber-rival Bolt to invest over 100m euros in European e-scooter market
summary: Estonia-based ride-hailing service Bolt plans to invest over 100 million euros in the European e-scooter market in 2021, aiming to become the largest e-scooter rental firm in Europe. The company aims to bring 130,000 scooters to over 100 cities, expanding aggressively across the continent. Bolt's CEO, Markus Villig, believes consumers will switch from taxis and public transport to e-scooters amid the coronavirus crisis, but sees no evidence of this yet. The investment will benefit from Bolt's established ride-hailing business, which has over 30 million users in 35 countries.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap five-day rally as vaccine optimism cools
summary: Australian shares closed 0.5% lower, snapping a five-day rally, due to fading optimism about a coronavirus vaccine's development. Financials and energy stocks declined, while tech stocks gained 1.1%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6418.2. The decline was attributed to investors reassessing the vaccine's near-term implications and challenges in manufacturing, delivery, and storage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower on profit-taking
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower on Thursday due to profit-taking from recent gains, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.22% to 26,169.38. The decline was also attributed to concerns over a surge in global virus infections that could impact economic recovery.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has introduced the Tech.Pass scheme to attract top global tech talents, with up to 500 proven founders, leaders, and experts to be supported. DBS is expanding its 24/7, self-service banking services to a third of its branches by 2022. Reforms to Singapore's Vehicular Emissions Scheme will increase rebates for cleaner cars and introduce EV battery leasing. Singtel's revenue growth is uncertain, while Surbana Jurong acquired a majority stake in environmental design consultancy Atelier Ten. DBS Private Bank sees strong demand for family-office services, and DHL Express is investing €750m in Asia-Pacific amid e-commerce growth.

images.alt_text: The EDB bills the scheme as an extension of the Tech@SG programme launched in 2019, to provide fast-growing companies greater assurance of accessing the talent they need.

site_title: Pimco CIO says vaccine boosts outlook for some pandemic-hit junk bonds
summary: Pimco's CIO Dan Ivascyn says a positive Covid-19 vaccine outlook has improved the outlook for high-yield credit, especially for pandemic-hit companies. He notes rising Treasury yields may remain range-bound due to a split US Congress. Ivascyn finds sectors like airlines, hospitality, and gaming attractive, particularly if virus containment progress is made early next year. A vaccine boost lowers stimulus prospects, but inflation remains subdued without new Treasury supply, keeping longer-dated Treasury bonds anchored and the yield curve flat. Interest rates are expected to remain near zero for several years.

site_title: Singapore-HK travel bubble sparks surge in bookings, hopes for broader reopening
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong's travel bubble, allowing tourism without quarantines, has sparked a surge in bookings and searches, with flights and hotels selling out ahead of its November 22 launch. The travel bubble, featuring a daily quota of 200 travellers, has seen a 300% increase in flight searches and a 200% increase in hotel searches. Airfares have risen by 35% and travellers will need to pay for two to three Covid-19 tests depending on their stay. The bubble is seen as a step towards a broader reopening of travel within Asia.

site_title: Gaming boom plays into Tencent's hands with 89% profit rise
summary: Tencent's quarterly profit rose 89% to 38.5 billion yuan (S$7.8 billion) due to strong growth in its gaming and advertising businesses. The company's flagship game, Honour of Kings, reached a record 100 million daily active users, and its revenue increased 29% to 125.4 billion yuan. Tencent's shares rose 4.72% after the announcement, rebounding from a 7% drop the previous day. The company's President, Martin Lau, downplayed concerns over draft anti-monopoly rules in China, stating that the regulations are not new and will not significantly impact its gaming business.

site_title: Standard Chartered Kenya to lay off 200 workers due to digitisation
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Kenya plans to lay off 200 workers, approximately 14% of its workforce, due to the digitization of some services. The layoffs will involve managers and staff members of the banking union, to be completed by the end of 2020. The bank aims to adapt to changing market conditions and improve efficiency through digitalization.

site_title: Metro records S$19.8m net profit for H1, down 5.7%
summary: Metro Holdings recorded a net profit of S$19.8 million for the first half of 2021, down 5.7% from the previous year. Revenue plummeted 71.5% to S$36.7 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The property division's revenue fell 83.4% to S$11.5 million, while the retail division recorded a loss of S$0.8 million. Despite the challenges, the group expects its investment properties to provide stable recurring income for growth. Average occupancy remains high at 92.3% for its five investment properties in Singapore and abroad.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed higher for the eighth consecutive session, gaining 0.68% or 171.28 points at 25,520.88. This comes as bargain-hunting partially offset profit-taking. The broader Topix index was down 0.16%. The gains follow a rally in other Asian markets, including Singapore's STI, which rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn Q3 profit near flat, beats estimates
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, reported near-flat quarterly profit of T$30.8 billion, beating market estimates. The company attributed the profit to firm demand for telecommuting devices, despite a decline in global smartphone shipments. Foxconn forecast weakness in its revenue-driving smartphone business but expects a boost from a new lineup of Apple iPhones. The company's share price rose 0.4% ahead of the earnings release, despite falling 10% this year.

site_title: ComfortDelGro back in black with S$21.7m net profit in Q3, thanks to government relief
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported a net profit of S$21.7 million for the third quarter, down 69% from the previous year, but improving from a net loss in the first half. Revenue declined 16.3% year-over-year to S$816.5 million, with public transport services and taxi segments experiencing significant losses. Government relief, including a S$44.2 million grant, helped the company achieve an operating profit. The group's balance sheet remains strong, and ridership has recovered in Singapore and China, but the UK and Australia face challenges due to the pandemic and Brexit.

site_title: Temasek eyes health, education tech investments after pandemic
summary: Temasek Holdings is in talks to make its first direct investment in health care and education tech startups in South-east Asia. The company's chief investment strategist sees multi-billion-dollar companies emerging in these sectors, citing the surge in digital health and education services during the pandemic. Temasek's bet on the region's digital economy, poised to triple to over US$300 billion by 2025, underscores its focus on health and education tech, with Indonesia emerging as a key market.

site_title: Typhoon shuts Manila as flood cripples cities
summary: The Philippines shut down financial markets, government offices, and closed ports and airports due to Typhoon Vamco (also known as Ulysses), which made landfall on Luzon's main island, causing widespread flooding and at least two deaths. The typhoon has left 40,000 homes submerged and 2.5 million homes without power. The storm has moved away from Luzon and is forecast to exit the country on Friday, with winds as fast as 130km per hour. The government has deployed rescue teams and aid will reach those in need, with the president promising to "not leave anybody behind."

site_title: Telstra to split into three, seeks buyer for mobile towers
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telecom firm, plans to split into three units and divest its mobile towers by December next year. The move aims to capitalize on heightened demand for infrastructure assets, driven by the pandemic. The three new units will be infrastructure assets, mobile tower assets, and radio access network and spectrum assets. Telstra's shares surged over 8% as the company values its towers at around A$4.5 billion. The split is seen as a strategic move to monetize the mobile towers and separate them from its fixed-line business.

site_title: Vietnam confirms Nguyen Thi Hong as first female central bank governor
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly has ratified Nguyen Thi Hong as the country's first female central bank governor, making her the first woman to hold the position in the bank's 7-decade history. Hong, 52, has worked at the State Bank of Vietnam since 1991 and was the sole candidate nominated for the post. Her appointment was backed by 97% of the legislature, amid challenges such as controlling bad debt and navigating the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as vaccine hope offset by virus surge
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, despite a week-long rally, due to concerns over a surge in virus cases threatening economic recovery. Vaccine hopes, fueled by Pfizer's 90% effective vaccine, and US President-elect Joe Biden's election win initially boosted sentiment. However, the split mood and uncertainty over virus cases and tariff uncertainty weighed on markets, with the STI up 0.4% despite the tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Pfizer CEO sold US$5.6m in stock on day of vaccine announcement
summary: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla sold $5.6 million of his US stock on the day the company announced a 90% effective Covid-19 vaccine candidate. The sale was reportedly part of a pre-arranged periodic divestment plan, designed to shield executives from insider trading accusations. Fellow executive Sally Susman also sold $1.8 million in stock. Following the announcement, Pfizer shares rose over 7% as the company's vaccine candidate showed promising results.

site_title: 5G users to make up a fifth of total in China, South Korea by end of H1 next year: Huawei
summary: Huawei expects 5G users to make up 20% of total users in China and South Korea by the end of 2021, with 5G adoption accelerating faster than predicted. China Mobile has already reached 130 million 5G subscribers, surpassing its target of 100 million for the year. This rapid growth is attributed to increasing demand for 5G services, with Huawei's Carrier Business Group President Ryan Ding stating that 5G adoption is happening faster than expected.

site_title: Boeing raises 20-year forecast for China aircraft demand despite pandemic
summary: Boeing has raised its 20-year forecast for China's aircraft demand to 8,600 planes, a 6.3% increase from its previous prediction of 8,090 planes. The increased demand is worth $1.4 trillion, driven by China's resilient growth drivers, including government investments in transportation infrastructure and a flourishing domestic market. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on global deliveries, Boeing sees China as a bright spot in the aviation market. This increase comes as Boeing and Airbus face competition from state-owned planemaker COMAC.

site_title: Burberry recoups sales growth in October despite closed stores
summary: Burberry reported strong sales growth in October, recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic impact, with comparable store sales falling 6% instead of the expected 12%. Revenue for the six months to Sept 26 fell 31% to £878 million, but adjusted operating profit rose to £51 million. The company attributed the growth to strong sales in mainland China, Korea, and the US, and is attracting new and younger consumers. Burberry plans to reduce markdowns, which will be a revenue headwind in the second half of its financial year.

site_title: Hot stock: Jiutian Chemical loses 23.5% on heavy volumes as rally fizzles
summary: Jiutian Chemical's shares plummeted 23.5% on Thursday, reaching a two-week low, amidst heavy trading. The company's recent rally fizzled out after it completed a share placement, raising S$10.3 million. Despite posting a record Q3 net profit of S$10.5 million, the sagging stock price was attributed to high volumes. This is the most heavily traded counter on the Singapore bourse in a single day, with 620 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Gold edges up as virus worries eclipse vaccine optimism
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,869.51 per ounce, driven by concerns over the economic impact of surging Covid-19 cases, outweighing optimism over vaccine news. Analysts say the vaccine may take time to become publicly available, and monetary stimulus is needed in the near-term to support the global economy.
