European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde signaled further support, and gold tends to benefit from widespread stimulus measures due to its hedge against inflation and currency debasement.

site_title: Food Empire Q3 net profit declines 19.5% on lower revenue, forex losses
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Food Empire Holdings reported a 19.5% decline in net profit for its fiscal third quarter, with US$6.3 million in profit, down from US$7.8 million in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 8.5% to US$70.3 million due to lower sales from Covid-19 disruptions in the Vietnam market and foreign exchange losses. The company expects business conditions to remain uncertain amid the resurgence of Covid-19.

site_title: OCBC says Singapore online sales boom doesn't spell demise of physical stores
summary: OCBC analysts believe that online sales in Singapore don't signal the demise of physical stores. Despite online sales increasing to 18.7% of total sales in June, brick-and-mortar stores still perform well, particularly suburban malls. OCBC notes that suburban malls have a natural catchment area, providing footfall and resilience. The bank ranks Frasers Centrepoint Trust and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust as the most resilient retail Reits, with tenants' sales recovering close to pre-Covid-19 levels. While malls will experience pains from the pandemic, OCBC expects them to adapt and continue to attract new tenants.

site_title: Singapore buyers of cleaner cars to get bigger rebates; EV battery leasing in the works
summary: Singapore will increase rebates for cleaner cars under its Vehicular Emissions Scheme (VES) starting January 1, 2021, with rebates for vehicles in Bands A1 and A2 increasing by S$5,000 and S$7,500, respectively. The government also plans to lease EV batteries, with Singapore utilities firm SP Group and Hyundai Motor Group developing a new business model. The enhanced VES and Electric Vehicle Early Adoption Incentive will offer combined cost savings of up to S$57,500 for new fully electric cars and taxis.

site_title: Renewables giant Equis bags US$1.25b from management and Abu Dhabi, Canada funds
summary: Equis Development, a Singapore-based renewable energy and waste infrastructure developer, has raised US$1.25 billion in capital funding from Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board, and its management team. The funds will be used for operational and investment activities, securing assets, and investing in existing portfolio sectors, including renewable energy, biomass, and waste recycling. Equis plans to commit over US$2 billion to renewable energy and waste infrastructure assets in Australia, Japan, and South Korea over the next two years, developing or constructing 40 assets in these markets.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil firm FGV says it will achieve 100% traceability by 2021
summary: Malaysia's largest crude palm oil producer, FGV Holdings, aims to achieve 100% supply-chain traceability by the fourth quarter of 2021. The goal is to ensure the palm oil is legally sourced and produced, and to prevent deforestation and exploitation. FGV has already achieved 81% traceability to plantations and is working to source its fresh fruit bunches from estates that do not contribute to deforestation. The move follows similar efforts by major buyers and companies to adopt sustainable practices and meet consumer demand for responsible palm oil production.

site_title: Australia: Shares trade flat as vaccine winners catch breath
summary: Australia's benchmark share index traded flat on Thursday, following a five-day rally, as losses in energy, financial, and travel-related stocks offset gains from tech firms. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% earlier in the day but later declined. Tech stocks jumped 3% as investors shifted focus to the sector. Energy stocks fell 0.6% despite a strong week, while financial stocks declined 0.9%. Individual stocks like Telstra Corp rose on restructuring plans, and Nine Entertainment hit a two-year high on an upbeat outlook.

site_title: Too early to tell how Singtel revenue might rebound past pre-pandemic base, says CEO
summary: Singtel's CEO Chua Sock Koong expressed caution on the telco's revenue recovery, citing a "still quite tentative" growth trend despite a 36.2% year-on-year decline in underlying net profit for the six months to Sept 30. Revenue dropped 10.2% year-over-year, while 5G services are expected to bring higher revenues. However, connectivity alone is not enough, and new revenue sources from applications and platforms are needed. The company's operating revenue declined year-over-year across all major business segments, but group enterprise saw a 2.5% dip.

site_title: Sabana's scheme meeting set for Dec 4; managers emphasise that 'bigger is better'
summary: Sabana Reit's scheme meeting is set for December 4, where unitholders will vote on a proposed merger with ESR-Reit. The merger is seen as "bigger is better" in the Reit space, offering opportunities for inclusion in key indices, access to capital, and lower costs. Unitholders must pre-register and vote by December 1. The enlarged Reit will have an unsecured debt basis and a larger debt headroom for redevelopment initiatives. Sabana Reit's CEO Donald Han believes the merger will provide a better chance for unitholders to make an informed decision.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the start of business Thursday, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine and following Joe Biden's election win. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.70% or 182.36 points to 26,409.34. This follows a rally in other Asian markets, with the Singapore Stock Exchange reaching a 5-day high. The gains come despite US President Donald Trump's recent threats to extend the stock market rally.

site_title: Huge China-backed trade pact to be signed at South-east Asian summit
summary: Fifteen Asia-Pacific nations, including China, Japan, and South Korea, are set to sign the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), the world's largest trade pact by GDP. The pact, first proposed in 2012, aims to promote economic cooperation and increase trade among the participating countries. The agreement is seen as a significant coup for China in extending its influence in the region. The RCEP is expected to boost economic growth and create new opportunities for businesses, but its impact on global trade and economic policies remains to be seen.

site_title: DBS to offer 24/7, self-service banking in a third of branches by 2022
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, plans to transform at least a third of its branch network to self-service banking with 24/7 access by 2022. The "phygital" concept will feature video teller machines, ATMs, and digital ambassadors. Wealth managers will also be on site to offer financial advice. The new branches will be smaller, averaging 1,000 sq ft, and include space for community engagement. The move aims to increase banking accessibility for less digitally-savvy customers, despite a 15% drop in monthly average branch visits and 22% decline in over-the-counter cash transactions since the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Singapore unveils Tech.Pass scheme to woo top global tech talents
summary: Singapore has launched the Tech.Pass scheme, a new program aimed at attracting top global tech talents. The program will provide up to 500 passes to proven founders, leaders, and experts, allowing them to move between various activities contributing to the country's tech ecosystem. The passes will be valid for two years and can be renewed based on criteria such as income, business spending, and local employment. The initiative aims to create new business opportunities and partner with institutes of higher learning to build the next generation of tech talent, as Singapore competes with other countries for global talent.

site_title: Asian Pay TV posts Q3 DPU of 0.25 S cent
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported a Q3 DPU of 0.25 Singapore cent, down 16.7% from the previous year. The company's net profit fell 12.9% to S$4.5 million due to higher expenses. APTT reaffirmed its distribution guidance of 0.25 cent per unit for the fourth quarter, subject to no material changes in planning assumptions.

site_title: US warns of more China sanctions over Hong Kong moves
summary: The US warned of additional sanctions against China, citing Beijing's "flagrantly violated" Hong Kong's autonomy after the ousting of pro-democracy lawmakers. US National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien stated that the Chinese Communist Party's actions demonstrate a "clear disregard" for international commitments. The US will continue to identify and sanction those responsible for extinguishing Hong Kong's freedom.

site_title: SingPost sets up S$1b debt programme; Halcyon Agri prices US$200m perps
summary: SingPost has established a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with HSBC as the arranger. The programme allows SingPost to issue notes and perpetual securities in Singapore dollars or other currencies. This move is part of the postal service provider's efforts to diversify its funding options.

site_title: ESR and Sabana's IFAs advise voting in favour of proposed merger
summary: Independent financial advisers for ESR-Reit and Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Reit have advised directors to recommend unitholders vote in favor of the proposed merger. Rothschild & Co and Deloitte & Touche Corporate Finance have deemed the merger "normal commercial terms" and not prejudicial to minority unitholders. The advisers considered liquidity, market performance, and valuation multiples before making their recommendations. As a result, the directors will now recommend unitholders vote in favor of the merger, which is expected to be distribution per unit accretive and net asset value dilutive for Sabana Reit's unitholders.

site_title: Gold market authority threatens to blacklist UAE and other centres
summary: The London Bullion Market Association (LBMA) is threatening to blacklist the UAE and other countries with large gold markets unless they meet regulatory standards on issues such as money laundering and gold sourcing. The LBMA has sent a letter to 12 countries, including the UAE, China, and India, outlining standards that must be met by December 11. Failure to comply may result in the LBMA stopping bullion from these countries from entering the mainstream market. The move aims to tackle the illegal or unethical production and trading of gold, particularly in Dubai, where the Financial Action Task Force has criticized controls.

images.alt_text: The world's most influential gold market authority is threatening to stop bullion from countries including the United Arab Emirates (UAE) entering the mainstream market if they fail to meet regulatory standards.

site_title: Tokyo's tiny noodle bars shut down rather than put up prices
summary: Tokyo's tiny noodle bars are facing a crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic and social-distancing measures, forcing owners to consider price increases or shutting down. Many proprietors are struggling to adapt their business model, which relies on serving quick and cheap food to customers eating in close proximity. While some are embracing price increases, others are reluctant to raise prices for their loyal customers, leading to a difficult decision for many owners.

site_title: Japan's machinery orders fall, clouding outlook for capital spending recovery
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 4.4% in September, the first decline in three months, and at a faster-than-expected pace, raising concerns about a quick recovery from the Covid-19 crisis. The decrease in core orders, a key indicator of capital spending, is attributed to corporate Japan's reluctance to invest amid a resurgence in coronavirus infections and darkened global demand outlook. This marks a setback for Japan's economy, which had been expected to show a brisk recovery.

site_title: Expedia Singapore website operator stops making false claims on promotions
summary: BEX Travel Asia, the operator of Expedia Singapore, has stopped making false claims on its "Daily Deals" promotions, following an investigation by Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS). The promotions involved listing daily deals that expired at 11:59pm, but prices remained the same after the deadline. The CCCS found 55 false claims and deemed them unfair practices. BEX has undertaken to comply with the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act and will ensure clear communication of promotion validity. The company will also cease making false claims about limited-time promotions.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% or 5.69 points to 2,718.97 at Thursday's open, tracking overnight gains from Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 47, with 141.1 million securities worth S$122.2 million changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma books provision for unsold Covid-19 test kits; Q3 profit halves
summary: Hyphens Pharma International reported a 53% drop in net profit to S$847,000 for the third quarter, despite a 2.4% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$31.4 million. The decline was primarily due to higher expenses. The pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare group attributed the drop to the provision of unsold Covid-19 test kits.

site_title: Logistics firm InPost is said to attract interest from Blackstone, GIC
summary: Logistics firm InPost is attracting interest from private equity firms including Blackstone Group and Silver Lake, as its owner Advent International pursues a dual-track sale process. European firms EQT and Hellman & Friedman, as well as the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and Singapore sovereign fund GIC, are also evaluating the business. A deal could value InPost in the billions of euros, making it one of Europe's largest private equity-backed transactions. Advent is also considering an initial public offering (IPO) for InPost.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened higher on Thursday, rising 0.60% or 152.85 points to 25,502.45, following a rebound in US high-tech shares. The move came as investors regained optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine, despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies. The broader Topix index slipped 0.07%.

site_title: Gold inches up on muted dollar, mounting virus cases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,878.54 per ounce, driven by a softer dollar and concerns over the logistical challenges of distributing a potential Covid-19 vaccine. The US dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold more attractive to holders of other currencies. The Federal Reserve warned of slowing US economic growth due to surging coronavirus cases, leading to calls for further monetary and fiscal support. Meanwhile, silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, as investors weighed the impact of the vaccine on risk appetite.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SingPost, Halcyon Agri, UOL, Jiutian Chemical, F&N
summary: Singtel reported a net profit of S$466.1 million for the six months ended Sept 30, reversing a net loss of S$127 million a year ago. SingPost established a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Bank of Japan's monetary policy can play bigger role in Covid-19 world: policymaker
summary: Bank of Japan policymaker Seiji Adachi suggests that the central bank's monetary policy can play a more significant role in addressing structural economic changes caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Japan's jobless rate remains low at 3%, but Adachi warns of increasing job losses for temporary workers and potential corporate bankruptcies if the economy takes longer to recover.

site_title: South-east Asia stocks' time to shine has finally arrived
summary: South-east Asian stocks have surged 14% in an eight-day winning streak, outperforming the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. The rally is driven by optimism over travel resuming as governments ease social distancing measures. The MSCI Asean Index has narrowed the gap with its peers, but remains down 14% for the year. The global rotation into value and out of growth sectors, following positive Pfizer vaccine results, is also contributing to the surge.

site_title: Trudeau says Canada won't give in to China pressure to free Huawei's Meng
summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau reaffirmed Canada's stance on Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou's extradition case, stating the country won't give in to China's pressure to release her. Meng was arrested in 2018 on a US warrant and has been fighting extradition since. The case strained Canada-China relations, with Beijing detaining Canadian citizens Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor in retaliation. Trudeau's firm stance maintains pressure on China to resolve the case.

site_title: HKEX's Q3 profit up 52% on trading revenue, listings boost
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) reported a 52% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$3.45 billion, driven by higher trading revenue and listing fees. Trading volumes rose due to large listings, including those by Chinese tech firms, while the bourse suffered a setback in its IPO bid after Ant Group's listing was suspended. HKEX CEO Charles Li expressed confidence in the company's role in global markets, citing robust trading volumes and a strong IPO pipeline.

site_title: Nissan's lawsuit against Carlos Ghosn to get first hearing
summary: Nissan's lawsuit against former chairman Carlos Ghosn is set to receive its first hearing in Yokohama on Friday. The automaker is seeking 10 billion yen (S$127.9 million) in damages from Ghosn, alleging years of misconduct and fraudulent activity. Ghosn's lawyers, Nobuo Gohara and a team, will represent him in the civil case, which was filed in February. Despite Ghosn's dramatic escape to Lebanon, others in his orbit remain embroiled in legal proceedings. The hearing marks a significant step in Nissan's efforts to recover damages from its former chairman.

site_title: Biden names longtime aide Ron Klain as White House chief of staff
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden has named Ron Klain, a longtime Democratic operative, as his chief of staff. Klain served as chief of staff for Biden when he was vice-president and brings a deep, varied experience and ability to work across the political spectrum. Biden praised Klain's skills, stating he is "precisely what I need" to bring the country together. This is Biden's first public White House personnel choice.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Joe Biden on Wednesday announced he has chosen Ron Klain, a seasoned Democratic operative, as his chief of staff, his first public White House personnel choice.

site_title: Japanese PM Suga speaks with Biden, confirms importance of Japan-US ties
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga confirmed the importance of Japan-US ties after speaking with President-elect Joe Biden, agreeing to strengthen the alliance and work together for a "free and open Indo-Pacific." The two leaders also expressed a desire to meet in person as soon as possible. Suga stated that Biden looks forward to strengthening the alliance and working together to achieve a free and open Indo-Pacific.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said on Thursday he spoke with US President-elect Joe Biden by telephone and confirmed the importance of bilateral ties, as well as a "free and open Indo-Pacific" region.

site_title: Rare Russian pink diamond sells for US$27m
summary: A rare 14.83-carat Russian pink diamond, "The Spirit of the Rose", was sold for US$26.6 million at Sotheby's in Geneva, setting a world record for a purple-pink diamond. The diamond, derived from a 27.85-carat stone, took a year to cut and preserve its pink color. This sale marks the fifth of the 10 most expensive diamonds ever sold, all of which are pink and were sold within the past decade, as the world's largest pink diamond mine in Australia recently stopped production due to depletion of supplies.

site_title: US: Nasdaq closes higher with technology stocks back in favour
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday as investors shifted back to technology stocks, boosting the Nasdaq 2% after a two-day rotation away from economically sensitive sectors. Technology-heavy stocks such as Microsoft and Netflix rose over 2% and 3%, respectively, while the Dow Jones fell 0.08%. Investors are cautious amid concerns over a potential surge in Covid-19 cases and renewed restrictions, but are optimistic about the long-term view of the economy post-vaccine and post-pandemic.

site_title: Singtel reverses from loss to post S$466.1m net profit in H1
summary: Singtel reported a net profit of S$466.1 million for the first half of 2020, reversing a net loss of S$127 million a year ago. The company's operating revenue declined 10.2% due to lower equipment sales, roaming, and prepaid mobile revenue, but the information and communications technology segment showed strong growth. Despite the challenges, Singtel's directors approved an interim dividend of 5.1 cents per share and a scrip dividend scheme. The company expects capital expenditure of around S$2.2 billion for 5G networks and dividends from regional associates to be approximately S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Greece to offer 50% tax break for returning professionals and "digital migrants"
summary: Greece plans to offer a 50% tax break to professionals and "digital migrants" moving to the country, aiming to reverse its brain-drain crisis. The incentive, available for 7 years, will be eligible to those not being Greek tax residents within the last 7 years. The goal is to attract professionals and lure back 800,000 Greeks who left during the debt crisis. The move also aims to capitalize on the "Brexit bonus" by attracting UK expats. Legislation will be brought to parliament by the end of the year.

site_title: UK 'sleep-walking' into personal debt crisis, warns charity
summary: The UK is "sleep-walking" into a personal debt crisis, warns charity StepChange, with 1.2 million people in severe problem debt and 5.6 million at risk of joining due to the pandemic. The charity urges the government to extend support, including help paying local taxes and interest-free loans, as millions struggle with mounting debts. Nearly 15 million people have been negatively financially impacted by the pandemic, with 30% of the adult population affected.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend rally on vaccine cheer, ECB comments
summary: Europe's stock market rose for a third consecutive day, driven by optimism around a potential Covid-19 vaccine and encouraging comments from European Central Bank chief Christine Lagarde. The Stoxx 600 index jumped 1% and gained nearly 45% since March, despite a 6.5% decline on the year due to the resurgence in Covid-19 cases. The ECB announced plans to focus on emergency bond purchases and cheap loans for banks in its new stimulus package next month.

site_title: Covid-19 pushes Frasers Property into S$45m H2 loss, full-year gain down 66%
summary: Frasers Property reported a S$45.7 million loss for its second half, with full-year profit down 66% to S$188 million due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 18% to S$1.5 billion in the second half. Despite weaker performance, Frasers' AsiaRetail Fund and Golden Land Property contributed to the group's revenue. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.5 cents, down from 6 cents per share in FY2019.

site_title: Cybersecurity talent gap leaves Singapore firms exposed Continued from Page 1
summary: Singapore is facing a significant cybersecurity talent gap, with 9,430 reported cases of cybercrime in 2019, a 51.7% increase from the previous year. To address the issue, public agencies, private companies, and academia are joining forces to upskill workers and develop curriculums in cybersecurity. The government has also passed amendments to its data protection laws, including stiffer penalties for non-compliance and compulsory reporting of severe breaches. Despite efforts to increase talent supply, a shortage of skilled professionals remains, with a need for expertise in areas like encryption, cloud security, and IoT security.

site_title: Brazil, UK discuss potential post-Brexit trade pact
summary: Brazil and the UK held a videoconference to discuss strengthening trade and investment links, including a possible post-Brexit bilateral trade deal. Trade and internal affairs secretary Roberto Fendt stated that Brazil must explore negotiating a trade agreement. Goods trade between the two countries totaled US$5.3 billion last year, with Brazil posting a US$639 million surplus. The UK reiterated its support for Brazil's accession to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

site_title: Nissan's prospects brighten as China rebounds, but struggle continues for weakened car maker
summary: Nissan is expected to trim its forecast for a full-year loss after a recovery in China, a rare bright spot for the Japanese automaker. The company's second-quarter results will likely highlight its struggles in North America, where an ageing vehicle line-up hampers demand. Analysts estimate an average operating loss of 335 billion yen for the full year, 28% less than Nissan's previous forecast. Nissan plans to launch new cars, including electric models, and cut production capacity and operating expenses to address its competitive shortcomings.

site_title: UK house price growth hits 21-year high, weaker 2021 likely: RICS
summary: The UK housing market experienced its highest house price growth in 21 years, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reporting a +68 reading in October, up from +62 in September. The surge in activity is attributed to pent-up demand from the coronavirus lockdown and temporary tax cuts. However, economists predict a quieter market in 2021, citing concerns over the employment picture and the withdrawal of government incentives. The RICS gauge of housing sales expectations for the next 12 months remained negative, reflecting the challenges ahead.

site_title: Malaysia economy likely to shrink at slower pace in Q3: poll
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to shrink at a slower pace in the third quarter, contracting 3.2% from the previous year, according to a Reuters poll of 15 economists. The economy rebounded after easing COVID-19 restrictions, but may slow again in the fourth quarter due to re-imposed curbs. Factory output rose for a third consecutive month, and exports grew at their fastest pace in nearly two years. The government expects the economy to fall 4.5% in 2020, but economists remain cautious due to tightened social-distancing measures.

site_title: Boeing sees more cancelled orders as MAX nears return
summary: Boeing reported 12 more cancelled orders for the 737 MAX, bringing the total to 24, as the aircraft nears its return to service after a two-year grounding. The plane's return is expected to be completed in the coming days, pending FAA approval. American Airlines plans to resume 737 MAX flights on Miami-New York routes in late December, while Southwest will not schedule passenger flights until the second quarter of 2021. Boeing delivered only 13 aircraft last month, amid a challenging aviation market due to the pandemic.

site_title: Workspace swings to loss as customers downsize due to virus
summary: Workspace Group posted a pretax loss of £110.4 million for the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis, with customers downsizing and vacating offices. The company attributed the decline to rising costs and defaults on rent payments. Despite this, customer enquiries for workspaces improved in September, and 95% of rents were collected as of November 2. The company has pushed back its decision on a full-year dividend and expects further pressure from virus-related occupancy and pricing curbs.

site_title: IMF eyes new relationship with biggest shareholder after Biden win
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is re-evaluating its relationship with the US, its largest shareholder, following the election of Joe Biden as US president. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva has sent "personal" letters to Biden and Kamala Harris, aiming to reset the relationship and incorporate green initiatives into the IMF's global economic recovery plan. Biden's commitment to multilateral institutions and climate change may help the IMF advance its targets, while the Trump administration's opposition to new IMF resources is expected to be reconsidered under Biden's leadership.

site_title: Sony PS5 sold out online as pandemic chills real-world retailing
summary: Sony's PlayStation 5 (PS5) console sold out online on its launch day in core markets, with first-day real-world sales limited due to the Covid-19 pandemic. To maintain social distancing, Sony made online sales only, calling for consumers to "be safe, stay home, and place your order online." The console, which retails for $500 or $400 without a disk-drive, was sold out on major retailing sites in Japan, with some conducting lotteries to distribute limited stock.

site_title: STI ekes out 0.3% gain despite easing vaccine optimism
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.31% to 2,713.28, driven by a 5% gain in Dairy Farm International, despite easing vaccine optimism and rising Covid-19 infections in some regions. Investors have shifted focus to vaccine distribution challenges. Analysts expect markets to remain volatile.

site_title: Toshiba will quit coal only after building more plants
summary: Toshiba will stop taking orders for new coal-fired power plants, following Japan's pledge to become greenhouse gas neutral by 2050. The company will complete existing orders, but shift focus to renewable energy investments, aiming to increase annual sales from its renewable energy business to 650 billion yen by 2031. Toshiba plans to invest 160 billion yen in renewable energy through 2023 and halve carbon dioxide emissions by 2030. The move highlights the company's diversification and its ability to adapt to changing market demands.

site_title: Mutant virus in mink raises doubts about the future of fur
summary: A mutation of the coronavirus found in mink has raised concerns about the future of the fur industry. Denmark has ordered the extermination of its entire mink population due to the risk of the virus spreading to humans. The country's prime minister has acknowledged that the industry may not recover. The luxury industry, including Versace, Gucci, and Prada, has joined the anti-fur movement. Experts warn that the virus can spread rapidly among mink, making it difficult to control. The industry's future is uncertain, with some nations considering drastic measures to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy lawmakers resign after ouster of their colleagues
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy lawmakers, who opposed Beijing's national security law and expansion of its influence, have resigned en masse after four colleagues were ousted from office. The move comes as Beijing passed a resolution giving local authorities broad powers to quash dissent. The lawmakers' resignation leaves the city's political landscape reshaped, with Beijing's influence over Hong Kong now more pronounced. The move signals the end of opposition in the city's last major forum for dissent, with Beijing welcoming the resignations as a means to carry out its policies without opposition.

site_title: Asean leaders to sign China-backed RCEP amid US election uncertainty
summary: Asean leaders are set to sign the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) free trade deal, backed by China, amid uncertainty over the US presidential election result. The deal, involving 15 countries accounting for a third of the world's population, is expected to lower tariffs and become the world's biggest trade agreement. The signing is seen as a significant boost to regional trade and will cement China's position as a major economic partner in the region.

site_title: Rainmaking launches network of executives to help maritime startups
summary: Rainmaking has launched Ocean Ventures Alliance, a maritime innovation advisory network in South-east Asia. The network, comprising over 30 industry leaders, aims to accelerate technology adoption in shipping, supply chains, and decarbonisation. Vetted startups will receive industry insights and strategic support from network members, including executives from Maersk Drilling Singapore and Saudi Aramco's Bahri. The network will also leverage Rainmaking's Trade and Transport Impact Programme partners, including Cargill and Shell, to support eligible startups. This initiative is timely, given the critical role innovation has played in global supply chains during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: PropNex net profit rises 10.6% in third quarter
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a 10.6% increase in net profit to S$6.8 million in its third quarter, driven by cost savings despite a 3.3% drop in revenue to S$118.5 million. The decline in revenue was mainly due to a decrease in commission income from agency services.

site_title: Singapore's travel easing is a risk game
summary: Singapore's gradual border reopening to other countries is not without risk, but balancing public health concerns with economic needs is crucial. Analysts suggest that countries like Taiwan and Thailand could be next on the list for unrestricted travel. The Republic aims to re-establish links with trading partners, with the first air travel bubble with Hong Kong set for November. Despite the risks, industry observers expect benefits from increased flights, particularly with nearby countries like Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Bahrain's crown prince appointed new prime minister
summary: Bahrain's Crown Prince, Sheikh Salman bin Hamad al-Khalifa, was appointed as the new Prime Minister after the death of his uncle, Prince Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, at the age of 84. Prince Khalifa was a controversial figure, accused of opposing reforms and cracking down on activists. His nephew, who is from a new generation of Western-educated Gulf leaders, has tried to build bridges with opponents. A week of official mourning will be observed in the country, and government ministries will be closed for three days.

images.alt_text: Bahrain's crown prince, Sheikh Salman bin Hamad al-Khalifa, was appointed prime minister on Wednesday after the death of his uncle, who had held the post since independence in 1971.

site_title: Republicans add another seat in US Senate with Alaska win
summary: The Republican Party won another seat in the US Senate with a victory in Alaska, putting them one vote away from a majority in the upper house of Congress. Incumbent Dan Sullivan was easily reelected with over 57% of the vote, confirming the strong performance of the Republican Party in the congressional elections. With 50 seats, the Republicans now hold a slight majority, while the Democrats have 48 seats, leaving two seats to be filled in a January 5 runoff in Georgia.

site_title: Airbnb said to delay IPO filing to distance it from US election
summary: Airbnb has delayed its initial public offering (IPO) filing until next week, citing a desire to avoid overshadowing the US election fallout. The company, which had planned to file on Thursday, now aims to make its public filing as soon as Monday. The delay is not related to market responses or regulatory hurdles. Airbnb is set to raise up to $3 billion in its Nasdaq debut, one of the largest IPOs on a New York exchange this year, following a record-breaking $140 billion in fundraising by US companies this year.

site_title: F&N's full-year earnings dip 2.1%, hit by lower soda sales
summary: F&N, a Singaporean beverage and publishing company, reported a 2.1% dip in net profit to S$149.2 million in its full-year earnings, hit by lower soda sales and revenue from its publishing business. Revenue fell 3.6% to S$1.83 billion, with a 6.8% decline in its beverage segment. The company attributed the decline to COVID-19 containment measures and closures of non-essential book retail outlets. Despite cost management initiatives, F&N's earnings per share fell to 10.4 Singapore cents, and the company proposed a reduced final dividend of 5 cents per share.

site_title: Brent touches US$45/bbl on vaccine hopes and US crude drawdown
summary: Global oil benchmark Brent rose to a two-month high of $45.30 a barrel on hopes of a Covid-19 vaccine boosting demand, but concerns about rising cases pulled it back. The price settled up 19 cents at $43.80, up 11% this week after Pfizer's vaccine trial data showed a 90% effectiveness. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude also rose, settling up 9 cents at $41.45. However, concerns about record-breaking cases weighed on the market, with analysts warning that the vaccine's impact may be delayed due to restrictions in Europe and the US.

site_title: Germany to buy 38 new Eurofighter jets
summary: Germany has signed a contract with Airbus to purchase 38 new Eurofighter jets, valued at approximately 5.5 billion euros. The planes, set to be delivered between 2025 and 2030, will replace Germany's aging fleet of combat aircraft. This decision is part of a broader plan to split the replacement between Eurofighters and American F-18 jets, aimed at supporting the European defense industry and meeting NATO defense spending commitments.

site_title: Hyflux receives term sheet from US fund manager
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment firm, has received a term sheet from US fund manager Strategic Growth Investments (SGI) for a negotiated transaction regarding the company's re-organisation and restructuring. The term sheet was announced last month after SGI expressed interest to invest at least S$204.78 million. Hyflux is considering the term sheet and will make further announcements as material developments occur.

site_title: Listed healthcare groups stand to gain from rising Covid-19 tests
summary: Singapore listed healthcare companies are expected to benefit from the increasing demand for Covid-19 tests as the country gradually resumes economic and community activities. The government has removed approval requirements for PCR tests from Dec 1, and industry players anticipate a growth in testing services. Analysts predict that healthcare providers will offer testing services, potentially becoming an "essential" service, and companies not offering testing services will be disadvantaged.

site_title: Newly discovered primate in Myanmar already facing extinction: report
summary: Scientists have identified a new species of primate, the Popa langur, in central Myanmar, with a mask-like face and grey hair. The species, which has been around for at least a million years, is now critically endangered due to hunting and habitat loss, with only 200-250 individuals remaining in the wild. The discovery was made through genetic analysis of museum specimens and field surveys, and experts are calling for urgent protection measures to save the langurs from extinction.

site_title: HK travel bubble to help Singapore aviation take off when time's right
summary: Singapore has launched its air travel bubble with Hong Kong, allowing for up to 200 travelers per flight, with designated flights increasing to two daily from Dec 7. The bubble, set to launch on Nov 22, is seen as a step forward for Singapore's aviation hub status, but industry practitioners note it may not significantly impact the tourism sector. The arrangement requires travelers to undergo PCR tests and follow specific protocols, with a two-week suspension if cases exceed a certain threshold. The move aims to prepare Singapore for potential travel resumption.

site_title: DBS digital exchange plans stir excitement among crypto players
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, is planning a digital exchange that could list top cryptocurrencies and offer institutional-grade custody solutions. The move is seen as a significant step towards mainstreaming blockchain technology and cryptocurrency. Industry players expect the platform to bring credibility and drive demand, while also injecting competition into the market. However, some are skeptical about a traditional bank's ability to operate in this space, citing regulatory hurdles and slower adaptability. The move is expected to prompt other financial institutions to follow, presenting opportunities for collaboration and innovation.

site_title: United Air returns to JFK after five-year absence
summary: United Airlines is set to return to New York's John F Kennedy Airport (JFK) on February 1, 2021, after a five-year absence. The airline will offer daily flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco, with a reconfigured Boeing 767-300ER featuring expanded premium seating. This move is seen as an attempt to tap into pent-up demand for transcontinental travel, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. United expects the Thanksgiving holiday week to be its busiest since March, with over 1,400 additional domestic flights added.

site_title: Bridgewater's Ray Dalio voices support for Ant IPO suspension
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, supports China's suspension of Ant Group's record US$37 billion listing, citing the need to curb risks from financial innovation. Dalio, a "chronic bull on China", believes not investing in the rising Asian power is "very risky" due to the US dollar's fundamentals undermining its value. He notes China is evolving into a reserve currency empire and sees the suspension as a necessary measure to regulate Ant's fintech business, which could threaten the banking system.

site_title: US dollar steadies as vaccine optimism wanes
summary: The US dollar steadied against other currencies as optimism about a potential Covid-19 vaccine faded, offset by concerns over vaccine distribution and rising US infections. The New Zealand dollar reached its strongest level in 1.5 years, while the euro and Japanese yen traded flat. Sterling strengthened against the US dollar and euro, while the yuan remained stable. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand kept interest rates on hold and introduced a new policy tool to encourage more loans, reducing concerns of negative interest rates.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's board is considering a requisition notice from Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital, seeking legal advice, after the fund managers proposed five resolutions for an extraordinary general meeting. Meanwhile, Jiutian Chemical Group reported a record Q3 attributable net profit of RMB51.9 million, driven by higher average selling prices and a recovering Chinese economy. Best World International also posted a 13.7% increase in Q3 net profit to S$28.2 million, largely due to lower import duties in China.

site_title: Ascendas Reit slumps on S$1.2b equity fundraising
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (Ascendas Reit) slumped 5% on Wednesday after announcing a S$1.2 billion equity fundraising to finance potential acquisitions in the US, Europe, and Australia. The counter dipped to an intra-day low of S$2.97 before closing at S$3.03. The trust plans to acquire data centers and office buildings overseas, with estimated total purchase price of S$2 billion. Analysts see benefits from the trust's diversified portfolio and strong inorganic growth visibility, maintaining "buy" calls and target prices.

site_title: URA's removal of some price information puts data transparency in focus
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) removed certain pricing data linked to home buying by foreigners from its Real Estate Information System (Realis) platform, highlighting the importance of data transparency in the property market. The removed data allowed for analysis of buying preferences by nationality, which was useful for developers and real estate agencies. Analysts see the removal as a loss, as it provided valuable insights into foreign buyers' purchasing patterns. The URA cited low usage rates as the reason for the removal, but experts argue that data should be available to promote informed decision-making and market research.

site_title: Alibaba boasts 372.3b yuan sales by morning of Singles' Day amid pandemic
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day sales exceeded 372.3 billion yuan by morning on November 11, surpassing Amazon's two-day global Prime Day by 16 times. The event, which started early this year, has brought in 16 million discounted goods and seen 13 brands record over 1 billion yuan in sales. The event is considered indicative of China's post-virus economic recovery, with lockdown-weary consumers splashing out on discounted goods.

site_title: Honda will be first to mass produce level 3 autonomous cars
summary: Honda Motor Co. announced it will be the world's first automaker to mass produce level 3 autonomous cars, allowing drivers to let their vehicles navigate congested expressway traffic. Honda's "Traffic Jam Pilot" technology has received Japan's government safety certification, enabling drivers to take their eyes off the road. The company plans to launch sales of a Honda Legend equipped with the technology before the end of March 2021. This move marks a significant step in the development of self-driving cars, which are expected to reduce traffic accidents and improve logistics.

site_title: Biden needs to re-enter CPTPP, build confidence with re-pivot to Asia
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden needs to re-enter the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) to re-engage with Asia in trade and geostrategy. The US has been absent from the agreement since 2017, and its re-entry is uncertain due to Republican protectionism and Democratic trade friendliness. Biden's administration should consider rejoining the CPTPP or negotiating a narrower interim deal to rebuild trust and momentum. The CPTPP countries, including Japan, Australia, and Vietnam, would welcome a US re-entry, but would not support major revisions to the pact.

site_title: Global economy still in a precarious position
summary: The global economy remains precarious due to severe lockdowns in the UK and European Union, causing businesses to struggle and unemployment to soar. Despite Pfizer's vaccine bringing a lift to confidence, logistical distribution challenges and ongoing pandemic cases in the US threaten a swift recovery. Economists predict a slow return to normal, with Goldman Sachs forecasting 6% global growth in 2021 and 6.1% for the UK. Policymakers must remain cautious, as the global economy remains in a precarious position.

images.alt_text: The Pfizer vaccine has given rise to optimism that a return to normal will take place much sooner than expected, resulting in a strong rebound in global stock markets.

site_title: ARA buys Seoul office tower; DBS, UOB grant S$385.8m green loan for 5One Central
summary: ARA Asset Management has purchased Parc1 Tower II in Seoul, South Korea, for approximately S$1.21 billion, the largest single asset transaction in Korea this year. The 53-storey office building, located in the Yeouido business district, features eco-friendly systems and is expected to generate strong leasing demand due to its prime location. Separately, ARA and British property group Chelsfield secured a S$385.8 million green loan to finance the acquisition and asset enhancement of 5One Central in Singapore.

site_title: It could be a K-shaped recovery in the labour markets too
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic may lead to a "K-shaped" economic recovery, where the wealthy and educated recover quickly, while the less fortunate struggle. A survey of 2,500 Americans found that 42% of full-time workers transitioned to remote work, while 33% were not working due to the recession. In contrast, those with low income or lower education levels often have limited job options, with only 1% working from home. This disparity highlights deep economic and social concerns, with many workers in low-paying services jobs facing permanent job loss and health risks.

site_title: Be a trendy teetotaller with alcohol-free beverages
summary: The trend of being a teetotaller is gaining popularity with the rise of alcohol-free "booze" options. Zero-alcohol beer, wine, and spirits are becoming increasingly available, with brands like Seedlip and Lyre's leading the market. Meanwhile, the Singapore International Film Festival is underway, and men are turning to jewelry for a stylish upgrade. A new Israeli street food joint, Miznon, has also opened, serving authentic Tel Aviv flavors. These developments showcase the shift towards a more inclusive and varied lifestyle, with options for those who choose not to drink.

site_title: Beijing ditches China's Internet playbook, but new giants will return
summary: China's antitrust watchdog has introduced draft rules aimed at rooting out monopolistic practices among Internet companies, including Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu. The new rules could curb the use of data to target specific customers, forcing companies like Alibaba to raise prices and churn a profit. Established players may struggle to adapt, but new entrants could emerge to challenge their dominance, potentially invigorating the market. Beijing's goal may be to clear the decks for fresh companies to enter, with a focus on data flow and control over information and money flows.

site_title: DBS Private Bank sees strong demand for family-office services
summary: DBS Private Bank has seen a strong response to its family-office services, with assets under management growing 40% since its establishment last year. The bank expects a compound annual growth of 20% in family-office assets over the next three to five years. Singapore's handling of the pandemic and its business-friendly regime have made it an attractive destination for wealthy families, with tax incentives and a new Variable Capital Companies framework also attracting interest. The bank expects to maintain this growth trajectory, driven by increasing demand for wealth structuring, tax planning, and philanthropic outreach.

site_title: Can Trump litigate his way to victory?
summary: US President Donald Trump and his team are launching legal efforts to contest the presidential election results, focusing on battleground states of Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin. The claims, led by former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani, include allegations of voting irregularities, such as unobserved mail-in ballot counting and votes cast by the deceased or illegal immigrants. However, the Trump team has yet to provide evidence of widespread fraud. The US Supreme Court has been mentioned as a potential venue, but it's unclear if they will rule in favor of Trump. The states must certify election results by December 8, and the outcome could impact the peaceful transfer of power.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental prices and volume up again in Oct: SRX
summary: Rentals for HDB flats and condominium units rose in October, with HDB rental volumes increasing 13.9% month-on-month to 1,734 units, while condominium rentals climbed 6.3% to 4,409 units. The increase may be partly attributed to new restrictions on developers re-issuing options to purchase (OTPs), which led to some buyers selling their homes to avoid paying additional buyer's stamp duty. HDB rents rose 0.7% and condominium rents 0.3% from September, with year-on-year growth of 0.8% and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: DBS Private Bank sees strong growth in family-office services
summary: DBS Private Bank has seen strong growth in family-office services since its establishment last year, with assets under management growing by 40% and the number of family offices more than doubling. The bank expects a compound annual growth rate of 20% in family-office assets over the next three to five years. Singapore's response to the pandemic has bolstered its reputation as a wealth-management hub, with families drawn to the country's transparency, rule of law, and business-friendly regime. DBS Private Bank has helped establish several family offices with average assets of around US$150 million, and plans to host a webinar to launch a study on the family office boom.

site_title: Cybersecurity talent gap leaves Singapore firms exposed
summary: Singapore's digitalization is exposing businesses to increasing cyber and data privacy threats due to a talent gap in cybersecurity and data protection. The country has seen a shortage of professionals with the necessary skills, with an estimated 2.6 million cybersecurity workforce gap in the Asia-Pacific region. This shortage is exacerbated by the niche nature of cybersecurity roles and the lack of emphasis on cybersecurity education in schools. To address the issue, public agencies, private companies, and academia are partnering to upskill workers and develop curriculums in cybersecurity, with the aim of reaching 20,000 individuals over the next three years.

site_title: Thailand's 'startup godfather' sees crisis as opportunity
summary: Thailand's "startup godfather" Ruangroj Poonpol, chairman of Kasikorn Bank's digital arm Kasikorn Business Technology Group (KBTG), views the COVID-19 pandemic as an opportunity to accelerate digital transformation in the country's technology sector. KBTG has launched various innovations, including online food ordering and digitalization of restaurants, and expects to launch 52 more by 2022. Ruangroj believes that the crisis has disrupted travel technology but accelerated e-commerce, logistics, and education technology, and that success stories are needed to inspire others and attract investors.

site_title: CapitaLand has a global philanthropic footprint in battle against Covid-19
summary: CapitaLand, a global real estate company, has pledged over $6 million globally to support communities affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's philanthropic arm, CapitaLand Hope Foundation, has contributed over $2 million in Singapore to support more than 55,000 people. CapitaLand has provided support in areas such as healthcare, food security, and digital inclusion, with initiatives including meal delivery, mask production, and funding for healthcare supplies. The company's efforts have extended globally, including China, India, Japan, Malaysia, and Vietnam, with donations totaling $2 million in China, $232,000 in India, and $1 million in Vietnam.

site_title: The logistical challenges of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The US is set to launch a massive Covid-19 vaccine distribution operation, aiming to administer up to 600 million doses in a few months. Pfizer's vaccine, which requires -94°F storage, will be distributed from a Michigan plant via thermal shipping containers filled with dry ice and flown to destinations in the US and globally. Distribution will be carried out by FedEx, UPS, and DHL, with an average of 20 daily cargo flights worldwide. The vaccine will initially be administered in hospitals or large distribution centers, with the goal of vaccinating vulnerable populations by the end of December and all Americans by April.

site_title: Democrats win House of Representatives but with slimmer majority
summary: The Democratic Party secured control of the US House of Representatives with a slimmer majority, winning at least 218 seats. This will be the second time since 1995 that they control the chamber for four consecutive years. Despite securing the House, Democrats fell short of taking a Senate majority, with Republicans holding 49 seats to 48. The outcome sets up a crucial pair of US Senate races in Georgia in January that will determine which party controls the legislative body.

site_title: China to step up crackdown on fintech dominance, risk controls
summary: China's top banking watchdog has doubled down on a crackdown on fintech firms, promising to eliminate monopolistic practices and strengthen risk controls. Vice-Chairman Liang Tao said fintech firms should be subject to the same supervision and risk management requirements as banks, with calls for better education for borrowers and bans on inducing customers to borrow beyond their needs. The move comes after a spate of new rules and a failed IPO for Ant Group Co, with regulators targeting internet behemoths such as Tencent Holdings Ltd and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO open to deals as bank mergers accelerate
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein signaled openness to potential acquisition opportunities as negative interest rates and over-banking in Europe drive lenders to deals. He joined other banking heads predicting an acceleration in domestic deals ahead of cross-border transactions. European banks are trying to bulk up in their home markets before cross-border consolidation takes hold, driven by revenue pressure and a surplus of banks in parts of Europe.

site_title: Global rich rushing to buy UK country estates
summary: Wealthy individuals are rushing to buy UK country estates, with 19 selling or under offer for over £15 million in 2020, according to Savills. The surge in demand is attributed to Covid-19-related lockdowns, which have led to a shift in buyer requirements, with many reassessing urban lifestyles and looking for second homes. Country houses are becoming primary residences, with buyers willing to endure longer commutes, and prices are rising despite stagnant values.

site_title: Government reliefs help SBS stay in the black for Q3
summary: SBS Transit reported a 3.3% dip in net profit to S$19.36 million for its third quarter, mainly due to lower service fees, rail ridership, and advertising revenue. Without government reliefs, it would have recorded an operating loss of S$4.04 million. Revenue fell 17% to S$301.99 million, while operating costs decreased by S$56.1 million, mainly from lower staff costs and expenses. The company has S$250 million in available cash to support its business and expects to benefit from government reliefs, including the Jobs Support Scheme, in 2021.

site_title: American Airlines to restart flights to China, bringing US weekly total to 10
summary: American Airlines is set to restart flights to China, increasing the US weekly total to 10 from eight. The US and China agreed in June to allow four weekly flights, raised to eight in August, and the US is now seeking to increase the number further. US carriers currently operate four weekly flights each to China, with United and Delta leading the way. The US is not satisfied with China's current adherence to the agreement, citing that China is not respecting the provision for more than 100 weekly flights.

site_title: Will Japan's carbon clean-up plan work?
summary: Japan's new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga aims to cut greenhouse gases to zero by 2050, prompting financiers Mitsubishi UFJ, Mizuho Financial, and SMBC to reassess their investments. The Government Pension Investment Fund has reduced its carbon intensity by 15% in the last financial year, while activists are pushing for climate action. Mizuho and MUFG have vowed to stop lending to coal projects by 2050 and 2040, respectively. Policymakers' plans may prompt change, including the use of a carbon price or renewable energy, and could lead to a shift towards more climate-conscious decision-making in banks' boardrooms.

site_title: Myanmar's 2020 vote endorses NLD but does not resolve issues
summary: Myanmar's 2020 election results favor the National League of Democracy (NLD), led by Aung San Suu Kyi, with a landslide victory. Despite the NLD's win, key issues remain, including the country's divided system, ethnic minority conflicts, and economic growth. The NLD's ability to govern and address these challenges will be crucial for democracy and economic development. The election's legitimacy has been questioned due to irregularities and voting cancellations, particularly in Rakhine state, and the military's criticism of the process. The new government must navigate these complexities to attract international investment and address crises such as the pandemic and ethnic tensions.

site_title: Pfizer agrees to supply EU with up to 300m doses of coronavirus vaccine
summary: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech have agreed to supply up to 300 million doses of their experimental coronavirus vaccine to the European Union, with deliveries expected to start by the end of this year. The companies reported a 90% effectiveness rate in initial trial results, following a European Commission announcement that it would soon sign the contract. This deal follows a separate US$1.95 billion contract with the US government to deliver 100 million vaccine doses.

site_title: Hong Kong opposition quits en masse to protest new China powers
summary: Hong Kong's opposition bloc resigned en masse after China disqualifying four lawmakers deemed insufficiently loyal under new rules. 15 members of the pro-democracy camp quit, citing Beijing's actions as a clear descent into dictatorship. The disqualification measure requires lawmakers to demonstrate loyalty to the central government, curbing debate in the democratic institution. The move has been met with concerns of a "rubber-stamp" legislature, but Chief Executive Carrie Lam dismissed these concerns, welcoming diverse opinions.

site_title: PSA Marine bags sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: PSA Marine, a Singapore-based harbour and terminal towage operator, has secured a 3-year, €30 million (S$47.8 million) sustainability-linked loan from DBS. The loan features an interest rate adjustment tied to the deployment of PSA Marine's crew transfer vessels to support offshore wind energy activities. This is the first sustainability-linked loan in Singapore's maritime industry, with DBS aiming to finance S$20 billion in renewable energy projects by 2024. The deal supports PSA Marine's growth in the renewable energy sector since 2015.

site_title: Rates gaming on mortgage relief in Singapore set to unwind
summary: Singapore's mortgage relief measures, which have deferred 15% of outstanding mortgages, are masking rates arbitrage by business owners taking advantage of low interest rates to roll debt backed by their homes and reduce higher-interest debt. Regulators introduced income impact as a qualifying term for mortgage moratoriums to curb this practice. While borrowers who need debt relief are being supported, regulators are tightening terms, including introducing reduced instalment payments pegged at 60% of monthly instalments for up to nine months, to encourage borrowers to resume full loan repayments.

images.alt_text: On the surface of it, having S$29 billion or about 15 per cent of outstanding mortgages in Singapore at end-August under deferred payments, should ring some alarm bells.

site_title: India unveils 1.46t rupee package to lure global manufacturers
summary: India has unveiled a 1.46 trillion rupee ($26.5 billion) incentive package to attract global manufacturers, offering production-linked incentives to 10 sectors over a five-year period. The plan aims to make India a global manufacturing hub, with textile units, food processing plants, and pharmaceutical product makers eligible for incentives. The move is part of the "Make in India" program, aiming to increase manufacturing's share in the economy to 25% from 16%. The plan is seen as a response to China's dominance and aims to lure companies away from the Asian nation.

site_title: Government reliefs lend SBS' bottom line a boost in Q3
summary: SBS Transit reported a 3.3% dip in post-tax profit to S$19.36 million for Q3, mainly due to lower service fees, rail ridership, and advertising revenue. Without government reliefs, the company would have recorded an operating loss. Revenue fell 17% to S$301.99 million, while operating costs decreased by S$56.1 million due to lower staff costs and expenses. The company has more than S$250 million in available cash and expects to benefit from government reliefs, including the Jobs Support Scheme, until 2021.

site_title: Suntec Tower Two's 42nd floor up for sale with S$33m guide price
summary: A 42nd-floor office floor in Suntec Tower Two, spanning 9,989 square feet, is up for sale with a guide price of S$33 million. The four contiguous strata office units, fully leased to multinational corporations, offer strong tenant covenants and immediate rental income. The floor boasts panoramic views of the Marina Bay Financial District and is part of the Suntec City integrated development. The offering is open to both foreigners and companies, with no additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty imposed.

site_title: Taking a sustainable digitalisation route
summary: Singapore takes steps towards sustainable digitalization, balancing economic growth with environmental responsibility. The country has implemented a moratorium on new data center construction until 2021 to reduce energy consumption and emissions. Major players like Singtel, Google, and Facebook are transitioning to renewable energy sources to power their data centers. The government is also promoting energy-efficient solutions, such as lower-carbon power and more efficient cooling systems, to reduce data center energy consumption. Additionally, businesses can adopt flexible consumption approaches, such as "as a service" models, to reduce unnecessary cooling and power costs.

site_title: Higher product prices drive Jiutian's Q3 results to another quarterly record
summary: JIUTIAN Chemical Group reported a record Q3 attributable net profit of RMB51.9 million (S$10.5 million) for the three months ended Sept 30, driven by higher average selling prices of dimethylformamide and methylamine. The company's performance was also aided by the closure of a competitor and strong demand from downstream customers. Despite a shorter operating quarter due to maintenance, Jiutian plans to focus on operating efficiently and increasing utilisation rates to take advantage of favourable operating margins.

site_title: UOL says retail portfolio faces headwinds, sees uptick in hospitality
summary: UOL Group reported a stable retail portfolio despite headwinds, with committed occupancy at 93.5% and average daily footfall recovering to 54% of pre-Covid levels in Q3. Office portfolio occupancy remains resilient, but leasing demand is expected to stay soft. Hospitality properties have seen occupancy averaging 68% and 57% in Singapore and Oceania, respectively. The company expects easing of Covid-19 measures and year-end holidays to boost staycation demand.

site_title: Good news on vaccine front but markets should stay circumspect
summary: A promising start to the year in the Covid-19 vaccine front, with several clinical trials showing over 90% efficacy in preventing the virus. The US FDA has set a 50% effective rate threshold for vaccine approval, and several major pharmaceutical companies are expected to report trial outcomes soon. Despite this, markets should remain cautious due to the long road ahead and the ongoing rise in Covid-19 infections and deaths in the US and Europe. A mass rollout of a vaccine is expected to take several months, and the World Health Organization estimates that 70% of a population must be inoculated to break transmission.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps at open as tech stocks snap back
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a faster-than-expected economic rebound due to signs of a working Covid-19 vaccine. The Nasdaq Composite rose 102.79 points, or 0.89%, to 11,656.65, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 103.43 points, or 0.35%, to 29,524.35. The S&P 500 opened higher by 17.69 points, or 0.50%, at 3,563.22.

site_title: Lower import duties in China help Best World's bottom line in Q3
summary: Best World International reported a 13.7% increase in its third-quarter net profit to S$28.2 million, driven by a 14.8% rise in revenue to S$131.3 million. Lower import duties in China, mainly due to preferential custom duty rates, contributed to the cost savings. Earnings per share rose to 5.19 Singapore cents. The company cited volatility in the Covid-19 situation and potential risks from revoked custom duty rates and increased operational costs, cautioning about its performance outlook for the next 12 months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are set to launch their bilateral air travel bubble on Nov 22, allowing travel without quarantine measures. ARA Asset Management has purchased a Seoul office tower for over $1.21 billion. Hyflux has received a term sheet from US fund manager Strategic Growth Investments for its reorganization and restructuring. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the third consecutive day, ending up 0.31% or 8.28 points to 2,713.28.

site_title: Oil rises on hopes for vaccine, falling US stocks
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday due to hopes of an effective Covid-19 vaccine, with Brent crude futures increasing 2.3% to $44.62 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 2.4% to $42.35 a barrel. US crude inventories fell more than expected, supporting the price rise. Despite this, fuel demand outlook remains clouded due to coronavirus curbs in Europe and the US, with analysts expecting a slow recovery. Oil prices have risen over 13% this week, driven by vaccine trial data showing a 90% effective rate.

site_title: Petronas launches LNG bunkering business with completion of first delivery
summary: Petronas has launched its liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering business with the completion of its first LNG bunkering operation at Pasir Gudang in Johor, Malaysia. The company's first LNG Bunkering Vessel (LBV), MV Avenir Advantage, has been delivered to serve customers in Southeast Asia. This marks a significant milestone for Petronas, as it is the first dedicated LBV to operate in the region, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from shipping.

site_title: Brexit talks set to miss deadline and continue next week
summary: Trade talks between the UK and European Union are set to extend beyond this weekend's informal deadline and continue in Brussels next week. Negotiators have pinpointed the end of this week as the last moment to strike a deal before the UK leaves the bloc's single market on December 31. Despite lack of a conclusion, officials believe progress has been made, and an agreement is in sight, with a possible deadline for a decision on November 19. The UK and EU are racing against time to ratify any agreement before the end of the year.

site_title: Trump to make first appearance since losing election to Biden
summary: US President Donald Trump makes his first post-election appearance on Veteran's Day, despite refusing to acknowledge Joe Biden's victory. Trump has remained at the White House, filing lawsuits alleging voter fraud with minimal evidence, and has not addressed the nation since the election. This refusal to concede is seen as undermining the democratic process and holding up the transition to Biden, who takes office in January. Some Republicans have called for Trump to concede, while powerful figures in the party have backed his bid to challenge Biden's victory.

site_title: Kirin halts payments to Myanmar beer partner linked to military
summary: Japanese beverage group Kirin Holdings has halted payments to its Myanmar beer partner, Myanmar Economic Holdings Public Company (MEHL), due to a lack of visibility regarding the future business environment in the country. The decision comes amid accusations of genocide against the Rohingya Muslim minority by Myanmar's military, which owns MEHL. Kirin's move is in line with Amnesty International's call for companies to cut ties with the entity. The company has hired a financial advisor to investigate its Myanmar operations, which include a 51% stake in two breweries.

site_title: Sembmarine expects losses to continue in Q4
summary: Sembmarine expects losses to continue into the fourth quarter due to low business volume and execution delays. The company reported a net loss of S$192.1 million in the first half of 2020 and has seen its Singapore yards resume production activities in July. Sembmarine is actively tendering for projects and has secured new orders, but delivery dates for existing projects have been rescheduled. The company's liquidity position has strengthened following the completion of a S$2.1 billion rights issue, and it will focus on executing projects and managing costs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.99 points to 1,570.08. Volume reached 14.481 billion lots worth RM5.952 billion, with 654 gainers outnumbering 573 losers.

site_title: BMW unveils electric SUV to challenge Tesla, plans US launch in early 2022
summary: BMW unveiled the electric SUV BMW iX, set to launch in the US in early 2022 to compete with Tesla. The iX has a 300-mile driving range and can add 75 miles in 10 minutes at a fast-charging station. Comparable in size to the BMW X5, the iX features a curved screen dashboard. The electric SUV enters a growing market of battery-powered SUVs targeting affluent customers, competing with Tesla's Model X, Nio, General Motors' Lyriq, Mercedes-Benz, and Volkswagen's electric models.

images.alt_text: German luxury automaker BMW unveiled on Wednesday an electric sport utility vehicle (SUV) called the BMW iX, planned to go on sale in the United States in early 2022 to compete with Tesla and other rivals.

site_title: Malaysia says aviation firms may need three years to recover
summary: Malaysia's transport ministry predicts airlines in the country may take three years to recover from the coronavirus pandemic, depending on the outbreak's impact. Passenger numbers are expected to shrink 75.6% to 26.6 million in 2020, down from 109.2 million in 2019. Airlines globally have suffered losses due to the pandemic, with Malaysia Airlines and AirAsia Group cutting staff and announcing restructuring plans. The Malaysian arm of Lion AirMalindo Air has also launched a retrenchment exercise, highlighting the significant challenges facing the aviation industry.

site_title: UOL says retail portfolio still faces headwinds, as hospitality picks up
summary: UOL Group reported that its retail portfolio still faces headwinds, despite stable committed occupancy at 93.5% and average daily footfall recovering to 54% of pre-Covid levels in the third quarter. The company offered targeted support for tenants affected by Covid-19, with operational updates showing "healthy" sales at residential projects. UOL's office portfolio remains resilient, but new tenant leasing demand is expected to remain soft. The group expects the easing of Covid-19 measures and year-end holidays to support demand for staycations, with most Singapore hospitality properties now open for staycations.

site_title: WeWork's chief legal officer Jennifer Berrent in talks to leave: sources
summary: WeWork's chief legal officer, Jennifer Berrent, is in talks to leave the company in the first quarter of 2021, according to two sources. The plans have not been finalized, and the reason for her departure is unknown. Berrent, who also served as co-president, did not respond to a Reuters email seeking comment.

site_title: Several wounded in WWI memorial attack at Saudi cemetery
summary: A bomb attack occurred at a World War I commemoration in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, injuring several people, amid Muslim anger over French cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. The attack, which also targeted a non-Muslim cemetery, comes after a Saudi citizen wounded a French consulate guard last month. French President Emmanuel Macron, who has faced ire from the Muslim world over satirical cartoons, attended a WWI memorial ceremony in Paris. Saudi Arabia and France have condemned the attack, with France urging its nationals in Saudi Arabia to exercise extreme vigilance.

site_title: ABN Amro profit exceeds estimates as provisions are kept low
summary: ABN Amro NV posted a stronger-than-expected profit of 301 million euros in the third quarter, exceeding analyst estimates of 110 million euros. The Dutch bank reduced costs and set aside less money for potential loan losses, reversing losses in the previous two quarters. CEO Robert Swaak had previously announced plans to cut corporate banking activities, a move aimed at improving the bank's performance.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 2-1/2-year high on vaccine hopes, strong exports data
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 2.5-year high, closing at 2,485.57, driven by optimism over a successful coronavirus vaccine and strong export data. The Kospi index rose 1.3% for its eighth consecutive session. The Korean won also strengthened to its highest level since early 2018, while the benchmark bond yield rose.

site_title: Singapore, US customs to explore trade data connectivity
summary: Singapore and US customs authorities have signed a letter of intent to explore a single window connectivity system for trade data exchange, aiming to facilitate cargo clearance and enhance supply chain security. The proposed system link-up will connect Singapore's Networked Trade Platform with the US Automated Commercial Environment. This collaboration aims to improve efficiency and reduce errors in customs clearance, ultimately benefiting businesses and the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower on profit-taking
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day lower on Wednesday, following a four-day rally fueled by optimism over a virus vaccine and the US election victory. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.3% to 26,226.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.5% to 3,342.20. The losses were attributed to profit-taking, with investors locking in gains from the recent rally.

site_title: STI up for third consecutive day despite easing vaccine optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.31% or 8.28 points to 2,713.28, despite easing vaccine optimism. Investors have shifted focus to vaccine distribution challenges and rising Covid-19 infections. Key performers included Dairy Farm International, which gained 5%, while Ascendas Reit lost 5% after launching a S$1.2 billion equity fund-raising. Markets are expected to remain volatile, with analysts citing a mix of optimism and fear over the vaccine's impact.

site_title: Sabana Reit mulls fund managers' requisition notice asking for EOGM
summary: Sabana Reit's manager board is considering a requisition notice from Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital, requesting an extraordinary general meeting (EOGM) to vote on proposed merger terms. The fund managers oppose the merger at current terms, citing 0.94 ESR-Reit units for one Sabana Reit unit. The Reit advises unitholders to exercise caution when dealing with their units, and will provide further updates on SGXNet.

site_title: Unilever picks Brazil for its pet care products debut
summary: Unilever has launched a new pet care brand, Cafuné, in Brazil, focusing on hygiene and cleaning products for dogs and cats.
