The brand, developed with veterinarians, aims to capitalize on Brazil's large pet population (2nd largest in the world) and projected growth to 101 million by 2030. The company invested in a 24-hour call centre to assist pet owners, alongside a range of products including shampoos, conditioners, and disinfectants. This launch follows a similar move by local pet products chain Petz, which debuted on the Sao Paulo stock exchange last month.

site_title: All 18 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore from overseas, highest daily imported figure in 7 months
summary: Singapore reported 18 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported and had been placed on stay-home notices. The total case count is now 58,091. The cases were from various categories, including permanent residents, work pass holders, and dependant's pass holders. This marks the highest daily imported figure in 7 months.

site_title: Europe: Markets advance at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced at open on Wednesday, driven by positive sentiment from a successful coronavirus vaccine trial and Joe Biden's US election victory. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.5%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 rose 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively. The rally was also fueled by gains in Asia and a new funding round for Airalo, an eSIM platform.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on continued hopes for vaccine
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.8% to 25,349.60, driven by continued optimism for a new coronavirus vaccine. The broader Topix index also gained 1.7% to 1,729.07. This marks the third consecutive day of gains, pushing the market towards a three-decade high.

site_title: Bridgewater's Ray Dalio supports Ant IPO suspension, bullish on China
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, supports China's decision to suspend Ant Group's record US$37 billion IPO, citing the need to curb risks from financial innovation. Despite this, Dalio remains bullish on China, stating that not investing in the country is "very risky". The suspension was made by Chinese regulators just days before the expected listing.

site_title: Australian Parliament to probe Murdoch media dominance
summary: Australia's Parliament will launch an inquiry into media ownership following a record-breaking petition of over 500,000 signatures demanding an investigation into Rupert Murdoch's news dominance. Murdoch's News Corp is the country's largest media organization, owning major newspapers, cable television networks, and magazines. The inquiry aims to address concerns over the concentration of media ownership and its potential impact on democracy. The move comes after former Labor Prime Minister Kevin Rudd launched the petition in October.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as vaccine euphoria lifts recovery hopes
summary: Australia's shares rose for a fifth consecutive session, driven by a 1.7% gain in the S&P/ASX 200 index. The increase was fueled by optimism over a promising Covid-19 vaccine, with Pfizer's 90% effective vaccine candidate boosting hopes for a swift global economic recovery. Financial and energy stocks led the gains, with airline, travel, and tourism stocks also benefiting from the vaccine news. The rally pushed the index to its highest level since March 3.

site_title: Australia's biggest IPO in two years to price from Friday
summary: Macquarie Group plans to price its IPO of majority-owned data analytics software business Nuix this week, earlier than planned, due to growing risk appetite after the US election. The cornerstone bookbuild is expected to be held on Friday to set a price for institutional buyers, with the Australian investment firm on track to triple its investment. A wider group of institutional investors is expected to be invited to the auction next week.

site_title: Toshiba retreats from coal-fired power stations
summary: Toshiba, a Japanese engineering giant, has announced it will stop building new coal-fired power plants and shift to renewable energy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The company, which has around 10 ongoing coal-power projects worldwide, will instead focus on cutting emissions by 50% by 2030. Toshiba's president, Nobuaki Kurumatani, made the statement, but noted that none of its existing projects will be scrapped.

site_title: China Construction Bank unit raising US$3b via blockchain bond
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) unit Longbond is raising up to $3 billion through a blockchain-based bond, the first such security to be publicly listed. The bond will be tradable on the Fusang Exchange in Malaysia and can be bought using Bitcoin or US dollars. The move aims to make the book building and allocation process cheaper and more efficient. CCB Labuan, the lead arranger, will offer an annualized rate of Libor plus 50 basis points. This is the first blockchain-based bond to be publicly listed and available to global investors, including retail investors.

images.alt_text: A China Construction Bank (CCB) unit in Malaysia said it is raising funds through the issuance of an up to US$3 billion bond using blockchain, the first such security to be publicly listed.

site_title: Pound hits two-month highs versus euro as vaccine seen as UK lifeline
summary: Sterling hits a two-month high against the euro due to optimism over a COVID-19 vaccine providing a lifeline to the UK economy. The vaccine's effectiveness, over 90%, has boosted investor confidence, particularly for the UK. This surge in markets follows Pfizer's announcement, with investors anticipating a positive impact on the UK's economy.

images.alt_text: Sterling hit its highest level in more than two months versus the euro on Wednesday as investors were optimistic that a vaccine against Covid-19 would provide a lifeline to the UK economy and more hopeful about the chances of a Brexit deal.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents, leasing volume rise again in October: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents rose in October, with HDB rental volumes increasing 13.9% to 1,734 units and condominium rentals climbing 6.3% to 4,409 units. This marks the second consecutive month of rising rental volumes.

images.alt_text: The increase in rental volume could partly be attributed to the new restrictions on developers re-issuing options to purchase announced on Sept 28, said Ms Sun.

site_title: Issues hit shoppers using GrabPay at start of 11.11 sales
summary: Grab users experienced technical issues with its e-payment feature, GrabPay, during the 11.11 sales event in Singapore. Some users, like Aaron Koh, were unable to complete transactions due to issues with one-time passwords and card details. Grab apologized for the inconvenience and attributed the problem to a 16-minute downtime experienced by its payment processing partner Tutuka. Many consumers reported that money transferred to their GrabPay accounts was stuck, and some were left hanging due to lack of updates from Grab.

site_title: Louis Dreyfus to sell big stake to Abu Dhabi fund after investor hunt
summary: Louis Dreyfus Company has agreed to sell a 45% stake in its unit, Louis Dreyfus Company BV, to Abu Dhabi-based holding company ADQ for at least $800 million. This marks the end of chairwoman Margarita Louis-Dreyfus' search for a new investor. The transaction will see ADQ invest a minimum of $800 million into the LDC unit, which operates in the commodity merchant sector. The deal's price was not disclosed, but it is expected to be significant.

site_title: Ex-Goldman veteran seeks A$150m for ESG fund
summary: Former Goldman Sachs Asset Management and Bankers Trust veterans Philip Moffitt and Christopher Selth are launching Beckon Capital to raise up to A$150 million for an ESG-focused equity fund. The fund will invest in small to medium-sized businesses in Australia and New Zealand, particularly those in healthcare and financial services for marginalized groups. Beckon aims to bring these companies to a broader investor base, with the goal of sourcing investment opportunities within six months.

site_title: HKEX's Q3 profit jumps 52% on trading revenue, listings boost
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) reported a 52% increase in third-quarter net profit to HK$3.45 billion, driven by higher trading revenue and listing fees. Boosted by large listings, including Chinese tech firms, trading volumes rose 40% compared to the previous weak quarter. Despite a setback in its IPO bid, HKEX chief executive Charles Li expressed confidence in the exchange's role in global markets.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on vaccine, Biden gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by positive sentiment over a highly successful Covid-19 vaccine trial and Joe Biden's US election victory. Stocks that had been beaten down due to lockdowns rallied, while tech titans and medical equipment makers took a hit. Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul rose over one percent, while Hong Kong and Singapore also saw gains. However, experts warned that the economic benefits of the vaccine may not be seen until the second half of next year, and that uncertainty remains due to ongoing lockdowns and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: PSA Marine granted sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: PSA Marine, a harbour and terminal towage operator, has been granted a 3-year, €30 million (S$47.8 million) sustainability-linked loan from DBS. The loan features an interest rate adjustment linked to an ESG target, requiring PSA Marine's crew transfer vessels to support offshore wind energy-related activities. This is the first sustainability-linked loan in Singapore's maritime industry. The loan supports PSA Marine's growth in the renewable energy sector, which has been expanding since 2015.

site_title: Gold firms on softer US dollar, concerns over rising virus cases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,882.06 per ounce, supported by a softer US dollar and concerns over rising Covid-19 cases in the US, which may lead to further stimulus and negatively impact the dollar. The dollar index fell 0.1% against a basket of currencies, making gold more attractive to other currency holders. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, driven by inflation and currency concerns.

site_title: UK independent bookshops go online to reach new audiences
summary: UK independent bookshops are banding together on the online platform Bookshop.org to reach new audiences and combat fierce competition from Amazon. With over 250 bookshops joining, the platform aims to provide a lifeline to small bookshops during the pandemic. Each bookseller receives 30% of the sale price, and customers can expect a 7% discount. The platform hopes to grow its number of partners and emulate the in-store experience online, offering a more personalized approach to book sales.

site_title: Hot stock: Ascendas Reit sheds 6.3% after unveiling acquisitions, S$1.2b fundraising
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (Ascendas Reit) shed 6.3% after announcing a S$1.2 billion equity fundraising and unveiling plans to acquire data centers and office buildings overseas, including a US acquisition of two freehold office properties in San Francisco. The trust's manager plans to use the funds to finance potential acquisitions in the US, Europe, and Australia, with a total estimated purchase price of S$2 billion. Analysts expect the acquisitions to boost the trust's assets under management and diversify its income streams.

site_title: Newly discovered primate in Myanmar 'already facing extinction'
summary: Scientists have identified a new species of primate, the Popa langur, in central Myanmar. The lithe tree-dwelling monkey has a mask-like face and grey hair, and is estimated to have existed for at least a million years. With only 200-250 individuals remaining in the wild, the species is classified as "critically endangered" due to hunting and habitat loss. Genetic analysis revealed the species' existence, with samples collected in the 19th century matching modern-day specimens. Conservation efforts are underway to protect the species from extinction.

site_title: China auto sales rise 12.5% in October, seventh straight monthly gain
summary: China's vehicle sales rose 12.5% in October, marking the seventh consecutive monthly gain, with 2.57 million vehicles sold. New energy vehicle sales surged 105% to 160,000, their fourth consecutive month of growth. This follows China's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, leading the global automotive industry.

site_title: SpaceX wins Nasa blessing to ferry astronauts to space station
summary: SpaceX has received formal NASA approval to transport astronauts to the International Space Station, marking a milestone for commercial space vehicles. The certification allows SpaceX's Dragon capsule and Falcon 9 rocket to carry crew on regular rotations, with the first flight planned for November 14 with four astronauts. This approval comes after a successful crewed test mission and makes SpaceX's vehicles the first to be rated for humans since the Space Shuttle. Regular crew rotations are set to begin, with additional missions planned for March and September/October.

site_title: Apollo to buy Great Canadian Gaming in C$3.3b deal
summary: Apollo Global Management Inc agreed to acquire Great Canadian Gaming Corp in a deal valued at over C$3.3 billion. The Toronto-listed casino operator will be acquired at C$39 per share, a 35% premium to its closing price. The deal has been unanimously approved by Great Canadian's board, with Apollo committing to reopening properties as soon as it's safe to do so. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand gaming and hospitality offerings, and follows the challenges faced by the casino industry due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong disqualifies four legislators for 'endangering security'
summary: Hong Kong's Legislative Council disqualified four opposition legislators for endangering national security, amid China's tightened grip on the city. The move comes after China's Parliament adopted a resolution allowing the city's executive to expel legislators deemed to be supporting Hong Kong independence or threatening national security. The disqualifications, part of a broader crackdown on dissent, raise concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms.

site_title: F&N's FY20 earnings hit by less fizzy soda sales
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) posted a 2.1% dip in net profit to S$149.2 million in FY20, as revenue fell 3.6% to S$1.8 billion. Lower sales from its soft drinks and publishing businesses were impacted by Covid-19 containment measures. The company's earnings per share was 10.4 cents, down from 10.6 cents last year. F&N proposed a final dividend of 3.5 cents per share, down from 5.5 cents previously, to maintain a strong balance sheet amidst uncertainty surrounding the health crisis.

site_title: Hyflux receives term sheet from US fund manager Strategic Growth Investments
summary: Hyflux has received a term sheet from US fund manager Strategic Growth Investments (SGI) for a proposed reorganisation and restructuring of the company and its affiliates. The term sheet is worth at least S$204.78 million, following a formal expression of interest from SGI last month. Hyflux is considering the offer and will provide further updates as necessary.

site_title: Suntec Tower Two's 42nd floor put on the market for S$33m
summary: A 42nd floor office floor at Suntec Tower Two in Singapore has been put on the market for S$33 million, with an average price of S$3,303 per square foot. The 9,989 square feet office space is comprised of four contiguous strata units, making it one of the prime office floors in the building. The listing marks a significant sale in the Singapore market, with experts citing the growing demand for prime office spaces.

site_title: Grounded Malaysian pilot's noodle stall takes off
summary: Malaysian pilot Azrin Mohamad Zawawi, 44, started a noodle stall called "Kapten Corner" after being retrenched due to the coronavirus pandemic. The stall, which serves Malaysian dishes, gained unexpected publicity after a photo of him in his captain's uniform went viral. Despite initial skepticism, customers praised the food and Mr. Zawawi's creative business approach. He hopes his experience can inspire others to find new ways to make a living during the pandemic, saying "Embrace the challenge and never give up... It's like flying the aircraft, we always move forward."

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascendas Reit, Sembmarine, Keppel, Valuetronics, Frasers Property
summary: Ascendas Reit priced its S$1.2 billion equity fundraising at S$2.96 per new unit, while Sembmarine incurred losses for its fiscal third quarter and expects continued losses in the fourth quarter. Keppel Corp divested a stake in a Chinese development company, Valuetronics Holdings posted a 12.1% drop in net profit, and Frasers Property saw a 66.4% drop in net profit for the full year. Bukit Sembawang Estates reported an 11% increase in net profit for the first half, and First Reit's distribution per unit fell 53%.

site_title: Drone taxis and bags of rice take flight in downtown Seoul
summary: South Korea successfully tested a drone taxi and delivery system near the Han River in Seoul, marking a step towards launching unmanned air vehicles by 2025. The demonstration featured small drones monitoring traffic conditions and a larger, two-seater drone, made by Ehang, which took off and landed successfully. The K-Drone System, worth 24.5 billion won, aims to develop flying vehicles for densely populated cities. The test paves the way for the country to become a leader in unmanned air vehicles.

site_title: Qatar puts up 'for sale' sign with new property visas
summary: Qatar has introduced a new property visa scheme, allowing foreigners to purchase homes or stores and secure residency. The scheme requires a minimum investment of $200,000 for temporary residency and $1 million for permanent residency, which includes free schools and healthcare. The move aims to diversify Qatar's economy and attract foreign capital ahead of the 2022 World Cup, as the country seeks to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels. The new policy could help alleviate an oversupply of units and boost demand for residential property.

site_title: China says Australia knows what it needs to do to improve ties
summary: China has urged Australia to take steps to improve strained relations, with Assistant Minister of Commerce Li Chenggang stating that both sides must nurture and care for their relationship. Ties have worsened since Australia called for an investigation into the COVID-19 pandemic's origins in China. China has responded with tariffs, bans, and economic coercion, prompting Australian Trade Minister Simon Birmingham to say the government is trying to resolve concerns and secure a better understanding with China.

site_title: ARA buys Seoul office tower; DBS, UOB grant S$385.8m green loan for former Manulife Centre
summary: ARA Asset Management has purchased Parc1 Tower II in Seoul for S$1.21 billion, in a deal that is expected to be the largest single asset transaction in Korea this year. The 53-storey office building, located in the Yeouido business district, features eco-friendly and energy-saving systems, including green energy and charging spots for electric cars. ARA and British property group Chelsfield have also secured a S$385.8 million green loan from DBS and UOB to finance the acquisition and renovation of 5One Central in Singapore, a 50:50 joint venture between the two firms.

images.alt_text: Currently the fifth-tallest office building in Seoul, Parc1 Tower II (second from left) comprises 53 storeys and has a gross floor area of 162,216 square metres.
Anthony Kang, chief executive of ARA Korea, said the group expects "strong leasing demand" for the Seoul office tower.
A rendering of 5One Central post renovation. The building was formerly known as Manulife Centre.

site_title: CEOs weather pandemic with compensation largely intact
summary: US CEOs' compensation largely intact despite pandemic, with only about 1/5 of Russell 3000 firms reducing CEO pay. Corporate boards have opted for generous packages for executives, even when firms are laying off workers. Many boards have adjusted compensation criteria to incentivize top executives, but rarely cut pay. Some notable cases of reduced compensation include United Airlines chairman Oscar Munoz and CEO Scott Kirby. Analysts say the trend towards proportionality in compensation and incentives has accelerated during the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a cheap yen against the dollar, which supported Japanese exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.04% or 259.35 points to 25,164.94, while the Topix index gained 1.16% or 19.80 points to 1,720.60.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at start after strong rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.28% lower on Wednesday, following a four-day strong gain of over 5% driven by vaccine hopes and the US election win. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,226.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also eased slightly. The dip marks a reversal from the previous day's rally, as investors appear to be taking profits.

site_title: Alibaba records billions in sales as China's first post-virus Singles' Day kicks off
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day sales reached $70.6 billion, surpassing Black Friday and Cyber Monday in the US, as China's economy experiences an economic rebound after controlling the spread of the novel coronavirus. The four-day shopping event, which started on November 1, saw over two million new products launched, with luxury brands expected to benefit from Chinese consumers stuck at home due to border closures. Analysts predict a boost for local spending, with 76,000 respondents planning to spend less than $1,000 and only 7,341 planning to spend more than $10,000.

site_title: New Zealand central bank holds rates at 0.25%, launches funding programme
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) held interest rates at 0.25% on November 11, 2020, as expected, and launched a funding-for-lending programme for banks. The bank also retained its large-scale asset purchase programme at NZ$100 billion. Economists had predicted a rate hold.

site_title: South Korea's Oct unemployment rate rises; jobs fall at fastest pace in six months
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate rose to 4.2% in October, the highest since July, due to the resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic. The number of employed people fell 421,000 from last year, the sharpest decline in six months. This marks a three-month high in unemployment rates.

site_title: Oil gains nearly 3% on vaccine hopes, even as nations reimpose lockdowns
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 3% on Tuesday as hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine outweighed concerns about fuel demand from new lockdowns. Brent crude futures gained 2.9% to $43.61 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 2.7% to $41.36. The vaccine's effectiveness and potential for increased travel demand boosted oil prices, despite ongoing lockdowns and rising coronavirus cases in the US and Europe.

site_title: Swiss spies benefitted from secret CIA encryption firm: probe
summary: A Swiss parliamentary probe revealed that Swiss spies benefited from a secret CIA encryption firm, Crypto AG, which was used to spy on governments worldwide. The CIA and German intelligence services controlled Crypto, rigging its equipment to break codes and read messages. The Swiss intelligence service had collaborated with foreign services since 1993, and the government was not informed until late last year. The probe raised concerns about gaps in control over the intelligence service, and several parties called for a full investigation.

site_title: Sembmarine expects losses to continue in Q4
summary: Sembmarine expects losses to continue into the fourth quarter due to low business volume and execution delays. The company incurred a net loss of S$192.1 million in the first half of 2020 and has seen its operating yard workforce increase to almost full levels. Sembmarine is actively tendering for new projects and has secured S$330 million of ongoing jobs, with delivery dates for existing projects rescheduled by 3-12 months. The company's stock rose 8.9% after the business update.

site_title: Valuetronics H1 net profit falls 12.1% to HK$91.5m on lower revenue
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 12.1% drop in net profit to HK$91.5 million for the six months ended Sept 30, 2020, due to a 19.9% decline in revenue. The electronics manufacturing service provider's revenue fell mainly due to decreased demand amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company expects to remain profitable for FY2021 but faces uncertainty due to the pandemic and Sino-US trade tensions.

site_title: Masayoshi Son's personal stake in SoftBank trading unit draws fire
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's stock and options trading program, which involves a personal stake by billionaire Masayoshi Son, is drawing criticism from investors over potential corporate governance concerns. Despite the company's mixed performance, with a significant derivative loss in the September quarter, Son defended the program as a way to utilize SoftBank's massive cash pile. Analysts question the attraction of short-term call-spreads for a long-term investor like Son, and the company's reliance on public stocks to fund the trading operation.

site_title: New Zealand central bank delays bank capital hike to 2022, to review LVR
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has delayed increasing bank capital requirements until 2022 to cushion the economic blow from the Covid-19 pandemic. The increase in the prudential capital buffer will begin in July 2022, and the bank will review its timing near the end of 2021. The RBNZ also announced it will consult on reinstating loan-to-value ratio (LVR) restrictions on high-risk lending.

site_title: Walmart partners GM's Cruise on self-driving delivery pilot in Arizona
summary: Walmart partners with General Motors' Cruise on a self-driving delivery pilot in Scottsdale, Arizona, starting early next year. This is part of Walmart's ongoing efforts to integrate self-driving technology into its delivery services. Cruise has been testing its vehicles in San Francisco and Phoenix, and has previously provided automated grocery delivery services. The partnership aims to make the first pilot successful, with Cruise backed by major investors including Honda, SoftBank, and T Rowe Price. Details on the number of vehicles to be deployed are not disclosed.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain for fifth session; New Zealand eyes RBNZ decision
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.3% to 6,340.5 on Wednesday, for its fifth consecutive gain, driven by financial and energy stocks. Travel-related companies and airlines, such as Qantas Airways and Webjet, also climbed on hopes of a economic recovery. Meanwhile, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index inched up 0.3% ahead of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's decision.

site_title: Boeing sees more cancelled orders as MAX nears return
summary: Boeing reported 12 more cancelled orders for the 737 MAX, bringing the total to 24, as the aircraft nears its return to service after being grounded since March 2019. The plane is expected to receive regulatory approval as soon as November 18, allowing airlines to begin training pilots. American Airlines plans to return the 737 MAX to service in December, while Southwest will not schedule passenger flights until the second quarter of 2021. The return to service comes after Boeing addressed safety issues that contributed to two deadly crashes.

site_title: UK plans sweeping new powers to stop deals that risk national security
summary: The UK government plans to introduce sweeping new powers to block deals that risk national security, including takeovers and corporate transactions in sensitive sectors such as defence and energy. The National Security and Investment Bill will give ministers the authority to scrutinize and intervene in "malicious" foreign investment, with fines and jail time for non-compliance. The bill aims to balance job-creating investment with national security concerns, with most transactions expected to be approved within 30 days. The move follows similar upgrades in oversight powers in the US and Australia.

site_title: Biden tells world leaders 'America is back' but Pompeo digs in
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden told world leaders that 'America is back' and plans to work with allies on fighting the Covid-19 pandemic and climate change. However, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo insisted that Donald Trump would remain in power, sparking a break in cooperation. Despite this, fellow leaders have congratulated Biden, including British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, French President Emmanuel Macron, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel. Pompeo's stance will be tested as he embarks on a seven-nation tour of allies that have congratulated Biden.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at open as vaccine optimism fades; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% at the open on Wednesday, following a mixed overnight session on Wall Street, amid fading optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 24.4 points to 2,680.60, with losers outnumbering gainers 83 to 76. Banking stocks were mixed, while glove makers and real estate investment trusts were also affected. The decline was attributed to the realization that economic gains from a vaccine will likely not be felt until late next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.99 points, or 0.76%, to 1,563.08. Volume was 469.26 million lots worth RM179.45 million. Gainers beat losers 280 to 171. The market trend was not directly linked to any major news event, with global markets instead influenced by US-EU trade talks and the S&P 500, Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Airbnb said to delay IPO filing to distance it from US election
summary: Airbnb has delayed its initial public offering (IPO) filing until next week, citing a desire to avoid being overshadowed by the US election fallout. The company, which had planned to file on Thursday, is instead planning to file on Monday. The delay is not related to market or regulatory concerns, but rather a strategic move to avoid being overshadowed by the election. Airbnb is expected to raise up to $3 billion in its Nasdaq debut, making it one of the largest IPOs on the New York exchange this year.

site_title: More tech executives than tech critics on Biden's transition team
summary: President-elect Joe Biden's transition team features more tech executives than outspoken tech critics, suggesting a strong influence from the tech industry in shaping his administration's policies. Executives from companies like Amazon, Microsoft, and LinkedIn are part of the review teams for various government departments, including the Department of State, Department of Treasury, and Office of Management and Budget. This move is seen as an effort to strengthen the tech industry's relationship with the Biden administration and ensure a voice in federal investigations of their business practices.

images.alt_text: Far more executives from technology companies than outspoken tech critics were named to President-elect Joe Biden's transition team on Tuesday, offering clues on who will decide on filling key roles and ultimately influence his administration's thinking in coming years.

site_title: China tech selloff deepens to US$203b after antitrust rules
summary: China's antitrust watchdog has unveiled regulations to curb monopolistic practices in the Internet industry, wiping out over US$200 billion in value from Chinese technology shares. The Hang Seng Tech Index slumped 3.9% on Wednesday, taking its two-day loss to almost 9%. The regulations, aimed at rooting out anti-competitive behavior and requiring specific operating approval for companies using Variable Interest Entities, are seen as a further tightening of the online economy. The move is expected to impact tech giants such as Alibaba and Tencent, potentially discouraging firms from listing in the near term.

site_title: US records new high of over 200,000 Covid-19 cases in 24 hours: tally
summary: The US recorded a new high of 201,961 Covid-19 cases in 24 hours, exceeding its previous daily record, with total cases reaching 10,238,243 and 239,588 deaths. This comes as the country struggles to contain the pandemic, with record hospitalizations and deaths. Meanwhile, Pfizer announced a 90% effective vaccine candidate, a major breakthrough in the search for a vaccine. The US is experiencing a surge in cases, with President Joe Biden emphasizing the importance of face coverings to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Pfizer vaccine provides hope for ending pandemic
summary: A Pfizer vaccine has shown "extraordinary" results in its final-stage trial, providing hope for ending the pandemic. The vaccine, developed in partnership with BioNTech, is expected to produce 1.3 billion doses by the end of 2021, enough to vaccinate 650 million people. Meanwhile, an Eli Lilly antibody therapy has been granted emergency-use authorization in the US, offering another treatment option for mild-to-moderate Covid-19. However, significant uncertainty remains in the race for immunization, including challenges in deploying mRNA vaccines and ensuring global access.

site_title: Lyft seeks slice of food-delivery amid a slow recovery in rides
summary: Lyft is expanding into the food-delivery market amid a slow recovery in ride-hailing demand, aiming to undercut competitors' commission fees. The company plans to offer delivery services for restaurants without launching a full consumer-facing platform. Lyft's third-quarter revenue fell 48% to $499.7 million, and the company reaffirmed its goal to reach profitability by the end of 2021. The move is seen as a response to Uber's dominance in the food-delivery market, with Uber reporting $3.13 billion in third-quarter revenue.

site_title: Australia's Nov consumer sentiment jumps to seven-year highs
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment reached a seven-year high in November, jumping 2.5% from October, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index. The optimism is driven by the easing of coronavirus restrictions and the reopening of the Victoria-New South Wales border. However, consumers expressed less confidence in their finances, with a 3.2% decline in family finances compared to the previous year. Despite this, the outlook for buying a dwelling improved, with a 8% increase. The index now stands at 107.7, indicating that optimists outnumber pessimists.

site_title: ByteDance asks US court to intervene in TikTok forced sale
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, has asked a US federal appeals court to intervene in a dispute over the forced sale of the app due to national security concerns. The Trump administration had demanded that ByteDance sell TikTok to American investors, citing concerns over data privacy and security. A deal was struck with Oracle and Walmart, but it is now in limbo amid changes in the White House. ByteDance claims it has offered detailed solutions to address concerns but received no substantive feedback, leading it to seek court intervention to defend its rights and employees.

site_title: Brookfield plots US$50b push into market for secondaries
summary: Brookfield Asset Management plans to invest up to $50 billion in the secondary market for private assets, starting with real estate secondaries. The Toronto-based alternative asset manager has made its first transaction in the space, purchasing an interest in a multifamily project in Los Angeles. Brookfield aims to build out teams for infrastructure and private-equity secondaries, with plans to hire former executives from Partners Group Holding. The company expects to generate mid-teens returns on secondary investments, and CEO Bruce Flatt believes the space could eventually reach $225 billion to $450 billion in assets under management.

site_title: Ascendas Reit prices preferential offering at S$2.96 per new unit
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (Ascendas Reit) has priced its S$1.2 billion equity fundraising at S$2.96 per new unit, a 7.8% discount to the volume-weighted average price. The trust will issue 133.9 million preferential offering units and 264.4 million private placement units. The fundraising will be used to finance potential acquisitions in the US, Europe, and Australia, including a US$560.2 million purchase of two office buildings and a portfolio of data centers in Europe. The trust plans to declare an advanced distribution to existing unit holders and resume semi-annual distributions after the placement units are issued.

site_title: US: Shares end mixed after Covid-19 vaccine high fades
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.9% and the S&P 500 dipping 0.1%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq lost 1.4% following optimism about a 90% effective Covid-19 vaccine, which is expected to take months to be widely distributed. Investors are shifting away from stay-at-home stocks and returning to back-to-normal shares, with Pfizer shares gaining initially but ending 1.3% lower. Uncertainty about a potential stimulus package has receded, and investors are focusing on sectors that will benefit from a vaccine once distributed.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hold eight-month highs despite lockdown fears
summary: European stocks held near eight-month highs, rising 0.9% on Tuesday, despite lockdown fears and economic concerns. The pan-European Stoxx 600 has surged 12% this month, driven by optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine breakthrough. However, strict lockdowns and investor sentiment have capped gains, with the European Commission set to approve a contract for Pfizer's potential coronavirus vaccine on Wednesday. Banking, auto parts, and energy stocks were among the biggest gainers, while travel & leisure stocks fell.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong air travel bubble to launch on Nov 22
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong will launch their bilateral air travel bubble on November 22, allowing people in both cities to travel without quarantine. Travellers must have been in either city for 14 days and take a pre-departure PCR test within 72 hours. The bubble will start with one flight per day into each city with a quota of 200 travellers, increasing to two flights per day on December 7. Foreign travellers must apply for an Air Travel Pass 7-30 days before entry and undergo post-arrival testing. The bubble may be suspended if COVID-19 cases exceed a certain threshold.

site_title: Covid-19 unlocks new interest in healthtech and edtech sectors: report
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated interest in healthtech and edtech sectors, with four times more people using digital health apps and three times more using top education apps compared to pre-pandemic levels. Investments in both sectors have surged, with healthtech seeing a 15.8% increase to $220 million in the first half of 2020, and edtech seeing a 3.5-fold increase to $270 million in 2019. The report predicts new startups will emerge and funding will continue to grow post-pandemic as investors seek edtech companies that have benefited from the online learning trend.

site_title: Frasers Property full-year profit tumbles 66.4% on Covid-19 hit
summary: Frasers Property, a real estate developer and manager, reported a 66.4% drop in net profit to S$188.1 million for the full year ended Sept 30, 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue slipped 5.1% to S$3.6 billion, and earnings per share fell to 3.81 Singapore cents from 15.94 cents in the previous year. The group's hospitality and retail properties were severely impacted, but its industrial and logistics segments showed resilience. The board recommended a final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share, citing the need to conserve financial resources amid uncertainties.

site_title: Demand for alternative strategies surges
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is investing more capital into alternative strategies in Asia-Pacific, driven by demand for sustainable infrastructure, private credit, and alternative income sources. The firm has invested around $1 billion annually in the region over the past three years and is now on track to channel more capital into real assets despite the pandemic. This trend is expected to continue, with BlackRock managing around $240 billion in alternative assets and seeing strong fund-raising momentum globally.

site_title: Apple begins selling Macs with its own chips to mimic iPhones
summary: Apple has begun selling Mac computers powered by its proprietary M1 chip, designed to mimic the performance of iPhones. The new M1 chip improves battery life and allows Macs to run apps designed for mobile devices. The MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, and Mac mini are the first to integrate the new chip, replacing Intel chips used on earlier models. This move aims to give Apple greater control over hardware and software, and to increase the Mac's market share, which currently stands at less than 10% compared to Apple's iPhones and iPads.

site_title: Catching the wave of blue finance
summary: The world's oceans are facing severe threats from overfishing, pollution, and climate change, with nearly half of coral reefs and mangrove forests lost in the past 50 years. To address this, investments in recovering and maintaining marine ecosystems are long overdue. Currently, only 0.1% of the ocean economy is invested in sustainable projects, with less than $25.5 billion committed in 2017. To change this, three challenges need to be addressed: standardizing the valuation of natural assets, assisting governments in governing ocean resources, and inspiring private sector initiative and capital.

site_title: Greed and fear, optimism and paranoia
summary: Investor Morgan Housel emphasizes the psychological side of investing as the most critical factor. In his book "The Psychology of Money," he argues that investing is not just about money, but about our relationship with greed and fear. Housel highlights the importance of a long-term mindset, observing patterns in history and real-time market behavior, and managing risk. He also stresses the need for a "barbell personality" that balances optimism about the long run with pessimism about the short run. This approach can help investors overcome greed and fear, moderate their emotions, and make more informed decisions.

images.alt_text: Investing legend Warren Buffett started investing at age 11 and continues today at age 90. So how much of his net worth came after his 50th birthday? About 96 per cent.

site_title: No more fiscal firehose? That might be okay by the Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy is expected to slow down due to a surge in novel coronavirus cases, and policymakers suggest a more targeted fiscal support rather than a "firehose" of aid. Federal Reserve officials, including San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly and Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan, call for extended unemployment insurance, additional funding for small businesses, and other measures to bridge the pandemic. They express concerns about downside economic risks and expect a challenging six-month period, but anticipate a strong rebound once a vaccine is widely available.

site_title: Britain unveils green plan for post-Brexit finance
summary: The UK has unveiled a green plan to support its transition to net zero carbon emissions by 2050, including a sovereign green bond to fund environmental projects. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak pledged the plan would help retain Britain's role as a premier global financial hub and aid economic recovery from the coronavirus fallout. The UK aims to meet the Paris climate agreement goal through measures such as compelling companies to disclose the impact of climate change and considering the issuance of digital currencies by central banks.

site_title: Rediscovering simple pleasures of being back at the office
summary: As Singapore's economy reopens, employees are slowly returning to the office, bringing back the simple pleasures of working together. Ergonomic designs, natural light, and friendly relationships among colleagues can boost productivity and well-being. A good office pantry and convenient coffee options, such as Nespresso Professional, can also foster creativity and connections. The company's sustainable coffee capsules and recycling program allow employees to recycle and reduce waste, making the office experience even more welcoming.

site_title: October new home sales dive by half following clampdown on OTP reissue
summary: Singapore's new private home sales plummeted by half in October to 630 units, down from 1,329 in September, following the clampdown on options to purchase (OTPs) by developers. Analysts attribute the decline to a knee-jerk reaction by buyers, who are waiting to see if developers will adjust prices. The tightened OTP rules, introduced on September 28, limit the validity of OTPs to three months and require buyers to sell their existing flats before purchasing a new one. Consultants expect the market to settle in a few months, with some projects experiencing a slower start.

site_title: Amazon hit by EU complaint, faces new probe over sales
summary: The European Union has launched a new probe into Amazon, alleging the company uses non-public business data from independent sellers on its platform to gain an unfair advantage. The EU also claims Amazon unfairly favors its own products by highlighting them in a prominent "buy box" and pushing retailers to use its logistics services. Amazon denies the allegations and says it will cooperate with the investigation, which could result in fines or changes to its business practices. The EU's antitrust commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, has been increasing scrutiny of big tech firms, including Apple and Facebook.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane seek Sabana Reit EGM to vote on five resolutions
summary: FUND managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital have made a requisition to Sabana Reit's board to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on five resolutions. The resolutions pertain to the independent status of director Ng Shin Ein and the proposed merger with ESR-Reit. The proposals include seeking clarification on Ng's declarations and disclosures, disclosure of the hiring of former ESR employees, and making the merger's basis and reasons known.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang H1 net profit rises 11% to S$73.7m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 11% increase in net profit to S$73.7 million for the first half of its financial year, driven by higher earnings per share and lower operating expenses. Revenue rose 2% to S$223.3 million, but gross profit fell 2% due to higher cost of sales. The company maintained a net cash inflow of S$174.7 million and plans to proceed with new residential projects despite uncertain global economic conditions.

site_title: DoctorxDentist to delist doctors who want profiles taken down
summary: DoctorxDentist, a Singapore-based online platform, has agreed to remove listings of doctors who have requested to have their profiles taken down from the website. The decision comes after a dispute with the Singapore Medical Association (SMA), following complaints that the company refused to remove profiles despite requests. The platform will also work towards an amicable resolution with the SMA, which had collated a list of doctors who did not want to be associated with the platform.

site_title: STI jumps 3.67% to 2,705 points in strongest session since April
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) surged 3.67% to 2,705 points, its strongest session since April 7, amid positive vaccine news. Investors bought shares in sectors hard hit by the pandemic, including aviation and travel-related stocks, which saw significant gains. The rotation from technology and medical equipment plays to broader financials, real estate, and consumer sectors drove the market. Notable gainers included Singapore Airlines and Genting Singapore, while healthcare and pharmaceutical plays declined. The market's rally continues ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Jack Ma's botched Ant IPO becomes a boost for state banks
summary: Chinese banks have seen a surge in stocks following new regulations that derailed Ant Group's massive IPO, aiming to curb fintech giants' rapid growth and leverage. State-backed lenders, such as China Merchants Bank, have emerged as the biggest winners, with their stocks rising 18% in Hong Kong. The new rules require fintech companies to provide at least 30% of funding for loans, increasing the risk and capital requirements for Ant and similar firms, potentially leading to a smaller valuation in the IPO.

site_title: Lockdown is Collins Dictionary's word of the year
summary: Collins Dictionary has named "lockdown" its word of the year for 2020, following a significant increase in usage due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The term became synonymous with governments' efforts to curb the spread of the virus, and its usage rose by over 24,000 times compared to the previous year. Six of Collins' 10 words of the year are related to the global health crisis, including "coronavirus" and "social distancing".

site_title: UK Reit's property value dives £945m in pandemic
summary: Land Securities Group, a UK real estate investment trust, reported a £945m (£1.69 billion) decline in property value due to the pandemic, with retail assets losing over 20% outside London and 17% in the capital. The company incurred an £835m loss before tax, with 78% of rent collected in September but only half of monies owed by regional retail tenants. Despite this, CEO Mark Allan believes the company remains in a "fundamentally strong position" and is ramping up asset sales and redevelopment efforts.

site_title: Axington in search of new auditor after plan to replace Nexia falls through
summary: Axington, a Singapore-based company, is seeking a new auditor after a plan to replace its current auditor Nexia fell through. The change of control was made by cousins Nelson and Terence Loh earlier this year. Nexia had received a professional clearance request from the proposed new auditor and submitted resignation letters, but the new auditor declined the appointment. The resignation will only take effect upon the appointment of another auditor, and shareholders must approve the change at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: 2020 heralds new era for South-east Asia's digital growth
summary: In 2020, South-east Asia's digital economy experienced significant growth, with 40 million new internet users, driven by the pandemic. The region's internet economy reached a gross merchandise value of $100 billion, despite a global economic downturn. The growth is expected to continue, reaching $300 billion by 2025. However, to unlock its full potential, concerted action is needed from businesses, governments, and civil society on four priorities: skills training and job creation, closing digital divides, guiding the next generation of startup founders, and fostering innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume up 21.6% in October as buyers sense worst is over
summary: Singapore condo resale volumes rose 21.6% in October, the highest since May 2018, with 1,509 units sold, according to SRX Property. Demand is strong, signaling recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with healthy prices and sales in various regions. Experts attribute the surge to buyers sensing the worst is over and confidence in the gradually recovering economy, with estimated sales of 8,500-9,000 units for 2020 and 9,000-10,000 units for 2021.

site_title: Bilateral pacts and Singapore's role in helping countries create a secure cyber domain
summary: Singapore plays a key role in helping countries create a secure cyber domain through bilateral pacts and regional cooperation. The country's robust cybersecurity measures have been recognized globally, and it is now being asked to lead efforts to help less advanced countries develop better cyber defenses. A global effort to frame a convention to deter cyberattacks has been underway for 20 years, but a regional approach to cyber capacity building holds great promise, with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) leading the way.

site_title: Structural changes could pose headwinds for MRO firms in post-Covid landscape
summary: Maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) firms face structural headwinds in the post-Covid landscape due to a slow recovery in travel and depressed demand for their services. International borders remain slow to reopen, and airlines are expected to rely on next-generation aircraft, reducing the global fleet size. MRO companies, such as SIA Engineering Co and ST Engineering, are adapting by investing in digitalization, expanding into new markets, and diversifying their services, including passenger-to-freight conversions and cargo operations.

site_title: A healthy dose of modesty needed against cultural blinkers
summary: The article highlights the need for a more open and inclusive approach to cultural understanding, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. Many in the West, especially those who speak English as their primary language, tend to be unaware of achievements and knowledge from non-European cultures, which can have serious consequences. The article cites examples of how Western countries failed to learn from Asian experiences, such as Singapore's successful "circuit breaker" lockdown, and instead relied on their own approaches. This Eurocentric and blinkered approach may have cost lives and hindered efforts to contain the disease, emphasizing the need for a more humble and open-minded approach to global knowledge and cooperation.

site_title: Shell Singapore to cut 500 jobs over three years
summary: Shell Singapore plans to cut 500 jobs from its workforce over three years as part of a refinery restructuring to reduce its carbon footprint. The company aims to halve its crude processing capacity and deliver a significant reduction in carbon dioxide emissions. The job cuts will result in a workforce of around 800 employees by the end of 2023, with the earliest staff movement taking place in the fourth quarter of 2021. The move is part of Shell's efforts to transform its businesses into low-carbon energy operations by 2050.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported financial updates for the third fiscal quarter. First Reit's distribution per unit fell 53% to 1.01 cents, while SingHaiyi Group's net loss narrowed to S$4.6 million. Tuan Sing Holdings completed a sale and purchase agreement for its Robinson Point office tower at S$500 million. Bumitama Agri reported higher revenue and net profit due to higher palm oil prices. EC World Reit's distribution per unit dropped 6.8% to 1.388 cents, while Far East Orchard posted a net loss of S$6.3 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its hospitality business.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit posts indicative Q3 DPU of 0.882 euro cent
summary: Cromwell E-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported an indicative distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.882 euro cents for the third quarter of 2020, up 5.8% quarter-over-quarter. Gross revenue grew 2.1% to 46.1 million euros, while net property income increased 14.3% to 30.6 million euros. The Reit's manager plans to increase portfolio exposure to light industrial and data-center assets, while divesting office and other assets.

site_title: Calmer waters: Biden's prospective foreign policy
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's foreign policy will differ from Donald Trump's in style, tone, and language, with a focus on consistency, stability, and calculability. The new administration will prioritize multilateralism, repairing alliances and relations with historical partners, and will invest in repairing damage done by Trump's unilateralist policy. Key changes include a return to international organisations such as the World Health Organization and Paris climate accord, and a more cautious approach to military interventions and trade liberalisation. Biden's approach will also aim to balance growing Chinese power by mobilising traditional allies in Europe and Asia.

site_title: FAA may lift 737 Max's grounding as early as next week
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is set to announce certification for Boeing's 737 Max to resume commercial service as early as November 18, potentially lifting the grounding that began in March 2019 after two crashes killed 346 people. The FAA is reviewing physical fixes, flight-control computer updates, and wiring improvements to ensure safety. Commercial flights are expected to begin around December 29, with American Airlines planning to start Max flights on the Miami-New York corridor. The move marks a major milestone for Boeing's recovery efforts, but the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel demand may limit the airline's ability to reap cash from deliveries.

site_title: Want to play La Parisienne? Here's how
summary: Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu, star of Netflix's Emily in Paris, discusses her portrayal of a French femme fatale, known as "the French bitch." Leroy-Beaulieu reveals that the character is a mix of fact and fiction, and that she drew inspiration from her mother, a designer, and her own experiences as a teenager in Paris. Despite facing ridicule for her accent and cultural differences, Leroy-Beaulieu says she identifies with the character's confidence and ambition. She notes that the series is not meant to be a realistic representation of Parisian women, but rather a caricature of the city's stereotypes.

site_title: Grab backs LinkAja in latest twist to e-wallet war against Gojek
summary: Grab gains a stake in LinkAja, an Indonesian e-wallet backed by state-owned enterprises, in a move against Gojek's GoPay. Grab is a minority investor in the Series B round valued at up to $100 million. This development escalates the e-wallet war between Grab and Gojek in Indonesia, with Grab aiming to counter Gojek's GoPay.

site_title: Positive vaccine news a shot in arm for aviation, tourism stocks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.67% on Tuesday, driven by gains in aviation and tourism stocks following positive news on Covid-19 vaccines. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines, SATS, and SIA Engineering jumped 12% on average, while glove and medical supply makers declined 13% on average. The vaccine news, combined with the US presidential election victory, lifted market sentiment, with shares of SIA soaring 14% and integrated resort operator Genting Singapore rising 6.5%. However, the recovery is expected to be cautious, with governments potentially keeping borders closed for international travel.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines, SATS and SIA Engineering which had averaged over 40 per cent decline for the year to Nov 9, averaged 12 per cent gains on Tuesday.

site_title: Redundancies in UK hit record high as job market slumps in Q3
summary: The UK job market experienced a record high in redundancies during Q3, with 314,000 workers made redundant, a 181,000 increase from the previous quarter. The unemployment rate rose to 4.8%, the highest since 2016. Employment fell by 164,000, exceeding expectations. The Bank of England forecasts unemployment to reach 6.3% by the end of the year and 7.7% in the second quarter of next year. Finance minister Rishi Sunak's support measures may have come too late to save jobs, according to economists.

site_title: 99 Group acquires real estate data provider SRX
summary: 99 Group, operator of 99.co, has acquired Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX) for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition is expected to widen the pool of listings, information, and data tools under 99 Group's umbrella. 99 Group will retain all SRX employees and integrate them into the team. The transaction is expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2021. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to meet evolving consumer needs in the digitalizing real estate industry.

site_title: Myanmar's army-backed party alleges 'contentious events' during election
summary: Myanmar's military-backed opposition party, the Union Solidity and Development Party, alleges "many contentious events" during the recent parliamentary election, which the ruling party claims it won by a landslide. The opposition leader, Than Htay, urged viewers to provide evidence of "illegal acts" without specifying incidents. The ruling party has yet to provide immediate evidence of violations, and the election outcome remains disputed.

site_title: Banks may soon tighten customer verification process amid rise in scams
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes that financial institutions (FIs) use additional information for non-face-to-face verification of customers' identities to combat rising impersonation scams. Proposed verification methods include at least one of the following: a government-issued ID number, date of birth, and other identifying details. The move aims to bolster consumer confidence and address risks of theft and misuse of personal particulars. The MAS also advises FIs to review their security controls and implement new measures to enhance cyber security amid the pandemic.

site_title: A logistical challenge like no other in history
summary: Singapore's strategic location makes it a critical link in the global distribution of the Covid-19 vaccine, but its cold chain capabilities are a concern due to its proximity to the equator. The country's logistics sector, led by Singapore Airlines Cargo, is well-equipped to handle temperature-sensitive goods, but maintaining a chain of custody and preventing counterfeits will require advanced technologies like blockchain and IoT. Singapore's ability to track vaccine distribution and storage will be crucial, and its infrastructure will need to be upgraded to support the vaccine's journey, from transportation to administration.

site_title: US: S&P 500 eases after vaccine news rally
summary: The S&P 500 decreased at the open on Tuesday, following excitement over a successful late-stage Covid-19 vaccine trial. Investors pulled money out of big tech companies, causing the Dow Jones Industrial Average to rise. The S&P 500 opened 0.20% lower, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.78%. The decline was attributed to fading excitement over the vaccine news and uncertainty surrounding the US economy.

site_title: US dollar slips after vaccine news boosts risk appetite
summary: The US dollar slipped slightly on Tuesday after a vaccine news boost initially boosted risk appetite, with investors shifting out of safe currencies like the Japanese yen and Swiss franc. The US dollar index was flat at 92.730, while the euro-dollar rose 0.1% to $1.18315. A large-scale clinical trial showed Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine to be over 90% effective, prompting a cautious reaction in the market. Analysts say the vaccine news is a positive step forward but also caution against excessive risk-taking.

site_title: Helping to shape the words of the President-Elect
summary: Jon Meacham, a presidential historian and biographer, is helping shape the words of President-elect Joe Biden by crafting speeches and offering edits on his campaign speeches. Meacham has been involved in writing drafts of Biden's acceptance speech, his speech in Gettysburg, and his acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention. Meacham's connection to Biden recalls historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s relationship with President John F. Kennedy. Meacham's role is seen as a way for Biden to use historical analogies and patriotic lore in his speeches, and he is well-suited for the task due to his moderate views and writing skills.

site_title: 8MRE pays S$26.4m for latest shophouse buys
summary: 8M Real Estate (8MRE) has acquired two shophouses in Singapore's Duxton Hill/Craig Road area for S$26.4 million. The properties, which have balance leasehold tenures of close to 68 years, were sold by entities linked to veteran property investor Stanley Quek. The acquisitions bring 8MRE's portfolio to nearly 60 properties, all in Singapore and predominantly conservation shophouses. Dr. Quek, who has divested most of his shophouses, plans to sell them to allow new investors to "enjoy and nurture" these heritage properties.

site_title: Keppel Land China divests Hill Crest Villas in Chengdu for 1.26b yuan
summary: Keppel Land China is divesting its 100% stake in Chengdu Hilltop Development Co Ltd for 1.26 billion yuan (S$250.4 million). The transaction is expected to earn the company a S$43 million divestment gain. The company will maintain its presence in China, particularly in the Chengdu metropolis, and regularly reviews its portfolio to seek higher returns.

site_title: S-E Asia's Internet growth to stay flat amid pandemic
summary: South-east Asia's internet economy is expected to reach $105 billion in gross merchandise value (GMV) this year, similar to 2019 levels, due to flat growth despite a surge in online shopping, entertainment consumption, and food delivery services. Singapore's digital economy contracted by 24% to $9 billion, while Vietnam and Indonesia experienced double-digit growth of 16% and 11% respectively. The report forecasts a slow recovery for the online travel industry, but expects other sectors like e-commerce, online media, and digital economies in Indonesia and Vietnam to grow.

site_title: Singapore in talks with Pfizer in quest for multiple vaccine sources
summary: Singapore is in talks with Pfizer to secure multiple COVID-19 vaccine sources, aiming to diversify its vaccine portfolio for different segments of the population. The government is also setting up a vaccine panel to assess the safety of vaccines and provide advice on vaccination strategy. Meanwhile, the country is implementing measures to increase COVID-19 testing accessibility and is requiring inbound travelers to undergo PCR testing before arrival. Singapore's economic reopening phase is contingent on achieving a higher TraceTogether participation rate and compliance with safe-distancing measures.

site_title: From Nov 17, travellers to Singapore from high-risk countries must take pre-departure Covid-19 PCR test
summary: Travellers from high-risk countries to Singapore will be required to take a pre-departure PCR Covid-19 test at least 72 hours before departure, starting November 17. This new requirement will also include a 14-day stay-home notice upon arrival and a test at the end of quarantine. The Health Ministry's new measure aims to strengthen Singapore's Covid-19 control measures.

site_title: Spotify agrees to buy Megaphone for US$235m
summary: Spotify Technology has agreed to acquire Megaphone, a podcast advertising platform, for US$235 million. The deal aims to expand Spotify's podcasting operations and advertising capabilities, valuing the acquisition at over US$800 million since the company's podcast acquisitions. Megaphone connects podcast publishers with networks of advertisers, and Spotify will use its tools to offer its advertising technology to thousands of additional podcasts, potentially justifying the investment in the still-nascent podcasting genre.

site_title: STI up 3.67% as investors pivot towards pandemic-hit sectors on vaccine hopes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.67% on Tuesday, its strongest session since April 7, driven by investors' optimism over vaccine news from drugmakers. The market saw a rotation from technology and medical equipment to broader sectors like financials, real estate, and industrials. Gainers outpaced losers 304 to 218, with 2.81 billion securities worth S$3.06 billion changing hands. The rally follows positive vaccine news, with investors seeking gains in pandemic-hit sectors.

site_title: Grab launches tech centre in Indonesia, its second headquarters
summary: Grab has launched a tech centre in Indonesia, its second headquarters, aimed at building tech solutions for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in South-east Asia. The centre will focus on digital and financial inclusion, enabling local tech talent development and contributing to Indonesia's economic recovery. Grab CEO Anthony Tan emphasized the firm's commitment to contributing to Indonesia's growth, with the tech centre set to invest in local talent and innovation.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to raise S$1.2b for US, Europe, Australia acquisitions
summary: Ascendas Reit has launched a private placement and preferential offering to raise S$1.2 billion, primarily for overseas acquisitions, including a US$560.2 million purchase of two office buildings in San Francisco. The funds will also finance a portfolio of data centres in Europe and a suburban office property in Australia. The total purchase price for the acquisitions is estimated at S$2 billion, with the US deal expected to take place in the current fiscal year, and expected to increase the Reit's exposure to the tech industry to 75 per cent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Shell Singapore plans to cut 500 jobs, approximately 38% of its local workforce, over the next three years as part of reorganisation efforts at its Pulau Bukom refinery. This move aims to adapt to changing market conditions and improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Formula One unveils biggest-ever 23-race calendar for 2021
summary: Formula One has unveiled its largest-ever 23-race calendar for 2021, starting in Australia on March 21. The season includes the first-ever race in Saudi Arabia on November 28, but the Vietnam event, originally scheduled for April, may not take place due to corruption charges against the event's supporters. The 23-race calendar marks the biggest season in Formula One history, surpassing the previous record of 22 races.

site_title: Oil prices rise on high hopes for vaccine
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, driven by high hopes for a Covid-19 vaccine, despite concerns over weakening fuel demand in coronavirus-hit countries. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 16 cents to $40.45 a barrel, while Brent crude futures increased 9 cents to $42.49 a barrel. Analysts predict a potential loss of one million barrels per day of oil demand in Europe by the end of the year, but a vaccine could mitigate this risk, according to JP Morgan.

site_title: Thai PM urges calm 'from all sides'
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha urged calm from all sides amid rising tensions between royalist groups and pro-democracy protesters demanding reforms to the monarchy. The protests, led by student leaders, have led to counter-protests by monarchist groups, resulting in minor scuffles. The kingdom has seen months of massive demonstrations calling for democratic reforms, sparking a backlash from the royalist establishment.

site_title: China turns up heat on Internet giants with antitrust rules
summary: China has introduced detailed regulations to curb monopolistic practices in the internet industry, targeting companies like Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings. The regulations aim to prevent anti-competitive behavior, including data sharing, alliances, and subsidizing services to eliminate competitors. The move follows heightened scrutiny of global tech giants and growing concerns over the influence of a handful of Chinese tech corporations. The regulations, proposed in accordance with China's Anti-Monopoly Law, will seek public feedback until November 30.

site_title: Box shipping is doing well despite Covid-19, but for how long?
summary: Container shipping companies have defied expectations, maintaining and even increasing rates despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. According to Xeneta's Shipping Index report, October saw a 1.3% increase in rates, with long-term contracted rates up 1.2% year-on-year. Carriers have successfully managed capacity, withdrawing tonnage when necessary, and shippers are facing increasingly difficult tenders. Analysts predict further rate increases in the contract market, with Maersk raising its EBITDA forecast to $7.5-8 billion. The industry's ability to balance supply and demand may bring financial sustainability.

site_title: Biden tightens claim on White House
summary: President-elect Joe Biden is moving forward with the transition to the White House, naming his coronavirus task force and planning to speak on the Affordable Care Act. Despite President Donald Trump's claims of election fraud, Biden has secured 290 Electoral College votes, surpassing the 270 needed for election victory. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has given Trump cover to pursue legal challenges, but only four Republican Senators have publicly acknowledged Biden's victory. Biden is also tackling the coronavirus pandemic, announcing a 13-member advisory council and urging Americans to wear masks and practice social distancing.

site_title: US results augur well for Asian equities
summary: The US election outcome has led to a more favorable environment for Asian equities, with Democrats' planned tax hikes and regulatory curbs unlikely to proceed. A Republican-led Senate may act as a brake on increased regulation, limiting negative impacts on corporate America. Historically, the US equity market has performed well when no party dominates all three branches of government, with a Democratic President and a split Congress delivering strong returns. The expected lower interest rates and bond yields due to a reduced fiscal stimulus also support Asian equity markets, particularly China and Singapore.

site_title: UK airports want immediate progress on testing, vaccine or not
summary: UK airports are urging the government to make immediate progress on Covid-19 testing for arriving passengers, citing the need for travel to resume safely. The UK's slow testing pace has put airports at risk of 100,000 jobs, with many already lost. Despite a promising Pfizer vaccine, airports need testing to be prioritized in the short to medium term. Industry leaders, including Heathrow CEO John Holland-Kaye and Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham, are criticizing the government's lack of urgency and support for the aviation industry.

site_title: Malaysia starts LNG bunkering operations; makes first delivery
summary: Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas has launched LNG bunkering operations, making its first delivery in Johor on Monday. The maiden operation supplied 1,150 tonnes of LNG to a vessel at Pasir Gudang port. This marks Malaysia as one of the few countries offering LNG bunkering services to the marine industry in the east. With an estimated market value of RM2 billion, Malaysia's bunkering services market is expected to be significantly larger than Singapore's, positioning the country as a major player in the LNG bunkering industry.

site_title: S-Reits' acquisition blitz set to hit S$10b in 2020 despite Covid-19
summary: S-Reits in Singapore are expected to reach a total acquisition value of S$10 billion in 2020, driven by low interest rates and increased debt capacity. Since July, S-Reits have announced S$7.3 billion in acquisitions, surpassing the S$1.4 billion in the first half of the year. Some managers prioritize income stability over DPU accretion, while others focus on diversification. The market is expected to continue its buying spree, with NTT DC Reit's public offer being oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Why punish corporations for their employees' crimes?
summary: The concept of punishing corporations for the crimes committed by their employees dates back to medieval times, where inanimate objects or animals causing death were forfeited to authorities. However, this practice seems absurd in modern times. Corporations, viewed as "deodands," can neither form criminal intent nor bear punishment, leading to punishment being borne by stockholders and employees. This system creates moral hazard and inefficiency, as employees may misbehave if they believe they can be punished. The justice system often prefers to impose penalties on corporations rather than individual employees, citing ease of prosecution and juror appeal.

site_title: EU charges Amazon with distorting online retail competition
summary: The European Commission charged Amazon with distorting online retail competition, opening a second investigation into its business practices. The charge stems from complaints about Amazon's dual role as a marketplace for merchants and rival seller, as well as its use of merchant data to select winners for the "buy box". This move targets Amazon's practices, similar to previous actions taken against US technology giant Google. The investigation is led by antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager, who has also targeted Google in the past.

site_title: Summit season starts as leaders dial in to Asean, Apec, G-20 meets
summary: World leaders are convening for a series of virtual summits in Vietnam, Malaysia, and Saudi Arabia over the next fortnight. The Asean, Apec, and G-20 summits will focus on the COVID-19 pandemic, global economy, and trade. Asean leaders will adopt the Asean Comprehensive Recovery Framework, while the Apec summit will launch the region's Post-2020 Vision. The G-20 summit will focus on economic stability and sustainable development. The summits mark a return to virtual meetings due to the pandemic, with leaders set to deliver speeches and carry out discussions via video-link.

site_title: Nearly US$2t traded on Covid-19 vaccine news
summary: A breakthrough in the Covid-19 vaccine race sparked a trading surge, with nearly US$2 trillion in trades on Monday, according to Reuters data. Traders flocked to riskier assets, such as equities and foreign exchange, while avoiding safe havens like technology stocks and bonds. The positive data release by Pfizer Inc led to a surge in volumes in sectors like airlines and banking.

site_title: Norwegian Air says it could run out of cash in early 2021
summary: Norwegian Air, a pandemic-hit budget carrier, warned it could run out of cash in early 2021 unless it secures fresh funding. The airline's cash and cash equivalents decreased to 3.4 billion Norwegian crowns (S$503.8 million) at the end of September, down from 4.98 billion crowns at the end of June. Norwegian Air plans to furlough 1,600 more staff, leaving 600 people working, down from 10,000 pre-pandemic levels. The company's CEO stated that the effects of the global Covid-19 pandemic continue to heavily impact its operations and financial position.

site_title: Germany expects EU to sign supply deal for BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine soon
summary: Germany's Health Minister Jens Spahn expects the European Commission to sign a purchase agreement with BioNTech-Pfizer for their potential Covid-19 vaccine in the coming days. The deal is for 200 million doses with an option to buy 100 million more. Germany is expected to receive up to 100 million doses. The vaccine has shown a 90% effectiveness rate, a major breakthrough in the fight against the virus.
