site_title: DoctorxDentist to delist doctors after clash with Singapore Medical Association
summary: DoctorxDentist, a Singapore-based online platform, will remove the listings of doctors who requested to have their profiles taken down following a dispute with the Singapore Medical Association (SMA). The SMA had collated a list of doctors who did not want to be associated with the platform, after some association members complained that the company refused to take down their profiles despite requests. This move comes after the startup was criticized for not consenting to doctors accepting appointments through its website.

site_title: First Reit Q3 DPU down 53% to 1.01 Singapore cents
summary: First Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 53% to 1.01 Singapore cents for the third fiscal quarter, down from 2.15 cents a year ago. The Reit's DPU for the first nine months of the year decreased 48.7% to 3.31 cents, primarily due to lower management fees and a one-month rental relief for Indonesian tenants. Distributable income fell 52.3% to S$8.2 million.

site_title: Singapore's Scorpio Electric raises US$6.3m to develop electric motorcycle
summary: Singapore's Scorpio Electric raises US$6.3 million to develop its first electric motorcycle, with plans to launch next year. The startup will use the funds for software and hardware development, as well as building its headquarters and assembly plant. The motorcycle is expected to feature artificial intelligence and data analytics for increased energy efficiency, targeting the South-east Asian market with a goal of producing up to 8,000 units annually.

site_title: E-scooter startup Tier raises US$250m to expand, build charging network
summary: Tier Mobility, a Berlin-based e-scooter startup, has raised $250 million in funding to expand operations to more cities and launch its own charging network. The Series C funding, led by SoftBank Group's Vision Fund 2, aims to support emissions-free urban mobility. This investment follows concerns over kick scooter startups contributing to urban congestion and the gig economy. Tier plans to build a charging network to mitigate these issues and promote sustainable transportation.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang H1 net profit rises 11% to S$73.7m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 11% increase in net profit to S$73.7 million for the first half of its financial year, driven by higher earnings per share. Revenue rose 2% to S$223.3 million, but gross profit fell 2% due to higher cost of sales. The company booked S$881,000 in other income from government grants and recorded a net cash inflow of S$174.7 million. Despite the uncertainty in the global economy, Bukit Sembawang plans to launch new residential projects, including The Atelier and LIV@MB condominium.

site_title: Those who need a Covid-19 test can get it from 600 approved providers, says Gan
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong announced that individuals requiring Covid-19 tests can access them from 600 approved providers, eliminating the need for approval from the Ministry of Health. Inbound travelers from high-risk countries must take a PCR test within 72 hours of departure. Meanwhile, Singapore has established an expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination to advise on vaccine safety and effectiveness, with a vaccine potentially available by early 2021. The country's reopening to Phase Three depends on TraceTogether participation rates and safe-distancing measures.

site_title: South Korea confirms H5N8 bird flu in wild birds, issues warning
summary: South Korea's agriculture ministry confirmed the presence of the highly pathogenic H5N8 bird flu strain in wild birds in the central west of the country. The virus was discovered in samples collected last week in Cheonan-si, Chungcheongnam-do, near Seoul. To contain the spread, the ministry has increased prevention measures and issued a highly pathogenic avian influenza warning, citing increased risks of the virus spreading.

site_title: How to find winning stocks in an uncertain recovery
summary: Singapore is poised to enter Phase 3 of its reopening, but the recovery will be uncertain due to ongoing Covid-19 safety measures. Investors should look for companies that benefited from the pandemic, such as Zoom Video Conferencing and PayPal, which have the opportunity to further monetize their user bases. Companies like Chipotle Mexican Grill, which adapted to digital sales, have also shown resilience. However, it's essential to focus on long-term growth and be prepared for unexpected events, as the road to full recovery may be long.

site_title: Shell Singapore to cut 500 jobs over three years amid Pulau Bukom reorganisation
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's Singapore subsidiary is cutting 500 jobs, approximately 38% of its Pulau Bukom refinery staff, over three years as part of a reorganisation. The staff reduction will be phased, with 1,300 employees dwindling to 1,100 by the end of 2021 and further to 800 by 2023. The earliest staff movement is set for the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up at the start of trading
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, following gains the previous session driven by hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and Joe Biden's US election victory. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices added 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. These gains follow a 5.0% and 7.6% increase in London and Paris on Monday.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as vaccine hopes lift energy, travel stocks
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth straight session, driven by hopes of a swifter global economic recovery after a Covid-19 vaccine showed 90% effectiveness in preventing the virus. Energy and travel stocks surged, with Flight Centre and Qantas rising over 8% each, while heavyweight financial stocks reached their highest levels since June. However, tech and consumer stocks dropped over 3% as investors shifted out of these sectors.

site_title: Offering discounts galore, Alibaba launches China's first post-Covid Singles' Day
summary: Alibaba launched China's first post-Covid Singles' Day event with discounts, amid a rebounding economy and after losing almost $76 billion in market value following China's suspension of the Ant Group listing. The online shopping extravaganza, which includes a livestream appearance by pop star Katy Perry, aims to capitalize on consumers' desire for deals. The event comes a week after Alibaba's market value slump, but will likely boost sales and help the company recover.

site_title: Bugis Street, Mustafa Centre, Jurong Point and Kitchener Complex among new places visited by infectious Covid-19 cases
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore announced nine new COVID-19 cases, including one community case, a 25-year-old Malaysian national who developed symptoms after working as a cleaner. The patient visited various locations, including Bugis Street, Mustafa Centre, and Kitchener Complex, while infectious, but no close contacts need to be notified as they would have been cleaned and monitored. The cases are largely imported, with seven out of nine being foreign nationals.

site_title: BOJ unveils scheme incentivising regional bank consolidation
summary: The Bank of Japan unveiled a scheme to incentivize regional bank consolidation, aiming to revitalize regional economies. The central bank will offer 0.1% interest on current account balances held by participating lenders. Regional lenders that opt for mergers or business integration will receive 3-year remuneration. The move follows growing concerns over the health of Japan's banking system, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and low interest rates.

site_title: UK property group LandSec's losses soar on pandemic hit
summary: UK property group LandSec reported a significant loss of over $1 billion in the first half of 2020 due to pandemic-hit businesses holding back rental payments. Like-for-like net rental income declined 10% and the company set aside an additional $154.7 million for bad debts. Despite the challenges, LandSec expressed optimism about its London portfolio, citing robust interest in high-quality office assets. The company plans to reinvest in its London portfolio and reduce its exposure to retail.

site_title: UK's Premier Foods raises profit outlook again as lockdown drives demand
summary: Premier Foods, the UK-based food manufacturer, raised its full-year trading profit outlook for the second time due to increased demand for its brands during the pandemic. Trading profit rose 28.7% to £65.8 million (S$116.80 million) for the 26 weeks ended Sept 26, driven by more people cooking at home during lockdowns. The company expects continued revenue growth in the second half, driven by new products and increased TV marketing, and may return to paying dividends.

site_title: Philippines turns corner in Q3 but recovery may be slow: economists
summary: The Philippines' economy may have turned the corner in the third quarter with a 11.5% year-on-year GDP fall, but growth momentum is expected to remain weak due to weak overseas remittances and high unemployment. Economists predict a subdued domestic demand recovery and export growth hindered by the Covid-19 resurgence in the US and Europe. This may result in a full-year growth of -9.5% in 2020, with economists maintaining a 2021 full-year growth estimate of 7%.

site_title: Softbank leads US$250m investment in e-scooter firm Tier Mobility
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund 2 led a $250 million investment in Tier Mobility, a Berlin-based e-scooter company, valuing it below $1 billion. Existing investors also participated in the Series C funding round. The funding will be used to expand into new micromobility vehicles and build out its charging network. With this investment, Tier Mobility overtook Lime to become the second-most valuable e-scooter company, behind Bird.

site_title: US Covid-19 hospitalisations surge to record of just over 59,000 patients
summary: US Covid-19 hospitalizations reached a record high of 59,008 patients on November 9, surpassing the previous high of 58,370 on July 22. This surge is 73% higher than 30 days ago, with Texas, Illinois, and California reporting the highest numbers of hospitalized patients. New infections exceeded 100,000 for the sixth consecutive day, and the death toll rose 15% over the previous week, taking the total to over 238,000.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with more big gains
summary: Hong Kong shares ended with a 1.1% gain on Tuesday, driven by global market surges after Pfizer's 90% successful vaccine trials. The Hang Seng Index rose 285.31 points to 26,301.48. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.4% and 1.1%, respectively. The gains followed positive market trends globally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Shiseido cuts outlook as prolonged pandemic hits cosmetics sales
summary: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics maker, has lowered its full-year outlook due to the prolonged pandemic's impact on sales. The company expects a net loss of 30 billion yen (S$385.61 million) and aims to cut costs to minimize operating losses. Sales in Japan, its key market, fell 32% year-on-year in the nine months ended September, but China's sales declined only 2%. Shiseido plans to clear inventory in Japan and restructure its US business.

site_title: Grab leads Series B round of up to US$100m into Indonesian e-wallet LinkAja
summary: Grab is leading a Series B round of up to US$100 million in investments into Indonesian e-wallet LinkAja, marking a new twist in the e-wallet war between rivals Grab and Gojek. The investment, joined by Indonesian heavyweights Telkomsel, BRI Ventures, and Mandiri Capital Indonesia, aims to accelerate financial inclusion in Indonesia. LinkAja has seen significant growth, with a threefold increase in Gross Transaction Value and transactions in Q3, and plans to leverage Grab's ecosystem and technology expertise to strengthen its services.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics organisers hail vaccine news as 'relief'
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers have expressed relief over news of a 90% effective coronavirus vaccine, but insisted their bio-security planning remains unchanged. The organising committee has focused on testing, social distancing, and athlete cooperation, with a successful vaccine seen as a significant factor in staging the postponed Games. The news comes after a successful international sporting event in Tokyo, which showcased the feasibility of the Games despite the pandemic. The International Olympic Committee has also welcomed the vaccine news, with the chief stating that sports can be organised safely under ongoing health restrictions.

site_title: Propelled by aviation, tourism plays, Singapore stocks soar higher; STI jumps 2.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surged 2.9% or 76.5 points to 2,685.89, driven by strong gains in aviation and tourism stocks, including Singapore Airlines, SATS, and Genting Singapore, amid positive news on a Covid-19 vaccine's effectiveness. The rally follows a rotation trade favoring cyclical value stocks, with analysts expecting the vaccine's implementation to take months. Other regional markets also saw gains, while beaten-down stocks in the aviation and tourism sector rebounded.

site_title: China turns up heat on Internet giants with new antitrust rules
summary: China has introduced new antitrust regulations targeting internet giants, including Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings, to curb monopolistic practices and anti-competitive behavior. The regulations aim to restrict data sharing, alliances that squeeze out smaller rivals, and subsidizing services below cost. The State Administration of Market Regulation will seek public feedback until November 30. The move follows heightened scrutiny of tech companies worldwide and comes as consumers in China protest against the erosion of their privacy. The regulations are part of China's Anti-Monopoly Law, which was introduced in January.

site_title: Adidas cautious for year end as pandemic returns
summary: Adidas predicts a sales decline similar to the third quarter, despite a return to growth in China's fourth quarter, driven by a resurgence of the pandemic. The company reported a 3% sales decline in the third quarter to 5.96 billion euros, with operating profit falling 12% to 794 million euros. E-commerce sales jumped 51% in the third quarter. Adidas expects a similar sales decline in the fourth quarter if over 90% of stores stay open, but predicts a return to growth in greater China.

site_title: Jack Ma's botched Ant IPO becomes a boost for state banks
summary: China's new regulations that derailed Ant Group's massive IPO have boosted state-backed lenders, particularly China Merchants Bank. The regulations aim to curb the rapid growth and leverage of micro-loan lenders, favoring traditional banks. China Merchants Bank has soared 19% in Hong Kong, its biggest seven-day advance in over five years, while other Chinese lenders gained. The regulations raise the bar for Ant and other online lenders, forcing them to set aside more capital and assume more risk, similar to standards already imposed on firms like China Merchants Bank.

site_title: SingHaiyi narrows half-year net loss with boost from Parc Clematis sales
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a narrowed net loss of S$4.6 million for the April-September period, down from a year-ago loss of S$12.8 million. Revenue almost quadrupled to S$50.6 million, driven by S$44.8 million in sales from the Parc Clematis condominium in Clementi. The group has sold 990 units of Parc Clematis and expects progressive revenue from three residential projects. However, gross profit margin shrank by 16.2 percentage points due to a change in geographical revenue mix.

site_title: Malaysia starts LNG bunkering operations, makes first delivery
summary: Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas has started LNG bunkering operations, making its first delivery of 1,150 tonnes of LNG to a vessel at the Pasir Gudang port. This move positions Malaysia as a key player in the LNG bunkering industry in the East, with the country's bunkering services market valued at RM2 billion. Petronas has been developing the necessary infrastructure since 2017, and the Avenir Advantage vessel will provide LNG bunkering services to international and domestic vessels passing through the Strait of Malacca.

site_title: Huawei to sell 100b yuan Honor unit to Shenzhen government, Digital China, others: sources
summary: Huawei plans to sell its budget-brand smartphone unit Honor to a consortium led by Digital China and the Shenzhen government in a 100 billion yuan (S$20.5 billion) deal. The sale, which could be announced as early as Sunday, includes almost all assets, including brand, research & development capabilities, and supply chain management. The deal will allow Honor to retain its management team and workforce, with plans to go public within three years. The move comes as US restrictions on Huawei force the company to focus on high-end handsets and corporate-oriented business.

site_title: India's Modi facing tough battle in first vote since pandemic
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party is facing a tough battle to retain control of the eastern state of Bihar, with the opposition alliance led by Tejashwi Yadav ahead in 100 seats. Most exit polls have shown citizens rejecting the ruling coalition, which could be a setback for Modi. Losing Bihar would be a significant blow, especially with the state's large population and significant influence on federal politics. The outcome may also raise questions about Modi's handling of the pandemic and his economic policies.

site_title: Blocking Taiwan at WHO will increase hostility to China, premier says
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang stated that China's efforts to block Taiwan's participation at the World Health Organization (WHO) will increase global hostility towards the country. Despite the WHO's claim that Taiwan cooperates with them on health matters, China's objections have created a gap in pandemic prevention. Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly (WHA) was rejected by member countries, with many countries supporting the island's inclusion. Su Tseng-chang warned that China's actions will only cause more countries to condemn them, further isolating the country.

site_title: Johnson presses on with Brexit law-break plan after Lords defeat
summary: The UK's House of Lords rejected key parts of the Internal Market Bill, which would have allowed the government to unilaterally rewrite parts of the Withdrawal Agreement with the EU. Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed to push ahead with the legislation, despite EU legal action. The bill's removal does not block it, and Johnson's office stated that the clauses will be reinstated when the draft law returns to the House of Commons. The move has raised concerns about the UK's commitment to international law and its impact on trade negotiations with the EU.

images.alt_text: The UK's House of Lords rejected government plans to break international law over Brexit, putting the onus back on Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who immediately vowed to push ahead with the legislation.

site_title: Electrifying growth of renewables despite pandemic
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that renewable energy growth has continued at a record pace despite the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2025, renewables are expected to become the largest source of electricity generation, surpassing natural gas and coal. The global electricity generated by renewables is set to increase by 7% in 2020, with a record 200 gigawatts of new capacity added this year. The IEA expects renewables to supply one-third of the world's electricity and double China's power capacity by then.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rally for seventh day on Covid-19 vaccine hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a seventh consecutive day, driven by hopes of a coronavirus vaccine's impact on global economic recovery. Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine showed a 90% effectiveness rate in a clinical trial, boosting risk appetite. Airlines and travel-related shares surged, while test kit makers and vaccine makers declined. The benchmark Kospi closed 0.23% higher at 2,452.83, with foreigners purchasing 156.6 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened, while bond yields rose, marking a positive trend in the market.

site_title: Singaporeans expect travel resumption by H2 2021 but remain cautious amid Covid-19: poll
summary: Singaporeans expect international travel to resume by the second half of 2021, with 81% of respondents anticipating a full recovery by mid-2021. However, they remain cautious, with 74% describing their behavior towards the pandemic as "highly cautious." In contrast, Vietnamese respondents are more eager to travel, with 54% saying they want to take a leisure trip soon. Despite optimism, 43% of Singaporeans plan to fly less in the future, and 60% of Asia-Pacific passengers expect to feel "fully ready to fly" within the next year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on vaccine news
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.26% to 24,905.59, and the Topix index climbing 1.12% to 1,700.80. The gains were driven by news that a coronavirus vaccine showed 90% effectiveness, offering hope for the economy's return to normal. Airlines and automakers surged, with Japan Airlines and Honda rising 21.20% and 3.31% respectively, while gaming companies fell after the possibility of an end to lockdowns.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane ask Sabana Reit's manager to convene EGM
summary: Sabana Reit managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital have requisitioned the board of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) due to concerns over the proposed merger with ESR-Reit. The two fund managers, which collectively hold over 11% of Sabana Reit, have proposed five resolutions to be voted upon by unitholders, including calls for clarification on declarations made by an independent non-executive director and disclosure of potential conflicts of interest. The proposed merger has been met with opposition from the managers.

site_title: Global sukuk issuance to decline slightly in 2020, says Moody's
summary: Global sukuk issuance is expected to decline slightly in 2020, reaching US$170 billion, down from US$179 billion in 2019, according to Moody's. The decline can be attributed to lower issuance activity in the first half of the year, partly due to the pandemic. However, sovereign issuance of shariah-compliant debt remained stable despite fiscal deficits caused by lower oil prices and spending related to the pandemic. The global sukuk market has grown rapidly over the past four years, supported by large pools of sharia-compliant funds in the Gulf.

site_title: China's Oct PPI falls faster than expected
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) fell 2.1% in October, missing expectations of a 2.0% decline, indicating a fragile economic recovery. Consumer inflation eased to its slowest pace since 2009, with a 0.5% year-on-year rise. The data suggests policymakers face pressure to maintain economic stability as growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Japan PM Suga instructs cabinet to compile new stimulus package
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga instructed his cabinet to compile a new stimulus package to revitalize the economy hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The package aims to cushion the blow, assist structural changes, and boost productivity through digitalization, with a focus on shifting to a "green" society. The size of the package has not been decided, but ruling party lawmakers have called for between 10 trillion yen and 30 trillion yen. Japan's economy is expected to have rebounded in the third quarter after posting a record postwar contraction.

site_title: UK redundancies hit record high as job market slumps in Q3
summary: The UK job market experienced a record high in redundancies, with 314,000 staff made redundant in the third quarter, a 181,000 increase from the second quarter. The unemployment rate rose to 4.8%, the highest since November 2016. The Bank of England forecasts unemployment to reach 6.3% by the end of the year and 7.7% in the second quarter of next year. Finance minister Rishi Sunak extended the furlough scheme until March and announced billions of pounds in support, but critics argue U-turns on employment policy hindered planning.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volumes rise 21.6% in October: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale volumes surged 21.6% in October, reaching 1,509 units, the highest level since May 2018. Demand is on the rise, with healthy demand for homes signaling recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Resale prices rose 0.8% month-over-month and 0.7% year-over-year, with the core central region (CCR) seeing a 2.9% drop. Experts attribute the surge to buyers entering the market, sensing the worst is over, and the gradually recovering economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend global rally on vaccine hope
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday as a 90% effective vaccine candidate was announced, fuelling hopes of a vaccine rollout this year and an end to the pandemic. Stocks soared, with airlines like Japan Airlines and Qantas jumping over 20% and 9% respectively, while tech firms retreated. Oil prices dipped, and safe-haven assets fell. Investors are optimistic about a "return to normality" and a potential boost to the global economy, despite concerns about a potential smaller US stimulus package.

site_title: MAS proposes new identity verification process as impersonation scams jump
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes a new identity verification process for financial institutions to combat rising impersonation scams. The proposed process requires at least one of four types of information for non-face-to-face verification, including passwords, biometrics, or unique account transaction information. The move aims to bolster consumer confidence in financial institutions and address the risks of theft and misuse of personal particulars. MAS also urges financial institutions to review their security controls and enhance cybersecurity measures amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tuan Sing inks sale and purchase agreement for Robinson Point divestment
summary: TUAN Sing Holdings has signed a sale and purchase agreement for the divestment of Robinson Point, a freehold office tower in Singapore, to One South Bay Group for S$500 million. The transaction, expected to be completed by end-June 2021, will strengthen the company's balance sheet and enable strategic acquisitions. The agreed property value is subject to adjustments based on the net asset value of the target company. Tuan Sing shareholders' approval is required for the deal, which is classified as a major transaction.

site_title: 99.co parent acquires real estate data provider SRX
summary: 99 Group, the parent company of property portal 99.co, has acquired real estate data provider SRX for an undisclosed sum. As part of the deal, 99 Group will acquire Streetsine Singapore, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, and retain all SRX employees. The acquisition aims to create a wider pool of listings, information, and data tools, enabling 99 Group to offer better value to consumers and real estate professionals in Singapore. The transaction is expected to complete by the second quarter of 2021.

site_title: Philippines economy contracts 11.5% y-o-y in Q3
summary: The Philippine economy contracted 11.5% in Q3, exceeding expectations, as the country continued to feel the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. This marks the first time the economy fell into recession in nearly 30 years, with a revised contraction of 16.9% in Q2. The country's GDP shrinkage was higher than the forecasted 9.8% contraction.

site_title: Gold firms as stimulus hopes, virus woes support appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 1% to $1,880.41 per ounce, driven by hopes of US stimulus measures to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, making it an inflation hedge. The price increase came after Pfizer announced a 90% effective Covid-19 vaccine, but uncertainties over the impact of surging cases in the US and Europe remained. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with silver up 0.5%, platinum 0.4%, and palladium 0.6%. Central banks are unlikely to change their accommodative stance in the near term, supporting gold prices.

site_title: Trump refuses to concede, Biden leads on Covid-19
summary: President Donald Trump refuses to concede the election, firing his defense secretary and blocking cooperation with President-elect Joe Biden's team. Biden, meanwhile, focuses on leading the country out of the Covid-19 crisis, announcing a new task force and urging Americans to wear masks. Official election results show Biden with a convincing lead, and the Trump administration's refusal to cooperate with the transition process raises concerns about a chaotic transition period.

site_title: 'Lockdown' is Collins Dictionary word of the year
summary: Collins Dictionary has named "lockdown" its 2020 word of the year, citing its widespread usage during the COVID-19 pandemic. The term saw a 25,000% increase in usage, surpassing 250,000 occurrences. The dictionary also recognized six other words related to the pandemic, including "coronavirus," "social distancing," and "key worker." The selections reflect the global health crisis and its impact on language.

site_title: US still faces possible default wave, asset declines due to pandemic: Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve warns of a possible wave of debt defaults and significant declines in asset prices due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and recession. Despite recent economic recovery efforts, loan defaults may rise, and businesses may struggle to service their obligations. Asset prices remain vulnerable to significant declines if investor risk sentiment falls or the economic recovery weakens. The Fed notes that government lending and relief programs have mitigated strains on the business and household sectors, but the risk of default and asset declines persists if the pandemic worsens.

site_title: US court suspends key permits for Equitrans Mountain Valley pipeline
summary: A US federal appeals court has issued a stay of key permits for the 300-mile Mountain Valley natural gas pipeline in two states, citing environmental concerns. The pipeline, which could cost up to $6 billion, was challenged by seven environmental groups. The stay will remain in effect until the 4th Circuit Court of Appeals rules on the groups' petition to overturn the water permits. Environmental groups welcomed the decision, while Equitrans expressed disappointment, stating it would continue work on unaffected parts of the project.

site_title: Australian business confidence jumps to 1-1/2 year highs
summary: Australian business confidence jumped to its highest level since mid-2019 in October, reaching +5, according to National Australia Bank's index. Conditions also improved, with the conditions index rising to +1, driven by a rise in trading and profitability. However, the employment index and forward orders remained in negative territory, suggesting monetary policy will continue to be stimulatory. The improvement in confidence and conditions is seen as fragile until a COVID-19 vaccine is available.

images.alt_text: A measure of Australian business confidence jumped to the highest since mid-2019 in October, though the employment index and forward orders stayed in negative territory, suggesting monetary policy will remain stimulatory for some while yet.

site_title: Electric-truck startup Nikola says talks with GM ongoing
summary: Nikola Corp, an electric-truck startup, is in ongoing talks with General Motors Co to discuss a potential strategic partnership. The deal, announced in September, would give GM an 11% stake in Nikola in exchange for providing battery and hydrogen-fuel cell technology. Despite a Dec 3 deadline, talks continue amid federal regulatory probes and allegations of deception. CEO Mark Russell stated the company has a "base plan" to proceed with its business model, and the deal may slip into early 2021.

site_title: Britain unveils green plan for post-Brexit finance
summary: Britain has unveiled a green plan to help it reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050, including a sovereign green bond to fund environmental projects and a rule requiring companies to disclose the impact of climate change. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak said the plan will help retain Britain's role as a premier global financial hub and aid economic recovery from the coronavirus fallout. The plan also aims to extend the UK's global leadership in green finance ahead of hosting COP26, the UN's global climate change summit in Glasgow next year.

site_title: Singapore could have a Covid-19 vaccine by early 2021
summary: Singapore is expected to receive its first Covid-19 vaccine shipments by early 2021, with the vaccine co-developed by Singapore researchers and Arcturus Therapeutics showing positive preliminary results from early-stage clinical trials. The vaccine, which could be effective as a single dose, has been manufactured with a US$45 million investment from Singapore's Economic Development Board. Preliminary findings indicate a strong immune response, with no serious adverse events reported. The vaccine's development comes as the global race to a Covid-19 vaccine heats up, with Pfizer and BioNTech announcing a 90% effective vaccine earlier this week.

site_title: New Xbox hits stores, launching holiday season console war
summary: Microsoft's new Xbox Series X console launched worldwide on Tuesday, kicking off the holiday season gaming season, competing directly with Sony's PlayStation 5. The pandemic has boosted gaming demand, with many consumers seeking distraction during lockdowns. The Xbox Series X features a faster graphics processor and 8K video capabilities, with a premium version priced at $499 and a digital-only "mini" version priced at $299. Analysts expect high demand for the consoles, with some expecting excess demand to last for several months.

site_title: Unicorn funding drops from 2018 high; strong growth for early-stage deals
summary: Funding for unicorns in South-east Asia has declined by 41.2% to $3 billion in the first half of 2020, down from a 2018 high. The decline is attributed to investors shying away from heavy cash-consuming businesses as sectors mature. However, non-unicorn investments have seen strong growth, with early-stage funding making up over 95% of yearly deal transactions. Investors are now focusing on profit levers and budding sectors like fintech, edtech, and healthtech, which are expected to continue growing in the coming years.

site_title: Big Tech welcomes Biden presidency, but battles loom
summary: Big Tech companies welcomed Joe Biden's presidency, but tensions remain over tech policy. Despite praise from key tech leaders, lawmakers and policymakers are expected to scrutinize tech giants over antitrust enforcement, social media regulation, and immigration. Potential battles include breaking up large tech firms, regulating internet liability and online privacy, and reversing Trump-era visa restrictions. Biden's administration is likely to support net neutrality, European-style privacy legislation, and trade with China, but faces challenges from a Republican Senate majority.

site_title: Ski industry faces steep slope with virus, warming
summary: The European ski industry is struggling to adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic and climate change, with the Alps generating 34 billion euros in revenue. The industry is heavily reliant on seasonal labor and is vulnerable to lockdowns, with a 20% drop in visitors during the 2020 pandemic. Climate change is also a concern, with melting glaciers and rising temperatures affecting snow conditions. The industry is taking steps to become more sustainable, with some resorts aiming to become carbon neutral by 2037. Additionally, the aging of the baby boomer generation is also affecting the industry, with younger generations showing less interest in skiing.

site_title: UK retailers enjoy a bit of growth before lockdown strikes
summary: UK retailers experienced a 5.2% increase in October sales on a like-for-like basis, driven by shoppers stockpiling food and home supplies before a second lockdown. Online sales surged 40% and contributed to 45% of total retail spending. However, the new lockdown will likely halt gains, with the British Retail Consortium estimating £2 billion in lost sales per week. Consumer spending slipped 0.1% overall, but sales on essential items and takeaways increased.

site_title: Brazil suspends trials of China's Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine due to 'adverse effect'
summary: Brazil's health regulator Anvisa has suspended trials of China's Sinovac Covid-19 vaccine due to a "severe adverse effect" that occurred on October 29, but did not provide further details. The decision was made despite the head of the medical research institute Butantan stating that the incident was unrelated to the vaccine and that it's not the right time to interrupt trials. No other country conducting Sinovac trials has announced a suspension, and late-stage trials are also being conducted in Indonesia and Turkey.

site_title: Oman seeks to raise billions by leveraging biggest oil block
summary: Oman plans to transfer its 60% stake in Block 6, a 650,000-barrel-per-day oil block, to a new company to raise billions of dollars without putting it on the government's books. The new firm may sell $3 billion of bonds in the first half of 2021, setting a precedent for other oil and gas producers in the Middle East. Oman's budget deficit is forecast to reach 19% of GDP this year, and the economy is expected to contract 10%. The move is part of the government's efforts to tame its budget deficit and steady the economy.

site_title: South-east Asia's Internet economy on track to pass US$300b by 2025: report
summary: South-east Asia's internet economy is projected to reach $300 billion by 2025, according to a report by Google, Temasek, and Bain & Co. Despite the pandemic, the region's internet economy remains on track, with sectors like e-commerce, payments, and online media experiencing accelerated growth. E-commerce is expected to reach $172 billion by 2025, with a 23% compounded annual growth rate. The report also notes that consumers have shifted towards online transactions, with a 25% increase in e-wallet transactions and a decline in cash transactions.

site_title: Ascendas Reit seeks to raise S$1.2b, plans US$560.2m purchase of office buildings
summary: Ascendas Reit is launching a private placement and preferential offering to raise S$1.2 billion, with S$800 million from institutional investors and S$400 million from unitholders. The trust plans to use the funds for a US$560.2 million purchase of two office buildings in San Francisco, partially funding a portfolio of data centers in Europe and a suburban office property in Australia. The acquisition will increase Ascendas Reit's exposure to the tech industry and add to its freehold properties.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens up over 1.5% on Covid-19 vaccine news
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.52% on Nov 10, 2020, following global market rallies after a coronavirus vaccine showed 90% effectiveness. The broader Topix index also increased 1.51%. The positive news lifted Tokyo stocks, but the article does not mention any further developments or conclusions.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit posts indicative Q3 DPU of 0.882 euro cent
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's indicative distribution per unit (DPU) rose 5.8% quarter-over-quarter to 0.882 euro cents for Q3, driven by 14.3% growth in net property income to 30.6 million euros. Gross revenue and distributable income also increased, with a 2.1% rise in gross revenue to 46.1 million euros and a 5.8% increase in distributable income to 22.5 million euros. The manager plans to increase the Reit's exposure to light industrial and data-centre assets while divesting office and other assets.

site_title: JC Penney rescue deal approved in bankruptcy court
summary: A US judge approved a rescue deal to save JC Penney from bankruptcy, averting liquidation and preserving approximately 60,000 jobs. The deal, worth $1.75 billion, involves forgiving $1 billion in debt in exchange for 160 properties and six distribution centers. Lenders and mall operators Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners will acquire the company's slimmed-down retail operations. The sale approval comes after a settlement with creditor groups and despite opposition from equity holders. JC Penney filed for bankruptcy in May with nearly $5 billion in debt.

site_title: Online presence a Covid-19 'vaccine' for small businesses
summary: Singapore small businesses face significant challenges due to the pandemic, with many struggling to sustain operations for less than six months. To overcome these challenges, many are turning to digitalization, with 3 in 4 already investing in technology. Government agencies and industry partners can guide businesses through the digitalization process, providing grants and financial support. Examples of successful digitalization include Chinatown Heritage Centre, which partnered with United Overseas Bank to set up an online store, and F&B companies that have established online sales presence. Digital solutions like e-commerce platforms and online directories can help small businesses build custom websites and increase their online visibility.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee, Novo Tellus fund propose scheme to take Sunningdale private
summary: Koh Boon Hwee and Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 have proposed a scheme to take precision plastic components manufacturer Sunningdale Tech private at S$1.55 per share. The offeror company, Sunrise Technology Investment Holding II, and Novo Tellus PE Fund 2 hold 64% and 36% stakes, respectively. The offeror plans to delist Sunningdale if the scheme becomes effective. The acquisition aims to capitalize on changing global market dynamics and provide flexibility for Sunningdale to focus on its long-term business plan.

site_title: Disneyland furloughs more workers, citing 'limbo' on reopening
summary: Disneyland is furloughing additional workers due to uncertainty over the state's timeline for reopening the theme park in Southern California. The company cited California health authorities' guidelines that require a county's Covid-19 risk level to fall to the lowest tier before large theme parks can reopen. This is on top of the 28,000 employees laid off in September. Furloughed employees will maintain health insurance, and Disneyland President Ken Potrock hopes to rehire them once the park reopens. The park has been closed since mid-March.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Co said on Monday it was furloughing additional workers from its Disneyland theme park in Southern California, because it still does not know when the state will allow it to reopen because of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Singapore's Internet economy drops 24% in 2020; Vietnam, Indonesia see double-digit growth
summary: Singapore's Internet economy declined 24% to $9 billion in 2020 due to a 70% drop in online travel, but other sectors grew 20% on average, driven by e-commerce. Vietnam's Internet economy grew 16% to $14 billion and Indonesia's grew 11% to $44 billion. Despite a short-term decline, Singapore remains a hub for unicorns and startups, with a strong ecosystem. The region's online population is expected to reach 400 million by 2025, with the Philippines set to experience the highest growth rate. Challenges remain, including talent shortages and uneven access to internet services.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Tuesday's session with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.76% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing to 26,474.04, following news of a highly effective virus vaccine. The Shanghai Composite Index also increased 0.41%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.07%. The gains come as investors remain optimistic despite global market uncertainty.

site_title: Egypt says it plans railway lines extending to Libya and Sudan
summary: Egypt's Transport Minister Kamel al-Wazir announced plans to construct a railway line to Wadi Halfa in Sudan and extend a line in the north to Libya's Benghazi, as part of efforts to overhaul the country's transport system. The projects aim to improve the country's rail network, which has been plagued by accidents and poor maintenance. The initiatives are part of Egypt's efforts to build cross-border railway lines with neighboring countries, amid Libya's ongoing chaos since the 2011 uprising.

site_title: US allows emergency use of first Covid-19 antibody drug
summary: US regulators granted emergency use authorization for Eli Lilly's bamlanivimab, the first Covid-19 antibody drug, to treat patients over 65 with mild-to-moderate Covid-19 and those 12 and older with underlying health conditions. The FDA approved the treatment for high-risk patients but not for those hospitalized or requiring oxygen therapy. The US government has purchased 300,000 doses and will cover costs for Americans, with Lilly anticipating manufacturing up to 1 million doses by the end of 2020.

site_title: Edtech startup LingoAce raises US$6m led by Sequoia India
summary: LingoAce, a Chinese language learning platform, has raised US$6 million in a Series A+ round led by Sequoia India. The funding will be used to expand in Southeast Asia, build technology capabilities, and recruit talent. Founded in 2017, LingoAce has over 2,000 certified teachers and 420 employees globally, with a platform featuring multimedia and gamification features. The company plans to expand to Jakarta and Bangkok, and will use the funds to meet growing demand amidst the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares open with big gains on vaccine hopes; STI up 2.5%
summary: Singapore shares opened with significant gains on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a COVID-19 vaccine being over 90% effective, according to Pfizer and BioNTech. The Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 2.5% to 2,674.80, with travel-related stocks such as Singapore Airlines and SATS surging. In contrast, glove makers took a hit, with Aspen Holdings and Top Glove declining. US shares also rose on the vaccine news, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 2.95% and the S&P 500 closing near a record.

site_title: Bumitama 9M net profit jumps 48.8% on higher palm oil prices
summary: BUMITAMA Agri Ltd has reported a 48.8% increase in net profit to 632.14 billion rupiah (S$59.6 million) for the first nine months of its 2020 fiscal year, driven by higher palm oil prices. Revenue rose 12.6% to 6.08 trillion rupiah. Despite lower sales volume, sales revenue for crude palm oil grew 13.3% and average sales price rose 25.6%. The company's operational performance was impacted by El Nino in 2019 and La Nina this year, but all estates and mills remained in full operation.

site_title: US justice chief authorises probes into voting
summary: US Attorney General William Barr has authorised federal prosecutors to investigate voting irregularities, citing claims of fraud in several states, despite a lack of evidence. The move comes as President Donald Trump claims he lost the presidential election due to fraud. Barr's letter gives prosecutors the green light to pursue allegations of voting and vote tabulation irregularities, but warns them to handle serious allegations with care. The decision is seen as a response to Republican claims of illegal voting and vote counting in several states, which await solid evidence.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit eight-month high on renewed vaccine hopes
summary: European shares surged to an eight-month high on Monday, driven by strong progress in the Covid-19 vaccine and President Joe Biden's election victory, which raised hopes for a more stable US trade policy. The Stoxx 600 index jumped 4% and its best day since late March, with travel and leisure stocks leading the gain. Pfizer's experimental vaccine was found to be over 90% effective in preventing Covid-19, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Evergrande scraps China listing, strikes more investor deals
summary: Evergrande Group has scrapped its plans for a backdoor listing in China and struck new deals with investors to avoid repayments of up to 86.3 billion yuan. The move comes as the company faces liquidity challenges, with its shares and bonds tumbling at the end of September. Evergrande has agreed to repay strategic investors with a potential guaranteed return, easing short-term liquidity concerns but leaving lingering questions over the company's long-term financial strength.

site_title: US: Stocks jump on Covid-19 vaccine news, Dow ends +3%
summary: US stocks surged on Monday after news of a 90% effective coronavirus vaccine, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 830 points to 29,157.97. The broader S&P 500 rose 1.1% to 3,550.5, nearing a record, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq slipped 0.7% to 11,713.78. Despite initial gains, Wall Street closed with modest gains, with stocks benefiting from the vaccine news and those affected by the pandemic losing ground.

site_title: Oil soars 8% on promising Covid-19 vaccine results
summary: Oil prices surged 8% on November 9, 2020, following Pfizer's announcement of a 90% effective Covid-19 vaccine. This boost was attributed to traders' hope that the pandemic would be tamped down next year, leading to increased fuel demand. Oil markets also rose as Saudi Arabia suggested adjusting its supply-cut pact, potentially releasing more barrels onto the market. Brent crude settled at $42.40 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $40.29 a barrel, their highest levels in five months.

site_title: US surpasses 10m coronavirus cases: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US surpassed 10 million coronavirus cases, with 10,018,278 cases and 237,742 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. This milestone comes as Pfizer and BioNTech announced their vaccine showed 90% effectiveness. Outgoing President Trump described the breakthrough as "great news," while President-elect Joe Biden urged Americans to wear masks to prevent the spread of the virus, calling it the "most potent weapon" against it.

site_title: Sitting pretty, thanks to quality gaming chairs
summary: Singapore-based gaming chair manufacturer Secretlab has experienced a meteoric rise in revenue, projecting to exceed S$300 million this year, 30 times its revenue just three years ago. The company, co-founded by 28-year-old Ian Ang, has built its chairs with professional gamers in mind and now sells over a million chairs annually in over 60 countries. With a focus on sustainable profit growth, Secretlab has maintained its private company status and has been named one of three EY Entrepreneur of the Year award winners in Singapore.

site_title: US hits four more officials over Hong Kong freedoms
summary: The US imposed sanctions on four Hong Kong officials, including Edwina Lau, head of the National Security Division of the Hong Kong Police Force, over allegations of curbing freedoms in the city. The move, led by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, aims to hold accountable officials undermining Hong Kong's autonomy. The sanctions follow China's implementation of a security law that bars subversion in the financial hub, where pro-democracy protests have been ongoing. The US pressure comes despite China's promises to ensure a separate system for Hong Kong before Britain handed it over in 1997.

site_title: G-20 backslides on fossil fuel subsidies: report
summary: Rich nations, responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions, are providing over half a trillion dollars annually to fossil fuel projects despite committing to slash emissions in line with the Paris climate deal. A report found that many nations' post-pandemic stimulus plans will increase funding to polluting fuels, with at least $170 billion pledged since the start of the pandemic. G-20 countries scored poorly in the assessment due to a lack of transparency and continued support for fossil fuels, undermining efforts to meet the Paris Agreement's goals.

site_title: EU 'regrettably' hits US with tariffs, seeks better Biden ties
summary: The European Union has imposed tariffs on up to $4 billion of US imports in retaliation for US subsidies to Boeing, in response to a 16-year trade dispute. The EU had sought a resolution under President-elect Joe Biden, but said the US had not made progress. The tariffs, which include 15% on planes and parts and 25% on other products, are the latest in a long-standing dispute. The EU hopes to improve ties with the US under Biden and reduce tariffs, while the US has warned it could respond with its own measures.

site_title: Dizzying heights of Animation Vertigo
summary: Animation Vertigo, Inc. has set a high bar in motion capture outsourcing, impressing clients with its attention to detail and high standards. Established in 2004, the company expanded to the Philippines in 2008 and utilizes technology from the military, medical, and entertainment industries to deliver cutting-edge visuals. In 2019, the global 3D motion capture market was valued at $145.53 million, driven by demand for higher-quality animation. AV has catered to both big-name producers and small-budget clients, demonstrating its ability to deliver high-quality services to a wide range of clients.

site_title: Multiple lawsuits added up can be material so why does Oxley Holdings not disclose them?
summary: Oxley Holdings is facing multiple lawsuits, including a chambers hearing with Gracious Land and a pre-trial conference with 40 home owners of Ampas Apartment, which it pulled out of a S$95 million en bloc transaction. Oxley did not disclose these cases to investors, citing confidentiality and materiality thresholds set by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company has a history of undisclosed disputes, including a S$21 million refund for Oxley Consortium and alleged misrepresentation claims from KAP Mall shop owners. Oxley's high gearing and multiple ongoing cases may pose a risk to investors.

site_title: SIA silent on S$6.2b of mandatory convertible bonds
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has yet to decide on issuing an additional S$6.2 billion worth of mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs), nor can it disclose how long its current liquidity will last. This decision and information on its liquidity remain unclear.

site_title: McDonald's launching meatless 'McPlant' burger
summary: McDonald's is launching a plant-based burger called the "McPlant" to cater to the growing demand for meatless options. The burger will be produced exclusively for McDonald's and will be introduced in selected markets next year. The move follows rival Burger King's launch of a vegetarian version of its "Whopper" burger in 2019. McDonald's had previously tested a plant-based burger in Canada with Beyond Meat, and the company is considering plant-based substitutes for chicken products and breakfast sandwiches. The introduction of the McPlant is part of McDonald's efforts to adapt to changing consumer preferences and boost internet sales.

site_title: Japan Airlines shares tumble after plan for new share sale
summary: Japan Airlines Co. shares plummeted 15% in early trading after announcing a plan to raise up to 168 billion yen ($2.2 billion) by selling new shares to support its finances during the coronavirus crisis. The airline will use the proceeds to repay debt and invest in its restructuring plan for the post-pandemic era. The stock has declined over 50% this year, marking the steepest decline on record.

site_title: Far East Orchard sinks into the red with S$6.3m nine-month loss
summary: Far East Orchard, a hotel operator and property developer, reported a net loss of S$6.3 million for the nine months ended Sept 30, 2020, due to the impact of COVID-19 on its hospitality business. Sales declined 25.1% to S$84 million, and total operating profit fell 74.8% to S$6.4 million. The group's PBSA business, however, remained profitable, with occupancy rates above 80% as of end September. Despite the challenges, Far East Orchard expects a protracted recovery period for the hospitality industry and plans to open approximately 1,300 rooms this year, including 650 rooms in the final quarter.

site_title: The US must accept China's rise
summary: The US must accept China's rise as a global economic power. Contrary to the view that China's economic success is due to unfair government intervention, a more thorough analysis reveals that successful grand economic development plans often align with the economy's fundamentals. Crediting state intervention for achieving targets is therefore misleading. As both parties in the US agree on the need to "stop" China, a more nuanced understanding of China's rise is necessary, acknowledging its economic and technological advancements as a legitimate outcome.

site_title: China's luxury shoppers call in the tidy teams
summary: China's luxury shoppers are seeking professional help to manage their overspending, with some hiring "home organisers" to sort through their closets. The trend is linked to China's rapid economic growth, which has led to a surge in conspicuous consumption. Experts are helping these shoppers to re-evaluate their spending habits and create more sustainable wardrobes. This trend highlights the growing demand for luxury goods in China and the need for individuals to manage their spending effectively.

site_title: EC World Reit cuts Q3 DPU by 6.8% to 1.388 S cents
summary: EC World Reit reported a 6.8% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.388 Singapore cents for Q3, from 1.489 cents last year. Gross revenue rose 10.8% to S$28.5 million and net property income (NPI) grew 14% to S$26.1 million. The decline in DPU was due to a 9% retention of distribution funds amid the Covid-19 situation and global economic climate. Despite this, the Reit's portfolio showed improvement with renewed leases and new signings at competitive rates.

site_title: New lockdowns in Europe to dent oil demand outlook: IEA
summary: Renewed lockdowns in Europe due to rising Covid-19 cases are expected to negatively impact global oil demand, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). IEA director Keisuke Sadamori stated the impact would be less severe than earlier lockdowns. However, the outlook for oil demand remains uncertain, and the full extent of the impact is yet to be determined.

site_title: How family enterprises can build resilience in a post-pandemic future
summary: Family enterprises can continue to flourish in a post-pandemic future by balancing stewardship and transformation, leveraging their long-term perspective and entrepreneurial spirit. They can adopt a patient capital approach, reduce debt, and focus on digital transformation. Successful digital transformation requires an innovative culture, a clear strategic vision, and recognition that protecting past successes is no longer enough. Family enterprises can also benefit from diversity in talent, forming partnerships, and leveraging mergers and acquisitions. A shared purpose and values are vital, and integrating younger generations into the business can help ensure a cohesive corporate culture.

site_title: Sustainability takes flight
summary: Composites Technology Research Malaysia (CTRM) has successfully implemented green strategies since its inception in 1990, reducing landfill usage, air pollution, and electricity consumption. The company established a Sustainability Steering Committee to ensure its sustainability strategy aligns with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and G4 Sustainability Reporting Guideline. Through initiatives such as waste management and awareness campaigns, CTRM has positively impacted the environment, demonstrating its commitment to sustainability in the aerospace composites industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares join global rally on vaccine hopes; tourism, oil stocks take off
summary: Australian and New Zealand stock markets surged more than 2% on Tuesday, driven by a global rally fueled by promising developments toward a coronavirus vaccine. The Australian benchmark index reached its highest level since March 5, with travel, leisure, and energy firms leading gains. Energy stocks climbed over 8% as crude prices surged, while real estate firms rose between 8% and 15%. In contrast, gold stocks slumped over 7% and tech shares fell 4% due to a decline in Afterpay's stock.

images.alt_text: Stock markets in Australia and New Zealand jumped more than 2 per cent on Tuesday, joining a global rally in equities overnight as investor risk appetite was boosted by promising developments toward a coronavirus vaccine.

site_title: When tenacity pays off
summary: CEO Christopher Loh transformed UAB Bank in Myanmar, turning a financial crisis into a profitable institution. Under his leadership, the bank's return on equity rose from -0.34% to 17.7%, and it reported a profit of $6.1 million in 2018. Loh also introduced community building initiatives, such as scholarships and sponsorships, to support underprivileged children and women. His determination and "righteous" approach earned him a spot in the ACES Awards Outstanding Leaders in Asia category, with one executive calling his story "thrilling" and "like it could be made into a movie."

site_title: Anticipating America's return to the world under Biden
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden will face significant challenges in reviving America's international credentials and restoring old partnerships with allies, following the Trump administration's retreat from the world. Biden aims to revive the Paris climate accord, recommit to military alliances, and rejoin multilateral institutions. However, he will need to navigate pressure from both progressive and Republican lawmakers, while also developing a new global strategy to address the evolving international order, particularly the US-China relationship.

site_title: Logistics players brace for delivery surge this 11/11
summary: Logistics companies in Singapore are preparing for a surge in deliveries on 11/11, driven by the growth of e-commerce during the Covid-19 pandemic. The event has seen a 477% increase in online retail sales and 126% in traffic in 2019. This year's edition is expected to see even stronger growth, with many brands setting up digital storefronts. Companies have ramped up manpower and resources, increased warehouse capacity, and tapped technologies to cope with the expected delivery surge.

site_title: From Germany to the world
summary: The Heraeus Group, a German technology conglomerate, was founded in 1660 as a family-owned pharmacy and officially established in 1851. Today, it operates in 5 sectors, employing 15,000 people in over 40 countries.

site_title: Sustainability - the name of the game
summary: Berjayapak Sdn Bhd, a Malaysian company, has made sustainability a core aspect of its business practices since 1989. The company sources wood from managed forests certified by the Forest Stewardship Council and has implemented a pallet recycling program. By adopting these methods, Berjayapak aims to minimize its environmental impact and promote ethical labor practices in the wood-based manufacturing industry. This approach sets the company apart from its competitors, contributing to a cleaner environment and a more sustainable future.

site_title: S$35m grant to help smaller financial institutions adopt digital solutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a S$35 million Productivity Solutions Grant to help smaller financial institutions adopt digital solutions for streamlined data reporting. Eligible institutions with up to 200 employees can receive up to 30% co-funding for qualifying expenses, capped at S$250,000. The grant aims to support these institutions in meeting regulatory requirements and improving operational capabilities. The program is initially focused on banks and will be expanded to include insurers and capital market intermediaries in the future.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SGX enables SingPass use for high-security CDP transactions, allowing investors to access portfolios and manage securities activities. Sembcorp Industries' $70 million South African water assets sale may be reversed due to legal proceedings. Vibropower Corporation shareholders failed to oust the board but passed a resolution allowing directors to issue shares. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Ant's stalled IPO could see its value slashed by US$140b
summary: China's move to halt Ant Group's IPO could slash its value by up to $140 billion, according to analysts. The halt, due to new regulations requiring Ant to raise capital and obtain national licenses, may reduce the fintech giant's valuation by about half. Ant's stock is currently valued at 4.4 times book value, compared to 2 times at top global banks. The regulatory details are preliminary and subject to change.

site_title: Britain pursues Brexit finance plan, door open to EU firms
summary: Britain's finance minister, Rishi Sunak, announced plans to help "renew" the City of London's pre-eminence in global finance after the Brexit transition period ends on December 31. The UK will grant access to its markets to EU financial firms, excluding some key sectors pending further negotiations. This move aims to provide certainty and stability for firms, while London remains locked in talks about a broader trade deal with the EU. Sunak also announced plans to bolster the UK's attractiveness, including reforms to rules for companies that list in London and the first sale of "green" government bonds.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Rishi Sunak said he was no longer waiting for Brussels to decide on access to its markets in return and castigated the EU for holding out on a deal key to Britain's 130 billion-pound (S$230.4 billion) financial sector.

site_title: Virgin's Hyperloop carries passengers for the 1st time
summary: The Virgin Hyperloop successfully carried its first passengers on Sunday, marking a major milestone for the high-speed transportation technology. The test, which took place in Los Angeles, demonstrated the potential of the Hyperloop to transport people at 1,000 km/h. The company claims this represents a significant step forward for the technology, which could revolutionize high-speed travel.

site_title: Riskier currencies maintain gains against dollar
summary: The US dollar stabilized after falling to a 10-week low following Joe Biden's election as US president. The euro/dollar pair remained below US$1.19, while the Japanese yen remained close to an eight-month high. Scandinavian currencies and the Australian dollar gained strength due to their sensitivity to international trade developments and investors' risk appetite. The Chinese yuan reached a 28-month peak of 6.5501 and rose 0.6% against the US dollar.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell E-Reit, Riverstone, Sunningdale, Bumitama Agri, Vicom
summary: Singapore stocks experienced varied developments on Tuesday, with Cromwell E-Reit's distribution per unit rising 5.8% to 0.882 euro cents, while Riverstone Holdings posted a 400% jump in net profit to RM178.6 million. Sunningdale Tech announced a proposed acquisition and trading halt, and Bumitama Agri reported higher revenue and net profit. Vicom's profit slipped 5% to S$6.82 million, and Elite Commercial Reit's distribution per unit rose 1.7% to 1.23 pence. Shares in Aspen Holdings rallied 15.1% after announcing a proposed placement.

site_title: China's tech industry relieved by Biden win - but not relaxed
summary: China's tech industry is relieved that Joe Biden won the US presidential election, as it may lead to a more constructive relationship. However, few expect the rivalry to de-escalate, with China focusing on improving its domestic tech capabilities. Chinese tech giants, including Huawei and ByteDance, have been affected by US sanctions and trade curbs. Analysts suggest that Biden's policy priorities may not include a blanket ban on China's semiconductor industry, but China is instead focusing on shoring up its vulnerable tech industry through its "dual circulation" model of growth.

site_title: Raring to Go
summary: GO-VA, a 6-year-old Australian-based company, has been recognized as one of the Most Promising SMEs by the ACES Awards. Founded by Matt Kesby and his sister Fiona, the company outsources low-value tasks to the Philippines to focus on strategy and business growth. GO-VA prioritizes employee care, offering benefits such as private medical insurance, loan assistance, and a chief happiness officer. The company has received awards for its business practices and supports local charity Mercy in Action, which provides aid to vulnerable children. GO-VA aims to create 4,000 jobs and stop the threat of dengue fever in Cebu City within the next decade.

site_title: S$6.8m disbursed to 2,700 food, retail businesses in Singapore for going digital
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has disbursed a total of S$6.8 million to 2,700 food and retail businesses in Singapore under the Digital Resilience Bonus (DRB) scheme, aimed at supporting the sectors badly hit by the pandemic. The payouts, ranging from S$2,500 to S$10,000, are given on top of other measures under the SMEs Go Digital programme, which has seen a doubling in the number of SMEs taking up digital solutions in the last six months.

site_title: New PlayStation and Xbox consoles enter US$150b games arena
summary: The next-generation PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S consoles are set to launch later this week, entering the US$150 billion video game industry. Sony's PlayStation 5 is expected to retain its edge over Microsoft's Xbox Series X/S due to its deep bench of games and broader fan base. However, cloud gaming is on the rise, potentially curbing console sales and benefiting Microsoft. The consoles are priced between $300 to $500, with pre-orders selling out quickly, and demand is expected to outstrip supply, leading to shortages in 2021.

site_title: Moving ahead with confidence
summary: M-DAQ's CEO Richard Koh describes the fintech startup as in "wartime" mode since 2019, driven by business and cap-table diversification goals. Koh attributes this to the company's readiness to adapt to changing circumstances, unlike the global economic forecasts for 2020, which were affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. Koh expects this "wartime" mode to persist globally for part of 2021, driven by M-DAQ's growth engines.

site_title: UN hails new therapy to prevent HIV in women
summary: The UN's UNAIDS body announced that a new anti-retroviral therapy, cabotegravir, is 89% more effective in preventing HIV in women compared to daily PrEP pills. Injected every two months, cabotegravir is a game-changer in HIV prevention for women, with a ninefold lower risk of infection. A trial involving over 3,200 women at higher risk of HIV found four women became infected with HIV while taking daily pills, compared to none while receiving injections. The therapy is seen as a breakthrough in HIV prevention, with UNAIDS calling for its accessible, affordable, and equitable distribution.

site_title: Aspen shares surge 15% after announcing placement
summary: Aspen shares surged 15.1% to S$0.305 after announcing a proposed placement to raise up to S$23.8 million, with 100 million new shares to be issued at 23.8 Singapore cents apiece. The placement aims to boost the company's visibility and financial position, following a recent diversification into glove-making. The deal, facilitated by PrimePartners Corporate Finance, will represent 9.2% of Aspen's enlarged issued share capital and will be used to fund capital expenditures and working capital.

site_title: Travel firms that are thriving amid Covid-19
summary: Travel firms thriving amid Covid-19 include members-only vacation clubs and experiential travel platforms. Peek, a US-based startup, saw bookings drop to zero in April but rebounded to $50 million in July. The company has since broken monthly sales records as travelers seek local experiences. This trend is attributed to the desire for exciting ways to explore one's own backyard during the pandemic.

site_title: Longtime host of Jeopardy! game show dies at 80
summary: Alex Trebek, the long-time host of Jeopardy!, has passed away at the age of 80. Trebek took over as host in 1984 and became a constant presence on television screens, known for his calm demeanor and twinkling eye.

site_title: How will Joe Biden change life for US businesses?
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden's administration is expected to bring significant changes to US businesses, including a potential increase in the corporate tax rate to 28% and a minimum tax on corporations making over $100 million. He also plans to invest $2 trillion in renewable energy and clean transportation, and restore power to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Additionally, Biden has pledged to rejoin the Paris Climate Accord, increase the minimum wage to $15 an hour, and decriminalize cannabis use. The outcome of these policies will depend on control of the Senate, which will be decided after two run-off elections in Georgia.

site_title: Number of manufacturing jobs doubles to 6,370 in two months
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has seen a significant increase in jobs, with the number of manufacturing jobs doubling to 6,370 in two months. Output in the industry rose 24.2% in September compared to the same period last year, with 10,400 jobs and training slots available under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package. This growth is attributed to companies hiring workers to support their transformation efforts, even in hard-hit sub-sectors like marine and offshore.

site_title: China yet to congratulate US presidential election winner Biden
summary: China has yet to congratulate US presidential election winner Joe Biden, despite other countries having done so. This is unusual, as China typically follows diplomatic protocol. The US presidential election was held on November 3, but incumbent President Donald Trump has not conceded and is making legal challenges to the outcome. China plans to follow custom in responding to the result, but the delay in congratulating Biden has raised questions about the country's intentions.

site_title: US election: China draws lesson from American democracy
summary: China has expressed cautious optimism about a potential improvement in its bilateral relationship with the US under the new administration of President-elect Joe Biden. Following Biden's victory, Chinese state media has quoted experts suggesting that a more moderate approach from Washington could lead to pragmatic cooperation on issues like the COVID-19 pandemic. However, China's Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng acknowledged "disagreements" between the two countries, while also highlighting "broad common interests and space for cooperation."

site_title: Secretlab CEO Ian Ang is Singapore's EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2020
summary: Secretlab CEO Ian Ang, 28, was named the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2020, becoming the youngest winner in the awards' 18-year history. He received the award in the Consumer Products category, beating two other entrepreneurs.

site_title: STI climbs 1.19% as Asian equities rally following Biden's victory
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.19% on Monday following US President Joe Biden's victory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending at 2,609.36. Analysts attribute the gains to Biden's promise of reconciliation, diplomacy, and international cooperation, which is expected to benefit emerging markets in Asia. Key local stocks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB also climbed, while SIA and Sembcorp Industries fell.

site_title: SoftBank's H1 net profit jumps over 4 times to 1.88t yen
summary: SoftBank Group reported a 346.7% surge in first-half net profit to 1.88 trillion yen ($24 billion), driven by gains on investments. The conglomerate has shed assets to shore up finances, including a planned sale of British chip designer Arm to NVIDIA for up to $40 billion. SoftBank's strong recovery from a massive annual loss in the previous fiscal year is attributed to robust gains in global equities markets and the success of its $100 billion Vision Fund.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Companies such as Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore's stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Putting pedal to the mettle
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) was postponed in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, marking a disappointment for the event's organizers. However, the pandemic also presented a trial by fire for corporations and business leaders, who demonstrated agility and resilience in the face of uncertainty. The ACES recognized companies that excelled in leading through crisis, with PT Mowilex Indonesia being named Asia's Best Performing Companies for its commitment to sustainability and environmental leadership.

site_title: Neo Group H1 earnings up 5 times to S$13.6m
summary: Neo Group's first-half attributable net profit surged 5 times to S$13.6 million, driven by higher financial grants, revenue growth, and reduced operating expenses. This marked a significant improvement from the S$2.3 million net profit in the same period last year. The company attributed the growth to its core businesses, including catering and manufacturing.

site_title: Growing from strength to strength
summary: Bangkok Life Assurance aims to boost financial literacy in Thailand, linking happiness and cultural heritage to financial planning. The company launched two concepts, "Bangkok Life Assurance: Live As You Design" and "Bangkok Life Assurance: A Happier Life," to promote joy in financial security. Established in 1951, the corporation prioritizes public education over product promotion, committing to sustainable business practices aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals. By doing so, Bangkok Life Assurance seeks to build security in people's lives through a sustainable framework.

site_title: Sun goes down on Singapore's first solar power firm Sun Electric
summary: Singapore's first licensed solar energy retailer, Sun Electric Power (SEP), has gone into liquidation after a court ordered its winding up due to non-payment of $7.5 million in incentive payments. The company's struggles stem from its failure to meet its market making obligations, with RCMA Asia winning the bid to wind up the firm. SEP has filed an appeal, but its status is now listed as "in liquidation." The company's collapse raises concerns about the viability of independent electricity retailers in Singapore's small market.
