summary: Former senior minister S Jayakumar has expressed concerns in his latest book that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong should not step down in the near future due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Jayakumar argues that changing leadership in the middle of the crisis could be detrimental to the country's stability. He suggests that PM Lee should stay in office longer to allow the next generation of leaders to work with more experienced ministers, and to ensure a strong and stable government.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best week in four on split US Congress hopes
summary: Australian shares closed 0.8% higher on Friday, marking its best weekly gain in four, as investors welcomed a divided US Congress and reduced corporate tax possibilities. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 4.4% for the week. Treasury Wine Estate shares surged 10% despite reports of Chinese buyers being told not to purchase Australian produce. The Australian gold index also gained 5.6%, with miners like Alkane Resources and Bellevue Gold rising.

site_title: China's Australian copper ban seen hurting smelters
summary: China's unofficial ban on Australian copper concentrate imports may hurt Chinese smelters in negotiations with miners on benchmark treatment charges for 2021. Chinese customs officials have informally warned importers of increased inspections, forcing traders to divert shipments. The move is seen as a diplomatic row between the two countries, with supplies from South America disrupted by the coronavirus epidemic. This may erode smelters' bargaining power, leading to lower prices for the 2021 benchmark, potentially settling near $60 a tonne.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund still RM32.3b in debt: government report
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund remains RM32.3 billion in debt as of September, according to a government report. The fund, established by former Prime Minister Najib Razak in 2009, has outstanding debt and billions of dollars unaccounted for. The government has provided RM9.4 billion in loans and advances to help meet financial commitments, and has recovered RM13.4 billion in assets linked to 1MDB. Goldman Sachs has also guaranteed to help recover US$1.4 billion more in 1MDB-linked assets. The US has estimated US$4.5 billion was stolen from the fund in an elaborate scheme.

site_title: Wealthy countries edge towards global climate finance goal
summary: Wealthy countries have increased financing to help developing countries combat climate change, contributing $78.9 billion in 2018, an 11% increase from 2017. The OECD says the $100 billion annual goal by 2020 remains within reach, despite a lack of growth in private finance. The European Union is the largest provider of climate finance, and most contributions target reducing greenhouse gas emissions and adapting to climate change impacts. However, the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on climate finance data is unclear.

site_title: Deutsche Bank alumni are helping Son remake SoftBank
summary: Deutsche Bank alumni, including Akshay Naheta, a former trader, are influencing SoftBank's strategy under billionaire Masayoshi Son. Naheta, a senior vice-president, has helped Son make key deals, such as the US$40 billion sale of chip designer Arm to Nvidia. Naheta's rise reflects SoftBank's shift to an investment-holdings model, where finance veterans with risk appetite hold sway. The group, which includes Rajeev Misra, Colin Fan, and Yanni Pipilis, has billions of dollars at their disposal and has made high-stakes bets, sometimes with controversy. Despite regulatory concerns, SoftBank's evolution into a financial giant is attributed to the Deutsche Bank alumni's expertise and risk-taking approach.

site_title: Toyota-backed startup Pony.ai raises US$267m in new funding round
summary: Pony.ai, backed by Toyota Motor, has raised US$267 million in its latest funding round, valuing the self-driving startup at US$5.3 billion. The funding, led by Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board, will be used to develop technology and expand its fleet. This round of funding makes Pony.ai one of the most valuable independent autonomous driving startups, surpassing rivals Aurora and Nuro. The investment comes as global automakers and tech firms continue to pour capital into developing self-driving vehicles.

site_title: Japan's GPIF posts US$47b quarterly returns as stock markets rally
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported a second-quarter investment return of $47.3 billion, driven by a global stock market rally. The world's largest pension fund earned a 3.1% return on overall assets, following a record return of 12.49 trillion yen (S$162.7 billion) in the previous quarter. This marks the second consecutive quarter of strong returns for GPIF.

site_title: StarHub Q3 net profit down 23.3% to S$44.5 million
summary: StarHub's third-quarter net profit fell 23.3% to S$44.5 million, impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic's effect on consumer demand. Revenue dropped 14.5% to S$489.7 million, with service revenue down 10.6% to S$388.7 million. The telco attributed the decline to reduced travel and a seasonal rise in operating expenses. Enterprise business services and newly acquired regional infocomm technology unit Strateq helped cushion the blow, with revenue growth of 11.4%. The company maintains its earlier guidance for FY2020, projecting a 10-12% service revenue decline.

site_title: Rich Filipinos are boosting beach home sales near Manila
summary: Rich Filipinos are boosting beach home sales near Manila as they seek second homes and healthier environments away from the capital region due to high daily infections. Land values in gated resort communities in Batangas increased 20-46% in October, with non-listed lots selling for up to 50 million pesos (S$1.4 million). Properties in suburban and beach areas are seeing a surge in demand, driven by the pandemic's focus on seaside havens, with increasing demand for resort properties in Subic and La Union.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed Friday slightly higher, ending a strong week on a healthy note. The Hang Seng Index added 0.07% to 25,712.97, driven by hopes for a new US stimulus and Joe Biden's expected win in the US presidency. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.24% and 0.77% respectively. The gains followed a surge in global markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log best week in five months as Biden heads toward victory
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Friday, marking their best weekly gain in five months, as US stocks rose overnight following investors' assessment of a Joe Biden presidency with a split Congress. The Kospi index jumped 6.6% for the week, boosted by alternative energy shares, while foreigners bought 788.4 billion won worth of shares. This week's gains bring the Kospi up 9.96% for the year, and the won up 3.2% against the dollar.

site_title: Allianz posts surprise 6% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: Allianz, a German insurer, reported a 6% rise in Q3 net profit to €2.06 billion, despite pressure from the pandemic. The company's full-year profit guidance remains unchanged, citing economic uncertainty. Net profit surpassed a consensus forecast of €1.63 billion. Allianz's combined ratio worsened to 94.5%, but readings below 100% indicate profitability. CEO Oliver Baete expressed confidence in the company's ability to weather the pandemic and build an even stronger Allianz.

site_title: Gold retreats as US dollar ticks up, but set for weekly rise
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.6% to $1,936.95 per ounce, despite a 2.4% surge on Thursday, due to a rise in the US dollar. However, gold is set for a 3.1% weekly gain, driven by expectations of central bank economic support under a Biden presidency. Investors expect a divided US Congress to maintain the status quo on policy, supporting gold's appeal as an inflation hedge. The US Federal Reserve also promised to keep interest rates low, further bolstering gold's value.

site_title: Honda doubles profit forecast, boosted by China rebound
summary: Honda Motor has doubled its full-year operating profit forecast to 420 billion yen, driven by a 28% growth in second-quarter earnings amid a rebound in China. The company now forecasts a full-year operating profit of 420 billion yen, exceeding analyst estimates of 254.6 billion yen. Honda expects to sell 4.6 million cars this year, up from a previous forecast of 4.5 million. The company is shifting focus to electric cars, aiming for two-thirds of its output to be new-energy vehicles by 2030.

site_title: New Zealand's Ardern sworn in for second term
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern was sworn in for a second term after the final election results showed her landslide victory was even bigger than initially thought. She won 50.0% of the vote, securing 65 seats in the 120-strong parliament, and her centre-left Labour Party achieved its biggest win since World War II. Ardern's priorities will focus on containing Covid-19 and rebuilding the economy, with plans for incremental reform on key issues such as housing affordability and climate change.

site_title: SIA reports record H1 loss of S$3.47 billion on huge impairments and retrenchment costs
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a record net loss of S$3.47 billion for the six months to September, more than doubling its Q2 loss of S$1.1 billion. The loss was driven by impairment charges for older aircraft and a S$42 million retrenchment cost. This marks a significant decline from the S$1.1 billion loss in the first quarter to June. The airline's net loss for the half-year period is S$2.3 billion, with Q2 losses accounting for twice the Q1 loss.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes at highest level since 1991
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index reached its highest level since 1991, closing at 24,325.23, up 0.91% or 219.95 points. The Topix index also rose 0.52% or 8.55 points to 1,658.49. Despite uncertainty over the US presidential election, the rally appears to be driven by traders brushing off new Trump threats, with many markets continuing their upward trend. The strong performance is also attributed to positive sentiments in other regions, including Europe and the US.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after week-long rally, with eyes on US vote
summary: Asian markets ended mixed on Friday, following a week-long rally, as traders awaited the US election outcome. The Federal Reserve pledged to support the economy with further stimulus measures, boosting stocks, particularly tech firms. Analysts expect a constrained Biden presidency, but the economic backdrop remains uncertain due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. US stocks extended gains, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq rising at least 2% for the fourth consecutive day.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts accused of 'arrogant indifference' to compliance at inquiry
summary: Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator, has been accused of having a "culture of denial and arrogant indifference to compliance" with junket operators. Lawyers argue that the company ignored warning signs and breached an obligation to deal with people of good repute. Crown's founder and 36% shareholder James Packer is under scrutiny, with the inquiry potentially resulting in regulatory action against him and the company. The casino's license could be suspended or cancelled, and an investigation into Crown's anti-money laundering protocols is underway.

site_title: Bombardier falls as UK probes 'suspected bribery'
summary: Bombardier's stock fell 1.7% after the UK's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) confirmed it was investigating the company over "suspected bribery and corruption" related to its dealings with Garuda Indonesia. The airline ordered Bombardier regional jets in 2012. The SFO's probe adds to Bombardier's challenges as CEO Eric Martel tries to remake the company into a private jet builder. Bombardier has begun an internal review into its transactions with Garuda, which was previously convicted of corruption in connection with the same transactions.

site_title: EA beats earnings expectations but outlook falls short
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) reported revenue of $1.15 billion in the recently ended quarter, beating expectations, but its outlook for the current quarter fell short, causing shares to sink over 7%. The company attributed the revenue growth to its Madden and Fifa franchises, and announced that its battle royale-style game Apex Legends is on track to become a billion-dollar franchise. Despite this, EA's projected revenue for the current quarter ($1.7 billion) was below Wall Street's forecast ($2.3 billion).

site_title: WhatsApp takes on Google, Alibaba in India's phone payment battle
summary: WhatsApp has launched its digital payments service, WhatsApp Pay, in India, marking a significant entry into the country's fast-growing digital payments market. The service allows users to send and receive money through the messaging platform, and has partnered with five Indian lenders, including State Bank of India and HDFC Bank. India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI) is also used by Alphabet's Google Pay, Walmart's PhonePe, and Alibaba-backed Paytm, which dominate the market. WhatsApp aims to boost innovation in payments and capitalize on India's large user base, with the potential to reach 20 million users in the first phase.

site_title: UBS sued for US$500m by Chinese tycoon over deal gone awry
summary: UBS Group is being sued by Chinese tycoon Guo Wengui for US$500 million over a margin loan gone wrong. Guo claims UBS pressured him into borrowing money tied to the purchase of shares in Haitong Securities, leading to a significant loss when the shares plummeted in 2015. UBS strongly disputes the claim and will defend itself, citing internal policies not to make margin calls to "highly valued customers" like Guo. This is not the first lawsuit Guo has filed against UBS, after failing to get a claim heard in New York.

site_title: Ant's IPO suspension is to safeguard consumer, investor interests: PBOC
summary: China suspended Ant Group's $37 billion IPO, thwarting its debut as the world's largest stock market listing. The decision was made to safeguard consumer and investor interests, amid broader efforts to prevent systemic financial risks and curb rising debt. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) and China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) cited laws and regulations in support of the decision, with regulators emphasizing the need for listed companies to comply with relevant laws and regulations. The move has thrown Ant's investors and executives into a tailspin, with executives racing to satisfy tighter regulations.

images.alt_text: The decision to suspend Ant Group's planned initial public offering (IPO) in China was based on a comprehensive consideration about safeguarding the interests of financial consumers and investors, a senior central bank official said on Friday.

site_title: China bars arrivals from France over virus fears
summary: China has banned foreign arrivals from France and several other countries due to concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. The ban, which was announced by Chinese embassies in various countries, aims to "temporarily suspend" non-Chinese nationals from entering the country. This move comes as China has tightened travel restrictions and health measures in recent months. Beijing defended the ban as "reasonable and fair" and cited the practices of many countries. The decision affects countries with high COVID-19 cases, including France, Russia, and Italy.

site_title: S$6.8m disbursed to 2,700 food, retail businesses in Singapore for going digital: IMDA
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has disbursed S$6.8 million to 2,700 food and retail businesses as part of the Digital Resilience Bonus (DRB) scheme. The bonus aims to encourage digital transformation in the F&B and retail sectors, which were severely impacted by the pandemic. Over 50,000 SMEs have adopted digital solutions under the SMEs Go Digital programme. IMDA's assistant CEO Jane Lim urged SMEs to digitalise and take advantage of available support measures to boost their digital transformation journey.

site_title: Robinsons' closing down sale begins on Friday
summary: Robinsons, a Singaporean retailer, is holding a store-wide sale at its last two stores starting Friday, offering discounts on fashion, beauty, homeware, accessories, and travel items. The sale, facilitated by liquidator KordaMentha, aims to clear remaining inventory. Customers who have pre-paid for Simmons, Sealy, Serta, or King Koil mattresses may still receive delivery, while those who made payments to Mattress International (MaxCoil) should contact their banks to cancel and redirect their purchases.

site_title: China needs to consider policy adjustments but cannot make hasty moves: PBOC vice-governor
summary: China's central bank vice-governor Liu Guoqiang stated that the country needs to consider policy adjustments as its economy recovers. To support the economy, financial institutions have already lowered interest rates and fees, resulting in 1.25 trillion yuan (S$254.6 billion) in profits being given up in the first 10 months of the year. The authorities are cautious, emphasizing the need for accurate economic assessments before making any policy changes. China is on track to reach its target of 1.5 trillion yuan in profits for the year.

site_title: Thai Airways seeks buyers for 34 used planes as part of restructuring plan
summary: Thai Airways International is seeking buyers for 34 used Airbus and Boeing planes as part of its restructuring plan due to the coronavirus pandemic's financial impact. The sale of the 12- to 28-year-old aircraft requires bankruptcy court approval and would help cut the airline's fleet size. The planes, including four-engined Airbus A340s and Boeing 747s, are being sold on an "as-is, where-is" condition, with delivery available in 2021. The sale is consistent with the airline's reorganisation plan to manage costs and reduce debt.

site_title: IndiGo prepares mega engine order, defying aviation gloom
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, is in talks with Pratt & Whitney and CFM International to order new engines for 150 Airbus A320neo jets, worth around $10.7 billion, including maintenance. This deal, if finalized, would be a significant move in the aviation industry, which has been paralyzed by the pandemic. Despite the market conditions, IndiGo is in a strong financial position, with $2.4 billion in cash and $3.5 billion in debt. The airline plans to trim its fleet size over the next two years before starting to grow again by 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on Friday with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on Friday with gains, extending the week's rally. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.21% to 25,750.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains followed a surge on Wall Street.

site_title: Top US$5 trillion investor group pushes firms to cut out thermal coal
summary: The Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance, a US$5 trillion investor group, is urging companies to stop financing, insuring, building, or developing new thermal coal plants. The group aims to meet the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C warming limit by phasing out thermal coal by 2030 and globally by 2040. Companies that fail to comply may face sanctions, including possible divestment, according to a report from the alliance. Member companies, such as Allianz, have developed plans to transition away from thermal coal and must adhere to the group's core principles.

site_title: RBA says Australian recovery underway, population slowdown a major drag
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has stated that Australia's economic recovery is underway, but a slowdown in population growth poses a significant challenge. The bank expects annual economic growth of -4% in the December quarter, down from a previous forecast of -6%. Unemployment is expected to peak at 8% and decline slowly to 6% by 2022. The RBA has cut interest rates to a record low of 0.1% and launched quantitative easing, pledging to buy A$100 billion in government bonds over six months.

site_title: Alibaba will feel the Ant sting
summary: Alibaba is facing financial pressure due to its ties with Ant, a reeling financial technology company. A suspended initial public offering (IPO) and new credit rules in Beijing are weighing on the e-commerce giant's $780 billion valuation. Growth at Alibaba's core shopping business has slowed, and the company's Hong Kong-listed stock price fell 7.5% after Ant's IPO was suspended. Alibaba's revenue grew 30% in the September quarter, but its main commerce unit saw a 29% increase, down from 40% a year earlier. The company's CEO, Daniel Zhang, will need to deliver results elsewhere to mitigate the impact of Ant's struggles.

site_title: Star Wars toys discovered in bin bags net £400,000 for UK couple
summary: A UK couple discovered a garage full of bin bags left by a neighbour, containing a vast collection of Star Wars toys worth £400,000. The collection, amassed over decades, included rare items such as a sealed Star Destroyer Commander and a Palitoy Jawa, fetching £32,500 and £27,280 respectively. The couple, who had initially no idea what to do with the items, were thrilled with the unexpected windfall, with auctioneer Chris Aston describing it as "one of the best Star Wars collections I've ever seen."

site_title: ARA H-Trust posts Q3 gross revenue of US$20.4m amid portfolio recovery
summary: ARA H-Trust posted Q3 gross revenue of US$20.4 million, more than double Q2's US$7.6 million, driven by portfolio recovery amid reopening and weekend leisure travel in the US. Gross operating profit reversed from a loss, reaching US$3.9 million, and net property income narrowed to negative US$1.3 million. The stapled group's hotels are operational, with extended-stay properties showing resilience and commanding premium occupancy and revenue. ARA H-Trust has adequate liquidity and will focus on proactive asset management, prudent capital management, and yield-accretive investment management for long-term value creation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.02 points, or 0.13%, to 1,499.47. Volume reached 335.45 million lots worth RM193.02 million. Gainers beat losers 328 to 110.

site_title: StanChart unveils permanent move to flexible working from 2021
summary: Standard Chartered plans to offer flexible work options to over 90% of its 85,000 staff, with about half expected to apply for hybrid work from early 2021. The bank aims to reach 75,000 workers in 55 markets by 2023. In talks with a third-party firm, Standard Chartered plans to provide "near-home" workspaces for staff. The move follows a survey showing that 60% of staff have accepted hybrid work offers, with 76% in the UK and 79% in the US in favor. This trend is expected to lead to a shift away from traditional office spaces.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered plans to offer flexible work options to more than 90 per cent of its 85,000 staff over three years, a sign of how pandemic crisis management is leading to long-term change in the role of the office.

site_title: Macquarie posts first-ever investment banking loss; beats H1 guidance
summary: Macquarie Group, Australia's largest investment bank and asset manager, reported its first-ever investment banking loss of A$189 million in the first half of 2020. The company's net profit dropped 32% due to delayed deals and increased impairment charges. Despite this, the company beat its forecasted 35% decline in profit. Macquarie's share price rose 2% after the earnings release, and the company slashed its interim dividend to A$1.35 per share. The company expects market conditions to remain challenging and refrained from providing guidance for fiscal 2021.

site_title: US networks break from live Trump address due to 'lies'
summary: US TV networks abruptly ended live coverage of Donald Trump's address due to his claims of widespread voter fraud and "illegal votes." The networks, including MSNBC, NBC, and ABC News, concluded that Trump's statements were "lie after lie" with no evidence. The move came as late vote counting showed Democrat Joe Biden steadily closing in on victory. The networks' decision was met with criticism, with CNN's Jake Tapper calling Trump's claims "smears" with no basis in fact. The incident highlighted the networks' commitment to fact-based reporting.

images.alt_text: Several US TV networks late on Thursday halted live coverage of Donald Trump's first public appearance since election night after concluding that the president was spreading disinformation.

site_title: Airbnb plans to unveil financials next Thursday ahead of IPO
summary: Airbnb plans to release its financial documents and make them public for the first time next Thursday, ahead of its initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to raise up to $3 billion on the Nasdaq Global Select Market, with trading expected to begin in early December. Despite a tumultuous year, including the COVID-19 pandemic, Airbnb has bounced back and is now valued at $22 billion. The IPO would be one of the biggest listings this year, following Facebook's $16 billion IPO in 2012.

site_title: Driving corporate culture
summary: A company's corporate culture can significantly impact its performance, with notable failures in the banking industry and other sectors attributed to ethics and culture issues. To address this, boards must establish a monitoring system to track organisational culture and set a clear tone from the top. A statement of values should be articulated and consistently enforced, with training programs explaining key ethical principles and behaviours. The reward system should also be designed to incentivize desired behaviours, with mechanisms to reduce bonuses for unacceptable actions. Boards can delegate culture management to committees, and companies should consider including culture information in their annual reports.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% on Friday to 2,577.79, as local banks and other index counters opened weaker amid mixed business updates. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 61, while US stocks rose for a fourth straight session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gaining 2% each.

site_title: Japan's household spending, wages slump as Covid-19 pain lingers
summary: Japan's household spending fell 10.2% in September from a year earlier, marking the fourth largest drop on record, and real wages slid 1.1% for the seventh straight month. The decline is a sign of sluggish domestic demand, which may drag on any recovery in the world's third-largest economy. Authorities face a challenge in balancing the need to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic and reviving economic activity. The government is expected to announce fresh stimulus measures to cushion the blow from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending slumped in September from a year earlier and real wages slid for the seventh straight month, data showed on Friday, a sign sluggish domestic demand will continue to drag on any recovery in the world's third-largest economy.

site_title: Toyota to double full-year profit forecast to more than over 1t yen: media
summary: Toyota is expected to more than double its full-year operating profit forecast to over 1 trillion yen (S$13 billion) due to a rebound in vehicle sales in the US and China. The company's previous forecast was 500 billion yen, the weakest in nine years, following a pandemic-induced slump. This prediction surpasses analysts' average estimate of 1.25 trillion yen.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Hongkong Land, FLCT, SPH, Prime US Reit
summary: Singapore stocks experienced varied developments on Friday, with Jardine Matheson Holdings reporting declining Q3 profits, while Hongkong Land's full-year performance is expected to be moderately affected by a reduced contribution from its investment properties. Distribution per unit of Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust rose 5.5%, and Prime US Reit's net property income exceeded projections by 9.8%. Meanwhile, Singapore banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC climbed to multi-month highs after exceeding expectations with their Q3 financial results.

site_title: GIC, Thrive invest US$150m in IAC's video platform Vimeo
summary: IAC/InterActiveCorp is considering spinning off its stake in Vimeo, the online video platform, after securing US$150 million from Thrive Capital and Singapore's GIC at a US$2.75-billion valuation. Vimeo has seen a surge in demand for its platform during the lockdown, with shares rising 8.8% in extended trading. IAC CEO Joey Levin stated that a full spin-off would enable Vimeo with the complete suite of tools available in the public markets, although terms are yet to be decided. The move comes after IAC has spun off and listed several companies, including Match Group.

site_title: Australia says industry reports on China trade 'deeply troubling'
summary: Australia's trade minister Simon Birmingham expressed concerns over "deeply troubling" reports from industry that Chinese buyers have been told not to purchase seven categories of Australian produce, amid strained diplomatic relations between the two countries. The reports come after Beijing's anger towards Australia's call for an international inquiry into the coronavirus source and foreign interference investigations. The Australian government is closely monitoring trade flows and hopes Beijing will follow through on its statements denying discriminatory actions.

site_title: Australia: Shares eye best week in three as US election results trickle in
summary: Australian shares rose, heading for their biggest weekly gain in three, as investors awaited the US election results and a possible Joe Biden presidency. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.5% to 6,172.5, driven by gold and mining stocks, which surged 4.5% on a weaker dollar. A divided US Congress could hurt plans for higher corporate taxes, easing investor worries. The index is poised to gain about 4.2% for the week, with financial stocks also rising on Macquarie Group's first-half profit.

site_title: Trump administration advances US$2.9b drone sale to UAE: sources
summary: The US State Department has given Congress informal notification of a potential $2.9 billion sale of 18 armed aerial drones to the UAE. This move comes after the Trump administration reinterpreted a Cold War-era arms agreement to allow US defense contractors to sell more drones to allies. The sale, if approved, would be the first armed drone export under the new policy. The US Senate and House of Representatives committees have the ability to review and block the sale, which would require formal notification within 30 days.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 profit beats estimates; bank loans under moratorium fall
summary: OCBC's third-quarter net profit fell 12% to S$1.03 billion, beating analyst estimates. The bank's loan moratoriums declined significantly, from 10% in Q2 to 5% of total loan book, following the exit of Malaysia's debt-relief scheme. Net interest income fell 11% and allowances rose 8% year-on-year. OCBC maintains its 100-130 bps credit cost guidance and expects asset quality to stabilize. The bank's common equity tier 1 ratio stood at 14.4% in Q3, and it has no plans for mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: GM thinks bigger in China with plan to import full-size SUVs
summary: General Motors plans to import full-size SUVs to China for the first time, offering Chevrolet's Tahoe and Suburban, Cadillac's Escalade, and GMC Yukon Denali. The move aims to boost its brand image and support sales growth in the country's largest car market. GM's China chief, Julian Blissett, sees opportunities for these vehicles due to expanding Chinese families. The company will showcase the models at the China International Import Expo and is exploring online sales, leasing, and other market plans.

site_title: ByteDance rival Kuaishou Technology files for Hong Kong IPO
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a Chinese video-sharing startup and rival to ByteDance's TikTok, has filed an application for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) with joint sponsors Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, and China Renaissance Holdings. The proposed IPO could raise up to $5 billion, despite a significant net loss in the first half of the year. Kuaishou has 776 million average monthly active users and generates revenue through a cut of user tips. The filing comes as technology companies continue to pursue mega stock offerings in Hong Kong.

site_title: Trump claims he would win unless Democrats 'steal' election
summary: US President Donald Trump claimed Democrats are trying to "steal" the election by counting illegal votes, despite his team launching a "tremendous amount of litigation" to counter alleged corruption. Trump said he would "easily win" the election if legal votes were counted, but his reelection hopes hang by a thread as several officials in battleground states defend the vote's integrity.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell 'reluctant' to discuss elections
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell avoided commenting on the US election, focusing instead on the economy's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. Powell stated he is "reluctant" to discuss politics, emphasizing the Fed's central focus on supporting the economy. The Fed plans to use all its tools to aid the recovery, with potential further direct spending by Congress amid rising Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to a higher yen against the dollar, despite Wall Street rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.19% or 46.61 points to 24,058.67, while the Topix index edged down 0.18% or 2.94 points to 1,647.00. The US presidential election uncertainty also contributed to the market's decline.

site_title: SingPost H1 net profit falls 42.1% to S$30.9m despite higher revenue
summary: SingPost reported a 42.1% decline in net profit to S$30.9 million for the first half of the fiscal year, despite a 9.6% increase in revenue to S$707.8 million. The decline was attributed to higher international conveyance costs and labour-related expenses due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite strong e-commerce volume growth, margins were eroded by higher costs, and the group has declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share. CEO Paul Coutts warned that earnings and operating cash flows will continue to face headwinds from the pandemic.

site_title: US: Stocks extend post-election rally, Dow +2.0%
summary: US stocks extended their post-election rally, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.0% to 28,390.18, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 2.0% and 2.6%, respectively. Despite the presidential contest remaining unresolved, analysts attribute the rally to "fear of missing out" and anticipation of a divided Washington, which may hinder sweeping policy changes. Economic data showed new unemployment applications held steady at 751,000, while the US reported over 99,000 new coronavirus cases.

site_title: Bentley's luxury car range to be fully electric by 2030
summary: Bentley Motors, owned by Volkswagen, plans to transition its luxury car range to fully electric by 2030, with all models being plug-in hybrids or electric by 2026. The company aims to accelerate electrification as part of its "Beyond100" strategy and reduce its workforce by nearly a quarter. This move follows Volkswagen's return to profit and comes amid tightening emissions limits in Europe and China. Bentley CEO Adrian Hallmark sees the company transforming into a "new, sustainable, wholly ethical role model for luxury" within a decade.

site_title: Media 'decision desks' under fire as tight US vote count nears end
summary: US media outlets' "decision desks" are facing criticism for prematurely proclaiming Joe Biden the winner in Arizona, citing incomplete results. Fox News and the Associated Press made the call, but other organizations, including CNN, did not. The Trump campaign disputed the call, claiming the president remained in contention. Experts say the decision may have been premature, but Fox News defended its decision, citing Biden's large early lead. The Arizona call has sparked debate, with some media outlets and analysts cautioning about projecting winners due to the uncertainty of the vote count.

site_title: Divvying up Robinsons' space a better leasing option
summary: Singapore's prime retail spaces at The Heeren and Raffles City Shopping Centre may be split into smaller plots to attract brands, as the current Covid-19 crisis limits demand. The 85,000-sq ft Robinsons space and 186,000-sq ft flagship at The Heeren are prime, but expensive to rent, with average rents at S$20.25 psf and S$33.73 psf, respectively. Co-working space operators and online retailers may also pursue a "clicks-to-bricks" strategy, while landlords are exploring options to rethink mall positioning and theme.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust H2 DPU rises 5.5%
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a 5.5% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.65 Singapore cents, driven by nearly doubling revenue to a record S$213.3 million and 80.6% growth in adjusted net property income. The company's full-year DPU rose 7.12 cents, and distributable income grew 48.8% to S$201.1 million. Despite the pandemic's impact, FLCT's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 97.5% as of Sept 30.

site_title: Robinsons' staff payout capped at S$13,000
summary: Robinsons, a 162-year-old department store in Singapore, will liquidate its assets after Dubai-based Al-Futtaim Group decided to close the stores. Staff of around 170 employees will receive a capped payout of S$13,000, which is equivalent to five months' salary or the lesser of the two amounts, under the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA). Employees who are working to support the business during the liquidation period will be paid according to their employment agreement. The liquidators aim to preserve the value of assets and maximize returns to creditors, with shoppers rushing to the outlets after the news broke.

images.alt_text: Staff of Robinsons hoping for a huge payout from a retrenchment exercise may have to temper their expectations.

site_title: US coronavirus cases climb by record for second day in a row, up over 109,000
summary: US coronavirus cases surged by a record 109,757 on Thursday, marking the second consecutive day of record increases. Nineteen states reported record one-day increases, with the Midwest particularly hard hit. Hospitalizations rose to over 52,500 for the 11th consecutive day. The US average daily deaths are increasing, with six states reporting their highest one-day increases in pandemic deaths. The outbreak is putting pressure on hospitals and prompting families to rethink Thanksgiving plans.

site_title: 'Buy now, pay later' deals changing the landscape for lending
summary: "Buy now, pay later" deals are changing the lending landscape, offering interest-free instalment payments to those without or unable to get a credit card. Providers like Rely, hoolah, Atome, and Octifi offer easy-credit terms, posing risks for consumers and the business model. This shift is accessible to cash-strapped individuals, making big-ticket items more manageable.

site_title: Two Clarke Quay shophouses for sale with S$6.2m guide prices
summary: Two 99-year leasehold conservation shophouses in Clarke Quay, Singapore, have been put up for sale via private treaty with an indicative guide price of S$6.2 million per shophouse. The shophouses, located at 13 and 15 New Bridge Road, can be sold separately and have a total floor area of approximately 5,395 sq ft and 5,570 sq ft, respectively. They are zoned for commercial use and eligible for purchase by local and foreign buyers, with the option to increase the lease to a fresh 99 years subject to authorities' approval.

site_title: Biden on cusp of White House victory with key results due soon
summary: US President Joe Biden is on the cusp of securing the White House, solidifying his lead over President Donald Trump in key battleground states. With Pennsylvania set to release results, Biden is one or two states away from securing the majority needed to take the White House. Biden currently has 253 of 538 electoral votes, and a win in Pennsylvania would give him 20 more, taking him over the 270 needed for victory. Trump has claimed fraud and demanded a halt to vote counting, but his campaign's lawsuits have been dismissed, and election officials predict a winner will be determined by Thursday's close of business.

site_title: Jeep Gladiator review: Roamin' empire
summary: The Jeep Gladiator, a unique truck featuring a solid axle, is reviewed for its off-roading capabilities and comfort. Powered by a 289 horsepower V6 engine, it boasts a longer wheelbase and reinforced chassis, making it suitable for serious off-roading. The Gladiator offers a quiet cabin, Android Auto, and Apple CarPlay, despite its rugged appearance. Its price is S$159,999 without COE, making it a premium option in Singapore. With its blend of comfort and off-road capabilities, the Gladiator is a standout in the market.

site_title: Johnson appeals for unity as England enters new lockdown
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has appealed for unity as England enters a second lockdown, with 56 million people in the country facing renewed stay-at-home restrictions and business closures. The lockdown, which will last four weeks, aims to combat spiking coronavirus infection rates, but public support is mixed, with concerns about the economic and mental health impacts. Johnson promised that compliance could lead to a normal Christmas, while the government unveiled additional economic support measures, including £150 billion in aid for furloughed workers.

site_title: Europe: US election bets, earnings drive stocks to two-week high
summary: European stocks reached a two-week high, driven by strong quarterly earnings, fresh stimulus for Britain's economy, and post-election gains for Wall Street. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.1% and is on track for its best weekly showing in over six months. Technology stocks led the gains, followed by media, automakers, and chemical companies. Investors are optimistic despite uncertainty over the US presidential election outcome, citing a possible split Congress limiting tax increases under a Biden administration.

site_title: It's possible to be profitable and principled
summary: A dozen companies were called out for compliance fails in 2019, including Google, Facebook, and pharmaceutical companies, due to antitrust, privacy, and unethical practices. To prevent such issues, companies should design compensation systems that reward ethical behavior and sound decisions, rather than just outcomes. Organisations such as Google, Kellogg, and Xerox have shown that it is possible to be profitable and principled, with Google's motto "Don't be evil" aligning with its business practices and numerous environmental and employee benefits initiatives.

site_title: Biden says has 'no doubt' he will win US election
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed confidence in winning the 2020 presidential election, stating he has "no doubt" he will be declared the winner. Biden is leading President Donald Trump in the race for 270 electoral votes, with his campaign believing they have enough votes to win in key battleground states like Pennsylvania. Biden's comments came after a day of vote counting, with the outcome expected to be known "very soon."

site_title: Umami Records: Rocking across the globe
summary: Umami Records, a Singapore-based label, has gained international recognition for promoting unconventional indie music. Founded in 2013, the label has worked with over 50 artists, including local musicians and international acts. Its releases consistently garner tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands of streams, with some artists gaining significant followings in countries like Thailand, Taiwan, and Japan. The label's success is attributed to its efforts in promoting releases to streaming sites and collaborating with artists from around the world.

site_title: Biden gains ground in vote count as Trump mounts legal challenges
summary: US President Joe Biden edged closer to victory in the presidential election, with narrow leads in key states Nevada and Arizona. President Donald Trump filed lawsuits and called for recounts in Pennsylvania and Georgia, but Biden holds a 264-214 Electoral College vote lead. The outcome remains uncertain, with the Electoral College set to meet on December 14. Protests and arrests were reported in several cities, with Trump's supporters claiming fraud without evidence. Biden has predicted victory and launched a transition website, while Trump vows to fight the results in court.

site_title: Indonesia poised for next phase of structural transformation
summary: Indonesia is poised for its next phase of structural transformation, driven by deregulatory reform, the emerging digital economy, and cooperation with China. According to a Morgan Stanley report, the country's GDP growth is expected to reach 5.6% in 2021, driven by the Omnibus Law, digital economy growth, and increased cooperation with China. The country's emerging digital economy is expected to continue to grow, with e-commerce platforms empowering micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. Indonesia's strong relationship with China is also expected to catalyze reforms, with the two countries agreeing on bilateral trade and direct investment.

site_title: Uber reports US$1.1b loss on revenue plunge
summary: Uber reported a US$1.1 billion loss in the recently ended quarter due to a 53% decline in revenue from its ride-share business, but a significant boost in food delivery revenue. The company's mobility and delivery units are poised to benefit from returning pre-pandemic lifestyles. Despite this, Uber's shares fell nearly 3% after the earnings release. The company's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, expressed confidence in the company's ability to return to profitability as the "gig economy" model survives a key test in California with the approval of Proposition 22, which preserves the use of contractor-drivers.

site_title: Oil falls amid European lockdowns, US election uncertainty
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 1% on Thursday due to the rise in coronavirus infections and uncertainty over the US presidential election outcome. Brent crude settled at $40.93 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $38.79 a barrel, with the European Union's economic forecast revised downward. The European lockdowns and Brexit risks weighed on the market, with 1.5 million barrels per day of demand removed. The US presidential election outcome has yet to be decided, with Democratic candidate Joseph Biden predicting victory and President Donald Trump alleging fraud.

site_title: Who wants to be a US presidential election pundit?
summary: US presidential election pollsters and pundits were wrong in predicting a major electoral loss for incumbent President Donald Trump, with the actual result being a narrow margin of victory for Democratic candidate Joe Biden. Despite initial predictions of a double-digit lead for Biden, Trump maintained his support among white blue-collar workers and rural districts. The election results show Biden's electoral momentum driven by young voters, the college-educated, and minorities, expanding his electoral base. Trump's base remains solid, and the Democrats face a challenge in drawing them back into their fold.

site_title: Stirred, but not shaken as Singapore banks beat Q3 estimates
summary: Singapore banks have released their Q3 results, beating estimates despite a global health crisis. DBS and OCBC reported record fee-related income, while UOB's fee income rebounded 15% quarter-over-quarter. However, net profits fell 20%, 12%, and 40% respectively due to provisions for bad loans. The banks' cautious outlook remains, with DBS and OCBC keeping guidance on total allowances between $3 billion and $5 billion. Despite this, some worst fears of bad loans have been eased, with OCBC expecting no fresh wave of loan moratorium requests.

site_title: New Kia Sorento review: The art of the big deal
summary: The Kia Sorento is a mid-size SUV that offers a spacious cabin, rugged design, and advanced features at an affordable price. The 2020 edition builds on its predecessor's strengths, with a more powerful engine, increased cabin room, and improved handling. Despite its size, the Sorento is a capable and comfortable driver, with a smooth transmission and responsive suspension. The Tech Pack adds advanced safety features and premium touches, making the Sorento a strong contender in its class, rivaling luxury brands like Volvo. With prices starting at S$154,999, the Sorento offers a compelling value proposition for families and those seeking a reliable, feature-packed SUV.

site_title: Post-US election, markets to take cue from earnings, pandemic recovery
summary: Asian stocks registered gains on Thursday as Democratic challenger Joe Biden solidified his lead over President Donald Trump, with investors focusing on earnings growth driven by the COVID-19 recovery. Despite the US presidential election outcome, analysts expect the post-pandemic economic recoveries in Asia to remain on track, with projected growth rates of +7.0% yoy for Asia and +7.5% yoy for China in 2021. Earnings growth is expected to override the impact of the US presidency, with valuations at attractive levels and 20% profit growth anticipated.

site_title: South Korean try to cap surge of throwaway plastic
summary: South Korean environmental activists, Kim Yona and Lee Dong I, launched the "Plastic Mill" workshop in Seoul to tackle the surge of throwaway plastic caused by the novel coronavirus. The project collected 85,330 bottle caps from 2,000 volunteers, who received a reward of upcycled tube-squeezers. The activists aim to reduce plastic waste and promote reuse, but acknowledge that their project won't end the problem. The coronavirus has led to a 14.6% increase in plastic production in South Korea, and the recycling rate has fallen to 40.6% in 2019.

site_title: US dollar set for biggest 3-day drop since July
summary: The US dollar is poised for its largest 3-day drop in over 3 months, falling 0.5% to 92.93 against a basket of rivals, its lowest level in over a week. The decline is attributed to uncertainty surrounding the US presidential election outcome, with the dollar weakened by a broad-based decline in US Treasury yields and President Trump's attacks on vote counts. The euro and British pound also saw gains, with the euro rising to a 2-year high and the British pound breaking above $1.30.

site_title: Win or lose, here's what to drink as election day drags on
summary: Bartenders and wine experts share their preferred drinks for a hypothetical win or loss in the US presidential election. Some, like Lynnette Marrero, plan to celebrate with fine wines, while others, like Bobby Heugel, will opt for comforting martinis. If a candidate loses, many will reach for spirits to cope, such as whiskey, absinthe, or strong cocktails. The drinks vary widely, with some choosing to toast with champagne, rosé, or scotch, while others prefer to drown sorrows in whiskey or rum.

site_title: YZJ Shipbuilding secures new orders, reports 17% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured new orders for 34 vessels worth about US$1.03 billion in the year to date, with 10 firm orders and 24 option orders. The company reported a 17% fall in Q3 net profit to 585.2 million yuan, driven by a decline in trading revenue and fewer vessels delivered. Despite a weak market, the company's CEO expressed confidence in its order book and ability to capture business opportunities amid the pandemic. The company's share price remained unchanged at 94 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise for fourth straight month in October: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose for the fourth consecutive month in October, with 13 flats sold for more than S$1 million, according to SRX data. This marks the highest number of such transactions for a single month since June 2018. Total HDB resale flats sold for over S$1 million in the first 10 months of this year reached 59. Demand remains robust, with prices increasing by 1.2% month-on-month. Experts attribute the demand to the pandemic, with large resale flats, particularly well-located ones, being in high demand.

site_title: Get back in shape
summary: Two new medical treatments, ReduStim and DRx Medical Weight Loss Program, aim to help individuals get back in shape. ReduStim uses a low-frequency alternating Biomagnetic field to reduce visceral fat, which is associated with health problems such as cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. Patients can expect a one to two dress size reduction in 12 sessions. The DRx program involves a 360-degree approach, including diet, exercise, medications, and lifestyle changes, and offers a 10% weight reduction after three months.

site_title: CRCT proposes to buy five business parks, remaining stake in mall for 4.95b yuan
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) proposes to acquire five business park properties and a 49% stake in Rock Square mall in Guangzhou for approximately 4.95 billion yuan (S$1.01 billion). The acquisition is CRCT's largest to date and will increase its portfolio to 18 properties, with a gross floor area of about 1.8 million square meters. The trust expects to finance the acquisition through an optimal mix of debt, equity, and hybrid securities, with distribution per unit accretion anticipated. The acquisition is expected to be completed by Q1 2021, with a 51% interest in the Ascendas Xinsu portfolio in Suzhou and other strategic assets in Xian and Hangzhou.

site_title: New SingPass feature allows digital signatures for property caveats
summary: Singapore's national digital identity system SingPass has introduced a new feature called "Sign with SingPass" allowing digital signatures for property caveats. The feature, piloted by the Singapore Land Authority, enables users to sign documents virtually using their fingerprints or faces on smartphones. The signature is encrypted and linked to the signee's identity, validated against the Government's database. The service is available on all major platforms and is free for now, supporting the government's digital government blueprint to enable 90-95% of e-government transactions without leaving homes by 2023.

site_title: UK ramps up £200 billion rescue
summary: The UK has extended its £200 billion economic rescue programme, including the coronavirus furlough scheme, until the end of March to support businesses affected by the new lockdown. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak increased support for self-employed people and raised guaranteed funding for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The furlough policy will be reviewed in January to assess whether employers can increase their contributions.

site_title: Apple faces shortages in power chips for iPhone 12
summary: Apple is facing a shortage of power chips for the iPhone 12, which could limit its ability to meet holiday demand. The shortage, caused by increased demand for silicon and supply-chain disruptions, affects power management in the device, particularly due to its 5G capabilities and additional camera features. Suppliers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, are prioritizing Apple and its power-hungry iPhone 12 over other customers, and the shortage may persist over the next two quarters.

site_title: Biolidics seeking arbitration after Japanese partner makes counterclaim in patent dispute
summary: Biolidics, a Singapore-based medtech firm, has issued a notice of arbitration to Japan-based Sysmex Corporation after the latter raised a counterclaim in a patent dispute. The dispute centers on intellectual property obligations related to a 2016 agreement to jointly develop biochips. Biolidics claims Sysmex breached the agreement by filing patent applications without discussing them with the company first, while Sysmex alleges Biolidics also breached the agreement. Biolidics is seeking arbitration at the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre and wants Sysmex to deliver its background IP and refrain from using or disclosing Biolidics' IP.

site_title: Hong Kong homeowners fleeing Beijing's grip look to sell their properties
summary: Hong Kong homeowners are fleeing the city due to the recession and China's national security law, leading to a surge in property listings. The number of listings at Centaline Property Agency has jumped 44% from last year to over 26,000. Many residents are selling their properties to fund purchases in the UK, which offers a pathway to citizenship for eligible Hong Kong residents. Despite increased supply, resale home values have remained resilient, slipping less than 1% since the start of the year. The UK is the most popular destination for Hong Kong residents seeking an exit plan.

images.alt_text: Rising tensions over Beijing's new security law and worsening unemployment are driving up home listings.

site_title: Manulife US Reit occupancy drops to 94.3%
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 94.3% portfolio occupancy for the three months ended Sept 30, down from 95.3% in the previous quarter. This decline was attributed to expiries unrelated to the pandemic and a slowdown in new leasing. Despite this, rental collection remained high at 94% for the third quarter and 98% for the year to date. The Reit's balance sheet remains strong, and the manager has started negotiations for 2021 loans, aiming for cost savings and targeting high-growth sectors.

site_title: Alibaba fraternity stamps mark on top-end Singapore properties
summary: Alibaba member Yu Yongfu, a Singapore permanent resident, has purchased a 6,372 sq ft Hilltops penthouse in Cairnhill for S$26m, further solidifying the fraternity's presence in Singapore's high-end residential market. This marks the latest investment by a prominent Alibaba affiliate in the city-state's prime properties.

site_title: Behind the scenes at Jack Ma's US$35b IPO fiasco
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group IPO, valued at US$35 billion, was cancelled at the last minute after Chinese regulators expressed concerns about the company's financial conglomerate status and potential risks. The cancellation has raised concerns about China's commitment to transparency as it tries to lure international investors. The company's bankers scrambled for clarity from regulators, and Ant's shares tumbled 8% on Tuesday, cutting Ma's wealth by almost US$3 billion. The IPO debacle has also spillover effects on Hong Kong's status as a premier financial hub and may impact Ant's growth and valuation as the company adjusts to new regulations.

site_title: Indonesia sinks into first recession in over 20 years
summary: Indonesia has entered its first recession in over 20 years due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with its GDP shrinking 3.49% year-on-year in Q3. Household consumption and investment fell, and 2.6 million people lost jobs, pushing the unemployment rate to a nine-year high of 7.07%. The government has implemented stimulus measures, but economists call for more support to lift the economy. Indonesia's first recession since the 1998 Asian financial crisis is attributed to the country's struggles to contain the coronavirus outbreak and its high caseload and death toll in South-east Asia.

site_title: Scorched-earth strategic thinking for Covid-19 times
summary: A new approach to strategic leadership, dubbed "The Phoenix Encounter Method," has been developed to help companies navigate the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. This method involves a three-stage process: Groundwork, Battlefield, and Breakthrough, where a group of executives assess their organization's weaknesses, envision potential destruction, and develop a plan to rebuild and renew. The approach has been tested with over 1,500 senior executives and has resulted in fundamental changes to strategies of various organizations, including banks, healthcare providers, and retailers. By adopting this method, companies can accelerate their transformation and emerge stronger from the pandemic.

site_title: 2020 Audi RS 5 Sportback review: A revised rocket
summary: The Audi RS 5 Sportback has been updated with a revised design, featuring a more aggressive stance, grey paintwork, and optional 20-inch bronze wheels. The car's interior has also been updated with a cleaner cockpit layout, a 10.1-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and a digital instrument panel with a sport display. The RS 5 remains powered by a 2.9-litre V6 with 450hp, paired with Audi's all-wheel drive system. The update adds a more aggressive gearshift programme and optional sports exhaust, enhancing the car's performance and fun factor.

site_title: Tokyo 'clinic' stuffs toys with love
summary: A Tokyo clinic, the Natsumi Clinic, specializes in restoring beloved stuffed toys to their original condition, delighting owners who consider their toys as family members. Founded by Natsumi Hakozaki, the clinic offers treatments such as "eye surgery" and hair transplants, and has gained a reputation for its unique approach. The clinic has seen a surge in demand, with clients sending toys from around the world for treatment, and prices ranging from $130 to $500,000. The clinic's success has been met with emotional responses from owners, who consider their toys as having a "soul" that can be transferred into a new body.

site_title: Epigram Books: Championing regional talents
summary: Epigram Books, a small independent publisher in Singapore, has expanded its scope to publish fiction manuscripts from regional writers, awarding S$25,000 to the winner and S$5,000 to five other shortlisted writers. Founded in 2015, the Epigram Books Fiction Prize was initially open to Singaporean writers but has since been opened to the region. The publisher aims to promote English language fiction writing in South-east Asia, with plans to distribute titles in the region's capitals once logistics and exchange rates become more manageable.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Diwali celebrations kicked off at The Tiffin Room in Raffles Hotel Singapore with a new Diwali Experience menu showcasing North Indian cuisine. The S$88 set meal features dishes such as Dahi Puri and tandoori grilled pomfret fillet. Meanwhile, chef Sebastien Lepinoy at three Michelin-starred Les Amis created a customised olive oil blend, Château d'Estoublon Special Pour, to enhance his cuisine, available for retail sales at S$48 a bottle starting December 3.

site_title: New lockdowns, Brexit push Bank of England to ramp up stimulus again
summary: The Bank of England increased its bond-buying stimulus by £150 billion, raising its asset-purchase programme to £895 billion, to prepare for economic damage from new coronavirus lockdowns and Brexit uncertainty. The central bank cut its forecasts for Britain's economy, expecting it to surpass its pre-pandemic size only in the first quarter of 2022. The benchmark Bank Rate remained at 0.1% and the BoE kept its two-year inflation forecast unchanged at 2%. Sterling rose against the US dollar and euro after the announcements, while the economy is expected to shrink by 2% in the fourth quarter and 11% in 2020.

site_title: They came, they saw, but didn't shop much in Sept
summary: Singapore retail sales declined 10.8% year-on-year in September, underperforming expectations. This reversal comes after the previous two months' trend of lessening declines. Economists expect further declines to lessen in the last quarter as a modest recovery takes shape.

site_title: New York Times Q3 revenue beats estimates
summary: The New York Times reported beating Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue, with total revenue falling 0.4% to $426.9 million in Q3. This exceeded analysts' estimates of $411.8 million, attributed to increased digital subscriptions during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: DBS sees non-performing assets picking up in 2021; Q3 profit exceeds expectations
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender by assets, reported a 20% decline in net profit to S$1.3 billion in Q3, despite lower net interest income, due to a higher non-performing asset (NPA) formation. CEO Piyush Gupta attributed the rise in NPAs to "some episodic corporate stress" as government relief moratoriums expire in 2021. DBS maintains its guidance for total allowances of S$3 billion to S$5 billion, with a focus on fee income and other types of income to offset lower net interest margin.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open as Blue Wave risks fade
summary: Wall Street jumped at the open on Thursday as investors bet on a Republican-held Senate, which would block potential regulation and tax increases under a Biden administration. The Dow rose 0.85%, the S&P 500 gained 1.23%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.95%. The market optimism was despite the presidential election remaining too close to call, with investors prioritizing Senate control over election outcomes.

site_title: One Animation: Rapid growth in five years
summary: One Animation, a Singapore-based animation company, has experienced rapid growth over the past five years, with its flagship show Oddbods receiving three International Emmy nominations and scoring 10 awards. Since 2015, Oddbods' viewership has exploded, with a 12,000% increase in YouTube subscribers and the show now available on 110 platforms in 180 countries. One Animation has also expanded its merchandise and opened theme parks in China, with plans to develop a full-length animated feature, positioning itself as a potential rival to Pixar.

images.alt_text: One Animation's cartoon Oddbods is so popular, it has spawned toys, merchandise and two theme parks in China.

site_title: UG Healthcare's Q1 net profit jumps to S$22.7m from S$305,000
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation reported a 74-fold increase in its Q1 net profit to S$22.7 million, exceeding its FY2020 net profit of S$13.4 million. Revenue rose to S$71.2 million, driven by higher volume and average selling prices of gloves, as well as stronger demand in Europe, South America, Africa, and Asia. The company's gross margin improved to 60.6% and is on track to achieve its production capacity expansion plans.

site_title: STI joins global share rally as US election hangs in the balance
summary: Stock markets worldwide staged strong rallies amid the US election's uncertain outcome, with analysts accepting potential gridlock may hinder stimulus efforts. The outcome may also prevent the reversal of Trump's tax cuts. In contrast, the Bank of Singapore suggests this gridlock could make it harder to enact stimulus spending programmes.

site_title: Lloyd's of London ditches plan to create own electronic exchanges
summary: Lloyd's of London has abandoned plans to establish its own electronic exchanges, opting instead to collaborate with existing platforms to streamline the underwriting process and reduce costs. The 330-year-old market, which still relies on face-to-face trading, has seen increased electronic trading due to the pandemic. The decision comes as the market faces competition from lower-cost rivals.

site_title: An air of finesse at Fleurette
summary: Fleurette, a new restaurant in Singapore, boasts visual flair but lacks substance, with a high price tag to match. Chef Tariq Helou, a 26-year-old Lebanese-Japanese-Chinese Singaporean, delivers a curious hybrid of Japanese-Asian-French cuisine, but his dishes often feel one-dimensional and literal. Highlights include a refreshing prawn noodle dish and a deconstructed soba recipe, while others, such as oyster tartare and Hokkaido pumpkin soup, fall short. Despite its polished atmosphere, Fleurette's pricing and limited range of flavors raise questions about its potential for long-term success. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: All the requisite trappings of an 'it' restaurant - like a Zén-inspired foyer and high ceilinged dining area with stylish open kitchen and counter seating.
Oyster tartare - a pretty composition with a garnish of Polish caviar, chopped chives and flowers and finished off with crunchy buttered croutons.
Prawn noodle is refreshing, with dribbles of oil made from the prawn shells shining on the surface.
Fleurette-o-fish is Chef Helou's tribute to his favourite fast food. Deep-fried amadei fillet with its distinguishing standup scales - crispy and moist within.
The A5 Miyazaki wagyu is a predictable affair, slow-grilled on bincho and draped with kampot pepper sauce.

site_title: Lufthansa braces for 'challenging' winter
summary: Lufthansa posts a Q3 net loss of 2 billion euros due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the airline bracing for a "hard and challenging" winter. It plans to fly 25% of normal capacity from October to December and expects to burn 350 million euros in cash a month. CEO Carsten Spohr urges widespread rapid tests to reduce quarantines deterring travelers. The airline aims to return to positive operating cash flow in 2021, but only if capacity increases to 50% of pre-crisis levels.

site_title: IBM unveils cloud for 5G telcos, gets Nokia and Samsung as partners
summary: IBM has launched a cloud platform for 5G telcos, partnering with Nokia and Samsung. The cloud platform uses software to perform network functions, helping operators build 5G networks faster and reduce costs. The US government has pushed big US companies to get involved with 5G, which promises to enable various applications. The move aims to support the growth of 5G networks and provide customized services to business clients.

site_title: UK's Sunak boosts £200b jobs rescue
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak increased funding for the £200 billion economic rescue package, in coordination with the Bank of England, to combat rising job losses due to the coronavirus surge. This is Sunak's fourth major revision to his economic plans in six weeks, amidst criticism that he failed to plan ahead. The move aims to stem job losses and provide further support to businesses.

site_title: Liew Mun Leong's son charged over false evidence
summary: Karl Liew Kai Lung, son of Liew Mun Leong, has been charged with giving false statements in the 2018 case of Ms Parti Liyani, a former maid accused of theft. Liew allegedly lied on oath that a cream-coloured poloT-shirt and a red blouse belonged to him. If convicted, he faces mandatory imprisonment. This development comes as the saga of his father's accusations continues.

site_title: Prime US Reit's Q3 net property income exceeds IPO projections
summary: PRIME US Reit reported a net property income of US$24.2 million in Q3, exceeding IPO projections by 9.8%. Gross revenue also outperformed forecasts by 9.1%, while distributable income exceeded projections by 15.4%. Strong rental collections and robust leasing activity contributed to the results.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall marginally
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 751,000 for the week ended Oct 31, down from 758,000 in the prior week, but remained high amid ongoing pandemic and fiscal stimulus end. Economists forecast 732,000 applications. The economy's recovery may be uncertain due to the presidential election outcome, potentially delaying a second coronavirus relief package.

site_title: Offer incentives to create change from within
summary: Business leaders are being urged to create opportunities for young entrepreneurs within their companies, rather than relying on management to rescue struggling sectors. Establishing starter funds for new ideas and allowing employees to own intellectual property can encourage innovation and prevent over-bureaucratic businesses. Internal competition and empowering employees to take charge can also drive growth and efficiency. By giving young talent the freedom to experiment and innovate, companies can stay ahead of the competition and adapt to changing market forces.

site_title: HSBC to cut around 100 jobs in UK retail bank
summary: HSBC to cut around 100 jobs in its UK retail banking business as part of a restructuring effort, following a similar move in its commercial banking business. The job cuts are in line with the bank's February strategy to transform its operations. This move is part of HSBC's broader efforts to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: China bars travellers from Britain, Belgium, India as global coronavirus cases surge
summary: China has imposed entry restrictions on non-Chinese travelers from Britain, Belgium, India, and the Philippines, effective immediately. The restrictions apply to those with valid visas and residence permits and coincide with enhanced testing requirements for arrivals from other countries. The move was met with concern from the British Chamber of Commerce in China, which expressed a need for further clarification on lifting the ban. The move aims to curb the spread of the coronavirus amidst a global surge in cases.

images.alt_text: China has barred non-Chinese travellers from Britain, Belgium, the Philippines and India, imposing some of the most stringent entry curbs of any country as global coronavirus cases surge.

site_title: Denmark's mink cull a 'black day' for farmers
summary: Denmark's government has ordered the culling of all 17 million minks to prevent the spread of a mutated coronavirus strain. The move, which could cost over $800 million, comes after health authorities discovered the strain in the animals and people. The industry association has called the decision a "black day" for Denmark, predicting economic collapse and the end of the country's pelt industry. Stricter lockdown measures have also been implemented in the north of the country to prevent human contagion.

site_title: Bombardier profit misses as pandemic weighs on transportation unit, jet deliveries
summary: Bombardier reported a third-quarter profit miss due to the pandemic's impact on its transportation and aviation units. Revenue from its transportation unit fell 2.5% and business jet deliveries decreased to 24 units, down from 31 last year. However, revenue from its business segment rose 10% due to the delivery of its flagship Global 7500 jet. The company is in the process of selling its rail division to Alstom.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Karl Liew Kai Lung, son of former Changi Airport Group chairman Liew Mun Leong, was charged with two offenses on Thursday for allegedly giving false statements in a theft case involving an Indonesian maid formerly employed by his father. The maid had been accused of theft, but Liew Kai Lung's statements are believed to have influenced the outcome of the case. The charges are related to the maid's employment by his father's company.

site_title: SPH subsidiaries' hearing date for interim JM application extension fixed for Feb 1, 2021
summary: SPH's subsidiaries, StreetSine Technology Group and StreetSine Singapore, have an interim judicial management order against them. The hearing date for applications to extend this order has been fixed for February 1, 2021. The order was initially made on June 22, and the Singapore High Court adjourned the hearing on October 29. SPH will keep shareholders informed of the matter's progress.

site_title: The connected cars of the future are all talk and some action
summary: Carmakers are racing to integrate into digital lifestyles, with connected cars potentially offering personal assistants. The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated digitalization, and carmakers have been working on inserting themselves into users' digital lives. While some cars may soon offer features like traffic advice and route optimization, the technology is still in its infancy, and the industry is struggling to deliver on its promises. Currently, cars are more about style and luxury than functionality, with many users unaware of the features being developed.

site_title: Jardine Matheson's Q3 net profit improves from Q2, but down compared with 2019
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported declining net profits in Q3 2020, down compared to 2019 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. However, some businesses saw improvement, including Jardine Pacific, Gammon Construction, and Jardine Motors. Others, such as Jardine Aviation Services, Jardine Strategic, and Mandarin Oriental, were significantly affected. Dairy Farm showed better performance, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage's performance was still impacted by challenging trading conditions.

site_title: Pope shakes up running of Vatican funds after London property scandal
summary: Pope Francis has stripped the Vatican's Secretariat of State of control over its funds, moving them to the supervision of its economic offices amid a scandal over a luxury London property deal. The investigation led to the suspension of five Vatican employees, the resignation of its police chief, and the exit of the former head of its Financial Information Authority. This move aims to contain the fallout from the scandal and restore transparency in the Vatican's financial management.

site_title: Hope yet for KL KidZania as Sim Leisure Group proposes RM3.8m offer
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a theme park developer, has proposed an RM3.8 million (S$1.2 million) offer to acquire KidZania's operator, Rakan Riang Sdn Bhd (RRSB), in Kuala Lumpur. The acquisition is pending approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and would allow Sim Leisure to avoid shareholder approval and independent valuation. RRSB recorded a pre-tax loss of RM1.4 million last year and RM4 million for the first half of this year.

site_title: Britain's most fashionable man? Vogue hails Prince Charles
summary: Prince Charles, 71, has been hailed as Britain's most fashionable man by Vogue editor-in-chief Edward Enninful. Enninful praised Charles' timeless dress sense, noting his preference for double-breasted suits with a tie and matching handkerchief. The praise came as a surprise to Charles, who is known for patching up and mending his clothes. The recognition highlights Charles' enduring style, which has been a subject of admiration for years.

site_title: Hongkong Land expects full-year performance to be 'moderately affected'
summary: Hongkong Land expects its full-year performance to be moderately affected by reduced contributions from its investment properties portfolio, primarily due to pandemic-related construction delays and adverse market conditions. The company's Hong Kong Central office portfolio saw negative rental reversions, while its Singapore office portfolio experienced positive reversions. Development properties in mainland China benefited from a market rebound, with attributable interest in contracted sales increasing to US$639 million in Q3. Hongkong Land's financial position remains strong, with net debt at US$4.7 billion and committed liquidity at US$4 billion.

site_title: Diversity is good business
