Futures on the Nasdaq 100 Index jumped 2.8% on Trump's prospects, while the US dollar surged as safe-haven buyers sought refuge. Analysts expect a volatile period, with a potential Biden presidency and Republican Senate leading to gridlock in Washington, delaying economic relief and market stability.

site_title: Twitter, Facebook suspend some accounts as US election misinformation spreads online
summary: Twitter and Facebook suspended several right-leaning news accounts for spreading misinformation about the US election, including claims of voting fraud and delays. Twitter suspended accounts with over 78,000 followers, while Facebook suspended accounts with over 20,000 followers, citing inauthentic behavior. Despite these actions, false reports continued to circulate, with some coming from official Republican accounts and online publications. The FBI and New York attorney general are investigating mysterious robocalls urging people to stay home. Social media companies claim these efforts were coordinated to deliberately blow out-of-proportion problems.

site_title: SIA Engineering to invest S$40m over next three years in digitalisation
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) plans to invest S$40 million over the next three years in digitalization efforts, including automation and data analytics, to boost its digital readiness and competitiveness. The company is restructuring its joint venture portfolio to curb losses and streamline operations, including selling its stake in Aviation Partnership (Philippines) Corp to Cebu Air. Despite concerns over losing contracts, SIAEC is seeing increased third-party work from other airlines in Clark, Philippines. The company booked a net loss of S$19 million in the first half of the fiscal year 2020/21, but is supported by government grants.

site_title: Ant's Asean ambitions may take backseat to battles at home
summary: China's tightening control of fintech companies has raised concerns about Ant Group's expansion plans in South-east Asia. The fintech giant's US$34 billion IPO was suspended amid regulatory concerns, and analysts expect it to put its global ambitions on hold to focus on domestic compliance issues. China's draft rules on online micro-lending may impose stricter capital requirements and operational rules on Ant's consumer credit businesses, limiting its expansion capacity. Analysts suggest that Ant may benefit from clearer regulation, which could give it more room to plan for future expansion in South-east Asia.

site_title: Ten ways coronavirus crisis will shape world in long term
summary: COVID-19 has had a profound impact on the world, causing 1.1 million deaths worldwide and a global recession. The crisis has highlighted the world's inability to cope with a pandemic, with varying degrees of success across countries. The pandemic has also led to economic damage, particularly among the young, unskilled, and vulnerable minorities, and has called into question globalization and global supply chains. Its long-term consequences are uncertain, but may include changes in business, economy, domestic politics, and international relations, with some changes already being seen, such as the rise of stablecoins and a shift in US foreign policy.

site_title: Asian markets resilient as hopes for a blue wave fade
summary: Asian markets displayed resilience on Wednesday as they moved away from initial hopes of a "blue wave" and towards a possible "Trump trade" amid the US election. Markets in Singapore, Japan, China, and Taiwan advanced between 0.2% and 1.7% despite the uncertainty, while indices in Hong Kong and Australia closed in the red. Oil prices rose over 2%, and gold traded lower. Analysts warn that the markets' subdued response may not last if the election results are disputed or if a decisive winner is not clear, and that a divided Congress could constrain pandemic recovery packages and fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Second lockdown may be final straw for English pubs
summary: English pubs may be forced to close permanently due to the second lockdown. The country's pubs are closing for a month, following a move to reduce novel coronavirus cases. Pub owners and industry organizations are concerned, citing the financial strain from the first lockdown. This may be the final straw for many pubs, which have struggled to recover.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AEM Holdings has raised its FY2020 revenue guidance to between S$500 million and S$520 million based on sales order visibility and business outlook. The company's revenue for the fiscal third quarter ended Sept 30 nearly doubled year on year. This upward revision follows a previous announcement in September, which set the FY2020 revenue guidance between S$480 million and S$500 million.

site_title: Ant's foiled IPO: Taming of Jack Ma or urgent need to rein in fintechs?
summary: China has blocked Ant Group's US$35 billion IPO, citing concerns that the fintech may not meet listing qualifications and disclosure rules. The decision came after Ant's advertisements were removed from billboards in Shanghai Metro stations, reportedly promoting unwelcome consumption values. This move is seen as a setback for Jack Ma's Ant Group, which had aimed for a dual listing on China's Shanghai Star Market and Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The Chinese government's action has raised questions about its approach to regulating fintechs.

site_title: M&S slides to first loss in 94 years as Covid-19 hits clothing sales
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) reported its first loss in 94 years due to a £17.4 million pretax loss before one-off items in the 26 weeks to Sept 26, 2020, impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. This marks a significant decline from the company's previous performance. The clothing sales were particularly affected, leading to the loss. M&S has struggled to recover from the pandemic's impact on the retail industry, and this loss is a concerning sign for the company's future.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's Q3 DPU rises 7.4% to 3.54 cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit's third quarter distribution per unit (DPU) rose 7.4% to 3.54 Singapore cents, up from 3.3 cents in the same period last year. On an annualised basis, the DPU increased 7.4% to 14.16 Singapore cents. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year.

site_title: GIC-backed SpaceDC launches premium data centre in Jakarta
summary: GIC-backed SpaceDC has launched JAK2, a 1.45 MW premium data centre in Jakarta, Indonesia, marking the company's first data centre. Certified as a Tier III facility by Uptime Institute, JAK2 requires no shutdowns for maintenance or replacement. The launch is part of a partnership between SpaceDC and GIC, positioning the facility as a key player in the South-east Asia market.

site_title: Phase 3 could last for a year or more: Gan
summary: Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stated that Phase 3 of Singapore's reopening could last more than a year, as it aims to establish a new normal rather than returning to pre-Covid status. The reopening phase is not expected to be lifted until the rest of the world has the virus under control or effective treatments/vaccines are widely available.

images.alt_text: "Our objective in Phase Three is to reach a steady state of permitted economic and social activities until an effective vaccine or treatment is widely available," says Mr Gan.

site_title: SK Hynix expects server demand to remain soft
summary: SK Hynix, the world's No 2 memory chip maker, expects server demand to remain weak due to a lack of significant growth in the industry. However, the company anticipates a boost in mobile demand in the current quarter due to Chinese smartphone vendors building up inventory to gain market share against Huawei, which faces US restrictions. This shift is expected to impact the company's revenue and profits.

site_title: AG did not know of proceedings against Parti before case went to court
summary: The Attorney-General of Singapore, Lucien Wong, revealed that he was unaware of the investigations against Parti Liyani before the case went to trial. The prosecution's knowledge of the case was initially limited to the police and the Home Affairs Ministry's senior management. This information came to light during the trial, highlighting a lack of transparency in the government's handling of the case. The exact reasons for the lack of knowledge remain unclear.

site_title: Mattress suppliers will honour customer orders from Robinsons
summary: Three mattress suppliers, Simmons, Sealy Singapore, and King Koil, will honour customer orders despite not being paid by Robinsons Singapore, which has gone into liquidation. Simmons stated they will deliver goods to customers who have paid in full to Robinsons, showing appreciation for customer loyalty and support. The move aims to alleviate customer distress and anxiety caused by the liquidation.

site_title: American companies add fewer jobs than forecast, ADP report shows
summary: US companies added fewer jobs than forecast in October, with 365,000 new hires, according to the ADP Research Institute. This was weaker than expected and below the median projection of 643,000. The slower hiring pace is attributed to the ongoing pandemic's impact on the service industry, particularly travel, hotels, and restaurants. The figures underscore the need for lawmakers to agree on additional fiscal assistance to support affected businesses and keep employees on payrolls.

site_title: Parti Liyani's investigation and prosecution not influenced by anyone: Shanmugam
summary: LAW and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam stated that the investigation and prosecution of Indonesian maid Parti Liyani were not influenced by anyone. He chronicled the investigation into her alleged theft from Liew Mun Leong, the former chairman of Changi Airport Group, and the subsequent prosecution of the case. Shanmugam's comments were made during a Parliament session.

site_title: Either Trump or Biden will win - but our deepest problems will remain
summary: The US presidential election may not resolve the country's deep-seated problems, which include social crisis, isolation, and despair. Instead, the root causes lie in failures of responsibility, cultural divisions, and a lack of solidarity. Local and state government, as well as civil society, hold the key to addressing these issues. The solution begins with individual actions, such as taking responsibility for one's role in institutions and prioritizing solidarity. By focusing on communal and interpersonal levels, Americans can work together to heal what is broken and create a more cohesive society.

site_title: Floating farms are a prelude to floating cities
summary: Floating farms can secure coastal cities' food supply chains and pave the way for sustainable floating cities. Rising sea levels and population growth make this a crucial step. Singapore, aiming to source 30% of its nutritional needs domestically by 2030, can test floating farms for aquaculture or agriculture. Currently, 9% of fish consumed in Singapore come from offshore farms, but they are cheaply designed and not optimized for large-scale production, exposing them to environmental threats. This concept could lead to the development of sustainable floating cities, addressing food security and environmental concerns.

site_title: US: Wall St gains as election hangs in balance
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as investors waited anxiously for the outcome of the presidential election, despite concerns over a potentially contested result. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all opened higher, with gains of 0.12%, 1.11%, and 2.54%, respectively. Despite uncertainty, investors appear to be optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Suspension won't be a dead Ant for world's biggest IPO
summary: ANT Group Co's $35 billion IPO has been suspended due to a "change in regulatory environment." The halt is a result of regulators asserting that the company prioritizes finance over technology, as seen with its fintech peers. Founder Jack Ma and Chinese regulators agree that finance and technology make for a powerful combination, but Ant's approach has raised concerns. The company must adapt to provide at least 30% of funding for loans to avoid being labeled as a financial institution rather than a tech company.

site_title: MAS boosts enforcement efforts, but some gaps still need plugging
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is increasing its focus on early detection of market misconduct and resolving cases more swiftly. Despite efforts to boost enforcement, gaps remain in addressing corporate disclosure breaches involving listed firms and their officers. The MAS's latest enforcement report highlights the regulator's actions between January 2019 and June 2020, but the complexity of financial misconduct and sophistication of breaches indicate ongoing challenges.

images.alt_text: For the 18 months ended June 2020, criminal prosecutions took an average of 24 months compared with 33 months in the previous reporting period, and civil ones 26 months versus 30 months previously.

site_title: US vote result won't impact trade with Europe: France
summary: France's finance chief Bruno Le Maire stated that the US presidential vote outcome will have little impact on US-Europe trade relations, as the US has taken a confrontational stance regardless of the winner. The US has imposed billions of dollars' worth of tariffs on European imports, and Le Maire views Europe as an "adjustment variable" for the US, with its strategic focus on China. The US administration's trade policies remain unchanged, with Europe being seen as a secondary priority.

site_title: UOB Q3 profit down 40% as provisions climb
summary: UOB's net profit dropped 40% in Q3 due to increased provisions for bad loans. The bank has set aside more provisions than necessary to cover potential future losses, particularly with automatic moratoriums ending in Singapore and Malaysia. Despite this, UOB remains confident in its ability to withstand further loan defaults, citing strong provisions.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 earnings rise 40% to S$287.9m on higher valuation of investments
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 40% rise in net profit to S$287.9 million for Q3, driven by higher valuation of investments and improved financial market conditions. Operating profit slipped 4% to S$171.4 million due to greater new business strain. Non-operating profit reversed from a loss to S$50 million. Total weighted new sales grew 36% to S$432.8 million, and new business embedded value edged up 2% to S$160.2 million. The company's focus on strengthening distribution capabilities contributed to the results.

site_title: T-Mobile to pay US$200m fine to resolve FCC subsidy investigation
summary: T-Mobile has agreed to pay a US$200 million penalty to resolve an FCC investigation into its subsidiary Sprint's failure to comply with Lifeline subsidy rules. The probe found Sprint claimed subsidies for 885,000 subscribers who weren't using the service. The settlement resolves allegations that Sprint misled the FCC and failed to accurately report subscriber information. The fine is a result of Sprint's pre-merger practices, and the issue is separate from T-Mobile's acquisition of Sprint.

site_title: India's central bank exploring investment options for reserves, sources say
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is exploring investment options for its $560.63 billion foreign exchange reserves, driven by falling global interest rates due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The central bank is likely to increase its gold investments and buy US dollars, while also considering investing in AAA-rated corporate bonds for the first time. The RBI aims to maintain a 73-75 per dollar range for the rupee, despite a contraction in India's GDP. This move is seen as a response to the country's strong stock market and foreign investment flows, which have remained healthy despite a global economic downturn.

site_title: Biden or Trump, there's no reset for US-Asia policy
summary: US presidential election uncertainty will not lead to a reset in US-Asia policy, with trade tariffs and supply chain shifts likely to persist. The Republican-controlled Senate and Democratic-controlled House may hinder significant legislation, forcing the president to rely on executive orders. Tense US-China ties and trade tensions will continue to affect the region, with cooperation between the two nations seen as crucial to regional success. A change in US leadership is expected to be incremental, with both Democratic candidate Joe Biden and incumbent Donald Trump taking a hard line on China, leading to continued global trade tensions.

site_title: Bankers reel as Ant IPO collapse threatens US$400m payday
summary: Bankers are facing a significant financial hit after Ant Group Co's initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong and Shanghai was abruptly derailed days before its scheduled trading debut. The deal, which was expected to generate an estimated US$400 million in fees for banks, has left dealmakers reeling and uncertain about the future. Despite the unexpected drama, financial professionals believe the impact on the broader IPO market is minimal, and the issue is likely to be resolved soon.

site_title: PDPA amendments could spur innovation in Singapore
summary: Singapore has passed amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), allowing companies to leverage customer data for innovation purposes while maintaining safeguards. The amendments, passed on November 2, 2020, introduce data portability, enabling data subjects to determine how their data can be reused or transferred. The Personal Data Protection Commission aims to develop technical standards for data portability, providing a more concrete approach than the EU's GDPR. The changes are expected to spur innovation in Singapore, with the government emphasizing the need for safeguards to protect personal data.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's wealth fund invests in SoftBank-backed tech startup
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment led a $700 million funding round for Reef Technology, a startup managing parking lot hubs for food delivery and Covid-19 testing. Reef was valued at $1 billion after SoftBank acquired a stake in 2018. This investment diversifies Mubadala's portfolio away from oil, as the fund seeks to boost its technology investments. Mubadala also plans to invest $2 billion in a technology fund and has invested in other companies, including Silver Lake and Evotec, to lessen its reliance on crude and help diversify its economy.

site_title: UK heading for double-dip recession this winter
summary: The UK is expected to enter a double-dip recession this winter, according to business surveys. The IHS Markit/CIPS services PMI fell to a four-month low of 51.4 in October, indicating the service sector was close to stalling before the latest lockdown was announced. The new orders component in the services PMI fell sharply, and businesses shed jobs for the eighth month in a row. Economists predict a 3% reduction in output for the fourth quarter and a challenging path to recovery in 2021, with hopes of a V-shaped recovery considered "dead and buried."

site_title: STI closes 0.75% higher at 2,515.98, with US vote count underway
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.75% higher at 2,515.98, despite concerns over a divided US Congress and potential delays in a pandemic recovery package. Key players like Mapletree Industrial Trust, Singtel, and Mapletree Logistics Trust led the gains, while Sembcorp Industries and Capital Integrated Commercial Trust declined. The US presidential election vote count is underway, casting a shadow over market expectations.

site_title: Lloyds cuts 1,070 jobs
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is cutting 1,070 jobs, while also creating 329 roles, according to union Unite. The move has been met with criticism from Unite, which questioned the bank's decision to reduce staff despite their commitment and dedication during the global pandemic. Lloyds has not commented on the matter.

site_title: When group hugs are smart...
summary: A successful business strategy for local creative businesses is embracing diversity and inclusivity, resulting in global success. Companies like One Animation, Umami, and Epigram have achieved this by incorporating culturally sensitive storylines, collaborating with talent from diverse backgrounds, and expanding their author pool. This approach has led to increased success, such as One Animation's 20 billion views for its children's show Oddbods. By prioritizing diversity and inclusivity, businesses can reap long-term benefits and establish a strong social definition of their brand.

site_title: Ant would need 95b yuan in capital to comply with draft lending curbs
summary: China's regulatory commission plans to discourage lenders from using Ant Group's credit platforms, which would render many of the company's existing transactions non-compliant. Ant would need to set aside 95 billion yuan in capital to comply with the draft regulations, equivalent to 2.7 times its current capital. The move aims to align Ant's business model with regulations and lower borrowing costs for the economy. The halt on Ant's US$35 billion IPO is part of a broader campaign to rein in the fintech empire controlled by Jack Ma, following his comments on the nation's financial system and global regulatory models.

site_title: KGB Museum closes; lipstick gun and other spy relics go on sale
summary: The KGB Espionage Museum in New York City, which featured a collection of over 3,500 Cold War relics, is closing permanently due to the pandemic. The museum, which opened less than two years ago, will put its entire collection up for auction, estimated to fetch anywhere from a few hundred dollars to $12,000. The collection includes items such as a lipstick gun, a replica of an umbrella with a hidden poison needle, and a bronze desk lamp believed to have been used by Josef Stalin. The museum's closure comes after criticism for its apolitical stance and lack of recognition as other Manhattan museums.

site_title: Thai protesters spurn reconciliation panel plan to ease tensions
summary: Thai pro-democracy activists have rejected a parliament-initiated plan to form a reconciliation committee, calling it a "political ploy to buy time." The protesters reiterated their demand for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's immediate resignation, citing that a committee would be meaningless without his departure. The youth-led protest groups have been holding daily demonstrations in Bangkok and other cities for three weeks, opposing the monarchy's reform. The parliament plans to deliberate a referendum on charter amendment, with Prayuth open to changing parts of the constitution and limiting Senate power.

site_title: Uber, Lyft win California bid to keep drivers as contractors
summary: Uber and Lyft have won a California ballot measure that will exempt gig-economy companies from a state law requiring most workers to be classified as employees. The measure, Proposition 22, passed with 58% of the vote, allowing companies to continue using independent contractors. Drivers will receive new benefits, such as a health insurance stipend and minimum hourly earnings, but won't be eligible for full employment benefits and protections. The companies will save an estimated $100 million a year in employment costs, and the decision is seen as a significant victory for the ride-hailing industry.

site_title: California projected to pass proposition to treat Uber drivers as contractors
summary: California voters have projected to pass Proposition 22, which would cement the status of Uber drivers as independent contractors, not employees. The measure, backed by Uber and its allies, aims to ensure flexibility for gig workers and provide modest benefits, including minimum pay and healthcare subsidies. The outcome is seen as a significant win for the gig economy and a setback for labor groups, who argued that drivers should be classified as employees.

site_title: GIC-backed SpaceDC launches data centre in Jakarta
summary: SpaceDC, backed by GIC, has launched JAK2, a 1.45 MW premium data centre in Jakarta, Indonesia, catering to the South-east Asia market. Certified as a Tier III facility, it offers 99.982% availability and features smart green features, dedicated staging and storage rooms, and office spaces. The facility provides "Smart Hands" service for companies to remotely set up and manage their operations. A larger, 24 MW Tier III facility, JAK1, is also under construction, set to launch in 2021. This marks SpaceDC's first data centre, expanding its presence in the region.

site_title: CapitaLand promotes spirit of volunteerism among its employees
summary: CapitaLand promotes volunteerism among its employees through various initiatives, including the International Volunteer Expedition (IVE) programme, which allows staff to volunteer on paid leave. The company's philanthropic arm, CapitaLand Hope Foundation, supports vulnerable children, elderly, and healthcare workers. Since 2006, CapitaLand employees have volunteered over 170,000 hours in Asia and beyond, and the company has contributed more than S$8 million globally to support over 55,000 people. CapitaLand's efforts have earned it recognition as a "Champion of Good" and it was named one of the five winners of the "Organisation of Good" award at the President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards 2020 Special Edition.

site_title: Here's how Ant can rise again after that IPO shock
summary: China's Ant Group, a fintech giant, faces a crucial test after the suspension of its US$35 billion IPO in Shanghai and Hong Kong. Founder Jack Ma and regulators agree that finance and technology make a powerful combination, but the government is cracking down on Ant's dominance, citing concerns over power over the nation's financial levers. Ant is likely to be forced to make changes to its business model, potentially including increased capital requirements and greater access to its data, as part of Beijing's efforts to roll out a central bank cryptocurrency and expand the surveillance state.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.16 points to 1,464.61. The market saw 702 gainers for every 377 losers, with a total trading volume of 7.304 billion lots worth RM3.361 billion.

site_title: China's Fosun Kicks off biggest pharma IPO in India
summary: China's Fosun Pharma is set to raise up to $1.18 billion in India's largest pharmaceutical IPO, surpassing Eris Lifesciences' 2017 offering. Fosun acquired a 74% stake in Gland Pharma in 2017 for $1.1 billion. The IPO will consist of 43.2 million shares marketed at 1,490-1,500 rupees each, with Citigroup, Haitong Securities, Kotak Mahindra Bank, and Nomura Holdings arranging the deal. The offering is expected to list in Mumbai on November 20.

site_title: Poland to announce new restrictions to curb Covid-19
summary: Poland is set to announce new COVID-19 restrictions, including limiting social contacts, after the country reported a record 21,897 daily cases. The government aims to avoid a total lockdown and has already closed bars and restaurants, and limited swimming pool operations. The move comes as Poland runs out of hospital beds, ventilators, and oxygen, and amid concerns about the impact on protests against a near-total abortion ban. The government seeks to balance controlling the pandemic with avoiding further restrictions.

site_title: US service sector cools in October
summary: The US services industry activity slowed in October, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index falling to 56.6 from 57.8 in September. This marks the first time the index has fallen below 57.3 since February, indicating a moderation in growth. The slowdown is attributed to concerns about ebbing fiscal stimulus and a resurgence in COVID-19 cases, which may lead to re-imposed restrictions and a further decline in spending. Economists expect a sharp slowdown in economic growth in the fourth quarter due to these factors.

site_title: BMW Q3 profit rebounds on China demand for luxury cars
summary: BMW reported a 9.6% increase in third-quarter pretax profit to 2.46 billion euros, driven by a 31% surge in deliveries in China and a 9.8% increase in BMW-branded vehicle deliveries globally. The company attributed the recovery to rebounding Chinese demand for luxury cars, despite a 15.7% drop in US demand due to the pandemic. BMW reiterated its 2020 Ebit margin outlook of 0-3% for the automotive segment, citing high risk due to the pandemic's resurgence.

site_title: EGMs, scheme meeting for proposed Sabana-ESR merger to convene on Dec 4
summary: Singapore's ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit will hold their proposed merger's extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) on Dec 4. The scheme meeting for Sabana Reit will also take place on the same date. The joint statement from the managers of both Reits did not specify the agenda for the meetings. The merger aims to create a larger industrial real estate investment trust. The exact outcome of the EGMs and scheme meeting is yet to be determined.

site_title: Seven new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with five imported and none in the community
summary: There were seven new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, bringing the total to 58,036, with five imported and two from worker's dormitories. All five imported patients tested positive on Tuesday and had been placed on stay-home notices. One patient has been discharged, and 57,923 have fully recovered. Globally, the virus outbreak has infected over 47 million people and claimed more than 1.2 million lives.

site_title: No clear visibility to 'end of tunnel' after new lockdowns: Credit Agricole
summary: France's second-largest bank, Credit Agricole, reported an 18.5% drop in third-quarter profit to 977 million euros, in line with expectations. The bank attributed the drop to higher provisions for bad loans, but said the government's stimulus helped stabilize the risk environment. Despite a second wave of lockdowns, Credit Agricole's chief financial officer believes provisions will not increase, and the bank is well-positioned to help the economy recover. The bank's revenue rose 2.4% to 5.15 billion euros, driven by strong performance in capital markets.

site_title: Mattress suppliers say they will honour Robinsons customers' orders; hundreds affected
summary: Three mattress suppliers, Simmons, Sealy Singapore, and King Koil, have announced they will honour orders from Robinsons customers despite the company's liquidation. Simmons will absorb over S$1 million in costs and contact customers for delivery, while Sealy and King Koil will also fulfill orders with no additional payment required beyond a S$50 delivery fee. The decision comes after Robinsons' closure resulted in hundreds of customers paying for mattresses that were not delivered due to unpaid supplier invoices.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors reports Q2 loss due to coronavirus slump
summary: Mitsubishi Motors reported a 29.3 billion yen operating loss in Q2 due to a coronavirus slump, down from a 6.3 billion yen profit a year earlier. The company is cutting its workforce and production capacity, and closing unprofitable dealerships to slash fixed costs by 20% within two years. Mitsubishi aims to lift annual operating profit to 50 billion yen by 2023, focusing on Asia and reducing its presence in Europe and North America.

site_title: Oil rises after Trump falsely claims victory in tight US election
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 3% on Wednesday after President Donald Trump falsely claimed victory in the US election, despite millions of votes still to be counted. A Trump victory is seen as bullish for oil due to sanctions on Iran and Saudi-led Opec oil cuts. Brent crude rose 2.67% to $40.80 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate increased 2.66% to $38.69 a barrel. The potential Trump victory was supported by Opec producers considering deferring a planned oil output increase, which could limit Iranian oil supply.

site_title: Australia's 'Big Four' banks pocket rate cuts, trim fixed loan rates
summary: Australia's four major banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, National Australia Bank, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, have refused to cut interest rates for most home loan customers despite the central bank's pledge to keep rates near zero for three years. Instead, they have cut rates for small businesses and lower fixed rates for mortgage holders to record lows, saving 3-5 basis points on net interest margins. This move is seen as a way for the banks to safeguard profits amid weak demand for credit.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend gains as investors eye tight US election race
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.6% to 2,357.32, tracking US stock futures after US President Donald Trump led Democratic rival Joe Biden in major battleground states, though a final outcome may not be known for days. The benchmark Kospi extended its gains for a third straight session. The Korean won weakened, while Samsung Electronics fell 0.5% and SK Hynix jumped 2.2% after posting a 175% operating profit jump.

site_title: Trump falsely claims victory with election too close to call
summary: US President Donald Trump falsely declared victory in the presidential election, despite several battleground states still counting votes. Trump said he would ask the Supreme Court to intervene, claiming the election was a "fraud on the American public." However, the Associated Press declared Joe Biden the winner of Arizona and three of Maine's Electoral College votes, giving Biden a 238-213 lead in the Electoral College. Biden is still 32 votes shy of the 270 needed for victory.

site_title: US dollar jumps as election race tightens; peso, yuan wilt
summary: The US dollar surged 1% against a basket of currencies as early election results showed a tight presidential race, contrary to market expectations of a clear Democratic victory for Joe Biden. The dollar's rise was attributed to President Donald Trump's win in key battleground states, which dashed hopes for a decisive result. In contrast, the peso and yuan weakened by more than 3% and 0.7% respectively, as investors awaited clarity on the outcome.

site_title: M&S slides to first loss as coronavirus hammers clothing sales
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) reported its first loss in 94 years as a publicly listed company, with a pretax loss of £17.4 million (S$30.8 million) in the 26 weeks to Sept 26. The loss was due to a 21.3% decline in clothing and home sales, which were heavily impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. In contrast, food sales rose 2.7% on a like-for-like basis, driven by a tie-up with Ocado. The company expects further losses due to the new lockdown in England.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower on US vote worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished lower on Wednesday due to concerns over the US election result, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.2% to 24,886.14. Meanwhile, Alibaba's Ant Group listing in China was suspended, causing its parent company to tumble. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.2% to 3,277.44. The US stock market, however, reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Democrats' prospects for Senate majority wither after GOP wins
summary: Democrats' chances of winning a Senate majority have dwindled after several vulnerable Republican incumbents successfully defended their seats, despite a strong Democratic showing. To gain control, Democrats would need an extraordinary surge in three remaining Senate contests, with only a win in Maine and North Carolina providing a viable path. Despite maintaining their House majority, Democrats suffered losses in several key districts, including Minnesota, Florida, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and North Carolina. The Republican-led Senate majority now stands at 53-47, with a runoff election in Georgia in January providing another opportunity for Democrats to challenge Republican Senator Kelly Loeffler.

site_title: Trek 2000 International reports net loss after tax of US$700,000 for Q3
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a net loss after tax of US$700,000 in Q3, down from a net profit of US$4,000 in the same quarter last year. The company attributed the loss to decreased market prices of its products due to increased competition during the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue grew to US$7.7 million, but the company incurred a gross loss of 9.4% due to a write-down of inventory costs. The company expects the industry to remain challenging in the next 12 months.

site_title: COE prices drop across the board following start of higher 3-month quota
summary: COE prices in Singapore dropped across the board in the latest tender, following the start of a higher three-month quota. Cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finished at S$35,990, down from S$37,334 two weeks ago. The Land Transport Authority's increased quota, which includes 4,865 COEs per month for November to January, led to the price decrease. Commercial vehicle COE price dropped to S$31,502, while motorcycle premium decreased to S$7,251. The total average monthly quota increased by 7.1% to 6,649.

site_title: Kingsmen Creative's Malaysian unit sells Selangor property for RM10m
summary: Kingsmen Exhibits, a Malaysian subsidiary of Kingsmen Creatives, has agreed to sell a freehold property in Selangor for RM10 million (S$3.26 million). The property, with a built-in area of 19,824 square feet, is currently rented out for income. The sale price is 5.1 million over the book value of the property, allowing the group to unlock its value and repay mortgage loans. The funds will also be used for general working capital requirements. The sale does not significantly impact the company's net asset value or net loss for the first half of 2020.

site_title: Twitter, Facebook push back on Trump's election posts
summary: Twitter and Facebook flagged President Donald Trump's election posts as potentially misleading. Twitter warned a tweet alleging an effort to steal the election was misleading, while Facebook flagged a post saying "We are up BIG" due to ongoing vote counting. The social media companies emphasized that final results may differ from initial vote counts. Trump's comments came as the US presidential election remained too close to call.

images.alt_text: Twitter and Facebook early Wednesday flagged President Donald Trump's comments on the US presidential election, which remained too close to call.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Phase Three reopening may last for a year or more, according to Health Minister Gan Kim Yong. The country's regulator, MAS, has accelerated reviews and investigations of market misconduct. CDL has appointed Deloitte to evaluate its investment in China's Sincere Property. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.75% higher at 2,515.98, amid US presidential election vote count. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over a US tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: CapitaLand chairman Ng Kee Choe to retire, deputy chairman Miguel Ko appointed successor
summary: CapitaLand's chairman Ng Kee Choe will retire as chairman and director at the conclusion of its next annual general meeting in April 2021. He will be succeeded by deputy chairman Miguel Ko, who has been on the board since August 2019. Under Ng's chairmanship, CapitaLand successfully undertook strategic initiatives, including the S$11 billion combination with Ascendas-Singbridge in 2019. Ko expressed confidence in CapitaLand's future growth and success under his leadership.

site_title: Denmark's Danske Bank lowers cap for negative rates on retail deposits
summary: Danske Bank, Denmark's largest lender, lowered its cap for applying negative interest rates to retail deposits to cope with an increase in deposits. The bank reported a net profit of 2.1 billion Danish crowns in the third quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. The move comes as negative interest rates have become the norm in Denmark, with the bank's CFO stating that the situation must be reflected in their interest terms. This decision follows the bank's previous profit guidance hike in July, citing lower costs and improved market conditions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide on US vote uncertainty
summary: European stock markets slid on Wednesday due to US election uncertainty, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.6% and the eurozone's DAX 30 index shedding 1.6%. The pound also declined over 1% against the dollar. President Donald Trump's plans to dispute the vote count contributed to the volatility.

site_title: Trump wins Ohio, key battleground state
summary: President Donald Trump won the key battleground state of Ohio, projected by Fox and NBC, defeating Democrat Joe Biden. Ohio accounts for 18 Electoral College votes and has been a Republican stronghold since 2004. Trump's victory in Ohio, where he won by over 8 percentage points four years ago, marks a significant win for his re-election campaign.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian initiates coverage on Jiutian Chemical with 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian initiated coverage on Jiutian Chemical Group with a "buy" rating, targeting 16 Singapore cents. The analyst, Clement Ho, attributes the company's earnings potential to the strong industrial recovery in China and high demand for its product, dimethylformamide (DMF). With Jiutian now the second-largest DMF producer in the world, average selling prices are expected to rise, providing a boost to earnings. The brokerage believes demand and prices for industrial products manufactured in China are sustainable.

site_title: No improper influence in investigation and prosecution of Parti Liyani: Shanmugam
summary: LAW and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam stated that there was no improper influence in the prosecution of Indonesian maid Parti Liyani, who was accused of stealing from then-Changi Airport Group chairman Liew Mun Leong. The investigation and prosecution were handled as any other theft case, with decisions made by an investigation officer and his supervisor. Shanmugam denied that Liew or anyone else exerted pressure on the police or prosecution. The maid was acquitted after her conviction was overturned, and further investigations found no evidence of improper influence.

site_title: US formally exits global climate pact amid election uncertainty
summary: The US formally exited the Paris Agreement on climate change, fulfilling President Donald Trump's promise to withdraw from the global pact in 2017. The outcome of the US election will determine how long the US remains outside the agreement. Joe Biden has promised to rejoin the pact if elected, while Laurence Tubiana warns that climate deniers in control of the White House and Congress will make it more challenging to achieve a climate-safe planet. Other major emitters, such as China, Japan, and South Korea, have continued to pursue climate action despite the US withdrawal.

site_title: Gold slides on dollar bounce as early US poll results trickle in
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,893.93 per ounce on Wednesday, as the US dollar strengthened after early voting results showed a close contest between President Trump and Democratic rival Biden in the US presidential election. Investors are losing confidence in a clear Biden victory, which could lead to reduced stimulus measures, affecting gold prices. The US dollar rose 0.7% against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: AEM raises revenue guidance for FY20 on sales order visibility, business outlook
summary: AEM Holdings has raised its FY2020 revenue guidance to between S$500 million and S$520 million, driven by a 93% year-on-year increase in Q3 revenue to S$161.8 million. Net profit jumped 77.4% for the quarter to S$24.3 million. The company expects to expand through mergers and acquisitions to solidify its position as a global leader in chip-testing solutions.

site_title: British retailer John Lewis to cut 1,500 head office jobs
summary: British retailer John Lewis plans to cut 1,500 head office jobs as part of its strategy to return to sustainable profit by 2025. The job losses, which will be completed by April 2021, are expected to save £50 million annually. The employee-owned department store group reported a £635 million loss in the first half of 2020. The cuts follow the announcement of store closures and a £1 billion investment in its online business. Partnership chairman Sharon White emphasized the need for agility and adaptation to changing customer needs.

site_title: Trade deficit in the US narrows for first time in three months
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $63.9 billion in September, its first decline in three months, driven by a 2.6% increase in exports to $176.4 billion and a 0.5% increase in imports to $240.2 billion. The merchandise trade deficit also narrowed, while the services trade deficit remained largely unchanged. The narrowing of the deficit reflects a two-year high in soybean exports and overseas shipments of capital goods, but elevated imports to meet consumer demand remain a concern. The outcome of the US election will impact trade policy, with both Trump and Biden proposing different approaches.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda says resurgence in US, European infections a concern
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed concerns over the overseas economic outlook due to a resurgence in US and European coronavirus infections. The spread of Covid-19 has not subsided globally, and public health measures have been tightened in European countries, making the consequences of Covid-19 on economies highly unclear. This uncertainty has skewed the outlook to the downside, adding to the high uncertainties over the economy and prices.

site_title: Trump takes five states, Biden six plus DC: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump has won five states, while Democratic challenger Joe Biden has won six states plus the District of Columbia. Trump has secured 42 electoral votes, while Biden has secured 57. Biden's electoral votes include his home state of Delaware and the District of Columbia. The two candidates are close to the 270-electoral-vote threshold needed to win the presidency, with Biden leading by 15 electoral votes.

site_title: Malaysia says over 2,600 Malindo Air employees affected by retrenchment plan
summary: Malaysia-based carrier Malindo Air has launched a retrenchment plan affecting 2,647 employees, with 439 receiving a year's unpaid leave and 347 opting for a voluntary separation scheme. The remaining employees received termination notices, along with minimum compensation. Affected workers will receive additional unemployment benefits and government training and job hiring programs. The move comes as the aviation industry struggles due to the coronavirus pandemic and travel curbs, with other airlines in the country also announcing job cuts.

site_title: BP nears sale of London HQ to Hong Kong department store operator: sources
summary: BP is nearing a deal to sell its London headquarters in St James's Square to Lifestyle International Holdings, a Hong Kong department store operator, for about £235 million. The sale would be the first big real estate acquisition in the UK for Lifestyle International, controlled by Thomas Lau, brother of Hong Kong property billionaire Joseph Lau. The deal comes as BP cuts 10,000 jobs amid the slump in oil prices and transitions to cleaner energy.

site_title: Biden at 88 electoral votes, Trump at 63: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump has secured 63 electoral votes, while Democratic challenger Joe Biden has garnered 88, surpassing the 270 needed to win the presidency. Biden has won key battleground states such as Illinois, Massachusetts, and Virginia, while Trump has maintained his hold on states like Alabama, Arkansas, and West Virginia. A long night of waiting for results is ahead as the hotly contested race for the White House continues.

site_title: Democrats retain control of House of Representatives: US networks
summary: Democrats retained control of the US House of Representatives, increasing their majority to at least four or five seats, according to US networks. This outcome is expected to bolster House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's efforts to roll back President Donald Trump's orders if he loses reelection.

site_title: Walmart to end experiment with robots in US stores
summary: Walmart has ended its experiment with robots to scan items in US stores after employing them in around 500 stores for five years. The retail giant had planned to use the robots in 1,000 stores, but reversed course due to mixed results. Despite the setback, Walmart will continue testing new technologies and investing in its processes to improve inventory management. The company's decision comes amid a shift towards e-commerce and a focus on providing a better customer experience.

site_title: Investors dig in for a long night after indecisive initial US election results
summary: US investors faced a choppy night as initial election results raised doubts about a decisive outcome, with President Donald Trump narrowly leading Democratic rival Joe Biden in Florida. Markets were uncertain, with US stock market futures volatile, and a clear winner seen as essential for fiscal stimulus and market stability. Republican Senator Cory Gardner's defeat in Colorado gave Democrats their first victory, but the outcome remains uncertain in key battleground states like Georgia and North Carolina. A clear victor is seen as crucial to alleviating market fears and securing a massive fiscal stimulus package.

site_title: Crown Resorts unsuitable for Sydney casino licence, inquiry hears
summary: Australian casino giant Crown Resorts is deemed unsuitable to hold a casino licence in New South Wales state due to its governance issues and influence of major shareholder James Packer, an inquiry heard. Crown spent A$2.20 billion on a 75-floor casino tower in Sydney, but allegations of dealings with junket operators linked to organised crime and Chinese anti-gambling laws have raised concerns. The inquiry may strip Crown of its casino licence or impose tough conditions, with a final report due by February.

site_title: China turns to lobsters, wine and coal to 'punish' Australia
summary: China has imposed a blacklist of Australian commodities, including coal, barley, copper, sugar, timber, wine, and lobster, as part of its pressure campaign against Australia. The move is expected to disrupt Australian exporters, particularly those in the coal and wine industries. China's blacklist does not cover iron ore or natural gas, which are less likely to be affected by the trade actions. The sanctions are seen as a major escalation in China's trade war with Australia, with potential long-term consequences for the country's economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch lower ahead of US election outcome
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.4% to 6,044.3, snapping a two-day winning streak, ahead of the US presidential election outcome. Investors await a clear result, hoping for more fiscal stimulus. US stock futures rose on expectations of a decisive result, while mining stocks and financials fell due to concerns over interest rates and economic growth. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand rose 0.3% despite a rise in unemployment.

site_title: Biden-Trump battle shifts to swing states after early, easy wins
summary: US President Joe Biden has scored early wins in traditionally Democratic states, while President Donald Trump holds leads in Republican strongholds. Biden won Colorado, New York, and Virginia, while Trump won Kansas, Arkansas, and Indiana. The Electoral College lead for Biden stands at 135-114, but many battleground states remain undecided, including Florida, North Carolina, Ohio, Georgia, Pennsylvania, and Michigan. The outcome may not be known until later in the night or in days/weeks if vote counts are close.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat after volatile trade as US vote too close to call
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday after a volatile trading session, influenced by the close US presidential election between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.1% down, tracking a rebound in US stock futures. Shares in the metals and mining sector declined 1.4%, with Fortescue Metals Group and Rio Tinto falling 4.3% and 1%, respectively. The outcome of the US election is expected to impact Australia's energy transition and climate reforms, with Joe Biden planning to push for climate reforms.

site_title: Bitcoin haul of US$1b on the move, possibly with Silk Road
summary: US$1 billion worth of Bitcoin, possibly linked to Silk Road, has been moved out of a wallet, according to blockchain tracker Elliptic. The 69,369 Bitcoins are from the world's fourth-richest Bitcoin address, which may be associated with the infamous online marketplace. The owner's intentions are unclear, with Elliptic's co-founder stating a 60% confidence that the funds are from Silk Road. The move may be a response to the risk of the wallet being cracked and the Bitcoins seized.

site_title: Trump's strong showing in South erases Biden hopes for early win
summary: President Donald Trump defied polls and predictions with a strong showing across the South, narrowing Democratic nominee Joe Biden's path to the White House. Trump's leads in North Carolina, Georgia, and Florida significantly reduced Biden's chances of a wave election victory. Biden's hopes now hinge on states like Pennsylvania, where a prolonged fight could be fatal to his chances.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump has once again defied polls and predictions, with a strong showing across the Sun Belt in early results appearing to significantly shrink Democratic nominee Joe Biden's path to victory.

site_title: Biden, Trump each voice confidence with race too close to call
summary: US President Joe Biden and incumbent President Donald Trump expressed confidence in their chances of winning the presidential election, with Biden saying he feels good about his chances despite some key battleground states remaining undecided. Trump won Florida, a crucial state, and outperformed in Miami-Dade County, while Biden won Minnesota. The early results gave Biden a 223-174 lead in the Electoral College, but Trump holds leads in several other key states. The outcome may not be known until Wednesday or later, with millions of mail-in ballots yet to be counted, and volatility persists in US equity futures.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher, all eyes on US election results
summary: Japanese shares rose 1.72% to close at 23,695.23, driven by a cautiously optimistic view of US presidential election results. Despite initial expectations of a Biden victory, which could ease political risk, gains were capped as Trump took the lead in key battleground states. Investors priced in a higher probability of a Trump win, leading to gains in stocks like Recruit Holdings and Fujikura. Renewable energy-related stocks, such as Renova, fell due to speculation of a Biden presidency leading to a shift away from coal-fired power.

site_title: Asia-Pacific real estate transactions up 35% on quarter in Q3, down 19% on year
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate transactions rose 35% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, but declined 19% year-over-year to US$35 billion. North Asia, particularly China, South Korea, and Japan, drove the recovery. Investors showed interest in logistics and data centers, with industrial transactions increasing 76% year-over-year. Office transactions dropped 35% year-over-year, while retail and hotel transactions declined 51% and 87% respectively. Cheaper financing costs may have contributed to the recovery, with more institutional investors returning in the third quarter.

site_title: Chinese tech giants take proxy war to New York
summary: Chinese tech giants Alibaba, JD.com, and Tencent are launching a proxy war in New York through a potential $300 million investment in Farfetch, a US-listed online luxury retailer. The move could give Alibaba another way to profit from luxury e-commerce growth, while JD.com would have a larger stake in the company. The investment may help boost Alibaba's business in China, where luxury purchases are increasing, but it also complicates Farfetch's governance and makes it harder for other companies to acquire the group.

site_title: India's services activity grows in October for first time in eight months
summary: India's services sector expanded for the first time in eight months in October, with a reading of 54.1, according to a private survey. The Nikkei/IHS Markit Services Purchasing Managers' Index climbed above the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. Despite this, firms cut jobs for the eighth straight month due to pandemic-related restrictions and fears of Covid-19 contamination. The composite PMI, which includes manufacturing and services, rose to 58.0, its highest since January 2012. A recovery in Asia's third-largest economy appears to be underway.

site_title: Anxious Americans show up for an election like no other
summary: In the US presidential election, anxious Americans turned out to cast their votes, with many expressing concern about the outcome and potential unrest. Despite the coronavirus pandemic and protests, over 100 million opted to vote early, with many citing a desire to make their voices heard. Key battleground states, including Pennsylvania, Florida, and Wisconsin, were crucial to the outcome, with some voters expressing anxiety about the possibility of violence or chaos. The election was seen as a crucial moment for American democracy, with many voters hoping to send a message about their values and priorities.

site_title: Phase Three of Singapore's reopening could last for a year or more: Gan
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong suggests Phase Three of the country's reopening could last for over a year due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. He emphasizes that Phase Three is not a return to pre-pandemic status but a new normal that will persist until the virus is under control or effective treatments/vaccines are widely available. The government will reassess and adjust measures based on factors such as pre-event testing, contact-tracing capabilities, and risk mitigation, with a focus on maintaining a steady state of economic and social activities.

site_title: CDL appoints Deloitte to evaluate investment in China's Sincere Property
summary: CDL appoints Deloitte as external financial adviser to review its investment in China's Sincere Property Group, citing challenges related to Sincere's liquidity position following the Covid-19 pandemic and new measures to tighten liquidity for real estate companies in China. CDL's director Kwek Leng Peck resigned last month, citing disagreements with the board and management. CDL's investment in Sincere totals about S$1.9 billion, with a 51% joint-venture equity investment and a liquidity-support undertaking. The review aims to assess the strategic investment's value and impact on CDL's global asset portfolio.

site_title: China's service sector recovery strengthens in Oct, hiring picks up: Caixin PMI
summary: China's service sector activity recovered for a sixth consecutive month in October, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI rising to 56.8 from 54.8 in September. Hiring picked up to the highest level in a year, driven by domestic demand, but overseas demand slipped due to coronavirus infections in Europe and the US. The services sector, accounting for 60% of China's economy, showed a strengthening recovery, with firms hiring at the fastest pace since September 2019. A continued recovery is likely, but policymakers should be cautious about normalizing monetary and fiscal policies.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises target price on FCT, says retail sales rebound may be sustainable
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price on Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) to S$3 from S$2.94, maintaining its "buy" call due to a potential sustainable retail sales rebound. Analysts Geraldine Wong and Derek Tan expect the Phase Three reopening of the Singapore economy to boost FCT's portfolio performance, driven by atrium sales and increased group sizes. The analysts also project a 6% increase in FCT's distribution per unit for FY2021, citing the PGIM Real Estate Asia Retail Fund acquisition as a positive factor.

site_title: Tunisian startup 3D prints solar-powered bionic hands
summary: A Tunisian startup, Cure Bionics, is developing 3D-printed solar-powered bionic hands to help amputees and disabled people in Africa. The affordable prosthetic can be customized for children and youths as they grow, and a virtual reality system is being developed to aid in physical therapy. The device uses sensors and AI-assisted software to transmit instructions to the digits, and can be printed locally using 3D printing technology. Cure plans to market the prosthetic in Tunisia and Africa, aiming to be accessible financially and geographically, with a price of around $2,000-$3,000.

site_title: Alibaba shares plunge 9.6% in Hong Kong after Ant IPO scrapped
summary: Alibaba's shares plummeted 9.6% in Hong Kong after Chinese regulators scrapped the public listing of Ant Group, a spin-off financial tech company. The decision follows a sharp eight percent drop in Alibaba's US share price overnight. The move is seen as a significant setback for Alibaba and Ant Group, which were expected to raise billions of dollars through the initial public offering (IPO). The cancellation of the IPO will likely have a ripple effect on the company's financials and valuation.

site_title: Sabana-ESR merger: EGMs, scheme meeting expected to convene on Dec 4
summary: ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit are set to hold extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) and a scheme meeting on December 4 to vote on their proposed merger. The meetings will follow the issuance of the EGM circular and scheme document on November 12. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has given in-principle approval for the listing of approximately 989.9 million new units. The merger's outcome will depend on unitholder approval and SGX's final approval. The Securities Investors Association of Singapore will also hold dialogue sessions for unitholders to discuss the merger.

site_title: Job whale done as Dutch train lifted to safety
summary: A Dutch train was lifted to safety after it became stuck under a 20-year-old sculpture of a whale's tail in a local park. The train, which was traveling at the time of the incident, smashed through buffers and became suspended 10m above the ground. Emergency services spent the day cutting and lifting the 22-tonne front carriage to safety, with some superficial damage reported on the sculpture. The cause of the crash remains unclear, but the train's black box data recorder is expected to provide more clues. The driver and no passengers were injured.

images.alt_text: Cranes safely lifted a Dutch metro carriage off a huge sculpture of a whale's tail on Tuesday, a day after the artwork stopped the runaway train from crashing to the ground.

site_title: Trump wins Indiana, Kentucky, Biden takes Vermont, Virginia: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump has won the states of Indiana, Kentucky, and West Virginia, while Democratic challenger Joe Biden has won Vermont and Virginia. This gives Trump 24 electoral votes to Biden's 16. With the magic number of 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidency, the outcome of the US presidential election remains uncertain, with key battleground states expected to decide the result.

site_title: Senate Republican leader McConnell wins reelection: US media
summary: Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell won reelection, ensuring his six-year stay in the chamber. He led Democratic challenger Amy McGrath by 13 percentage points with over half of precincts reporting. McConnell, 78, has served in the Senate since 1985 and is a key ally for President Donald Trump. Despite being critical of the president's pandemic response, McConnell's reelection maintains Republican control in the Senate.

site_title: Trump wins Indiana as polls begin to close: Edison Research
summary: US President Donald Trump was projected to win Indiana's electoral votes, the first state to be decided in the 2020 presidential election. Trump also won Kentucky, while Joe Biden was projected to win Democratic-leaning Vermont and Virginia. The election, held amid the COVID-19 pandemic, saw a high turnout of over 100 million voters, with Biden leading on the economy and Trump focusing on his handling of the pandemic. The outcome could determine the direction of the country, with Biden promising to address the pandemic and bridge America's political divide.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand, Great Eastern, Parkway Life Reit, SIA Engineering
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on November 4, 2020, with UOB posting a 40% drop in net profit due to credit allowances. CapitaLand expects its FY2020 financial performance to be adversely impacted. Great Eastern Holdings rose 40% in net profit, while Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit increased 7.4%. SIA Engineering Company's net loss was cut to S$19 million due to government grants.

site_title: Maradona in recovery after successful brain surgery
summary: Argentine soccer legend Diego Maradona is in recovery after successful brain surgery to treat a subdural hematoma, a blood clot on the brain, according to his doctor Leopoldo Luque. The 60-year-old was admitted to hospital on Monday for anemia and dehydration, before being transferred to Olivos Clinic in Buenos Aires. The 80-minute surgery was deemed "routine" and Maradona tolerated it well, with fans gathered outside the clinic celebrating the successful outcome. Maradona's condition will be closely monitored, with observation and controlled steps taken to ensure his recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.34 points to 1,462.79. Volume was 269.48 million lots worth RM89.73 million. Gainers beat losers 286 to 83.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 earnings rise 40% to S$287.9m on valuation of investments
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 40% rise in net profit to S$287.9 million for the third quarter, driven by higher valuation of investments. Operating profit slipped 4% to S$171.4 million, while non-operating profit rose to S$50 million. Total weighted new sales grew 36% to S$432.8 million. The group's focus on strengthening distribution capabilities and adapting to the digital and technology infrastructure contributed to the results.

site_title: SK Hynix expects soft server demand after Q3 profit surge
summary: SK Hynix, the world's No.2 memory chip maker, expects soft server demand in the current quarter due to inventory build-up by competitors in China. The company reported a surge in Q3 profit, driven by Huawei's orders before US restrictions, but expects weak server demand to continue. SK Hynix plans to fund its $9 billion acquisition of Intel's NAND memory chip business using a combination of cash, borrowing, and asset securitization. The company aims to expand in the data center market and triple its NAND revenue in the next five years.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix, the world's No.2 memory chip maker, said it expected inventory build-up by Huawei's competitors in China to boost mobile demand in the current quarter, but its mainstay server demand would remain week.

site_title: As Japan moves to revive its countryside, pandemic chases many from cities
summary: Japan's rural regions are experiencing a surge in population as the pandemic pushes people out of Tokyo, the first time in years. According to government data, 30,644 people moved out of Tokyo in September, a 12.5% year-on-year increase, while 27,006 moved in, a 11.7% decrease. Many companies, such as staffing firms, are adopting telecommuting models, allowing workers to avoid crowded cities and find more affordable living options. The shift is seen as a boon for Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's rural revitalization plans, which aim to boost economic growth in decaying rural areas.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall at Wednesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the start of trade on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.60% to 24,790.00. The decline was attributed to Alibaba's 9.9% drop after the debut of its financial unit Ant Group was suspended. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw declines, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths posts over 12% rise in Q1 sales as lockdowns boost demand
summary: Woolworths Group reported a 12% rise in Q1 sales, driven by increased demand for food supplies and cleaning products during coronavirus-related lockdowns in Australia. Total group sales reached A$17.85 billion for the 14 weeks to Oct 4, ahead of smaller rival Coles Group. However, the company's hotels division saw a 33.2% decline in sales due to closures and restrictions. Woolworths has been paying back-store staff for underpayment issues, with A$164 million paid during the quarter.

site_title: CapitaLand expects materially adverse impact for FY2020 financial performance
summary: CapitaLand expects its FY2020 financial performance to be "materially adversely impacted" due to a subdued operating environment and lower expected capital recycling. Despite this, the property giant sees encouraging signs of recovery in Q3 operating metrics, particularly in residential, retail, and lodging segments. The group remains confident in its financial resilience and expects to deliver positive cash profits from diversified income streams. CapitaLand also expects a cautious business and consumer sentiment to persist until the global economic recovery picks up.

site_title: Some in Bank of Japan urged scrutiny on Covid-19 response: Sept meeting minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers debated deeper scrutiny on its response to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing uncertainty in the economic outlook. Some members urged re-examining the central bank's strategy to achieve its 2% inflation target, while others suggested addressing structural problems such as digitalization and job losses. Despite the discussion, the BOJ kept monetary policy steady in September, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda prioritizing liquidity support for cash-strapped firms and pushing the debate on inflation targets to the backburner. The BOJ's current ultra-loose monetary policy was seen as sufficient to cushion the economic blow.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens more than 1.5% up as US votes for president
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened over 1.5% higher on November 4, 2020, following US market rises. The benchmark index rose 355.34 points to 23,650.82, while the Topix index gained 18.84 points to 1,626.79. The gains followed a day of US presidential vote polls.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's key Nikkei 225 index opened more than 1.5 per cent higher on Wednesday, tracking rises on US markets a day earlier, as polls began closing in the US presidential vote.

site_title: US judge orders postal service to check for delayed ballots in battleground states
summary: A US judge ordered the US Postal Service to inspect mail processing facilities in 12 battleground states for delayed election ballots, citing concerns that mail delays could cause votes to be disqualified. The order, issued by Judge Emmet Sullivan, aims to ensure timely delivery of ballots and comply with voting rights groups' lawsuits. The inspection must be completed by 3pm ET, with postal officials expected to certify by 4.30pm ET that no ballots were left behind. The USPS has expressed operational limitations and a need to avoid disrupting key activities on Election Day.

site_title: UOB Q3 profit falls 40% to S$668m
summary: UOB reported a 40% drop in net profit for its third quarter to S$668 million, due to pre-emptive credit allowance build-up. Net interest income fell 13% to S$1.47 billion, while non-interest income declined 15%. The bank's asset quality remains manageable, and it is adequately provisioned despite the expiry of moratorium programmes. UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong noted the economic trajectory remains uneven, with the bank remaining vigilant in key regional markets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit one-week high as investors await US election outcome
summary: European stocks reached a one-week high, closing 2.3% higher, as investors anticipated a clear win for Democrat Joe Biden in the US presidential election, which could lead to more economic stimulus. Banking and auto stocks led gains, with French lender BNP Paribas jumping 6.1% and Ferrari surging 7.1% after forecast 2020 earnings. A Biden win is expected to boost European equities in the near-term, with luxury automaker Ferrari also seeing gains.

site_title: Thailand approaches former prime ministers to lead reconciliation panel
summary: Thailand's parliament proposes a reconciliation committee to resolve issues with pro-democracy protesters, who demand transparency, accountability, and constitutional changes. Former prime ministers Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, Anand Panyarachun, and Abhisit Vejjajiva are willing to support the panel, led by House Speaker Chuan Leekpai. The move comes after King Maha Vajiralongkorn's olive branch to protesters, but protesters threaten to remain on the streets until demands are met. The parliament will restart the process for charter amendment on Nov 17 and vote on constitutional rewriting by Nov 18.

site_title: Japan Reits feel pinch as Tokyo population drops amid pandemic
summary: Japan's real estate investment trust (Reit) index has fallen to a five-month low due to Tokyo's declining population, which dropped by around 10,700 in October to 13.971 million. This trend, driven by telecommuting and the pandemic, is putting pressure on Reits that rely on pricey properties in Tokyo. Analysts predict a weakening demand for office space and a potential economic downturn could exacerbate the damage, with the office sector being the worst affected.

site_title: Apple to launch MacBooks with in-house chips
summary: Apple is set to launch three new Mac laptops, the 13-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pros, and a 13-inch MacBook Air, with in-house designed chips instead of Intel processors. The move marks the end of a 15-year partnership with Intel, with the first Mac processors based on the A14 chip found in the latest iPhones and iPad Air. The transition is expected to take two years, with Apple already working on redesigned iMac and Mac Pro models. The change aims to improve power efficiency and provide a common architecture across all Apple devices.

site_title: Social media firms on alert for Election Day misinformation
summary: Social media firms Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube are on high alert for Election Day misinformation as voters cast ballots in the US. To prevent the spread of false information, Facebook activated its election hub and removed content calling for voter suppression or interference with voting. Twitter updated its civic integrity policy and YouTube added information panels to videos about voting by mail. However, activists note that loopholes and glitches may hinder efforts to curb misinformation, with some unverified claims resurfacing on Facebook.

site_title: FCT H2 DPU drops 26.1% as Covid-19 rental relief hits earnings
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 26.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.372 Singapore cents for the half-year period ended Sept 30, due to rental relief provided to tenants amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Gross revenue fell 33.8% to S$64.5 million, and net property income declined 42.8% to S$38.6 million. The decline in distribution was partially offset by retained distribution and dividend contributions from investments. FCT's gearing level stood at 35.9% and portfolio occupancy was 94.9% as of Sept 30.

site_title: ECB may cut support for indebted countries in nudge towards EU loans
summary: The European Central Bank may reduce its support for indebted eurozone countries when introducing a new stimulus package in December, aiming to encourage them to apply for European Union loans tied to productive investments. The ECB has been using its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme to lower borrowing costs for countries like Spain and Portugal, but this has discouraged them from seeking EU loans. A compromise may be reached, with both the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme and Asset Purchase Programme being expanded, but the former remaining the main instrument.

site_title: Not all employers need to cut wages to save jobs: Josephine Teo on NWC guideline
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council (NWC) expects wage adjustments in the next 12 months to vary across sectors and firms, as not all employers need to cut wages to save jobs. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo stated that employers with no reduction in demand or those who have already adjusted wage levels can proceed without cuts. The NWC also recommends that employers freeze wages for workers earning below S$1,400 to avoid retrenchments, rather than cutting them.

site_title: MAS accelerates reviews, investigations of criminal and civil cases
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has accelerated reviews and investigations of criminal and civil cases, completing them in an average of 24 months for criminal prosecutions and 26 months for civil cases, down from 33 months and 30 months respectively in the previous reporting period. MAS imposed S$11.7 million in civil penalties and S$3.4 million in financial penalties on 18 financial institutions, and took action against 9 criminal convictions, 25 prohibition orders, and 124 warnings. The regulator attributes the improvement to refining processes, leveraging technology, and strengthening collaboration with partners.

images.alt_text: MAS is taking less time to complete reviews and investigations of criminal and civil cases, according to its enforcement report on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open on US gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by overnight US gains, as polls closed in the US presidential vote. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 31, with Jiutian Chemical, Sembcorp Marine, and Singtel leading the gainers. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB increasing between 0.5% to 0.9%. The US market saw a 2.1% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and 1.8% in the S&P 500.

site_title: Framework to exit contracts will help SMEs reset their business: Edwin Tong
summary: Singapore is introducing a Re-Align Framework to help small and micro enterprises renegotiate or exit contracts without penalties due to Covid-19. The framework, part of the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) (Amendment No 3) Bill, aims to prevent businesses from being stuck in limbo and ensure they can reallocate resources. The government is also introducing a Simplified Insolvency Programme to help firms restructure debts or liquidate assets.
