The framework will not apply to contracts terminated before November 2, and eligibility will be based on revenue thresholds.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 2.1% to conclude strong Election Day session
summary: US stocks ended a strong Election Day session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.1% to 27,480.03, while the S&P 500 advanced 1.8% to 3,369.16 and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.9% to 11,160.57. Analysts say the rally reflects a hope for a straightforward election outcome and a desire to avoid a prolonged fight, with a stimulus package expected regardless of the winner. A contested result could increase market volatility and civil unrest.

site_title: Fresh recession fears as Europe enters new lockdowns
summary: Europe is entering new lockdowns amid recession fears, with the EU's economic affairs commissioner Paolo Gentiloni stating the measures will affect economic activity but not as badly as during the first coronavirus wave. Eurozone head Klaus Regling warned of a "double dip recession" risk, citing deteriorating health conditions. Meanwhile, eurogroup chief Paschal Donohoe urged swift approval of a massive EU stimulus package to support economic recovery. The eurozone economy recently experienced a 12.7% surge in the third quarter, but the new lockdowns pose a significant challenge to its nascent recovery.

site_title: US Election Day kicks off in climate of tension
summary: US Election Day has begun amidst a third wave of Covid-19, foreign interference threats, and a polarized political environment. Polls opened in several states, including New Hampshire, New York, and Virginia, with President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden campaigning in key battleground states. With 98 million ballots cast, a record number, the election is expected to be closely contested, with national surveys giving Biden the advantage. A Biden win would be historic, with Kamala Harris becoming the first Black and Indian-American woman to hold the vice presidency.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit raises Q3 DPU by 7.4% to 3.54 S cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit raised its Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) by 7.4% to 3.54 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from Japan nursing rehabilitation facilities and higher rent from Singapore properties. Gross revenue increased 0.8% to S$30.2 million, while net property income grew 2% to S$28.1 million. The Reit's distributable income to unitholders rose 7.4% to S$21.4 million. The CEO attributed the improvement to the Reit's strong portfolio and active capital management strategies.

site_title: US malls dragged into bankruptcy by carnage at retail tenants
summary: Two major US mall landlords, Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust (PREIT) and CBL & Associates Properties Inc, have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection amid the pandemic-induced decline of brick-and-mortar retailers. The two companies, which own 87 million square feet of real estate, are struggling with a surplus of retail space and reduced sales per square foot. The bankruptcy filings aim to restructure debt and secure funding, but face opposition from creditors and potential lawsuits.

site_title: PayPal tops estimates amid surge in online shopping but outlook disappoints
summary: PayPal reported a 36% increase in quarterly payments to $247 billion, beating estimates, but forecasted adjusted profit below expectations. The company added 15.2 million new active customers and processed its all-time highest daily payments volume in October. PayPal's Venmo processed $44 billion in payments, up 61%. The company expects revenue to grow 17-18% in the current quarter, below analyst estimates. PayPal's shares fell over 6% after the earnings report.

site_title: Reading storm warnings
summary: Market analysts are closely monitoring the US presidential election outcome, using the VIX Index (also known as the Fear Index) to gauge market expectations of future volatility. The VIX has risen to near 40, indicating a high level of uncertainty, with potential outcomes including a clear victory, a narrow but accepted victory, or a contested outcome and chaos. The S&P 500 is expected to react differently to each outcome, with a clear victory potentially driving the market up and a contested outcome unleashing bearish sentiment.

site_title: Manufacturers to pick up speed in year-end
summary: Singapore manufacturers are heading into the year-end with a more optimistic outlook, as the PMI reading rose to 50.5 points in October, its fourth straight month of growth. The electronics cluster also expanded for the third consecutive month, driven by demand for semiconductors and biomedical products. Analysts predict the growth momentum will sustain into 2021, with drivers including global demand for pharmaceuticals and the development of a Covid-19 vaccine. However, risks include slower growth in inventory levels and rising input prices, which could pose higher cost pressures on manufacturers.

site_title: Virtual twin: Visualising success in the factory of the future
summary: Manufacturers are facing unprecedented uncertainty due to the pandemic, with only 10% of supply chain executives prepared to address disruptions. To stay ahead, they are adopting smart manufacturing and leveraging big data, including the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT). A virtual twin, a complete digital replica of a physical asset, enables real-time monitoring and adjustments, driving flexibility and productivity. Manufacturers are also focusing on end-to-end visibility, autonomous workers, and integrated product development to stay competitive. With the average lifespan of a Fortune 500 company now under 20 years, manufacturers must adapt to the rapidly changing landscape to remain successful.

site_title: Oil rises 2% but traders brace for wild ride on US Election Day
summary: Oil prices rose 1.9% to $39.71 a barrel and 2.3% to $37.66 a barrel on US Election Day, driven by financial market gains and a weaker US dollar. Traders expect volatility depending on the voting results. A Democratic sweep could lead to a stimulus package, boosting oil prices. The threat of lockdowns and Opec's planned output cuts capped gains, but sources suggest deeper cuts may be considered early next year to strengthen the oil market.

site_title: Reimagining global supply chains in a pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the transformation of global supply chains, exposing weaknesses in production processes, transportation, and financing. Companies are reimagining their supply chain capabilities, leveraging digital solutions such as smart factories, digital control towers, and artificial intelligence to create more resilient networks. Experts advise businesses to diversify supply chain risks by adopting data-driven and machine learning tools, managing costs, and creating network flexibility. While there is no overarching strategy for developing a resilient supply chain, Singapore can benefit from its position as a regional hub, leveraging its skilled workforce and infrastructure to become a supply chain hub or manufacturing hub for high-end industries.

site_title: MH17 crash suspect 'saw no sign of missile'
summary: A Russian suspect in the MH17 crash trial, Oleg Pulatov, claims to have seen no BUK missile on the day of the crash. Pulatov, one of four men tried in absentia over the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, says he heard about the crash from his soldiers and was told of bodies falling from the sky. The trial, which began in March, continues to hear defence submissions concerning evidence. Investigators still seek the crew of the BUK missile system, believed to be from Russia's 53rd Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade.

site_title: Greenback retreats ahead of US election results
summary: The US dollar retreated 0.4% against a basket of currencies on Tuesday ahead of the US presidential election, with analysts expecting a Biden win to weaken the greenback due to increased spending on stimulus and trade. The euro rose 0.49% and sterling 0.56% against the US dollar, while European stock markets and eurozone government yields also surged. Investors are cautious about taking positions due to uncertainty over the election outcome, with some warning of potential volatility if no clear winner emerges swiftly.

site_title: How would an immigration surge affect your pay cheque?
summary: A study found that immigration affects labor markets differently depending on job type, location, and skill level. Tradable jobs, such as manufacturing and computer science, are less affected by immigration, while non-tradable jobs, like housekeeping and firefighting, see a decline in employment for native workers. However, in non-tradable jobs favored by immigrants, immigration leads to a 24% drop in native employment. The study suggests that targeted policies, rather than blanket curbs on immigration, are needed to address the varying impacts on local labor markets.

site_title: US TV networks prepare to deliver results of an unprecedented election
summary: US TV networks prepare for an unprecedented election night, with President Donald Trump and former Vice-President Joe Biden competing amid a global pandemic and record mail-in votes. Networks are under pressure to report results accurately, facing challenges such as a president stoking fears of ballot fraud and a divided electorate. To address these concerns, networks are investing in more polling, deeper data analysis, and additional reporting on voting integrity and misinformation. The networks will combine data from different providers to make projections, with some networks, like Fox News, relying on online and telephone surveys and others, like NBC News, using over 100 journalists for coverage.

site_title: Get ready for Goldilocks phase in 2021
summary: Asia ex-Japan economies are transitioning to a "Goldilocks" phase in 2021, characterized by accelerating and above-trend growth, rising but manageable inflation, and "big easy" policy. The region's GDP growth is expected to accelerate to 8.4% year-on-year in 2021, driven by sequential momentum and low base effects. Inflation is expected to remain manageable, with headline inflation at 3.1% y-o-y, and policy support will reinforce growth tailwinds. Economies such as India, Indonesia, and the Philippines may be more favourably positioned in 2021 due to their dependence on external funding and potential benefits from supply chain relocation.

site_title: IS claims Vienna shooting as Austria mourns
summary: A lone gunman, identified as 20-year-old Kujtim Fejzulai, a self-described IS sympathizer, opened fire on a busy area of Vienna, killing four people and injuring 23. Austrian investigators claim Fejzulai acted alone, but IS has claimed responsibility for the attack. The gunman had been convicted of a terror offense, but managed to secure an early release from a 22-month prison sentence after participating in a government-funded de-radicalization program. Chancellor Sebastian Kurz called for a European response to "political Islam" and condemned the attack as a "repulsive terror attack".

site_title: Thematic funds to invest in megatrends
summary: Thematic funds, launched by Natixis Investment Managers affiliate Thematic Asset Management, aim to profit from megatrends. The five funds focus on global, long-term trends, cutting across sectors and geographies. They include Thematics AI & Robotics, Safety, Water, Subscription Economy, and Meta Fund, with assets under management of approximately 2.5 billion euros. The funds are actively managed and unconstrained, with most co-founders being veteran fund managers from Pictet Asset Management. Despite a short track record, the funds have shown strong performance, with a common growth-oriented and small-to-mid-cap focus.

site_title: Kimly and Tenderfresh enter joint venture to open halal coffee shop
summary: Kimly, a Singaporean coffee shop operator, has entered a joint venture with Tenderfresh Fried & BBQ Chicken to open a halal-themed eatery in Clementi. Kimly holds a 51% stake, while Tenderfresh holds 49%. This collaboration aims to cater to the growing demand for halal food options in Singapore.

site_title: Not to be missed live-streamed concerts
summary: Notable live-streamed concerts are available this month, offering a diverse range of musical performances. The Detroit Symphony Orchestra premieres Tyshawn Sorey's "For Marcos Balter" on November 6, while pianist Vicky Chow performs Cassie Wieland's "HYMN" on November 12. The Los Angeles Opera streams "The Anonymous Lover" on November 14, and the San Francisco Symphony premieres Nico Muhly's "Throughline" on November 14. Other notable performances include the Seattle Symphony's premiere of Tyshawn Sorey's "For Roscoe Mitchell" on November 19, and a recital by pianist Igor Levit and cellist Julia Hagen at Wigmore Hall on November 30.

site_title: As one IMO icon passes, which way will the organisation sail?
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is mourning the death of its former secretary-general, William O'Neil, at the age of 93. O'Neil, a Canadian citizen, served four terms as secretary-general from 1990 to 2004 and was known for his dedication to maritime safety and the universality of IMO. During his tenure, he oversaw significant improvements in maritime safety standards, including the adoption of the International Safety Management (ISM) Code and the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers (STCW). Current IMO secretary-general Kitack Lim praised O'Neil's legacy, saying he left a lasting impact on the organization and its work.

site_title: ESG is having its moment, and so are its female champions
summary: Women are increasingly taking on prominent roles in traditionally male-dominated fields like finance and real estate, particularly in sustainability and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives. In Singapore, initiatives such as City Developments' Women4Green network and the Monetary Authority of Singapore's green investments program are promoting female leaders in ESG. Experts attribute the growing prominence of women in ESG to their long-term perspective and ability to consider groups and systems over individual interests. With the COVID-19 pandemic accelerating the ESG agenda, female advocates emphasize the need for collective ownership and system-wide participation to drive sustainability goals.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.01 points lower on Tuesday at 1,461.45. The index saw a trading volume of 6.448 billion lots worth RM3.305 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 669 to 384.

site_title: Kimly and Tenderfresh enter joint venture to open halal coffeeshop
summary: Kimly, a coffee shop operator, has entered a joint venture with Tenderfresh Fried & BBQ Chicken to open a halal-themed eatery in Clementi, Singapore. Kimly holds a 51% stake, while Tenderfresh holds 49%. The coffee shop, branded Kedai Kopi, is expected to reopen in mid-December after enhancement work.

site_title: Biden victory seen as positive for Asian equities: analysts
summary: US President Joe Biden's victory is seen as positive for Asian equities, particularly Singapore, according to DBS Group Research. A Biden win is expected to ease US-China trade tensions, benefiting companies with exposure to the US and China, such as Valuetronics and Hi-P. China-related stocks like China Aviation Oil and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust are also poised to benefit from a Biden victory. Analysts predict a smooth passage of a second US fiscal stimulus and a lift in international travel once a vaccine is available, positioning Singapore's aviation and hospitality stocks for recovery.

images.alt_text: The DBS research team noted that Mr Biden is likely to end the United States' trade war with the EU, and adopt a more open and negotiable approach with China with tariffs being reconsidered or removed.

site_title: The war against Big Tech
summary: The US Department of Justice has filed an antitrust case against Google, alleging the company has made its search engine the default choice in electronic devices, hindering competition. This landmark lawsuit received bipartisan support, marking a rare feat in US politics. The case may signal a shift in power dynamics between governments and corporations, potentially leading to changes in regulation of Big Tech.

site_title: Built-environment measures aim to spread out Covid-19 burden
summary: Singapore has introduced new measures to alleviate the burden of the pandemic on the built-environment sector. The measures include a four-month extension of construction contracts, with contractors, developers, and purchasers eligible for similar extensions and reimbursement of costs incurred due to delays. Minister for National Development Desmond Lee aims to ensure no single part of the sector bears an disproportionate share of the burden.

site_title: US Election Day begins
summary: US Election Day began on November 3, 2020, with polls opening in several states, including New York, New Jersey, and Virginia. The first polling stations opened in New Hampshire's Dixville Notch and Millsfield villages at midnight. The election marks a referendum on Donald Trump's presidency, with Joe Biden urging Americans to end it to restore democracy.

site_title: US construction spending rises less than expected in Sept
summary: US construction spending rose 0.3% in September, less than the expected increase. This was driven by gains in private-sector investment, but public outlays declined. Data for August was revised down to 0.8%, not 1.4% as initially reported. The decrease in public outlays partially offset the private sector gains, resulting in a slower-than-expected increase in construction spending.

site_title: Xi warns of rising risks as CCP charts course for next five years
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned of rising risks as the Communist Party charts its course for the next five years. The warning comes after a four-day meeting on economic and social policy goals, which concluded last month. Xi expressed concerns about significant risks facing the country, but no specific details were provided. The meeting's recommendations will guide the party's decisions on economic and social policies for the next five years.

site_title: KLM pilots agree to extended wage freeze, clearing way for state support
summary: KLM pilots have agreed to an extended wage freeze, meeting government demands for 3.4 billion euros in state-backed support. The pilots' union initially agreed to a 3-year wage cut, but the government asked for a 3-year freeze. The agreement clears the way for the airline to receive the government support, with Finance Minister Wopke Hoekstra now determining whether the demands have been met.

site_title: US: Wall St gains at open on Biden victory bets
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Tuesday, driven by bets on a Joe Biden victory, with the Dow Jones gaining 213.64 points, the S&P 500 opening higher by 26.01 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 81.05 points. These gains come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions. The market is positioning for a potential Biden presidency, which investors expect could lead to policy changes and increased economic growth.

site_title: US factory orders up 1.1% in September
summary: US factory orders rose 1.1% in September, surpassing economists' expectations of a 1.0% increase. The boost was driven by demand for primary metals, computers, and motor vehicles. However, orders for machinery, furniture, and electrical equipment fell. The solid growth is expected to be short-lived, as government aid for businesses and workers impacted by the pandemic is set to expire, potentially slowing consumer spending.

site_title: Major leak sees one million Swedes' data shared with Facebook, Google
summary: Folksam, Sweden's largest insurer, accidentally leaked private data on around one million customers to tech firms including Facebook, Google, and Microsoft. The data was shared without consent, and the company has since stopped sharing it and requested its deletion. Folksam's head of marketing stated that the incident was taken seriously, but no further information was provided about the incident's cause or potential consequences.

site_title: Deutsche Bank wants to cut ties with Trump, but sees no good options
summary: Deutsche Bank is seeking to end its relationship with US President Donald Trump due to negative publicity stemming from their ties. The bank has approximately $340 million in loans outstanding to the Trump Organization, led by his sons. Despite this, Deutsche Bank finds no viable options for severing ties, given the potential reputational damage and potential legal implications. The bank's decision highlights the challenges of distancing oneself from a high-profile client like Trump.

site_title: Hopes of a blue wave lift global markets; but FOMO may mask risks
summary: Global markets surged ahead of the US presidential election, with Asian markets rising and Wall Street opening on a bullish note. The Singapore market was among the best performers, with analysts predicting volatility to spike in the next 48 hours. Companies like NTT DC Reit and OCBC also made headlines, with NTT DC Reit's public offer being oversubscribed 9.8 times and OCBC announcing the retirement of its CEO and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as the new CEO.

site_title: The war on truth reaches its climax
summary: The article discusses the author's experience writing about presidential candidates' false claims in the early 2000s. The author notes that their editors initially discouraged using the word "lie" to describe such claims. However, by now, most observers have accepted that US President Donald Trump lies constantly. The article highlights the growing trend of truth being distorted and manipulated, particularly under Trump's presidency, and questions the future of truth in journalism and politics.

site_title: China consumers splurge on 2,700-yuan hairy crabs
summary: Chinese consumers are spending large amounts on hairy crabs, with prices doubling compared to last year. These delicacies can cost up to 2,700 yuan (S$550) for a box of eight and are only available for a few weeks in autumn. Workers at an aquaculture farm in Shanghai are packing and shipping the crabs to customers nationwide, meeting high demand for the seasonal treat.

images.alt_text: As more customers treat themselves to homegrown luxuries, prices for hairy crabs - which can only be purchased for a few weeks in autumn - have doubled compared to a year ago.

site_title: Global financial institutions sinking sustainability roots in Singapore
summary: Global financial institutions are setting up dedicated sustainability teams in Singapore, drawn by the city-state's good regulatory oversight, green economy, and strong investor ecosystem. Investment firms such as Fidelity International are establishing teams to promote sustainable development. Singapore's regulatory environment and investor ecosystem are attracting financial institutions to the city-state, with many opting to set up operations there. This trend is expected to continue as Asian companies, investors, and consumers increasingly prioritize sustainability.

site_title: Seeking additional compensation? Be transparent about it
summary: Singapore's trade-dependent economy may need to reduce labor costs to survive the pandemic, prompting some employees to seek additional income streams. Employees must be transparent when doing so, as required by the CFA Institute's Additional Compensation Arrangements Standard. This includes obtaining written consent from employers and disclosing all compensation arrangements to avoid conflicts of interest and maintain objectivity. Employees must also report any additional compensation to their supervisors and comply with the standard's procedures to ensure ethical behavior.

site_title: Temasek invests in China fund aimed at developing agrifood technology
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investment firm, has invested in a US$30 million fund focused on developing agrifood technology in China. The fund, launched by Chinese venture capital firm Bits x Bites, aims to address challenges such as swine fever and Covid-19 outbreaks. Other limited partners include Heritas Capital Management and several Chinese institutions. This investment marks Temasek's further push into the agrifood space, highlighting the growing interest in sustainable food production and technology.

site_title: Lendlease Reit says Covid-19 may cut rents at 313@somerset
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) warns that Covid-19 may lead to depressed rents at 313@somerset due to a subdued retail sector and weak leasing demand. The company expects leasing activities to remain soft, despite the recovery of the economy. This could result in lower rents for both new and renewed leases, impacting the property's income.

images.alt_text: Occupancy at the Singapore mall totalled 95.6 per cent by the end of September, although LReit's manager has secured a new tenant since then, which will improve the occupancy to 98 per cent.

site_title: More option-to-purchase data from developers will benefit homebuyers, shareholders
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has allowed developers to continue honouring prior commitments to property buyers, including option-to-purchase (OTPs) issued before September 28, 2020. This move aims to reduce distortions in the sales volume of developers. The URA's decision applies to OTPs with existing agreements and re-issuance periods. This relief is expected to benefit homebuyers and shareholders, as it will provide more clarity and stability in the market.

site_title: Singapore, regional markets surge on eve of US election
summary: Markets worldwide surged on the eve of the US presidential election, driven by anticipation of US fiscal stimulus post-election. The S&P 500 Index rose 1.23%, outpacing the Nasdaq Composite Index's 0.42% gain. A Biden win, initially expected to be negative for stocks, is now seen as a catalyst for broader stimulus, rather than tax hikes. Despite uncertainty surrounding the election outcome, investor sentiment remains positive, with Singapore and regional markets leading the gains.

site_title: Semiconductor sector likely to emerge stronger post-pandemic
summary: The semiconductor sector is poised to emerge stronger post-pandemic, driven by businesses accelerating technology investments. Despite a year-to-date low in March, semiconductor companies have recovered, and sales growth has risen by 4.1% and 5.5% year-over-year in Q1 and Q2 2020, respectively. Supply chain disruptions and dampened consumer confidence initially affected chipmakers, but the industry is expected to benefit from the shift towards technology investments. As the global economy recovers, the semiconductor sector is likely to gain further upside.

site_title: Donald Trump's Covid-19 comeuppance
summary: US President Donald Trump's handling of the Covid-19 crisis is seen as a reflection of his career pattern of serial bankruptcies. The pandemic has exposed his poor judgment, inability to think about others, and tendency to shift blame onto others. The human and economic losses from the crisis are substantial, but Trump will likely walk away with minimal consequences, blaming everyone else. This marks a stark contrast to the long-term consequences faced by the US and its citizens.

site_title: World's biggest IPO halted as Ant Group feels Shanghai's bite
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) has suspended Ant Group's $34 billion dual listing, just two days before the planned IPO in Shanghai and Hong Kong. The move comes after a meeting between Ant Group co-founder Jack Ma and top exchange executives. The cancellation is a shock decision, and the reasons behind it are not yet clear. The suspension is a significant blow to Ant Group and the global IPO market, with investors waiting to see what the future holds for the company.

site_title: China stops Jack Ma's US$35b Ant IPO from going ahead
summary: China halted Ant Group's US$35 billion initial public offering (IPO) on Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges after Jack Ma's firm faced increased scrutiny and restrictions on capital and leverage, similar to those for banks. The move came after Ma was summoned to a meeting with regulators, who warned of significant changes in the regulatory environment. The IPO, which would have valued Ant at US$315 billion, has been suspended, and Alibaba Group's US-traded shares plummeted 9.6% in response.

site_title: Malaysian Budget: Coalescing of political rivals comes not a moment too soon
summary: Malaysia's 2021 Budget is expected to receive bipartisan support, following meetings between Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Abdul Aziz and opposition parties. This comes after a state of emergency attempt was deemed an attempt to circumvent parliamentary scrutiny. The Budget speech is set for delivery on Friday, with input from opposition Pakatan Harapan coalition parties and Umno representatives. The move suggests a shift towards cooperation between ruling and opposition parties, providing a measure of stability in a tumultuous political landscape.

site_title: Indonesian president quietly signs divisive stimulus into law overnight
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo quietly signed a divisive stimulus bill into law, expanding from 812 to 1,187 pages and sparking widespread protests. The law strips labor and environmental protections, allowing for projects to proceed without assessments or consultation with Indigenous people. It also gets rid of minimum severance pay requirements and allows businesses to replace full-time employees with cheaper contract workers. Critics argue the law is detrimental to workers, while the Indonesian government claims it will generate 1 million new jobs a year, sparking a nationwide strike and potential judicial review.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment gauge rises by 0.2 point to 50.5 in October
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment gauge rose to 50.5 points in October, its strongest showing since March 2019, indicating growth. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading increased by 0.2 point, driven by faster growth in new orders, new exports, and factory output. The electronics industry also saw growth, with its PMI reading reaching 51.0 points. While overall employment readings posted slower rates of contraction, electronics employment may be bottoming out and could move towards expansion.

site_title: A case of he said, she said, no one said
summary: A new Neil LaBute play, "True Love Will Find You in the End," opened at the Denizen Theatre in New Paltz, New York, featuring a live audience but recorded actors due to COVID-19 restrictions. The 46-minute play explores the subject of marriage through a twisty plot and abstract presentation. Critics praise the actors' performances but find the story slim and the presentation too gimmicky. The play tackles themes of marriage, love, and deception, and some critics have previously criticized LaBute's portrayal of women. The production offers a gentler view of the gender wars, presenting the husband as a likable character.

site_title: Jewellery maker Pandora warns new lockdowns may hurt peak season sales
summary: Danish jewellery-maker Pandora reported an 8% decline in third-quarter sales to 4.07 billion Danish crowns, despite positive sales momentum in October. The company expects new coronavirus lockdowns to force it to close 18% of its shops worldwide in November, affecting peak season sales. Pandora revised its full-year profit guidance upward in the previous month but now cites "downside risk" due to the lockdowns and potential Covid-19 escalation.

site_title: Hong Kong's financial system battered by big IPO deals
summary: Hong Kong's financial system is vulnerable to large flows of money due to its small size, open capital borders, and pegged currency. The city's stock market is becoming the main beneficiary of Chinese firms' shift away from Wall Street, with the Ant Group's cancelled IPO being a notable example. The massive demand for Ant's shares would likely prompt more firms to sell shares in Hong Kong, boosting its market capitalisation and rivaling New York. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority intervened to flood the banking system with liquidity, which could lead to increased central bank intervention and potential economic instability.

site_title: Construction sector given more time and other help to share burden across value chain
summary: Singapore's government proposes new measures to support the construction sector affected by the pandemic, including a universal four-month extension of time for construction contracts and reimbursement of costs incurred due to delays. The measures aim to share the burden across the value chain, including contractors, developers, and property purchasers. The government also provides for co-sharing of additional costs and dispute resolution mechanisms to ensure fair treatment of all parties involved.

site_title: Robinsons' liquidators 'hopeful' of continuing sales to mid or end December
summary: Robinsons, a 162-year-old department store in Singapore, has announced it will liquidate its two remaining stores due to changing consumer tastes and cost pressures. The decision, made after an inability to continue operations due to weak demand, is expected to be completed by mid to end December 2020. Customers can still shop at the brick-and-mortar stores, while the e-commerce platforms have ceased operations. The liquidators, KordaMentha, are working with stakeholders to agree on a sales timeline.

site_title: North Korea building two submarines, one capable of firing ballistic missiles, says lawmaker
summary: North Korea is building two new submarines, including one capable of firing ballistic missiles, according to a South Korean lawmaker. The submarines, a modified Romeo Class and a new medium-large size one, are part of a large submarine fleet and come after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's vow to unveil new strategic weapons. This development follows recent military parades showcasing North Korea's long-range missiles and a successful test-fire of a submarine-launched ballistic missile from the sea.

site_title: SIAEC records net loss of S$19m in H1, Covid-19 impact cushioned by govt grants
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) recorded a net loss of S$19 million in the first half of its financial year due to a 56.5% decline in revenue and a 47.4% decrease in expenditure. The group's business activities were reduced due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but government grants partially cushioned the impact. SIAEC's operating loss was S$27.2 million, and the group incurred a non-cash impairment loss of S$35 million on its base maintenance unit's assets. The company remains cautious about its recovery outlook and is implementing cost-management measures to adapt to the changing market environment.

site_title: Employers exempt from paying income tax on Jobs Support Scheme payouts
summary: Employers in Singapore who received wage subsidies under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) and other government payouts will not have to pay income tax on these subsidies. The exemptions apply to the 2021 and 2022 tax years, allowing citizens and business owners to benefit from the full amount of support measures without paying tax.

site_title: UK unfrozen property funds see more than £300m in Oct outflows: Calastone
summary: UK property funds saw 336 million pounds in net outflows in October, the third worst monthly performance on record, with 70 billion pound sector experiencing a six-month freeze due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Several major asset managers have reopened their funds, leading to a "shake-out" of investors withdrawing their capital. The sector has only seen more outflows on two previous occasions, and Calastone expects more redemptions until the appetite to sell is sated.

site_title: Microsoft to join US$100m investment in Indonesia's Bukalapak
summary: Microsoft is set to join a $100 million investment in Indonesian online marketplace Bukalapak.com, valuing the company at $2.5-3 billion. This deal brings Microsoft together with existing backers GIC and Emtek Group, and is part of Bukalapak's efforts to raise $200 million for online expansion. This investment follows other major tech companies, including Google, Facebook, and PayPal, which have also invested in Indonesian startups.

site_title: Nine new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with seven imported and none in the community
summary: Nine new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 58,029. Seven cases were imported, with none in the community. Two cases were detected in worker's dormitories. The remaining five imported cases tested positive on Monday, including a 42-year-old Singaporean woman who returned from the Philippines. With 57,922 patients recovered, 38 remain in hospital, and 28 deaths have been reported from Covid-19 complications.

site_title: Eggless egg-maker Eat Just prepping for Europe rollout next year
summary: Eat Just Inc, a plant-based food startup, is preparing for a European rollout of its eggless egg product next year, pending EU safety approvals. The company has lined up a manufacturer, distributor, and delivery service, and is in talks with major retailers and restaurants. With growing demand for plant-based proteins in Western Europe, Eat Just aims to expand beyond its current markets in the US, Hong Kong, and mainland China, with a planned factory in Singapore set to open by mid-2022.

site_title: Philippines allows land-based casinos to accept bets online
summary: The Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp has approved land-based casinos to accept online bets, aiming to mitigate losses from the pandemic. The move allows Bloomberry Resorts Corp's Solaire Resort and Casino, City of Dreams Manila, and Okada Manila to operate online betting, with gaming stocks rising. This decision is expected to help integrated casino resorts "survive and get through the pandemic," generating revenue and offsetting the 96% decline in Philippine gross gaming revenue in the second quarter.

site_title: One Parisian infected with Covid-19 every 30 seconds - health minister
summary: France's health minister, Olivier Veran, stated that one Parisian is infected with Covid-19 every 30 seconds, and another arrives in the hospital every 15 minutes due to the disease. Veran emphasized that opening small businesses during the new lockdown would be too risky given the high infection rates in Paris. France reported a record 52,518 new Covid-19 cases on Monday, with a death toll of 37,435.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Tuesday, extending a previous day's rally, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street ahead of the US presidential election. The Hang Seng Index climbed 1.96%, reaching 24,939.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.42% and 1.43%, respectively. The rally follows recent gains in the US market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Julius Baer CEO expects M&A restrictions to be lifted next year, open to big acquisitions
summary: Julius Baer CEO Phillipp Rickenbacher expects restrictions imposed by Switzerland's financial watchdog FINMA to be lifted in 2021, following improvements in the bank's anti-money laundering compliance. The restrictions, imposed in February, prohibited the bank from making large acquisitions. Rickenbacher stated that acquisitions will continue to play a role in the bank's future, and he is open to big, transformational acquisitions.

site_title: Beijing puts Ant on a shorter leash
summary: Beijing has taken steps to rein in Ant Group, a fintech giant, ahead of its record-setting IPO. Founder Jack Ma was summoned by regulators for a chat, and new draft rules have been released to treat technology middlemen more like banks. The rules, open to public feedback until Dec 2, include caps on leverage and require firms like Ant to shoulder default risks together with banks. The move could significantly impact Ant's business model, which relies on processing huge amounts of credit without capital constraints.

site_title: Hong Kong seen selling debt to mop up cash after Ant's IPO
summary: Hong Kong's central bank is expected to sell extra debt, specifically Exchange Fund Bills, to absorb liquidity following Ant Group's initial public offering, which drew HK$1.3 trillion in orders. The move aims to manage liquidity and prevent excessive risk-taking by investors. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has already planned to sell about HK$829 billion of the bills this quarter, with the possibility of additional sales to withdraw liquidity. The sale will be done in small sizes to minimize volatility in interbank borrowing costs.

site_title: Singapore will stop issuing S$1,000 notes next year to curb money laundering risks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will discontinue the issuance of S$1,000 notes from January 1, 2021, to curb money laundering risks. Existing notes in circulation will remain legal tender and can be recirculated by banks. To meet demand, the MAS will provide sufficient quantities of other denominations, particularly the S$100 note. This move aligns with international norms and aims to prevent large-denomination notes from facilitating illicit activities.

site_title: Billionaire Adani set to develop Sri Lanka's port terminal
summary: India's Adani Group, led by billionaire Gautam Adani, is set to develop Sri Lanka's stalled East Container Terminal in Colombo port. The project, which was initially stalled due to labor protests, has received in-principle approval from Sri Lanka's government. The deal, which involves a local partner, will hold a majority stake in the project. This development comes as Sri Lanka seeks to diversify its infrastructure development and reduce its dependence on China, with rising regional tensions between India and China.

site_title: Regus operator IWG sees improving sales activity
summary: IWG, the operator of Regus offices, reported improving sales activity and increasing interest in flexible working as companies address post-pandemic work arrangements. Revenue fell 10.2% to £583.3 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, but the company is on track to achieve targeted annualized cost savings of £200 million. IWG's shares rose 2.6% following the announcement, driven by the company's growth prospects in suburban locations and small office sales. The company is also close to deploying the first tranche of capital raised in May.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain the most in nearly 5 months on strong global data
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.88% to a near five-month high, driven by strong factory output data from major economies, including China, the US, and the Euro zone. The Kospi index gained 43.15 points to 2,343.31. The market shrugged off concerns over a resurgent pandemic and US election jitters, with foreigners buying US$180.10 million worth of shares. Analysts expect market uncertainties to persist if the US presidential election result is disapproved.

site_title: STI climbs 2.21% to 2,497.22 points on eve of US presidential polls
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.21% to 2,497.22 points on the eve of the US presidential election, outpacing global markets. The rally was driven by anticipation of a broader fiscal stimulus, regardless of the winner. Technology-heavy stocks initially fell but rebounded, while market bellwether DBS and Thai Beverage were among the top performers. The STI's gain was attributed to investors focusing on the potential stimulus, rather than the potential impact of a Biden win on corporate tax cuts.

site_title: EssilorLuxottica quarterly sales recover as second virus wave looms
summary: EssilorLuxottica reported a 1.1% decline in third-quarter sales to 4.09 billion euros, recovering from a 50% drop in the second quarter as stores reopened globally. The company remains cautious about the near-term impact of COVID-19 and potential pent-up demand. Despite this, it expressed confidence in the structural resilience of optical needs and confirmed its target of 420-600 million euros in net synergies by 2023. The company also considers paying a dividend in December, suspended in March, and will appeal against a Dutch court's verdict rejecting its bid for GrandVision.

site_title: The truckers who keep India's coronavirus patients breathing
summary: Indian truckers, like Subhas Kumar Yadav, have played a crucial role in delivering medical oxygen to hospitals during the coronavirus pandemic, despite facing challenges such as deserted roads, police checks, and shuttered roadside facilities. The government has seen a surge in demand for oxygen, with around half of India's total liquid oxygen production now used for medical needs. Companies like Linde India have responded by increasing production and deploying their entire fleet of trucks to deliver oxygen to hospitals, with no single stock-out situation reported.

site_title: BNP Paribas' profit drops less than feared in Q3
summary: BNP Paribas reported Q3 net income of 1.89 billion euros, down 2.3% from the same period last year, beating analyst expectations. Revenue was flat at 10.89 billion euros. Trading revenue rose 17.4% and fixed-income trading revenue jumped 36%. The bank attributed the results to bumper trading volumes and a more optimistic outlook on loan losses. Its cost of risk increased by 47% to 1.24 billion euros, but lower than expected. Net income in the first nine months fell 13.4% and remains ahead of the bank's full-year profit guidance of minus 15-20%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is moving towards recovery, with Second Minister for Law Edwin Tong calling for businesses to reallocate resources to more productive uses. The government has proposed measures to support the construction sector, including a four-month extension of time for contracts, to share the burden of the pandemic. The Straits Times Index rose 2.21% to 2,497.22 points, driven by all 30 component stocks in positive territory. Meanwhile, Temasek and Heritas Capital have invested in a Chinese agrifood tech fund, and ARA Logos raised S$50m in a private placement to finance its acquisition of Australian properties.

site_title: Roma mansions in Moldova abandoned in economic exodus
summary: In Moldova's Soroca town, 30 grand Roma mansions built in the 1980s are now abandoned, reflecting the community's economic exodus. The extravagant homes, designed to flaunt wealth, were built in various styles inspired by international destinations. Many owners have left, with some settling in post-Soviet countries like Russia and Azerbaijan. Only a handful of homes remain inhabited, while others stand empty, symbolizing the community's decline in the impoverished European country.

site_title: Lenovo profit beats expectations, helped by remote working trend
summary: Lenovo reported a 53% jump in quarterly net profit to US$310 million, beating estimates of US$224 million, driven by the "new normal" of remote working due to Covid-19. Revenue increased 7% to US$14.5 billion. The company's PC sales benefited from the shift to remote work, with Lenovo continuing to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: China's Meituan says it has no plans for a second listing on the mainland
summary: Meituan, China's food delivery giant, has stated it has no plans for a secondary listing on the mainland. The company had been considering a listing on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext board, but now says it will not pursue this option. Meituan's shares rose 2% following the news, and the company has seen its shares quadruple since its Hong Kong debut two years ago as it expands into new areas, including fresh food delivery.

site_title: Melbourne Cup's grim toll grows with Anthony Van Dyck death
summary: The Melbourne Cup, Australia's prestigious horse racing event, experienced a grim toll with the death of Epsom Derby winner Anthony Van Dyck, who broke down and was euthanized with 350 meters to run. The incident has raised concerns over the treatment of thoroughbreds, with seven horses killed in the event since 2013. The death has sparked anger from animal rights activists, who argue that the horses are being used for "gambling money." Racing Victoria has promised a "fatality report" to prevent similar incidents in the future, amid a decline in attendances and growing protests from animal rights groups.

site_title: Re-Align Framework tackles power imbalance faced by small, micro firms
summary: Singapore is introducing the Re-Align Framework to help small and micro enterprises renegotiate or exit contracts without penalties due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The framework aims to enable businesses to reallocate resources to more productive uses, rather than being stuck in unproductive struggles. The government is also introducing the Simplified Insolvency Programme to make it easier for firms to restructure debts or liquidate assets. The framework will cover contracts such as leases, supply contracts, and hire-purchase agreements, and will have an objective criterion for determining eligibility based on revenue fall.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain 2% as central bank trims rates, expands bond buying
summary: Australian shares rose 2% to their best session in nearly a month, driven by the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to trim interest rates and expand its bond-buying program. The central bank moved rates to near zero and announced a $100 billion quantitative easing program. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished at 6,066.40, with domestic energy stocks and gold rallying. The decision aims to aid economic recovery from the country's worst recession in a generation, despite ongoing border closures and weak business investment.

site_title: STI jumps 1.4% on Tuesday afternoon as investors eye US election results
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 1.4% on Tuesday, driven by expectations of a "blue wave" victory for Joe Biden in the US presidential elections. The rally was also fueled by overnight Wall Street gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing 1.6% higher. Key gainers included Jiutian Chemical, Sembcorp Marine, DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Analysts believe Biden's victory could lead to reduced tariffs, benefiting China-related stocks such as China Aviation Oil and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust.

site_title: Broker's take: Biden victory may give boost to Hi-P, Valuetronics, China Aviation Oil, HPHT
summary: US Democratic candidate Joe Biden's victory may boost Asian equities, particularly Singapore-listed companies with exposure to the US and China. Companies such as Hi-P, Valuetronics, and China Aviation Oil are expected to benefit from eased US-China trade tensions. A Biden win could also lead to the smooth passage of a second US fiscal stimulus, benefiting Singapore-listed oil service providers. Analysts at DBS Group Research predict a positive impact on Asian equities, with the Straits Times Index likely to recover above March lows.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open on US election day
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced at the open on US election day, with London's FTSE 100 up 1.1%, Paris's CAC 40 adding 0.9%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 increasing 0.6%. Investors are bracing for significant volatility as Americans prepare to vote, with many betting on a Democratic sweep that would likely lead to a huge economic stimulus package. The US presidential election has driven sentiment, with nearly 100 million people having already voted, and Joe Biden maintaining a healthy lead over Donald Trump in national polls.

site_title: Looking for job advice? Try TikTok
summary: TikTok has become a platform for career coaches to share job search advice and provide free guidance to job seekers, particularly during the pandemic. Influencers such as JT O'Donnell, Madeline Mann, and Cathryn Patterson have gained significant followings, offering tips on resume writing, interviewing, and navigating job insecurity. These creators aim to disrupt the traditional coaching business model by offering affordable, bite-sized advice and resources, with some even receiving income from the TikTok Creator Fund.

images.alt_text: JT O'Donnell has been helping people navigate their job searches and career paths for nearly 20 years. But only recently did she start doling out professional advice on TikTok.

site_title: Wingstop tests chicken thighs to offset soaring US wing prices
summary: Wingstop, a restaurant chain, is testing bone-in chicken thighs to offset rising US wing prices, which have been volatile due to inflation and increased demand. The company has added thighs to its menu in some markets and raised prices for consumers. Wholesale wing prices in the Northeast are at their highest since 2010, according to Department of Agriculture data. The thigh test began two weeks ago in seven US markets. Wingstop's shares dropped 2.4% after the earnings call.

site_title: Philippines' Petron says Bataan refinery back to normal operations
summary: Petron Corp, the Philippines' only oil refiner, has resumed normal operations at its 180,000-barrel-per-day Bataan refinery, which was shut down in May for maintenance and financial reasons due to the pandemic. The company aims to keep its refinery running but seeks government support via tax relief, citing higher taxes on refiners compared to importers. Energy Secretary Alfonso Cusi is evaluating the impact of the refinery's closure on pricing and energy security.

site_title: Saudi Aramco Q3 profit slumps 44.6% as pandemic chokes demand
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 44.6% drop in Q3 net profit to 44.21 billion riyals due to lower crude oil prices and volumes sold amid the coronavirus crisis. The company's refining and chemicals margins also decreased, contributing to the decline. Despite this, CEO Amin Nasser noted early signs of a recovery in the third quarter. Aramco plans to distribute a dividend of $18.75 billion for the quarter, helping the Saudi government manage its fiscal deficit.

site_title: Former Thai prime ministers to be part of reconciliation panel
summary: Thailand's House Speaker Chuan Leekpai has proposed a reconciliation committee to resolve issues raised by pro-democracy protesters, which may include former prime ministers and representatives of political parties. The move comes after King Maha Vajiralongkorn's olive branch to protesters, who are demanding transparency, accountability, and constitutional changes. The committee's formation may help diffuse political tension, but protest groups have threatened to remain on the streets until their demands are met. The parliament will restart discussions on charter amendment on November 17, with a vote on rewriting the constitution scheduled for November 18.

site_title: Hugo Boss focused on China and online to bolster sales
summary: Hugo Boss reported a return to profitability in the third quarter, driven by a 27% increase in sales in mainland China and a 66% jump in online sales. The company launched ecommerce in 24 more markets, bolstering its online presence. Revenue fell 24% to 533 million euros, missing forecasts, but operating profit was slightly ahead of consensus. Hugo Boss shifted its focus to casual wear and sports styles, with sales of its Hugo label targeting younger consumers only down by a mid single-digit percentage.

site_title: 7-Eleven parent to sell up to 300 petrol stations after buying Speedway: sources
summary: Seven & i Holdings Co, parent of 7-Eleven, is planning to sell up to 300 gas stations following its $21 billion acquisition of Marathon Petroleum Corp. The company is working with investment bank Nomura Holdings to solicit buyers, with private equity firm TDR Capital set to make an offer for the stations. This move aims to address overlap between 7-Eleven and Speedway stores, as Seven & i seeks to focus on other markets where its business is growing.

site_title: Investors in Thailand undeterred by political unrest: Report
summary: Thailand's foreign direct investment (FDI) remains on track despite ongoing political unrest, according to a report by DBS economists Radhika Rao and Philip Wee. The analysts note that while the Covid-19 outbreak and protests have pressured inbound tourism, the impact on the economy is unlikely to be long-lasting. The report highlights growth drivers such as Thailand's manufacturing capabilities and investment incentives, including a 50% corporate tax cut. A fiscal spending package is underway, and disbursement of FY2021 Budget funds is not expected to be delayed. FDI commitments have not been deterred.

site_title: Tired of Trump, Deutsche Bank wants out but sees no good options: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank is seeking ways to end its relationship with President Donald Trump after the US elections due to negative publicity stemming from the ties. The bank has about $340 million in loans outstanding to the Trump Organization, with three loans set to come due in 2023 and 2024. Deutsche Bank management has discussed selling the loans in the secondary market, but this idea has not gained traction. The bank is considering alternative options, such as demanding repayment or foreclosing, but its plans will depend on the outcome of the elections. If Democrats take control, Deutsche Bank executives believe they will have more freedom to deal with the loans and end their relationship with Trump.

site_title: BlackRock upgrades EM, Asia stocks on Blue Wave expectations from US election
summary: BlackRock upgraded Asia ex-Japan and emerging market equities to overweight ahead of the US election, citing positive spillovers to global growth from increased fiscal stimulus and a more predictable US trade and foreign policy under a Democratic sweep. This upgrade comes as investors expect a Blue Wave, with BlackRock also downgrading European equities to neutral and Japanese shares to underweight. The move is in line with other analysts, including JPMorgan Chase, which also upgraded emerging Asian equities.

site_title: Bayer flags US$750m higher Roundup settlement bill
summary: Bayer has increased its estimated settlement bill for Roundup weedkiller cancer claims by US$750 million, now totaling US$2 billion. The company initially estimated costs at US$11 billion. The increase is due to a revised class plan, which Bayer now expects to cost approximately US$2 billion, up from the original US$1.25 billion.

site_title: China issues draft rules to regulate online micro-lending business
summary: China's central bank and regulators have issued draft rules to regulate online micro-lending businesses, aiming to boost oversight and control rising debt levels in the coronavirus-hit economy. The draft rules set a 5 billion yuan registered capital threshold for micro-lenders and require them to provide at least 30% of loans funded jointly with banks. Micro-lenders sourcing borrower data from e-commerce platforms will also need to share credit information with the central bank. The rules, open for public feedback until December 2, are expected to lead to more cautious lending practices among banks.

site_title: Temasek, Heritas Capital invest in China agrifood tech fund by Bits x Bites
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings and Heritas Capital Management have invested in China agrifood tech fund Bits x Bites' $70 million fund. The fund aims to grow agrifood technology in China, focusing on precision agriculture, crop and animal health, and protein alternatives. Bits x Bites, backed by these LPs, has already invested in portfolio companies such as Mojia Bio and Tropic Biosciences, and expects a final closing in the coming months. The investment aims to advance bioscience and data science to tackle challenges in the food supply chain, particularly in China where self-sufficiency and sustainability are urgent concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong will require all cryptocurrency trading platforms to be regulated: SFC
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) will require all cryptocurrency trading platforms to be regulated, regardless of whether they trade securities. This move aims to bring cryptocurrency trading under the regulatory framework, following the SFC's previous 'opt-in' approach, which allowed some platforms to operate unregulated. The decision aims to increase transparency and protect investors in the city's cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.83 points or 0.19% to 1,469.29. Volume was 351.54 million lots worth RM119.14 million, with 302 gainers out of 71 losers.

site_title: Hairy crabs are selling out in China as consumers splurge
summary: China's demand for hairy crabs, a delicacy, is skyrocketing due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with prices doubling compared to last year. The seasonal delicacy, usually reserved for special occasions, is now being bought by big-spending consumers treating themselves to home-grown luxuries. With improved logistics, farmers can now deliver fresh crabs nationwide within two days, leading to a surge in demand, expected to reach 150 billion yuan this year.

site_title: NWC does not expect all employers to need to cut wages in next 12 months: Josephine Teo
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore does not expect all employers to cut wages in the next 12 months, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo. While some employers may need to adjust wages to save jobs, others have already adjusted or seen no reduction in demand. The NWC has set out a roadmap for eventual wage restoration and recommends that employers freeze wages for workers earning below S$1,400 to avoid retrenchment. The council aims to balance flexibility with safeguards against unwarranted wage cuts.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to pay RM34b government dividend in 2020: minister
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas will pay a government dividend of 34 billion ringgit (S$11.15 billion) in 2020, despite posting a loss of 21 billion ringgit in the second quarter. The company had initially committed to pay 24 billion ringgit, but increased the amount due to its affordability. The government expects a reduction of six billion ringgit in revenue this year due to lower oil prices.

site_title: Australia central bank trims rates, expands bond buying
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, trimmed interest rates to near zero and expanded its bond-buying program to aid economic recovery from its worst recession in a generation. The bank cut its three-year bond yield target to 0.1% and will buy A$100 billion of government bonds over the next six months. The move aims to sustainably keep inflation within a 2-3% target band, with the cash rate remaining unchanged until then.

site_title: California mayors plead for reopening of theme parks
summary: California mayors of eight major cities, including Los Angeles, appealed to Governor Gavin Newsom to ease COVID-19 restrictions on theme parks, citing concerns over 200,000 job losses and $1 billion in revenue. They requested that large parks like Disneyland and Universal Studios reopen in tier three with reduced capacity, rather than waiting for tier four, to avoid prolonged shutdowns.

images.alt_text: California mayors appealed to the state's governor Monday to ease Covid-19 restrictions that have shuttered theme parks such as Disneyland, warning that hundreds of thousands of jobs and billions in revenue were at stake.

site_title: Poll shows fintechs bullish about expanding businesses and workforce: Ng Chee Meng
summary: Singapore's financial technology sector remains optimistic about expanding businesses and workforce despite the COVID-19 crisis, according to a survey by the Singapore FinTech Association. Most fintech firms are bullish about growth, with a new report highlighting the significant growth of digital challenger banks in South-east Asia, attracting $15 billion in funding. Secretary-general of the National Trades Union Congress Ng Chee Meng urged financial institutions to invest in their workforce while embracing digital transformation, citing examples of traditional banks reskilling staff.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Tuesday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.94% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 24,689.56. The rally followed a strong performance on Wall Street, as voters went to the polls in the US presidential election. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, with the latter increasing 0.38%. The gains came despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend his rally, which traders brushed off.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 1.6% ahead of Election Day
summary: US stocks rose 1.6% on Monday, driven by gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The Dow ended at 26,925.05, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.2% and 0.4%, respectively. The gains came ahead of the US presidential election, reversing a week-long decline that marked the market's worst week and month since March.

site_title: Twitter board backs chief Jack Dorsey after ouster bid
summary: Twitter's board has backed CEO Jack Dorsey after an activist investor's bid to oust him. The decision came after a management review prompted by Elliott Management's efforts to remove Dorsey. The review found confidence in management and recommended keeping the current structure in place. Twitter had agreed to a deal with investors to launch a $2 billion share repurchase plan and created a temporary board committee to evaluate leadership. The committee's recommendations were endorsed by the board, allowing Dorsey to remain chief.

site_title: Ireland's Twilight Payment wins Melbourne Cup
summary: Ireland's Twilight Payment won the Melbourne Cup at an eerily quiet Flemington on Tuesday, with Jye McNeil in the saddle, defeating Tiger Moth and Prince of Arran in a thrilling finish. The 8-year-old held off competition in the 3,200-metre handicap, considered the ultimate test of stamina and staying power. This win marks a significant moment for the Irish raider, with McNeil expressing emotions of overwhelm and pride.

site_title: Malls dragged into bankruptcy by carnage at retail tenants
summary: Two major mall landlords, Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust (PREIT) and CBL & Associates Properties Inc, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection amid the pandemic's impact on brick-and-mortar retailers. The REITs, which own over 87 million square feet of real estate, cited pandemic-induced pressures on tenants and themselves. The bankruptcy filings follow a steady stream of chains seeking court protection, with over 30 CBL tenants going bankrupt in 2020. The companies aim to restructure and repay creditors, with PREIT seeking $150 million in additional capital and CBL slashing $1.5 billion in debt.

images.alt_text: America's ailing malls suffered a pair of body blows over the weekend as two major landlords followed their ever-growing list of bankrupt tenants into Chapter 11 protection.

site_title: StanChart Singapore awarded global certification for gender equality
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore has been awarded the EDGE certification, a global assessment methodology for gender equality, becoming the first financial institution in Singapore to receive this certification. The bank has a 45% female workforce, 35% female management team, and 31% female senior positions. To advance gender equality, StanChart Singapore has implemented policies such as paid maternity and adoption leave, awareness training for leaders, and flexible work arrangements. The bank aims to increase female representation in senior management to 35% by 2025.

site_title: South Korea's inflation slows in Oct, core CPI declines at fastest pace in over 21 years
summary: South Korea's inflation slowed in October, with the core CPI declining 0.3% year-on-year, the sharpest fall in over 21 years. The headline consumer price index rose 0.1% from a year earlier, well below expectations. The government's 20,000 won phone bill subsidy temporarily pulled down the data, but is expected to return to a positive territory in November. The country's total stimulus package amounts to 310 trillion won, aiming to soften coronavirus impacts on households and small businesses.

site_title: PipeChina halts construction at Beihai LNG terminal after fire kills 5
summary: PipeChina halted construction at its Beihai liquefied natural gas terminal in southern China after a fire killed five workers and injured three, with one person still missing. The fire occurred during pipeline construction at the terminal's second phase, which was scheduled to complete by June 2020. The company has suspended terminal operations and is cooperating with the rescue operation. The incident has also led to a ban on vessels entering and departing the port of Tieshangang, where the terminal is located.

site_title: Hungry hogs spark a green fuel rethink by Chinese energy giant
summary: China's oil refiner Sinopec Group is scaling back its sales of E10 fuel due to a "severe shortage" of ethanol supplies, mainly caused by a surge in corn prices driven by a boom in hog herds. Corn prices have jumped over 30% this year, making ethanol production more expensive. The shortage has led to reduced ethanol output, making it harder for fuel suppliers to meet demand, and may further reduce China's adoption of E10 fuel nationwide.

site_title: Gold inches lower as investors await US election outcome
summary: Gold prices edged down 0.1% to $1,892.52 per ounce, awaiting the outcome of the US presidential election. Investors are cautious due to the uncertainty of the election's outcome, which could impact fiscal stimulus and the dollar's value. Analysts say a Biden win could boost the bullion rally, while a Trump re-election could weaken gold due to uncertain or contested results. The Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Wednesday is also expected to keep interest rates unchanged.

site_title: FBI warns of possible US election violence in protest-riven Portland
summary: The FBI has warned of potential armed clashes and violence in Portland, Oregon, ahead of the US presidential election, citing a history of polarized protests and the potential for right-wing militias to clash with left-wing groups. The city has seen mass anti-racism rallies and federal officer deployments, and Governor Kate Brown has deployed state forces and put the National Guard on standby. The FBI has devoted additional resources to election crimes and is monitoring threats of voter suppression and foreign cyber threats.

site_title: Airbus wins satellite mission to gauge global warming accuracy
summary: Airbus has won a 16 million-euro contract to build a European Space Agency satellite, TRUTHS, to improve climate change prediction accuracy. The satellite will collect absolute measurements of Earth's surface light, enabling standardization of data and speeding up processing times. This will allow scientists to calibrate data in orbit, resulting in more accurate forecasts and analysis. Launch is foreseen for 2028, and design studies will run through 2022. The project aims to enhance the European Copernicus program's data collection and analysis capabilities.

site_title: Asia: Markets tracks Wall Street rally as US election comes to a head
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend on Tuesday as investors awaited the US presidential election, betting on a Democratic sweep that would likely lead to significant economic stimulus. Despite Joe Biden's lead in national polls, some investors remain cautious due to the risk of a disputed election outcome. However, experts point out that the economy will receive a fresh injection of cash regardless of who wins, and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy continues to support the global recovery. Markets in Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore rose, while oil prices held steady after recent declines.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on rate cut expectations; energy shares surge
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% to 6,032.7, their biggest gain in three weeks, ahead of a widely expected interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The benchmark index is expected to trim its cash rate to a new low of 0.1% and shift to quantitative easing. Energy stocks surged, led by a 3% rebound in oil prices, while gold and financials also rose. The RBA's policy meeting is due at 0330 GMT.

site_title: SIA sets up academy to offer external training programmes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has established a new academy to offer external training programs in areas such as service excellence, operational excellence, and digital transformation. The academy will customize packages for individual companies, with courses led by certified SIA trainers. This move aims to add a new revenue stream for the airline, amid reduced air travel during the Covid-19 pandemic. SIA's previous forays into revenue generation include a "flight to nowhere" concept and training center tours, which have been successful. The academy's launch is seen as a strategic move for the airline.

site_title: SAP's CEO says sales weakness is evidence of cloud transition
summary: SAP's CEO, Christian Klein, downplays the company's slowing revenue growth, citing the COVID-19 pandemic as an inflection point for customers' desire to transition to cloud-computing products. Despite a 4% decline in revenue and a 30% loss in stock value, Klein says more than 50% of clients are moving to cloud-based software, with cloud revenue up 26% in Q3. The company aims to accelerate cloud growth by 2025 and is focused on meeting customer needs, according to Klein.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking Wall Street; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, tracking a US market that closed higher overnight, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 15.52 points or 0.6% to 2,458.65. Local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose 1.2-0.3%, while Singtel, Wilmar International, and ARA Logos Logistics Trust also saw gains. The trust raised S$50 million from a private placement to finance its acquisition of Australian properties and investment in sponsor funds.

site_title: Lack of passenger flights squeezes air freight capacity in peak season
summary: A sharp decline in passenger flights due to the coronavirus pandemic, combined with rising e-commerce demand, is setting the stage for tight air freight capacity and higher rates during the peak Christmas season. Industry experts estimate a 20% gap in capacity, with flights operating at 90% full on most freight lanes. Major airlines are benefiting from strong cargo demand, particularly on trans-Pacific routes, but lost passenger revenue is not offset. Air freight rates have risen significantly above historical levels, with rates for China-US and China-Europe air freight beginning to increase again in October.

site_title: Thai women use pro-democracy protests to challenge sexism
summary: In Thailand, pro-democracy protests have given voice to young women challenging sexism and patriarchal norms in society. Led by 18-year-old Napawn Somsak, who denounced sexism and the royal family's treatment of women, protesters are demanding reforms, including equal pay and the abolition of the monarchy's absolute power. The protests have led to increased discussions on women's rights, with over 40 cases of sexual harassment reported and petitions calling for abortion and prostitution decriminalization. The movement has empowered young women, who feel suppressed by the traditional school system and societal norms.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Tuesday
summary: Japan's financial markets closed on Tuesday for a public holiday, with trading resuming on November 4. This news article does not relate to the market information provided in the other articles.

site_title: MGM Growth Properties interested in buying the Venetian casino
summary: MGM Growth Properties, a real estate investment trust (REIT), expressed interest in acquiring a major Las Vegas Strip casino, such as the Venetian, if a suitable partner can be found to operate it. The company's CEO, James Stewart, stated that MGM Growth would consider the acquisition if it can ensure the rent is paid. This comes as Las Vegas Sands, the current owner of the Venetian, is seeking at least $6 billion for its Las Vegas properties. Vici Properties and Gaming & Leisure Properties, other large REITs, have also expressed interest in acquiring a large Las Vegas asset.

site_title: Straits Clan club to be co-managed with lifestyle, hospitality player Mandala Group
summary: Straits Clan, a Singapore-based private membership club, has partnered with lifestyle and hospitality group Mandala Group to prepare for its next stage of growth. The club, which has around 1,000 members, will be co-managed with Mandala, with Straits Clan maintaining a controlling share. The partnership aims to expand Straits Clan's regional presence through Mandala's overseas properties and revive concepts from Mandala's closed F&B outlets. The collaboration is expected to support Straits Clan's continued profitability and growth.

images.alt_text: The facade of the Straits Clan clubhouse in Bukit Pasoh Road. Its co-founder Wee Teng Wen says The Lo & Behold Group remains the majority and controlling shareholder in the club.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit's 313@somerset may see impact on rents during lease renewals
summary: Lendlease Global Reit's 313@somerset may see depressed rents during lease renewals due to the subdued retail sector and weak leasing demand. Occupancy at the Singapore mall was 95.6% by September, but improved to 98% after securing a new tenant. Tenant sales and visitor numbers have also recovered, with sales exceeding 70% of pre-Covid-19 levels. The stable revenue from Sky Complex in Milan is expected to help protect LReit's income, with leases expiring by June 2021 making up a small portion of the portfolio.

site_title: Japan property funds feel pinch as Tokyo population drops amid pandemic
summary: Japan's Tokyo population dropped by 10,700 in October to 13.971 million, its fourth decline in five months, amid the pandemic. This trend is putting pressure on real estate investment trusts (REITs), which have seen the city's daytime population shrink over time. REITs, which rely heavily on pricey properties in Tokyo, are experiencing a decline in demand, with occupancy rates and house prices not yet decreasing. Analysts predict that as more people work from home, the demand for Tokyo properties will weaken, potentially affecting the office sector and Japan's 12 trillion yen REITs.

site_title: ARA Logos raises about S$50m in private placement
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has raised approximately S$50 million from a private placement to partially finance the acquisition of five Australian properties and investment in two sponsor funds. The issue price represents a 3.8% discount to the adjusted VWAP of 57.43 Singapore cents per unit.
