site_title: MAS subsidies drove first-time Singapore bond issuances in 2019: report
summary: MAS subsidies boosted first-time bond issuances in Singapore in 2019, with average annual first-time issuance volume more than doubling since the Asian Bond Grant Scheme's launch in 2017. The scheme supports up to 50% of bond issuance-related expenses for first-time Asian issuers. Singapore's bond market maintained record issuance volumes of S$95 billion in 2018, with SGD bond issuance registering good growth in 2019, and total outstanding corporate bonds rising 10.2% to S$420 billion by December 2019.

site_title: Singtel names new CEO for cybersecurity arm Trustwave
summary: Singtel appoints Eric Harmon as CEO of Trustwave, replacing Art Wong, who is stepping down after three years. Harmon, a former adviser to SecureTrust and executive at DXC Technology, brings extensive experience in enterprise solutions and cybersecurity. Trustwave employs 2,000 cybersecurity professionals and has formed strategic alliances with major providers.

site_title: Biden warns Trump against declaring early White House win
summary: US President Joe Biden warned his opponent, Donald Trump, against declaring victory in the election before the results are clear, saying "the president is not going to steal this election." Trump denied the report, but criticized the counting of late-arriving ballots, saying his campaign will fight it. Biden urged supporters to push to the polls, saying "every day is a new reminder of how high the stakes are" and that Trump is "terrified" of Pennsylvania's voters. Biden's campaign is focusing on getting Black voters to the polls, and he will barnstorm the state on Monday.

site_title: Chevron aims for Nov restart of LNG production at Australia's Gorgon plant
summary: Chevron expects to restart liquefied natural gas production at Train 2 of its Gorgon plant in Western Australia in the second half of November, delaying it for a second time. The plant has been shut since May for maintenance, initially planned to be completed by early September, but was further delayed due to cracks found in propane kettles. Chevron's CFO, Pierre Breber, stated that weld repairs are complete, and the plant is undergoing recommissioning, with first LNG production expected in late November.

site_title: Singapore Airlines' Training Centre tours see 'overwhelming demand'
summary: Singapore Airlines' Training Centre tours have seen "overwhelming demand" after bookings opened on Sunday, with over 6,800 registrations received within nine hours. The tours, which cost S$15 for children and S$30 for adults, offer behind-the-scenes access to the training facility and various add-on experiences. The airline closed bookings after the maximum capacity of 500 customers per day was reached. SIA has also seen strong demand for its other add-on experiences, including a flight simulator and wine appreciation sessions.

site_title: Ant Group's lead IPO sponsor CICC rises 31% in Shanghai debut
summary: China International Capital Corp (CICC), a joint lead sponsor of Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO), rose 31% on its Shanghai debut, triggering a 30-minute trading halt. The IPO was a big win for CICC, with the brokerage raising 13.2 billion yuan from its listing. CICC is set to vault above US stalwarts Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley this year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The deal attracted demand for 2,847 times the amount of shares initially offered to retail investors online.

images.alt_text: One of the key investment banks responsible for Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO) soared on its own trading debut in Shanghai.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on US vote
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by investors' focus on the US presidential election and other market-moving events. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.61% to 23,116.99, while the Topix index gained 1.04% to 1,595.70. The positive trend follows the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq's fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and comes ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.46 points, or 0.37%, to 1,461.43. The market saw 201.68 million lots traded worth RM81.94 million, with losers beating gainers 267 to 107.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Monday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.69% to 24,274.83, following last week's losses. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. Market sentiment is driven by the upcoming US presidential election and the recent US-EU trade talks. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remain positive, with the STI rising 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Win the vote but still lose? Behold the US Electoral College
summary: The US Electoral College system, established in 1787, will be in focus as the 2020 presidential election approaches. A presidential candidate must obtain 270 of 538 electoral votes to win, but has no obligation to match the popular vote. The system has been criticized, with the 2016 election being a notable example where Donald Trump won despite losing the popular vote. The 538 members of the Electoral College will gather in December to cast votes, with the winner being certified by Congress on January 6, 2021.

site_title: Australia: Shares cautious as investors await RBA decision, US election
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 5,922.8, tracking a cautious global market ahead of the RBA decision and the US presidential election. Financials dropped 0.4% after Westpac's weaker full-year cash profit results. Technology and energy shares also declined. Investors are waiting for the RBA decision, which is expected to cut key rates, and the US election's outcome, which could lead to electoral uncertainty and delay fiscal responses to the coronavirus situation.

site_title: UK's Johnson says there is no alternative to lockdown
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will announce a national lockdown in England due to the COVID-19 pandemic, effective from November 5 to December 2. The lockdown will restrict non-essential shops, schools, and universities, while essential services and pubs with takeaways will remain open. The move comes as the UK grapples with over 20,000 new cases a day and scientists warn of a potential worst-case scenario of 80,000 deaths. The lockdown is seen as a necessary measure to contain the spread of the virus, with lawmakers set to vote on the measures on Wednesday.

site_title: FBI looking into Trump fans who harassed Biden bus: report
summary: The FBI is investigating an incident where Trump supporters allegedly harassed a Biden campaign bus in Texas. The bus was en route to an event in Austin when a caravan of vehicles with Trump signs and flags approached, yelling profanities. No one was hurt, but local law enforcement was called. The Biden campaign scrapped the event, and President Trump tweeted a video of the incident. The Trump campaign has denied endorsing the harassment, with Ronna McDaniel stating that the president would not endorse such behavior.

site_title: Australian lobster halted by Chinese customs checks, fuels trade dispute concerns
summary: Australia has halted sending rock lobster to China due to new customs inspections, amid diplomatic tensions. The inspections, which began on Friday, involve checking for trace elements of minerals and metals, despite the seafood having already been tested before export. The move has raised concerns in Australia about trade reprisals from Beijing, and most Australian exporters have stopped sending lobster to China until the risk of delays is mitigated. The decision is the latest in a series of tensions between the two nations, including tariffs on barley and wine imports.

site_title: Hotel Grand Central to sell New Zealand commercial building for NZ$60m
summary: Hotel Grand Central is selling its commercial building, PwC Centre in Christchurch, New Zealand for NZ$60 million. The property, purchased for NZ$49 million in 2017, has a lettable area of 7,872 sq m and 103 car park spaces. The deal is expected to be completed on Nov 11, allowing the company to realise its investment in the office building asset. Net sale proceeds will be placed into interest-bearing bank term deposits, pending future investment opportunities. The sale is expected to increase Hotel Grand Central's earnings per share and net asset per share.

site_title: Oil prices slump 4% on jitters over Europe lockdowns, US elections
summary: Oil prices dropped 4% to their lowest levels since May due to concerns over Europe's coronavirus lockdowns and the upcoming US Presidential election. Brent crude fell to $36.32 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate declined to $34.17 a barrel. The lockdowns in Europe, along with rising supplies from Libya and Iraq, are weakening fuel demand and causing oil prices to fall for the second consecutive month. Opec+ is set to hold a policy meeting on November 30 to address the situation.

site_title: Just when Australia needs it, wheat farmers start bumper harvest
summary: Australia is experiencing a bumper wheat harvest, with the country expected to produce its third-largest wheat crop in 30 years, at 29 million tonnes. This comes after three years of devastating drought in the eastern wheatbelt, with farmers now harvesting large quantities of grain. The bumper harvest coincides with rising international wheat prices, which have reached a six-year high of above US$6.30 a bushel due to dry conditions in the Black Sea region. The agricultural sector is looking for workers, with many farmers reporting an increase in demand for skilled staff.

images.alt_text: For the past few years, crop machinery has sat idle in many Australian farm sheds as a devastating drought left almost nothing to harvest across the country's pancake-flat eastern wheatbelt.

site_title: Tencent backs its former QQ head's Zoom-for-business startup
summary: Tencent Holdings led a $50 million investment in Zego, a real-time communications software developer, as part of the company's post-pandemic growth. Zego, co-founded by former Tencent QQ head Lin Youyao, offers videoconferencing technology and has seen its revenue double this year. The company has provided solutions to over 1,000 customers and has been profitable since 2016. The investment underscores the growing interest in online education and videoconferencing in the post-pandemic era, with the global communications platform-as-a-service market expected to reach $17 billion by 2023.

site_title: US election boils down to six swing states
summary: The US presidential election is largely determined by six swing states: Florida, Pennsylvania, Michigan, North Carolina, Wisconsin, and Arizona. Joe Biden leads in these states by an average of 3.2 percentage points, according to RealClearPolitics. If Biden can flip just two of these states, Florida and Pennsylvania, he could win the White House. Biden's campaign has focused on the Rust Belt, where Pennsylvania is his birth state, and has poured resources into the state. Trump has also visited key battlegrounds, including Michigan and North Carolina, where he is trailing by significant margins.

site_title: Australia home prices rise in Oct to snap five-month losing streak
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.4% in October, ending a five-month losing streak, driven by record-low interest rates and limited housing stock. National prices were up 3.9% from October last year, with regional housing in demand. Major cities such as Adelaide and Darwin saw significant gains, while Sydney and Melbourne showed modest increases. Analysts attribute the surge to strong buyer demand and persistently low housing stock. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut its cash rate to a record low, further supporting the market.

site_title: DBS names Rachel Chew as head of group cash product management
summary: DBS appoints Rachel Chew as group cash product management head, effective November 1, to strengthen its transaction banking team. Chew, a Singaporean with over 20 years of experience, takes over from Jasmin Ng, who now leads group consumer banking operations. Chew's priority is to shape and execute the bank's cash product proposition in Asia and expand its cash management franchise. This appointment aligns with DBS's commitment to gender diversity, with women making up 40% of the bank's senior management.

images.alt_text: With more than 20 years of experience in digital business and product development, Rachel Chew will lead the bank's regional cash product management team.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 4.45 points to 2,428.29. Losers outnumbered gainers 94 to 63, despite 89.3 million securities changing hands. Wilmar International rose 1.7% after reporting a 20% year-on-year increase in net profit to US$536.6 million. Meanwhile, US stocks finished their worst week and month since March, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average shedding 0.6%.

site_title: Japan's Zozo says new body-measuring suit overcomes flaws of original
summary: Japan's Zozo has released an updated version of its body-measuring suit, the "Zozosuit 2", addressing the flaws of its original version. The new design features 20,000 measuring markers and improved algorithms, allowing for more accurate and easy-to-use technology. The company aims to offer the suit within a year, targeting the fashion industry's need for reduced returns. Zozo's success in this area has also led to interest in partnerships with fitness and healthcare sectors, further expanding the company's potential.

site_title: US will 'vigorously defend' TikTok executive order despite ruling
summary: The US Commerce Department will "vigorously defend" an executive order aimed at banning transactions with Chinese-owned TikTok, despite a federal judge halting the action. The order, set to take effect on November 12, would have barred ByteDance-owned TikTok from operating in the US. Judge Wendy Beetlestone blocked the order, ruling that the government's national security concerns are hypothetical. The Commerce Department plans to comply with the injunction but will defend the executive order from legal challenges, amid ongoing talks to finalize a deal for Walmart and Oracle to oversee US operations.

images.alt_text: The US Commerce Department said on Sunday it would "vigorously defend" an executive order that seeks to bar transactions with Chinese-owned short video-sharing app TikTok after a federal judge halted the action.

site_title: UK's Nigel Farage set to relaunch Brexit Party as anti-lockdown party
summary: Nigel Farage is set to relaunch the Brexit Party as Reform UK, an anti-lockdown party, in response to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government-imposed measures. The new party will focus on protecting the most vulnerable while allowing the rest of the population to develop herd immunity. The name change was submitted to the Electoral Commission, with Farage and party chairman Richard Tice arguing the party's ambition is to "Reform UK". This comes as the UK faces a second wave of COVID-19 infections and a lockdown has been imposed in England.

site_title: Is Nanofilm the growth stock we need to revive investor enthusiasm for equities?
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a Singapore-based technology company, made a lukewarm debut with a 12.4% gain on its first trading day, despite a strong subscription rate. The company generates revenue from coating technologies and advanced materials, with potential for growth in fields like optical sensors and solid state batteries. Singapore investors' preference for yield-oriented stocks may be limiting the growth of non-dividend paying companies like Nanofilm. The company's market price should not slide back to its IPO price, and investors are eager to gain exposure to Nanofilm, but the company needs to prove its value and unlock growth potential.

site_title: Dollar gains on US election caution, surging Covid-19 cases
summary: The US dollar rose to a four-week high due to election jitters and the surge in global COVID-19 cases, forcing lockdowns in parts of Europe. The dollar index gained 1.4% for the week, its best performance in over a month. The euro fell 0.3% to $1.1643, while the yen rose 0.2% to 104.66. The US recorded its 9 millionth COVID-19 case and nearly 229,000 deaths. Investors are cautious ahead of the US presidential election, driving up demand for safe-haven assets like the dollar.

site_title: China's factory activity rises to near-decade high in October: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity surged to a near-decade high in October, with the Caixin PMI rising to 53.6, the highest since January 2011. Domestic demand and exports drove the rebound, with total new orders reaching a 10-year high. The pandemic has largely controlled China's economy, but the global outlook is dimming due to rising Covid-19 infections in Western countries. Analysts expect China's economy to grow around 2% in 2020, and policymakers need to be cautious about normalizing post-coronavirus monetary and fiscal policies.

site_title: Sembcorp sells Panama water business, gets S$21m net gain
summary: Sembcorp Industries sold its entire stake in its Panama water business, Aguas de Panama S.A., to an affiliate of Seven Seas Water Corporation for US$47 million. The sale resulted in a net gain of about S$21 million, aligning with the company's capital-recycling efforts. The divestment is expected to have no material impact on Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share and net asset value per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Nielsen to sell retail arm to Advent in US$2.7b deal
summary: Nielsen Holdings Plc agreed to sell its Global Connect Unit, providing research data to consumer goods companies, to private equity firm Advent International in a US$2.7 billion deal. The sale will help Nielsen focus on its media arm and reduce debt. The Global Connect unit will be renamed NielsenIQ, and David Rawlinson will remain CEO. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2021, with NielsenIQ headquartered in Chicago and licensing Nielsen's branding for 20 years.

site_title: Thai king calls nation 'land of compromise' as protests persist
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn called the nation "the land of compromise" amid ongoing anti-government protests, offering a rare public comment. The protests, driven by discontent with Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha, have raised concerns about democratic reforms and accountability. Despite initial reluctance, the monarch expressed support for protesters, saying "we love them all the same." However, the government has maintained a firm stance, with Prayuth dismissing rumors of military action and vowing to prevent the situation from escalating.

site_title: Westpac cuts annual dividend as cash earnings plummet 62%
summary: Westpac Banking Corp cut its annual dividend by 61% to 31 cents per share due to a 62% plunge in cash earnings, mainly caused by write-downs and a record fine of A$1.3 billion over a money-laundering case. The bank's cash earnings dropped to A$2.61 billion, significantly lower than A$6.85 billion last year. Westpac's value has fallen by about a third since the November announcement, and the bank expects to see improvement in 2021.

site_title: UK lockdown could last longer than one month
summary: The UK government has announced a new four-week coronavirus lockdown in England, set to begin on November 5 and end on December 2, unless infection rates improve. The lockdown will remain in place if the R rate, the number of people one infected person is likely to infect, remains above one. Schools, colleges, and universities will remain open, while pubs, restaurants, and non-essential shops will close, except for takeaway food. The lockdown is aimed at reducing infection rates, which have surpassed one million cases in the UK, with over 47,000 related deaths.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Wilmar, Yanlord, Mapletree NAC Trust, Hotel Grand
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: Key developments include Singtel's acquisition of amaysim Australia for A$250 million, Wilmar's 20% year-on-year profit rise, and Yanlord's acquisition of two Shanghai sites for S$859.8 million. Hotel Grand Central agreed to sell a commercial building in New Zealand for S$54 million. Other notable moves include Keppel Corp's return to profit, Nanofilm Technologies' mainboard debut, and ComfortDelGro's award of ride-hail service operator licences.

site_title: Glasgow artist launches plastic bag museum
summary: Glasgow artist Katrina Cobain, 24, has launched a museum dedicated to plastic carrier bags, which she considers historical items representing consumer excesses of the 20th and 21st centuries. Her collection includes bags from around the world, commemorating events like the Concorde supersonic jet and Prince Charles's wedding to Lady Diana. Cobain's museum, launched online due to the coronavirus pandemic, aims to raise awareness about the environmental impact of plastic bags and promote a shift towards sustainability.

site_title: Trump, Biden campaign in final sprint before vote
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Joe Biden are in their final sprint before the election, with Trump campaigning in swing states and Biden focusing on Pennsylvania. Despite polls showing Biden's lead, Trump remains confident, claiming his chances of winning. The campaign has been overshadowed by the COVID-19 pandemic, with Trump downplaying its severity and criticizing public health experts. Biden has emphasized the importance of unity and change, with former President Barack Obama joining him on the campaign trail. A record 92 million early votes have been cast, and the election is expected to be highly contested, with potential for violence and anxiety.

site_title: The economy is down, so why are home prices up?
summary: US and global home prices are rising despite a struggling economy, with median US home prices surpassing $300,000 for the first time. The cause is "easy money" from central banks, which has led to a global market boom in housing, stocks, and bonds. This boom is fueled by low interest rates and stimulus plans, resulting in severely skewed resource allocation and potential wealth inequality. Experts warn that prices may eventually reach bubble levels, leading to a severe economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The valuations of stocks, bonds and housing have risen sharply this year to levels seen only around 2000 and 2008, periods characterised by financial bubbles.

site_title: A big trader of Evergrande bonds braces for more wild swings
summary: Evergrande Group, China's largest issuer of junk bonds, is bracing for more market volatility as it tries to address its massive debt pile. A seasoned distressed bond trader, Michel Lowy, expects the company to face a "rocky end" to the year, citing long-term doubts about its financial strength. Despite recent steps to avoid a liquidity crunch, Evergrande's bonds have seen significant price swings, with yields ranging from 10% to 18%. Lowy warns of a "binary outcome" and a potentially long recovery time for investors if the company defaults, predicting a "fair price" of around 75 cents for the 2025 bond.

site_title: Singtel's Optus to buy Australia MVNO Amaysim's mobile business for A$250m
summary: Singtel's Optus subsidiary is acquiring Amaysim Australia's mobile business for A$250 million, with plans to keep Amaysim as a standalone brand. The deal, expected to complete in January 2021, will see Optus take over Amaysim's 1.2 million subscribers and mobile business, which operates on the Optus 4G Plus network. The acquisition is part of Optus' strategy to disrupt the mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) market in Australia, offering simple plans and budget-friendly services.

site_title: White House and US's top virus doctor clash ahead of election
summary: US top virus doctor Anthony Fauci has urged a change in US policy on the coronavirus, warning of "a whole lot of hurt" unless immediate action is taken. The Trump administration has rebuked Fauci, calling his comments "unacceptable" and "playing politics." The US has seen record-high cases of COVID-19, with over 230,000 deaths, and Fauci criticized the country's current situation.

site_title: Nearly 50 economies join US initiative aimed at limiting Chinese firms
summary: The US has brought 49 economies, representing two-thirds of global economic output, into its "Clean Network" initiative, aimed at limiting Chinese firms' access to sensitive sectors like cloud computing and 5G networks. The move is seen as a response to China's growing global ambitions and the US concerns about national security risks posed by companies like Huawei. The Clean Network initiative has secured commitments from countries including Taiwan, European nations, and the Middle East, and is seen as a significant blow to Huawei's access to crucial technology.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired two prime development sites in Shanghai for 4.2 billion yuan (S$859.8 million) through a joint venture with Huafa Industrial Co Ltd Zhuhai. The sites will be developed into high-end residential apartments, cultural institutions, offices, and commercial developments. Meanwhile, Tee International has redesignated Eric Phua Boon Kin as group CEO, replacing his brother Phua Chian Kin after discovering unauthorized transactions totaling S$6.55 million.

site_title: Japan to loosen work rules on foreigners stuck due to pandemic
summary: Japan is loosening regulations on part-time work for foreigners stuck in the country due to the pandemic. Starting Tuesday, those with 90-day short-stay permits can renew their permits and work up to 28 hours a week. Technical trainees can change their visas to work permits for six months. About 21,000 foreigners may be eligible. Labour activists say the measures are insufficient, calling for permanent resident status.

site_title: Unilever to trial four-day working week in New Zealand
summary: Unilever is to trial a four-day working week in New Zealand, where all 81 employees will work for four days on full pay. The trial aims to enhance worker wellbeing and boost productivity, with a focus on measuring performance on output rather than time. The trial, which starts this month and will run for a year, is limited to New Zealand but may explore broader implications. The company believes the four-day week will help maintain a competitive edge, increase productivity, and improve wellbeing.

site_title: Trump, Biden close drama-filled race with sprint to Election Day
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump and Joe Biden concluded their highly dramatic and unpredictable election campaign on Election Day, with no significant changes to the initial course of the race. Despite a hospitalized president, a resurgent pandemic, and other significant events, neither candidate's stance shifted. The outcome of the election was set months ago, and now voters will decide the fate of the White House.

site_title: CapitaLand sells three malls, office building for S$448.7m; enters Japan logistics sector
summary: CapitaLand sold three Japanese malls and an office building for S$448.7m, divesting mature assets to unlock value for new growth opportunities. The company also entered Japan's logistics sector, partnering with Mitsui & Co Real Estate to develop a logistics project in Greater Tokyo. Post-divestments, CapitaLand retains S$3.8 billion of assets in Japan and S$2 billion in Korea, exceeding its annual capital recycling target of S$3 billion.

site_title: KLM's 3.4b euro bailout hits crisis as unions reject paycut plan
summary: The Dutch government suspended plans to provide a 3.4 billion euro bailout to KLM, citing the unions' rejection of a pay-cut plan. The deal, which included a five-year salary reduction, was deemed non-negotiable by the government. Without the bailout, KLM's future is uncertain, with the airline stating it would not survive without a massive government injection. Talks with unions are ongoing, but the fate of KLM, the world's oldest airline, remains in jeopardy.

site_title: Qian Hu's incoming CEO buoyant about aquaculture in expansion plans
summary: Incoming CEO of Qian Hu Corporation, Yap Kok Cheng, aims to boost revenue past S$100 million within two months, a target set by his uncle Kenny Yap. Despite a 10.2% drop in revenue in 2019, net profit increased 128.9%. Cheng plans to expand the company's aquaculture business, which began in 2017, to achieve this goal. He believes the industry will remain resilient during crises, citing past sales increases in the Asian Financial Crisis and other crises.

site_title: Low placement rates might reflect barriers to entry
summary: The Manpower Ministry's 11th Jobs Situation Report highlights the low placement rates in various industries, with some sectors having less than 15% of available roles filled. The report suggests that barriers to entry, including the need for technical skills qualifications, salary levels, and working conditions, may be contributing to the low take-up rates. Exceptions include tourism and food industries, which have relatively higher placement rates. Experts cite skills mismatch, inertia, and investment required for training as significant factors hindering jobseekers from entering these industries.

site_title: Hamilton says 'no guarantee' he will remain in F1
summary: Lewis Hamilton, a six-time Formula One world champion, expressed uncertainty about his future in the sport, stating there's "no guarantee" he'll remain in F1 next season. Both Hamilton and Mercedes' team boss Toto Wolff are out of contract at the end of the season, fueling speculation. Despite Wolff's likely departure, Hamilton said it doesn't concern him, and he plans to remain active outside of racing upon retirement. Hamilton is set to clinch his record-equalling seventh drivers title in Turkey.

site_title: Spanish 'ghost airport' reinvents itself as park for idle jets
summary: Spain's abandoned Ciudad Real airport has transformed into a storage facility for grounded planes, accommodating up to 300 jets. The airport, built in the early 2000s, initially operated as a hunting destination but faced collapse due to the Covid-19 pandemic. After renovation, it now generates revenue from plane storage and is profitable. This pivot comes as 31% of the global fleet, or over 8,100 planes, remain idle worldwide due to travel restrictions and demand. Other airports, including Teruel and Chateauroux, have also adopted similar storage-focused strategies.

site_title: Wall Street is learning to love Joe Biden
summary: The stock market has defied conventional wisdom by rising steadily alongside Joe Biden's victory prospects, despite his promises of higher taxes and regulations. Investors view Biden as a more stable, "pro-market" alternative to President Trump, who has been known for his impulsive decisions. Sectors that stand to gain from Biden's promises, such as health-insurance companies and renewable energy producers, are already seeing gains. However, a Biden victory is not yet fully priced in, and investors are cautious about the potential for market volatility or a contested election outcome.

site_title: Saudi Twitter users grapple with 'digital authoritarianism'
summary: Saudi Arabia has been accused of "digital authoritarianism" following the mysterious disappearance of former Deputy Finance Minister Abdulaziz al-Dukhail and other public intellectuals who expressed criticism of the state. The disappearances are linked to a 2015 Twitter data breach that exposed the identities of regime critics, with at least three individuals arrested or unmasked as a result. The case highlights the Saudi government's efforts to harness social media to promote its reforms while silencing dissent. Human rights groups have criticized Saudi Arabia's anti-cyber-crime law, which allegedly criminalizes online criticism of the government.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's market report for the week of October 30, 2020, reveals a lackluster week for shipowners, with rates declining across various segments. The Capesize market saw a drop in rates, with the 5TC index falling to $15,550, while the Pacific route's C5 West Australia to China route plummeted to $7.10. The Atlantic market was also subdued, with rates for US Gulf loading steady but South America lacking fresh cargo. The Supramax market remained on a negative slide, with limited activity from the Continent and Mediterranean.

site_title: Two schemes launched for SMEs that owe debts to multiple lenders
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched two schemes to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in financial distress due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Sole Proprietors and Partnerships (SPP) Scheme and Extended Support Scheme - Customised (ESS-C) offer debt restructuring options for SMEs with debts owed to multiple lenders. The SPP Scheme allows sole proprietors and partnerships to restructure their unsecured business debts with lower monthly instalment payments, while the ESS-C enables SMEs to restructure their credit facilities across multiple financial institutions.

site_title: Australia welcomes Qatar action against invasive airport searches of women
summary: Qatar has taken steps to prosecute those responsible for subjecting female travelers to gynaecological searches at Doha's airport, following international condemnation. At least 13 Australians were among those affected on flights departing October 2. Australian Foreign Minister Marise Payne welcomed the Qatari government's acknowledgment and assurance that the incidents will not be repeated. Qatar has vowed to guarantee the safety and security of passengers ahead of hosting the 2022 World Cup, amid concerns over its human rights record. The government has referred those responsible for the searches for prosecution.

site_title: Two debt restructuring schemes launched to help distressed SMEs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, Association of Banks in Singapore, and Finance Houses Association of Singapore have launched two debt restructuring schemes to help distressed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Sole Proprietors and Partnerships (SPP) Scheme and Extended Support Scheme - Customised (ESS-C) will allow SMEs to restructure credit facilities and debts owed to multiple lenders, with loan repayment periods extended to up to eight years and interest rates capped at 7% per annum. The schemes aim to provide relief measures for SMEs with viable business models.

site_title: From tentative secret agent to suave Bond
summary: Sean Connery, the first and most iconic James Bond, has passed away at 90. Connery's portrayal of the character in the 1960s cemented his status as the "best Bond" in the public's imagination. Critics and fans praise his natural authority, seductive charm, and confidence, which made him the epitome of the Bond persona. Connery's performance improved over time, but he eventually grew bored with the series, leading to his departure. He returned for a few more films, including the non-Eon production Never Say Never Again, which remains a beloved Bond classic.

site_title: Singapore banks' Q3 results in focus over Malaysia debt holiday impact
summary: Singapore banks' Q3 results will focus on the impact of Malaysia's tightened loan moratoriums, which could affect UOB and OCBC, key markets for the two banks. Analysts expect repayment trends to hold up, but credit costs may remain elevated due to the economy's slow recovery. UOB is expected to see higher provisions, while DBS and OCBC are expected to see larger credit cost improvements. Net interest margins are expected to remain under pressure, but fee income is expected to support revenue. The banks will report their Q3 results on November 4-5, with UOB kicking off the season.

site_title: How Covid-19 is hitting the reset button on the global economy and property
summary: The Covid-19 recession of 2020, the worst contraction in history, is impacting properties globally. Winners include industrial/logistics, data centres, and life sciences, which benefit from the shift to online shopping and remote work. In-betweeners, such as office spaces, will experience a delayed recovery due to structural changes like WFH. Losers include retail, which faces declining revenues and bankruptcy, and multi-family apartments, which will be negatively impacted by job losses. Despite challenges, the article concludes that sectors with healthy demographic and structural drivers will recover more rapidly, while others will be more challenged, creating opportunities for occupiers.

site_title: Euro, sterling weaker on lockdown, recession fears
summary: The euro and sterling are weakening due to ongoing coronavirus lockdowns and economic downturns in Europe. The euro has fallen 3% since its peak in August, while the sterling has dropped 4.8% from its summer high. Economists predict a bleak winter, citing a slowdown in the euro zone's third-quarter GDP growth and concerns over France and Italy's debt. The European Central Bank and Bank of England are expected to boost quantitative easing, further weakening the currencies.

site_title: New coronavirus curbs spark exasperation, anger
summary: European nations have implemented new coronavirus curbs, including lockdowns and restrictions, to combat the surge in infections and deaths. Anger and exasperation have grown as protesters clashed with security forces in several countries, including Spain, England, Austria, France, and Ireland. The measures aim to slow the spread of the virus, but many are concerned about the economic impact, with some predicting "financial Armageddon" for businesses. The global death toll has surpassed 1.2 million, with the US registering its highest number of fatalities on Saturday, and the situation is deteriorating in other parts of the world, including war-torn Syria.

site_title: America's choice: At a crossroads
summary: The US presidential election is approaching, with Joe Biden expected to be sworn in on January 20, 2021, as predicted by many experts due to his significant lead in polls. Donald Trump's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic and economic issues has been criticized, with many arguing that his policies have had a negative impact on the country. Despite this, Trump's supporters believe he can still win, citing his ability to energize his base and the electoral college system. However, experts warn that the outcome is uncertain, and the electoral college system can lead to unexpected results.

site_title: Alibaba's secret three-year experiment to reinvent the factory
summary: Alibaba has successfully conducted a three-year experiment to reinvent China's outdated factories, unveiling its first smart factory, Xunxi, on the outskirts of Hangzhou. The facility uses consumer data, AI, and robotic arms to improve efficiency and meet consumer expectations. Alibaba aims to cut order lead times by 75% for garment companies, addressing the growing demand for instant gratification among China's Gen-Z consumers. The company plans to become a one-stop production solution provider for garment merchants on its Taobao and Tmall marketplaces.

site_title: UBS chief retires from banking in pandemic drift
summary: UBS Group AG CEO Sergio Ermotti is retiring after nine years at the helm, citing the pandemic's vulnerability of European banks to low interest rates and economic downturns. Ermotti notes that the industry's survival is due to regulatory and strategic actions, but warns of modest growth and structural overcapacity in the sector. He also suggests that mergers of back offices are becoming more likely, and that London's status as a financial center is fading, with growth in China primarily driven by local institutions.

site_title: Fortress fails to sell record bond deal for Las Vegas rail
summary: Fortress Investment Group is postponing its plan to build a train line to Las Vegas from Southern California after failing to sell a record amount of unrated municipal debt to finance the project. The company had marketed $3.2 billion of debt, but ultimately sold $2.4 billion, citing a lack of liquidity and economic uncertainty. California Treasurer Fiona Ma said the project will be delayed until market conditions improve, and the state will take back the bond capacity to support affordable housing projects.

site_title: Watch sales pick up, but not to pre-Covid-19 levels
summary: Singapore's luxury watch retailers report a pick-up in sales with locals buying more than before, but it's not enough to return to pre-Covid-19 levels. Retailers are targeting local buyers and focusing on online selling, while brick-and-mortar businesses remain popular. "Revenge spending" and border closures contribute to the increase in sales. Brands like Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet remain in high demand, with limited supply. Despite higher earnings for local watch retail chains, the industry still faces challenges due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Mars and Hershey's accused of avoiding fair pay for cocoa farmers
summary: West African nations Ghana and Ivory Coast have accused US chocolate companies Hershey's and Mars of avoiding paying a $400 per tonne bonus to cocoa farmers, known as the living income differential. The bonus is intended to boost the incomes of poor farmers. The Ghana Cocoa Board and Coffee Cocoa Council have cancelled sustainability schemes with the companies, citing a "breach of confidence" and accusing them of not paying the LID. Hershey's denied the allegations, while Mars stated it had long supported the initiative.

site_title: Singapore firms keen to expand international trade amid pessimistic outlook: survey
summary: Singapore firms are expanding international trade despite a pessimistic outlook on business due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 87% of Singapore firms plan to expand international business over the next 3-5 years, with 51% immediately investing overseas. The main areas of attraction for new markets are proven customer demand, access to new suppliers and partners, and building businesses ahead of competitors. However, businesses in Singapore are more pessimistic about 2021 than global peers, with a lower business optimism rating of 19% and a slower expected recovery, with 27% expecting it to take until 2025.

summary: Vietnam estimates typhoon damage at 10 trillion dong (approximately $588.4 million), citing a meeting between Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc and local authorities. Typhoon Molave destroyed over 700 houses and left 80 people dead and missing. The storm is considered one of the two most powerful in Vietnam in the past 20 years.

site_title: One year in, Lagarde stamps her style on crisis-fighting ECB
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde has made a distinctive approach to crisis-fighting since taking office last year, prioritizing communication with the public and engaging more frequently than her predecessor Mario Draghi. This has led to more frequent remarks and a more open approach, but also risks mixed or unscripted messages affecting markets. The ECB has been active in addressing the coronavirus crisis, with the Governing Council unanimously supporting additional stimulus. Despite some criticism, Lagarde has established herself as the ECB's public figurehead and is working to balance communication with investors.

site_title: Earthlings, it seems, not aliens, removed the Utah monolith
summary: A metal monolith in a Utah desert, sparking international attention, was dismantled 10 days after its installation, with no apparent government involvement. An adventure photographer, Ross Bernards, captured images of four men dismantling the sculpture at night, with one saying "Leave no trace." The men were seen breaking it apart and ferrying it off in a wheelbarrow. Despite speculation about the artist's identity, officials claim no knowledge of the installation or removal, and the case remains unsolved.

site_title: Market value of homegrown Nanofilm close to S$2 billion
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International (NTI), a leading provider of nanotechnology solutions, made its debut on the SGX Mainboard with a strong investor demand, with its shares 23 times oversubscribed. The company's market value is close to S$2 billion, comparable to global tech leaders. NTI commands a valuation in line with its earnings per share, with a price-to-sales ratio of around 13 times. The company's revenue grew at a CAGR of 17% from FY17 to FY19, driven by its advanced materials segment. NTI's listing reinforces Singapore's supportive economic ecosystem for tech startups.

site_title: Commodity-finance industry in Singapore gets code of best practices
summary: Singapore has launched a code of best practices for commodity financing, aimed at boosting transparency and trust in the industry. Developed by the Association of Banks in Singapore, with support from regulatory bodies, the code sets out key principles for prudent commodity trade financing practices. The code is designed to promote sustainable credit flows, greater transparency, and accountability, and is expected to encourage stronger participation from the industry in implementing best practices.

site_title: Google says don't be distracted by antitrust case
summary: Google is facing an antitrust case similar to the 1998 US government lawsuit against Microsoft, which slowed the software giant down and allowed upstarts like Google to gain a foothold. Google CEO Sundar Pichai and top lawyer Kent Walker have urged employees to keep their heads down and focus on delivering great products, warning against speculation on legal issues and choosing words carefully to avoid antitrust scrutiny. Despite the case, Google continues to push ahead with a large acquisition and pursue search partnerships, sparking concerns that the company may be trying to avoid distractions and maintain its dominant position in the search market.

site_title: Twitter suspends Thai royalist account linked to influence campaign
summary: Twitter has suspended a Thai pro-royalist account linked to the palace, which was found to be connected to thousands of other accounts spreading royalist messaging in an effort to counter a months-long protest movement. The @jitarsa-school account, which had over 48,000 followers, was suspended for violating Twitter's rules on spam and platform manipulation. The move comes as the Thai government and monarchy face growing criticism from protesters, who have used social media to mobilize against the government.

site_title: Yanlord JV acquires two residential integrated development sites in Shanghai
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired two residential integrated development sites in Shanghai's Jingan District for 4.2 billion yuan (S$859.8 million). The joint venture, held by Yanlord and Huafa Industrial Co Ltd Zhuhai, will develop high-end residential apartments, cultural institutions, offices, and commercial developments. The sites have a total gross floor area of 79,699 square meters and were acquired via public land auction. Yanlord shares remained unchanged at S$1.05 following the announcement.

site_title: The Pines owner had no intention of informing members of site's sale: Plaintiffs
summary: Plaintiffs in a lawsuit against The Pines club in Singapore claim that the club's owner, Exklusiv Resorts, had no intention to inform members of the property developer Oxley Holdings' purchase of the premises in 2013. Former general manager Jeffrey Leong testified that despite members' inquiries, he was not informed by Exklusiv Resorts to post a notice or inform members about the sale. The hearing continues on Monday, with the plaintiffs seeking to show a breach of contract and deceit.

site_title: No bonus for civil servants this year; 2,400 lower-wage workers to get S$1,200
summary: Singapore will not offer year-end bonuses to about 85,000 civil servants due to the challenging economic conditions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. However, 2,400 lower-wage workers will receive a one-time payment of S$1,200. The decision was made after consultation with public sector unions.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF increases Riverstone stake to 6.03%
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) increased its stake in Riverstone Holdings to 6.03% after acquiring 1,046,300 shares at S$3.72 each, with a consideration of S$3,887,737. This move follows the EPF's previous acquisition of 2 million shares at S$3.29 each on September 17. The EPF's total interest in Riverstone Holdings now surpasses the 6% threshold, requiring it to file substantial shareholding changes.

site_title: Infrastructure investment to lead S-E Asia's recovery
summary: A joint report by Deloitte and Infrastructure Asia (IA) emphasizes the importance of infrastructure development in leading South-east Asia's economic recovery. Infrastructure investment can boost economic activity and create jobs, making it a critical factor in a sustainable and resilient future. The report suggests infrastructure development can be divided into three phases: responding to immediate disruptions, recovering from the pandemic, and thriving in a low-carbon future. Investments based on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria have outperformed non-sustainable counterparts during the Covid-19-led downturn.

site_title: What to look out for in election week
summary: Global stocks plummeted in the week ending October 30, with the MSCI All Country World Index falling 5.3% and the S&P 500 ending 5.6% lower. The US presidential election, with its uncertain outcome, is a major concern, with a potential win by incumbent Donald Trump potentially upsetting the market. Markets will also be watching for control of the US Senate, which could impact fiscal expansion and legislation. Meanwhile, investors are keeping an eye on macroeconomic data and earnings reports from companies, with the US Federal Reserve meeting on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia's October CPI falls 1.5% y-o-y, faster than forecast
summary: Malaysia's October Consumer Price Index (CPI) fell 1.5% year-over-year, surpassing the 1.4% forecast by economists. The decline was driven by lower retail fuel prices and lean costs for housing, utilities, and clothing. The transport sector index dropped 10.2% on-year. This marks the eighth consecutive month of declining consumer prices, indicating a slowdown in inflation.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as vaccine doubts weigh
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.5% to 6,601.1 points, marking the second straight day of losses, as doubts about the efficacy of a COVID-19 vaccine candidate from AstraZeneca weighed on investor sentiment. Treasury Wine Estates plummeted 14% after China announced plans to impose temporary anti-dumping tariffs on Australian wine imports. Oil stocks also declined, with Beach Energy and Oil Search losing 3.8% and 3.7% respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for its best month ever, driven by optimism over multiple potential treatments for COVID-19.

site_title: Biden says Americans 'won't stand' for attempt to derail election result
summary: President-elect Joe Biden stated that Americans "won't stand" for attempts to derail the US election outcome. In a speech, Biden emphasized the importance of honoring election results and the laws of the land. Meanwhile, Donald Trump continued to claim the election was rigged and called for the results to be overturned. Despite Biden's hardening line, Trump remains defiant and is reportedly considering a 2024 presidential run, despite losing the election.

site_title: Hydrogen wars pit Europe vs China for US$700 billion business
summary: European countries are racing against China to become the leader in the hydrogen market, with a potential $700 billion business by 2050. The European Union aims to invest $750 billion in hydrogen infrastructure, while China is building a giant wind and solar farm to produce hydrogen. European companies such as Green Hydrogen Systems and ITM Power Plc are scaling up production to meet growing demand, with combined annual output of over 830 megawatts. China, however, has an advantage due to lower costs for labor and raw materials, and is expected to soon crack the European market.

site_title: Wirecard auditors face German lawmakers' 'considerable doubts'
summary: German lawmakers will question Wirecard's auditors over their alleged failure to detect $3.04 billion in non-existent assets, sparking considerable doubts about the auditing process. Ernst & Young (EY) auditors Christian Orth, Stefan Heissner, and Martin Dahmen are set to appear before the parliamentary committee, while Andreas Loetscher, who left EY in 2018, is unavailable due to his role at Deutsche Bank. EY has called the missing assets an "elaborate" fraud, and lawmakers have threatened fines if the auditors refuse to cooperate, potentially leading to a court decision on lifting confidentiality obligations.

site_title: SUSS, SACEOS team up to develop training courses for MICE practitioners
summary: Singapore University of Social Sciences (SUSS) and the Singapore Association of Convention & Exhibition Organisers & Suppliers (SACEOS) have partnered to develop training courses for event management practitioners, focusing on digital skills to address post-Covid-19 challenges. The BSc Events Management with Minor programme, set to begin in July 2021, will cover topics such as virtual and hybrid events, financial and risk management, and virtual reality. The partnership aims to build capabilities for the future and support the resilience of the MICE sector. The courses will be developed in collaboration with industry experts.

site_title: Shell may permanently shut Louisiana refinery next week: sources
summary: Royal Dutch Shell may permanently shut its 211,146 barrel-per-day Convent, Louisiana, refinery early next week, following the failure to find a buyer amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This would be the first US Gulf Coast refinery to close due to pandemic-related demand decline. The move comes as the US Energy Information Administration reported that US refineries ran at 78.8% of their capacity in August, down from 83.1% in March. Eight other North American plants have been idled or targeted for shutdowns, citing weak demand for refined products.

site_title: Berlin fintech Solarisbank eyes European expansion in 2021
summary: Berlin-based fintech Solarisbank plans to expand into new European markets in 2021, becoming the first German bank to shift its entire operation into the cloud. The company, which operates a "banking as a service" model, aims to grow with existing partners such as Samsung Electronics and will focus on countries like France, Italy, and Spain. Solarisbank has already raised 160 million euros in funding and hosts 750,000 accounts, with CEO Roland Folz predicting a substantial financial powerhouse for tech giants.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as vaccine progress fuels recovery hopes
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Monday as hopes for the availability of a Covid-19 vaccine within weeks boosted economic recovery expectations. The Dow Jones rose 69.34 points, or 0.24%, to 29,332.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 9.28 and 61.79 points, respectively, to 3,566.82 and 11,916.76. This renewed optimism fueled bets for a swift economic recovery next year, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: DBS requesting RSM be named as liquidators of Novena Global Healthcare: Terence Loh
summary: DBS is seeking to wind up Novena Global Healthcare Pte Ltd (NGHPL), a scandal-hit company co-founded by Singaporean cousins Terence and Nelson Loh. DBS has filed a winding-up application with Singapore's High Court, requesting accounting firm RSM to be named as joint and several liquidators of NGHPL. Terence Loh, co-founder, stated he will continue to engage with RSM until liquidation occurs.

site_title: Thailand moves to cool baht rally that threatens pandemic recovery
summary: Thailand's central bank plans to ease rules on capital outflows to curb a strengthening baht, which is threatening to derail the country's economic recovery from the pandemic. The baht has surged 8% since April, driven by foreign investors seeking riskier emerging-market assets amid a weak US dollar. The government has called on the Bank of Thailand to restrain the currency to protect exports, which are the country's only source of external revenue. The measures aim to minimize the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on Thailand's trade-dependent economy.

site_title: OUE C-Reit confirms in talks with Allianz entity for OUE Bayfront partial sale
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) is in talks with an entity linked to Allianz Real Estate for a partial sale of its Grade A office asset, OUE Bayfront. The potential buyer is expected to pay around S$3,200 per square foot, or S$1.28 billion, for a half stake in the building. Negotiations are ongoing, and no binding agreement has been reached. The trust's manager advises unitholders and investors to exercise caution and will make an announcement if any material development occurs.

site_title: USDJPY expected to see impending break out of descending triangle
summary: The USDJPY pair is expected to break out of a descending triangle pattern, a classic continuation pattern indicating a bearish break. The pattern's characteristics include lower highs and same lows, resembling a contracting range. Key indicators for the break include a price break below 104.13, a neutral to overbought stochastics oscillator reading, and a MACD indicator below the zero line. A potential break could lead to prices reaching 102.26 and then 100.26, but a rebound is more likely in the shorter term.

site_title: China planning hydropower on key Tibet river: Global Times
summary: China plans to develop hydropower on the Yarlung Tsangpo River, a key source of water for Bangladesh and India, according to a report by the Global Times. The project, part of China's next five-year plan, aims to generate 300 billion kilowatt-hours of carbon-free electricity annually, accounting for about 4% of China's total demand. The project has been discussed for years, with Chinese officials researching the site's feasibility. The development of hydropower on the Yarlung Tsangpo River could provide a significant source of renewable energy for China.

site_title: Singapore Airlines prices S$500m of 3.5% 10-year notes
summary: Singapore Airlines priced S$500 million of 3.5% 10-year notes, upsizing from S$5 billion under its S$10 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme. The notes are expected to be issued on Dec 2, with DBS Bank and United Overseas Bank acting as joint lead managers. The offer was increased after strong appetite from private investors, responding to an initial expression of interest.

site_title: The Crown is here again, and all that fact-checking is royal
summary: The latest season of The Crown has sparked controversy among royal watchers, with some criticizing the portrayal of Prince Charles as a "wimp" and his wife Princess Diana as an "unpleasant person." However, experts point out that the show's dramatization of events, such as the car crash killing Princess Diana, may be based on unverified facts. The show's producers have been accused of taking artistic liberties, while the BBC faces an inquiry into a 1995 interview with Princess Diana. Despite these inaccuracies, some historical events depicted in the show, such as the relationship between Queen Elizabeth II and Margaret Thatcher, are based on real accounts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday due to profit-taking after recent rallies driven by coronavirus vaccine developments and an economic recovery. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% to 25,882.14, while the Topix index dropped 0.49% to 1,726.11. This decline follows a strong rally in recent days, with investors taking profits amid uncertainty about future market movements.

site_title: Isetan Singapore expects Covid-19 to hit financial performance, no recovery in 2020
summary: Isetan Singapore expects the COVID-19 pandemic to negatively impact its financial performance, with no material recovery expected in 2020 due to a "very challenging" retail environment. The company has mitigated losses with government grants and rental rebates, but these are not expected to recur. Revenue from sale of goods and consignment income are down, and rental income is also lower. Isetan aims to improve operational performance for long-term sustainability, with plans to scale up e-commerce and complete renovations at Isetan Scotts by the end of the month.

site_title: Google to integrate bank accounts in payments app
summary: Google is partnering with 11 banks and credit unions to offer mobile-based bank accounts through its Google Pay platform, starting next year. The "Plex" accounts will have no monthly fees, overdraft charges, or minimum balance requirements. The new accounts will be integrated into Google Pay, allowing users to manage their accounts and make payments more easily. This move follows similar efforts by tech giants such as Apple and Amazon, which are expanding their presence in personal finance.

site_title: Spotlight on private stock deals in China
summary: China's private share placements have seen a significant increase in fundraising, with 151 deals raising 321 billion yuan (S$65.5 billion) this year, surpassing other equity-linked fundraising tools. The relaxed rules in February have helped revive the market, with more than 500 private placements in the pipeline to raise at least 709 billion yuan. Companies are using private placements as an alternative to bonds, and the market's success has attracted investors, with some funds gaining significant returns. However, not all cash-strapped companies can access the market, and investors are becoming increasingly selective when it comes to companies with heavy debt burdens.

site_title: CDL responds to commentary regarding leadership change
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has responded to criticism regarding its leadership change, dismissing it as speculative and irresponsible. CDL, one of Singapore's largest real estate companies, has a 57-year history and a strong track record of good governance, with its executive chairman, Mr Kwek Leng Beng, credited for steering the company's transformation from losses to success. CDL's leadership change was not elaborated upon in the response, but the company maintained its confidence in its future performance.

site_title: UK's Johnson says Scottish devolution a 'disaster'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson described Scottish devolution as a "disaster" and ruled out giving Edinburgh more powers, citing his government's response to the pandemic as a reason. This comes as opinion surveys show a majority of Scots support independence, prompting a push for a second referendum. Johnson's comments have been criticized by Scottish nationalists, including First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who believes that independence is the only way to strengthen the Scottish Parliament.

site_title: Lum family, Ellipsiz to make mandatory offer for Lum Chang at S$0.38 per share
summary: Singapore-based engineering solutions firm Ellipsiz and the Lum family, controlling Lum Chang Holdings, plan to make a mandatory offer for the remaining 57.3% of Lum Chang shares at S$0.38 per share, maintaining the company's listing status. The offer is triggered by the Lum family's acquisition of a 0.2% stake in Lum Chang at S$0.37 per share. The offer is expected to give shareholders a premium of 8.6-10.1% over the volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 50.75 points to 1,575.07 on Tuesday, closing higher. The market saw 12.312 billion lots worth RM8.446 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 747 to 609. This follows a broader regional market trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Fuelling the future
summary: Siemens Energy's CEO, Jochen Eickholt, emphasizes that the energy transition to a decarbonized world is a "set of different journeys" for various countries and companies. While environmentalists may view traditional energy generation as unsustainable, firms like Siemens Energy are working to support customer transitions to a more sustainable energy future. The company has solutions for every stage of the transition, including conventional electricity generation, industrial applications, and renewable energy solutions. Eickholt highlights the importance of green hydrogen as a store of energy and a potential game-changer for the transition. However, cost is a significant obstacle, and market dynamics and political incentives are needed to drive down costs and overcome practical roadblocks.

site_title: Iliad's third-quarter revenue rises on strong subscriber gains
summary: Iliad SA, Europe's sixth-largest mobile operator, reported a 6.3% rise in third-quarter revenue to 1.42 billion euros, driven by record net adds for its French fiber offering and strong demand for its new cable box. The company added 99,000 net new broadband subscribers in France, its best performance in nearly eight years. Iliad also reported a 56.3% increase in revenue in Italy, where it reached its end-2020 target of having over 5,000 active sites. The company attributed its success to its transformation plan and investments in fiber optics.

site_title: Markets soar as Pfizer, BioNTech report 90% success for Covid vaccine
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech announced a 90% success rate for their Covid-19 vaccine in a study of tens of thousands of volunteers. The preliminary results paved the way for emergency-use authorization from regulators, with the Dow Jones surging 1,500 points and the FTSE 100 Index surging 5.5%. The companies expect to seek authorization in the US this month, with a rolling review in Europe underway. The vaccine's effectiveness is a significant boost to public health, with the companies planning to produce 1.3 billion doses by the end of 2021.

site_title: Bright prospects for precision engineering that supports 5G, IoT: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing announced an extension of the Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) scheme until March 2022, increasing financial support for original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to 70% for manpower categories and 50% for other cost categories. The scheme aims to support precision engineering firms, enabling Singapore to become a hub for 5G, IoT, autonomous vehicles, and biotech sectors. The government expects a "huge demand" for precision engineering products and services, with over 1,500 companies benefiting from the scheme in the past 10 years.

site_title: From condo flippers to homebuyers: Are buying patterns shifting for foreigners in Singapore's real estate?
summary: Foreigners buying properties in Singapore have shifted their perspective from quick flips to holding onto their homes for the long term, driven by the 20% additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and market cooling measures. Data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority shows a decline in foreign buying since 2018, with the top nationalities being Chinese, Malaysians, Indians, Indonesians, and Americans. Foreign buyers prefer homes priced between $1.5 million and $5 million, with a preference for prime districts and landed homes in Sentosa Cove. The wealthy see Singapore as a safe investment environment and a jet-set lifestyle, with some projects attracting international buyers.

site_title: UK economy loses more speed in September, before new lockdown
summary: The UK economy grew by 1.1% in September, slower than expected, before new lockdown restrictions were implemented. This follows a record 15.5% growth in the July-September period. Despite £200 billion in emergency spending and tax cuts, the economy still suffered its biggest drop among major economies, with GDP remaining 10% smaller than before the pandemic. The slowdown is attributed to Covid-19 restrictions, with the Bank of England forecasting a 11% shrinkage in 2020 and a 7% growth in 2021.

site_title: Poorer nations face vaccine wait as West locks down supply
summary: Poorer nations are facing significant challenges in accessing the newly approved Covid-19 vaccine, with many countries having pre-ordered doses and wealthy nations snapping up most of the available supply. The World Health Organization's Covax facility aims to ensure equitable distribution, but experts warn that logistics and finance are major hurdles. The vaccine requires ultra-cold storage, which is a significant challenge in low- and middle-income countries. Despite efforts to address these challenges, many experts fear that the vaccine may not reach those who need it most, potentially exacerbating the pandemic in poorer nations.

site_title: Alibaba beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: Alibaba Group beat quarterly revenue estimates with 155.06 billion yuan in revenue, a 30% increase, driven by its core e-commerce business growth. Sales rose 29% to 130.92 billion yuan. However, net income slumped 63% to 26.52 billion yuan due to a one-time gain from its Ant Group interest last year. The company's US-listed shares fell 2% despite a 39% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 9.33 points, or 0.59%, to 1,560.75 on Thursday, with 786.39 million lots traded worth RM182.81 million. Gainers beat losers 249 to 145. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, where the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday. Global markets remained positive, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: Hyflux placed under judicial management
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore water treatment company, has been placed under judicial management by the court. Interim judicial managers Borelli Walsh have been appointed to oversee the company's debt restructuring. The decision comes after a judge noted that the repeated extension of the debt moratorium must come to an end. This move follows a recent chastisement of Hyflux's lawyer for making a last-minute request for an adjournment.

images.alt_text: Sias and Hyflux's creditors raised concerns that the appointed JMs should not be closely connected to any stakeholder group of Hyflux.

site_title: US Fed set to join climate-change grouping for central banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to join the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), a group of 75 central banks aiming to combat climate change. Fed vice-chair Randal Quarles confirmed the request, with a possible membership decision before the NGFS's annual meeting in April. The move comes as the Fed has begun to incorporate climate change risks into its financial stability report, citing severe storms and higher global temperatures as economic uncertainties. The decision follows President-elect Joe Biden's pledge to rejoin the Paris Climate Accord, which the US withdrew from under President Donald Trump.

site_title: Not forever: World's biggest pink diamond mine closes
summary: The Argyle mine, the world's largest pink diamond mine, has closed after exhausting its reserves. Located in Western Australia, the mine produced over 865 million carats of rough diamonds, including more than 90% of the world's pink diamonds. The mine's closure will push the price of pink diamonds higher, with some fetching up to $3 million per carat. Rio Tinto expects the decommissioning process to take around five years, with the land to be rehabilitated and returned to its traditional custodians.

site_title: Global strategist
summary: UN Under-Secretary-General Izumi Nakamitsu emphasizes the organization's potential role in preventing conflicts in a new global paradigm. The world has entered a "turning point" with great power competition and rising regional powers, making international relations more complicated. The UN can still play a major role in preventing conflicts, but it needs to adapt to the changing landscape. Key challenges include addressing cyber attacks, nuclear technology, and artificial intelligence, which can be deployed by anyone. The UN aims to develop a global normative framework for responsible state behavior in cyberspace, and Nakamitsu advocates for a voluntary, non-binding checklist to help countries implement norms.

site_title: Thailand unveils fresh tax breaks for EV makers
summary: Thailand has introduced new tax breaks for electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, aiming to promote local production and its supply chain. The incentives, approved by the Board of Investment, include a three-year tax holiday for plug-in hybrid vehicle makers and an eight-year corporate income tax waiver for battery electric vehicle makers. The package requires a minimum investment of 5 billion baht for four-wheel vehicle manufacturers and offers tax exemptions for motorcycle and ship manufacturers. The move seeks to position Thailand as a center for battery-powered vehicles in Southeast Asia, with its combination of policies and incentives considered the most advanced in the region.

site_title: Digital Transformation is a marathon, not a sprint - here's why SMEs should keep the pace
summary: Singaporean Small, Medium, and Corporate (SME) companies are struggling to keep pace with digital transformation due to accelerated global pandemic-induced digitalization. Despite 73% of mid- and large-sized companies speeding up digitalization, 30% of SMEs were forced to adapt, but more than half reported delays. High implementation costs and lack of internal resources hinder digital transformation. SMEs must adopt a marathon mindset, invest in digital skills, and leverage government grants to narrow the gap with larger corporations. Investing in digital transformation can deliver significant cost savings and revenue gains, but SMEs need to prioritize long-term thinking and persistence.

images.alt_text: Vivek Chatrath, Small, Medium and Corporate Lead at Microsoft Singapore

site_title: World leaders congratulate Biden, see challenges ahead
summary: World leaders have congratulated US President-elect Joe Biden on his victory, with many expressing hopes for cooperation in addressing future challenges. Leaders from Germany, France, Britain, Ireland, Greece, Italy, Spain, Israel, Iraq, Iran, Egypt, Jordan, Palestinian territories, and others have extended their congratulations, with some highlighting the importance of the US alliance in tackling global issues like climate change and security. Many leaders also look forward to working with Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris to address common challenges, including terrorism and economic growth.

site_title: Axington in search of new auditor, after proposed change of auditors falls through
summary: Axington, a professional services group, is seeking a new auditor after a plan to switch auditors to Nexia fell through due to Nexia's resignation. The company, controlled by cousins Nelson and Terence Loh, had initiated the process in August but was informed by Nexia of its intention to resign in September. Despite confirming Nexia's intention, the new auditor firm declined the appointment, citing no professional reasons. Axington will need shareholder approval to change auditors at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Huawei appeals ban from 5G networks in Sweden: telecom regulator
summary: Huawei has appealed Sweden's decision to exclude the Chinese telecom equipment maker from being a supplier in the roll-out of 5G networks in the Nordic country. The Swedish telecoms regulator PTS announced the appeal, which will be handled by the administrative court of Stockholm. This decision follows other European nations that have restricted the role of Chinese suppliers on security grounds.

images.alt_text: Huawei has appealed Sweden's decision to exclude the Chinese telecom equipment maker from being a supplier in the roll-out of 5G networks in the Nordic country, the Swedish telecoms regulator PTS said on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.10 points, or 0.07%, to 1,525.42 on Tuesday, with volume reaching 938.89 million lots worth RM463.36 million. Gainers beat losers 334 to 285.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.43 point lower on Monday at 1,466.46. The market saw 5.933 billion lots worth RM3.285 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 688 to 364.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Nov 2)
summary: Dropbox invests in new local partnerships to support distributed work. Engine Biosciences CEO Jeffrey Lu discusses the impact of diet on cardiovascular health. Meanwhile, experts share insights on bridging Singapore's data skills gap and changing developments in the city-state. The article also covers various financial topics, including market trends and the potential for private equity to open up to regular investors.

site_title: Euro zone factories boomed in October as Germany roared
summary: The euro zone's manufacturing sector experienced a boom in October, driven by Germany's robust growth, with the Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 54.8, its highest reading since 2018. However, the recovery is tempered by concerns over a second wave of the coronavirus pandemic, which has led to lockdown measures in Germany and France, impacting the dominant service industry. The overall Composite PMI is expected to show a contraction, and policymakers are worried about the nascent euro zone recovery being halted by the resurgence of the virus.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing growth in the euro zone boomed in October but the recovery from severely depressed activity at the height of the coronavirus pandemic was again mostly driven by a buoyant Germany, a survey showed.

site_title: Government grants cut SIAEC's H1 loss from S$114m to S$19m
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC), the maintenance arm of Singapore Airlines, reported a net loss of S$19 million in the first half of its financial year, reversing a net profit of S$87.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue more than halved to S$223 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic, while group expenditure slid 47.4%. Government grants, particularly the Jobs Support Scheme, cushioned the impact, preventing a loss of S$114.6 million.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering Company has signed an inventory technical management programme with Thai VietJet, a low-cost carrier based in Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi Airport, Thailand.
